column2: More of your standup comedy (send via the comment link below):
Seeing Deon Sanders on his new reality series seems only to confirm his particularly entitled brand of genius.
We know a lot about the course of untreated depression, probably more than we do about very long-term antidepressant use in this population.
A look at a two-bedroom apartment in Rio de Janiero.

If the results of a study by SearchIgnite, a search advertising technology firm, prove representative of the broader search market, something unusual happened in search ads in the first quarter: Google lost share to Yahoo in the United States.
With Joba Chamberlain unavailable, who pitched the eighth inning for the Yankees on Monday? The same guy who gave up the lead in the seventh - Brian Bruney.

"Owners of more than 800 local TV stations where ad revenue has plunged recently said they've formed a group that's testing three standards for sending local digital TV signals to cell phones, laptops and other mobile devices," the Associated Press reports.

Hillary Rodham Clinton will make her first appearance on Comedy Central's "The Colbert Report" on Thursday, the Associated Press reports. Barack Obama "has thus far declined Colbert's invitation. Obama's wife, Michelle, will appear on the show Tuesday."
A judge and lawyers are struggling with the legal and logistical morass of deciding the fate of 416 children seized by Texas authorities in a raid at a polygamist sect.
Often, it seems, special interests are finding that buying up judges likely to side with them in big-dollar cases is a good investment.
I propose we stop saying “taxes” and start calling them “dues,” which is a term rooted in social obligation and duty.
The dismantling of electronic circuit boards, which contain lead, zinc, copper and other metals, can be dangerous to human health, a new study suggests.
Scientists have discovered the first completely lungless frog.
Scientists report a strong correlation between the intensity of sound recorded by an undersea microphone and the wind power of a hurricane that passed over it.
To condemn or condone plastics categorically makes no sense.
The semiconductor maker reported solid global demand for its chips, soothing investor concerns that economic softness would rattle the technology industry.
The country’s largest savings and loan said it was hit by mounting credit losses as more mortgage borrowers fell behind on payments.
The Supreme Court dealt a setback to the State of Illinois in a tax dispute over the $1.5 billion sale of the data retrieval service Lexis/Nexis.
Merck drafted dozens of studies for a best-selling drug, then lined up prestigious doctors to put their names on the reports before publication, according to an article in a leading medical journal.
Executives said that a new and more flexible contract with Delta pilots would allow the company soon after completing its merger to begin swapping planes in an effort to lift sales.
Oil rose to nearly $114 a barrel, as pipeline interruptions and a weak dollar pressured a tight global market.
The European Commission said that worries about human rights and Tibet should not be “walled off” from Europe’s trade relationship with China but that it did not support boycotts.
One of the best, and least costly, ways to market your business and generate sales is through referrals, but it’s not always clear how to get your customers to recommend your business.
A Chinese government entity has acquired a sizable stake in BP for about $2 billion, the latest indication that China is becoming an increasingly important global investor.
A gauge of prices paid by American producers jumped 1.1 percent in March as oil and food costs reached records, leaving Fed policymakers in a difficult spot ahead of their meeting this month.
The decision will save $75 million annually and came after the company saw weakness since August at its properties.
With the Yankees’ game rapidly unraveling, Robinson Canó restored order by driving a homer deep into the right-field, breaking a tie and lifting the Yankees to a victory.

Roger Federer, stuck in a slump, said on his Web site that he would work with a new coach, José Higueras, at the Estoril Open in Portugal this week. Federer begins the European clay-court season having failed to reach a final in four tournaments this year. Higueras is a clay-court specialist who coached a teenage Michael Chang to the 1989 French Open title. Federer has worked without a coach since splitting with Tony Roche last May.

Ryan Harrison, 15, beat Pablo Cuevas of Uruguay, 6-4, 6-3, in the United States Clay Court Championship in Houston to become the 10th player in the Open era to win a main-draw match before his 16th birthday. Harrison, a Texan, is the youngest player to get a main-draw win on the ATP Tour since Rafael Nadal, the current No. 2 in the world, won his first tour match in Mallorca, Spain, in 2002. Harrison is the third player this decade to do it before turning 16.
Genentech and Biogen Idec’s cancer drug Rituxan did not slow the disabling effects of the most difficult form of multiple sclerosis in a large clinical trial.
The Washington Wizards’ backups were more than enough to eliminate the sub-.500 Indiana Pacers from the playoff race Monday with a 117-110 victory.

Iván Rodríguez hit a tying two-run triple in a six-run eighth inning, and then scored the go-ahead run on a sacrifice fly as the Detroit Tigers defeated the visiting Minnesota Twins, 11-9, on Monday night.
A Brooklyn grocery store owner was charged with assault for hitting a 15-year-old boy in the head with a hammer during a confrontation at his store, the police said.

German prosecutors dropped a fraud investigation against the former Tour de France winner Jan Ullrich in return for a fine. The deal ended a 21-month investigation into whether the retired Ullrich defrauded his T-Mobile team by taking performance-enhancing drugs, thus increasing his income by illegal means.

A large sketch of the former Kansas coach Roy Williams was removed from the men’s room of the Downtown Barbershop in Lawrence, Kan., where it had hung as a symbol of fan anger since Williams departed for North Carolina in 2003. Williams’s sketch is back where it used to be, prominently displayed among hundreds of sketches, photographs and memorabilia. Kansas beat Williams’s North Carolina team, 84-66, in the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, on its way to winning the national championship.

Michael Beasley, Kansas State’s all-American freshman, announced Monday that he would skip his final three seasons to enter the June 26 N.B.A. draft, where he could be the No. 1 overall pick. Beasley, the Big 12 player of the year, had the second-most rebounds and third-most points of any freshman in N.C.A.A. history, leading Kansas State to its first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in 20 years.

Liu Xiang, the world champion hurdler who is expected to be the face of the Beijing Olympics for the host country, is scheduled to compete at the Reebok Grand Prix on May 31 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island. Liu is the Olympic champion and the world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles. He won the event at last year’s Reebok Grand Prix in 12.92 seconds. Also scheduled to compete are the sprinters Veronica Campbell-Brown and Lauryn Williams. Campbell-Brown edged Williams in the 100 meters at the world championships last year.
The visit of a pope and preparations for Passover are making this a hectic week for Rabbi Arthur Schneier.
Lines stretched for blocks at phone stores as Cubans were allowed to sign up for cellphone service for the first time.
Biranchi Das, the former coach for Budhia Singh, the slum boy, then 5, whose long-distance running set off an outcry two years ago, was shot to death Sunday in Bhubaneswar.
Riots erupted when members of a shadowy sect blockaded roads to protest the killing of their leader’s wife.
Lawmakers in Northern Ireland’s dominant Protestant party, the Democratic Unionist Party, chose its deputy, Peter Robinson, to succeed Ian Paisley.
Journalists at Le Monde, one of France’s most authoritative newspapers, went on strike for only the second time in its 64-year history to protest planned cuts in newsroom staff.

Toshiro Shirasu, the vice minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries, said it was “regrettable” that Japan’s whaling fleet was returning from its annual five-month hunt after killing just 551 whales.
A Long Island boy was seriously injured Monday afternoon when a stray bullet passed through a wall of his house in North Bellport and struck him in the face, the police said.
The New York Legislature approved a measure last week that requires online retailers to collect state sales tax and remit it to the state.
Federal authorities said they ran an electronic lottery to select 85,000 highly skilled immigrants to receive temporary work visas for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.
Kansas and Kentucky are the first states to approve a compact that will make it easier for children of military families to change schools if enough other states sign on.
The last of 14 people indicted in the nation’s deadliest human smuggling attempt pleaded guilty, federal prosecutors in Houston said.

Donald H. Rumsfeld, who resigned as secretary of defense in late 2006, will write his memoirs for the Sentinel imprint of Penguin Group USA. Mr. Rumsfeld, 75, will cover not only his years in the Bush administration but also his experiences with Presidents Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford and Ronald Reagan; his work in the private sector; and his early life. In contrast to other recent political figures who have produced memoirs, Mr. Rumsfeld is forgoing an advance and will donate profits to a nonprofit foundation he recently established to make educational grants to young people interested in public service and establishing links between the United States and Central Asia.
The recent draft recommendations of a housing task force in New Jersey is a blueprint for rolling back environmental protections.
Inncumbent Senator Frank R. Lautenberg faces an unexpected and unwelcome challenge from a Bergen County representative.
The detectives investigating the puzzling killing of a Massachusetts woman in the Bronx on Sunday are working to zero in on the gunman.
WASHINGTON (AP) — Jim Bowden sauntered out of the home clubhouse at Nationals Park and headed toward Washington Manager Manny Acta, raising his voice loud enough for bystanders to hear.
The merger deal will create the world’s biggest airline and may trigger other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.
Despite security fears and an avalanche of cheap imports from China and Syria, Hassan Attiya has managed to keep his shoe business afloat.
Frustrated fans at Shea Stadium are prepared to boo at almost every provocation, the Mets’ comeuppance for their monumental collapse down the stretch last season.
The red ink at Wachovia, the country’s fourth-largest bank, signals that the pain for the financial industry is far from over.
Christie’s had described the collection as “the most important antique jewelry in history.”
Gov. David A. Paterson and his wife earned $269,815 in income in 2007 but gave only one charitable donation, worth $150, for the year, according to tax returns.
A consumer spending slump and tightening credit markets are prompting thousands of store closings.
The efforts to pass new restrictions on guns come after nearly a decade in which gun advocates have dominated.
Stephen A. Feinberg, the reclusive founder of Cerberus Capital Management and the money man some hope will save Detroit, is no Gordon Gekko.
Boos greeted Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas before tipoff, and they would probably have been louder if everyone’s mouths were not stuffed with free eats on fan appreciation night.
When Harlan Chamberlain was hospitalized Sunday night in Lincoln, Neb., the Yankees players knew just how deeply Joba Chamberlain must have been affected.
Barack Obama’s campaign has said that he does not recall meeting the investor, who has been convicted on fraud charges in Europe.
Mr. Ehrlich, a self-educated lexicographer, wrote 40 dictionaries, thesauruses and phrase books for the “extraordinarily literate.”
Sidney Crosby and Marian Hossa each had a goal and an assist in the third period Monday night, when the Pittsburgh Penguins scored three times to break open a tie game in a 4-1 victory.
Robert K. Steel’s apparent conversion to the merits of regulation illustrates how the laissez-faire bones of the Bush administration have been rattled by the trauma of the credit crisis.
Washington needs to rein in drug companies by encouraging generic competition for biological drugs.
A construction worker fell to his death from an East Side building on Monday when a safety strap system intended to secure him to the building failed, the authorities said.
Skier Lindsey Vonn is not quite sure what to make of her accomplishments. She knows what she has done, but she is not certain what it means.
The former director of the Smithsonian Latino Center charged the office for personal expenses, a report from the Smithsonian’s inspector general says.
The former heavyweight champion Vitali Klitschko is a contender for another title — mayor of Kiev.
The new president needs to be persuaded to rebuild wild salmon populations and the economies that depend on them.
The I.A.A.F. raced Monday to support Maurice Greene, a four-time Olympic medal winner, after he disputed a report that he had used performance-enhancing drugs.
The line between J.K. Rowling’s magical world and the muggle courtroom became somewhat blurred during the author’s testimony in a copyright infringement case.
The Archdiocese of Washington predicts that the pope’s visit to the capital will cost at least $3 million, but the Archdiocese of New York has not ventured an estimate.
The trial of three police detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell ended on Monday with one of the most fractious days in seven weeks in the courtroom.

Because of an editing error, a Sports of The Times column on Sunday about efforts to renovate Fenway Park without damaging its traditional charm misstated, in some editions, the source of the phrase “do no harm.” It is from Hippocrates’ work “Epidemics,” not from the Hippocratic oath.

An article on Monday about a large increase in insurance co-payments for high-priced drugs misstated the way the multiple sclerosis drug Copaxone is administered. It is injected, not taken in pill form.
FRONT PAGE.

An article on Saturday about the struggles of Freedom’s Watch, a political organization aligned with the Republicans, misstated the winner of a special 2007 Congressional election last year in Ohio in which the group spent $86,000. The winner was the Republican candidate, Robert E. Latta, not the Democratic candidate.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about “Invisible Nation: How the Kurds’ Quest for Statehood Is Shaping Iraq and the Middle East,” by Quil Lawrence, misstated the timing of Mr. Lawrence’s reporting for National Public Radio, The Los Angeles Times and The Christian Science Monitor. He reported for NPR from 1996 to 2000, and for The Los Angeles Times and The Christian Science Monitor from 1996 to 2001. He has not been reporting on Kurdistan for those three organizations for the last seven years. Mr. Lawrence is now the Middle East correspondent for the BBC/PRI radio program “The World.”.

An article on Monday about the value of the veteran catcher Jason Varitek to the Boston Red Sox described his history with the team incorrectly. He joined the organization in 1997 from the Seattle Mariners’ minor league system; he is not “a home-grown player.”.

An article on Saturday about Democratic efforts to build voter data banks misstated who can use a data bank managed by the Democratic National Committee. The data bank is being used by the Clinton and Obama campaigns; it is not closed to Democrats in primary races.

A picture caption on Saturday with an exhibition review of “Creating the United States,” a show at the Library of Congress that uses technology to illuminate history, misidentified the document a visitor was examining at a touch-screen kiosk. It was the Declaration of Independence, not the Constitution.
Circuit City said it doubted that Blockbuster could find adequate financing to seal the deal, despite assurances that Carl C. Icahn would provide support.
Ms. Tunney’s secret romance and subsequent marriage to the former heavyweight champion Gene Tunney was one of the most sensational love stories of the 1920s.
The Supreme Court accepted an appeal that could help define prosecutorial immunity. Under longstanding doctrine, prosecutors are immune for their judgments.
Joseph P. Brandon, the chairman and chief executive of the insurance company, resigned under pressure on Monday. The company said its president, Franklin Montross, will succeed him.
President Bush and Nancy Pelosi intensified a fight over a stalled trade deal with Colombia, trading accusations over who was best protecting American workers.
The parents of a victim of last year’s Virginia Tech killings have honored her memory with an organization that repairs dilapidated houses in Appalachia.
The deal is limited to two products, but analysts say Chrysler and Nissan could eventually join forces in many areas of their operations to become more competitive.
The quarrel between the companies sheds a light on the insular world of Silicon Valley’s investors in environmentally friendly technologies.

CLUB In Mexico, the country’s most popular club, Chivas Guadalajara, extended the winless streak of the richest, Club América, to 10 games with a 3-2 victory on Sunday. Host Chivas built a 3-0 lead at Jalisco Stadium and played with a man advantage for the final 35 minutes after Juan Carlos Silva was red carded. But América’s Salvador Cabañas scored two late goals in a four-minute span.
In accepting an appeal on the role of cost-benefit analysis in establishing Clean Water Act standards, the Supreme Court set the stage for an environmental policy debate.
Manchester United is committed to clinching its second consecutive English Premier League title in the next two weeks, perhaps sooner.
In his first public remarks on the issue, John McCain said that comments by Barack Obama about working-class voters were “elitist.”
Barack Obama should be advised to meet as often as possible with skeptical, and even hostile, working people in Pennsylvania and elsewhere.
American Airlines became the last of the major network carriers to join in a new across-the-board fare increase.
Mayors in favor of gun control, led by Michael R. Bloomberg and Thomas M. Menino, reached a 10-point agreement with Wal-Mart, the country’s largest gun seller.
Stocks finished a quiet session moderately lower Monday after Wachovia surprised investors with disappointing quarterly results.
The tranist authority’s solar project is a step toward its goal of using renewable energy sources to generate 7 percent of its total electricity needs by 2015.
The standoff between Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick, who refuses to resign as he battles charges of perjury, and the City Council grows more bitter by the day.
FGIC, a money-losing bond insurer owned by the Blackstone Group and the PMI Group, is seeking investors and may consider selling the company.
Mr. Holmes, the Boston Braves outfielder who hit in 37 consecutive games in 1945, set a modern National League record that endured for 33 years.
Samuel Israel III, the founder of the hedge fund Bayou Group, was sentenced for his role in a scheme that cheated investors out of more than $400 million.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she would return to academic pursuits at the end of the Bush administration.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,025 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:.
In Alaska, flying in a small plane to remote parts of the huge state can be deadly; in 2007, there were 104 aircraft accidents and 30 deaths in the state.
In a medical office setting, there are specific protocols that are followed. But on a plane all bets are off.
Earnings for the quarter showed that the bank was able to stay profitable even as the tight credit market worsened. Yet the results were just shy of Wall Street’s projections.
Seagate Technology made a pre-emptive strike against STEC, an emerging competitor, claiming that the latter’s solid-state drive products violate four Seagate patents.

In his column on Friday, Paul Krugman discussed an anecdote told by Hillary Clinton about a woman in Ohio who supposedly lost her newborn child, and then her life, because of bills run up when she did not have health insurance. Mr. Krugman relied on early news accounts of the incident, but later accounts, including one from The Columbus Dispatch, show that those bills did not lead to loss of care. Mr. Krugman has posted a detailed explanation on his blog at krugman.blogs.nytimes.com.
How paradoxical, and delightful, that Bangalore, a city that has leapt to global prominence on the back of work outsourced by America, is now itself outsourcing from America.
Bilal Hussein has been jailed in Iraq by the U.S. military for two years on accusations of terrorism and kidnapping.
President Nicolas Sarkozy’s fondness for showbiz pals, his new marriage and the appointment of a culture minister widely regarded as weak have produced a culture shock.

Brian May, above, already a rock star and astrophysics scholar, has added a new title: university chancellor. Taking up his position as chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University in England, Mr. May, 60, the guitarist of Queen, accepted the largely honorary post and told an audience of about 500 people, including Cherie Blair, wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair, that British science needed more support, Agence France-Presse reported. “It is a rather sorry state of affairs,” Mr. May said. He also spoke about Queen’s forthcoming album, its first in 13 years, and a European tour from September to November. “The long arm of Queen has pulled me back in at the moment,” Mr. May said. “It is a beast.”.
“Pure Country” is a new musical in the works with a planned Broadway opening sometime in the 2008-9 season.

Preparing for unofficial and official summer, the New York Philharmonic has announced its annual schedule of free concerts, beginning with its 17th Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Led by David Robertson, music director of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra and principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the performance, at 8 p.m. on May 26, will include Schubert’s Symphony in B minor (“Unfinished”) and Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 4 (“Italian”). The 2008 Concerts in the Parks series, with all performances at 8 p.m., opens on the Great Lawn of Central Park on June 24, with a program including works by Shostakovich, Mendelssohn, Tchaikovsky and Sousa. A program of Mozart, Bach and Elgar will be heard on July 8 at the Richmond County Bank Ballpark on Staten Island; on July 9 at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J.; on July 10 at Cunningham Park, Queens; on July 11 in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx; and on July 12 at Heckscher State Park in East Islip, N.Y. Bach, Beethoven and Sibelius will be heard on July 14 in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and the series will conclude on July 15 with works by Tchaikovsky, Beethoven and Sibelius on the Great Lawn in Central Park. All New York concerts will be followed by fireworks.
To the Editor:.

After 20 years as the founding president of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Ruth J. Abram is stepping down on June 1. She will be replaced by Morris Vogel, a history professor at Temple University, where he has been on the faculty since 1973, serving as department chairman and acting dean of the College of Liberal Arts. From 2004 to 2006 he was an official at the Rockefeller Foundation. Under Ms. Abram the museum, which opened in 1988, has grown to about 80 staff members, 130,000 visitors a year and an annual budget of $4.5 million from 23 volunteer staff members and a budget of $75,000. The museum interprets the history of immigrant families who lived at 97 Orchard Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, using their stories to encourage discussion of contemporary immigration. Mr. Vogel is a first-generation American, born in Kazakhstan to a German-Jewish family who escaped during World War II. After living in a displaced-persons camp in Poland, his family immigrated to the United States.

From 2004 until her death at 96 in 2007, the actress, singer and arts advocate Kitty Carlisle Hart celebrated her birthday by performing at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. On Monday at 8:30 p.m., with Michael Feinstein as the host, a benefit performance for New Dramatists will salute Miss Carlisle, with tributes by Mario and Matilda Cuomo and Anne Kaufman and performances by Jane Powell, Dina Merrill, George S. Irvin, Christine Andreas, K T Sullivan, Anna Bergman and others. New Dramatists is a nonprofit center for the development of playwrights. ... Plácido Domingo is to deliver the commencement address at the Juilliard School’s 103rd commencement ceremony on May 23 in Avery Fisher Hall, where honorary doctorates will be awarded to the jazz pianist Hank Jones; the dancer and choreographer Carmen de Lavallade; the philanthropist Charles Simonyi; the actress, playwright and author Anna Deavere Smith; and the pianist Mitsuko Uchida.

The return of “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday, as 16 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m., Eastern and Pacific times, for the first new episode of the series since early January, Nielsen reported. Despite delivering the series’s lowest ratings to date among adults 18 to 49, “Desperate Housewives” still easily led the night in that demographic. Rounding out ABC’s schedule were “Oprah’s Big Give” at 8 (8.9 million) and “Eli Stone” at 10 (9.2 million). CBS, runner-up to ABC in the 18-to-49 set, tied for first in total viewers thanks to an overrun of its afternoon “Masters” golf coverage well into the 7 o’clock hour, followed by “60 Minutes,” which attracted roughly 11 million viewers. NBC and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third, although Fox fared better in the 18-to-49 age group, as new episodes of “The Simpsons” at 8 (6.9 million) and “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (6 million) drew particularly strong ratings in that demographic.

Jet Li, above, was named best actor when the Hong Kong film awards were handed out late Sunday in a glittering ceremony, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Li won for his performance in “The Warlords,” an action drama set in 19th-century China that also carried off the prizes for best film and best director (Peter Chan) among its eight awards. Andy Lau, a co-star of “The Warlords,” won the prize for best supporting actor for the crime thriller “Protégé,” and Siqin Gaowa of the quirky tragicomedy “The Postmodern Life of My Aunt” was chosen best actress. The award for best Asian film went to Ang Lee for “Lust, Caution,” and a lifetime achievement award was given to Raymond Chow, whose Golden Harvest studios fostered the careers of Jackie Chan and Bruce Lee.
The city of Luang Prabang in the mountains of central Laos is being transformed into a replica of itself: its dwellings into guest houses and its rituals into shows for tourists.
To the Editor:.
What exactly makes a dance feel too long? A program of seven new dances called “pocketworks,” presented at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Saturday night, raised this question.
Witnesses said four teachers, one of them a Briton and two others Kenyans, were killed by Islamist insurgents during a midnight raid on an English-language school.
Of the six choreographers presented by Ballet Builders on Saturday night at Kaye Playhouse, Emery LeCrone was the only one to make something fresh of that idiom.
All six employees on the production staff of the New York Theater Workshop were told that they will be laid off, and that their jobs will be performed by temporary workers.
On Sunday afternoon Kathleen Battle's management, Columbia Artists, presented her in what was more or less a re-entry recital at Carnegie Hall.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The billionaire Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right coalition won a convincing majority in both houses of Parliament.
To the Editor:.
A new type of hearing aid, called the Lyric, appears to have overcome many of the problems associated with traditional hearing aids.
A cholera outbreak in New York in 1832 led to broad efforts to clean up the city and others like it.
The one-liners fly like rockets in “The New Century,” the rollicking bill of short plays by Paul Rudnick. And more often than not, they hit their targets smoking.
The veneration of the printed word as a source of wisdom, redemption and refuge animates many of William Styron’s essays in this volume.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

On Sunday, James Conlon led the second of three concerts of “degenerate” — the term the Nazis applied to the works of Jewish composers and some others — and “generative” music, Mr. Conlon’s term for music written under unrestricted circumstances.
The Minnesota Orchestra  sounded more brightly polished and supercharged than ever when it played under Osmo Vanska’s baton at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon.
A team of scientists has uncovered new evidence that the ship’s builder used substandard rivets and rushed the project.
Only 350 miles separate the two California business cultures, but executives are once more trying to bridge the gap between technology and entertainment.
The European airline, which has a history of provocative marketing stunts, has drawn some unwanted attention lately — from a French court and the British advertising watchdog.
If your latest battle with your H.M.O. has you pounding your head with frustration, “Sick Around the World” on PBS may spur you to more drastic action, like leaving the United States altogether.
Pakistan’s new parliament passed a unanimous resolution urging the government to approach the United Nations for an investigation into the assassination of Benazir Bhutto.
At times it seems that there isn’t much daylight between skilled acrobatic troupes like Aeros and many of today’s commercially minded contemporary-dance companies.
Allen Baron’s “Blast of Silence” stands out for its relentlessly bleak vision. And Grand Guignol does not get much grander than in “Inside.”
Emphysema robbed my patient of a way to show her grief.
The Palestinian West Bank got a boost on Monday: the announcement of a plan to help tens of thousands of ordinary people buy their own homes.
The conductor Eve Queler, who made a pioneering recording of Puccini’s early opera “Edgar” with the Opera Orchestra of New York in a 1977 Carnegie Hall concert, revived it there on Sunday night.
Twenty-nine people suffered lead poisoning, but the authorities do not know where the tainted marijuana came from or why the lead was added.
Barely two years out of the jungle, former Maoist guerrillas were poised on Monday to lead Nepal’s new government after partial results of last week’s voting were released.
Am I still getting vitamin D when I’m outside on a gray, cloudy day?
The reproduced office of G.V. Black is a central feature of the National Museum of Dentistry in Baltimore.
Heavy rains the past month have created a fertile breeding ground for mosquitoes carrying the deadly dengue fever virus, deepening a crisis that has now claimed at least 80 lives.
Two journalists, one the victim of a kidnapping, the other held by American forces, won their liberty on Monday.
A new study finds that changes in the brain that may contribute to dyslexia are different for English speakers and Chinese speakers.
Having high blood pressure may lower the chances of having headaches, including migraines, researchers said Monday.
Chinese officials laid out a sweeping series of measures intended to clear the air for the Olympics this summer.
The decisions of a small group of scientists to stop accepting payment from food, drug and medical device companies repudiate decades of industry influence.
The ruling was a rebuff to the opposition party, which had demanded that election results be released immediately.
The attack was yet another illustration of how weak Afghanistan’s police force remains.
Shares in Europe and Asia fell on Monday after a meeting of the Group of 7 finance ministers and central bankers ended with no announcement of significant action.
The lot of left-handers worsened in the 1980s when a study suggested they had a higher risk of headaches. But is it true?
Funeral “pre-planning” is a phenomenon receiving increased attention, and a growing number of Web-based guides tell how to go about it.
Biofuels are fast becoming a new flash point in global diplomacy, putting pressure on Western politicians.
The Devils were infuriated with Sean Avery when he stationed himself in front of Martin Brodeur in Game 3 and obscured his vision, even though they knew there was no rule against what he did.
Gov. Edward G. Rendell is an undeniable asset for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Pennsylvania.
Whom can we trust to do hard-headed calculations to prove that a scientific experiment will not lead to the end of the world?
In recent years, the number of immigration appeals has more than quintupled, a consequence of revisions to the way immigration cases are handled.
Repeat after me the next time you arrive at the entrance of an airport: Abandon all hope ye who enter here.
Ivana Hong is a gymnast hoping to make it to the Beijing Summer Games, a Chinese-American whose parents had to cheat death to escape the governmental abusers of human rights.
The loud martial music CBS Sports used so relentlessly was meant to evoke heraldry. But the Masters is not “Braveheart” and Trevor Immelman is not William Wallace.
Several abuse victims said that Pope Benedict XVI’s comments about the child sexual-abuse scandal rang hollow.
Among the questions to emerge in the wake of the Masters is the annual argument about whether changes to the course at Augusta National have succeeded only in lessening the drama.
Gone are the days when several hundred men at a time studied to be ordained as priests for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Today, only 22 are enrolled.

In the most expensive restoration of stained glass ever undertaken in the United States, conservation is under way on the famous Whitefriars windows of St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan.
Wind turbines are attracting homeowners with their ease of use, financial incentives and low environmental effects.
What Rome’s Palazzo Massimo lacks in organization, it makes up for in a treasure trove paintings, frescoes, mosaics and sculptures.
Solar thermal systems are built to gather heat from the sun and then store the heat for hours or even days, like water behind a dam.
Democrats, who lost among Catholics in the 2004 presidential election, are trying to woo them back.
Barack Obama’s speech on Monday on the economy put him in the no-man’s land between Lou Dobbs-style populism and Bill Clinton-style free trade.

BERNSTEIN--Caryl Ann, 77, on April 13, 2008 after a bout with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Martin David Bernstein. She was a member of the School of American Ballet and was a teacher for the Board of Education. She leaves son and daughter-inlaw Jonathan and Susan, grandchildren Jenna and Bethe and son David and Avital. She will be missed by family, friends and neighbors.

Caja Madrid, a Spanish savings bank, said it bought an 83 percent stake in City National Bank of Florida for $927 million, in its biggest foreign acquisition. City National Bank, which is based in Miami, has assets of $2.76 billion and had profit of $68.5 million last year, Caja Madrid said. Since 2007, two other Spanish banks have bought Florida lenders. Banco Popular Espanol agreed last July to buy TotalBank of Miami for $300 million, extending its business beyond Spain and Portugal into the United States. In January 2007, Banco Sabadell agreed to buy TransAtlantic Bank of Florida for $175 million.

Preparing for unofficial and official summer, the New York Philharmonic has announced its annual schedule of free concerts, beginning with its 17th Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Led by David Robertson, music director of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra and principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the performance, at 8 p.m. on May 26, will include Schubert's Symphony in B minor (''Unfinished'') and Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 4 (''Italian''). The 2008 Concerts in the Parks series, with all performances at 8 p.m., opens on the Great Lawn of Central Park on June 24, with a program including works by Shostakovich, Mendelssohn, Tchaikovsky and Sousa. A program of Mozart, Bach and Elgar will be heard on July 8 at the Richmond County Bank Ballpark on Staten Island; on July 9 at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J.; on July 10 at Cunningham Park, Queens; on July 11 in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx; and on July 12 at Heckscher State Park in East Islip, N.Y. Bach, Beethoven and Sibelius will be heard on July 14 in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and the series will conclude on July 15 with works by Tchaikovsky, Beethoven and Sibelius on the Great Lawn in Central Park. All New York concerts will be followed by fireworks.

Cobb in ''Death of a Salesman''; and working on his first screenplay, ''Young Frankenstein.'' The tribute continues with two of Mr. Wilder's most popular collaborations with Mr. Brooks -- ''The Producers'' (1968) at 9:15, and ''Blazing Saddles'' (1974) at 11 -- followed at 2:15 a.m. by ''Start the Revolution Without Me'' (1970), starring Mr. Wilder and Donald Sutherland as two pairs of twins switched at birth. 8 P.M. SPITZ--Harry, died on April 8 at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in NYC at age 86 after open heart surgery. He was a WWII Veteran and Police Sergeant with the New York Police Department retiring after 30 years of service. His vigorous lifestyle after retirement led him to acquire the title of ''Mayor of Marine Park'', as on a daily basis, he could be found ''walking with the boys,'' and extending good tidings to all. He is survived by his daughter and son-inlaw Audrey and Rob Greenfield and grandchildren Rory and Adam Greenfield. He will be missed dearly by his sister and brother-in-law Janice and Leon Yedin and all three generations of the Yedin family.

LODERHOSE--Richard E. Born in Brooklyn, New York, August 16, 1925, he passed peacefully on April 10, 2008, in Tampa, Florida. He attended Richmond Hill High School and the University of Rochester as a Naval cadet. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War Two as a Specialist for Welfare and Recreation and was the organist for all chapel activities at the U.S. Naval Base in Little Creek, Maryland. Subsequent to his naval service he was employed in the family business in New York City, then known as the United Paste and Glue Company. Along with his father, Herman C. Loderhose, he built United into the national adhesive manufacturer called United Resin Products, Inc. He was a gifted CEO, master salesman, and innovator in packaging patents, coatings and adhesives. In 1997, Mr. Loderhose sold United to the Henkel Corporation and remained with Henkel for the next four years as a senior director of the company. Mr. Loderhose had a lifelong passion for music, particularly the theatre organ. He was well known for his preservation, restoration, perfor mance, and support of the instrument. The gem of his extensive collection being the 55 rank New York Paramount Studio Theatre Organ, until recently located at the family owned Bay Theatre in Seal Beach, California. In June, 2007, Mr. Loderhose gifted this magnificent instrument to The Beatitudes Campus in Phoenix, Arizona where it is being reinstalled for the enjoyment of the residents, members, congregants, staff and the entire Phoenix and theatre organ community. He was a past president and founding member of the American Theatre Organ Society. He played the organ professionally under the name Dick Scott and made numerous recordings for his own label, Renwick Recordings, Inc. as well as for United Artists Records. An avid yachtsman, Mr. Loderhose also had a great passion for World War Two Air Sea Rescue boats. He refurbished and restored numerous rescue/crash boats during his lifetime (Music Man I through VI) and was often a speaker at events sponsored by crash boat organizations throughout the country. His philanthropy included the donation of a restored 64 foot rescue boat to the Sea Scouts of Marina Del Rey, California. When Mr. Loderhose retired from the glue business in 1997 he spent most of his remaining years in Newport Beach, California attending to his yachting and musical interests. He was a member of the Balboa Bay Club, Newport Beach, California. His final years were spent in Tampa, Florida. He is at rest now knowing that whatever his passion, he succeeded. He would want everyone to know that he truly had a ball and would go out playing ''Ain't Misbehavin'' or ''Anchors Away'' if he could; and those who knew him would agree. Life was good. He dearly loved his family and friends and was grateful for the life he led. He is survived by his daughters, Rena L. Singer and her husband Joel B. Singer, Mari J. Galloway and her husband, Michael G. Galloway; six grandchildren, Beryl, Garrett and Lindsay Firestone and Robin, Adam and Shannon Galloway, his loving sister, Grace E. Kerr, and former wife, Marie Tepper. Remembered lovingly by his first wife, and lifelong friend, the late Jane D. Loderhose. Donations can be made to the American Theatre Organ Society, or the charity of your choice in his memory. Memorial service to take place at Prince of Peace Lutheran Church in Phoenix, Arizona on Saturday, April 19, 2008 at 2pm. Marsicano-B. Marion Reed-Stowers Funeral Home.

Sir Elton John's recent performance at a fund-raising event for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has drawn a formal complaint from Judicial Watch, a conservative watchdog group. Mr. John, a foreign national, cannot under federal law make any contribution to a federal, state or local election campaign. The group, in a letter from its president, Tom Fitton, described Mr. John's appearance at the fund-raiser as an ''in-kind contribution from a foreign national.''

In his column on Friday, Paul Krugman discussed an anecdote told by Hillary Clinton about a woman in Ohio who supposedly lost her newborn child, and then her life, because of bills run up when she did not have health insurance. Mr. Krugman has posted a detailed explanation on his blog at krugman.blogs.nytimes.com.

Brian May, above, already a rock star and astrophysics scholar, has added a new title: university chancellor. Taking up his position as chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University in England, Mr. May, 60, the guitarist of Queen, accepted the largely honorary post and told an audience of about 500 people, including Cherie Blair, wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair, that British science needed more support, Agence France-Presse reported. ''It is a rather sorry state of affairs,'' Mr. May said. He also spoke about Queen's forthcoming album, its first in 13 years, and a European tour from September to November. ''The long arm of Queen has pulled me back in at the moment,'' Mr. May said. ''It is a beast.''

If we tell ourselves enough times that Governors Island will be the Central Park of the 21st century, does that make it true?The 172-acre island, abandoned by the Coast Guard in 1996 and transferred to the state and city of New York in 2003, lies a mere 800 yards — a seven-minute ferry ride — from the tip of Lower Manhattan. But at times, despite the investment of $120 million in state and city money in recent years, the goal of a majestically transformed public space in the middle of New York Harbor seems as maddeningly elusive as the island itself, viewed from the Battery, on a clear spring day.

Foreign tourists are counterbalancing New York’s economic slump, according to an article by Patrick McGeehan. New York is one of the few places where foreign tourism is actually up since Sept. 11, 2001. While the number of international tourists coming to the United States last year was still two million below the number who visited in 2000, about one million more visitors came to the city — more than one-fifth of them foreigners — in the first three months of 2008 than in the first quarter of last year, according to preliminary estimates.

If you like Latin, then you might want to tune into the coverage of the Evening Prayer tonight at the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, in Washington, D.C. The opening song will be Tu es Petrus; the Magnificat will be chanted in Latin; and so will the Lord's Prayer (also in Latin).

Yesterday was the first press day of the Milan Furniture Fair (Salone di Mobile). One of the most beautiful collections the T Magazine team saw was an exhibition of silver pieces by the famed Italian architect Gio Ponti. Held at the Triennale Museum, the exhibition consists of over 30 pieces designed by Ponti for Christofle, created between 1925 and 1978, many of which are now being produced for the first time. Ponti developed a close relationship with the French silver manufacturer (his niece even married the company's director at the time, Tony Bouilhet) that spanned more than 50 years. From the early symbolism of the Flèche candy boxes, topped with a heart pierced by an arrow, to the sculptural modernism of the Pompeii candelabra and the Tubi vase, to the surrealism of the Il Diavolo decorative mask, the breadth of Ponti's genius is covered in the new collection. The pieces will be available in limited editions in the fall.

Director Canas is right that the perspective of educators across the country has shifted in the wake of Virginia Tech, bringing a heightened awareness of the responsibility of every institution to upgrade security and increase vigilance to keep our students, faculty and staff safe. Of course, this is a huge challenge, not least because colleges and universities, by their very nature, are designed to be constructive learning communities. As we all grapple with the new, post-Tech reality, we walk a difficult line between keeping our campuses safe and ensuring they don't become "police states."

Declaring himself to be "deeply ashamed" by the misbehavior of Catholic priests in the sexual abuse cases, the Pope said it "is more important to have good priests than many priests." While this remark may seem obvious, it strikes a hollow note for many Catholics in the United States and around the world who suffer from the lack of adequate priestly ministry in their parishes. As the numbers of Catholics grow, and the numbers of priests decline, an increasing number of Catholic parishes lack resident priests. They make do with lay leaders, women and men, who, while dedicated, lack the ability to administer the sacraments that are key to Catholic religious life.

Alan Faena is a gazillionaire fashion designer-turned-property developer who has created an arts village of sorts in the Buenos Aires neighborhood of Puerto Madero. After opening the swish Hotel Faena + Universe there in 2004, he's building a cultural center and residential complex next. So now Faena needs some stuff to decorate them. Enter the 2nd annual F a las Artes, the only pan-Latin American arts prize, which just announced its winner. The panel of judges - Jessica Morgan from the Tate Modern among them - chose the 30-year-old Cuban installation artist Wilfredo Prieto. Prieto, who has shown at the Dia Center for the Arts and countless biennials, will fill a vast space in the soon-to-open Los Molinos building, a former grain factory, with dried corn while a single chicken pecks its way through the mounds. For this, he will be paid 100,000 Argentine pesos. We assume the chicken is just doing it for the food.

Interviews from a dozen home building supply manufacturers have confirmed that, after a dozen seasons of hope, the window of opportunity could close tonight on the Ottawa Senators. Being swept after going to the finals last year just might set off a giant rebuilding. Father Martin, in his last post, says that the pope's statement yesterday on the sexual abuse crisis in the church will not likely be his last. By choosing to engage the most heated subject so early in his trip -- from his plane yesterday, before he arrived in the afternoon -- Benedict XVI made it clear, Colleen Carroll Campbell noted, that "he does not intend to soft-pedal his response." Alejandro Bermudez found the pope's remarks to be "the first breath of a gust of fresh air that the pope's trip could bring." No doubt there will be more reaction today, including on this blog. We will move on to other subjects as well.

The tragic shooting at Virginia Tech was an unprecedented event in higher education -- not only for the loss of life but for the way it changed how campuses view security and student issues. It has led to changes at the federal, state, and campus level, and while you cannot control random acts of gun violence, subsequent events at Delaware State University and Northern Illinois University show a dramatic change in response to such events on campus.

Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Today is April 15, and that means taxes were due today. I don't mind the taxes, but I don't like writing the check. I thought we were supposed to be passing the bill for irresponsible spending on to our grandchildren. What happened to them?

One thing that doesn't seem to have gotten much scrutiny in the "bitter" controversy is the suggestion that the past 25 years have been an era of continuous economic hardship for the American heartland. If we're talking about the decline of industrial cities, there's some truth to that picture. But if we're talking about incomes and employment, the Clinton years were pretty good for middle-income Americans -- and especially good for middle-income Midwesterners.

The horrific events at VaTech a year ago hit New Jersey with its 59 campuses of higher education with the same effect as no doubt every other state. It was, and is, a national tragedy. The shock had not worn off when the Governor, the Commissioner of Higher Education and I met in Newark on April 20 with every university and college president to review best practices. We formed a task force and on Oct. 21, 2007 published our report and recommendations. We focused specifically on mental health awareness training and security notification issues for all students and employees of our campuses.

This is a technique that can be used with most vegetables and fish.

Yesterday's strong reactions to Pope Benedict's unexpected comments about the sexual abuse scandal underline how much the issue is still part of the life of the Catholic Church. Though the U.S. bishops adopted draconian guidelines in 2002 to prevent future abuses; though abusive priests have been removed from ministry; though bishops, superiors of religious orders and the Vatican have pledged never to move around, let alone tolerate, sexual abuse; though clergy and members of religious orders must regularly attend seminars to teach them how to spot signs of potential abuse; and though millions of dollars in restitution have been paid to victims (sometimes willingly, sometimes unwillingly) by dioceses and religious orders, the wound is still an open one.

Unlike yesterday's numbers from Rasmussen that showed Hillary Clinton pulling away from Barack Obama in Pennsylvania, the latest Los Angeles Times/Bloomberg polling shows him within 5 points and gaining. The most surprising finding, however, is pointed out by the paper's Scott Martelle in a blog post at Top of the Ticket: "Twenty four percent of likely Pennsylvania voters thought more highly of Barack Obama after his handling of the Rev. Jeremiah Wright controversy, while 15 percent said they thought less of him. The vast majority - 58 percent - said it made no difference."

By this time exactly one year ago, two students lay dead of gunshot wounds at Virginia Tech, an event that would by itself have been the latest addition to a sad storyline of campus shootings. But 30 more students and faculty members would die there at the gunman's hand that day, leaving Virginia Tech to recover from the most violent blow that an American university had ever suffered.

Urban planning laid out much of Manhattan as a grid of about 2,000 blocks long before the population filled the space. The Commissioners' Plan of 1811 determined that the avenues would run roughly north and south (actually skewed about 29 degrees along the spine of the island), with the streets perpendicular.
A year ago today, Americans were united in horror, outrage and sadness at the obscene carnage unfolding before us at Virginia Tech.

No doubt Barack Obama's "bitter" remark will be brought up in some form during tonight's Democratic debate at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia. The question is whether he'll be grilled by his rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, moderators Charlie Gibson and George Stephanopoulos of ABC News, or by the audience of Pennsylvanians who still may be ruffled by the comment.

Hedge fund managers, those masters of a secretive, sometimes volatile financial universe, are making money on a scale that once seemed unimaginable, even in Wall Street's rarefied realms.
Critics blasted the Treasury Department's call for the hedge fund industry to police itself better, saying its voluntary guidelines did little to protect investors and regulate the pools of capital.

Time Warner's AOL unit said Tuesday that it bought Sphere Source, which provides contextual content searches for Web publishers. Financial terms weren't disclosed, but the TechCrunch blog put the price "in the $25 million range."

The Senate proclaimed a fierce bipartisan resolve two weeks ago to help American homeowners in danger of foreclosure. But while a bill that senators approved last week would take modest steps toward that goal, The New York Times says it would also provide billions of dollars in tax breaks -- for automakers, airlines, alternative energy producers and other struggling industries, as well as home builders.

UBS's newly appointed chairman, Peter Kurer, suggested it could take years for the Swiss bank to get past the reputational damage suffered after it bet massively -- and wrongly -- on the U.S. mortgage market and became the world's hardest-hit bank from the subprime crisis.

JPMorgan Chase reported first-quarter earnings of $2.4 billion on Wednesday, a nearly 50 percent slump from the same time last year, but still a show of some strength at a time when its rivals have suffered worse.

Lehman Brothers said it named Jerry A. Grundhofer, the former chief executive of U.S. Bancorp, to its board of directors. Mr. Grunhofer, who is 63, was chairman of U.S. Bancorp from December 2002 until December 2007 and its chief executive from February 2001 until December 2006.

Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg's legal woes are apparently not over, despite reportedly nearing a settlement with three former classmates, who have accused Mr. Zuckerberg and the original crew behind Facebook of pilfering their profitable idea.

A unanimous Supreme Court decision on Tuesday limited the ability of states to tax the income that companies with out-of-state headquarters earn from their investments in businesses in their home state.

Private equity bidders were reportedly lining up this week to submit 1.5 billion pound ($2.96 billion) bids for Infineum, an oil additives venture between Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell, in what would be one of the biggest buyouts in Britain this year.

Corel, which makes graphics and publishing software, said Monday that it has hired a financial adviser, Genuity Capital Markets, to review last month's unsolicited buyout bid its majority shareholder, private equity firm Vector Capital.

The newspaper described the move as the latest sign that Citadel's founder, Kenneth Griffin, is hoping to compete with big Wall Street firms for business.
Stocks gained on Tuesday as record oil prices lifted energy shares and stronger-than-expected quarterly results at several regional banks helped shares of financial companies.
The European Commission Wednesday cleared French insurer Groupama's 617 million euro ($977 million) deal to buy OTP Garancia, the insurance arm of Hungarian bank OTP Bank.

Buddy Media, a New York-based company that operates a number of social-media developer platform applications including Pirates vs. Ninjas, Zombies vs. Werewolves, Pub Darts, and a Sudoku game, announced Tuesday that it has raised $6.5 million in Series B funding in a round led by Softbank Capital.

Hudson's Bay Company, the Canadian retailer, may find itself on the block again after U.S. billionaire Jerry Zucker died over the weekend, leaving his wife, Anita, at the reins.

Providence hired Drake’s Keno Davis as its new coach, less than two weeks after he was named the Associated Press national coach of the year. In his first season as a head coach, he took Drake to its first N.C.A.A. tournament since 1971, and led it to a school-best 28-5 record and its first national ranking in 33 years. He replaces Tim Welsh, who was fired last month.
Mike Pelfrey threw seven scoreless innings in an encouraging display of efficiency to, almost paradoxically, stake his claim as one of the rotation’s more reliable members.
