The Nets finished their home schedule on Tuesday with an overtime victory against the Charlotte Bobcats, but they will miss the playoffs for the first time since 2001.

The Connecticut sophomore guard Doug Wiggins asked to be released from his scholarship so he could transfer. Wiggins was suspended for two games in January after he and guard Jerome Dyson were caught on campus with alcohol.

The marathoner Joan Benoit Samuelson, the figure skater Brian Boitano, the boxer Oscar De La Hoya and the volleyball player Karch Kiraly lead the list of this year’s inductees into the United States Olympic Hall of Fame. Other inductees include David Robinson (basketball), Bruce Baumgartner (wrestling). J. Michael Plumb (equestrian), Lones Wigger Jr. (shooting), Amy Van Dyken (swimming), John Morgan (Paralympic swimming), Carol Heiss Jenkins (figure skating, veteran), Carlo Fassi (figure skating, coach), Frank Marshall (special contributor) and the 1996 women’s gymnastics team (Shannon Miller, Dominique Dawes, Dominique Moceanu, Kerri Strug, Amanda Borden, Amy Chow and Jaycie Phelps). Induction is June 19.

Titans cornerback Pacman Jones said he had delayed filing for reinstatement with the N.F.L. until a possible trade was worked out. Jones told the Michael Irvin Show on ESPN Radio that he had planned to seek reinstatement. He was suspended for the 2007 season for his off-field conduct, but the suspension does not stop the Titans from trading him.

Boston Marathon officials announced that for the first time in the race’s 112-year history, corporate advertisements would appear at the start and finish lines. The Boston Athletic Association, which organizes the race, also said that prize money for this year’s race would be $796,000, up from $575,000 last year.

The Memphis freshman Derrick Rose announced he was jumping to the N.B.A., the same day Coach John Calipari agreed in principle to a contract extension with the university. Terms of Calipari’s deal have not been completed.
Chargers linebacker Stephen Cooper was suspended by the N.F.L. for four games for testing positive for a banned stimulant. He will miss San Diego’s first four games of the 2008 season.
A federal appeals court ruled that a public school district did not violate the constitutional rights of a football coach by banning staff from participating in student prayers.
Legal wrangling has halted what was to be a historic jewelry auction at Christie’s.
Miguel Cabrera hit a two-run homer to cap the Detroit Tigers’ three-run, eighth-inning rally in a 6-5 victory against the host Minnesota Twins on Tuesday night.

NEWARK — As a federal jury entered its fifth day of deliberations on Tuesday, Sharpe James, the city’s former mayor, wandered aimlessly through the halls of the federal courthouse here, swinging an empty soda bottle, pausing to huddle on a bench with his lawyer.
The mayors were charged with helping rebels write requests to the Danish prime minister not to shut down a Danish-based Kurdish satellite broadcaster.
The military junta detained more than 20 people as they walked through the northwestern city of Sittwe in a peaceful campaign against the country’s proposed constitution.
A nighttime fire tore through an elementary school dormitory on the outskirts of the capital, Kampala, killing 19 girls and 2 adults.
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police raided the national headquarters of the governing Conservative Party in Ottawa.
The driver of a sealed truck in which 54 migrant workers suffocated on their way from Myanmar to Thailand has surrendered after a seven-day manhunt.
The world’s top golfer had arthroscopic surgery to repair cartilage damage, and he is expected to miss at least a month.
Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, 78, plans to marry his 43-year-old companion, Maike Richter, an economist at the Economy Ministry.
The opposition leader Severo Moto has been arrested in Spain on charges of trying to smuggle weapons to Equatorial Guinea.
Major League Baseball received its best grade for racial diversity in hiring, even as the percentage of black players dropped again last year.
A state judge has allowed the daughter and son of the artist Mark Rothko to have his body disinterred from a Long Island cemetery and reburied in a Jewish cemetery in Westchester County.

Pedro Feliz hit a run-scoring double in the bottom of the ninth inning to cap a four-run rally that carried the host Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-3 victory against the Houston Astros on Tuesday night.

An explosion blew the top off a house where a registered sex offender who was described as acting strangely had rented a room and appeared to have been making bombs, deputies said. Investigators in Puyallup found a body in the rubble, said a Pierce County sheriff’s detective, Ed Troyer. They believe they know the person’s identity but did not release details. Detective Troyer said the couple who owned the house told the authorities that they had returned from a trip and found their tenant was making explosive devices. Detective Troyer said the man was in the kitchen when deputies arrived. The man quickly grabbed bottles and a duffel bag containing what the deputies recognized as components of explosive devices and ran upstairs. The deputies got the owners out of the house, and about 10 minutes later it exploded.

A man accused of stabbing his wife to death and killing his four children in a house fire hanged himself in his jail cell, officials in Lebanon said. The man, Michel Veillette, 34, had pleaded not guilty to 13 counts of aggravated murder and two counts of aggravated arson and was awaiting trial. “Obviously, he was facing the death penalty, multiple counts of murder for the deaths of his wife and children, so it’s hard to tell what was going through his mind,” said the Warren County prosecutor, Rachel Hutzel.

Senator Arlen Specter’s cancer has returned. A statement released by his office said that a medical scan, followed by a biopsy, had detected an early recurrence of Hodgkin’s disease, which is a cancer of the lymph system. Mr. Specter, 78, a Republican from Pennsylvania, was treated for the same type of cancer in 2005 and was later given a clean bill of health. “I was surprised by the PET scan findings because I have been feeling so good,” Mr. Specter said in the statement. “I consider this just another bump on the road to a successful recovery from Hodgkin’s, from which I’ve been symptom-free for three years.”.

The Army said it would begin destroying a stockpile of old chemical weapons found during cleanup of a training range on the island of Oahu. Army officials called it the largest concentration of unexploded chemical weapons ever found in the United States. Most of the artillery shells and other weapons contain the choking agent phosgene, and one holds an agent that causes a reaction like tear gas. The Army says the weapons were produced beginning in World War I and were stockpiled at the Schofield Barracks military base through World War II. Army officials say a transportable detonation chamber will contain the weapons while they are destroyed one at a time with explosives. Heat and a series of filters will neutralize their poisonous contents.

A Detroit man who served 12 years in prison for rape is free after DNA tests cleared him of the crime. Macomb County authorities dropped charges against the man, Nathaniel Hatchett, 29. He had received a 25- to 40-year sentence after being convicted of raping, carjacking, kidnapping and robbing a woman in 1996. The police in Detroit found Mr. Hatchett driving the woman’s car and arrested him. He admits stealing the car after it had been sitting near his house for several days but said the police duped him into confessing to other crimes. Mr. Hatchett was freed in part through DNA evidence with help from the Cooley Innocence Project at Cooley Law School in Lansing.

The fourth suicide this year among mentally ill patients treated at the Dallas V.A. Medical Center has led the hospital to close its psychiatric ward to new patients, and investigators from the national Veterans Affairs office are expected to arrive next week to assess safety. Joseph Dalpiaz, director of the V.A. North Texas Health Care System, ordered the shutdown after a man hanged himself April 4. The hospital stopped admitting patients to its 51-bed psychiatric unit the next day; 10 previously admitted veterans are still being treated there. In January, two men who met in the hospital’s psychiatric ward committed suicide days after being released. In February, a veteran in the ward hanged himself.

President Bush nominated a Michigan appellate judge and a federal prosecutor to the federal bench in a deal with the state’s Democrats that will break a long impasse over judicial nominations. Mr. Bush nominated Judge Helene White of the Michigan Court of Appeals to serve on the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit and United States Attorney Stephen J. Murphy of Detroit to fill the vacancy on the Federal District Court for Michigan’s Eastern District. As part of the compromise, the White House withdrew Mr. Murphy’s nomination to the Sixth Circuit and nominated Judge White for that post. Mr. Murphy was then nominated to the district court seat. Judge White, Mr. Murphy and Raymond Kethledge, a lawyer in Troy, Mich., who was previously nominated to fill another vacancy on the Sixth Circuit, are expected to be considered by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Kenneth G. Langone, a billionaire financier and a founder of Home Depot, is matching the donation that he made anonymously in 1999.
Gov. David A. Paterson and his wife listed only one charitable gift, of $150 in items donated to the Salvation Army, on a tax return declaring $269,815 in income last year.
Critics say the housing relief bill is adding up to a bailout for businesses, as the legislation includes billions of dollars in tax breaks for automakers and airlines.
Given the bad basketball and bad karma of the past four years, Knicks president Donnie Walsh has his work cut out for him after the team’s final game of the season Wednesday.
The retreat was a blow to the American effort to push the Iraqis into the lead in the struggle for Sadr City.
Pope Benedict XVI’s comments appeared to soothe many Catholics, but they left others demanding more action.
David West scored 32 points and Chris Paul had 12 during a decisive third-quarter run as the New Orleans Hornets clinched the Southwest Division by defeating the Los Angeles Clippers, 114-92.
Hedge fund managers are making money on a scale that once seemed unimaginable, even on Wall Street.
Shares of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines slid following the announcement of the merger and Northwest pilots vowed to kill the $2.7 billion deal.
Efforts to convince people to leave forests raise the question of the price to pay to save the forests and for whom — humans or animals.
Officials cut off power to part of the city’s subway system after passengers, ignoring the pleas of transit workers, left a stalled train and climbed onto the tracks.
Mothers from the Yearning for Zion ranch denounced the authorities two days before a hearing that may decide the custody of their children.
The lawyer, Bryan Konoski, said in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that a psychiatrist he hired to examine the murder suspect, David Tarloff, said he had “very strong grounds” for such a defense.
An e-mail scam aimed at the nation’s top executives is raising new alarms about the ease with which people and companies can be deceived by online criminals.
The chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee said today’s athletes should not be lumped into any group of athletes who have used performance-enhancing drugs.
To settle a lawsuit, the New York Police Department has agreed to formalize changes it had made in its crowd-control procedures during political demonstrations, the authorities said on Tuesday.
The Pequeños packed their four children into their S.U.V. and left Texas on a pilgrimage to see Pope Benedict XVI.
President Bush on Wednesday will lay out specific goals for limiting the greenhouse gases that scientists say are responsible for warming the planet.
The computer chip maker reported that global demand for chips was “solid” during the first quarter, soothing fears that a soft economy was hitting the tech sector.
At least some New York Democrats have reportedly been pitching the idea of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton running for governor if she doesn’t get the Democratic presidential nomination.
The forward remained the center of attention after the N.H.L. targeted the stick-waving, goalie-distracting tactic he used in Game 3.
A rising tide of foreign visitors is providing New York City with a counterbalance against the economic downturn.
Three prominent academic publishers are suing Georgia State University, contending that the school is violating copyright laws.
The librarian at the heart of the Harry Potter copyright-infringement lawsuit stood up to J. K. Rowling in a Manhattan courtroom, and then broke down sobbing.
Dr. Stendahl opened new ways of interpreting the Apostle Paul and pushed churches toward unity and tolerance.
Documents unearthed in lawsuits over the pain drug Vioxx provide a rare, detailed look at the industry practice of ghostwriting medical research studies.
The rezoning would remake 125th Street, one of the city’s liveliest streets — and home to many small businesses like clothing stores and hair salons — into a regional business hub.
Mr. Hillery served 14 years as Ireland’s president after a long ministerial career that won him admiration for his handling of the volatile issue of British rule in Northern Ireland.
Linens ’n Things said it would defer paying about $16.1 million in interest payments due Tuesday as it worked to stave off a bankruptcy filing.

A day after his surprisingly robust victory in the Italian elections, Silvio Berlusconi immediately set out to govern with the theatrical flair that was a trademark of his two previous stints as prime minister.
Church of the Ascension on the Upper West Side stands as just one example of a parish that remains a vibrant presence in the lives of its ever-changing — and still growing — congregation.

The Link by Link column on Monday, about collecting publicly available data and using computers to turn the information into a book, misstated the title of Philip M. Parker, who has used the process to generate more than 200,000 books. He is the chaired professor of management science at Insead, a business school based near Paris — not the school’s Eli Lilly professor in innovation, business and society.
FRONT PAGE.

An article on Friday about a lawsuit over judicial pay filed against New York State by Judith S. Kaye, the state’s chief judge, misidentified the party represented by Kenneth Feinberg in a similar lawsuit filed in 1991 by Sol Wachtler, the chief judge at the time. Mr. Feinberg was the lawyer for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, not Judge Wachtler.

An article on Monday about food shortages and rising food prices described incorrectly a comment by Robert B. Zoellick, president of the World Bank, about the World Food Program’s efforts to raise $500 million in food aid for poor countries by May 1. He said that nearly half the money had been raised, not enough to meet the goal. He did not say that the program would not meet its May 1 deadline.

An article on Tuesday about the growing use of residential wind turbines to produce electricity misstated the name of the New York State agency whose president, Paul Tonko, commented on renewable energy incentives for the turbines. It is the Energy Research and Development Authority, not the Renewable Energy Development Authority.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the Web site The Smoking Gun, which broke the story that The Los Angeles Times relied on fraudulent documents for an article on a 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur, misstated the nature of the assault. Mr. Shakur was shot five times; he was not murdered. (He died in September 1996 of multiple gunshot wounds suffered in a drive-by shooting.).

An article on Thursday about the small-business opposition to some federal tax proposals referred incorrectly to people to whom the businesses must now supply 1099 forms, which are used to report payments over $600. The forms are provided to independent contractors, not employees. (Employees receive W-2 forms.).

An article in some editions on Saturday about a decision by Basil Paterson — a powerful union lawyer and the father of David A. Paterson, New York’s governor — to seek the advice of a state ethics commission on avoiding potential conflicts of interest referred incorrectly to a bill that was supported by the president of the New York City teachers’ union. The bill would prohibit — not allow — the linking of decisions on teacher tenure to student test scores, and it was passed by the Legislature, not killed.

An article on Thursday about possible disruptions to air passengers because of a federal directive on aircraft inspections misstated part of the name the law firm of L. Nick Lacey, a former director of flight standards at the Federal Aviation Administration. His firm is Morten, Beyer & Agnew — not Morton, Beyer & Agnew.
Miguel Cabrera hit a two-run homer to cap the Detroit Tigers’ three-run, eighth-inning rally in a 6-5 victory against the host Minnesota Twins on Tuesday night.
The strike was timed to the day of Pope Benedict XVI’s arrival on American soil to send a sharp message to the Archdiocese of New York.
A lawsuit charges that Oklahoma’s foster care system, which has one of the country’s worst records of abuse, has exposed many children to lasting psychological damage.
The Masters champion is reveling in the whirlwind of celebrity appearances that follows a victory at Augusta.
The state attorney general’s office needs to undertake an intensive program to impress upon police officers the limits of their powers and the need to end the abuse.
José Reyes rejoined the Mets’ lineup for Tuesday night’s game against the Washington Nationals after a two-game absence, although he did so feeling a bit hesitant.
Silvio Berlusconi’s first two terms as prime minister were disappointingly weak on reform. Italy needs him to do better this time.
The Supreme Court should stand by its past rulings that murder is the only crime committed by one person against another that can be punished by death.
Mr. Johnston was the last of the Disney “nine old men,” as the studio’s core group of senior animators was called.
Help may be in sight for apartment dwellers in Texas who have been living in deteriorating conditions since their landlord defaulted on hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of mortgages.
Joba Chamberlain is eligible to come off the bereavement list Thursday, but Manager Joe Girardi said Chamberlain would miss the series as he tends to his father, Harlan.
Alan Rosenberg said Tuesday he remained angry enough over performer compensation levels to bring the entertainment industry to a halt again.
The Food and Drug Administration needs far more money than the White House has proposed for next year, senators of both parties said Tuesday.
In the trendy meatpacking district, an office tower used to be as rare a sighting as a fanny pack. But the area is starting to attract new corporate tenants.
It’s not clear why Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama want to spar over guns and religion — not big issues for Democratic primary voters.
Johnson & Johnson posted better-than-expected first-quarter earnings as the weak dollar offset plunging sales of medicines facing generic competition.
Shares in the drugmaker soared on news that it reached a deal with an Indian company, delaying the release of a generic competitor to its heartburn drug Nexium.
Cindy McCain’s favorite family recipes, as listed on the McCain campaign Web site, were Food Network favorites first.
The 15 advertising agencies that agreed to be monitored for three years on their minority hiring practices met 24 of the 30 goals they set for themselves in 2007.
The task was previously administered by the State Department, and the defense secretary asked to raise the annual budget for the effort to $750 million, a 250 percent increase.
The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. denounced what he described as a “violent attack orchestrated” by the Service Employees International Union against other unions.
The Army Corps of Engineers proposed on a new plan to expand storage in upstream lakes and lower river flows into Apalachicola Bay, Fla.
United States home foreclosure filings surged 57 percent in the 12-month period that ended in March, and bank repossessions soared 129 percent from a year ago.
States are experimenting with a broad range of solutions to the foreclosure crisis, resulting in a changing patchwork of local approaches.
Stocks gained as record oil prices lifted energy shares and stronger-than-expected quarterly results at several regional banks helped shares of financial companies.
Surprising no one, President Vladimir V. Putin agreed to become the chairman of United Russia, a party that has been regarded as an arm of the Kremlin since its creation in 2001.
French legislators adopted a pioneering law Tuesday aimed at stifling a proliferation of Web sites that promote eating disorders with “thinspiration” and starvation tips.
It is the first time in 43 years that a Pakistan-made movie is showing in India.
By overreacting to the shooting at Virginia Tech, college administrators are instituting security measures that may undermine the carefree atmosphere of campus life.
The most consequential speech that Pope Benedict XVI will give for American Catholics may be his address to the presidents of Catholic colleges and universities tomorrow.
In light of the Virginia Tech massacre, can it be a good idea to present school shootings as entertainment?
Many say the $611 million publicly financed stadium for the Washington Nationals has accelerated a striking change in a long-languishing area.
The Port Authority’s concern is underscored by a risk assessment that said there was less than a 5 percent probability that the $2.221 billion budget would be met.
Pope Benedict XVI’s expression of remorse for the church’s sexual abuse scandal prompted an angry response from victims.
In a unanimous decision, the Supreme Court limited states’ ability to tax income that companies with out-of-state headquarters earn from their in-state investments.
“The Orangeburg Massacre” never pierced the nation’s collective memory of the 1960s, but new media coverage may give the shootings their historical due.
The actress Zooey Deschanel is showcasing her harmony-loving side in a new band, She & Him, with the singer-songwriter-guitarist M. Ward.

Jazz at Lincoln Center will celebrate the induction of the pioneering jazz guitarists Django Reinhardt, above left, and Charlie Christian, right, into the Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame with concerts at 8 p.m. May 2 and 3 at Rose Theater in Frederick P. Rose Hall. Music by Reinhardt and Christian will be performed by Bobby Broom, Biréli Lagréne, Russell Malone and Frank Vignola, backed by a rhythm section featuring the drummer and music director Lewis Nash, Peter Washington on bass and Mulgrew Miller on piano.
The Goodman Theater of Chicago will bring in troupes from the Netherlands and Brazil as it turns a 21st-century lens on Eugene O’Neill.

The New York buzz band Vampire Weekend and the author Richard Price will be part of Central Park SummerStage this year. In addition to concerts by Mavis Staples, Sharon Jones and others already disclosed, the City Parks Foundation has announced the remainder of its 32 free performances: Vampire Weekend with Kid Sister (June 14); the French-Israeli singer Yael Naim (June 22); Vieux Farka Touré and Fallou Dieng (June 28); Rachid Taha and Dengue Fever (July 5); dance with Rennie Harris/Puremovement (July 11); the novelist Junot Díaz (July 17); Santogold with Diplo (July 20); Skatalites with Taj Mahal (July 27); Mr. Price (July 31); Roy Hargrove (Aug. 2); Los Lonely Boys with Los Lobos (Aug. 14); Battles and Black Dice (Aug. 16); and Ms. Jones (Aug. 17). Among the six paid benefit shows are Mark Knopfler (July 23); Crosby, Stills and Nash (July 29); and Sonny Rollins (Aug. 6). Information: summerstage.org.

Under normal circumstances the Academy Award nominees are announced on a Tuesday, but next year, revealing the names of the Oscar competitors will be postponed for two days, until Thursday, Jan. 22, Variety reported. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is delaying the announcement to avoid a conflict with the presidential inaugural ceremonies on Jan. 20. The 81st Academy Awards will be presented on Feb. 22 at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. ABC will televise the event.

Every note written by Chopin, below, will be performed on May 2 and 3 when BBC Radio 3 dedicates a weekend to exploring how he revolutionized piano music, the BBC reported. The program, “The Chopin Experience,” which also examines the composer’s troubled personal life, follows similar tributes by the station to Beethoven, Bach, Mozart and Tchaikovsky. The most famous recordings of Chopin’s works will be heard, and his 24 Études will be broadcast in an unbroken sequence featuring 24 pianists.

André Watts will replace Martha Argerich as the soloist in five performances of Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 1 with the New York Philharmonic, led by Charles Dutoit. The orchestra announced that Ms. Argerich had been advised by her doctor to rest after an illness. The concerts, at 7:30 p.m. April 23 and 24, 8 p.m. on April 25 and 26, and 7:30 p.m. on April 29, include Mozart’s Overture to “The Marriage of Figaro,” Rachmaninoff’s Symphonic dances and Ravel’s “Valse.” ... Since 1991, when the Shakespeare Theater Company of Washington first presented free Shakespeare shows with a production of “The Merry Wives of Windsor,” more than 560,000 people have attended these performances. This year, 30,000 people are expected, the company said, when it presents “Hamlet” at Carter Barron Amphitheater in Rock Creek Park from May 22 to June 1. ... Michael McKean, a star of the Broadway revival of “The Homecoming,” has a date to star for the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago in “Superior Donuts,” a new play from Tracy Letts, who won a Pulitzer Prize this year for “August: Osage County,” Variety reported. Mr. McKean will play the owner of a Chicago doughnut shop whose sole employee, a black teenager portrayed by Jon Hill, wants to improve the place.

An American, three Britons and two Canadians made the shortlist on Tuesday for the Orange Broadband Prize for Fiction, an annual award for works by women published in Britain in the past year, Agence France-Presse reported. The American, Patricia Wood, was chosen for her debut novel, “Lottery,” about an orphaned 31-year-old man with an I.Q. of 76 who wins the Washington State Lottery. The Britons are Sadie Jones, for “The Outcast”; Rose Tremain, for “The Road Home”; and Charlotte Mendelson, for “When We Were Bad.” The Canadians are Heather O’Neill, for “Lullabies for Little Criminals,” and Nancy Huston, for “Fault Lines.” The winner of the prize, worth $59,000, will be announced in London on June 4.

A 90-minute “Dancing With the Stars” may have afforded ABC the most viewers over all on Monday, but in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49 CBS eked out a slight victory thanks to its comedy lineup. Nielsen reported that “Dancing With the Stars” averaged 17 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., easily the night’s largest audience, but down considerably from the 19.7 million the show drew a week ago. Meanwhile, CBS’s 9 p.m. comedy “Two and a Half Men” (13.8 million) delivered the night’s top ratings in the 18-to-49 set. CBS remained in the lead in that demographic at 9:30 with “Rules of Engagement” (10.3 million), which significantly outperformed ABC’s sitcom “Samantha Who?” among adults 18 to 49 despite the ABC show’s competitive showing in total viewers (10 million). At 10, ABC’s “Bachelor” earned a third-place finish (7 million) behind CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (10.5 million) and NBC’s “Medium” (9.6 million), which led the hour in the 18-to-49 set. NBC finished third for the night, attracting 9.6 million viewers earlier for a two-hour edition of “Deal or No Deal.” Fox was fourth, drawing 6.8 million viewers for the finale of “New Amsterdam” at 9 p.m.

GOTTEHRER--Barry. We all came of age together--working with Barry for the City we love and its courageous Mayor when New York teetered over the flames that engulfed so many American cities -ignited by race, poverty, Vietnam and the anger of ignored communities. Barry's Bronx street smarts and underdog sensibility were indispensable to our coming through, together. He was our comrade-in-arms, our brother, an unsung New York hero. Our love to those he loved most Pat, Kevin and Andrea. Thanks, Sam Roberts, for the perfect Times obit and moving podcast essay (Google ''an - agent - of - change - at - a time of chaos''). A New York Memorial will be held in June. Lindsay Colleagues of Barry

The American Leadership Project, an outside group that is supportive of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, is planning to hit the airwaves in several television markets in Pennsylvania on Wednesday with a commercial praising her stances on health care. Representatives for the group indicated, however, that they were planning to spend only about $250,000 initially, a relatively small amount. Although the group has been actively soliciting individual donors, the money for the commercials comes mostly from two unions that have endorsed Mrs. Clinton, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and the Machinists Union. As a ''527,'' one of the groups thus designated because of the part of the tax code they fall under, the American Leadership Project is barred from coordinating with the Clinton campaign and cannot explicitly call for Mrs. Clinton's election. But with Senator Barack Obama spending more than twice as much on advertising in Pennsylvania so far, according to the latest figures from the Campaign Media Analysis Group, which tracks advertising spending, Mrs. Clinton could clearly use the help in getting her message out on the airwaves.

SWEET--Melvin Douglas. Quintessential New Yorker, a Lower East Side kid with big dreams and an enormous love of life. At 83 years, not nearly old enough to be lost to us. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends, especially his wife, his most beloved Ann; his daughters Ivy and Melanie, sons-in-law Arty and Greg, grandchildren Emilia, Kate, Douglas and Alissa and great-grandchildren Kyle and Mia. In his memory take a walk around Manhattan, eat something wonderful at Shun Lee, have a vodka gimlet and a good cigar. Try to get in a good game of golf. Play ''Misty''. Breathe in the New York air and thoroughly enjoy the time you have.

GARRISON--Reverend Canon Maurice Allen Martin, age 83, of Virginia died Monday, April 14, 2008 in the Virginia Regional Medical Center. Maurice was ordained a Priest on March 21, 1953 by Bishop Boynton at the Church of the Holy Apostles in New York City. Father Maurice served God in a remarkable variety of locations and tasks, Most of his 50 years as a priest were spent in missionary work and theological teaching overseas. Father Garrison also served a number of parishes in the City of New York. He was curate at Trinity Church-St. Augustine's Chapel, the Brooklyn House of Detention, St. Mary the Virgin, and the Church of the Transfiguration, in 1990 and from 1998 to the present. Maurice is survived by sisters: Evelyn (Gerald) Perron of International Falls, MN and Mary (Lawrence) Perron of Steinback, Manitoba; nieces and nephews; his adopted African son: Simeon Garrison and his son: Judah. He was preceded in death by his parents; his stepmother: Agnes Garrison and a sister: Beverly McMillen. Funeral services will be held at 12 Noon on Friday, April 18, 2008 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Virginia. Family services provided by Bauman-Cron, A Bauman Family Funeral Home in Virgina. To share a personal remembrance of Maurice online, please see: www.baumanfuneralhome .com

LODERHOSE--Richard E. Born in Brooklyn, New York, August 16, 1925, he passed peacefully on April 10, 2008, in Tampa, Florida. He attended Richmond Hill High School and the University of Rochester as a Naval cadet. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War Two as a Specialist for Welfare and Recreation and was the organist for all chapel activities at the U.S. Naval Base in Little Creek, Maryland. Subsequent to his naval service he was employed in the family business in New York City, then known as the United Paste and Glue Company. Along with his father, Herman C. Loderhose, he built United into the national adhesive manufacturer called United Resin Products, Inc. He was a gifted CEO, master salesman, and innovator in packaging patents, coatings and adhesives. In 1997, Mr. Loderhose sold United to the Henkel Corporation and remained with Henkel for the next four years as a senior director of the company. Mr. Loderhose had a lifelong passion for music, particularly the theatre organ. He was well known for his preservation, restoration, perfor mance, and support of the instrument. The gem of his extensive collection being the 55 rank New York Paramount Studio Theatre Organ, until recently located at the family owned Bay Theatre in Seal Beach, California. In June, 2007, Mr. Loderhose gifted this magnificent instrument to The Beatitudes Campus in Phoenix, Arizona where it is being reinstalled for the enjoyment of the residents, members, congregants, staff and the entire Phoenix and theatre organ community. He was a past president and founding member of the American Theatre Organ Society. He played the organ professionally under the name Dick Scott and made numerous recordings for his own label, Renwick Recordings, Inc. as well as for United Artists Records. An avid yachtsman, Mr. Loderhose also had a great passion for World War Two Air Sea Rescue boats. He refurbished and restored numerous rescue/crash boats during his lifetime (Music Man I through VI) and was often a speaker at events sponsored by crash boat organizations throughout the country. His philanthropy included the donation of a restored 64 foot rescue boat to the Sea Scouts of Marina Del Rey, California. When Mr. Loderhose retired from the glue business in 1997 he spent most of his remaining years in Newport Beach, California attending to his yachting and musical interests. He was a member of the Balboa Bay Club, Newport Beach, California. His final years were spent in Tampa, Florida. He is at rest now knowing that whatever his passion, he succeeded. He would want everyone to know that he truly had a ball and would go out playing ''Ain't Misbehavin'' or ''Anchors Away'' if he could; and those who knew him would agree. Life was good. He dearly loved his family and friends and was grateful for the life he led. He is survived by his daughters, Rena L. Singer and her husband Joel B. Singer, Mari J. Galloway and her husband, Michael G. Galloway; six grandchildren, Beryl, Garrett and Lindsay Firestone and Robin, Adam and Shannon Galloway, his loving sister, Grace E. Kerr, and former wife, Marie Tepper. Remembered lovingly by his first wife, and lifelong friend, the late Jane D. Loderhose. Donations can be made to the American Theatre Organ Society, or the charity of your choice in his memory. Memorial service to take place at Prince of Peace Lutheran Church in Phoenix, Arizona on Saturday, April 19, 2008 at 2pm. Marsicano-B. Marion Reed-Stowers Funeral Home.

8 P.M. (13, 49) ILLICIT: THE DARK TRADE It's a new kind of crime wave: illicit trade, whether in counterfeit Prada bags, airplane parts, weapons-grade uranium or even humans. And the global value is estimated to be as much as $3 trillion a year. Based on the book ''Illicit: How Smugglers, Traffickers and Copycats Are Hijacking the Global Economy'' by Moisés Naim, this National Geographic documentary, above, looks at the manufacture and sale of goods ranging from fake purses to counterfeit pharmaceuticals, and supports Mr. Naim's thesis that illicit trade could be as big a threat as, if not bigger than, terrorism. 8 P.M. (ABC) PRESIDENTIAL DEBATESenators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama discuss the issues at the National Constitutional Center in Philadelphia; Charles Gibson and George Stephanopoulos moderate.

Michelle Obama, appearing at Haverford College in Pennsylvania, gave a strong response on Tuesday to criticism that her husband's remarks at a San Francisco fund-raiser were elitist. ''There's a lot of people talking about elitism and all of that,'' Ms. Obama said at a gathering of students and townspeople, alluding to responses to her husband's remarks. ''Yeah, I went to Princeton and Harvard, but the lens through which I see the world is the lens that I grew up with. I am the product of a working-class upbringing. I grew up on the South Side of Chicago in a working-class community.''

A new book of documentary photographs, “Shelter,” examines a group of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender young people living, off and on, at a homeless shelter in Hell’s Kitchen — a group for whom growing up could hardly be more difficult. That the book is the product of a 27-year-old photographer who is gay, grew up in poverty and once lived in a homeless shelter himself explains its empathetic tone and morally urgent message.The photographer, Lucky S. Michaels, shot roughly 4,000 images over three years, 2003 to 2006, while he worked as an overnight counselor at the shelter, Sylvia’s Place, which is run by the Metropolitan Community Church of New York, at 446 West 36th Street, between Ninth and 10th Avenues.

Any Catholic college or university presidents bracing for a scolding from Pope Benedict probably breathed a sigh of relief after hearing his remarks at the Catholic University of America today. Benedict made no mention of pro-choice commencement speakers or performances of "The Vagina Monologues." He said that a school's Catholic identity "is not simply a question of the number of Catholic students" and cannot "be equated simply with orthodoxy of course content" -- remarks that surely came as good news to leaders of the many Catholic schools that fall short on both counts.

Today's Papal Mass at Nationals Park, in Washington, D.C., brought together over 46,000 people to join in prayer with Pope Benedict XVI. Most in the vast congregation participated in a complicated lottery to obtain a ticket; many came from great distances; all were required to be in their seats several hours before the Mass began. In short, nearly everyone in the crowd expended an enormous amount of effort just to be in the same sports arena with an elderly German man.

In the United States, the Muslim-Catholic dialogue formally began in 1985. National and regional meetings have been co-sponsored by U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, the Islamic Society of North America and several other Muslim organizations. In the realm of online dating, there is an awkward moment in which one party removes his or her profile before the other. By "delisting," the removing party is basically saying that she (or he) is no longer looking. Interestingly, the way the delisting party figures this out is by logging onto the site and looking, which raises the issue of whether the other half of the couple is, in fact, completely not looking.

To mark the sixth annual Poem in Your Pocket Day (not to mention National Poetry Month) volunteers with the Academy of American Poets handed out poems this morning to commuters at Grand Central Terminal. The poems included works drawn from New York City life by Edna St. Vincent Millay, Claude McKay, Walt Whitman and Emma Lazarus, as well as verses of the poetry legends Robert Frost and Emily Dickinson.

Société Générale, the French bank that was rocked by a rogue trading scandal that cost it 4.9 billion euros or about $7.1 billion, said late Thursday that Daniel Bouton would step aside as chief executive but would remain non-executive chairman as part of a reorganization of its senior management structure.

Milan design week kicked off with a party celebrating the International Herald Tribune edition of T Design. On Tuesday evening, the rain clouds finally parted and the garden of the Bulgari Hotel was illuminated with an installation inspired by the issue's cover story, "Seeing the Light," not to mention the presence of pretty much every design luminary in town, including Murray Moss, who was also one of the party's hosts, Philippe Starck and his wife Jasmine, Jasper Morrison, Marten Baas, Yves Behar, Fernando and Humberto Campana, Ronan Bouroullec, Inga Sempe, the architect John Pawson, the fashion designer Miuccia Prada and the artist Francesco Vezzoli. The jury is still out as to who works harder (and dresses better) in Milan: the fashion crowd or the design crowd. But in terms of prosecco consumption, the design people appear to be holding their own.

RALEIGH, N.C. - Senator Barack Obama delivered a mocking critique of Wednesday night's Democratic presidential debate, telling an audience here that the 90-minute session with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton exemplified the problems with Washington by not focusing on issues that truly matter to the American people."They like stirring up controversy and they like playing gotcha games, getting us to attack each other. And I have to say Senator Clinton looked in her element," Mr. Obama said. "She was taking every opportunity to get a dig in there. You know, that's all right. That's her right. That's her right to kind of twist the knife a little bit."

[UPDATE, 1/30: A new report on ocean acidification has been released. Some scientists who question whether the carbon dioxide buildup poses a danger to corals stress that corals have endured for hundreds of millions of years. Today's reefs may not be as durable as the species that built them. One way or the other, it's clear that the direct chemical impacts of accumulating CO2 on marine life have received less attention, and been less studied, than the climatological consequences.]

Rosemary Ruether in her latest posting, said that the Pope's attack on the "dictatorship of relativism" implies a rejection of religious pluralism. In the summer of 2005, Mark Warner, then Virginia's governor and a likely candidate for president, was the honored guest at a meeting of liberal donors just north of San Francisco-the same kind of crowd to whom Barack Obama was talking last week when he made his comments about bitterness, guns and religion. On that night, Mr. Warner proudly rose to make his case for why his success in Virginia could translate into Democratic success in other rural states, and to explain how he had improved schools and local economies in the state's forgotten mining towns. But to his frustration, the donors were far more concerned about his stands on social issues - why he had capitulated to rural voters by embracing gun rights and parental notifications for abortions. At the end of the evening, as one of the donors pushed him further on abortion, Mr. Warner finally lost his cool. "This is why America hates Democrats," he blurted before he drove away.

Commentators seeking a shorthand way to characterize Pope Benedict frequently have resorted to depicting him as an ecclesiastical version of Dr. Jekyll-and-Mr. Hyde. The "good" Benedict recognizes the longings of our spiritually hungry age and calls for compassion for immigrants and the poor. The "bad" Benedict emphasizes the importance of fidelity to Catholic moral teachings on such controversies as abortion and same-sex marriage while promoting the revival of traditional Catholic devotions.

In the far-reaching oral history “All For a Few Perfect Waves: The Audacious Life and Legend of Rebel Surfer Miki Dora” (HarperEntertainment, $25.95), there’s no shortage of opinion about the enigmatic beach legend -- just not from the author, David Rensin. Oh, those poor, beleaguered Minnesota Timberwolves. The team’s fortunes have turned so sour since Kevin Garnett left that the front office has even taken to pushing season tickets in the nosebleed seats for next season at prices pegged to the draft lottery outcome - just $1 a game if the team lands the No. 1 pick. That’s $41 for the year. A 12-pack of meat kolaches costs more.

Once Sara Hall, a world-class runner, switched to competing in races about a mile long instead of more than three miles, she reconfigured her training to focus more on speed work. Now, she can run greater distances faster than ever before. Her training regimen, The Times reports today, provides a good model for how recreational runners -- not just the elite -- can get swifter and sharper. For example, Hall has reduced the miles that she runs each week, and has added hard interval sessions twice a week on a track. “The most common mistake” made by recreational runners, says Terrence Mahon, Hall’s coach, “is running the same pace all the time.”.

This offseason, in the manner of the old Politburo airbrushers, the San Francisco Giants set about scrubbing virtually every reference to their erstwhile star Barry Bonds -- the banners, the murals, the signs commemorating his pursuit of Hank Aaron’s record -- from their bright little toy of a ballpark. If you haven’t seen it, AT&T Park is one of those overpraised retro chic palaces that was built, I suppose, to transport the paying customer back to that quaint time when all our ballparks were outfitted with 80-foot Coke bottles and ye olde Wi-fi. (Perhaps I’m being unfair. The stadium has plenty to recommend it. I hear they serve an excellent Sterling Vintners Collection Chardonnay.) Which is to say, you shouldn’t go to AT&T Park, or any ballpark for that matter, expecting an honest reckoning with history. But the Giants’ purge of Bonds -- from a stadium designed expressly for his game, no less -- was something else entirely. It was a fitting tribute, if not to Bonds, then to the most insecure and insufferable franchise this side of Yawkey Way.

ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson’s nominee to take over the beleaguered State Police, Harry J. Corbitt, was confirmed by the Senate on Wednesday after promising this week to repair the agency’s reputation and to conduct a review of the security detail provided to governors.

A federal judge has ruled that water regulators did not consider the effects of global warming and other environmental issues related to disappearing California salmon when they approved increased pumping of the state’s Delta region. The judge, Oliver W. Wanger, of Federal District Court in San Francisco, tossed out a study prepared in 2004 by federal regulators, saying it was scientifically inadequate. The study had concluded that more water could be taken from the Central Valley to quench residential and agricultural thirsts throughout the state. The plan was already on hold because of a similar ruling the judge made about the Bush administration’s failure to address effects on Delta smelt species.

In its first full year, universal health coverage in Massachusetts will cost the state $153.1 million more than was budgeted, according to a supplemental budget request released Monday by Gov. Deval Patrick. The state had appropriated $472 million for the fiscal year ending June 30, but enrollment in the state’s subsidized insurance programs for low- and middle-income workers exceeded expectations. About 340,000 of the state’s estimated 600,000 uninsured have gained coverage since Massachusetts began requiring health insurance. The state had projected that 136,000 people would sign up for its Commonwealth Care policies, but 174,000 are now enrolled. Cyndi Roy, a spokeswoman for Mr. Patrick, a Democrat, said this year’s shortfall would be offset by surplus revenues in the state’s general fund. For the coming fiscal year, Mr. Patrick has requested $869 million for Commonwealth Care, but his aides have already conceded that will not be enough as enrollment continues to grow.
The number of neurological illnesses among workers who processed pig brains at pork plants in three states has grown to as many as 24, researchers said.
An elderly woman was convicted of murdering two homeless men to collect millions of dollars in insurance money.
A judge denied a request to subpoena Vice President Dick Cheney in a lawsuit filed by a man who claims he was wrongfully arrested for comments he made to Mr. Cheney about the Iraq war.
As Thomson officially completes its takeover of Reuters, the company will be unveil its new log and name: Thomson Reuters.
As one of the most prominent sponsors of the Olympics, Coca-Cola found itself on the hot seat on Wednesday at its annual shareholder meeting.
Calorie counts must be posted alongside prices in some New York City restaurants, a federal judge ruled in upholding revised city regulations.
Pope Benedict XVI warned that a secular tradition often prevented Americans from living their beliefs fully.
America’s biggest pension funds lost ground in the first quarter, joining the ranks of homeowners, lenders and others hurt by the turmoil in the financial markets.
Ken Mehlman, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, is the latest high-profile hire by the private equity giant as it prepares to go public.
The government said price controls had limited the cost of many essential items and exports to the United States had weakened.
Secretary General Ban Ki-moon told the Security Council that he was “deeply concerned” by the delay in releasing the results of Zimbabwe’s presidential election.
An Iraqi Army captain insisted that he had left his 70 soldiers in the midst of a battle in Sadr City the day before to take his long-overdue three-day break.
Because much of the technology services company’s business is outside the United States, a falling dollar lifts reported earnings.
A flurry of reports portrayed a U.S. economy limping its way through a broad-based downturn, with consumer demand softening and labor and housing markets still struggling.

Travis Ford is leaving as the head coach at Massachusetts to take over the Oklahoma State program, both universities confirmed. Oklahoma State said it planned to formally introduce Ford at a news conference on Thursday. The job became open April 1 when Sean Sutton resigned under pressure.

Tyreke Evans, the most valuable player of the McDonald’s all-American game last month and one of the country’s last undecided high-profile recruits, will spend next season at Memphis. Evans announced his decision Wednesday at a news conference surrounded by his family at American Christian School in Aston, Pa., a Philadelphia suburb. A three-time state player of the year, Evans averaged 29 points a game as a senior and capped it off with a 21-point, 10-rebound performance in the McDonald’s game, the top event for high school seniors.

A Boston Marathon tradition that brought Kenyan runners to a Hopkinton, Mass., elementary school had to be canceled this year when several pupils caught chicken pox. Kenyan runners have been visiting second and third graders at Elmwood Elementary School for the last 15 years. Rather than risk the health of the athletes, the event was canceled on the advice of marathon medical advisers and the state public health department.
The Supreme Court upheld Kentucky’s method of execution by lethal injection, rejecting the claim that its protocol posed an unconstitutional risk.
Faced with an economic slump, a growing number of national retailers are abandoning the tradition of reporting monthly store sales and forecasting profits.
A construction worker’s attempt to curse the Yankees by burying a Red Sox jersey at the team’s new stadium has raised questions about the nature of the occult.
The better course would be for America to undertake Justice John Paul Stevens’s hard look at capital punishment — and leave it behind.

The pope’s visit lacks the historic drama that colored Pope John Paul II’s trips to the United States, but the occasion is still momentous enough to pump up the live shots, telegenic priests and papal biographers.
The billionaire financier Wilbur L. Ross Jr. has compiled a shopping list of small struggling banks that might prove to be good investments.
John Donahoe, the new chief of the Internet’s largest e-commerce site, wants eBay to operate less like an unruly flea market and more like a strip mall.

A document outlining the American negotiating position for talks with Sudan offers normalized relations if the Sudanese government agreed, among other steps, to allow peacekeepers in its Darfur region.
The Yankees are the first major league team since the 1996 Baltimore Orioles to play 18 of 20 games on the road.
Abbott Laboratories said itst first-quarter earnings rose 34 percent on higher sales of its prescription drugs and medical devices and favorable foreign exchange factors.
Wall Street analysts are suggesting the breakup of General Electric after an unusual earnings shortfall.
A jury found former Mayor Sharpe James of Newark guilty for conspiring to sell city-owned properties.
The pope should demand more from diocesan authorities who continue to deny their own complicity in covering up the abuse of pedophile priests.

Texas child welfare officials and parents of many of the more than 400 children seized in a raid on a polygamist religious compound in West Texas differ sharply on how the children are faring after two weeks in state custody.
A Texas court has rejected a request by several banks to dismiss a lawsuit seeking to force them to finance a $20 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications.
Two City Council aides have been indicted on charges of embezzling at least $145,000 in city funds and sending some of the money to relatives in Jamaica.
The Supreme Court’s decision may actually slow executions in some parts of the country.

Gov. David A. Paterson will remove Anthony E. Shorris, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in a move that could come within a week, people aware of the governor’s plans said.
Alex Ovechkin’s answers about his playoff slump were brief, and the Washington Capitals’ stay in the postseason might be brief as well if he cannot quickly rediscover his touch.

Shareholders, to be sure, will collect their payment, but Microsoft will likely need to offer financial incentives to prevent engineers and managers from hopping to other jobs.
President Bush called for the United States to stop the growth of greenhouse gas emissions by 2025 and challenged other countries to commit to goals of their own.

Before deregulation, tickets were expensive and routes were limited. Thirty years later, the question is raised anew: Has deregulation really worked out?

The Department of Defense has identified 4,029 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:.

A picture caption last Thursday about rioting in Haiti over high food prices misstated President Rene Préval’s position on the issue. He urged Haitians to become agriculturally self-sufficient; he did not say he would urge Haiti’s congress to cut taxes on imported food.
FRONT PAGE.

A review on Tuesday of Kathleen Battle’s recital at Carnegie Hall misstated the composition she sang unaccompanied. It was “Were You There When They Crucified My Lord?” — not “Good News,” which she performed with accompaniment.

Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about foreign policy advisers to Senator John McCain referred incorrectly to an error he made at a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee on April 8. He briefly referred to Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia as a Shiite group, rather than a Sunni group; he did not repeat an error during the hearing that he had made on a trip to the Middle East last month when he said several times that he was concerned that Iran, a Shiite nation, was training Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, a Sunni group.
In Connecticut, a radio system that plays music for students on the bus is getting attacked for the commercials that sometimes annoy students and worry parents.

An obituary on Monday about the physicist John A. Wheeler referred incorrectly to J. Robert Oppenheimer’s position when he first discussed a theory of black holes with Dr. Wheeler in 1939. Dr. Oppenheimer, who clashed with Dr. Wheeler over the theory, had yet to take over the Manhattan Project, since it had not begun. He was not “formerly the head” of the project at the time. The obituary also misstated the origin of the term “many worlds,” a description of the parallel universe theory of Dr. Wheeler’s student Hugh Everett. It was coined by Bryce DeWitt, of the University of Texas in Austin, not by Dr. Wheeler.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption and an article on Monday about Ryan Hall’s fifth-place finish in the London Marathon referred imprecisely in some editions to his accomplishment. Hall became the second-fastest American marathoner, but his time of 2:06:17 was not the second-fastest performance ever. That distinction is held by Khalid Khannouchi, who has run the top two times since becoming a United States citizen. The article also misstated, in some editions, the overall ranking for Hall’s performance. It was the 22nd-fastest marathon in history, not the 18th fastest.
The Anaheim Ducks, who revived their season with an impressive victory on Tuesday, now look as if they will get their leading scorer back as soon as Thursday.

The Bloomberg administration has revised its redevelopment plan for the Coney Island waterfront in an effort to break a deadlock with some landowners and elected officials while still preserving the area’s historic amusement district, which includes the Wonder Wheel and the Cyclone roller coaster.

An article on Monday about problems facing the Catholic church in the United States even as it welcomes Pope Benedict XVI for a visit misstated the estimated number of victims of the church’s sexual abuse scandal. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops has acknowledged about 13,000 victims — not 5,000, which is the approximate number of priests and deacons who have been accused of abuse.
An article on Monday about an IAC/InterActiveCorp search engine aimed at a black audience misspelled the surname of a singer hired by IAC to promote the service. She is Regina Belle, not Bell.

An article in some editions on April 6 about the death of a Columbia University graduate student who was struck by a vehicle while fleeing an assault in Manhattan gave erroneous information from the police in some copies for the location of the assault. It took place on a median on Broadway at 122nd Street; the median is between 121st and 122nd Streets, not between 122nd and 123rd. (The error was repeated in articles in some editions on April 7 and April 8, and again in some copies of an article on Friday.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the effect of biofuels on the price of food misidentified the representatives who criticized Western biofuel policy during a meeting in Washington last weekend on global economic issues. Much of the criticism came from representatives of poor countries that have been hit hard by rising food prices. It did not come from the finance ministers or central bankers of seven leading industrial countries.
The Obamas reported a household income of $4.2 million in 2007, a substantial jump from their roughly $1 million in income in 2006.
AS Andy Potts, one of the top triathletes in the world, trains for the Olympic trials Saturday in Tuscaloosa, his wife, Lisa, battles cancer. It is a team effort.

The financial troubles plaguing some of New York City’s biggest employers have not yet cut into the paychecks of city residents or curtailed consumer spending in the city, the latest tax collection figures show.
One of former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy’s co-conspirators admitted Wednesday to paying for picks and intentionally defrauding the league.

MINEOLA, N.Y. (AP) — More than 20,000 pairs of counterfeit Nike sneakers, as well as fake batteries, baseball caps and Louis Vuitton handbags, were among $25 million in goods seized in raids in New York City, on Long Island and in New Jersey, the authorities said on Wednesday.
The federal Department of Transportation proposed auctioning landing and departure slots to airlines at La Guardia Airport to reduce persistent delays.

Jack South, Prisoner No. 90T1984, has endured the kind of life — foster homes, post-traumatic stress from his time in the Army, drug abuse — that may or may not have led to his history of crime, including bank robbery and escape from a federal prison.
Dmitri A. Medvedev, who will take office as Russia’s president on May 7, appears likely to defer to his predecessor, Vladimir V. Putin. This seems to be an arrangement that many Russians want.

Leona Lewis, a 23-year-old British singer whose lungs of steel first brought her to fame two years ago on the television talent show “The X Factor,” has earned another prize: No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Her debut, “Spirit” (Syco/J), was released in the United States last week and sold 205,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is more than triple the sales of her nearest competitor on the chart, George Strait’s “Troubadour” (MCA Nashville), which moved 59,000. The country singer James Otto bows at No. 3 with 58,000 sales of “Sunset Man” (Warner Brothers). Ray J, whose older sister is the R&B star Brandy, reached No. 7 with 39,000 sales of his new album, “All I Feel” (Koch), and the Christian metal band P.O.D. is at No. 9 with its new “When Angels & Serpents Dance” (Columbia), which sold 34,000. “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 27 fell one spot to No. 4, and R.E.M.’s “Accelerate” (Warner Brothers) dropped three to No. 5.

The Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim Foundation have received permission to proceed with a lawsuit intended to establish their ownership of two Picasso paintings, Bloomberg News reported. The ruling, by Judge Jed S. Rakoff of United States District Court in Manhattan, rejected a motion by Julius Schoeps, a professor in Germany, to dismiss the museums’ petition for a ruling that he had no valid claim to the paintings. He said the paintings, “Boy Leading a Horse,” above, and “Le Moulin de la Galette,” were sold under duress by onr of his Jewish relatives in Germany as the Nazis rose to power. The court decision leaves open the possibility of a trial on the merits of the competing ownership claims.
The Room to Improve column last Thursday, about décor for children’s bedrooms, misidentified the maker of wall decals. They were made by Fastsigns, not FedEx Kinko’s.

The Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, charged its financial director with embezzling more than $775,000, Agence France-Presse reported. The Guggenheim said that it filed the case against the director, Roberto Cearsolo Barrenetxea, “for financial and accounting irregularities.” In a statement the museum said he had admitted diverting money to his own account since 1998. He was fired on Tuesday.

An Italian artist, hitchhiking through Turkey in a wedding dress as part of an international art-performance piece, was raped and strangled by a driver who picked her up, government officials say. The naked body of the artist, Giuseppina Pasqualino di Marineo, 33, was found Saturday in the bushes in Gebze, a village in Kocaeli province, about 70 miles southeast of Istanbul, said Sadik Guvenc, a village official, quoted by the Anatolian Agency. He said that a suspect, Murat Karatas, identified on Saturday after using the victim’s cellphone with his own smart card, led investigators to the body. Stefano Canzio, the Italian consul in Istanbul, told the Italian news agency Ansa that Mr. Karatas had confessed to the killing. Wearing wedding dresses, left, Ms. di Marineo, known professionally as Pippa Bacca, and Silvia Moro, another artist, had left Milan on a mission to promote peace. They planned to hitchhike through the Balkans and Turkey en route to Tel Aviv, their final stop. They parted ways on March 19, agreeing to meet later in Beirut, but Ms. di Marineo fell out of touch. The last sign of her was a phone message sent to a friend in Italy and a purchase on her credit card in Gebze on March 31. Her body has been flown back to Italy.

The writers Robert A. Caro and Calvin Trillin are among eight newly elected members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. The other writers who will be inducted on May 21 are Kwame Anthony Appiah, Stephen Greenblatt, Paul Muldoon and Joy Williams. They will be joined by the artists John Baldessari and Ursula von Rydingsvard when Ezra Laderman, the president, presents more than 50 awards in architecture, art, literature and music at the academy, based in Manhattan. Richard Meier is to receive the organization’s gold medal for architecture and Edmund S. Morgan its gold medal for history. Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will receive the award for distinguished service to the arts.

A French singer who plans to sing in English at the Eurovision Song Contest next month in Belgrade, Serbia, has outraged many of his countrymen, Agence France-Presse reported. The singer, Sebastien Tellier, 33, intends to perform “Divine” with almost exclusively English lyrics, becoming the first French competitor to do so since the contest began in 1956. “Many of our citizens will not understand why France has chosen not to uphold its language before millions of television viewers around the world,” said François-Michel Gonnot, a French legislator. Christine Albanel, the culture minister, said France should be “solidly behind” Mr. Tellier, above, but added that “it is a shame that there is no French song” to represent that nation. Mr. Tellier’s producer, Stéphane Elfassi, said, “Out of the 40 countries participating at least 25 will present a song in English.”.

Despite competing opposite “American Idol” and “Dancing With the Stars,” the fifth season finale of “The Biggest Loser” delivered NBC’s largest audience in the 8 to 10 p.m. time period on Tuesday in nearly eight months. Ali Vincent became the first female winner of the series, shedding nearly 48 percent of her body weight, as the finale attracted an average of 11.2 million viewers, Nielsen reported. Among adults 18 to 49 “The Biggest Loser” drew the night’s third-highest ratings behind only Fox’s “American Idol,” which attracted 23 million total viewers during the 8 p.m. hour, and NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,” which led the 10 p.m. hour with 13.3 million viewers. NBC ranked second for the night overall behind Fox. ABC edged past CBS for third place in total viewers thanks to “Dancing With the Stars” at 9 (15 million). CBS’s “NCIS” fared nearly as well, however, at 8 p.m. with 14.9 million viewers.

Another successful entertainment figure has been accused of fabricating details of a hard-knock criminal life. Only this time it’s not a well-reviewed memoirist but Akon, left, the multiplatinum-selling R&B singer. On Wednesday the Web site The Smoking Gun (thesmokinggun.com) posted a 3,900-word investigation of the star’s criminal record, which Akon — who was born Aliaune Thiam and grew up in Senegal and the United States — alludes to in his music and has boasted about in numerous interviews. Although he claims to have spent more than four years in prison and says his crimes include leading an extensive car-theft ring, the only felony conviction among his six arrests was for gun possession, for which he received three years’ probation, The Smoking Gun reported. And while Akon, who titled his second album “Konvicted,” was arrested in 1998 for possession of a stolen BMW and was held for several months in jail, all charges were dropped, and he was released, according to the Web site. Akon’s representatives at Universal Motown, his label, did not respond to requests for comment.

“The Leaf,” originally thought to have been made around 1839 or later, has become the talk of the photo-historical world. It may be, in fact, one of the oldest photographic images in existence, dating to the 1790s.

IF I had only a few pots on a terrace, or a tiny outdoor plot, I would grow one big pot or a square foot of mesclun, a mix of salad greens that includes arugula, Japanese mustard, endive, and red and green lettuces. Simply fill a pot with a mix of potting soil and organic compost, and moisten well. Sprinkle the seeds over the surface, cover with a quarter inch of compost and water lightly to moisten the seeds. As the first baby greens grow, pull out any weeds and thin out the mesclun, eating the leaves you pull. Start more greens every couple of weeks, and move the pots into semi-shade when hot weather arrives. Or switch to heat-tolerant lettuces, like oak leaf and buttercrunch.

After more than 30 years, the history of a bombing resurfaced as the focus of a sharp exchange at Wednesday’s Democratic debate.
Hillary Rodham Clinton warned that Barack Obama would be deeply vulnerable in a general-election fight.
Barack Obama was under attack for his former friends, while Hillary Rodham Clinton was under attack from former friends.
Why has the U.S. produced a magnificent Holocaust Memorial Museum before opening an institution of equivalent stature dedicated to slavery and segregation?
Even though the policy differences between the two Democratic candidates are minimal, each camp is becoming increasingly aggravated at the other.
In the first half-hour of the 24th debate Wednesday night, the Democratic candidates for president tossed personal baggage back and forth like a tennis ball.
Talking points for patients and physicians.

8 P.M. (13) PRIMO In 1943, at 24, Primo Levi was arrested for being a member of the Italian resistance. The next year he was sent to Auschwitz when it was discovered that he was Jewish. He spent 11 months at the camp before it was liberated in January 1945 and was one of only 22 Italian Jews there to survive. In this ''Great Performances'' presentation, recorded at Hampstead Theater in London, Antony Sher, above, portrays Levi in Mr. Sher's own adaptation of Levi's classic memoir ''Survival in Auschwitz.'' 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE The search by Lex (Michael Rosenbaum) for the secret of Veritas has him on a collision course with Clark (Tom Welling). And someone dies.

DISERENS--Helen Barnett, 89, passed away on April 15. Following her graduation in 1941 from the University of Michigan as one of two women chemistry majors in her class, she moved to the New York area, where she worked for Elizabeth Arden, Hoffman LaRoche and Bristol Myers. While at Bristol Myers, as head of one of their consumer products research laboratories, she was responsible for the development of Ban deodorant and the first roll-on applicator, as well as the reformulation of Bufferin aspirin, Ipana toothpaste and other products. After a break to raise her young children, she returned to work. During her second career, as Business Manager of the Rippowam Cisqua School in Bedford, NY, she served as Chair of the Business Affairs Committee of the National Association of Independent Schools. In this capacity she co-authored, with John Shank of the Harvard Business School, a book that for the first time standardized accounting practices for independent schools. Following her retirement from Rippowam Cisqua School after 30 years, she continued to work in her own business, Money Minder, in which she managed personal and household finances for women in Northern Westchester. She completely retired at the age of 84. Helen was born in Huntington, West Virginia, daughter of Arthur Leroy and Leah Barnett. Wife of the late Robert C. Diserens, Jr., Helen is survived by her sister, Betty Jane Miller, of Blue Hill, ME, her daughter, Deborah Diserens of Philadelphia, PA, her son, Robert C. Diserens, III of Bronxville, NY, and four grandchildren. She was a resident of Mount Kisco, NY for 55 years and will be remembered by her family and friends for her ingenuity, intelligence, no nonsense common sense, strong will, talent for flower arranging, flare for fashion, dedication to her community, and never flagging devotion to her family and home. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthews Church in Bedford, New York on May 10 at 11:30am. Contributions in her memory may be made to Rippowam Cisqua School, Rte. 22, Bedford, NY, 10506 or St. Matthews Church, Rte. 22, Bedford, NY.

An article in some editions on April 6 about the death of a Columbia University graduate student who was struck by a vehicle while fleeing an assault in Manhattan gave erroneous information from the police in some copies for the location of the assault. It took place on a median on Broadway at 122nd Street; the median is between 121st and 122nd Streets, not between 122nd and 123rd. (The error was repeated in articles in some editions on April 7 and April 8, and again in some copies of an article on Friday.)

WHILE protective gear for the martial arts is nothing new, lately one piece of equipment has become more common. In the last two years, two martial arts associations have mandated the use of face shields attached to headgear during tournament sparring to protect noses and eyes. The North American Sport Karate Association, the host of a dozen open tournaments in North America annually, requires athletes under age 18 to wear them, while the American Taekwondo Association (ATA), which has 1,500 schools worldwide, specifies their use for all ages. ''It's like wearing a seatbelt, a preventive measure,'' said Jay Kohl, the ATA's international chairman of tournaments.Not every martial arts federation requires them. Notably absent is the World Taekwondo Federation, recognized as the sport's governing body by the International Olympic Committee. ''The face shields pose a risk of no clear vision,'' said Ji Ho Choi, the president of the Pan American Taekwondo Union, one of the regional taekwondo organizations of the World Taekwondo Federation. Face shield makers prefer clear plastic as a material, because it is transparent and lighter than older-style wire cages. The shields are attached to headgear with Velcro straps and sit off the face for ventilation. Christina Park, 27 and a third-degree black belt, tested four face shields at West Side Taekwondo in New York, where she is an instructor. Ranked by USA Taekwondo, one of the regional taekwondo organizations of the World Taekwondo Federation, she is a two-time national middleweight sparring champion and does not regularly use shields, only headgear. She preferred one-piece shields free of vented cutouts, which she said impeded her vision. By YISHANE LEE

KIMMEL--Martin S. The American Jewish Committee profoundly mourns the death of our beloved friend and extraordinarily generous benefactor, Martin Kimmel, to whom we owe an enormous debt of gratitude. Marty was an AJC Honorary Vice President and, along with his cherished wife, Helen, a member of our National Leadership Council. We were proud to pay tribute to him in 2005 with our most prestigious honor our Herbert H. Lehman Human Relations Award. In January 2008, through a major gift, we established the Helen and Martin Kimmel Young Leadership Institute, allowing AJC to more energetically and creatively engage and train emerging Jewish leadership. Buoyed over the years by his loving partnership with Helen, Marty's unshakable trust in AJC's mission and his unfaltering confidence in our ability to make a lasting difference were both inspiring and empowering. His insightful counsel and wholehearted support enabled AJC to intensify our work in pursuit of a more tolerant and compassionate world. This was a man of distinction who touched the lives of so many whom he never met, but who are forever enriched by his benevolence. This was a man of incomparable integrity, determined yet unassuming leadership, and inexhaustible humanity and compassion. This was an altruistic man whose heart was deeply touched and whose spirit was passionately stirred by his abiding love for Israel and the Jewish people and by those Jewish values and ideals that epitomized his very being. Through his extraordinary generosity, he has made possible for us all a better, more hopeful future. With Marty's passing, this world has lost a gentle and noble advocate for humankind, and AJC has lost a treasured and irreplaceable member of our family. Yet even at this time of profound sadness, we remain eternally grateful for Marty's life and his remarkable legacy of philanthropy, decency and human kindness that will long be remembered. At this painful time, we extend our heartfelt condolences and prayers to our dear friend Helen, to Adam Kimmel, and to the rest of the grieving family. May his memory always be a blessing. Richard J. Sideman, Pres. David A. Harris, Exec. Dir. Jaime Kelstein, Assoc. Exec. Dir. KIMMEL--Martin S. The Board of Directors, Officers and all Associates of Kimco Realty mourn the loss of Martin S. Kimmel, our Chairman Emeritus and co-founder. Marty had been a guiding force in Kimco's success. His historical perspective and knowledge was a treasure trove for Kimco. He was admired, respected and held in great esteem and affection by everyone at Kimco. Our sincere condolences are extended to his son Adam and his wife Helen. Kimco Realty Corporation KIMMEL--Martin S. We are terribly saddened by the loss of Martin Kimmel, our wonderful friend and partner. We started with a handshake 50 years ago and that was all that was ever needed. Marty always tried to do the right thing and used his energy, vigor and zeal to try to make our world better. Marty was blessed with much sweetness and joy in his life. He became the father of Adam and they shared a very close bond. Marty was so very proud of Adam as a person and of his accomplishments. He was blessed that he found a devoted love relationship with his wife Helen. A relationship that brought him much pleasure and enhanced and extended his life. We treasured our years together and will miss him very much. Shirley and Milton Cooper and Family KIMMEL--Marty. The finest gentleman we have ever known. We will miss you. Our deepest sympathy to Helen and Adam. Mara Urshel Ronnie Rothstein KIMMEL--Martin.
