The leadership, staff, and entire community of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of Martin Kimmel, our longtime friend, devoted supporter, and generous benefactor of the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel. Marty was a founding member of the President's Circle, a Vice President of the American Committee's Board of Directors, and was an Institute Governor and recipient of an honorary doctorate from the Weizmann Institute. His impact on the shape and spirit of the Weizmann Institute is immeasurable; among his most recent contributions were an Award for Innovative Investigation, an Institute for Stem Cell Research, and a Center for Nanoscale Science. Marty was a source of profound inspiration for all of us. Along with his wife, Helen, whom he met at a Weizmann Institute event, Marty's devotion to and love for the Institute have changed the face and future of science forever. Over the years, the Kimmels' support encouraged the research of over 60 scientists at the Institute, and has expanded not only its intellectual activities, but the Institute's campus itself. Marty's warmth, compassion, and wisdom will be dearly missed by the entire Weizmann Institute family. We extend heartfelt condolences to Helen and the entire Kimmel family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson President American Committee Marshall S. The entire New York University community deeply mourns the death of Martin Kimmel -trustee of the NYU Medical Center, esteemed member of the university's Sir Harold Acton Society and its Bronfman Center Advisory Board. He was a prominent real estate developer and a co-founding partner of Kimco Realty Corporation, the nation's largest publicly traded REIT, with properties in 45 states, Canada, Mexico and Puerto Rico. Deeply generous of his time and talents, he served as trustee and director of several major civic and philanthropic endeavors. With his beloved wife, Helen, he leaves a magnificent legacy of philanthropy from the Helen & Martin Kimmel Foundation to numerous intellectual and cultural institutions. At NYU's Medical Center, they made possible the Helen and Martin Kimmel Center for Stem Cell Biology, named professorships, and a wide range of programs, including epilepsy research, the Rusk Institute, molecular immunology, pharmacology, urology, cancer, and vascular research. Their giving embraced the entire university, including its Trustee Partners' Faculty Initiative Fund and a signature gift established at the heart of NYU's Greenwich Village campus --the Helen and Martin Kimmel Center for University Life located on Washington Square. His devoted leadership and superb generosity have been instrumental in the rise of the university from a regional school to a residential research and teaching institution of international distinction. We will treasure our memories of this wise, deeply generous and cherished colleague. We express our profound sympathy to Helen, his son, Adam, his stepdaughters, Abby Leigh and Betsy Karel, and the entire family. Martin Lipton, Chair NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU KIMMEL--Martin. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Adam, passed away peacefully on April 15, aged 92 years. The Manhattan Theater Club announced four productions for its 2008-9 season, two of them scheduled for the Biltmore Theater on Broadway. One is the premiere of ''To Be or Not to Be,'' a black comedy by Nick Whitby based on the 1942 Carole Lombard-Jack Benny movie of the same title, which will be directed by Casey Nicholaw. The other is an early Richard Greenbergplay, ''The American Plan,'' to be directed by David Grindley (''Journey's End''). MTC's Off Broadway theater, New York City Center Stage I, will present the premiere of ''Romantic Poetry,'' a musical by John Patrick Shanley and Henry Krieger,to be directed by Mr. Shanley; and ''Ruined,'' a new play by Lynn Nottage (''Intimate Apparel'') set in an African mining town. A third Biltmore production and two productions at New York New Yorkter Stage II will be announced later.

The Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, charged its financial director with embezzling more than $775,000, Agence France-Presse reported. The Guggenheim said that it filed the case against the director, Roberto Cearsolo Barrenetxea, ''for financial and accounting irregularities.'' In a statement the museum said he had admitted diverting money to his own account since 1998. He was fired on Tuesday.

The writers Robert A. Caro and Calvin Trillin are among eight newly elected members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. The other writers who will be inducted on May 21 are Kwame Anthony Appiah, Stephen Greenblatt, Paul Muldoon and Joy Williams. They will be joined by the artists John Baldessari and Ursula von Rydingsvard when Ezra Laderman, the president, presents more than 50 awards in architecture, art, literature and music at the academy, based in Manhattan. Richard Meier is to receive the organization's gold medal for architecture and Edmund S. Morgan its gold medal for history. Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will receive the award for distinguished service to the arts.

THE Hello Kitty fad that swept in from Japan decades ago is influencing the design of all sorts of home furnishings, but with a new attitude and an edge. Many of these products are by contemporary artists, and leading the pack is Takashi Murakami, whose exhibition, ''$; Murakami,'' is at the Brooklyn Museum through July 13, and whose production pieces are being sold in the museum shop. Chad Phillips, the director of creative development of Kidrobot, a chain of stores that carry cartoon-like objects for adults, offered an explanation. ''You think they're charming and adorable, and they are,'' he said. ''But look again. There is often something twisted or sinister in the imagery. That's what makes it different from Hello Kitty.''

GREENHALL--Armand, on April 14th, 2008, age 74. Loving son of the late of Sylvia May. He was very generous to many charities. A native New Yorker his entire life. He will be greatly missed by everyone.

"Sh'ma Yisrael," sang the choir at the Park East Synagogue in New York. "Hear O Israel," goes the ancient song, taken from the Book of Deuteronomy. "The Lord is our God, the Lord is One." Those sacred words have been sung countless times in the beautiful synagogue, which was founded by Austro-Hungarian Jews in 1890, on the East Side of Manhattan. But never in the presence of a pope.

I admire Pope Benedict, just as I admired his recent predecessors. As an evangelical Protestant, I don't believe in "papal authority." But I do see him as having an important pastoral role in the broader Christian community. In many ways and on many subjects, he speaks for me. So I pray for the success of this important visit to the United States.

When Pope Benedict XVI met with Catholic educators yesterday, he used the occasion to warn them of the limits of academic freedom in Catholic schools. "Any appeal to the principle of academic freedom in order to justify positions that contradict the faith and the teaching of the church would obstruct and even betray the university's identity and mission," he said.
Hillary Rodham Clinton added a new trio of superdelegates to her tally on Friday.

Pope Benedict probably went away happy from his meeting yesterday with Catholic educators. The educators probably went away happy, too. Naturally they applauded him at the beginning and the end - and spontaneously when he urged men and women in religious orders not to abandon their work in schools, especially in poorer areas. Many in the audience, after all, were priests, sisters and brothers who were doing exactly that work.

The pope's meeting on Thursday with the clergy sex abuse victims dominated the coverage yesterday and, as Peter Steinfels says, the event may turn out to be the most important moment of Benedict's trip. In this Sunday's Book Review - just in time for Earth Day! - there's a witty essay by Paul Greenberg comparing Ernest Callenbach's 1975 hippie-futurist classic "Ecotopia" (think: 20-hour work week, organic plastics, free love in redwoods) with the grimmer version of our collective future after the oil runs out in James Howard Kunstler's new novel "World Made by Hand" (think: globally warmed weather, backbreaking labor, sub-British dentistry).

Ah, the efficiency of America's film critics. Like clockwork, they produce a wealth of opinions on movie after movie, keeping citizens informed as they consider spending up to $35 for a ticket. If only the leading voices in the political world were as dependable.

Woody Allen has ended his film boycott of New York City, temporarily. After filming four consecutive movies in Europe, he has returned to his hometown to film his yet-unnamed comedy starring Larry David and Evan Rachel Wood. (The production offices are in Queens.)

When Citigroup unveiled a $5.1 billion loss on Friday, it wasn't unexpected. The banking giant has already raised more than $30 billion in capital in recent months, a necessary action given the more than $20 billion in losses it had announced before Friday.

When this little advance in polar-science research emerged on Thursday, it had Case In Point written all over it. A pair of studies published in the journal Science explain how a vast lake of meltwater could have vanished from the Greenland ice cap in less than 24 hours back in the summer of 2006. And that vanishing lake seems likely to take up residence among the anecdotes that all sides in the global-warming argument lob at one another.

Updated, 7:41 p.m. | Pope Benedict XVI paid a 22-minute visit to the Park East Synagogue -- the first papal trip to a United States synagogue -- on Friday afternoon. He presented the synagogue with a replica of a medieval Jewish manuscript from the Vatican library and received three gifts: a seder plate, a Passover haggadah and a box of matzo. The pope offered warm remarks and was showered with praise and music, but in a brief, three-minute address, he did not address the Holocaust, anti-Semitism or historic tensions between Jews and the Catholic Church.

Work, work, work. That was my adolescent take on growing up on a family farm in northwestern Indiana in the early '60s. Actually, it started even earlier; chores like feeding and watering the sheep and pigs were assigned to me when I as young as 8. Tractors came later, hours and hours from spring through fall. The first task was preparing the soil, plowing and discing; then planting corn or beans in rows; later cultivating (requiring exact driving so as not to cover up the young plants); finally, in the fall, combining the beans and picking the corn.

It seems as if some virtuoso is always leaving a Stradivarius in a yellow cab in this city. Then some good Samaritan returns the irreplaceable instrument and can be seen posing with the grateful musician in front of news cameras. So when I saw fliers pasted along Broadway last weekend -- "Found upright bass in black case" -- I called the number on the flier to get the story. I got a 64-year-old man named Manny Ramirez, who lives at 108th Street and Broadway in Manhattan.

One of the most interesting aspects of foreign soccer leagues is not the battle for the championship, it is the struggle to avoid relegation and the fight for spots in the lucrative UEFA Champions League that creates drama at the top, bottom and middle of the league tables. The promotion/relegation system keeps teams and fans engaged until the end.

Updated April 19 | A four-foot-long, approximately 40-pound beaver was pulled to safety at 12:45 p.m. from the West Channel of the East River by police harbor and scuba units. The special units were patrolling the United Nations in connection with the visit of Pope Benedict XVI and said the beaver appeared to be struggling to swim. [Update: The beaver died on the way to a wildlife medical specialist upstate.]Lt. John Harkins, the commanding officer of the scuba unit, said the animal was tilted unnaturally and showed "labored breathing," according to a New York Police Department statement.

"What is that?" a television commentator asked me about Benedict's white silk mozzetta, the ermine-trimmed half-cape that he wore before the Vespers service on Wednesday night at the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington. Afterward, the pope changed into a brocaded gold cope, the large cape used for vespers and benedictions, and was escorted down the aisle by two deacons, who held open his cope to reveal a rich red lining. Atop his head the pontiff sported a tall golden miter, and in his hand held a heavy gold processional cross.

The pope is making several of stops on the East Side of Manhattan today. It's warm and sunny, and the streets and parks are packed. This morning he started with a speech to the United Nations that defended global human rights as "based on the natural law inscribed on human hearts." There was not much in the way of specifics, but maybe one of our experts will have an observation or two. In the afternoon, Benedict is visiting the Park East Synagogue on East 67th Street - the first visit by a pope to an American synagogue. We'll hear more from Rabbi Rudin, who met personally with Benedict yesterday in Washington. But, first, Father Martin considers the papal wardrobe.

The main facade of the new Museum of Arts and Design, overlooking Columbus Circle, has fully emerged from its cocoon of scaffolding. Thin is not only for models; it's a trend in tables, too. At last year's Milan furniture fair, Bertjan Pot's wood-veneered Slim Table for Arco owed its svelte lines to a hidden metal structure. This year's winner in the skinny stakes uses carbon fiber as a reducing aid. The Surface Table - at Established & Sons, the no-longer-upstart British company that is making its impressive fourth showing in the Italian design capital - is a collaboration between the furniture designer Terence Woodgate and the pioneering Formula One race-car designer John Barnard (his F1 car for Ferrari is in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art). The table owes its gravity-defying three-meter length and its wafer-thin edges to a high-tech carbon fiber structure. Like all super-thin models, though, this one doesn't come cheap - and, at 25,000 British pounds, the only thing missing is an engine.

The Onion News Network, a video series produced by the Onion fake-news empire, made a low-key debut a year ago. A scandal over appropriations continues to plague Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker. After announcing dismal earnings and layoffs on Thursday, John A. Thain, still new to his role as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch, dialed onto a conference call with some of the bank's 16,660 financial advisers to answer tough questions.

Cuomo, has reportedly subpoenaed 18 banks that underwrote and brokered auction-rate securities, including Citigroup, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and UBS, as state regulators step up their inquiries into the securities and how Wall Street banks sold them to investors.

Since the credit squeeze has brought the market for initial public offerings to a near standstill, special purpose acquisition companies have been the one bright spot in the landscape for new offerings.

After The New York Times Company posted a $335,000 loss in the first quarter - one of the worst periods the company and the newspaper industry have seen - industry observers are betting that two activist hedge funds may ratchet up the pressure on the newspaper publisher.

PBS’s movie about Rudyard Kipling’s son is like a well-made hospital bed, all four corners too tightly tucked.

Those excited by the words “Zombie Strippers” alone won’t be disappointed by Jay Lee’s unabashedly schlocky film, which he wrote, directed, shot and edited.

A women-behind-bars plot seething with lesbianism, incest, hanging and catfights — on paper, at least, “Four Minutes” promises more fun than a Roger Corman marathon.
“Forgetting Sarah Marshall” does not entirely play by the established conventions of its genre.
There are a lot of horses but absolutely no sense in “The First Saturday in May,” a glib, lazy documentary about six trainers on the road to the 2006 Kentucky Derby.
One of the sleaziest documentaries to arrive in a very long time, “Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed” is a conspiracy-theory rant masquerading as investigative inquiry.
The serial killer in “Anamorph” shows promise, even if some of his best moves are derivative.
President Bush appointed Maj. Gen. Douglas O’Dell as the new Gulf Coast recovery chief.
A roadside bomb attack on Friday killed the son of the Netherlands’ top military officer, a day after his father took command of his country’s armed forces, officials said.
The move to ban polycarbonate infant bottles is the first action taken by any government against bisphenol-a, a chemical that has induced long-term changes in animals exposed to it.
The country’s agreement to allow American beef imports, was an indication of the eagerness of President Lee Myung-bak to mend ties with Washington.
A non-binding resolution seeks to put to rest any question about John McCain and that murky “natural born Citizen” clause.
Pope Benedict XVI told the United Nations that human rights should be the basis for ending war and poverty.
The results contained few surprises, and investors responded to the bank’s $5.1 billion loss by pushing markets sharply higher.
The Mets’ relief corps did not allow a run in seven innings Thursday for the third consecutive game, taking over for a solid Nelson Figueroa, and not letting up through the 14th inning.
Josh Beckett restored order to a cluttered Red Sox universe by silencing the Yankees and preserving a weary bullpen in a 7-5 victory.
Mr. Federici’s stylish work helped define the E Street Band’s sound on hits from “Hungry Heart” through “The Rising.”
The man charged with arranging for himself and his girlfriend to be shot in a staged robbery now says that he wanted to foil the attack seconds before it happened, but it was too late.
Manny Ramírez eclipsed the Yankees’ Lou Gehrig on the career home run list with his 494th in the second inning, then added another homer in the third en route to the Red Sox’ victory.

Davis Love III is back on top at Harbour Town. Love, the five-time tournament champion, shot a five-under-par 66 for a share of the first-round lead in the Verizon Heritage in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He is tied with Justin Leonard and Lucas Glover.

Lorena Ochoa got off to a solid start in a bid for her fourth consecutive victory and fifth in six starts this year. Playing for the fourth straight week, Ochoa shot a four-under 68 in the first round of the Ginn Open in Reunion, Fla., to finish a stroke behind the leaders, Carin Koch and Teresa Lu.

Steve McNair announced his retirement Thursday, ending a 13-year career in which he was selected the co-most valuable player, led the Tennessee Titans to the Super Bowl and orchestrated the most successful regular season in the Baltimore Ravens’ history.
Higher unemployment claims and weak readings from two economic indexes reinforced recession worries Thursday.
The managers’ raises were part of a compensation package that would grow considerably should the video game company be acquired by Electronic Arts.
The Boston Bruins worked hard to get a break and Carey Price gave a big one right to them.
Through each of Nelson Figueroa’s 101 pitches on Thursday night, 14 of his family members squeezed to the front of Billy Wagner’s box on the first-base side to live every moment.

A judge temporarily blocked Philadelphia from enforcing new gun-control ordinances until she heard a challenge from the National Rifle Association. The gun group argues that state law prevents Pennsylvania municipalities from regulating guns, a view that even Philadelphia’s district attorney shares. City lawyers posit that Philadelphia can pass gun-control ordinances if they are outside the scope of state measures. The judge, Jane Cutler Greenspan, scheduled arguments for April 28. Among other things, the five ordinances passed April 10 ban the sale of assault weapons, require owners to report a lost or stolen gun within 24 hours and limit firearms purchases to one a month. They came in response to the city’s one-a-day murder rate.

A judge has dismissed felony charges against two men accused of attacking Yale University singers in a 2007 New Year’s Eve brawl in San Francisco. The judge, Kathleen Kelly, dropped the felony charges against the men, Brian Dwyer and Richard Aicardi, both 20, on Wednesday, saying prosecutors lacked evidence. Judge Kelly dismissed all the charges against Mr. Dwyer and reduced the case against Mr. Aicardi to a single count of misdemeanor assault. Witnesses said that after the all-male a cappella group sang “The Star-Spangled Banner,” the attackers hurled anti-gay epithets and then beat and kicked some of the singers.

The authorities have charged a western Oklahoma sheriff with coercing and bribing female inmates so he could use them in a sex-slave operation run out of his jail. The sheriff, Mike Burgess of Custer County, resigned, just as state prosecutors filed 35 felony charges against him, including 14 counts of second-degree rape, seven counts of forcible oral sodomy and five counts of bribery by a public official. Mr. Burgess, the top officer in the county of 26,000 people since 1994, appeared in court and was released after posting $50,000 bail. Among other things, he is accused of having sex with a female drug court participant who was in his custody. The crimes are said to have occurred between October 2005 and April 2007. Mr. Burgess also faces two counts each of sexual battery, rape by instrumentation and subornation of perjury, and engaging in a pattern of criminal offenses, indecent exposure and kidnapping.

An agreement between the State of Montana, Yellowstone National Park and a private ranch will allow a small number of bison from the park to use a winter grazing area that had been off limits. As part of the agreement, Yellowstone will commit $1.5 million, with an additional amount that will be paid largely by conservation groups, to a 30-year lease for the ranch land north of the park. Record numbers of bison have been killed this winter as part of a culling effort to protect cattle from brucellosis, sometimes carried by the bison, and to keep bison from roaming outside the park. The culling has angered groups trying to protect bison and drew criticism in a Government Accountability Office report. State and park officials hope the additional land, more than 5,000 acres, will save bison and cattle. “This is a good day for bison, livestock, and Montana,” said Gov. Brian Schweitzer, above.

The Department of the Interior says it needs at least 10 more weeks to decide whether polar bears should be listed as threatened or endangered. Assistant Secretary Lyle Laverty replied to a lawsuit filed by three conservation groups. Mr. Laverty said the proposed listing raised “significant and complex factual and legal issues.” A decision had been due Jan. 9. Conservation groups petitioned to list polar bears as threatened more than three years ago because many scientists say their habitat, sea ice, is shrinking from global warming. Kassie Siegel, spokeswoman for the Center for Biological Diversity, said the request for more time should be rejected. Ms. Siegel said that the law required a decision by scientists, not lawyers, and that wildlife biologists had made their determination that polar bears needed additional protection.

A bill awaiting the South Carolina governor’s signature would require abortion providers to ask women whether they want to see ultrasound images of their fetuses before the procedure. As part of a legislative compromise, women must wait at least an hour after seeing an ultrasound to have an abortion. The governor, Mark Sanford, left, a Republican, has said he supports the bill generally but will review its specifics before deciding whether to sign it. Also, in Oklahoma, the Legislature voted to override Gov. Brad Henry’s veto of a bill that would require doctors to perform an ultrasound on a woman planning an abortion. Mr. Henry, a Democrat, said he thought it was “unconscionable” to require victims of rape and incest to undergo an ultrasound.

On Thursday, the hottest ticket in the Bronx — aside from the Yankees-Red Sox game being played a few blocks down 161st Street — may have been the scramble to get a decent seat in the Bronx Hall of Justice.
E*Trade Financial, the ailing online brokerage firm, posted its second consecutive quarterly loss on Thursday.
Shares in Nokia, the world’s largest maker of mobile phones, plunged more than 13.5 percent on Thursday after the company downgraded its forecast for the global handset market.
The Pulitzer jurists for this year’s poetry prize evidently felt the pain of Philip Schultz.
The House has backed a measure aimed at ensuring that students get college loans amid the turmoil in the credit markets.

The Bulls, who finished 11th in the Eastern Conference, fired their interim coach Jim Boylan. The Bulls, who won 49 games and reached the second round of the playoffs last season, were 33-49 this season. They were 24-32 with Boylan, who was promoted after Scott Skiles was fired in December.
Linens ’n Things, the troubled housewares and bedding chain, has hired Financo, an investment bank specializing in retail companies.
Kate O’Neill has run one marathon in her life. But at the United States Olympic trials for women on Sunday, she is hoping to qualify for Beijing.
The CIT Group, a commercial lender hit hard by the credit crisis, posted a quarterly loss Thursday.
The meeting made clear that a message concerning priestly abuse was central to Pope Benedict XVI’s visit.
United Technologies said Thursday that its first-quarter earnings rose 26 percent as the weak dollar bolstered profits throughout the business.
Officials are investigating whether the housing secretary, Alphonso R. Jackson, enriched himself and friends.

Nikki Caldwell, who assisted Pat Summit at Tennessee the past six seasons, was hired to coach U.C.L.A.’s women’s team. Caldwell, 35, is only the fifth women’s coach in U.C.L.A. history. She succeeds Kathy Olivier, who resigned last month after 15 years on the job. The Bruins were 16-15 last season.

Serena Williams set up a quarterfinal match against Maria Sharapova in the Family Circle Cup in Charleston, S.C., overcoming a sprained ankle and a sluggish performance to beat Katarina Srebotnik, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. The second-seeded Sharapova beat Taiana Perebiynis, 7-5, 6-2. Jelena Jankovic, the top seed, defeated unseeded Anastasia Rodionova, 6-0, 6-2. Jankovic will face ninth-seeded Vera Zvonareva.

U.C.L.A.’s all-American freshman Kevin Love and Brandon Rush and Darrell Arthur of N.C.A.A. champion Kansas announced Thursday that they would enter the N.B.A. draft. Love led the Bruins in scoring (17.5 points) and rebounds (10.6) on the way to a 35-win season. Rush, a 6-foot-6 junior guard, averaged 13.3 points, helping Kansas to its third national title. Arthur, a 6-9 sophomore forward, has not signed with an agent, meaning he can return to Kansas.

A development center being built in Oregon at Nike’s world headquarters is being named for C. Vivian Stringer, Rutgers women’s basketball coach. The 35,000-square-foot C. Vivian Stringer Child Development Center will open in June and house 26 classrooms, providing care, learning and development for 300 children. Stringer is the third woman, the second coach and the first African-American woman to have a building named after her on Nike’s campus.

The NFL Network filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission against Comcast in the latest legal wrangling between the sides. The NFL Network accused Comcast, the nation’s largest cable operator, of discriminatory and anticompetitive treatment in violation of the Cable Act of 1992. The sides have been feuding over Comcast’s decision to place the NFL Network on a premium sports tier for which customers must pay extra to receive. The NFL Network sued Comcast in October 2006 over the move.
The construction of a massive concrete wall is intended to turn the southern quarter of Sadr City near the Green Zone into a protected enclave.
The Internet’s potential for disgrace came into relief as Tricia Walsh Smith voiced her gripes on YouTube.
In interviews, 15 superdelegates said that they had not been persuaded much by the attacks on Barack Obama.
There are far too many important projects in New York City in need of the support and direction of a top-flight developer and negotiator.
The shrinking of hours and pay for millions of workers appears to be a bigger contributor to the economic decline than the loss of jobs.
Students at the Catholic University of America said Catholicism was an influence they sometimes welcomed and at other times strained against.
Congress has been too acquiescent, standing aside as the Bush administration undermined the constitutional system. It may finally be ready to act.
Wyoming should begin phasing out its elk feed grounds since chronic wasting disease poses a far more serious threat than brucellosis.
African leaders need to make clear to President Robert Mugabe’s cronies that any further effort to manipulate the election vote will be punished.
The Internet search giant on Thursday reported better-than-expected financial results for the first three months of the year, igniting a huge rally in the company shares.
Justice John Paul Stevens has revised his position on many issues during his tenure, but it is on the death penalty that his evolution is most apparent.

Officials of a nurses’ union in California, saying they had been threatened by members of a competing health care union, have obtained a court order barring the members from stalking and harassing them.
A seemingly mundane act of teenage roughhousing at Nyack Senior High School sparked an afternoon of gang violence in the picturesque village.
Prosecutors say the accused is a political extremist who acted deliberately, but that he is mentally ill, so they are not seeking the death penalty.
A spokesperson for the supermarket chain said that the virus for infectious salmon anemia, which does not pose a risk to humans, was affecting the size and taste of the fish.
About 100 lawyers participated in an emergency court hearing on the fate of 416 children taken by the state from a polygamist compound two weeks ago.
Howard D. Schultz, who recently took back control of the Starbucks coffee empire, wants to unravel his sale of the Seattle SuperSonics.
A form of flattery, Kevin Youkilis of the Red Sox is one of the players Yankees fans love to hate.
Going against the grain of top state Democrats, the Penn Dems, a student group with 3,258 members, endorsed Senator Barack Obama in the state’s primary.
The Bush administration appears to be preparing to back away from a demand that North Korea fully disclose all of its past nuclear weapons activities.
Some church sex abuse victims have largely ignored the pope’s visit and say they are dubious about his public pronouncements about how deeply he has been affected by the scandal.
Continental and Southwest, two of the healthiest major American carriers, said on Thursday that they would cut growth plans after record-high fuel costs led to disappointing quarterly earnings.
Chris Anthony, a standout wide receiver for the Arena Football League’s New York Dragons, plans to leave the league to attend medical school next fall.

City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn is facing a growing rebellion of council members for the way she responded to revelations about the Council’s appropriation of money to fictitious organizations.

Serbia said that it would extend its May 11 parliamentary and municipal elections to 16 Kosovo municipalities, including the capital, Pristina. The plan defies a United Nations warning against such a vote and ignores Kosovo’s declaration of independence. In the past, the United Nations has allowed Kosovo Serbs to vote in Serbia’s parliamentary and presidential elections, but local elections are seen as undermining international authorities because they deal directly with Kosovo’s internal municipal arrangements. There was no immediate comment from United Nations officials.

Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative party, the Christian Democrats, and the left-wing environmentalist Greens agreed to join forces to form a government coalition in Hamburg. The alliance could set a precedent, on the federal level as well, and become potentially a turning point in German politics. The accord was reached seven weeks after the Christian Democrats lost their majority in Hamburg, forcing them to seek a partner to remain in power. Despite the parties’ longstanding differences, Ole von Beust, the conservative mayor, decided to open negotiations with the Greens rather than ask his party’s traditional partner, the Social Democrats, to enter into a coalition, because, his aides said, of growing public disillusionment over how the so-called grand coalition of that party and his has performed on the federal stage. The Hamburg experiment will be watched closely by all the political parties as the countdown to federal elections next year starts in earnest.
A change to a 2005 bill reallocated $10 million for roadwork in Florida, reportedly to benefit a political contributor of Representative Don Young of Alaska.

A bomb exploded outside the office of Spain’s governing Socialist Party in Bilbao, the Basque region’s main city, wounding seven police officers after a warning call in the name of the Basque separatist group ETA. The early morning blast badly damaged the party office. The officers were helping to evacuate people and cordon off the zone. The Socialist prime minister, José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, beginning his second term, appealed last week to opposition conservatives to join him in a united front against ETA.
The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices posted its sixth consecutive quarterly loss on Thursday.

Court officials in Moscow say that Russia’s former nuclear energy minister, Yevgeny O. Adamov, has been released from prison. He was convicted in February of stealing millions in United States government funds earmarked for strengthening security at Russian nuclear plants and was sentenced to five and a half years in prison. A spokeswoman for the Moscow City Court said the court revised the sentence, giving Mr. Adamov a suspended sentence and setting him free. He was arrested in Switzerland and jailed for nearly six months in 2005 at the request of American prosecutors. But Russian officials, fearing he could reveal nuclear secrets, succeeded in having him sent to Russia to face trial on similar charges.

The government has shut down a prominent and outspoken newspaper catering to ethnic minority Indians. The paper’s news editor, B. R. Rajan, called the move punishment. The Tamil-language daily, Makkal Osai, or People’s Voice, provided wide coverage for the opposition party of Anwar Ibrahim and for activists who marshaled 20,000 ethnic Indians to protest last November against racial discrimination in Malaysia.

The top opposition leader, Raila Odinga, left, who claims to have won the presidential vote in December, was sworn into office as prime minister, fulfilling a main step in a power-sharing deal aimed at ending the violent political crisis that followed the deeply flawed election. More than 1,000 people died in fighting between allies of Mr. Odinga and President Mwai Kibaki, who was declared the winner. They agreed in February to share power but then wrangled over how to allocate cabinet posts. On Thursday, 40 cabinet ministers took up their positions, 20 from each camp. Mr. Kibaki’s party retained the finance and security ministries; Mr. Odinga’s allies will head up agriculture and oversee local government. The entire government, including Mr. Odinga, swore an oath of loyalty to the president.
The officers, their lawyers and courtroom onlookers in the Sean Bell case are sifting through the varying outcomes of similar cases in the past as they seek hints of what the future may hold.
Federal regulators plan to announce on Friday a legal settlement with executives over their roles in an accounting scandal that surfaced in 2004.
Despite all that preparation, draft-day decisions often come down to something trivial. Like a bathroom break.
10 home day care and foster homes had their licenses suspended after a state audit found evidence that convicted sex offenders might be residing in them.
Hours after reporting its worst results in years on Wednesday, JPMorgan Chase quietly disclosed plans to raise $6 billion in expensive debt.
Société Générale said late Thursday that Daniel Bouton will be succeeded by Frédéric Oudea as a deputy chief executive.
When the Yankees open a three-game series against the Orioles at Camden Yards on Friday night, many fans will come from out of town to cheer for the visiting team.
FRONT PAGE.

A summary in some editions on Thursday of an online article about Comcast’s decision to hire the veteran producer Mike Weisman to improve its national sports networks described the personnel move incorrectly. He was hired as a consultant; he was not hired “away from NBC,” where he remains under contract.

An article on Thursday about a $100 million donation from AT&T to fight the problem of high school dropouts misstated the time frame of a similarly large gift by Goldman, Sachs & Company this year to advance women’s business education. That donation will be given over a five-year period, not 10 years.

A review and a picture caption on Tuesday of Ballet Builders 2008, a program of dances by choreographers interested in the classical ballet canon, misstated the affiliation of the performers in “Pulling to Break.” They are freelancers, not members of North Carolina Dance Theater Two. (Members of that company danced the work’s premiere in 2006.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about efforts by state lawmakers across the country to pass new restrictions on guns referred imprecisely to the Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence. While it supports some firearms restrictions and enforcement of legal regulations on gun ownership, it is not an “antigun group.”.
An obituary on Thursday about Martin S. Kimmel, a developer of strip malls, misstated the relationship of one of his survivors. Abby Leigh is his stepdaughter, not his daughter.

An article on Wednesday about a Texas family’s pilgrimage to see Pope Benedict XVI misspelled the surname of a friend of the son, Ricky Pequeño, who was planning to see the papal Mass in Nationals Park on Thursday. She is Stephanie Zavala, not Zazala.

A picture on Tuesday with the Well column, about a new hearing aid that has been enthusiastically received by some patients, including Mike Waufle, the defensive line coach for the New York Giants, was published in error. It showed Peter Giunta, a Giants secondary coach — not Mr. Waufle.
Prince Fielder waited a long time for this one — 54 at-bats, in fact.
John A. Thain, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch, dialed onto a conference call with some of the bank’s 16,660 financial advisers to answer tough questions.
Three members of Congress want the Justice Department to investigate whether the Bowl Championship Series is an illegal enterprise.

The high-rise building under construction on the East Side where a crane collapse last month killed seven people did not conform with zoning regulations and was approved in error, the city’s buildings commissioner said.
The Pequeño family and a contingent of friends plunged into a furious schedule of pope-cheering in Washington D.C.
A New Orleans Mardi Gras trinket warehouse grew into an appreciated 24-hour grocery after Katrina, but local neighbors are unhappy at the prospect of liquor sales.
A computer science professor claims he accepted deportation in exchange for pleading guilty to one terrorism-related charge, but the government seeks further testimony in other cases.
José Reyes is back to being his jubilant self again, and he has abandoned his spring avowal to tone down his on-field exuberance.
An investigation found that a $50 million contract to promote the Thunderbirds aerial stunt team was tainted by improper influence and preferential treatment.

Jackie Walker, an all-American linebacker at the University of Tennessee, had faded from the record books, largely because he was gay. But on Sunday, he will become part of the Greater Knoxville Sports Hall of Fame.
Pfizer reported a worse-than-expected drop in quarterly earnings on Thursday.
Mr. Vogel’s care of an ailing friend, the novelist Joseph Heller, became the fodder for a darkly comic best-selling chronicle of a friendship, “No Laughing Matter.”
Federal authorities want to know the identity of a steroid distributor that José Canseco said he introduced to Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez.
Plum may become the new black for advertisers and media companies.
Rising prices for organic groceries are prompting some consumers to question their devotion to food produced without pesticides, chemical fertilizers or antibiotics.
The New York Times Company reported a $335,000 first-quarter loss on Thursday.
The Devils accused the Rangers of trying to knock their goalie, Martin Brodeur, off his game by literally knocking him off his game on Wednesday night.
The plant would be the first in the United States since 1973, and would be part of an effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the state.
The attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, has subpoenaed 18 banks that underwrote and brokered the investments.
Students will now be able to borrow a total of $31,000 though federal programs to pay for undergraduate education.
This year, the particular strain of influenza that predominated caught vaccine makers off guard, making flu shots less effective.
A disheartening number of new sins issued by the Vatican all but define New York City.
The Bank of England and the British government are considering actions that would mirror steps taken by the United States Fed to restore liquidity to the money markets.
The Bush administration has relied too heavily on Pakistan’s military to achieve its counterterrorism goals, according to a searing report by a government auditor.
Mr. Césaire was an anticolonialist poet and politician who was honored throughout the French-speaking world and who was an early proponent of black pride.
Mr. Zucker was a self-made billionaire who turned a small holding company into an empire that eventually bought the Hudson’s Bay Company of Canada.
British Prime Minister Gordon Brown met with the three senators vying for the presidency before going to the White House on Thursday.
A teller at a Lower East Side bank that the authorities say was robbed twice last year by a New York City police officer has confessed to being the officer’s accomplice.
It is called pitching backward, and Phil Hughes dislikes it.
A chorus girl in the 1940s and ’50s, Ms. Burton later started a talent agency that represented River and Joaquin Phoenix and Henry Thomas, the boy in “E.T.”
Representatives from Madison Square Garden and the Rangers met with gay advocacy groups to address concerns about anti-gay slurs.
Ms. Court was a British actress who began as a popular ingénue and became a cult figure as a “scream queen” in horror films on both sides of the Atlantic.
Giants General Manager Jerry Reese would like to know before the draft if defensive end Michael Strahan plans to retire, but he does not expect a decision that quickly.
The city’s jobless rate rose to 4.5 percent in March from 4.1 percent in February. The national jobless rate rose to 5.1 percent last month.
Mr. Humphrey’s innovative designs and building techniques helped increase the volume, sustaining power and projection of the classical guitar.
The C.I.A. said that a search of its records has found no evidence that it violated a judge’s order by destroying videotapes showing harsh interrogations.
Wall Street finished an erratic session mixed on Thursday after an uneven batch of earnings reports made investors cautious about buying stocks.
A ruling overturning the convictions of four businesses for having sold leavened bread during last year’s Passover has set off a debate over the country’s collective identity.
The producer Scott Rudin has made a seven-figure deal to acquire film rights to the new Philip Roth novel, “Indignation,” to be published by Houghton Mifflin in September, Variety reported.
In a shake-up that reflects the end of an era, Sony BMG Music said Thursday that the longtime industry executive Clive Davis would relinquish daily control of his label, the RCA Music Group.
Belgium celebrated on Thursday the golden anniversary of the Atomium, an aluminum and steel sphere that represents an iron atom magnified 165 billion times.
Laura Jacqmin, a 25-year-old Chicago playwright, is the recipient of the $25,000 Wasserstein Prize.
News about Second Stage, the Roundabout and a musical about Harry Houdini.
The producer Scott Rudin has made a seven-figure deal to acquire film rights to the new Philip Roth novel, “Indignation,” to be published by Houghton Mifflin in September, Variety reported.
The Italian Culture Ministry announced on Thursday the discovery of a late-second-century Roman sarcophagus on the outskirts of Rome.
An incident that has gone largely unpublicized in the West has crystallized the outrage and humiliation felt by many Chinese over recent protests against the Olympics.
US Airways pilots ousted their union, replacing it with an insurgent group, which raised questions about the airline’s ability to merge operations after its 2005 merger with America West.
About 2,300 members of the U.A.W. union went on strike at a G.M. plant in Michigan, halting production of three popular vehicles that have been bright spots in a dismal market.
Will the Romans someday take to Benedict XVI, as we did John Paul II?
Here is a selection of the approximately 70 record stores still open in Manhattan. Since 2003, at least 80 shops have closed in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Two friends traveling with the man, an Orthodox Jew, said that the prayer in question was a type that must be finished without interruption.
Artists are known to get itchy and move up the gallery food chain. Here are four notable new artist-dealer matches, ranging from grandiose to discreet.
Dan Flavin at Zwirner & Wirth, McDermott & McGough at Cheim & Read, Detroit at Nicholas Robinson Gallery and Peter Hujar at Matthew Marks.
President Bush and Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain expressed mounting impatience Thursday with Iran for proceeding with its nuclear enrichment work.
MOVIES.
FOR CHILDREN.
AROUND TOWN.
Selective listings from art critics of The New York Times.
Selective listings from theater critics of The New York Times.
“Velocity,” as seen on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, was a feast of evocative dances showcasing the subtle dramatic gifts of Horse, a charming dance troupe from Taiwan.
The Morgan Library is affording viewers a rare opportunity to study its copy of “Le Livre de la Chasse” and its lavish illustrations.
Andras Schiff performed cogent, vital readings of some of Beethoven’s 32 piano sonatas at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday.
“God’s Ear,” an arrestingly odd new play by Jenny Schwartz, is receiving a superbly realized production at the Vineyard Theater.
The jeweler Ralph O. Esmerian is scheduled to pay down a chunk of his Sotheby’s debt with his Edward Hicks painting, which is estimated at around $6 million to $8 million.
To the Editor:.
This weekend’s Green Apple Festival, which includes free concerts in eight cities, will feature a nontraditional lineup in the hopes of getting a younger audience.
The Green Apple Festival concerts will be held on Sunday in eight cities:.
To the Editor:.
Now added to the endangered species list in New York City: the neighborhood record store. But the survivors aren’t giving up just yet.
Olafur Eliasson’s work, as seen at both the Modern and at P.S. 1, is enchanting and intellectually stimulating, and reminds us how far in the current decade art has not come.
“Reflecting Antiquity” examines how archaeological discoveries inspired the glass industries of England, France, Italy and Germany in the 19th century.

A new book of documentary photographs, “Shelter,” examines a group of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender young people living, off and on, at a homeless shelter in Hell’s Kitchen — a group for whom growing up could hardly be more difficult. That the book is the product of a 27-year-old photographer who is gay, grew up in poverty and once lived in a homeless shelter himself explains its empathetic tone and morally urgent message.
“A Catered Affair,” the undramatic new musical drama of disappointed lives, is all pale, tasteful understatement that seems to be apologizing for asking for your attention.
Hu Jia, a prominent human rights advocate, missed the deadline to appeal a conviction after prison guards would not allow him to meet with his lawyer.
The Palestinian Authority’s foreign minister on Thursday offered an unusually bleak assessment of the negotiations with Israel.
A new exhibit at the New-York Historical Society offers an overview of the history of the Oriental-rug mystique in New York.
A hearing on the fate of 416 children taken from a polygamist compound recessed after 45 minutes of wrangling.
“Dargerism” at the American Folk Art Museum is enlightening: Seeing Henry Darger among other artists brings into focus what makes him so singular.
The private meeting with several victims of priestly abuse brought the pope face-to-face with a scandal that has left deep wounds in the American church.
A suicide bomber blew himself up outside a mosque in southwestern Afghanistan on Thursday, in an attack that the provincial governor said targeted police officials.
The event was so overshadowed by fears of anti-Chinese protests that no members of the public were allowed close enough to witness it.
Joshua Kendall's biography Peter Mark Roget, the creator of Roget's Thesaurus, suggests that his obsessive list making served as a bulwark against depression and mental instability.
Anthony E. Shorris’s resignation paves the way for a replacement to be named at the agency’s next board meeting on April 24.

Whew! A major matchup right off the bat in the N.B.A. playoffs: Suns vs. Spurs, starting Saturday in San Antonio. Who will win that matchup, who will win the West and can Boston or any team in the East challenge them?.
The detention of a high-profile Tibetan broadcaster suggests that the crackdown has not yet run its course.
A suicide bomber blew up a funeral gathering for the nephews of a prominent local American-backed Sunni chieftain in northern Iraq on Thursday.
The government accused the opposition of plotting to overthrow President Robert Mugabe, and South Africa toughened its position by calling for the release of election results.
Lee Kun-hee was charged with evading taxes on billions of dollars he had hidden in accounts under other names.

CLASSICAL.
A flagship residential resort on Providenciales Island in the Turks and Caicos, and an oceanfront whole- and fractional-ownership development in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico.
Because it’s in the heart of Texas Hill Country, Bandera draws a somewhat eclectic range of second-home owners and weekenders.
If you are going to transform your snow den into a summer retreat, you might want to think about a few changes to the look and to the layout.
“Harbor Springs is a quaint community, and from the beginning, we wanted to be sure our house fit in with the look.”
Iceland’s long economic boom has ended in a painful bust, with a collapsing currency, rising inflation, double-digit interest rates and predictions of its first recession since 1992.
Nalgene, the brand that popularized water bottles made from clear and nearly unbreakable polycarbonate, will stop using the plastic because of concern over one of its ingredients.
Global food prices are spiraling out of reach, sowing discontent and putting pressure on fragile governments.

The High & Low column last Friday, about North Carolina golf communities, misstated the location in South Carolina of Sea Pines, which is considered the first master-planned golf home community. It is in Hilton Head, not Myrtle Beach.

Furiously courting Democratic primary voters and apparently exhausted, Barack Obama has emerged as a more conventional politician and a more orthodox liberal.
Barack Obama’s “bitter” comments combined assertions about economics, sociology and voting behavior. In each case, his assertion was mostly if not entirely wrong.

"Don't drink the water!" and other advice still leaves travelers sick. Can a new drug help?
Research studies now recruiting patients.

Dr. David Freedman is a travel medicine specialist at the University of Alabama in Birmingham and a director of the GeoSentinel surveillance network, which uses research from six continents to track what travelers get sick from when visiting the far corners of the world. Here are some signs to look for, he says, to help determine whether common travel ailments may be harmless or more serious.
Dr. Phyllis Kozarsky on top health risks while hitting the road.

LONDIN--Barbara , born 1931 in NYC, died peacefully in her home surrounded by family. She is survived by her daughter Victoria (Richard), son Robert (Cara) and her grandchildren Sophie, Zoe, Joshua and Dillon as well as her brothers Mark and R. Anthony Goldman. Barbara, a lifelong New Yorker, was a painter, a producer of radio programs for WBAI, and an avid student of literature and history. Her creative and humanitarian contributions and her passion for the arts will be sorely missed. Services will be held Tuesday, April 22nd at 9:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations can be made to Heffer International.

LEIF OVE ANDSNES There are some performers whose personalities or eccentricities become inseparable from their music making. Then there are musicians who reveal themselves only through music. The brilliant, unassuming Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, above, falls into this category. Mr. Andsnes, 38, who grew up on an island off the west coast of Norway and won the prestigious Gilmore Artist Award in 1998, frequently demonstrates that he is a pianist of magisterial elegance, power and insight in repertory including Mozart, Schubert, Prokofiev and Bartok.

LEWIS--Loretta Varon , on April 15, 2008. Loving wife, sister, mother, ''Nona'' and friend. An acclaimed coloratura soprano, she provided great joy throughout her life to those who were touched by her beautiful voice. Loretta was born in NYC on December 2, 1928 to Julia and Benson Varon. Recognized early for her musical gift, she held her first recital when she was 12 years of age, and was accepted to and graduated from the High School of Music and Art. Although a dedicated wife and mother, Loretta was an accomplished artist with performances at Carnegie Hall, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and on radio and TV. During her singing career, she performed as the main soloist in such operas as the Marriage of Figaro, La Boheme, Aida, and Madame Butterfly, and sang in over seven languages. A woman of grace, style, elegance and substance, her passion for the arts was matched only by her love of family, gardening, interior design, sewing, cooking and travel. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Norman; sons and daughters-in-law, Jeffrey and Kaye; Peter and Wendy; and Kenneth and Lori; as well as her grandchildren Theodore, Alexander, Julia, Amy, Daniel, Eliza, Andrew, Nathaniel and Teddy; her sister Anita and Niece Julie. All of our lives are richer for having known her and her presence will shine brightly in our hearts forever. A gathering to celebrate her life will be announced shortly. Donations in her memory can be made to the Loretta Varon Lewis Scholarship in Voice at the Juilliard School, NYC, attention Ms. Karen Raven.

FOR CHILDREN ANCIENT GREEK FESTIVAL (Saturday through Thursday) Young students are invited to spend their spring vacations on Mt. Olympus, thanks to the Children's Museum of Manhattan. In addition to exploring the museum's 4,000-square-foot exhibition, ''Gods, Myths and Mortals: Discover Ancient Greece,'' a child's version of Homer's ''Odyssey,'' they can make masks of Greek gods, build models of temples and victory wreaths, see an Aesop's Fables puppet show and experience part of ancient Greece directly: its food. At the Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street, (212) 721-1223. Full schedule at cmom.org. All activities free with admission: $9; $6 for 65+; free for members.

MOSES--Henry . Prep for Prep mourns the passing of our longtime Trustee, friend, and advocate Henry C. Moses. During his 17-year tenure as Headmaster of Trinity School and Prep Trustee, Hank was a tireless partner in our work to create a more diverse generation of leaders. With Hank at the helm, nearly 200 Prep students of color received a superb Trinity education. For our students, alumni, and the wider world, he showed all the traits of true leadership. Our condolences go to his wife Missy and his children during this difficult time. Martin Lipton Chairman Emeritus John L. Vogelstein Chairman Anne Gilchrist Hall President And the Prep for Prep Board of Trustees MOSES--Henry C. The members of the New York Interschool Association deeply mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Henry C. Moses, a preeminent educator and the beloved Headmaster of Trinity School since 1991. Hank will be sorely missed for his vision, his wise counsel and his boundless enthusiasm for teaching and for helping young people reach their highest academic and personal potential. We are grateful for Hank's many contributions to education in New York and beyond. We extend our profound sympathies to his family on their loss. Stephanie J. Hull, The Brearley School Stephen M. Clement III, The Browning School Patricia T. Hayot, The Chapin School Lee Levison, Collegiate School Ellen C. Stein, The Dalton School Dorothy A. Hutcheson, The Nightingale-Bamford School Bodie Brizendine, The Spence School MOSES--Henry C. The Horace Mann School notes with deep sorrow the passing of Dr. Henry C. Moses, 27th Headmaster of the Trinity School. Visionary leader, outstanding headmaster, wonderful colleague, Henry Moses epitomized Trinity School's motto, ''Labore et Virtute'' -hard work and moral excellence -throughout his celebrated professional career and daily personal life. Dedicated to this ''high calling,'' he conducted his affairs with dignity, compassion, wisdom, kindness and humor. A beloved headmaster and intellectual scholar, he was a highly respected leader in the independent school community and among independent school heads. ''It was a privilege to have such an accomplished and principled individual in our midst,'' said Dr. Kelly, Head of Horace Mann. ''We mourn his loss. We celebrate his legacy.'' Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Mary Sarah Holland; his children; Laurence Holland, William Holland, James Moses, Bruce Moses, Paige Lewin, and to the rest of his devoted family. To the Editor: Re ''A Red Carpet for Gay Weddings'' (April 11): Lesbian and gay couples are not the only ones rewarding Massachusetts, Vermont and other states for their progressive stance on marriage equality. My wife and I chose to have our wedding in Cambridge, Mass., rather than in Atlanta, where we live, largely for that reason. As a heterosexual couple, we could have gotten married anywhere, but we wanted to use our wedding dollars to make a statement of sorts about this important civil-rights issue. Bryan L. Sells Atlanta

LYONS--John L. , of Greenwich, CT, age 85, died peacefully April 16th, 2008 after a long bout with Leukemia. He graduated from Yale and Annapolis in 1944. He served honorably during the war as a Lieutenant on the USS Maryland. He earned a Masters from both Northwestern U. and NYU. He lived and worked in Italy under the Marshall Plan, and in England for Time Inc. as head of PDI. Upon retirement from Time he setup the International Business curriculum at Pace U., where he taught for 25 years. John was active in community affairs in Greenwich including the Retired Men's Club. He is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Nancy Kelly Lyons, daughters Margaret and Anne, son Michael, their spouses Steven, Michael and Dawn, granddaughters Lilly and Emma and great-grandaughter Abigail. He was a proud Eagle Scout, so please make contributions in lieu of flowers to The Boy Scouts of America.

BOATHOUSE ROW is in Fairmount Park, along the Schuylkill River in Philadelphia. Kelly Drive, which winds along the shoreline in the park, is off Exit 340A (Kelly Drive/Lincoln Drive) of Interstate 76, the Schuylkill Expressway. Free curbside parking is available along Kelly Drive when boats are not racing. On days of large regattas like the Dad Vail and Stotesbury Cup, when access is more restricted, follow Kelly Drive to the police barricades and then follow signs to remote parking. Shuttles are provided, but the course is within walking distance of the parking lots. The Embassy Suites Hotel at 1776 Benjamin Franklin Parkway (215-561-1776; www.embassysuites.com; rates from $170 is about a mile walk to Boathouse Row. Other major hotels are two miles away from the boathouses in Center City, near City Hall. Some hotels offer packages in conjunction with the Dad Vail regatta (www.dadvail.org).

The image of the French daredevil Philippe Petit, dancing across a high wire between the twin towers of the World Trade Center in James Marsh's exhilarating documentary ''Man on Wire,'' is as rich a metaphor for the 2008 Tribeca Film Festival as you could imagine. On Aug. 7, 1974, Mr. Petit, then 24, tiptoed onto a cable suspended 1,350 feet above the ground and crossed it eight times in 45 minutes before the police forced him down. Peter Scarlet, the Tribeca festival's artistic director, describes Mr. Petit's feat as epitomizing the festival's precarious ''balancing of art and commerce.''

TREISMAN--Norman J. , on April 15, 2008, at age 71. Loving father of Joel and Jeffrey, beloved grandfather to Rachel, Maya and Jordana, loving friend of Mary Lee Calimano, and lifelong friend and trusted advisor to his first wife, Dorothy. He is remembered with love by his daughter-inlaw, Margie, his sister-in-law, Ling, and his niece, Joanne. He was a son of the late Bessie Treisman Strange and Hyman Treisman and brother of the late Jerome Treisman. Norman was born in Concord, NH and lived in Westchester and Manhattan for many years. He earned an undergraduate degree from Brandeis University and an MBA from the University of Chicago. He began his career in sales and marketing, joined the Sales Group of Philip Morris USA in 1964, and retired in 1993 as President, Philip Morris Capital Corp, the financial services subsidiary of Altria, Inc. After retiring, he became a savvy and successful private investor and was a trusted financial advisor to many friends and family members. He was an independent thinker, a die-hard fan of the Boston Red Sox and NY Giants, an avid tennis player, and he enjoyed singing in the shower. A memorial service will be held at noon, Monday, May 12, 2008 at the Lotos Club, 5 East 66th Street, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Joslin Diabetes Center, One Joslin Place, Suite 745, Boston, MA 02215.

THE NEW YORK COMIC CON For its third outing, this three-day celebration of all things comic books has moved from the chilly month of February to the more welcoming warmth of April. The better weather -- and the later start date -- has brought with it an even bigger Hollywood presence, thanks to this summer's vast selection of geek-friendly films. ''The History of Superhero Movies'' (Friday at 6 p.m.) is a panel discussion looking back at the costumed champions that have starred in cartoons, film serials and big-budget blockbusters. At 2 p.m. on Saturday, Universal Studios presents a look at ''Wanted,'' based on the comic about a wimp turned super-assassin, and a glimpse of ''Hellboy 2: The Golden Army,'' with scheduled appearances from its director, Guillermo del Toro, and stars, Ron Perlman and Selma Blair. An hour later, Universal and Marvel Studios offer a peek at ''The Incredible Hulk.'' And at 4:15, Lionsgate will show footage of ''Will Eisner's The Spirit'' (left, a poster), along with an appearance by the film's writer-director, Frank Miller, whose own comic book projects have included ''The Dark Knight Returns.''

'A (TOOTH) FAIRY TALE' Childhood often seems wonderful to people who have left it far behind. But those right in the middle of the experience don't necessarily share that perspective. Consider Samuel, a 10-year-old Upper West Sider. While some kids march to a different drummer, what he hears is more like an entire band. Samuel doesn't understand why you can't have a day of recess or leave for school through the window or turn that molar you've lost into wearable art. And therein hangs -- like an extremely loose tooth -- a tale. Determined not to surrender his molar for a quarter (it does seem cheap; this is, after all, Manhattan), Samuel accosts the Tooth Fairy. When she voices her own longings to be an ordinary New Yorker, Samuel offers to trade lives. (Sure, he's a boy, but flying is cool.) The fairy is thrilled, proclaiming that there's ''no other place where the people are as happy and well adjusted.'' Poor girl -- couldn't someone have shown her a Woody Allen movie?

AKRAM KHAN COMPANY As a solo dancer, Akram Khan seemed to absorb the space around him until there was nothing but him on the stage. That's not surprising, perhaps, in someone who began training at the age of 7 in the complex ancient North Indian dance form called Kathak. His choreography fused Kathak seamlessly with Western contemporary dance, winning him awards, international touring and the admiration of major dance figures in Europe like William Forsythe and Pina Bausch, all by his early 30s. But recent works have looked outward with a vengeance, in a trio of duets that were unlikely collaborations with a French ballerina (Sylvie Guillem), a Flemish-Moroccan former hip-hop dancer and choreographer (Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui) and this year with a French actress (Juliette Binoche). Memories of living in a teeming, disorderly larger world -- hanging from a tree as a child in his parents' native Bangladesh, smoking a cigarette on a Brooklyn fire escape as a teenager, and endless and sometimes dangerous border-crossing journeys as an adult -- have crowded in on Mr. Khan's work.

BRITS OFF BROADWAY For the fifth year, Elysabeth Kleinhans and Peter Tear, the artistic director and executive producer of 59E59 Theaters, have invited some inventive productions from Britain to take over their Midtown Manhattan theater complex for this annual program. This year's slate of eight productions includes three from Scottish companies and the festival's first musical. The Scottish playwright David Greig will be quite conspicuous in New York during the coming months: he has two entries in this festival, and in July his adaptation of ''The Bacchae'' will be part of the Lincoln Center Festival. (''The Bacchae,'' featuring Alan Cumming, comes from the National Theater of Scotland, the company behind ''Black Watch'' at St. Ann's Warehouse last fall.) Brits Off Broadway kicks off on Wednesday with Mr. Greig's ''Yellow Moon'' (with, above from left, Keith Macpherson, Nalini Chetty and Andrew Scott Ramsay). This coming-of-age drama about two teenagers on the run in the Scottish Highlands was presented by TAG Citizens Theater of Glasgow at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last summer, where it got several good reviews -- most of them referring to the lead couple as a modern-day Bonnie and Clyde. Subtitled ''The Ballad of Leila and Lee,'' Mr. Greig's play has a bit of ''Romeo and Juliet'' about it as well.

GREGORY CREWDSON With production credits to rival those of a James Cameron movie, Gregory Crewdson's photographs are elaborately contrived micro-epics. The final installment of his series ''Behind the Roses,'' the entirety of which has just been published in a single volume, is refreshingly low-key. In these pictures Mr. Crewdson pulls back a bit from the domestic environment, coaxing drama from the arrested development of New England suburbs. The photographs were shot in Rutland, Vt., and in North Adams and Pittsfield, Mass. (Several of Mr. Crewdson's massive soundstages were assembled at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art.) They are titled after different seasons, but the time of day -- twilight -- is a constant, as is the unremittingly bleak suburban architecture. Figures, seemingly lifted from Edward Hopper paintings, hover in doorways and driveways and on other thresholds. One woman stands outside in the snow with her arms pinned to her sides, staring at a screen door 10 feet away. A man, right, pauses in similar fashion beneath the movie-theater marquee on a small-town street, the traffic lights permanently set to yellow.

WEISS--Stephen H . The Trustees and staff of the National Humanities Center are deeply saddened by the death of Stephen H. Weiss on April 16. Stephen Weiss joined the Board of the National Humanities Center in 1996 and served as a Trustee until his retirement from the Board in 2005, when he was elected Trustee Emeritus. He was chairman of the Center's investment committee and a member of the executive committee of the Board. In 2006 he permanently endowed the Meyer H. Abrams Senior Fellowship, which is awarded annually by the Center to a distinguished literary scholar. All who knew Stephen Weiss at the National Humanities Center will gratefully remember his depth of judgment and generosity of spirit. Carl H. Pforzheimer III, Chairman, Geoffrey Harpham, President and Director, and members of the Board of Trustees. WEISS--Stephen. Dearest Suzanne, our deepest sympathy, heartfelt thoughts, prayers, and love are with you and your wonderful children at this very sad time and forever. We will miss Steve so very much. Richard and Diana Feldman WEISS--Stephen H. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Stephen H. Weiss. Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University, Counselor to the University President and a member of the Board of Trustees for 24 years, Steve championed the needs of Weill Cornell Medical College, where he served as the institution's first Chairman of the Board of Overseers in 1980. As a steadfast guardian of the institution, Steve oversaw the process of putting Weill Cornell at the forefront of education, cutting-edge biomedical research and unexcelled patient care. A committed Life Overseer and among the Medical College's most generous benefactors, Steve and his wife, Suzanne, endowed the Medical College's deanship in 1984. They have also supported many different clinical areas, with a special emphasis on cardiovascular medicine and the work of Dr. O. Wayne Isom, Chairman of the Department of Cardiothoracic Medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College. Generous with his time, energy, and good counsel, Steve's loyalty and genuine love for the institution serves as an example to us all. He will be sorely missed. On behalf of the Weill Cornell Medical College community, we extend our heartfelt sympathies to his dear wife, Suzanne, and his children Michael David, Jonathan, Natalie Christine and his stepdaughter, Heather. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Stephen and Suzanne Weiss Dean Weill Cornell Medical College Provost for Medical Affairs Cornell University Sanford I. Weill Chairman of the Board of Overseers Weill Cornell Medical College WEISS--Stephen H. Beloved husband of Suzanne Rogers, adored father of Heather, Michael, Jonny and Nathalie, cherished brother of Roger and step-sisters Barbara Stern and Jane Scheiber. Stephen, 72, a resident of Greenwich, CT, died April 16 in New York Hospital, of heart failure. He had a distinguished career as an investment banker, philanthropist and former chairman of the Cornell University Board of Trustees. Above all, he was devoted to his family. Mr. Weiss began his career at A.G. Becker & Co. where he served for 11 years, and was a vice president, shareholder and member of the board of directors. In 1970 he co-founded the investment management firm of Weiss, Peck & Greer, and was the firm's managing partner until the firm was sold in 2001. Most recently he was a managing director of the investment firm of Neuberger Berman, LLC. A 1957 graduate of Cornell University, Mr. Weiss was an enthusiastic and generous supporter of the University, and served on the Board of Trustees for 24 years. He was the board's chairman from 1989-1997. He was the first chairman of the Board of Overseers of the Cornell Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences. In 1980 he was named a Life Overseer. His affection for Cornell and his belief in the importance of education led him to serve on and chair many university committees. His activities at Cornell involved all aspects of the university, including serving on four presidential search committees. In 1984 he and his wife Suzanne endowed the deanship of the Weill Cornell Medical College. In 1992 he established the Stephen H. Weiss Presidential Fellows Awards to honor professors exhibiting an outstanding commitment to undergraduate education. A man of great energy and devotion to the community at large, Stephen was a board member of the National Humanities Center, and vice chairman of the Teagle Foundation. He was a member of the Citizens Budget Commission of New York City, and vice chairman of the Centurion Foundation. In 2000 he was appointed an honorary police commissioner of New York City. He also served on the Board of Visitors of California's School of Medicine, Davis, and was a member of the AACU's National Leadership Council for Liberal Education. Recently he was elected to serve on the Board of Tulane University. There will be a private funeral service for the immediate family. A memorial service at a future date will be announced. In lieu of flowers, those who wish to may send donations to: Cornell University, Attn: President David J. Skorton; or to Weill Cornell Medical College, Attn: Dr. O. Wayne Isom. WEISS--Stephen H., our partner in business for the past three years. His gracious presence, lively wit, never failing care for others, and astute judgement made our workplace better for all of us here. Tragically, he will be missed by every person who worked with him. Michael Kamen McGehee Porter Axel Schupf And all the members of our team

The High & Low column last Friday, about North Carolinagolf communities, misstated the location in South Carolina of Sea Pines, which is considered the first master-planned golf home community. It is in Hilton Head, not Myrtle Beach.

Some of my fellow bloggers have returned to the subject of the Pope's meeting with the presidents of 200 plus Catholic colleges and universities earlier this week. They justly argue that Benedict was not capable of defining with precision how to reconcile fidelity to the Magisterium with the great value of academic freedom.

It is difficult to find any Protestant leaders at the time of the Reformation in the 16th century saying anything nice at all about Roman Catholics. But here is one nice exception to the general trend: In a treatise entitled "The Right of Magistrates," Theodore Beza, an associate of John Calvin, attempted to bolster one of his arguments by claiming that the point he was making would be endorsed by "the more sensible part of those who call themselves Roman Catholics."

Earlier today, Colleen Carroll Campbell and Peter Steinfels looked at the statistics on young Catholics, and drew different conclusions on what they mean for the future of the church. And in delving into the pope's words at St. Patrick's Cathedral earlier this morning, both Father Martin and Amy Welborn were struck by Benedict's reference to himself as "a man with his faults" and to St. Peter "who also was a man with his flaws and his sins." Finally, if you're burning the midnight oil, check out Alejandro Bermudez's next entry: he challenges the view that the pope was not clear on the subject of intellectual freedom at Catholic colleges.

The ailing beaver that was pulled out of the East River by police scuba units on duty Friday for the pope's United Nations visit died a day later while being transported upstate for treatment by a wildlife medical specialist.Dr. Paul Howell, the owner and lead veterinarian at the hospital that treated the animal overnight, Animal General on the Upper West Side, said a vehicle was hired to transport it to the specialist in Utica, but it died en route.

Why is this night different than all other nights? Besides being the first night of Passover, it is the Red Bulls' only appearance on a Saturday night this season on TV in high-definition ... on HDNet. And because of the holiday, that is our vantage point for the match. The view was much better than watching from the nosebleed territory that is the press box at Giants Stadium.
Nationalistic messages calling for Chinese solidarity and the boycott of foreign goods  have spread like wildfire in Internet chat rooms.

April is the month for considering financial-aid offers from colleges and universities. This is not a typical year, however. Good news first: the trend toward no-loan packages at top colleges. Now, the bad: an economy in turmoil and more than 55 lenders withdrawing from the system of federally guaranteed student loans. Will there be trouble securing a loan? How do you compare aid packages? What is this thing called need, anyway?Five financial-aid directors - Sarah Clark Donahue of Harvard, Caesar T. Storlazzi of Yale, Kent McGowan of Buffalo State College (State University of New York), Ronald W. Johnson of the University of California, Los Angeles, and Jorge Rodriguez of St. John's University, in New York City - address reader questions, both personal and general, until April 22.
A look inside an American Airlines maintenance center where crews inspect and repair the carrier's fleet.

Today I got to swing Babe Ruth's bat. I imagine this must be like strumming Jimi Hendrix's guitar or painting with Michelangelo's brush. It was heavier than I'd use in a game, but lighter than I expected. The wood was warped a bit, so the bat curved from the handle to the end of the barrel. It was also notched, about seven times, for reasons unknown.
I was so looking forward to continuing my snacking "research", to include iced bubble tea, egg tarts, wonton soup-noodles, fried fish skin, dessert soups and other cheap culinary curiosities.
