In 1993 I witnessed the enthusiasm and fervor of hundreds of thousands of young Catholics who greeted Pope John Paul II at World Youth Day in Denver. For several days they rushed around downtown attending religious education sessions and other events. Finally they hiked to a nearby state park and stayed out all night for a glorious morning Mass celebrated by the Pope.

Aired Friday night on CBS: Hillary Clinton now says over the weekend that she's pro gun, likes guns, and loves to hunt ducks. Here is what Hillary likes to do on weekends. She likes to squat in a duck blind wearing a camouflage pantsuit.

On early Saturday afternoon, the Popemobile made its way up Fifth Avenue from St. Patrick's Cathedral to East 72nd Street. The pope's vehicle was flanked by scores of police and Secret Service officers and law enforcement vehicles.

Updated, 6:45 p.m. | YONKERS -- On the penultimate day of his visit to the United States, Pope Benedict XVI arrived at St. Joseph's Seminary here for a meeting with about 50 disabled youngsters, followed by a rally for about 26,000 young people on the grounds of the seminary. At the rally, the pope made reference to his own youth in Nazi Germany -- a regime that he said "banished God and thus became impervious to anything true and good." The pope spoke against relativism -- a longstanding stand of his theological teachings -- and urged the young to consider religious vocations.

The Brewers have raised eyebrows this season by regularly batting their pitcher eighth and Jason Kendall, the three-time All-Star catcher, ninth. The strategy, occasionally used by Tony La Russa and the Cardinals, has less to do with the pitcher than it does with the Brewers trying to get more batters on base for their power hitters.

Seeing Pope Benedict XVI riding in the popemobile around the warning track at Nationals Park on Thursday conjured up images of a bygone tradition when relief pitchers were ferried from the bullpen to the mound in golf carts, a Datsun, motorcycles with sidecars and even a tugboat on wheels.

One of the keys to the Phillies' late surge to the National League East championship last season was their ability to fill holes with support players when injuries cropped up. One of those players, outfielder Jayson Werth, is at it again for the Phillies, who are two games out of first despite losing Jimmy Rollins, the N.L.'s reigning most valuable player, and Shane Victorino, their starting center fielder.

The Blue Jays omitted Frank Thomas's name and .167 average from the middle of their order on Saturday. Thomas, below, who turns 40 next month, has not homered in 35 at-bats, and 4 of his 11 R.B.I. came on a grand slam. Matt Stairs, who is hitting .308, replaced Thomas as the designated hitter Saturday, and Scott Rolen could return from the disabled list in two weeks. Keep in mind, if Thomas gets 376 plate appearances, his $10 million option for 2009 is guaranteed.

So, I've got my Kindle! I quickly used it to download Alan Furst's The Foreign Correspondent, which I unaccountably missed when it came out.* I'm only a little way in, but first reactions:

It happens every time the pope encounters a young crowd, and it is happening again at the papal youth rally in Yonkers: Young Catholics will turn out in droves to give Pope Benedict a warm, rock-star welcome. And many of their elders will watch and wonder: What do they see in him?
Times columnist George Vecsey examines L'Affaire Avery in the context of the greater sporting world.

Kyle Farnsworth said his pitch behind Manny Ramirez's head "just slipped" on Thursday. Major League Baseball disagreed, suspending Farnsworth today for three games. Farnsworth will appeal the punishment and we'll see him down in the locker room shortly.
Pope Benedict XVI called for a "new spring" in a divided church during Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the symbolic seat of American Catholicism.

Many of those thousands who came to see Pope Benedict XVI as he headed up Fifth Avenue in the Popemobile after the Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral spoke about investing significant expense and travel time to be there. Then there were those who were there by accident - and, in fact, did not want to be there at all.

When Jose Reyes of the Mets slid into second base on Friday night, his head smashed into Chase Utley's knee. Reyes lifted his left hand to call a timeout, but he did not stand up. As Reyes lay in the dirt, the notorious Phillies fans cheered. Mets Manager Willie Randolph called it a disturbing display.

After posting a potentially nasty fingerpointing jab at the IRL below I suddenly felt a tinge of remorse. How dare I laugh at the shaky situation in the IRL and former Champ Car? Is Formula One itself not in something of a precarious position because of the Max Mosley affair?

Benedict XVI today became the first pope to celebrate mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. I'm guessing he is also the first pope to refer to Nathaniel Hawthorne (though I could be wrong, since Hawthorne's youngest daughter, who became a nun, has been officially proposed as a candidate for sainthood by Cardinal Edward Egan). In referring to the cathedral's majestic windows, Benedict said: "Writers - here in America we can think of Nathaniel Hawthorne - have used the image of stained glass to illustrate the mystery of the Church herself."

The Twin Ring Motegi Long Beach Grand Prix. Something like that, anyway. That's the curious weekend the two Indy racing series are hosting this weekend. Remember, Champ Car no longer exists. This isn't the first time we've had a simultaneous runup in the prices of oil, food, and many other commodities. The great commodity boom of 1972-75 was, if anything, bigger. And there are extraordinary parallels with current events: it was an energy crisis, but there was also a world food crisis, and prices of metals also soared.

Pope Benedict XVI spoke yesterday at the United Nations of the responsibility of every government to protect human rights. He emphasized the importance of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as key to the safeguarding of human dignity, insisting that such rights are founded on the essential nature of the human persons, and not simply legislative enactment.

My Sunday column is about climate change, and it was inspired in part by an important article in Nature this month. For those interested in reading more, the present cover story of Time magazine is about climate change, as is the latest issue of Mother Jones.

As the presumptive Republican nominee, Senator John McCain does not have to compete in the Pennsylvania primary (in which not everyone engaged is voting). But he does plan to be competitive in the lately blue state during the general election -- and in nearly two dozen other states. His campaign hopes to broaden the field of up-for-grabs states to try to capture some that Senator John Kerry took in 2004.

Updated, 1:45 p.m. | Shortly after 1:20 p.m, the Popemobile turned onto Fifth Avenue near St. Patrick's Cathedral. Preceded by policemen on motorcycles and accompanied by a procession of Secret Service agents and New York City police officers, it made its way up Fifth Avenue toward 72nd Street. (Traffic on the avenue usually goes in one direction the other way, downtown.) Helicopters flew overhead and counter-snipers were positioned on every building within site of the cathedral along Fifth Avenue. As the Popemobile drove by, with Pope Benedict XVI waving, the crowd cheered. A sea of hands rose -- many of them holding digital cameras and cellphone cameras.Further up Fifth Avenue near the Plaza Hotel, Corey Kilgannon of City Room used a Wi-Fi camera to capture video of the pope in his vehicle and the crowd's reaction. Here are a couple of the clips. (See the bottom of this blog post for further explanation of this experiment.)
Images from the small-paintings exhibitions in Manhattan.

The third meeting of the world's "major economies," in White House parlance -- or biggest emitters of greenhouse gases, by another measure -- concluded Friday evening in Paris. But deep divisions persisted over how to set a long-term global goal for cutting emissions and what to expect from individual countries in charting their own paths toward achieving such a goal later in the century.

Shaila Dewan of The Times had a fascinating article about Grace Wang, a Chinese student at Duke University who tried to encourage dialogue between pro-Tibet protesters and pro-China protesters. Grace is from China, and bloggers there perceived her as betraying her country and siding with Tibetan independence. The result was a nationalist explosion on the Chinese web, with people posting her parents' home address and comments that came across as threatening. Her parents abandoned their home for reasons of safety.

PHILADELPHIA -- Senator Barack Obama drew what may be his biggest crowd yet here Friday. His campaign, quoting Frank Friel, director of security at the Independence Visitor Center, pegged the number at 35,000.

The New York Knicks have fired Isiah Thomas as head coach of the N.B.A. team, club president Donnie Walsh announced on Friday.
Following is the prepared text of Pope Benedict XVI’s remarks at an April 19 rally for about 26,000 youths at St. Joseph’s Seminary and College in Yonkers, N.Y., as supplied by the Vatican.
Sears Holdings said on Friday that a credit agreement with Bank of America would come to an end after the bank would not agree to renew it under existing terms.
Despite a blockbuster year in which Amazon.com’s profit more than doubled, compensation for its chief executive officer, Jeffrey P. Bezos, was unchanged from the previous year.
Trian Partners, an investment company controlled by the billionaire Nelson Peltz, said in a regulatory filing Friday that Wendy’s International had rejected two offers to be purchased.
The American buyout group J. C. Flowers has formally withdrawn its £3.5 billion ($7 billion) pursuit of the British life insurer Friends Provident.
The American oil field services company Halliburton said on Friday that it was considering a counterbid for the Expro International Group of Britain.

Schlumberger, the world’s largest oil field services company, reported a nearly 14 percent rise in first-quarter income Friday, but results missed Wall Street forecasts and were seen as largely lackluster.
Honeywell International, the world’s largest maker of airplane controls, posted a 22 percent gain in first-quarter earnings on Friday.
Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida opposed a federal proposal allowing Georgia to keep more water during droughts that would otherwise had flowed into his state.
A federal judge has denied a bid by a Florida deep-sea exploration company to keep secret the details of a 19th-century shipwreck that has yielded $500 million in treasure.
The political fund-raiser Antoin Rezko was freed on an $8.5 million bond pending the outcome of his trial on charges of plotting to obtain kickbacks from companies seeking state business.
An animal rights group is not giving up on blocking the government and two states from harming California sea lions that are feasting on the spring chinook salmon run at a dam on the Columbia River.

Sam Hornish Jr. said he would pass on the Indianapolis 500. His plans were the subject of much speculation after the owner Roger Penske entered a No. 77 car in the Indy 500 and did not say who would drive it.
Starter Phil Hughes showed improvement before unraveling in the sixth inning, as the Yankees starting pitchers continue to show no signs that they can carry the team very far.
A 61-year-old Connecticut man has been charged with sexual abuse after following three children into two public bathrooms in Brooklyn on Thursday and molesting them.
The Rangers scored three goals in the first period and held off a furious comeback in the second on Friday to eliminate the Devils.
Including the regular season, the Devils lost 11 of 13 games to the Rangers, who seemed to have a gear the Devils did not.
Johan Santana pitched seven sparkling innings on Friday, outshining the National League’s other premier left-handed starter, Cole Hamels.
As Johan Santana acclimates himself to the National League, he is relying on catcher Brian Schneider to shepherd him.

An article on the Street Scene page on Friday about JPMorgan Chase’s plans to raise $6 billion in additional capital misspelled the surname of its chief financial officer in some editions. He is Michael J. Cavanagh, not Cavanaugh.
NATIONAL.

An article on Wednesday about President Bush’s plan to lay out specific goals for limiting greenhouse gases misstated a short-term goal for such gases that Mr. Bush announced in 2002. He called for an 18 percent reduction of growth in emissions relative to economic growth by 2012, not a reduction of overall emissions by 18 percent.

A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about forecasting hurricanes by using undersea microphones misstated the surname in one reference for an author of the research. He is Joshua D. Wilson, not “Dr. Johnson.”.

The About New York column in some editions on Wednesday, about Ruth Proskauer Smith, a centenarian who teaches a class on the Supreme Court through Quest, an educational organization for retirees, misstated the group’s Web address. It is questonline.org.

An article in some editions on March 3 about an uproar among Orthodox Jews over the cancellation of a New York concert that was to feature a popular Hasidic entertainer misspelled the surname of a Brooklyn rabbi who mobilized opposition to the concert. He is Avraham Schorr, not Shor. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message this week.

The Weekend in New York column on Page 11 of the Travel section this weekend, about finding places in the city that evoke Europe, carries an outdated reference to the restaurant Provence in Greenwich Village. After the article went to press on Monday the restaurant announced that it is closing on Sunday. (The owners will reopen the restaurant in May as Hundred Acres, with a rustic, farm-focused menu.).

Alliance Data Systems, the credit card processor, sued the Blackstone Group in New York State court late Friday, accusing the private equity firm of breaching its agreement to buy the company for $6.4 billion.

An article on April 1 about the weather-related decision to move the opening-day game at Yankee Stadium to the next night gave an incorrect number from the Yankees for previous nighttime openers at the Stadium. It was at least two, not one. (Besides the 2005 night opener noted in the article, another was in 1972.).

An article on April 4 about a disclosure by Speaker Christine C. Quinn that the New York City Council had been appropriating city funds to nonexistent organizations misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a top finance staffer for Ms. Quinn who has since left her office. And a correction in this space on April 9 also misspelled it. He is Michael Keogh, not Keough or Keoug.

An article on Thursday about the indictments of two New York City Council aides on charges of embezzling funds from a nonprofit agency, and a related federal investigation into the Council’s practice of appropriating discretionary funds to nonexistent organizations, misspelled the surname of a Bronx councilman who attended a briefing about the inquiry with private lawyers hired by the Council. He is G. Oliver Koppell, not Koppel.

The Talking Business column last Saturday, about China’s efforts to develop popular brands, referred incorrectly in one instance to Chiang Jeongwen, a marketing professor who commented on the effort. He is Mr. Chiang, not Mr. Jeongwen.
The Knicks and the Minnesota Timberwolves won tie breakers Friday, increasing their chances of picking higher in the N.B.A. draft in June.
A top official suggested that the Roman Catholic Church is considering changes related to the statute of limitations on child sexual abuse.
Critics say Senator John McCain’s descriptions of the enemy in Iraq oversimplify its hydra-headed nature.
A Texas judge ordered that children seized in the raid of a polygamist religious sect stay in protective custody.
Some students had job offers rescinded, leaving them to confront one of the worst financial job markets in years.
Speaker Christine Quinn must do a lot more to ensure that New York City funds will not be waylaid for private or political use.
Joseph Dion, a Miami-based trainer, denied Jose Canseco’s implications that Dion helped Alex Rodriguez use steroids in the late 1990s.
A crackdown is intended to send a message that the government is serious about protecting the rain forest.
The Federal Aviation Administration deserves much of the blame for canceled flights, American Airlines says.
Senator John McCain’s political advisers said Friday that they believed his potential appeal to independents could make him competitive in up to two dozen toss-up states.
As Congress prepares to debate President Bush’s request for $108 billion for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, lawmakers are demanding that Iraq pay a larger share of the costs.

The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission is looking into the possible health hazards of lead in artificial turf installed at schools, parks and stadiums across the country. Two fields in New Jersey were closed this week after state health officials detected what they said were unexpectedly high levels of lead in the synthetic turf, raising fears that athletes could swallow or inhale fibers or dust from the playing surface.
The SuperSonics will pay the league $30 million to move to Oklahoma City pending the resolution of litigation that was intended to keep the team in Seattle.

The defending champion, Tom Watson, shot an eight-under 63 to take a three-stroke lead over Mark Wiebe and David Eger after the first round of the Outback Steakhouse Pro-Am in Lutz, Fla. Watson, 58, shot a seven-under 28 on his last nine holes, the front nine of the T.P.C. Tampa Bay, missing two birdie putts — a 12-footer on No. 2 and a 20-footer on No. 8.

Chris Douglas-Roberts, an all-American guard at Memphis, will enter the N.B.A. draft, joining his teammate Derrick Rose as an early entry to the pros, the university announced. Douglas-Roberts led the Tigers with 18.1 points a game as a junior and helped them set a Division I record with 38 victories. He was picked for the N.C.A.A. all-tournament team after Memphis lost the championship game to Kansas, 75-68, in overtime.

Lucas Glover shot his second consecutive 66, moving to 10 under, and took a one-stroke lead over the defending champion, Boo Weekley (64), in the Verizon Heritage at Harbour Town Golf Links on Hilton Head Island. Anthony Kim (67) was alone in third at eight under, with Stewart Cink (68), Cliff Kresge (66), and Stephen Ames (64) another shot behind.

Rape charges, and all others, were dropped against the former Penn State running back Austin Scott. The decision came after Pennsylvania’s Superior Court ruled earlier in the day that jurors could hear testimony about the accuser’s involvement in a separate sexual assault case in 2003. The defendant in that case was acquitted. The Centre County district attorney’s office said it withdrew the charges because there was “no reasonable likelihood” it could meet the burden of proof. Scott, 23, was suspended Oct. 5 by Coach Joe Paterno and missed the rest of his senior season.

Serena Williams extended her winning streak over Maria Sharapova with a 7-5, 4-6, 6-1 victory, advancing to the Family Circle Cup semifinals in Charleston, S.C. Williams has defeated Sharapova four consecutive times since 2005 and is 5-2 over all against her. Sharapova had won her first clay-tournament title last week at Amelia Island.

The kayaker Carrie Johnson clinched a spot in this summer’s Beijing Games by winning a 500-meter qualifying race at the United States Olympic Trials in Oklahoma City. Johnson led throughout the race, beating Maggie Hogan by more than two boat lengths. Johnson, who made her Olympic debut four years ago in Athens, finished in 2 minutes 13.978 seconds.

Lorena Ochoa, who is trying to win her fourth consecutive tournament, shot a five-under-par 67 on Friday in the second round of the Ginn Open at Reunion, Fla. Leaders of the Writers Guild of America East and the Writers Guild of America West settled a score with 28 writers who abandoned their guild status during the three-month writers’ strike by publishing their names on a pair of guild Web sites. In a letter sent to members on Friday, Patric M. Verrone, president of the West Coast guild, and Michael Winship, his East Coast counterpart, said those who deserted during the strike by adopting financial core status “should not share in our victory.” (Those who elect financial core status in a union can work under its contract, but do not participate in its elections or other activities.) Almost all the writers named have worked on soap operas, including “The Bold and the Beautiful” and “Days of Our Lives.” The 21 western members were publicly listed on the Writers Guild of America West Web site (wga.org). The East Coast guild disclosed names of seven writers who adopted financial core status in a portion of its site available only to members, a spokeswoman said.

A Yale University art student’s startling claim that she artificially inseminated herself, induced repeated abortions and used the blood for her senior project is false, Yale officials said after her account was published in the student newspaper, The Associated Press reported. In an article on Thursday in The Yale Daily News, the student, Aliza Shvarts, was quoted as saying she had inseminated herself “as often as possible” while taking herbal drugs to induce miscarriages as her senior year performance art piece. Her account found its way to the Internet and news outlets before Yale said it had investigated and found it to be false. “The entire project is an art piece, a creative fiction designed to draw attention to the ambiguity surrounding form and function of a woman’s body,” said Helaine Klasky, a university spokeswoman. Ms. Klasky said that when confronted by three Yale officials, Ms. Shvarts acknowledged that she had never been pregnant and did not induce abortions. On Friday, however, Ms. Shvarts had insisted that she had really experienced “repeated, self-induced miscarriages,” although she had said that she had never known if she was actually pregnant. Ms. Klasky responded that the university had expected her to maintain her story: “She said if Yale puts out a statement saying she did not do this, she would say Yale was doing that to protect its reputation.” In Friday’s Yale Daily News, Ms. Shvarts said she planned to display a work that consisted of a cube lined with plastic sheets, with a mixture of blood and petroleum jelly in between, onto which she would project video footage of herself “experiencing miscarriages in her bathroom tub.” Andrew Mangino, the editor in chief of the Yale Daily News, said the newspaper had published the article after receiving a news release about the project. The Associated Press said it was unable to reach Ms. Shvarts for further comme

CBS earned the most viewers on Thursday, thanks partly to “Survivor,” the most-watched show of the night, with 12.1 million viewers at 8, Nielsen estimated. Afterward, repeats of “CSI” at 9 (10.7 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 (9.1 million) extended CBS’s lead. Among adults 18 to 49, CBS was runner-up to NBC, which took that demographic from 9 to 11 with “The Office,” followed by “Scrubs” and “ER.” "The Office" was the night’s top-rated show among those 18 to 49. Fox ranked third in that age group and second in total viewers, with “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” at 8 (9.2 million) and “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” at 9 (9.5 million). ABC was fourth over all.

Lawrence B. Salander, a prominent Manhattan art dealer, suffered a defeat in a Poughkeepsie, N.Y., court when he and his wife, Julie, were ordered to cede control of their finances to an independent trustee, Bloomberg News reported. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Cecelia G. Morris approved a motion brought by lawyers for the Justice Department to convert the Salanders’ case from a Chapter 11 reorganization to a Chapter 7 liquidation, in which a trustee sells everything except “exempt assets.” The Salanders opposed the motion. Eric Small, a Justice Department lawyer, said that since the Salanders filed for bankruptcy protection in November, they had been slow to sell assets and quick to accumulate new debt. Mr. Salander ran the Salander-O’Reilly Galleries on the Upper East Side. By the time he filed for bankruptcy, complaints were mounting from people who said they had consigned artworks to the gallery but were never paid for them. Mr. Salander has denied any wrongdoing.

Leslie Moonves, below, the chairman of CBS, and Sean McManus, the president of CBS News, made a surprise visit to the regular noon meeting at CBS News headquarters on Friday and delivered pep talks to the news division, which has endured a week of reports of uncertainty about the future of Katie Couric, the anchor of the network’s nightly news. “The genesis was, both were getting frustrated with everything being written about CBS News,” said one executive who attended the meeting and asked not to be named because the meeting was intended to be off the record. Mr. Moonves was “very forceful,” the executive said, quoting him as saying that he “could not be happier with the content of CBS News and with the ‘Evening News’ anchor” and that Ms. Couric would be the anchor “today, tomorrow and in the future,” while acknowledging that the ratings for the evening newscast were “very frustrating.” CBS executives held a meeting in February to discuss possible changes in Ms. Couric’s role, but the executive who was at the meeting said no decisions would be made until after the presidential election. Ms. Couric also addressed the meeting and thanked the staff for working hard despite the rumors, specifically thanking the London bureau for setting up an exclusive interview with the prime minister of Britain, Gordon Brown. Mr. Manus was also “looking to buck people up,” the executive said, and emphasized that there was no better news division than CBS’s.

Ryan Phillippe, above left with Mr. Cooper, is Eric O’Neill, a young agent in training who brought down Mr. Hanssen in February 2001 after investigating him for sexual deviance. MOSES--Henry C . We mourn the untimely death of our beloved Hank, such a caring friend to our family. His persona embodied decency, fairness and strength; and the twinkle in his eye prepared you for his sharp wit. We express our heartfelt condolences to his dear wife, Missy, to his family and to Trinity. Sylvia, David, Rachel, Raphael & Courtney Posner MOSES--Henry C. The students, staff, alumni, and trustees of Trinity School mourn the death of Henry C. Moses, our beloved headmaster since 1991. Hank was a passionate, inspiring, and visionary leader who loved Trinity School. His 17 years as headmaster brought Trinity to a position of preeminence among independent schools in New York and throughout the nation. Each of us who has known him, learned from him, and worked with him is the greater for it. He was an example to all of us of Trinity's motto, Labore et Virtute, and we dedicate ourselves to honoring his memory by striving always to live out that high calling to ''hard work and moral excellence.'' To his wife, Mary Sarah Holland, sons Laurence Holland, William Holland, James Moses, Bruce Moses, and daughter Paige Lewin, and all his family we extend deepest sympathy and our love. The Trustees of Trinity School Andrew R. Brownstein, President MOSES--Henry C. We mourn the passing of our beloved teacher and friend, Hank Moses. Hank lived with passion and energy. He was an inspirational leader. Our sincerest condolences extend to Missy Holland and Hank's entire family. Elise, Andrew, Julia and Alex Brownstein

The last vestiges of Isiah Thomas's authority were stripped away Friday afternoon, freeing the Knicks to begin fixing the mess he left behind. Donnie Walsh fired Thomas as coach, two weeks after supplanting him as team president. Thomas will remain with the team as a personal adviser to Walsh, but with no title and no authority.

As Gil Brandt, the NFL.com analyst, said about this year's draft, ''There are so many guys who all look alike.'' That means that this is a deep class, chock full of talent through about two rounds. That is especially good news for a team like Atlanta, which has multiple picks in the early rounds and just as many needs to fill. But most draft analysts think this group lacks immediate-impact players like tackle Joe Thomas, who became a Pro Bowler for Cleveland as a rookie, and running back Adrian Peterson, who electrified the N.F.L. for the Vikings. After Boston College's Matt Ryan, it may not even have another first-round quarterback. The biggest name in this draft could be running back Darren McFadden. He is gifted and fast, but he may be best known for off-the-field issues that could make some teams skittish. That means lots of teams near the top will be happy to trade down to avoid paying the exorbitant guaranteed money commanded by those at the head of the draft. The problem is that the absence of a slam-dunk top pick also means they will find few takers. Here is a look at the first round, with each team's needs. 1. Miami Bill Parcells is the wild card of the draft. The Dolphins have many needs everywhere and he is said to be negotiating with at least one of the top few players to try to pound out a below-market deal before the draft. Offensive tackle Jake Long may be his favorite -- although General Manager Jeff Ireland's slip of the tongue at a news conference might have inadvertently revealed a preference for defense. In that case, it could be a linebacker/end, Chris Long or Vernon Gholston. 2. St. Louis The Rams need help along both lines. Chris Long would fit the bill and, because of his Hall of Fame pedigree, is the safest pick in the draft. 3. Atlanta The Falcons need just about everything, and Mike Smith, the new head coach, is a defensive mind. But has any team ever needed a quarterback -- one with no baggage -- more than the Falcons? 4. Oakland The Raiders' defense is weak, but they could also relieve some pressure on JaMarcus Russell with a powerful running game. Will Al Davis be able to resist the game-breaking allure of Darren McFadden? 5. Kansas City The Chiefs need plenty, especially on offense (which turned into a disaster last season) and on an aging defense. The offensive line needs starters now, but if Matt Ryan is available, the Chiefs will have a hard time passing him to take over for Brodie Croyle. 6. Jets If all of their big acquisitions in free agency pan out, the Jets will have addressed almost all of their significant needs, although another pass rusher or a big playmaker on offense would be nice. 7. New England After losing Asante Samuel and Randall Gay in free agency, the Patriots need cornerbacks. And they could use another infusion of youth at linebacker. 8. Baltimore Steve McNair retired on Thursday, continuing the Ravens' never-ending quest for a quarterback. 9. Cincinnati The middle of the defense is trouble for the Bengals, from the line to linebacker. But what this team really needs is to find players who won't add to the off-field distractions. 10. New Orleans Defensive needs are everywhere for the Saints, and this class is deep at cornerback. 11. Buffalo A big-time receiver would take the heat off Lee Evans and give Trent Edwards another reliable outlet. 12. Denver Both lines are threadbare and with Jay Cutler's rising stature at quarterback, the Broncos have to get him protection from a tackle, and perhaps a receiver. 13. Carolina Calling all offensive tackles -- the Panthers have a job for you immediately. 14. Chicago The good news is returner Devin Hester is still here because he is the only Bears player who reliably provides points. The quarterback situation is still a mess, but at this spot, the Bears may concentrate on replacements for their offensive line. 15. Detroit Memo to Matt Millen: No more wide receivers. How about an offensive lineman or a defensive end? 16. Arizona Still, the Cardinals need more help on defense, perhaps at cornerback, than on offense. 17. Minnesota An edge rusher is the most glaring need, although the Vikings could go for an offensive lineman, too. 18. Houston Injuries to Dunta Robinson mean the Texans need a cornerback. 19. Philadelphia A big-play receiver would be good for Donovan McNabb, but if Lito Sheppard is traded, they will need a cornerback. 20. Tampa Bay Jon Gruden wanted Calvin Johnson last year, and they still need a playmaking receiver. But the Buccaneers may be desperate for a running back, too. 21. Washington Jim Zorn, the rookie coach, wants to run the West Coast offense, and he needs a receiver to do it. 22. Dallas If they Cowboys get cornerback Pacman Jones in a trade, and if he is reinstated, they will have filled a big need. In that case, they can go for a running back. 23. Pittsburgh The Steelers have to shore up an offensive line seriously weakened by the departure of guard Alan Faneca. 24. Tennessee The Titans' biggest need is a receiver who can help Vince Young, who regressed last season. 25. Seattle Matt Hasselbeck needs better blocking around him, so the Seahawks could go for an offensive lineman or for a tight end. 26. Jacksonville If the Jaguars are finally going to challenge for the A.F.C. South title, they have to get a pass rusher. 27. San Diego The Chargers have no gaping holes in their starting lineup -- a luxury -- but they could use depth at cornerback. 28. Dallas See No. 22. 29. San Francisco The offense was a mess last season, and the 49ers could go for an offensive lineman. But they also need linebackers. 30. Green Bay Aaron Rodgers can't take over for an icon all by himself. The Packers could use offensive linemen. 31. Giants They need defense, especially someone to replace safety Gibril Wilson, or maybe a linebacker because Kawika Mitchell is also gone. Jerry Reese had such a successful first draft that it wouldn't be surprising if he unearthed a hidden gem with this pick. TEAMS WITH NO FIRST-ROUND PICKS Indianapolis The Colts could use reinforcements on the defensive line and linebackers. Cleveland But everyone in Cleveland should go out and enjoy the spring day because the Browns' first pick is in the fourth round.

HALPERN--Betsy Steele , died April 3 peacefully at her home surrounded by her family. She was 86. A graduate of UCLA and the University of Chicago, Betsy Halpern worked as a Jungian analyst in New York City and Princeton, NJ. A world traveler, she traveled extensively in Europe, the Middle East and Asia. She is survived by her four children, Jeff, Tamara, Tia and Nick and her grandchildren, Zach, Noah, William, Paula, and Sara. Donations in her name can be made to Grameen Foundation, www.grameenfoundation.org 888-764-3872 x125.

PROFIT UP AT HONEYWELL Honeywell International, the world's largest maker of airplane controls, posted a 22 percent gain in first-quarter earnings on Friday, beating analyst estimates, and said annual profit would be at the high end of its earlier range. Net income climbed to $643 million, or 85 cents a share, from $526 million, or 66 cents, a year earlier, the company, based in Morris Township, N.J., said. Sales rose 11 percent, to $8.9 billion, with two-thirds of the increase coming from outside the United States. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

WEISS--Stephen H . The partners and staff of Eisner LLP express profound sorrow over the passing of Stephen Weiss, our friend and client for over 40 years. His humanitarianism, family values, and success were inspirations to us all. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Suzanne, and his children, Heather, Michael, Jonathan and Nathalie. WEISS--Stephen. The Rogosin Institute mourns the passing of Stephen Weiss. He cared greatly about patient care and helped create The Institute, remaining a dedicated friend throughout the years. We extend sympathy to his wife, Suzanne, and the entire family. Barry Smith, M. D. Director Sidney Knafel, Board Chairman The Rogosin Institute WEISS--Stephen H. The twinkle in your eyes, the lilt in your laugh, and the warmth of your heart will live in our memories forever. Adios, Amigo. The Mexicans WEISS--Stephen H. Beloved husband of Suzanne Rogers, adored father of Heather, Michael, Jonny and Nathalie, cherished brother of Roger and step-sisters Barbara Stern and Jane Scheiber. Stephen, 72, a resident of Greenwich, CT, died April 16 in New York Hospital, of heart failure. He had a distinguished career as an investment banker, philanthropist and former chairman of the Cornell University Board of Trustees. Above all, he was devoted to his family. Mr. Weiss began his career at A.G. Becker & Co. where he served for 11 years, and was a vice president, shareholder and member of the board of directors. In 1970 he co-founded the investment management firm of Weiss, Peck & Greer, and was the firm's managing partner until the firm was sold in 2001. Most recently he was a managing director of the investment firm of Neuberger Berman, LLC. A 1957 graduate of Cornell University, Mr. Weiss was an enthusiastic and generous supporter of the University, and served on the Board of Trustees for 24 years. He was the board's chairman from 1989-1997. He was the first chairman of the Board of Overseers of the Cornell Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences. In 1980 he was named a Life Overseer. His affection for Cornell and his belief in the importance of education led him to serve on and chair many university committees. His activities at Cornell involved all aspects of the university, including serving on four presidential search committees. In 1984 he and his wife Suzanne endowed the deanship of the Weill Cornell Medical College. In 1992 he established the Stephen H. Weiss Presidential Fellows Awards to honor professors exhibiting an outstanding commitment to undergraduate education. A man of great energy and devotion to the community at large, Stephen was a board member of the National Humanities Center, and vice chairman of the Teagle Foundation. He was a member of the Citizens Budget Commission of New York City, and vice chairman of the Centurion Foundation. In 2000 he was appointed an honorary police commissioner of New York City. He also served on the Board of Visitors of California's School of Medicine, Davis, and was a member of the AACU's National Leadership Council for Liberal Education. Recently he was elected to serve on the Board of Tulane University. There will be a private funeral service for the immediate family. A memorial service at a future date will be announced. In lieu of flowers, those who wish to may send donations to: Cornell University, Attn: President David J. Skorton; or to Weill Cornell Medical College, Attn: Dr. O. Wayne Isom. WEISS--Stephen. Steve, we miss you already. You were a warm and wonderful friend, not only to us but to our children. With you the glass was always half full. Suzanne, we embrace you and send our love. Dalia and Larry WEISS--Stephen H. Cornell University mourns the loss of one of its most devoted and beloved alumni, Stephen H. Weiss, whose leadership at Cornell spanned four decades and was characterized by his extraordinarily high standards and intellect, a dedication to supporting the faculty and excellence in research and teaching, and a generosity of spirit that consistently brought out the best in others. A member of the Class of 1957, Steve played a transformative role in the history of the university as a presidential councillor and as a trustee for 24 years, including eight as chair of the board --a role that was not just an assignment for him, but a passion. He considered his fellow trustees, as well as the Cornell administrators, faculty, and staff with whom he worked, an extended family. His enduring commitment to the Cornell faculty and their research inspired a lifetime of significant philanthropy, including the creation of the Weiss Presidential Fellowships, which recognize professors for their inspirational teaching of undergraduates and their distinguished scholarship. He also gave generously to colleges and departments throughout the university --in Ithaca and at Weill Cornell Medical College --establishing professor ships, visiting professorships, research funds, and discretionary funds in honor of faculty. Steve was the driving force behind the creation of the Weill Cornell Medical College Board of Overseers in 1980 and served with distinction as its first chair and then as a life overseer. In December 2007, he was awarded the Frank H.T. Rhodes Exemplary Alumni Service Award, one of the university's highest distinctions. The Cornell community will deeply miss his keen intellect, wit, warmth, and gracious manner. Steve's love for and pride in his family was clear to all who knew him. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Suzanne, their children Heather, Michael, Jonny, and Nathalie, and the entire Weiss family. Peter C. Meinig, Chair of the Board of Trustees, David J. Skorton, President Cornell University WEISS--Stephen H. Congregation B'nai Yisrael mourns the loss of Stephen H. Weiss, whose vital presence in our midst touched our hearts. We share our sorrow with his wife Suzanne, their children Heather, Michael, Jonathan and Nathalie, and their family. Frederic J. Siegel, President Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz Rabbi Seth M. Limmer Cantor Hayley Kobilinsky WEISS--Stephen H. Lehman Brothers mourns the loss of a respected colleague, philanthropist, community leader, and valued friend. A top-caliber asset manager, he will be remembered for his impeccable reputation in the financial industry, as well as his devotion to his beloved alma mater, Cornell University. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Richard S. Fuld, Jr. Chairman & CEO Lehman Brothers

FINKEL--Roslyn (Tisch) , passed away at 92 on April 16, of Forest Hills, NY and Hollywood, FL. Cherished wife of Irving for 67 years. Devoted mother to Frank (Lois), Alan, Clare (Tom) Vandewart. Adoring grandmother to Pamela, David (Nicki), Stacey (Rueben) Glazer, and Drew Vandewart. Loving great-grandmother to Sam and Matthew. She was a True Sister. Tisch you will be missed.

SHIP--Jonathan A. , DMD. New York University College of Dentistry records with profoundest sorrow the untimely passing of our peerless colleague, teacher, and friend, Dr. Jonathan A. Ship, Professor of Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology, Radiology & Medicine and Director of NYU's Bluestone Center for Clinical Research. An outstanding clinician, teacher, and researcher, Jon was the principal investigator responsible for bringing an NIH grant of $26.7 million to the NYU College of Dentistry --the largest NIH grant ever received by any school at NYU. An expert in aging and oral health, Jon was also an award-winning author, lecturer, and practitioner beloved by his students, colleagues, and patients. Over the past year of Jon's terrible illness, his bravery, nobility, and grace were extraordinary. With his spectacular intelligence, humor, humanity, optimism and compassion, he set an example for us all. Jonathan Ship's passing leaves us heartbroken. We extend deepest condolences to his wife Sherry, their children, and his entire family. Charles N. Bertolami, DDS, DMedSc Herman Robert Fox Dean

Updated, 10:45 a.m. | Pope Benedict XVI knelt and prayed at ground zero in Lower Manhattan this morning, blessing the site where more than 2,600 people were killed in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center more than six years ago. The pontiff offered a prayer to God for peace, mentioning the attacks on 9/11 on the Pentagon in Washington and on a jetliner that crashed near Shanksville, Pa. He made only one, indirect, reference to terror: "Turn to your way of love those whose hearts and minds are consumed with hatred." The pope made no other public remarks during his half-hour visit to the site, but offered private words of comfort to survivors who were injured and relatives of victims who were killed in the attacks.

An article last Sunday about the changing fortunes of Roman Catholic schools in the region misstated the enrollment among Catholics and minorities in the six elementary schools in Bridgeport, Conn. To the Editor: Nicholas Kulish’s Footsteps column, “Milan Kundera’s Prague: Trumping the Unbearable Darkness of History” (March 30), reminded me of my visit to Prague in February 1966. On a dark, frigid evening I arrived from Warsaw aboard the equivalent of a Soviet built DC-3. The only light piercing the somber surroundings was a beam from the open passenger door of a Cubana airliner where two female flight attendants were swaying to mambo rhythms.
The city prides itself on maintaining a low profile, despite its abundance of art treasures, both trend-setting and classic.
A cadre of experimental chefs have pulled the city into the 21st century, leaving Paris kilometers behind.
A reader is interested in meeting friends in a charming Eastern European city that’s not too touristy and easy to walk around.
Within a 10-minute stroll from the Puerta del Sol, music lovers can take their pick of live jazz, rock, flamenco or folk-rock, or a fusion of all the above.
Bosnia as an outdoor travel destination remains off the radar to many travelers outside Europe.
Before it’s signed, sealed and delivered, as his campaign song goes, Barack Obama will have to balance his cool with some heat, as J.F.K. did.
None of the presidential candidates focus adequately on climate change, for this will be one of humanity’s great tests in the coming decades — and so far we’re failing.

TO illustrate the confounding nature of green building, Lindsay Suter, a Connecticut architect, likes to start with a question: Between a stone and plastic foam insulation, which one is green? ''You'll go, 'Of course, Lindsay, the stone is a natural product,' '' said Mr. Suter, who was trained at the Yale School of Architecture, where he now teaches part time.

KLIGER--Jack Alan, died at the age of 14 on April 10, 2008 from complications due to Canavan's Disease. His quiet presence and pure spirit has touched the lives of many and he will be sorely missed by all who loved him. An angel on earth, he is returned to heaven. Jack is survived by his parents, Benedetta and Sam, as well as his four siblings Tina, Michael, Ryan and Charlie. His grandparents, aunts, uncles and many cousins deeply mourn his passing.

ZINN--Morton, died peacefully on April 17, 2008 at age 91. Beloved husband of Natalie for 67 years. Loving father of Ellen and Herb Freiman and Karen and Alan Rosenthal. Devoted grandfather of Max, Peter and Jeff Malkin, David Fox and Lisa Shapiro. Cherished great-grandfather of Theo, Zoe, Matthew, Noah, Talulah and Ethan. Graveside Services Monday, 1pm at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

SKJELBRED--Perry Werner, 61, of Oldfield Farm, Greenwich, CT passed away April 11, 2008 at his home after a long illness. Born March 10, 1947 in Oslo, Norway to Reidar and Reidun Skjelbred, he graduated from Jamaica High School, Queens, and Pennsylvania State University. The friendships he made at Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity shaped his life. He received a MBA from Columbia University. A member of the reserves for six years, he served at Fort Campbell, Kentucky with the 101st Airborne Army Division. He held executive positions with the U.S. Trust Company and Savings Bank Trust Company and Directorships with the Excelsior Fund and Medical Manager Inc. In 1993 he retired to concentrate on private investments and his Fund, Enterprise Capital. He is survived by his eight year old twins, Elizabeth and Perry and his wife Catherine. Perry will be missed deeply by his many friends and loved by his family forever. Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home assists in funeral services. A memorial service will be held Wednesday April 23, 2008 4pm at First Church of Round Hill, corner of Round Hill and John Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Greenwich Land Trust.

No matter what headline high jinks designers propose, businessmen are not budging from their tried and true suits, ties, pocket handkerchiefs and wingtip shoes. The tie remains the one bit of freedom of expression, through color and pattern. That said, a surprise seen last week were a few younger businessmen, tieless in open-collar shirts, suggesting a new, only slightly dressed-down look for Fridays.

DOLECKI--Robledano Charlotte, M.D., 69, of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, New York on April 11th, 2008 (at home) after a long illness. A graduate of Women's College of Medicine in Philadelphia (Drexel University), internship and residency at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York (St. Vincent's Medical Center) with specialization in internal medicine, hematology and oncology. She was an attending Physician at Beekman Downtown Hospital (New York Downtown Hospital) as well as at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Director of the Village Nursing Home. After years of doing occupational medicine, her last position prior to her retirement was as Associate Director of Medicine at JP Morgan Chase. She is survived by her loving husband Emilio Robledano as well as many cousins, nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to Plan USA, 155 Plan Way, Warwick, RI 02886, mentioning in memory of Dr. Charlotte Dolecki. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

AMONG those blamed for the nation's foreclosure crisis, one of the most prominent targets is mortgage brokers, who have been cited by regulators, legislators and borrowers as steering people into risky and costly loans. A new study by the Center for Responsible Lending, a Washington-based consumer advocacy group, heaps more blame on the group and particularly cites brokers of subprime loans, made to borrowers with poor credit.

MOSES--Henry. We were saddened by the death of Henry C. Moses, Headmaster of Trinity School. Hank exercised his stewardship with honesty, integrity and commitment to academic excellence. We all benefitted from his wisdom, humor and dedication to the wider Trinity community. Our thoughts are with Missy and his family. Kathy Cropper, Joan, DaceySeib, Jane Dietche, Rita Haves, Patti Lieberman, Lisa Pinero, Diane Rosen, Jean Schrag, and Marlene Turner Past Presidents, Trinity Parents Association MOSES--Henry C. We mourn the passing of our beloved teacher and friend, Hank Moses. Hank lived with passion and energy. He was an inspirational leader. Our sincerest condolences extend to Missy Holland and Hank's entire family. Elise, Andrew, Julia and Alex Brownstein MOSES--Henry C. The students, staff, alumni, and trustees of Trinity School mourn the death of Henry C. Moses, our beloved headmaster since 1991. Hank was a passionate, inspiring, and visionary leader who loved Trinity School. His 17 years as headmaster brought Trinity to a position of preeminence among independent schools in New York and throughout the nation. Each of us who has known him, learned from him, and worked with him is the greater for it. He was an example to all of us of Trinity's motto, Labore et Virtute, and we dedicate ourselves to honoring his memory by striving always to live out that high calling to ''hard work and moral excellence.'' To his wife, Mary Sarah Holland, sons Laurence Holland, William Holland, James Moses, Bruce Moses, and daughter Paige Lewin, and all his family we extend deepest sympathy and our love. The Trustees of Trinity School Andrew R. Brownstein, President MOSES--Henry. Prep for Prep mourns the passing of our longtime Trustee, friend, and advocate Henry C. Moses. During his 17-year tenure as Headmaster of Trinity School and Prep Trustee, Hank was a tireless partner in our work to create a more diverse generation of leaders. With Hank at the helm, nearly 200 Prep students of color received a superb Trinity education. For our students, alumni, and the wider world, he showed all the traits of true leadership. Our condolences go to his wife Missy and his children during this difficult time. Martin Lipton Chairman Emeritus John L. Vogelstein Chairman Anne Gilchrist Hall President And the Prep for Prep Board of Trustees

WEISS--Stephen H. The Board of Directors of The Centurion Foundation are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and treasured board member Stephen H. Weiss. Stephen was a very enthusiastic and generous supporter, and served as Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors for 20 years. In 2000, he was appointed Honorary Police Commissioner of New York City. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Suzanne and his children, Michael, Jonathan, Natalie and Heather. Albert Fried, Jr. Chairman Joseph Dippell, President and all the members of our Board of Directors WEISS--Stephen. The loss of Stephen H. Weiss is mourned by the NewYork Weill Cornell Council. Steve received the Council's Leadership Award in 2005 for his many years of dedicated service to Weill Cornell Medical College. His guidance, vision, and great wisdom will be missed. Jeffrey W. Greenberg, Chairman, NewYork Weill Cornell Council WEISS--Stephen H. The Tulane University community deeply mourns the passing of Stephen H. Weiss. An extraordinary advisor, supporter and friend, Mr. Weiss was a member of the Board of Tulane University since 2006, serving on its governance, development, investment, athletics and health sciences committees. His generosity to Tulane included the establishment of the Suzanne and Stephen Weiss Presidential Fellowships for Undergraduate Teaching, which each year honors and provides funding to faculty members who have displayed sustained, inspired and distinguished teaching of undergraduate students. In addition to his support of teaching, Mr. Weiss, whose son is a member of the Tulane baseball team, also had a great love for Tulane athletics, which he also supported through both his generosity and passionate attendance of games. Tulane President Scott Cowen had recently visited with Mr. Weiss. President Cowen recalls that Mr. Weiss was his usual engaging, thoughtful and delightful self, laughing, enjoying life and expressing deep interest in the well-being of Tulane and its students. That is the way the Tulane community will remember Mr. Weiss. WEISS--Stephen H. Cornell University mourns the loss of one of its most devoted and beloved alumni, Stephen H. Weiss, whose leadership at Cornell spanned four decades and was characterized by his extraordinarily high standards and intellect, a dedication to supporting the faculty and excellence in research and teaching, and a generosity of spirit that consistently brought out the best in others. A member of the Class of 1957, Steve played a transformative role in the history of the university as a presidential councillor and as a trustee for 24 years, including eight as chair of the board --a role that was not just an assignment for him, but a passion. He considered his fellow trustees, as well as the Cornell administrators, faculty, and staff with whom he worked, an extended family. His enduring commitment to the Cornell faculty and their research inspired a lifetime of significant philanthropy, including the creation of the Weiss Presidential Fellowships, which recognize professors for their inspirational teaching of undergraduates and their distinguished scholarship. He also gave generously to colleges and departments throughout the university --in Ithaca and at Weill Cornell Medical College --establishing professor ships, visiting professorships, research funds, and discretionary funds in honor of faculty. Steve was the driving force behind the creation of the Weill Cornell Medical College Board of Overseers in 1980 and served with distinction as its first chair and then as a life overseer. In December 2007, he was awarded the Frank H.T. Rhodes Exemplary Alumni Service Award, one of the university's highest distinctions. The Cornell community will deeply miss his keen intellect, wit, warmth, and gracious manner. Steve's love for and pride in his family was clear to all who knew him. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Suzanne, their children Heather, Michael, Jonny, and Nathalie, and the entire Weiss family. Peter C. Meinig, Chair of the Board of Trustees, David J. Skorton, President Cornell University WEISS--Stephen. Dearest Suzanne, our deepest sympathy, heartfelt thoughts, prayers, and love are with you and your wonderful children at this very sad time and forever. We will miss Steve so very much. Richard and Diana Feldman WEISS--Stephen. Steve, we miss you already. You were a warm and wonderful friend, not only to us but to our children. With you the glass was always half full. Suzanne, we embrace you and send our love. Dalia and Larry WEISS--Stephen H. Beloved husband of Suzanne Rogers, adored father of Heather, Michael, Jonny and Nathalie, cherished brother of Roger and step-sisters Barbara Stern and Jane Scheiber. Stephen, 72, a resident of Greenwich, CT, died April 16 in New York Hospital, of heart failure. He had a distinguished career as an investment banker, philanthropist and former chairman of the Cornell University Board of Trustees. Above all, he was devoted to his family. Mr. Weiss began his career at A.G. Becker & Co. where he served for 11 years, and was a vice president, shareholder and member of the board of directors. In 1970 he co-founded the investment management firm of Weiss, Peck & Greer, and was the firm's managing partner until the firm was sold in 2001. Most recently he was a managing director of the investment firm of Neuberger Berman, LLC. A 1957 graduate of Cornell University, Mr. Weiss was an enthusiastic and generous supporter of the University, and served on the Board of Trustees for 24 years. He was the board's chairman from 1989-1997. He was the first chairman of the Board of Overseers of the Cornell Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences. In 1980 he was named a Life Overseer. His affection for Cornell and his belief in the importance of education led him to serve on and chair many university committees. His activities at Cornell involved all aspects of the university, including serving on four presidential search committees. In 1984 he and his wife Suzanne endowed the deanship of the Weill Cornell Medical College. In 1992 he established the Stephen H. Weiss Presidential Fellows Awards to honor professors exhibiting an outstanding commitment to undergraduate education. A man of great energy and devotion to the community at large, Stephen was a board member of the National Humanities Center, and vice chairman of the Teagle Foundation. He was a member of the Citizens Budget Commission of New York City, and vice chairman of the Centurion Foundation. In 2000 he was appointed an honorary police commissioner of New York City. He also served on the Board of Visitors of California's School of Medicine, Davis, and was a member of the AACU's National Leadership Council for Liberal Education. Recently he was elected to serve on the Board of Tulane University. There will be a private funeral service for the immediate family. A memorial service at a future date will be announced. In lieu of flowers, those who wish to may send donations to: Cornell University, Attn: President David J. Skorton; or to Weill Cornell Medical College, Attn: Dr. O. Wayne Isom. WEISS--Stephen H. The Directors and staff of the Teagle Foundation mourn the death of Stephen H. Weiss on April 16, 2008. Mr. Weiss was named by Cornell University as its representative on the Board of the Teagle Foundation in November 1998. During his years of service on the Foundation's Board, he chaired its governance committee and investment committee, and was elected Vice Chair of the Board. His incisive judgement, generous spirit and deep commitment to higher education will be remembered by all who knew him. John Chalsty, Chairman of the Board W. Robert Connor, President and members of the Board of Directors WEISS--Stephen H. The Partners of Weiss, Peck & Greer mourn the passing of Stephen Henry Weiss and extend our heartfelt sympathy to Suzanne and the entire Weiss family. Stephen founded Weiss, Peck & Greer in 1970 with Philip Greer, Stephen Peck and Roger Weiss and established an enduring and well - respected investment management firm characterized by loyalty, dedication and service. As Managing Partner, Stephen led the Firm through the ups and downs of the markets and never lost sight of his commitment to our clients. He knew every employee and was a role model and inspiration to all. We owe Stephen our gratitude and respect for his leadership, vision and courage. WEISS--Stephen H. Steve's thoughtfulness and generosity were key factors in the growth of the Citizens Committee over the years. Our deepest sympathy to Suzanne and their children, who made Steve so proud. Osborn Elliott, Founding Chairman Citizens Committee for New York City WEISS--Stephen H. The twinkle in your eyes, the lilt in your laugh, and the warmth of your heart will live in our memories forever. Adios, Amigo. The Mexicans WEISS--Stephen H. The HealthCare Chaplaincy mourns the loss of a member of its President's Advisory Council, a faithful friend and supporter. We extend our love and prayerful condolences to Suzanne and to your wonderful family. Lawrence J. Toal, Chairman The Rev. Doctor Walter J. Smith S.J., President and CEO

FISHER--David W., died April 17, 2008, aged 81. He was Naomi's devoted husband for 55 years until her death last May. With extraordinary love and effort, he cared for her to the end, even as her spirit receded behind what he called ''the cruel cloud of Alzheimer's Disease.'' He was the loving father of Paul (Margaret Reid) and Robert (Yasmin Khakoo), and doting grandfather of M. Caitlin, Jeremy, Gillian, Alex and Aliya. In recent years he found great joy in the love and companionship of Maxine Rosen. He was the cherished uncle of Helen Freedman, Henry Edelstein and Daniel Edelstein. He also leaves behind loyal canine companions, Popcorn and Cody. A proud practitioner of print journalism -mainly medical -he cofounded Hospital Practice, where he was Editorial Director and president of Maclean Hunter Medical Communications group. A political activist, union organizer and delegate (for Eugene McCarthy) to the 1968 Democratic Convention, he will be remembered for his compassion, decency and commitment to social and economic justice; he will also be remembered for his puns sometimes good, sometimes bad (mostly by his account), but always entertaining. Avid tennis player and lifelong Yankee fan, lover of language and of life, he took great pleasure in sharing these passions with his children, grandchildren and other loved ones. To those whose lives he touched, he was not merely a presence but a force -often irresistible and now terribly irreplaceable. The family extends special thanks to the physicians, nurses and staff of the Cardiothoracic ICU, Stony Brook University Hospital, for their valiant efforts and compassionate care and support during his final struggle. FISHER--David. Beloved friend, you will be missed so very much. Maxine Rosen and Family FISHER--David. You have been so important to me in the world of medical publishing and to so many others as well. Thank you. Amy Selwyn

An essay on April 6 satirizing the questions often provided by publishers and Web sites to stimulate discussion of specific books misspelled the surname of a character in Jane Austen's ''Pride and Prejudice'' and part of the title of a novel by Oscar Wilde. The Austen character is Elizabeth Bennet, not Bennett, and Wilde's novel is ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' not ''Grey.'' The essay also misspelled the name of the author of ''The Red and the Black.'' It is Stendhal, not Stendahl.

SATURDAY@PHILLIPS isn't your Russian oligarch's auction. With lower-priced lots (presale estimates range from $500 to $20,000) and an atmosphere more akin to a cocktail party, this Phillips de Pury auction series, now in its second year, draws ''younger'' collectors, or those with an eye for cutting-edge art and design but not the budget. Giving it an added spin this season is the inclusion of contemporary fashion. Alongside the Tom Sachs Chanel rat trap, Richard Prince prints and Jeff Koons skateboard decks, there will be one-of-a kind pieces from the New York label Electric Feathers (above and below), a favorite of the fashion muse Irina Lazareanu, who modeled the clothes for the catalog. THE NEWS The president of the World Bank called on governments to contribute $500 million in aid to help poor countries cope with food prices that have doubled in the last three years. BEHIND THE NEWSRobert B. Zoellick, the bank's president, said a wave of deadly rioting in Haiti last weekend over food prices underscored the need for quick action. Food riots have also erupted in recent weeks in Africa and Southeast Asia. Mr. Zoellick warned that surging food prices could push 100 million people in low-income countries deeper into poverty. ''This is not just a question of short-term needs,'' he said. ''This is ensuring that future generations don't pay a price, too.''

EDELSTEIN--Betty F. (nee Joseph), on April 18, 2008. Beloved wife of Marvin. Loving mother of Andrew and Sally. Cherished grandmother of Jessie and Sam. Fond sister of Jay and the late Judith Wachtel. Beloved aunt. Services Tuesday April 22, 2008, 12 noon at Gutterman's 175 N. Long Beach Rd.

HOLMES--Richard, beloved teacher at Brooks School in North Andover, MA, died peacefully in Vero Beach, FL on March 30. He was 83. He came to Brooks School in 1948, intending to teach for only one year; forty-three years later he retired as assistant-headmaster of the school and settled in Cape Town, South Africa. His proudest achievement during his tenure was the introduction of the African Exchange Program between Brooks students and their counterparts at Bishops School in Cape Town. Richard hoped to encourage his students to become ''citizens of a larger world community''. The program was ahead of its time and has become a model for several schools since then. A lover of American art and artifacts, Richard befriended Andy Warhol in the 1960s and soon began collecting the artist's work. His entire collection of Warhols was recently given to Williams College, his alma mater. Brooks School will have lending rights. Richard will be sorely missed by the countless Brooks students he mentored and by the many families and friends who shared his love of Africa. A memorial service will be held at 11am on June 15 in the Ashburn Chapel at Brooks School. Gifts may be made in his name to the Richard F. Holmes Memorial Fund to benefit the African Exchange Program.

BY DESIGN Philippe Starck's product design often entered the realm of pure silliness, perhaps epitomized by the goblet-shaped toddler sippy cup in plastic masquerading as crystal that Starck designed for Target back in 2002. Or maybe the WW Stool he designed for Vitra, described as a stool or a ''support for users who prefer to stand,'' priced at an astonishing $4,670. (I will give him a nod for his spider-legged juice squeezer for Alessi; if you'll pardon the unpardonable pun, that design has legs.) I write of Starck in the past tense because the increasingly cynical vibe of his creations seems to have caught up with him. In an interview with the German newspaper Die Zeit recently, Starck proclaimed that ''everything that I designed is absolutely unnecessary.'' This continued a jag of self-deprecation started at the TED conference in March, where Starck began by addressing his audience thusly: ''I must tell you I am like that [indicates shaking hands], not very comfortable, because usually, in life, I think my job is absolutely useless.'' Starck also announced his impending retirement (not effective immediately, but two years from now, so we can expect more of the same).

In the 2008 primary campaign, the Web has come into its own as a medium for serious stumping, a powerful tool for organizing and expressing support. The Internet both replicates ''old'' media -- photo ops, clips of televised debates and news coverage -- and gives rise to new campaign forms like ''contributed videos,'' made by those with few resources beyond editing software. It also allows media sophisticates to disseminate high-quality productions virally in spaces usually devoted to college pranks and pet videos. While some images cited here emanated from campaign organizations, even more came from bloggers and YouTubers who, without consulting paid political professionals, are taking candidates' images into their own hands. DAVID S. BIRDSELL and DOUGLAS MUZZIO 1. Some voters have shown their enthusiasm for their candidates by producing videos. Early in the primaries, Amber Lee Ettinger (above) became known as:

AS Doug Abraham, the owner of the vintage shop Bess, will tell you, studs are more than just a punk thing: Jimi Hendrix wore them. As did Elvis. ''I have a picture of Frank Sinatra in a studded denim pantsuit,'' said Mr. Abraham, who also designs his own line of jewelry, and is a jewelry designer for Ralph Lauren. And since he started studding myriad items in his store -- hats, moccasins, motorcycle jackets -- he has added a range of fashionable folk to the list, including Erin Wasson (who has a pair of the jean shorts) and Lauren DuPont (who wears one of the floppy straw hats). ''I love the straw hat,'' Mr. Abraham said. ''Studs just take the sissy right out of it.'' Studded straw hat, $210, and denim shorts, $165, at Bess, 292 Lafayette Street (between Prince and Houston Streets), (212) 219-0723.

SMITH--Lester J., a leading radio and television news and sports journalist for over fifty years, died at his home in Riverdale, New York on April 11, 2008 at the age of 90. After working for over a dozen years in Boston at WNAC as a reporter and anchor, and doing play-by-play for various major league and college sports teams, in 1957 Mr. Smith began a career in New York City at WOR Radio and TV. For over three decades, his deep, melodic voice became familiar to New Yorkers as they listened to him bring them the news and commentary from the studio, the street, presidential conventions, inaugurations, NASA space flights and every kind of disaster and national tragedy. He was the original host of William F. Buckley's TV show, 'Firing Line,' the anchor of 'New York Report' on Channel 9 for 20 years (19641984), and the radio voice of the New York Knicks basketball team and Army football. At one point, the New York Daily News dubbed him 'the Walter Cronkite of news radio.' He once told his son, Mark, that ''I liked hearing the phone ring at four in the morning. It meant I might be on my way to something big.'' In addition to his son, Mr. Smith is survived by his wife, Mildred, and three grandchildren, Zachary, Rachel and Lexie. His daughter Deborah died in 1978.

An article last Sunday about the changing fortunes of Roman Catholic schools in the region misstated the enrollment among Catholics and minorities in the six elementary schools in Bridgeport, Conn. In those schools, 41 percent are non-Catholic, 30 percent are Hispanic and 39 percent are black. The schools are not 11 percent non-Catholic, about 10 percent Hispanic and about 10 percent black. (Those figures were for all elementary students in the Diocese of Bridgeport, which encompasses all of Fairfield County.)

HANSON--Margaret Hixon, beloved wife of the late Maury F. Hanson, died peacefully at her home in Naples, Florida on April 10, three days before her 93rd birthday. A daughter of the late Robert and Marguerite Hixon of Lake Forest, Illinois, she was a longtime resident of Greenwich, Connecticut until her move to Florida. She is survived by her three children, Robert Hixon Hanson (Arlene) of Wapiti, Wyoming, Michael Francis Hanson (Patsy) of Bonita Springs, Florida and Barbara Hanson Pierce (Charles) of New York City and Salt Point, New York. Additionally, she is survived by seven grandchildren and eight great - grandchildren, and by her two sisters, Barbara Hixon Wilson of San Francisco and Joan Hixon Martin of Mill Valley, California. A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 25 at 11:00am in the chapel at Christ Church Greenwich, 254 East Putnam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to Avow Hospice, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, Florida 34105.

Katharine Blake Schogol, a daughter of Elizabeth Duff Schogol of Drexel Hill, Pa., and the late Marc Schogol, was married on Saturday evening to Seth Thayer Pidot, a son of Jeanne S. Pidot and Whitney D. Pidot of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. David Prior, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla. Mrs. Pidot, 26, teaches Spanish to middle school students at the Friends' Central School in Wynnewood, Pa., and is in her third year of study for a master's degree in Hispanic studies at Villanova. She graduated from Haverford.

A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about members of the Nordstrom family who are executives at the namesake store referred incompletely to discounts they received last year. Although the company's managers do indeed occasionally receive discounts of 40 percent at Nordstrom stores, they usually receive a discount of 33 percent.

FINKLE--S. Marcus, passed away peacefully Monday, April 14th, 2008. Marc is survived by his wife Sara Figi Finkle, his two sisters, Ann Miller and Patricia Klein, and his children Bonnie and Tim Burns, Betsy and Clifford Ross, Debbie and Richard Jelinek, Elizabeth and Steven Sans, F. Scott Thomson, Anna and Chris Patterson, as well as nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Formally from New York where he was a member of the New York Stock Exchange, Marc made his home in Aspen for the past 27 years. He was involved with several charitable organizations in Aspen and his generosity touched the lives of many people. Marc had a multitude of friends from all walks of life and he will be greatly missed by everyone who knew him. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Preston Robert Tisch Brain Cancer Clinic (Marc Finkle fund) Duke University Hospital, care of Henry Friedman Box 3624, Duke University, Durham, North Carolina, 27710 or Challenge Aspen 970923-0578 or Aspen Valley Ski Club Endowment Fund 970925-2720.

To the Editor: Your article ''For Aging Pedestrians, a Survey of Street Dangers'' (April 13), about a study of pedestrian safety on the Upper West Side, neglected to mention a leading cause of pedestrians' death and injuries in New York: the failure of drivers to yield when turning into a crosswalk.

To the Editor: I am so glad that in ''Dear Watchdogs: Rein In Wall Street'' (April 13), Ben Stein addressed the need for more regulation of banks and all financial companies, including hedge funds, private equity funds, investment companies, brokers, mortgage companies, credit rating agencies, etc. Very little is being said in other media about the need for regulating the derivatives markets.

Mr. Tenney's family was instrumental in developing many gas and electric utility companies in the Northeast and he served as Chairman of the Board for several of these companies including Bay State Gas Company, Unitil Corporation and Orange and Rockland Utilities. He was the husband of the late Gloria Bond ''Bonnie'' Tenney, who died this past November. Surviving him are his two sons, Rockwell C. Tenney of New York, NY and Charles H. Tenney III (and his wife Constance) of Sherborn, MA; two stepsons, Roger A. Young (and his wife Linda) of Steamboat Springs, CO and Robert H. McC. Young (and his wife Victoria) of Proctor, VT; grandson, Andrew C. Tenney; granddaughter, Mariel H. Tenney; and sister, Nancy Tenney Coleman of Greenwich, CT. Graveside Service will be held at 11am, Saturday, May 24th at Westview Cemetery, Lexington, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 311 Arsenal St., Watertown, MA 02472, www.alz.org.

To the Editor: Pay phones wouldn't be going the way of the dodo, as suggested in ''Shrinking Portals to the Past'' (The City Visible, April 13), if the telephone booth were still around. That truly was a street enclosure, with doors that kept out the deafening noise of the street and a generous shelf for pen and paper.

In Search of a Lost Africa I was delighted to read Helene Cooper's article (April 6) on her life and Liberia. It had everything: humanity, a strong and uncommon point of view and lots of historical information. I was amazed how much I learned and felt at the same time -- a rare achievement in a very brief memoir. HARRY JOHNSON

As Gil Brandt, the NFL.com analyst, said about this year's draft, ''There are so many guys who all look alike.'' That means that this is a deep class, full of talent through about two rounds. That is especially good news for a team like Atlanta, which has multiple early picks and just as many needs to fill.

A brief article on March 23 about three books by writers like Ken Kesey who challenged society in the late 1950s and '60s erroneously ascribed a writing technique to William S. Burroughs in his novel ''Naked Lunch,'' one of the three. Burroughs used the ''cut-up'' nonlinear technique in later novels, not in ''Naked Lunch.''

Four years after breaking into the IndyCar circuit with much fanfare and high expectations, Danica Patrick broke into victory lane. Patrick became the first woman to win an IndyCar race Sunday, taking the Indy Japan 300 after the top contenders were forced to pit for fuel in the final laps.

ROEGGE--Frank, 88, of Madison, CT, passed away March 30, 2008. Frank is survived by loving wife of nearly 50 years, Mary (Connors) Roegge, and children: John Roegge of Pawling, NY and William Roegge and his wife Diana of Branford, CT, four grandchildren and one greatgranddaughter. Frank received his B.A. from Northwestern University and his J.D. from University of Michigan Law School, in 1947. He served as a Navy/Japanese Language Officer stationed in Hawaii during World War II and retiring from the reserves as a Lt. Commander. From 1951 to 1982, Frank worked for Metropolitan Life Insurance Company becoming Vice-President and Associate General Counsel. He was a long-time director of Apple Bank for Savings in New York and co-editor of Practicing Law Institute books on real estate. Funeral service was private at Swan Funeral Home, Madison, CT.

HARRIS--Myron W., Ph.D . Born in Los Angeles May 4, 1922. Died in New York April 14, 2008. Psychologist, Social Justice, Human Rights Activist, mentor, teacher and author. Lifelong service to inner city youth. Co-founded Cat Rock Gang, therapeutic program for inner city youth using adventure-based challenges to help teenagers realize inner strengths and full potential. Longtime private practice in Scarsdale. Volunteered for numerous schools leading therapeutic student groups. Many years of service at Bronx Psychiatric Center treating patients and working with staff regarding issues of race, class and culture and their impact on mental health. Served as navigator in the US Army Corps in the Pacific. World traveler and accomplished sailor. Survived by his wife Hilda O'Connell, godchildren and many friends. No funeral services are planned, private celebration of Mike's life will take place at his home.
