THREE of the most startlingly fast cars around appear in new advertisements for Tommy Hilfiger: belly tank lakesters, built from fighter plane fuel tanks for speed runs at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah and other dry lakebeds. The ads feature models draped over the cars, a not-quite-accurate portrayal of the usual scene at Bonneville Speed Week. The cars come from Bobby Green, who was finishing up runs at Speed Week last October when a scout for the fashion brand approached him about using his car, named Old Crow, for a shoot.

I had to chuckle (O.K.: LOL) at the title of the television program for Click and Clack: ''Nova: Car of the Future.'' The old Chevy Nova (1962-1979) was one of the most reliable and best-loved American cars ever made. My '78 Nova had a straight six engine in it. I sold this grand old car with more than 200,000 miles on it to a kid who was thrilled to buy it for 200 bucks. If only Detroit could have continued making such reliable automobiles, I would not have jumped ship to Honda. -- GREGORY HUTH

As part of a turnaround effort at Starbucks, Howard Schultz, the chief executive, wants to make sure that his company is ''the undisputed coffee authority.'' Whether he is successful will depend, in part, on coffee farmers like Jorge Torres of Costa Rica, above. The Starbucks farmer support center in Costa Rica is teaching Mr. Torres and other farmers to grow coffee the company's way. For example, if farmers ''don't care about the drying, they can spoil the coffee and get some bad flavors,'' said Carlos Mario Rodriguez, agronomy director of the center. At top, in Costa Rica beans are turned for drying; at right, they are sorted and stored.

THE dynamic brothers better known as Click and Clack of NPR's ''Car Talk,'' Tom and Ray Magliozzi, are taking their banter beyond public radio with two coming television shows. ''Car of the Future,'' which will be broadcast on April 22 at 8 p.m., is an episode of ''Nova'' that centers on Tom's search for a car to replace his ailing 1952 MG roadster.

STUDENTS LOOKING SMART Baggy jeans, baseball caps, pajama bottoms, T-shirts -- the presentation distressed the new president of Paul Quinn, a historically black college in Dallas. ''Our students were not dressing up to par,'' says the president, Michael J. Sorrell, who put in place a business casual dress code last fall. To take the sting out of the cost of a new wardrobe -- most students are ''of humble origins,'' he says -- he reached out to the community for donations and set up the Clothes Closet, a free ''boutique'' where students can get new items as well as the occasional gently worn Armani suit or St. John dress. Yes, those are Ferragamos on Joseph Adams (left), a freshman majoring in business who has always prized dressing well. The shoes, slacks and tie were a gift from a mentor. ''The idea,'' Mr. Adams says, ''is to empower young African-Americans -- no, people of different colors -- to say, 'Look, when you dress up, you feel like you run things, don't you?' '' MISSION STATEMENTS The dress code at Brigham Young reflects the mores of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints: no extreme fashions (navel piercings, minis, halter tops, for girls) or hairstyles (covering ears or below the collar, for boys). That's not to suggest B.Y.U. lacks style trends. Young Mormons typically do missionary work, spreading their faith while doing community service projects. Back on the Provo, Utah, campus, students sport their souvenirs, including a messenger bag handpainted with the name of the Taiwan high school where the student taught English; a fur hat from St. Petersburg, Russia; and a shark bone necklace from Samoa.

TREISMAN--Norman J., on April 15, 2008, at age 71. Loving father of Joel and Jeffrey, beloved grandfather to Rachel, Maya and Jordana, loving friend of Mary Lee Calimano, and lifelong friend and trusted advisor to his first wife, Dorothy. He is remembered with love by his daughter-inlaw, Margie, his sister-in-law, Ling, and his niece, Joanne. He was a son of the late Bessie Treisman Strange and Hyman Treisman and brother of the late Jerome Treisman. Norman was born in Concord, NH and lived in Westchester and Manhattan for many years. He earned an undergraduate degree from Brandeis University and an MBA from the University of Chicago. He began his career in sales and marketing, joined the Sales Group of Philip Morris USA in 1964, and retired in 1993 as President, Philip Morris Capital Corp, the financial services subsidiary of Altria, Inc. After retiring, he became a savvy and successful private investor and was a trusted financial advisor to many friends and family members. He was an independent thinker, a die-hard fan of the Boston Red Sox and NY Giants, an avid tennis player, and he enjoyed singing in the shower. A memorial service will be held at noon, Monday, May 12, 2008 at the Lotos Club, 5 East 66th Street, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Joslin Diabetes Center, One Joslin Place, Suite 745, Boston, MA 02215.
To the Editor: Re ''A Lender Failed. Did Its Auditor?'' (April 13):

A typical American single-family home is responsible for more than 11 metric tons of carbon-dioxide emissions every year through its energy use. You would need to plant more than 250 tree seedlings and let them grow for 10 years to absorb that much CO2. Here's where those emissions come from. IN THE BASEMENT: THE NONDESCRIPT EQUIPMENT LURKING IN THE CELLAR CAN HAVE A HUGE CARBON FOOTPRINT. THE WATER HEATER (1) AND THE MAIN HEATING SYSTEM (2) ARE RESPONSIBLE ON AVERAGE FOR MORE THAN 4.5 METRIC TONS OF CO2 A YEAR ALONE. YOUR CLOTHES DRYER (3) CAN USE ALMOST 10 TIMES AS MUCH ENERGY AS YOUR WASHER (4). IN THE KITCHEN: OLDER REFRIGERATORS (5) -- THOSE THAT DON'T MEET ENERGY STAR STANDARDS -- ARE USUALLY AMONG THE WORST ENERGY DRAWS IN THE HOUSE AND OVER A YEAR CAN BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ALMOST A TON OF CO2 EMISSIONS. IN THE LIVING ROOM: A SIMPLE REAR-PROJECTION TELEVISION (6) DRAWS ONLY ABOUT A TENTH OF THE ENERGY ANNUALLY THAT AN OLD REFRIGERATOR CAN, BUT THE AVERAGE AMERICAN HOUSEHOLD HAS MORE TELEVISIONS THAN PEOPLE. AIR-CONDITIONING: IF YOU RELY ON A CENTRAL AIR SYSTEM (7), YOU MIGHT AS WELL BUILD YOUR OWN SMOKESTACK. IT ACCOUNTS FOR ABOUT 2.2 METRIC TONS OF CO2 ANNUALLY, 20 TIMES MORE EMISSIONS THAN A HOUSEHOLD'S CEILING FANS (8). CHARLES WILSON (SOURCE: ''ELECTRICITY CONSUMPTION BY END USE IN U.S. HOUSEHOLDS, 2001,'' ENERGY INFORMATION ADMINISTRATION, U.S. DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY)

TAKING A BREATHER ON PRAÇA DO COMÉRCIO, APRIL 4, 2008 Joanna Beaufoy, 19, with her friend Thomas Petit, 20, both students at Cambridge University, toward the end of their five-day hitchhiking trip from Paris to Lisbon. ''We actually came up with the idea after a few drinks. In English university there's something called 'Jailbreak,' where you have to get as far as you can in a week and back, without spending any money, for charity. I was living in Paris over the holidays so we started there. I wanted to stand outside the Arc de Triomphe -- I thought it would be hilarious to stand there dressed as a hitchhiker. That didn't work, so we walked down the Champs Élysées, and then a man stopped and took us on our first hitch. I think we took 27 lifts, 9 of which were in big lorries. The whole trip was all these random experiences, meeting so many different people who were all really kind to us. We didn't have any aggressive remarks, unpleasant experiences. It all went off completely without a hitch.'' As told to Austin Considine

THE sandal maker Barbara Shaum prefers to focus on her craft, not changing trends. (''So gladiator sandals are popular again?'' she asked recently, only moderately curious.) Since opening her business in 1954, her technique has stayed pretty much the same. Customers still choose from about 30 classic styles and an assortment of skins; their feet are measured, patterns are drawn; a couple weeks later, there's a fitting. The age-old craft was taught to her by Menalkas Duncan, who learned it while visiting Greece with his aunt, Isadora. ''I'm not really fashion-fashion,'' Ms. Shaum, 79, said as an employee fielded a call from a Vogue editor. ''I'm more traditional.''

9 P.M. (13) MY BOY JACK Daniel Radcliffe (left with Kim Cattrall), moves out of the shadow of Harry Potter and into the role of Rudyard Kipling's son in this ''Masterpiece'' adaptation of the play by David Haig. Mr. Radcliffe plays Jack Kipling, who, under age, cursed with poor eyesight and sharing his father's belief in the power of war, desperately longs to join the fight at the outbreak of World War I. After Jack fails his induction eye exam twice, his father uses his influence to gain his son, not yet 18, an officer's commission in the Irish Guards. And then, in the Battle of Loos, Jack goes missing. Mr. Haig plays Rudyard Kipling; Ms. Cattrall is his American wife, Carrie. 1 P.M. (G4) HALF BAKED G4 goes up in smoke for the day with programming extolling the virtues of cannabis culture, beginning at 1 p.m. First, this comedy starring Dave Chappelle, Guillermo Díaz and Jim Breuer as party guys hatching a scheme to bail a friend out of jail. Other highlights include ''Attack of the Show: Jamaica,'' at 3, which reports on the state of marijuana consumption in Toronto, Vancouver, Los Angeles and San Francisco; ''Code Monkeys: The Story of 420,'' at 5; the cult classic ''Reefer Madness,'' tweaked with new characters and voices in ''Reefee's Madhouse,'' at 6; and at 7, the best scenes from the Troma horror flick ''Class of Nuke 'em High'' in ''Grindcore.''

In researching my column on how small business owners deal with health insurance, I talked to Rosalind Joffe, an executivecoach who specializes in helping people who have chronic illnesses. Ms. Joffe has suffered from multiple sclerosis and ulcerative colitis, both of which have stabilized with treatment -- the removal of her colon for the colitis, and the medication, Avonex, for her MS. Prior to getting sick, Ms. Joffe had two successful careers, first as a multimedia producer and then as a professor of communications at Boston University. She became a coach because she wanted a job that she could do from home and that would be flexible enough to allow her to modify her schedule whenever she had a bad day. She credits her ability to make that career change to the fact that her husband had a good health insurance policy that could cover her as well -- yet another example of health insurance affecting a career choice.

The colt broke his maiden in dazzling fashion his first time out Feb. 23 in Kyoto. He rocketed the one and one-eighth miles, taking the lead from the start and, while still under a strong hold, he continued to increase his advantage with every stride, winning by about 12 lengths under a hand ride from Yutaka Take.

Can a typeface truly represent a presidential candidate? It depends on the typeface and the candidate. John McCain's printed material relies on Optima, a modernistic sans serif designed by the German type designer Hermann Zapf in 1958 that was popular among book and magazine designers during the 1970s.While it is not the most robust sans serif ever designed, it is not entirely neutral either. It embodies and signifies a certain spirit and attitude. And if a typeface is not just an empty vessel for meaning, but a signifier that underscores personality, then it is useful in understanding what the candidates' respective typefaces are saying about them and their campaigns.

In the Washington area, we are always hearing about the deer problem faced by suburban communities. The main complaint is the danger they pose to traffic. I wrote a piece on the subject in The Washington Post and received a flurry of letters from people angry at my seeming indifference to human safety, one woman telling me about her friends' daughter who had died in a deer-related car accident. Among the lesser complaints is that the deer are known to avail themselves of shrubbery adorning people's finely kept gardens, remorselessly nibbling away at the petunias and azaleas.

Land managers are aware of the catastrophic impact of super-abundant deer on tree regeneration and the loss of biodiversity in the metropolitan New York region's herbaceous forest wildflowers. Now another phenomenon, the loss of the woody shrub layer, has reached a critical stage across most of the region (outside the New Jersey Pine Barrens). Above-ground stems of native forest shrubs are relatively short-lived compared with the life span of the rootstock. Vigorous new shoots replace older, senescent stems on a regular basis.

Updated, April 22 | Readers of The New York Post may have noticed something different in the tabloid's pages on Monday: white space. The margins at the top and bottom of each page were significantly larger than usual, and the bottom of each inside page -- even the ones with advertisements -- was a thin strip advertisement.The change was not a printing error, but rather a dry run, if you will, for a change in the paper's look. Starting on Tuesday, The New York Post will be 12 inches high, down from 13½ inches now.

The reality charity competition has seen its ratings decline steadily after drawing 15.7 million viewers in its debut on March 2. Still, the finale managed to dominate its 8 p.m. time slot ahead of CBS's "Big Brother" (6.8 million) and NBC's "Monk" (5.7 million).

Ed and I both grew up eating salami and eggs. You cut thick slices of salami (Ed's right: kielbasa is better, but we didn't know that back then), into chunks and brown them a little bit. In Ed's household you would use that as the base of an omelette; in mine, you would scramble the eggs, keeping them soft, and top with mustard. (I don't usually disagree with Ed, but when he's wrong, I have to say so.) These were the delicacies that defined New York a half-century ago. --MB

The National City Corporation, the nation's tenth-largest bank, said on Monday that it plans to raise $7 billion from a group of investors as it seeks to shore up its balance sheet against continued trouble in the mortgage market. But the plan also involves slashing the bank's dividend and a big dilution of current shareholders.

Completing a six-day visit to the United States, Pope Benedict XVI flew back home on Sunday evening. BNP Paribas is in advanced talks to buy the equities prime brokerage unit of Bank of America in a move that would boost the French group's presence in the U.S. and enable its U.S. rival to scale down its investment banking business, The Financial Times.

Serena Williams won the Family Circle Cup title, defeating Vera Zvonareva, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, for her first clay-court title since the 2002 French Open. Williams’s third title of the year was expected to lift her to No. 6 in the rankings. She is 19-1 this year.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a medical journal study that raised concerns about electronic health records incompletely described the rules that currently govern the use of such records by medical researchers. As the article noted, the rules do bar researchers from access to individual patients’ identities. But an independent ethical review panel can allow exceptions.

An Inside The Times capsule summary on Wednesday of a Sports of The Times column, about protests related to the Olympics, misidentified the writer in some editions. The column was by George Vecsey, not Harvey Araton.

An art entry in the Listings pages on Friday for an exhibition of Gregory Crewdson’s photographs, at the Luhring Augustine gallery in Chelsea, misstated the title of the series to which the photographs belong, which is also the title of a book published by Abrams in conjunction with the exhibition. It is “Beneath the Roses,” not “Behind the Roses.”.
SUNDAY BUSINESS.

An article on Sunday about companies that missed Wall Street earnings estimates after a long history of exceeding them misstated General Electric’s results for the first quarter of this year. It earned $4.3 billion; it did not have a quarterly loss.

An article on Friday about anger across the globe over a food crisis misidentified the food item that was cut in price by 15 percent after Haiti’s president, René Préval, responded to the public outcry. It is rice, not sugar.

An article on Friday about Democratic superdelegates who said in a survey that they were unswayed by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s attacks on Senator Barack Obama in Wednesday’s Democratic debate in Philadelphia referred incorrectly to the nominating contest in Colorado won by Mr. Obama. It was a caucus, not a primary.

A chart on Wednesday with the Economic Scene column, about the relationship between income and personal satisfaction, misidentified the country shown with a gross domestic product of just under $8,000 per capita and a satisfaction score of just over 5. It was Iran, not Ireland. (As the chart correctly noted, Ireland has a gross domestic product of more than $32,000 per capita and a satisfaction score above 7.) A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/business.

A picture caption in some editions last Monday with an article about the New York Baseball Giants Nostalgia Society misidentified the Giants’ opponent and misstated the score for their final game at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 29, 1957. It was the Pirates — not the Phillies — and the Giants lost the game by 9-1, not 2-1. (The Phillies defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers that day, 2-1.).

A theater review on Friday about the musical “A Catered Affair” at the Walter Kerr Theater, which is based on the 1956 film “The Catered Affair,” as well as on the original Paddy Chayefsky teleplay, referred incorectly to a change in the plot. The character of the dead son who was killed in Korea did indeed exist in the film; it was not added for the musical. (The time of the death has been moved closer to the events portrayed in the musical.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a report by the Smithsonian Institution’s inspector general that concluded that a former director of the Smithsonian Latino Center committed ethical breaches misspelled the inspector general’s middle name. She is A. Sprightley Ryan, not Sprightly.

An article on Tuesday about concerns over the health of Harlan Chamberlain, the father of Yankees pitcher Joba Chamberlain, misstated part of the name of the hospital in Lincoln, Neb., where he was admitted last week. It is St. Elizabeth Regional Medical Center, not St. Vincent.

Anne marks the position of her ball and taps down her marker with her putter. Audrey marks the position of her ball, lifts her ball and walks to the hole to remove a twig. She walks back and crouches down to read her putt. She notices that her marker has stuck to her shoe. At the same time, Anne notices that her marker is missing and has stuck to the bottom of her putter when she tapped her marker down. Do Anne and Audrey incur any penalties?.
With Dean Reinmuth.

KIMMEL--Martin . MEF (Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc.) profoundly mourns the death of our patron and benefactor, Martin S. Kimmel, who with his beloved wife, Helen, gave unstintingly to music and musicians. He saw a need and provided for it without being asked. He gave funds that underwrote performances through MEF that provided critical work opportunities for musicians. He reached out to young and old with a generosity and care that embraced both body and spirit. Marty's and Helen's love of music and the arts are well known and his personal support brought performances to the stage that otherwise would not have made it. His generosity and love of music will live on for generations to come and the beauty and example of his life and his greatness are his legacy. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Helen, his son, Adam and his step-daughters, Abbey Leigh and Betsy Karel. Robert A. Behren, Esq., President Thomas W. Ledwith, Esq. Exec. Vice Pres. Marie M. Ashdown, Executive Director The Board of Directors of MEF

PHILADELPHIA -- The announcement that Phillies shortstop Jimmy Rollins had been placed on the disabled list came as sweet relief to the Mets on Sunday. As Rollins tried to play through an ankle injury, he had spent the past two series looming as a threat off the bench and in the Mets' heads. At the end of last season, Rollins gave voice to the Mets' epic collapse. He tormented them with his cocksure comments off the field and his M.V.P.-caliber play on it. But after spraining his left ankle in the Mets' home opener on April 8 -- right after helping complete a Phillies comeback with a run-scoring single in a 5-2 victory -- Rollins could no longer hurt them with his bat. Playing without him, the Phillies seemed to lose some of their edge.

VLADECK--Bobb C., M.D . He was a graduate of Columbia University, trained at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and did his residency at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Dr. Vladeck was a founding member of the American Association of Breast Surgeons and a fellow of the American College of Surgeons. Practicing medicine in Rockland County since 1974, Dr. Vladeck was Chief of Surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital. A kind and generous doctor, distin guished by his compassionate care, he was a loving and beloved husband to Cheryl, father to Andrew, Michael, Naomi and Eric Putter, grandfather to Sophie and Levi, and brother of Susan C. Vladeck and Amy V. Heinrich. Donations to: American Cancer Society.

FEDERICI--Danny , New York City, NY. Danny Federici, keyboard player for Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, died April 17, 2008 of melanoma. He is survived by his wife, Maya, his son Jason and his daughters, Harley and Madison. Federici, known to legions of fans as Phantom Dan, played with Springsteen for 40 years, beginning in the New Jersey band Steel Mill in 1968. He also recorded with several other artists, including Graham Parker, the Bodeans, Garland Jeffreys, Gary U.S. Bonds, and Joan Armatrading. Federici also made two solo jazz albums, Flemington and Out of a Dream. Often regarded as the heart of the E Street Band's sound, Danny Federici's distinctive work on organ, accordion and glockenspiel in classic E Street songs such as ''Sandy,'' ''Hungry Heart,'' ''Racing in the Street,'' ''independence Day,'' ''Fade Away'' and on the most recent album, Magic, ''Living in the Future'' makes him an eternal presence in Springsteen's music in particular and rock & roll in general. He will be missed but never forgotten. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be sent to aid melanoma research at their website, www.thedannyfederici melanomafund.com. Services will be held privately under the direction of the Holcombe-Fisher Funeral Home, 147 Main Street, Flemington, NJ. Please visit www.holcombefisher.com for further information or to send condolences.

FISHER--Bernard , of Tucson, AZ and Amagansett, NY. The Fisher Family mourns the passing at age 87, of their father, Bud, a retired private practice psychoanalyst/therapist and faculty professor at Cornell Medical School, Payne Whitney Institute. Preceded in death by his beloved wife Ellie; survived by his children, Dick Fisher (Sandra), Jane Fisher Hamilton (Dr. Allan), and grandchildren Josh, Luke, Tessa, Alexa, Zoe, Eliot, Isabella and Rebecca, his beloved brother Martin Fisher (Bernice) and his sister Rita Shapiro. Also survived by Judge Newton Greenberg and wife Emily. Bud died peacefully in the home he shared with his son Dick, daughter-in-law Sandra and their children, in Tucson, AZ on April 18th. He will be buried with honors for his service during WWII at Southern Arizona Veterans Memorial Cemetery following funeral services at 10am on Tuesday, April 22 at Brings Funeral Home in Tucson. FISHER--David W., died April 17, 2008, aged 81. He was Naomi's devoted husband for 55 years until her death last May. With extraordinary love and effort, he cared for her to the end, even as her spirit receded behind what he called ''the cruel cloud of Alzheimer's Disease.'' He was the loving father of Paul (Margaret Reid) and Robert (Yasmin Khakoo), and doting grandfather of M. Caitlin, Jeremy, Gillian, Alex and Aliya. In recent years he found great joy in the love and companionship of Maxine Rosen. He was the cherished uncle of Helen Freedman, Henry Edelstein and Daniel Edelstein. He also leaves behind loyal canine companions, Popcorn and Cody. A proud practitioner of print journalism -mainly medical -he cofounded Hospital Practice, where he was Editorial Director and president of Maclean Hunter Medical Communications group. A political activist, union organizer and delegate (for Eugene McCarthy) to the 1968 Democratic Convention, he will be remembered for his compassion, decency and commitment to social and economic justice; he will also be remembered for his puns sometimes good, sometimes bad (mostly by his account), but always entertaining. Avid tennis player and lifelong Yankee fan, lover of language and of life, he took great pleasure in sharing these passions with his children, grandchildren and other loved ones. To those whose lives he touched, he was not merely a presence but a force -often irresistible and now terribly irreplaceable. The family extends special thanks to the physicians, nurses and staff of the Cardiothoracic ICU, Stony Brook University Hospital, for their valiant efforts and compassionate care and support during his final struggle.

GILFORD--Madeline Lee . The much beloved actor, writer and producer of the N.Y. theatre scene for over 50 years, passed away in her home on Tuesday in her 85th year. Maddy has been celebrated for her tireless support of the theatre community as an advisor, friend and cheerleader to countless numbers of aspiring creative artists. She and her late husband, Jack Gilford, were famously blacklisted during the McCarthy era. She is survived by her three children, Lisa, Joe and Sam, and three grandchildren, Max, Molly and Jacob.

A memorial service celebrating Caroline Pezzullo's life and 60 year commitment to people centered international development will be held Tuesday April 22 from 10am-noon at the Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th St. in Manhattan. A lifelong social activist and movement builder, Caroline represented SID and chaired the human settlements NGO committee at the UN. TOKYO POLICE CLUB ''Elephant Shell'' (Saddle Creek) Tokyo Police Club, a four-piece postpunk band from the vicinity of Toronto, caused something of a stir in indie circles with ''A Lesson in Crime'' (Paper Bag), an urgent EP released two years ago. (It opened with this salvo: ''Operator? Get me the President of the World! This is an emergency!'') The terse assuredness of the EP, along with some subsequent touring, fueled anticipation for the group's full-length debut. Now, finally, here it is: ''Elephant Shell,'' a first album that feels an awful lot like a second one.

WHEN Bertrand de Frondeville, a retired nuclear engineer who lives in Rye, N.Y., discovered that his wife, Barbara, a former teacher, had in her 403(b) tax-sheltered account annuities that are already tax sheltered, he was alarmed. He knew that the assets were not being used to their best advantage, so he set to work restructuring the investments. Investors like the de Frondevilles who are nearing retirement or retired have already sorted out their asset allocation -- that is, they have achieved a balance of equities and fixed income that will produce stable growth for their portfolios and allow them to rest easily at night. But as the de Frondevilles have discovered, that's only the first step to sound portfolio management. Investors must also consider asset location.

The influence of Internet radio, where listeners can find broadcast radio that is streamed over the Web as well as Web-only music, is growing. A survery conducted in January and February by Edison Media Research found that 13 percent of Americans listened to radio on the Internet each week, up from 11 percent the previous year. More listeners in 2008 chose the Internet as the place they ''turn to first to learn about new music,'' and 25 percent went online for new music, up from 9 percent in 2007. SHELLY FREIERMAN

MASSAR--Phyllis Garland , died peacefully in her home on April 18, 2008 surrounded by her loving family. Born in Brooklyn on January 29, 1926, she graduated from Cornell University in 1947 and earned an MLS from Pratt Institute in 1970. She worked at the Ferguson Library in Stamford, CT for 36 years. An active, lively and beloved mother, grandmother and friend, Phyllis will be remembered for her enthusiasm, intrepid travels, warm hospitality and professional dedication. Her family and many friends delighted in her humor, sharp wit and passion for books, music, theater and museums. She is survived by her daughters, Susan, Betsy and Andrea; her sons-in-law, David Dollar and Jeremiah Cassidy and her grandsons, Noah and Matthew Cassidy. She will be dearly missed by all those she touched.

BLUMBERG--Herbert Kurt , age 82, of Edgartown, MA and Longwood, FL, died peacefully April 17, 2008 after a long illness. Kurt is survived by his loved and loving wife of 58 years, Doris Gaines Blumberg; his children, Kurt Eric, Ann Catherine and Charles Newton, their spouses, Lynn Blumberg, Stephen Graham and Norma Benardette; his sister, Adelaide Reisfeld; grandchildren, Kurt Scott and Christopher and step-grandchildren, Lillian, Emily and Caroline Graham; and his beloved West Highland Terrier, Skeeter. A graduate of Princeton University, class of 1946, Kurt served honorably in the US Army Infantry in the Pacific during WWII. He joined the Navy Reserve following the war, and retired as a Captain in 1981. A business executive for more than 50 years, he began his career at R.H. Macy and Company and was the General Manager of WNEWTV in New York, a part of Metromedia, a company that owned radio and television stations around the country. With degrees in Political Science and Engineering, as Chairman and CEO, he led Irvin Industries, a global manufacturer of automotive and aerospace equipment. Under his leadership from 1966 to 1989, Irvin built on its legacy as an innovator in parachute systems design to manufacture products ranging from automobile seat belts, slings for cargo handling, and canning machinery. He was especially proud of Irvin's contributions to life saving driving and flying safety equipment. He was an honorary member of the Caterpillar Club, an association founded by Irvin in the 1920s to recognize people who successfully used a parachute to bail out of a disabled aircraft. He was also an influential advocate for the first seat belt legislation in the United States. He was member of the Board of Advisors of the Peter J. Tobin College of Business at St. John's University. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to either of these conservation organizations: The Sheriff's Meadow Foundation, Wakeman Conservation Center, 57 David Ave, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568 (www.sherrifsmeadow.org) or Friends of Sengekontacket, Inc., PO Box 740, Edgartown, MA 02539 (www.senge kontacket.org. Memorial services in Edgartown and New York are planned.

WEISS--Stephen H . The Board of Tulane University and the entire Tulane community deeply mourn the death of Stephen H. Weiss. Steve was a thoughtful, caring and engaging man of many interests and achievements whose primary enjoyment in life was derived from the love of his family and his passion for helping others. His philanthropy and dedication to education spanned the country from his devotion to his alma mater, Cornell University, to his service and leadership ofTulane University where, as a member of the Board of Tulane, he provided extraordinary advice and support. Steve's breadth of knowledge and vision was critical to Tulane's recovery from Hurricane Katrina, as he lent his expertise and wisdom to the governance, development, investment, athletics and health sciences committees of the Board of Tulane. Indeed, there was not a single aspect of Tulane life that did not benefit from Steve's inspired guidance and stewardship. His generosity to Tulane always had as its focus the Tulane student and included the establishment of the Suzanne and Stephen Weiss Presidential Fellowships for Undergraduate Teaching. This annual award honors and provides funding to faculty members who have displayed sustained, inspired and distinguished teaching of undergraduate students. In addition to his support of teaching and in keeping with his abiding care for the development of the ''whole'' Tulane student, Steve, whose son is a member of the Tulane baseball team, also had a great love for Tulane athletics, which he supported through both his generosity and passionate attendance at games. We treasure our all-too-brief relationship with him and will forever miss his guidance, his laughter, his friendship and his love for Tulane University. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Suzanne and his children Heather, Michael, Jonathan and Nathalie. Philip Greer, Chair of the Board, Tulane University Scott S. Cowen, President, Tulane University

EVEN for people who have built up a decent nest egg, deciding how to use it is one of the demands of early retirement. The good life may be within reach, but the financial logistics still require careful attention. ''We were thinking, We've got the time now, but how do we finance it?'' said Cathy Odlaug, recalling how she felt two years ago when her husband, Bruce, went part time at his Minneapolis law firm, giving up his partnership and 60 percent of his income.

EDWARD M. HOUGHTON, a human resources executive at Pitney Bowes, was sick of traffic jams and unpredictable hours. Bina Kozak, who matches patients to cardiologists at a Scripps Health clinic in San Diego, wanted to volunteer for nonprofit agencies. James M. Wing, a pharmacist for CVSCaremark in Cincinnati, hated Ohio's harsh winters. Each planned to retire last year. Back in the 20th century, their companies would have probably sent them off with gratitude and maybe a gold watch.

WITH his longtime New York City estate and business law practice winding down, Robert Rubinger was ready to retire five years ago, at age 76. But his wife, Nancy, who was then 66, was not. Ms. Rubinger had started working at a nonprofit organization only 13 years earlier, after the couple's two children were grown. ''I was really having a very good time,'' she said. ''I find it extremely gratifying to help people.''

In the aftermath of the debate on Wednesday, support for Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama remains close among Democratic voters, according to the latest Gallup tracking poll. The nationwide poll cannot be used to suggest the level of support either candidate may have on Tuesday in the Pennsylvania primary or in any of the other remaining statewide contests. The Gallup poll was conducted April 17-19 with 1,252 voters nationwide who said they were Democrats or leaned Democratic. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Gallup's general election matchups, based on interviews conducted April 15-19, also suggest a close contest between either Democrat and the presumptive Republican nominee, Senator John McCain. Gallup's daily tracking poll results are available at www.gallup.com.

In January, I called the effort by Jerry Yang and Sue Decker to justify the company's weak performance a "droning, jargon-filled" explication of a "vision-goes-here strategy." Two days later, a letter from Redmond arrived with an offer that Yahoo is still working hard to refuse.

Multichannel News: The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences will hand out a new Emmy Award this fall: "outstanding host for a reality or reality competition program." The 60th annual prime time Emmys will be held on Sept. 21.

Associated Press: "Showtime's The Tudors and star Jonathan Rhys Meyers will return for a third season, with production set to begin in June in Ireland." The show is midway through its second year. The next season will air in 2009.

The Pennsylvania Democrats who cast their ballots in Tuesday's primary did so with the economy weighing heavily on their minds, according to surveys of voters leaving polling places. Those surveys showed that more than half the voters questioned believe that the worsening state of the American economy is the most important issue confronting the country, with about 90 percent saying the United States has already slipped into a recession.

It might feel a bit like déjà vu, but it's official - no cellphones allowed in public schools. The Appellate Court has ruled that the Department of Education has the right to enforce a cellphone ban, despite the outcry from students and their parents. The battle has been waged for several years, with parents claiming that it was a violation of constitutional rights and that because they were unable to reach their children by phone, their safety was being endangered.

Yes, I know, we have some pending business. But the New York weather has been so gorgeous recently that I can't help thinking about German riesling. Every spring, when the weather really begins to turn, I start thirsting for German riesling. This year, though, I was thinking about dry rieslings because I've had a fair number of really good ones in the last few months. You can read my column on dry German rieslings in the newspaper on Wednesday.
Watching the Champions League semifinal first-leg match between Liverpool and Chelsea on TV here at The New York Times sports desk, four things jump out at me:

Felix Salmon links us to an article pointing out that fertilizer is made mainly from natural gas, which tends to follow the price of oil, which may be a good part of the reason we're seeing food prices spike along with oil.
April's chorus of concern on the intensifying worldwide food crisis was punctuated today with a World Food Programme news release headlined "The silent tsunami."

In what is certainly a smart move developmentally, the Miami Dolphins have signed Michigan tackle Jake Long and will select him with the first pick in Saturday's draft. (Although wouldn't it be great if, just for fun, they gave Roger Goodell a card with Matt Ryan's name on it?)

On an April afternoon in Paris, worker bees hum on the southwestern edge of the Jardin du Luxembourg while human workers simply loll. There's something hypnotic about pulling up a metal chair at lunch time in the park to watch the ongoing dramas of a live bee apiary while basking in the spring sun.

We are in a new gilded age (though this is not a good time to remind us how the first one ended), and the weddings have blossomed to match. There was no better place to witness that phenomenon on Monday than the Wedding Salon, a luxury bridezilla convention that was founded by Tatiana Byron and held at Gotham Hall. The entrance fee was $75, but women (almost all were women) lined up around the block. By the end of the day, about 2,800 people marched through the hall to talk with florists, caterers and honeymoon specialists.In New York, luxury weddings are taken to another level: more personalized, more indulgent. A New York wedding could easily run in excess of $100,000, compared to $28,000 for the nationwide average, Ms. Byron said. (Of course, cost is all relative, as some cultures are arguably even more demanding that a wedding be celebrated in grand style).

ALBANY -- Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has announced the appointment of Sharon L. McCarthy, a former prosecutor for the United States Attorney's Office, as special counsel for the investigation into possible political interference in the New York State Police.Mrs. McCarthy spent 12 years in the United States Attorney's Office in the Southern District, where as Deputy Chief of the Criminal Division and later Chief of the Violent Crimes unit, she focused on violent crime, organized crime and corruption.

Yahoo did just well enough in the first quarter for it to be able to hold its head up high as it tries to justify its continued rejection of Microsoft's hostile bid. The company's earnings, after special charges, were 11 cents a share, compared to the 9 cents that analysts had forecast. Its revenue, excluding payments to sites that display its ads, were $1.35 billion, $30 million more than analysts expected.

But if anyone was going to push book promotion to the max, it was bound to be Crosley, who works by day as publicist for Vintage/Anchor books. I grew up in America hearing tales of epic concerts in Bombay. She remembers jazz festivals and outdoor Indian classical festivals that evolved into spontaneous, lively jam sessions and stretched into the early hours of morning.

Manolo Blahnik has helped out during many a crisis of footwear, but coming to the aid of Thai elephants? It's not such a stretch for the shoemaker, who just debuted a special-edition stiletto to benefit the Golden Triangle Asian Elephant Foundation. Blahnik got involved after Carolyn Butler, the owner of the Napa Valley shoe shop Footcandy, vacationed with her husband at the Four Seasons Tented Camp in northern Thailand. Butler fell in love with the resort's resident elephants and later convinced Blahnik to create the shoes, a pair of sexy pony-hair, leopard-print pumps with patent leather trim, three-and-a-half-inch heels and an open toe. All proceeds from the $645 shoes, which are sold exclusively at Footcandy (and can be shipped anywhere), go toward creating a safe haven for abused elephants.

Tacos are so simple you wonder why supermarkets sell kits to make them. Most often the filling is ground beef, but there is a lighter way: tacos with fish.

Updated, 12:51 p.m. | An off-duty New York City correction officer was shot and killed early this morning in what appeared to be a robbery, possibly over a motorcycle, in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. The shooting occurred at Avenue A and East 87th Street, in the 67th Precinct, the police said.

Warner Brothers Television Group and Time Inc., two media units of Time Warner, are teaming up in an effort to turn Essence magazine into a multimedia brand for African-American women. The companies will first re-launch Essence.com, then turn their attention to television.

Last week, city officials disclosed that the building under construction at 303 East 51st Street, where a tower crane collapsed on March 15, killing seven people, should never have received permits because its design conflicted with zoning regulations. An uproar ensued, and today, Charles V. Bagli and Diane Cardwell report that the pressure on the Buildings Department shows no signs of abating. To the department's critics, the mishandled permits -- along with an increase in fatal construction accidents this year and other high-profile problems -- raise sharp new questions about Buildings Commissioner Patricia J. Lancaster, an architect hired by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to modernize the 1,286-person agency.
Six weeks of solid campaigning for this day. The polls are finally open in Pennsylvania. They close at 8 p.m.
The Royal Bank of Scotland on Tuesday said that it planned to raise 12 billion pounds ($23.7 billion) through the sale of shares to existing investors in an attempt to bolster its capital position.

Warburg Pincus, appearing to shrug off the credit squeeze that has made life harder for many of its buyout rivals, said Tuesday that it raised $15 billion for its new global fund, easily surpassing its $12 billion target.
The Tribune Company has reached agreement in principle to sell Newsday to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation for about $580 million in what would be a joint venture, according to press reports.

UBS, which has written off more debt from the subprime crisis than any other bank, conceded in a report on Monday that a blind drive for revenue led the Swiss financial giant to take more risks than it should have.

Citigroup on Monday sold $6 billion of preferred shares to shore up its balance sheet after the largest United States bank recorded over $16 billion in write-downs and credit losses in the first quarter.
Air France-KLM said Monday that its offer to buy the struggling Italian airline Alitalia for 139 million euros ($220 million) was "no longer valid."
The bill for the credit mess keeps rising.

Lee Kun Hee, Samsung Group's chairman, indicted on tax evasion charges, announced Tuesday that he would step down after 20 years of leadership, during which Samsung soared to become South Korea's best-known global brand but was dogged by corruption scandals.

Just four months after Rupert Murdoch took control of Dow Jones, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal, the newspaper's top editor, Marcus W. Brauchli, is expected to step down, according to reports.
Hedge fund assets barely grew during the first quarter as losses and deleveraging made investors wary of allocating new money to the industry, Hedge Fund Research said Monday.

National City Corporation's stock took a beating Monday as investors worried about the dilution from the bank's $7 billion bailout by a consortium led by Corsair Capital. But Fortune.com argues that it may be the private equity investors that finds themselves on the wrong end of the deal.
In Philadelphia, Chelsea Clinton was called on to answer her assertion that her mother would be a better president than her father had been.

A little less than two weeks to the Derby and we have seen a number of the contenders complete their next-to-last piece of work. This is typically five-eighths of a mile, although a few worked a half-mile or up to seven-eighths of a mile. Depending on the circumstances, this will be the last serious work. The final work, early during Derby week, will be a light tuneup to enable the horse to get a little more wind and stretch his legs. It would be silly to try to work a horse to gain more fitness the week of its biggest race. The horse should be fit now.

An article in some editions on Friday about the Giants’ plans heading into the N.F.L. draft misstated a postseason statistic for the team’s promising young tight end, Kevin Boss, and gave the wrong timing for one of his performances against the Patriots. He had five, not eight, postseason catches. And four of those catches, including one for a touchdown, came in the final regular-season game against New England — not in the Super Bowl victory, in which he had one catch for 45 yards.

An article on Sunday about the Pentagon’s relationship with news media military analysts misidentified the military affiliation of one analyst, John C. Garrett. He retired as a colonel from the Marines, not the Army.

The Books of The Times review on Monday, about “Bad Money: Reckless Finance, Failed Politics and the Global Crisis of American Capitalism,” by Kevin Phillips, misidentified the era of Britain’s decline in which Mr. Phillips has seen parallels with the current situation in the United States. It was the early 20th century, not the early 19th century.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the many sports books claiming to chronicle the best or greatest game misidentified, in some editions, the author of “The Boys of Winter,” about the United States hockey team’s defeat of the Soviets at the 1980 Winter Olympics. He is Wayne Coffey — not Charles J. Sanders, whose book with the same title is about United States ski troops in World War II.
SPORTS.

An obituary on April 7 and in some copies on April 6 about the actor Charlton Heston misstated the year he enlisted in the Army Air Forces, as well as other aspects of his life. He enlisted in 1942, not 1944. He served in the Aleutian Islands about two years, not three. And he and his wife, the former Lydia Clarke, an actress, spent less than one year, not several seasons, at the Thomas Wolfe Memorial Theater in Asheville, N.C., which they founded after the war.
A rejuvenated river has turned once barren Oklahoma City into an unlikely mecca for elite water sports.

An article in some editions on Friday about a meeting between Madison Square Garden officials and advocacy groups to discuss concerns over the shouting of antigay slurs at Rangers games referred imprecisely to the role of Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, in addressing the issue. Although she helped arrange the meeting, she was not present. The article also omitted part of the name of an advocacy group. It is the New York City Gay Hockey Association.

A picture caption on April 13 with an article about lessons that the privatization of the Indiana East-West Toll Road might hold for New Jersey — whose governor, Jon S. Corzine, wants to lease his state’s toll roads — misidentified the toll plaza shown. It was the eastern entrance to the Chicago Skyway, not the western end of the Indiana toll road.

It is Positive Nature, not Perfect Nature.

Ivan Dominguez, a Cuban riding for Toyota-United, won the 71.8-mile opening stage of the weeklong Tour de Georgia, sprinting across the finish line a tenth of a second ahead of a crowded peloton. Dominguez finished the stage from Tybee Island to Savannah in 2 hours 30 minutes 18 seconds.

Edgar Prado, seventh on the career earnings list and only the fourth rider with more than 500 victories in a season when he rode 535 in 1997, was named as part of a class of six for induction into the National Museum of Racing Hall of Fame. Prado rode Barbaro to a Kentucky Derby victory in 2006.

First Quantum Minerals, a Canadian miner of copper in Zambia and Congo, agreed to buy Scandinavian Minerals for about 281 million Canadian dollars ($280 million) to add a nickel mine in Finland. Scandinavian Minerals investors will receive 9 Canadian dollars in cash and 0.01 of a common share of First Quantum for each share they hold, First Quantum said. The offer values Scandinavian Minerals at 41 percent higher than its April 18 closing price. The transaction will give First Quantum, which is based in Vancouver, full control of the Kevitsa property in northern Finland, which has as much as 831 million metric tons of nickel-ore resources on an indicated and inferred basis, according to Scandinavian Minerals.

Nestlé reported a 6 percent increase in sales in the first quarter, helped by organic growth and acquisitions. Nestlé, the world’s biggest food and drink company, said sales reached 25.7 billion Swiss francs ($25.21 billion) in the three months ended March 31, up from 24.25 billion francs in the period last year, beating analyst expectations. Sales were bolstered by acquisitions, particularly of the Gerber baby food unit and the medical nutrition business from Novartis, the company said. The company, which reports profit figures only for the half year and full year, said organic growth rose 9.8 percent, from 7.4 percent.

A former executive with Wal-Mart, Allan Leighton, became president of Canada’s largest grocery retailer, the Loblaw Companies, on Monday. Once known for its innovation, Loblaw has stumbled recently as the company deals with Wal-Mart Canada’s gradual move into the grocery business. Mr. Leighton, left, was the chief executive of Asda Stores, a British supermarket chain, when it was acquired by Wal-Mart in 1996. He was subsequently made president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Europe and later became nonexecutive chairman of the Royal Mail of Britain. The Weston family of Toronto, who control Loblaw as well as several businesses in Britain, brought Mr. Leighton to the Canadian chain as deputy chairman in 2006, a position he will retain. Mark Foote, the company’s president and chief merchandising officer, has left Loblaw, the company said, as has Pietro Satriano, its executive vice president for food.

The Ford Motor Company will add 1,500 workers at a Russian factory to increase production in that country by almost 75 percent, the company said. Ford plans to increase capacity at the Vsevolozhsk plant near St. Petersburg to 125,000 vehicles next year, a spokeswoman in Moscow, Ekaterina Kulinenko, said. The factory produces the Focus hatchback, Russia’s best-selling foreign-brand car in 2007, and will start making the midsize Mondeo this year, Ms. Kulinenko said.

10 P.M. (Discovery) THE ALASKA EXPERIMENT Goodbye, city life! Sheltered by cabins or canvas tents and bolstered by minimum rations of dry food, four groups of urban dwellers (above, the Wise family) try to survive in the Alaskan wilderness for three months. That means hunting big game, catching salmon and adjusting to life without power, running water or modern conveniences in a region where 40-below temperatures and 200 inches of rainfall annually are the norm, and the only blackberries are the ones growing on bushes. 6 P.M. SIEFERT--Harry W. October 13, 1919-April 20, 2008. Harry William Siefert, 88, died April 20 at his home in Chapel Hill, NC. A 33-year resident of Chapel Hill, he moved to Carolina Meadows in July 2006. Born October 13, 1919, in Philadelphia, he was educated by the Philadelphia school system and the University of Pennsylvania. In 1943 he successfully qualified as a Certified Public Accountant. He began his career with the accounting firm of Fernald and Company, then spent seven years with Lybrand, Ross Brothers and Montgomery (now Price Waterhouse Coopers). Leaving public accounting, he joined the controllers department of The Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company. He also was employed by American Standard, Inc., National Lead Company, CNA Financial, and finally The Liggett Group, from which he retired in January 1982 as Senior Vice President of Finance and a Director. After his retirement, he and his wife spent winters at their residence in Naples, Florida, where he enjoyed golf and dancing at the Country Club of Naples. He was formerly a member of the Chapel Hill Rotary, Chapel Hill Country Club, and Croasdaile Country Club. Harry Siefert is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Margaret Metzler of St. David's, Pennsylvania, daughters Joan Siefert Rose (Jim) of Chapel Hill and Janet Siefert Goss (Edgar) of New York City, and grandsons Andy and Ian Rose of Chapel Hill. The family will receive visitors at 304 Magnolia Drive, Carolina Meadows, from 2-4pm Saturday, April 26. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Carolina Friends School, 4809 Friends School Road, Durham, NC 27705.

RIMSKY--Robert , beloved husband of Renee Svigals Rimsky and the late Jeanne Meyers Rimsky, and loving father of Rena Wing, Douglas, Lee and Don, passed away peacefully in his home on April 18, at the age of 87. He is also survived by his children's spouses, 2 stepchildren Dr. Paul Svigals and Susan Kirschenbaum and their spouses, 12 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He is a graduate of the Townsend Harris High School, Rutgers University and Harvard Business School. Bob served as a Naval Supply Officer during World War II. He worked with his father in the garment district and continued the tradition his father started of building the business through intelligence, diligence and trustworthiness. Bob became Chairman of Lucerene Textiles and changed the textile industry through his revolutionary business approach. He created the Lucerene Foundation for his family's philanthropic interests. Contributions included: North Shore Hospital for the Rimsky Center for Surgery, North Shore Child & Family Guidance Center for the Renee and Robert Rimsky Abuse Prevention and Treatment Center, Landmark on Main Street in Port Washington, NY, for the Jeanne Rimsky Theater, and Playwrights Horizons Theater in New York, NY. Friends may visit Monday 6-9pm and Tuesday and Wednesday 12-5 and 7-9 at their LI home. Donations in his memory may be made to any of the organizations Bob supported. RIMSKY--Robert. In memory of Robert Rimsky, generous long-time supporter and an advocate for children, youth and families. The North Shore Child & Family Guidance Center ''family'' honors his legacy and offers condolences to his family and friends. Andrew Malekoff, Executive Director/CEO Jo-Ellen Hazan, President RIMSKY--Robert. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend Bob Rimsky. Our thoughts are with his beloved wife, Renee and his entire family. Rochelle and Hal RIMSKY--Robert. A special man who will be missed by all who were privileged to know him. Sincere condolences to his wife, Renee and the entire family. Renee and Paul Lawrence and family.

RAPOPORT--Carl A. , 91, of West Hartford, CT. Carl Rapoport died peacefully at home on April 20, with his family by his side. He was born January 2, 1917, and graduated from New York University in 1937. After serving honorably in the Navy, escorting Franklin Roosevelt to Yalta aboard the USS Carmick, he entered the glass business, and in 1962 founded Merchants Glass Distributors in Lynbrook. After 30 successful years, he retired to his art, creating 300 welded steel sculptures exhibited in galleries and shows throughout the NY area. His wife of 57 years, Florence (Rosenberg), taught high school English for 26 years in Great Neck, where they lived. They loved each other, traveled extensively, and enjoyed a full life of friends and family. She predeceased him in 2002. Carl is survived by two brothers: Morris, of Scarsdale and his wife Blanche, and Bernard of New York. Also, two sons: Mark, Pediatrician and former Health Commissioner of Westchester County, and now of Hanoi, Vietnam, creator of 54 Traditions, a gallery of tribal art, and his wife, Jane Hughes; and Miles, of West Hartford, CT, President of the public policy center Demos and former Secretary of the State of CT, and his wife, Sandra (Sam) Luciano. Carl was beloved by four grandchildren; Robert Rapoport, Alison Rapoport, Jeff Luciano, and Ross Rapoport. Funeral services will take place at Weinstein Mortuary in Hartford on April 23, at 1:00. On April 24, a graveside service will be held at United Hebrew Cemetery on Arthur Kill Rd, Staten Island at 1:00, followed by a gathering of friends and family at La Strada Restaurant, 139 New Dorp Lane.

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 4-7 pm Tuesday. Service at the Funeral Home on Wednesday, April 23 at 11am.

WEISS--Stephen . The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Stephen Weiss, who expressed an unwavering commitment to strengthening the Jewish community, in New York, in Israel, and around the world. Stephen's philanthropic spirit will continue to touch the lives of many for years to come. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Suzanne; his children, Heather, Michael, Jonathan, and Nathalie; and to the entire Weiss Family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO WEISS--Stephen H. The Board of Tulane University and the entire Tulane community deeply mourn the death of Stephen H. Weiss. Steve was a thoughtful, caring and engaging man of many interests and achievements whose primary enjoyment in life was derived from the love of his family and his passion for helping others. His philanthropy and dedication to education spanned the country from his devotion to his alma mater, Cornell University, to his service and leadership of Tulane University where, as a member of the Board of Tulane, he provided extraordinary advice and support. Steve's breadth of knowledge and vision was critical to Tulane's recovery from Hurricane Katrina, as he lent his expertise and wisdom to the governance, development, investment, athletics and health sciences committees of the Board of Tulane. Indeed, there was not a single aspect of Tulane life that did not benefit from Steve's inspired guidance and stewardship. His generosity to Tulane always had as its focus the Tulane student and included the establishment of the Suzanne and Stephen Weiss Presidential Fellowships for Undergraduate Teaching. This annual award honors and provides funding to faculty members who have displayed sustained, inspired and distinguished teaching of undergraduate students. In addition to his support of teaching and in keeping with his abiding care for the development of the ''whole'' Tulane student, Steve, whose son is a member of the Tulane baseball team, also had a great love for Tulane athletics, which he supported through both his generosity and passionate attendance at games. We treasure our all-too-brief relationship with him and will forever miss his guidance, his laughter, his friendship and his love for Tulane University. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Suzanne and his children Heather, Michael, Jonathan and Nathalie. Philip Greer, Chair of the Board, Tulane University Scott S. Cowen, President, Tulane University

GILFORD--Madeline Lee . The much beloved actor, writer and producer of the N.Y. theatre scene for over 50 years, passed away in her home on Tuesday in her 85th year. Maddy has been celebrated for her tireless support of the theatre community as an advisor, friend and cheerleader to countless numbers of aspiring creative artists. She and her late husband, Jack Gilford, were famously blacklisted during the McCarthy era. She is survived by her three children, Lisa, Joe and Sam, and three grandchildren, Max, Molly and Jacob. Contributions in her memory may be to Actors Fund of America.

EPSTEIN--Natalie . We mourn the loss of our beloved mother, grandmother, great grandmother and sister, Natalie Epstein of Cedarhurst, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Natalie, 85, passed away peacefully at her Cedarhurst home on Monday, April 21st, 2008. Natalie was the beloved wife of the late Morton Carlin and Sidney Epstein and loving partner of Irwin Blocker. Natalie's funeral will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY at 10am on Wednesday April 23rd. Interment will follow at Beth-David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Natalie was an extraordinary person who brought happiness, love and friendship into every relationship. Her optimism and positivity was inspiring. Natalie is survived by her children Jeffrey, Christine, Neil, Peter, Carole, Jane and Martha. Natalie was also a proud and loving grandmother to Benjamin, Jessica, Melissa, Michael, Matthew, Shelby, Hunter and Marilyn and greatgrandmother to Sam, Jack and Gabriel. She is also survived by many friends, cousins, nieces and other extended family. Natalie was an accomplished businesswoman and was highly creative and expert in both knitting and sewing. We remember her with love, admiration and affection. She was truly a woman of valor.

JOHNSON--Malcolm , of Bronxville, NY, age 94, died April 16, 2008. He was the beloved husband of Janet Morse Johnson for 67 years; father of Judith Johnson Smith, M. Davis Johnson, Martha Johnson Bays, Frank Johnson; grandfather of Peter Smith, Heather Thiry, Jennifer Sober, Bonnie Johnson, Carter Bays, Abigail Bays, Sarah Johnson, Lucy Johnson, Malcolm Johnson; and greatgrandfather of four. Malcolm was a founding partner of the law firm of Everett, Johnson and Breckinridge and a frequent lecturer on federal taxation. He received an A.B. from Princeton University, 1934, and a J.D. from the University of Louisville, 1937. He served as Navy CIC officer on a destroyer in World War II during the Okinawa campaign. Malcolm exemplified devotion to his community as a member of the choir for over 40 years and the Consistory of the Reformed Church, a past president of the Bronxville School Board and of the Public Health Nursing Organization of Eastchester. A memorial service will be held at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on May 2, at 3pm. Memorial gifts may be made to the Reformed Church Music Fund or Princeton University.

A Moscow court sentenced an American pastor to more than three years and two months in prison for bringing a box of ammunition into Russia. The pastor, Phillip H. Miles, left, an evangelist from Christ Community Church in Conway, S.C., had been confined to a Moscow jail since his arrest on Feb. 3. He was charged with failing to declare a $25 box of rounds he intended to as a gift to a fellow pastor and hunting enthusiast in Perm, a city in the Ural Mountains, where he was involved in missionary work. ''I'm very disappointed,'' Mr. Miles said after his sentencing, The Associated Press reported. ''It's a strange sentence for one box of hunting bullets.'' Customs officials stopped Mr. Miles when he arrived at Moscow's Sheremetyevo Airport on Jan. 29. He was accused of failing to declare the ammunition but allowed to continue on to Perm. He was arrested when he returned to the airport five days later. The State Department said through a spokeswoman in Washington that diplomats in Moscow would continue to raise Mr. Miles's case with Russian officials. His lawyer said he would appeal.

A 150,000-ton Japanese oil tanker was damaged by an unspecified projectile when it was fired on by a small unidentified boat in the Gulf of Aden off Yemen as it was heading for Saudi Arabia to pick up a load of oil, said the tanker's owner, Nippon Yusen. There were no injuries, the company said, and the movement of the tanker, which was not carrying oil when it was attacked, was not impaired. Japan's coast guard said the projectile appeared to be a rocket, though information was still limited, according to local media reports. The attack rattled the nerves of global energy traders, sending the price of benchmark light, sweet crude to a record $117.40 per barrel. Oil prices had also briefly touched $117 per barrel last week, after rebels attacked a pipeline in Nigeria, Africa's largest oil producer.

SALTON--Milton R. J., Ph.D. The Board of Trustees, faculty, staff, and students of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the death of Milton R. J. Salton, Ph.D., Professor Emeritus and former Chairman of the Department of Microbiology. An expert on the microbial cell wall, Dr. Salton's distinguished career at NYU spanned nearly 30 years. He was one of the first to utilize detergents to solubilize bacterial membrane proteins, and his work helped to determine the nature of the gram stain and the action of penicillin on the bacterial cell wall. To his wife Joy, children Stephen and Alastair, and grandsons Gregory and Alexander, our sincere sympathies. Robert I. Grossman, M.D. Dean & CEO NYU Langone Medical Center

Donald R. Diamond, a wealthy Arizona real estate developer, was racing to snap up a stretch of virgin California coast freed by the closing of an Army base a decade ago when he turned to an old friend, Senator John McCain. When Mr. Diamond wanted to buy land at the base, Fort Ord, Mr. McCain assigned an aide who set up a meeting at the Pentagon and later stepped in again to help speed up the sale, according to people involved and a deposition Mr. Diamond gave for a related lawsuit. When he appealed to a nearby city for the right to develop other property at the former base, Mr. Diamond submitted Mr. McCain's endorsement as ''a close personal friend.''

SPOTNITZ--Hyman, Dr. , died of natural causes in Manhattan on Friday, April 18, 2008, at age 99. A research psychiatrist, neurologist and the founder of Modern Psychoanalysis, he grew up in Boston. He received a B.A. from Harvard, an M.D. from Friedrich Wilhelms University (Berlin), and a D.Med.Sci. from Columbia P & S. He was certified in Psychiatry and Neurology in 1941. He was married to Miriam Berkman, his childhood sweetheart, until her death in 1977. They had three sons. Dr. Spotnitz believed that psychoanalysis could cure narcissistic disorders that Freud deemed untreatable. Dr. Spotnitz believed schizophrenia was reversible. He sought a cure in private practice and in collaborative research and supervision at the Jewish Board of Guardians. ''In Modern Psychoanalysis of the Schizophrenic Patient (1969),'' he described a theory and technique for treatment. His career included research at the N.Y. State Neurological Institute and the N.Y. State Psychiatric Institute. He was Adjunct Psychiatrist at Mount Sinai and the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was honorary President of the Center forModern Psychoanalytic Studies, The Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis and the MidManhattan Institute for Psychoanalysis. His books include ''Psychotherapy of Preoedipal Conditions,'' and, with Phyllis Meadow, Ph.D., ''Treatment of the Narcissistic Neuroses.'', ''The Couch and the Circle (1961)'' and other books were aimed at a general audience. He published over 100 articles and was a distinguished supervisor, training analyst, lecturer and group psychoanalyst. He received the Sigmund Freud Award from the American Society of Psychoanalytic Physicians (1988) and was honored by the American Psychiatric Association for 50 years of service (1991). His last videotaped interview was released in 1999. He lived with his wife, Dorothy Harten Spotnitz until her death in 2007. He is survived by his loving family, Drs. Henry, Alan, and William Spotnitz, Dr. Elizabeth Goldberg, Drs. Sharon Spotnitz, Arlene Bonapace, and Denise Schain, and Mr. Richard Goldberg. He is also survived by his loving grandchildren, Margo, Jennifer, Michelle, Matthew, Russell, Joanna and Alexander. A memorial service is being planned. Contributions may be made to the American Neurological Assoc, Columbia U. or Harvard U.

A federal appeals judge on Wednesday delayed the enforcement of new city rules requiring calorie counts to be posted alongside prices in some restaurants. The delay ordered by Judge Robert A. It was one of those chance encounters on the City Hall steps. As the Rev. Al Sharpton prepared to begin a news conference calling for guilty verdicts for the detectives on trial in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell, Mr. Sharpton was greeted by somewhat of a surprise guest. Bloomberg was on his way out of the building to a press conference to open the TriBeCa Film Festival when he greeted Mr. Sharpton and others, including Mr. Bell's fiancée, Nicole Paultre Bell.After the mayor left, Mr. Sharpton went on to call for convictions for the three detectives on Friday morning, when a verdict is expected from Justice Arthur J. A day after the resignation of Patricia J. Lancaster, the first woman in a long line of embattled buildings commissioners, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered a sympathetic view of the pressures she faced and acknowledged the challenge of finding a replacement."When you go and do big search you always say, 'Oh it's going to be tough,'" Mr. Bloomberg said at a public school in St. Albans, Queens, adding that it would be "a great challenge" but he would find someone to run the Buildings Department. "Being a commissioner in the city of New York is a really challenging job, but a wonderful job, and there are people who like being challenged, who like being, have to work under pressure, who like what looks like at the beginning an insurmountable problem. Those are the people who take it to the next level."

Hello, I'm Patrick Patten of Handride fame. Is it fame? Well my relatives are at least amused by my "web-logging," so that counts for something. I'm your basic blogger: I think I'm always right, I look down on your opinions, and I have no fundamental connections to the sport I write about. However, I do love the sport in a way that is not healthy: switching cable providers to one with the horse racing networks, leaving my 4-week-old first-born to go to Chicago and watch the Arlington Million, writing and updating a blog every day. It's this passion that I'm allowed to pass on that some professional writers are sometimes unable to. For example, in my next post I'm listing seven horses that are NOT going to win the Derby.

Recently a group of editors from the Book Review went to see the off-Broadway production of George Packer's play, "Betrayed." I think it's fair to say that we were all moved by it (if it's not fair, I'm sure my loquacious and opinionated colleagues will let you know). Based on Packer's reporting on Iraq for The New Yorker, it tells of three decent, Western-oriented Iraqis who celebrated the overthrow of Saddam Hussein, went to work for the American occupation forces and were broken on the wheel of bureaucratic and military cruelty (as well as the sectarian fanaticism of their own countrymen).
The Russian Orthodox Church has endorsed President Vladimir V. Putin, and the government has in turn suppressed Protestants.

BRIEFS The past four weeks have spawned three interesting tidbits on coral: 1) It survives on junk food, "carbohydrates and fats" produced by algae. 2) It thrives in a place struck with a 15 megaton hydrogen bomb in 1954. 3) It turns seas pink during mating periods. Alas, corral is also in trouble in many places.

The rising design star Martino Gamper has collaborated on the interior of the shoe designer Diego Dolcini's new store, which opened here in Milan this week. Gamper, who is known for such design derring-do as "If Gio Only Knew," a performance piece in which he chopped up Gio Ponti furniture from the hotel Parco dei Principi, Sorrento and reassembled it into other furniture of his own design, or the relatively self-explanatory project "100 Hundred Chairs in 100 Days," has created a series of stacked wooden shelves for the store that coyly mimic the boxes Dolcini's shoes come in. It's a little like Payless, but a lot more elegant. As high-concept as Gamper can sometimes seem, he's definitely not one to only think outside of the box: word on the street is that he and Dolcini are working together on a collection of shoes for the fall.

Admirals' Row in the Brooklyn Navy Yard was home to high-ranking naval officers and their families. The houses, built from 1864 to 1901, were part of a six-acre site, including stables and tennis courts. They have been unoccupied for decades, and their future is undetermined.

There has been all kinds of speculation about what Apple might do with its pile of cash, especially as it tries to build on the success of its iPhone. There's plenty of fuel for such speculation: At the end of 2007, the electronics giant had more than $18 billion in cash and short-term securities on its balance sheet.

Rupert Murdoch is seeking to tighten his already-imposing grip on American news media, striking a tentative agreement to buy his third New York-based paper, Newsday, for $580 million. As he nears completion of that deal, Mr. Murdoch appears likely to pose the first significant challenge to the media ownership rule that the Federal Communications Commission recently adopted.

The name will appear five times on the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue: at the base of each of the two center columns leading to the century-old building's main entrance; on a gold plaque on the marble floor just outside the front door; and in the marble of the pedestals beneath the lamps at the library's 42nd Street entrance. The letters will range from 1 to 2 ½ inches in height, those cut into stone etched in a new font that gives the patina of age.

An answer in the Q&A column on April 15, about people getting vitamin D from exposure to the sun on a cloudy day, and a column on May 17, 2005, about getting the vitamin from exposure to sunlight through a window, incorrectly attributed a position to the National Institutes of Health about sun exposure and vitamin D. The columns also referred to an outdated fact sheet posted on the N.I.H. Web site. The recommendation for 10 to 15 minutes of exposure twice a week is the view of an author cited by the institutes; the N.I.H. itself makes no recommendation on sun exposure. An updated fact sheet on the topic can be found at dietary-supplements.info.nih.gov/factsheets.

An art review on Friday about “Dargerism: Contemporary Artists and Henry Darger,” at the American Folk Art Museum, misstated the number of artworks Darger created to illustrate his epic adventure tale, “The Story of the Vivian Girls, in What Is Known as the Realms of the Unreal, of the Glandeco-Angelinnian War Storm, Caused by the Child Slave Rebellion.” It was 150 double-sided watercolor paintings for a total of 300 works, not almost 300 such paintings for a total of nearly 600 works.

An article on Tuesday about the growing scrutiny faced by Patricia J. Lancaster, New York City’s buildings commissioner, after a series of fatal construction accidents misstated the source and timing of a revelation that an East Side building that was the site of a fatal crane accident last month was too tall for its location. That statement was made by a Buildings Department official in an interview on Friday, not by Ms. Lancaster during a City Council hearing on Thursday. (At the hearing, Ms. Lancaster would say only that the building proposal should not have been approved because it did not conform to zoning regulations.).
BUSINESS DAY.

A Calendar listing on Sunday gave an incorrect date for a tribute to The Band and for a tribute to Johnny Cash by Michael Patrick’s Ring of Fire Band, both at Mexicali Blues Cafe in Teaneck. It is Friday, not next Monday.

An article on Tuesday about the financial struggles of large banks erroneously included one bank among several seeking to raise additional capital to shore up their balance sheets. While Merrill Lynch, JPMorgan Chase and Wachovia have indeed announced such plans, Wells Fargo has not.

A film review on Friday about “Constantine’s Sword” misidentified the birthplace of the Roman emperor Constantine I. He was born in what is now the city of Nis in Serbia, not in Trier, Germany, where he built a church. The review also misidentified the river on which Trier is situated in referring to Crusader attacks on Jews. While Crusaders did sail down the Rhine, destroying Jewish settlements, Trier is on the Mosel River, not the Rhine.

Dwight Howard became the first player in nearly 40 years to record consecutive playoff games with at least 20 points and 20 rebounds as Orlando beat the Raptors on Tuesday.

A federal appeals court ruled that Christie Whitman the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, could not be held liable for saying the air was safe to breathe after the terrorist attack in 2001.
