The Florida State star Preston Parker was arrested late Monday and charged with carrying a concealed .45-caliber pistol and a small amount of marijuana. The Seminoles already have six starters sitting out suspensions from a classroom cheating scandal last year. Parker was named Florida State’s most valuable player last season after leading the team with 1,513 all-purpose yards and 62 receptions.

Boston College forward Shamari Spears is transferring to Charlotte after finishing as the Eagles’ third-leading scorer last season. A Charlotte spokesman said Tuesday that Spears wanted to be closer to his home in Salisbury, N.C., because of an undisclosed family medical issue. The 6-foot-6 Spears averaged 9.6 points and 6.1 rebounds for the Eagles and played nearly 27 minutes a game last season.

Connecticut forward Curtis Kelly in transferring in hopes of earning more playing time. Kelly, a sophomore, has not decided where he will go, UConn said. Kelly, a 6-foot-9, 234-pound Bronx native, appeared in 51 games in two seasons with the Huskies. He averaged 2.4 points and 2.2 rebounds.

Angie Loy scored two goals to lead the United States to a 7-0 victory over France at an Olympic qualifying tournament in Kazan, Russia. The Americans (3-0) have outscored their opponents, 17-2, at the six-team event, which they must win to advance to the Beijing Games. By winning the tournament, the Americans would compete in the Olympics for the first time since 1996, when they qualified as the host country.

The American sprinter LaTasha Jenkins can compete again after the World Anti-Doping Agency dropped its appeal of a United States arbitration ruling that cleared her of a positive drug test. The decision means Jenkins is the first athlete to beat the United States Anti-Doping Agency on a drug charge. Jenkins tested positive for the steroid nandrolone at a meet in Brussels in July 2006. A three-person arbitration panel had ruled against Usada in December. It said results of her test were compromised because both European labs testing her sample violated international standards that require the tests be run by two different technicians.

The All-Star DeLisha Milton-Jones returned to the Los Angeles Sparks in a trade with the Washington Mystics for Taj McWilliams-Franklin and the Sparks’ 2009 first-round draft pick. Milton-Jones played six seasons in Los Angeles, helping the team win W.N.B.A. championships in 2001 and 2002. She was traded to Washington in 2005 and averaged 13.4 points and 6.4 rebounds last season for the Mystics.

In a significant reversal, major meat and dairy industry groups backed a total ban on so-called downer cattle from entering the food supply. Calls for such a ban have come from watchdog groups and some lawmakers in the wake of the large beef recall from a Southern California slaughterhouse in February, but the industry had resisted. Current law bans slaughter of most cows that are unable to stand, or downers, but allows them in if they fall after passing a veterinarian’s inspection and then are reinspected. Advocacy groups called that a loophole, but the Agriculture Department and the meat industry opposed changing it. Now, under pressure from Congress and outside groups, the industry has reconsidered. The American Meat Institute, the National Meat Association and the National Milk Producers Federation said they had petitioned the Agriculture Department to enact a total ban. “We think that the time has come,” said Jeremy Russell, spokesman for the National Meat Association, which represents some 400 packers and processors. “We want to send a clear message to consumers that we’re putting their welfare and concerns ahead of the economics.”.

A former high-ranking official in the Justice Department pleaded guilty to a charge of conflict of interest in the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal. The former official, Robert E. Coughlin II, admitted in federal court that he had accepted meals, concert tickets and luxury seats at sporting events from a lobbyist while helping the lobbyist’s clients. He faces up to 10 months in prison under a plea deal with the government. Mr. Coughlin accepted the gifts from 2001 to 2003 while working on legislative affairs for the Justice Department. He later became deputy chief of staff of the department’s criminal division, which is handling the Abramoff inquiry. He resigned a year ago.
A former state judge in Brooklyn pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a misdemeanor charge in connection with the theft of $160,000 from his aunt.
The Washington Post removed Susan B. Glasser from her job as an assistant managing editor in charge of national news, amid complaints and poor morale.

President Bush criticized a farm bill making its way through Congress, saying it would increase spending by at least $16 billion at a time of record farm income. Mr. Bush issued a statement intended to put pressure on House and Senate negotiators to develop legislation that would be acceptable to the White House. On Friday, Mr. Bush signed a one-week extension of current farm law to give lawmakers more time to work, and urged a one-year extension of the law. “With record farm income, now is not the time for Congress to ask other sectors of the economy to pay higher taxes to increase the size of government,” Mr. Bush said. House and Senate negotiators are trying to resolve differences in bills approved by both chambers last year that authorize $286 billion in spending over five years.

The pilot of a container ship that spilled 53,000 gallons of oil into San Francisco Bay has been charged with two felony counts of lying to Coast Guard officials. The pilot, Capt. John Cota, was charged with lying about his prescription drug use. Captain Cota had previously been charged with two misdemeanor environmental crimes for his role in the Nov. 7 accident that fouled the bay, killed or injured thousands of birds and forced the closing of beaches throughout the Bay Area. The new, more serious charges accuse him of lying on annual medical records required by the Coast Guard.
The guilty plea carries strong accusations against Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, whose name has surfaced repeatedly in a trial against a former fund-raiser, Antoin Rezko, a supporter of Barack Obama.

A federal grand jury in Las Vegas has charged a man who was believed to have ricin poisoning with possessing the deadly toxin and weapons. The indictment against Roger Bergendorff lists three counts: possession of a biological toxin, possession of unregistered firearms and possession of firearms not identified by serial number. The charges carry a possible penalty of 30 years in federal prison. Mr. Bergendorff, 57, an unemployed graphic designer, has been jailed since last week when he was released from a hospital. The authorities say Mr. Bergendorff made the ricin as part of a scheme to hurt unspecified enemies.

9 P.M. (13) NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC'S STRANGE DAYS ON PLANET EARTH In this two-part special narrated by Edward Norton, left, National Geographic resumes its investigation into the health of the world's water supply and some rather peculiar events that have scientists scratching their heads. The first stop: Ghana, where overfishing has resulted in putrid gases that occasionally waft into the coastal villages of Namibia. And then the program speculates on the link between starving seabirds in the remote Pacific and striped bass whose flesh is melting in the Chesapeake Bay. 8 P.M. (13) SECRETS OF THE DEAD: AZTEC MASSACRE Textbooks tell us that in the 15th century, the Aztecs put up little resistance to the arrival of Spanish conquistadors, whom they believed to be light-skinned gods. But a recent discovery of more than 400 bodies outside Mexico City reveals another story, à la Indiana Jones, in which the Aztecs not only resisted the invaders but also sacrificed them alive, pulling their still-pumping hearts from their chests and stringing their heads up for public display.

WALTON--Clyde Everett. Passed away on February 15, 2008 at the age of 57. A beloved father, family man, friend and neighbor, Clyde touched the hearts and minds of all those whom his life's path crossed. Known for his boyish sense of humor, sharp wit and captivating charm, Clyde was generous in sharing his wise council to those who sought to address life's challenges. He will be deeply missed and is survived by his fiance Tanya, her daughter Nicolette, his sons Charles and Nicholas, mother Jane, sister Linda, brother Birge and his beloved dogs Cosmo and Cleo. Farewell our love! God knows when we shall meet again.

EPSTEIN--Natalie. We mourn the loss of a great, gracious and beautiful lady, our beloved sister-in-law and aunt. The Maisel Family EPSTEIN--Natalie. We mourn the loss of our beloved mother, grandmother, great grandmother and sister, Natalie Epstein of Cedarhurst, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Natalie, 85, passed away peacefully at her Cedarhurst home on Monday, April 21st, 2008. Natalie was the beloved wife of the late Morton Carlin and Sidney Epstein and loving partner of Irwin Blocker. Natalie's funeral will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY at 10am on Wednesday April 23rd. Interment will follow at Beth-David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Natalie was an extraordinary person who brought happiness, love and friendship into every relationship. Her optimism and positivity were inspiring. Natalie is survived by her children Jeffrey, Christine, Neil, Peter, Carole, Jane and Martha. Natalie was also a proud and loving grandmother to Benjamin, Jessica, Melissa, Michael, Matthew, Shelby, Hunter and Marilyn and greatgrandmother to Sam, Jack and Gabriel. She is also survived by many friends, cousins, nieces and other extended family. Natalie was an accomplished businesswoman and was highly creative and expert in both knitting and sewing. We remember her with love, admiration and affection. She was truly a woman of valor.

ANATOLE--David, October 14, 1909 -April 20, 2008, of Greenwich, CT and formerly of Egremont, MA and Lawrence, NY died after a short illness, but a long and very rich life. Devoted husband for 66 years to the late Babs Anatole. Loving father of Amy Schwab and her husband Jim, and Mark Anatole and his wife Jodi. Proud Poppy to Kate and Joanna Schwab and Emily and Carter Anatole. ''Tolia'' as he was known to his old ''China hand'' friends and family, was born in Kiev, Russia. His 98 years were Horatio Alger-like. David's formal education ended when he left school at age 12 to support his mother and sisters. As a young adult he lived in China where his experiences were the stuff that Hollywood scripts are made of: his travels via caravan to Mongolia to buy wool for British colonials (he was typically the first Caucasian the locals had seen), marriage solicitations from Asian royalty, assisting cavalry escorts fighting bandits in the Gobi Desert before being kidnapped and on and on. David came to the U.S. at age 26 with broken English... and a letter of business introduction. Over the next four decades and throughout his business career, he traveled throughout Europe, Asia, and South America as President of the textile division of a U.S. conglomerate, and later his own company, Haroco, Inc. David was blessed with a lifelong passion, horseback riding and jumping and the hunt, that extended from childhood to his early 90s. His beloved horses, from Adventurer to Captain George all too often gave Babs competition for weekend quality time. At age 90, David wrote his memoirs, ''Ma Chu'', which will remain a wonderful legacy to his family and future generations. Poppy, as Babs always reminded the family, ''Happy Times.'' Donations to the Humane Society (hsus.org) and the Alzheimer's Association, (alzheimersassociation.org)

Today is Professional Secretaries' Day. Whether you're high up enough to have an administrative assistant or still working your way out of (up to?) being one, you'll want to celebrate with Reverend Jen. The elfin-eared downtown doyenne is hosting her 12th annual extravaganza at the Bowery Poetry Club. There'll be the usual oddball open-mic performances, along with some unusual holiday perks, like a piñata filled with stolen office supplies and free backrubs for tired secretaries. Go and don't expect to fetch anyone's coffee.

RUDNER--Oscar C., of Darien, CT formerly of Dorset, VT and Little Silver, NJ died peacefully with his loving children by his side on April 18, 2008. He was the son of Oscar and Mary Rudner of Lansford, PA. He was the loving husband of the late Brenda L. Rudner. He was the most devoted father to Christopher C. Rudner (deceased), Robert V. Rudner II, Stephen C. Rudner, Curtis S. Taylor, Nancy L. Taylor-Wing, Margaret T. McManus and David F. Taylor. He is survived by six grandchildren and three nieces and nephews. He was also the husband of the late Anna Louise Campbell Jeffers of Lincroft, NJ, and the late Miriam Cornish Fitzhugh of Little Rock, AR. Mr. Rudner graduated high school in Lansford, PA, went on to serve his country in WWII in the ETO, attaining the rank of Major. He was awarded two Bronze Stars and two Combat Infantry Badges. After the war, he enjoyed a successful career in the textile industry. His immediate family gathered at graveside at the Dellwood Cemetery in Manchester, VT to honor the memory of his long and fruitful life. In lieu of flowers, his family encourages consideration of memorial gifts to the World War II Veterans Committee of the American Veterans Center.

He won three Kentucky Derbys, so you would think Bob Baffert could pick this year's winner in the 134th running of America's greatest race. He does not have a horse in the field, but he is looking among what he says is a nice group of 3-year-olds who have been racing in California on synthetic surfaces. ''We've had some nice horses out here, and they really haven't been able to show their stuff,'' Baffert said Monday in a telephone interview. ''These new surfaces make every two-turn race like a turf or European heat. You lope along, lope along in a pack and then try to sprint home.''

The Popular Demand listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday, about the growing popularity of Internet radio, gave incorrect figures for the percentage of Americans, by age group, who said they listened to satellite radio in January and February. (The figures were a duplicate of the percentage of people who listened to radio online.) Correct figures for satellite radio listeners can be found at nytimes.com/business. The listing also misstated the year that 9 percent of listeners used the Internet to learn about new music. It was 2002, not 2007. (That figure was compared to a 25 percent increase in such listeners in 2008.)

Memorial donations to the Bernards Township P.B.A., 1 Collyer Ln, Basking Ridge, NJ 07920 would be appreciated.

RIMSKY--Robert. Beloved husband of Renee Svigals Rimsky and the late Jeanne Meyers Rimsky, and loving father of Rena Wing, Douglas, Lee and Don, passed away peacefully in his home on April 18, at the age of 87. He is also survived by his children's spouses, 2 stepchildren Dr. Paul Svigals and Susan Kirschenbaum and their spouses, 12 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He is a graduate of the Townsend Harris High School, Rutgers University and Harvard Business School. Bob served as a Naval Supply Officer during World War II. He worked with his father in the garment district and continued the tradition his father started of building the business through intelligence, diligence and trustworthiness. Bob became Chairman of Lucerene Textiles and changed the textile industry through his revolutionary business approach. He created the Lucerene Foundation for his family's philanthropic interests. Contributions included: North Shore Hospital for the Rimsky Center for Surgery, North Shore Child & Family Guidance Center for the Renee and Robert Rimsky Abuse Prevention and Treatment Center, Landmark on Main Street in Port Washington, NY, for the Jeanne Rimsky Theater, and Playwrights Horizons Theater in New York, NY. Friends may visit Monday 6-9pm and Tuesday and Wednesday 12-5 and 7-9 at their LI home. Donations in his memory may be made to any of the organizations Bob supported. RIMSKY--Robert. We hope you find the silver lining, you deserve it. We'll miss you. Barbara and Ed and Barbara and Allan RIMSKY--Robert. We extend our love and heartfelt sympathies to Renee and the entire Rimsky family. Robert was an elegant, warm and lovely man who enriched all of our lives. Alan, Patricia, Adam and Joshua Abramson

MURDOCH EXTENDS HIS REACH Rupert Murdoch struck a tentative deal to buy his third New York-based paper, Newsday, from the Tribune Company for $580 million. A takeover of Newsday by the News Corporation, which also owns two television stations and two newspapers in New York City, could face trouble with federal regulators. [C1.]

NIVEN--Jeanne. Longtime resident of Oyster Bay, NY passed away in Ft. Lauderdale, FL on April 18th at the age of 87 following complications from hip surgery. She was predeceased by her husband William S. Niven and by her son John B. Niven who died at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. She is survived by her son William S. Niven, Jr. of Ft. Lauderdale, FL and her daughters Susan M. Niven of Locust Valley, NY and Wendy Cross of Los Angeles, CA and two grandchildren Jamie Cross of Los Angeles and John B. Niven, Jr. of Locust Valley and NYC. She was an accomplished gardener and active member of the North Country Garden Club. A graveside service will be held July 5th at Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the North Shore Animal League or SPLIA.
SORELL--Michael, M.D., died 4/20/07. In loving memory, Caroline, Penn, Reid, Jack, & sister Mindi Sorell Dudley. Sign guest book at legacy.com

BOTWIN--Deborah (nee Gladstein), on April 19, 2008 of Englewood, NJ. Loving wife of the late Elliot. Beloved mother of Lois Botwin (Englewood, NJ) and Natalie (Kenneth) Vinocur. Dear sister of Stanley (Judy) of Florida and Harvey (the late Joyce) Gladstein of New York. Cherished grandmother of Erin and Randi. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Service Wednesday, 10am at Wien & Wien, Hackensack, NJ. For information 1-800-322-0533

WEISS--Stephen H. New York-Presbyterian Hospital is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend Stephen H. Weiss. As a member of the joint board for The New York Hospital - Cornell Medical Center from 1977 to 1997; the first Chairman and Life Overseer for the Board of Overseers at Weill Cornell Medical College, our academic affiliate; and Chairman Emeritus and longtime Cornell University Trustee, Steve charted a course that advanced treatment for patients in New York and around the world. A consummate gentleman and a wise and astute counselor with an infectious passion for the transformative power of academic medicine, he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Suzanne; his brother, Roger; four children, Heather, Michael, Jonathan and Nathalie; and the entire Weiss family. John Mack, Chairman Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

NESCI--Pat, on April 19, 2008. We mourn the loss of Patsy. Former husband to Marie, and father to Justin, father-inlaw to Nikki and grandfather to Isabel, Owen and Nathaniel. Brother to Carmela Tino and uncle to Carla Miklos and Laura Tino. Services will be held Friday, 2 pm at ''Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations to: Make-AWish Foundation of Metro New York, 152 W. 57th Street, 35th Floor, New York, New York 10019 (212)957-WISH.

WOLINSKY--David (Danny), died April 21 of cancer at his Queens home. He was a resident of Boca Raton, Florida. Born to Dinuh and Morris Wulinksy in New York City October 21, 1923, Danny served in the US Army in France and Germany during WWII, graduated City College, was a CPA, and an executive at Metallurg, Inc. for over 30 years. Married for 61 years to his beloved Adele, he leaves three sons Steven (Naomi), Eric (Kate), and Ronald, eight grandchildren, Sara (Judah), Ben, Rebecca, Nora, Adam, Paige, Julia and Matthew, and four great-grandchildren Yaacov, Avraham, Yonatan, and Rachel. He also leaves his sister Gladys (Eddie) and brother-in-law Jerry (Rona) and sister-in-law Jeanne, many nieces and nephew, and innumerable friends. They all loved and admired him very much. Services at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens, Wednesday April 23, 11:15. Burial will take place at New Montefiore Cemetery.

This newspaper was the principal conduit for early notice of "The Original of Laura," the novel that Vladimir Nabokov was working on before his death in July 1977 at the age of 78, and the literary world has remained intrigued ever since. (As my colleague Greg Cowles mentioned here yesterday, Nabokov's son and literary executor, Dmitri Nabokov, is reported to have decided to publish the manuscript - actually 138 pencil-inscribed index cards - which his father had enjoined should be destroyed.) In the archives, I found a couple of old articles that not only hinted at the gestation of "Laura" but that are otherwise full of lovely Nabokoviana.

I think that most Americans view bacon less as a meat than as a seasoning. The existence of vegetarian-friendly "bacon" bits suggests this, and the fact that people buy them probably confirms it. Bacon, generally, is hardly even a noun. It is incinerated strips of adjectives: dark brown, crisp, salty, sweet and smoky.

There are yet more reports this week designed to press authorities like the European Commission to pare plans to meet a growing proportion of transport needs with biofuels. Policy makers like Energy Minister Malcolm Wicks of Britain and the Venezuelan oil minister, Rafael Ramirez, are decrying biofuels as one of the chief culprits behind the destruction of rainforests (because trees are felled to create more cropland) and for high food prices (because using soy and corn to make fuel mean they are no longer available as food).

Having regained some force in Pennsylvania, the tornado of insult and innuendo that is the Democratic Party's nomination fight will now touch down in four more states. But while Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama regroup this week, John McCain is off doing something that, while lacking the same kind of drama, has a significance of its own. Mr. McCain and his advisers decided this week to embark on a tour of some of the places that symbolize the fragility of America's promise, even if they aren't the kind of places that Republicans often go: Selma, Ala.; Youngstown, Ohio; New Orleans; Inez, Ky., the Appalachian town where Lyndon Johnson once touted his War on Poverty.

Gov. David A. Paterson said Thursday that he would like to take the rare step of reopening the already approved state budget before the end of the legislative session in June so that more spending cuts can be made, in response to a weakening economy and falling revenue projections.

The San Antonio Spurs have revived the Hack-a-Shaq strategy in building a 2-0 lead over the Phoenix Suns, intentionally fouling Shaquille O'Neal even when he doesn't have the ball. This turns the game into a slow-motion hugging match. Should the league consider altering the rules, and if so, how? Or is the strategy a legitimate way to exploit a player's poor free-throw shooting?

Yesterday, the Morning Skate looked ahead at the Canadiens-Flyers series, which starts tonight, by looking back on a few tawdry episodes that have marked their rivalry. So, in the interest of fairness to the Western Conference, we now examine, but not very throughly, the resumption of the Detroit-Colorado blood feud, which also starts tonight and is the subject of John Niyo's column in today's Detroit News. "As nasty as it was and as much hate as there was with everything going on, there was some tremendous hockey being played," says Kris Draper, one of the eight remaining players who has been on the ice for each playoff encounter. "I mean, you're talking about a lot of Hall of Famers that were a part of that rivalry. That kind of made it that much more special."

Yates, reiterated the administration's statement that the judge had simply decided to remain on the bench."I don't think it was really in his DNA to do this at this time," Mr. Paterson said, adding that he thought Mr. Yates had initially agreed to join the administration because the two men have a history of working together going back to the days when Mr. Yates when was a top aide to former Assembly Speaker Melvin H. Miller.

One of the simpler pleasures my wife and I enjoy, as stubborn consumers of old media, is listening to the radio together - generally to WFUV-FM, the public station out of Fordham University in the Bronx, which carries an impressive range of music: new, old, roots, folk, rock, soul, jazz. We don't like everything we hear, and we don't always agree about what we do like (she grudgingly tolerates Beck; I only pretend to like Rickie Lee Jones), but on the whole it's nice to live in the broadcast area of a truly eclectic college station with professional production values.

The four (so-called) masculine perfumes from the relatively new men's brand Cereus - launched in November 2007 - vary in aesthetic usefulness. All are competent, three are of interest, and two are quite good, which in the scheme of things is a very decent batting average. The collection deserves a solid three stars.

I am 18 and not a terribly experienced traveler. I have traveled in the United States, Spain and Portugal. This May a friend and I are braving our way to Thailand. The tickets have been purchased, but the itinerary is not yet set, and we have our anxieties, as do our mothers. Do you have any advice on where to go? We are doing the trip on a budget, and we are looking for a very cultural, and exciting, experience.

Sheep Meadow Cafe may be the only restaurant in New York where half the clientele are dogs.

Edgar Prado, who will ride Adriano in the Derby, had a scare Wednesday at Keeneland in the seventh race when he was dumped by May Meeting shortly after the break. Prado, newly elected to the Hall of Fame, was taken to the hospital and was out by 6:15 p.m., Claire Novak writes in the Blood-Horse.

US Airways on Thursday joined the other large, United States-based network carriers in reporting a major quarterly loss: It said it was $236 million in the red. As the city braces for the judge-issued verdict in the Sean Bell shooting, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg espoused themes of communication and tolerance near the neighborhood where the shooting took place, The Times reports. That may be what he says, but police officers will not be allowed to take any time off during a four-day period starting on Friday, to prepare for the possibility of widespread street protests, according to The Post.

Wendy's International said Thursday it agreed to sell itself to Triarc Companies, the franchisor of the Arby's restaurant chain, in a stock swap valued at about $2.3 billion. The announcement appeared to mark a victory for Nelson Peltz, the billionaire investor who is Triarc's chairman and who has long been agitating for change at Wendy's.

With big wins in Ohio and Pennsylvania, Hillary Rodham Clinton continued to make the case for her continued run for the presidency Wednesday. She also pointed to a flood of donations to her campaign post-Pennsylvania as a sign that people believe in her.

The chief executives of Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines are likely to face tough questions about their proposed merger as they testify Thursday in back-to-back hearings before the House and Senate Judiciary committees.

Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking giant, on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss nearly three times worse than analysts had expected as it wrote down $5.3 billion in soured investments. But net new money inflows into its wealth management business were roughly in line with average expectations, suggesting clients remain confident despite problems at Credit Suisse's investment banking arm.
Two of London's top hedge fund managers have sold a stake in their firm to Goldman Sachs, banking a multi-million pound payout, The Telegraph reported.

The Ambac Financial Group may have made hedge fund manager William Ackman's day Wednesday when the bond insurer posted a surprisingly wide first-quarter loss after setting aside $1 billion to cover future payouts on mortgage bonds.

Barclays, Britain's third-biggest bank, said its profits in the first quarter fell from a year earlier after its investment bank and fund management arms were hit by tough financial market conditions.
Beleaguered Bank of America shareholders pleaded Wednesday with the bank's chief executive not to proceed with a $4 billion acquisition of distressed subprime mortgage lender Countrywide Financial.
Sharper Image put itself up for sale on Wednesday, just over two months after the retailer of high-end gadgets and appliances filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

The Children's Investment Fund will probably contest Japan's rejection of the United Kingdom-based hedge fund's bid to double its stake in the country's largest electricity wholesaler, Bloomberg News reported.
Linden Lab, the company that created the virtual world "Second Life," now has its second chief executive: Mark Kingdon, former head of digital marketer Organic Inc.

Jumping the SPAC bandwagon, investment firm Angelo Gordon & Co. on Wednesday said it has filed for an initial public offering of Angelo Gordon Acquisition Corp., its newly-formed special purpose acquisition vehicle.

New World Resources, a Czech coal miner, is looking to raise up to 1.1 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) in its initial public offering in London, with the proceeds put towards expanding its growth in the Czech Republic and neighboring Poland.
Altor Networks, a network security start-up, said Wednesday it raised $6 million in a second funding round led by Accel Partners and Foundation Capital.
Russell Read is resigning as chief investment officer of Calpers, the biggest American pension fund, a fund spokesman said on Wednesday.

Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, preparing to merge amid a steep industry downturn, reported a combined first-quarter loss of $10.5 billion on Wednesday, most of it an accounting recognition that the two carriers are worth far less than when they emerged from bankruptcy a year ago.

General Electric's chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, delivered a mea culpa to investors and analysts at the company's annual meeting on Wednesday after the company failed to hit first-quarter goals.

Alliance Data Systems said Wednesday that first-quarter earnings fell 13 percent, in part due to the loss of a contract and costs related to the company's failed buyout deal with the Blackstone Group.

RightScale, a software service provider for applications that run on Amazon Web services, is expected to announce Thursday that it raised $4.5 million in first-round of funding from Benchmark Capital, CNet News.com reported.
Russia's gas export monopoly Gazprom will buy majority control of oil major TNK-BP, which is half owned by BP, for $20 billion by the end of the year, the Vedomosti daily reported on Thursday.

It was a huge win for the Belleville Bulls, however you looked at it.

In the pre-dawn haze the elegant old Keeneland Race Course is difficult to discern from the adjacent Blue Grass Airport. And every April, long-hanging dense fogs can make the two places almost indistinguishable.

As we wait for the next wave of breezes and activity that will follow over the next few days, I thought I would write a little bit about my recent involvement in horse welfare issues that have now become an important part of my life.
We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Apr. 24 column.
Many voters in Kokomo, Ind., expressed queasiness over the notions of change that both Democratic candidates have proudly pledged elsewhere.
APC has taken a healthy step in the right direction with its Power-Saving SurgeArrest surge protector power strip.

I forget who said this - for some reason I've always attributed it to Tug McGraw - but it strikes me as important when evaluating a pitcher like Mike Mussina: "When you get older, you can still do the same things you always did. You just can't do them as often."

Now that Earth Day 2008 has come to a close, it's easy to be cynical. I won't even begin to list all the examples of crass commercialism/brand opportunism/greenwashing/totally missed-the-point-ism that transpired. Too many easy targets, too few surprises. As one blogger on Treehugger.com appropriately quipped, "Earth Day is the new Christmas."
Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, will be available to answer questions from readers today on the Fifth Down.
The Kremlin has turned the Russian Orthodox Church into a de facto official religion, warding off other Christian denominations through a variety of harassing measures.
Nepal appeared to be on the verge of Maoist-led rule, as election results signaled that the country’s former guerrillas had won the largest share of seats for a Constituent Assembly.
Iraq’s largest Sunni bloc has agreed in principle to return to the cabinet after a nine-month boycott, several Sunni leaders said.
On an individual level, any heavy smoker who might want to get screened should recognize that there can be harms as well as benefits.
Events and exhibitions in the New York area.
Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers to stop the bloodshed, unite with all Iraqis and focus their firepower on driving out the “occupation forces.”
Microsoft may be struggling to buy Yahoo, but the giant software maker’s current business is humming along smoothly.
Under pressure from rival airlines, the commission said it would look into whether a government loan of 300 million euros or $478.5 million to the carrier constitutes illegal state aid.
It was an unexpected improvement amid a slump in the U.S. market that has cut sales of the carmaker’s most lucrative vehicles.

For a league that seems to be reinventing itself every three years or so, the N.B.A. sports a fan base and chattering class that is awfully concerned with its players’ legacies. It is an old maxim that an athlete’s career is never quite complete unless he wins a championship. But there’s a difference between the way Ernie Banks and Barry Sanders are remembered, and the way, say, Charles Barkley, Patrick Ewing and Karl Malone are remembered.
Here are some of your responses to last week’s question, about the effect of the N.B.A.’s rule requiring players to spend a year in college:.

The Boston Marathon, won for the fourth time by Robert Cheruiyot on Monday, requires strict requirements for entry, and most runners find the standards all but impossible to meet. As Gina Kolata writes in The Times today, “All of this helps make the Boston marathon unique and makes running it a dream for many athletes. It also raises two questions: Why does the Boston Marathon make it so hard to enter? And how often do runners sneak in by trading or buying one another’s entries?”.
Inventories rose as sales of new homes fell 8.5 percent, a far sharper decline than was forecast.

Lenny Dykstra, the gruff and hard-charging former outfielder known as “Nails” who has recently rediscovered the spotlight, this month launched his latest venture in a weirdly successful career after his sporting life: Players Club, a magazine available only to professional athletes about living well during their playing careers and long afterward. Think self-help for celebrities, with lush photographs and fresh first-person stories.

As illustrated brilliantly by last month’s N.C.A.A. Final Four soiree, San Antonio knows how to throw a party. All of the action, including the major hotels, dining and drinking establishments, civic attractions and big games, revolve around the city’s historic River Walk, so hoofing it on foot is the norm, as is making merry with a margarita or two. If there’s any excuse to engage an automobile, it’s for traveling to San Antonio’s excellent collection of public golf courses. Westin La Cantera’s Resort layout has played host to the P.G.A. Tour since 1995. Justin Leonard’s up-and-down career includes three wins there; perhaps it’s no surprise that the seventh fairway of this rolling Tom Weiskopf and Jay Morrish design overlooks a theme park roller coaster. Many contend that La Cantera’s sister course, an Arnold Palmer design that opened in 2001, is even better.

The San Antonio Spurs have built a 2-0 lead in their series against the Phoenix Suns, along the way employing a strategy of intentionally fouling Shaquille O’Neal, even when he doesn’t have the ball. This turns the game into a slow-motion hugging match. Should the league consider altering the rules to prevent this spectacle, and if so, how? Or is the strategy a legitimate way to exploit a player’s poor free-throw shooting?.
The bank’s first-quarter loss was nearly three times worse than analysts had expected as it wrote down $5.3 billion in soured investments, but its shares rose in Zurich trading.
Stock prices gained over 9 percent in China after the government moved to restore confidence in the market by reducing taxes on trades.
Triarc, the investment company controlled by Nelson Peltz, said that it was buying the fast-food chain in an all-stock deal.
It was an unexpected improvement amid a slump in the U.S. market that has cut sales of the carmaker’s most lucrative vehicles.
A construction worker at Lincoln Center was hospitalized after falling 30 feet from a scaffold on Wednesday night, according to the police and officials at the performing arts complex.
Mike Mussina found a way to win on Wednesday, using a darting fastball, a curveball and a changeup to hold the White Sox to four hits, a walk and two runs.
Wednesday night was garbage night in part of East Harlem, and it may have saved a man who jumped from his flame-engulfed apartment.
The Shanghai composite index opened up 7.98 percent at 3,549.868 points, after the government cut the share trading tax to support the market.
Democrats pushed a $15 billion housing bill through a House committee. The would send federal loans and grants to cities and counties hit hardest by the housing crisis.
The Mets revealed a remarkable ability to capitalize on their opponent’s mistakes in a victory over the Washington Nationals on Wednesday.
Biofuels are suddenly being blamed for every global ill. Most of this, to borrow a farm image, is hogwash and bilge.
Rajon Rondo outplayed Mike Bibby and helped the Boston Celtics silence Atlanta and its blustery point guard.
Kazuo Matsui’s two-run single fueled a seven-run fourth inning for the Houston Astros on Wednesday night in a 9-3 victory over the Reds in Cincinnati.
Gary Matthews Jr. hit two homers and the Angels ended the host Boston Red Sox’s six-game winning streak.

Acer, a maker of personal computers, posted strong results for its core business in the first quarter and raised its sales forecast. Ranking behind Hewlett-Packard and Dell but ahead of Lenovo of China, Acer has expanded into fast-growing consumer markets like China, India, Russia, Latin America and the Middle East. Profit fell to 2.95 billion Taiwan dollars ($97 million) from 5.66 billion Taiwan dollars a year earlier, when the company had one-time investment gains, and beat market forecasts for 2.51 billion Taiwan dollars.

Siemens said Erich R. Reinhardt, the head of its health care division, would resign after compliance violations at the company’s medical group were found to have taken place during his leadership. Mr. Reinhardt, left, who will leave at the end of April, was not personally involved in the far-reaching violations, the company said. Siemens, based in Munich, said Mr. Reinhardt, 61, decided to resign after an investigation into accusations of corruption in compliance cases in the former Siemens Medical Solutions Group. It did not reveal the findings. Jim Reid-Anderson, 49, the chief executive of the diagnostics division in Siemens’s health care unit, will succeed Mr. Reinhardt, who has led the medical division since 1994, the company said.

Deutsche Bank is cooperating with an investigation by a German prosecutor’s office into reports of insider trading of IKB Deutsche Industriebank shares, the bank said. Deutsche Bank said the Frankfurt prosecutor’s office had told it that a complaint had been filed accusing one of the bank’s employees of insider trading. Deutsche Bank said that to the best of its knowledge, the inquiry did not refer to trading in the bank’s accounts but to trading on behalf of clients, and that the bank had not benefited from it.
Nothing, it seems, can bring down the Club Kalua, which has survived repeated attempts by the city to close it. It has even survived the notoriety of the Sean Bell shooting.

A subdued Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, working to avoid flaring tensions as a verdict approaches in the trial of three police officers charged in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell, took a message of open communication and neighborly cooperation on Wednesday to the area of Queens where Mr. Bell died.
Citing “serious threats,” Denmark closed its embassy in Afghanistan and relocated all staff members, said a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry.

Rescuers have reached a cluster of brightly colored party balloons floating in the ocean off Brazil’s coast, but did not find the Roman Catholic priest who had been using them in an attempt to set a flight record.
Prime Minister Gordon Brown, left, made concessions on tax reform to end a rebellion by members of his own party which had threatened to erode his authority further.
German authorities staged raids across the country as part of an investigation into nine people suspected of trying to spread radical Islamic thinking.
A 27-year-old Thai man who refused to stand up when the royal anthem was played in a movie theater has been charged with lèse majesté, offending the dignity of the monarch, the police said.
The Pepsi Bottling Group said its quarterly profit fell 3 percent because of one-time charges, but the results topped Wall Street estimates, sending shares higher.
Rising medical costs and pricing problems pushed the health insurer WellPoint’s profit down 25 percent, missing Wall Street expectations.
Europe’s biggest carmaker by sales said its first-quarter net profit rose by more than 25 percent, and predicted a substantial increase in demand in 2008.
Allstate’s reported a greater-than-expected first-quarter profit drop of 77 percent on investment losses and heavy claims from winter tornadoes.
Boeing said its profits rose 38 percent, to $1.21 billion. General Dynamics said its net income jumped 32 percent, to $572 million.

A judicial officer in Oakland on Tuesday lifted an order that the Service Employees International Union and its president, Andrew L. Stern, left, not stalk or harass officials of the California Nurses Association. The officer, Jon Rantzman of Alameda County Superior Court, decided that the nurses’ association did not provide sufficient evidence to justify the order that he issued on Thursday. In recent weeks, the union sent members to California to confront officials in the nurses’ group after its organizers campaigned in Ohio to undermine the service employees’ effort to unionize 8,300 hospital workers there. The service employees said their members were not stalking or harassing nurses’ union officials, but were exercising their free speech.

A federal magistrate judge in Chicago has ruled that protecting state secrets is not a valid argument for the government to refuse to tell American citizens whether they are on the terrorism watch list, the Terrorist Screening Database. The ruling, signed on April 16 but made public by the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois on Wednesday, ordered the Department of Homeland Security and the F.B.I. to give the court the files regarding the 10 Muslim or Arab-American plaintiffs who filed a lawsuit starting in 2005, seeking court protection from what they contend is unwarranted harassment at the border. The magistrate judge, Sidney I. Schenkier of Federal District Court, said the court could review the information to decide whether it should remain classified. The F.B.I. said it had no comment. NEIL MacFARQUHAR.

The No. 2 official at the Census Bureau is stepping down amid criticism the agency bungled a technology contract, adding billions to the cost of the 2010 count while jeopardizing its accuracy. The official, Preston Jay Waite, the deputy census director, said he was retiring after nearly 38 years at the agency to spend more time with his family. He said he had been planning to leave earlier, but stayed when the technology problems came to light. Mr. Waite, 62, is described in a Census Bureau biography as the architect of the 2010 census.
Atmospheric levels of carbon dioxide are continuing to rise at an accelerating rate, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported.
At a gas station in Westchester County, higher prices make one owner nostalgic.

Neither of the front-runners vying to fill northern Mississippi’s vacant Congressional seat won a majority on Tuesday, setting up a May 13 run-off. The candidates, Travis Childers, a Democrat, and Greg Davis, a Republican, are among six candidates seeking to fill the seat vacated after Gov. Haley Barbour appointed Roger Wicker, a Republican, to the Senate to succeed Trent Lott. Mr. Childers garnered 31,138 votes, or 49.4 percent, while Mr. Davis had 31,066 votes, or 46.3 percent. Only Mr. Childers, the chancery clerk of Prentiss County, and Mr. Davis, the mayor of Southaven, will be in the run-off.
The shipping carrier said it earned $906 million, or 87 cents a share, compared with $843 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
It has been so distressing to see all three of the presidential hopefuls pretend they can make good on their promises without broadly raising taxes.

Investigators believe they have identified a group responsible for what Staten Island residents have called the “ninja burglaries.” But the police say they do not have enough evidence to pursue charges.
Defeating Hugo Chávez’s supporters at the polls would send a clear message that Venezuelans are truly fed up with his authoritarian ways.
Danica Patrick walked onstage at the “Late Show with David Letterman” to the tune of “Used to Be My Girl,” a reference to the fact that Letterman was once her team owner.

Connecticut legislators announced a compromise that will allow UConn to play a six-game series with Notre Dame, even though none of the games will be played in Connecticut. UConn and Notre Dame had been negotiating a 10-game series. The Fighting Irish wanted five games played in South Bend, Ind., and the five UConn home games played at large stadiums in the New York or Boston metropolitan areas — not at the Huskies’ 40,000-seat Rentschler Field.

The Kansas star Mario Chalmers was one of several big-name players who declared themselves eligible for the N.B.A. draft Wednesday. Chalmers did not sign with an agent, leaving open the possibility of a return to the Jayhawks. Chalmers, a junior, said he would come out only if it looked as if he would be picked in the first round. Chalmers hit the game-tying 3-pointer that forced overtime in Kansas’ victory over Memphis in the N.C.A.A. championship game.

The three-time French Open champion Gustavo Kuerten will not play in next week’s ATP event in Barcelona because of a muscle injury. Kuerten, on his farewell tour, received a wild card to play in what would have been his penultimate event before ending his 14-year career at Roland Garros next month.
Hillary Rodham Clinton says she is best positioned to win in the fall, but exit polling shows that Barack Obama could do just as well.
Call it the Lasik indicator. As consumers cut back on discretionary spending, the number of laser vision-correction surgeries has been falling.
Trevor Immelman had a busy week after his victory at the Masters, but he is ready to play again, in the EDS Byron Nelson Championship.
ATLANTIC CITY (AP) — Ending a battle of more than a year, the City Council voted unanimously on Wednesday to ban smoking on the gambling floor at all 11 Atlantic City casinos, starting on Oct. 15.
In any standard lexicon, the term “floater” refers to a few whimsical images of nature: a gull on the breeze, a passing cloud.
Tracking the quid pro quo money flow in Washington is an urgent priority and long overdue.
A Uruguayan man pleaded guilty Wednesday to charges involving an attempt to conceal the source of $800,000 allegedly intended for the campaign of Argentina’s president.
An Indiana election has not meant so much for decades, but residents of Kokomo said they worried about doing things — anything — very differently.
Mets manager Willie Randolph did not wait long this year to move Carlos Delgado, who has had 3 hits in his last 35 at-bats, down in the batting order.
The White House is set to make public a video showing North Koreans working at a suspected Syrian nuclear reactor.
OVERSEAS DEBT COLLECTORS As the economy weakens and consumers struggle to pay their bills, debt collection is becoming a growing business for outsourcing companies.
THE ARTS.

An article on April 10 about the coming film “The Incredible Hulk” referred incorrectly to the portrayal of the Hulk in the 1978-82 television series about him in citing earlier depictions of the character. He did not speak.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about a split in the Democratic primaries between older and younger voters misidentified a Clinton supporter from Sullivan County, Pennsylvania. Of the two women shown looking over a pamphlet, Germaine Donahue was at left. (The woman on the right was not identified.).

An article on Wednesday about former President Bill Clinton’s criticism of a reporter for what he said was a misinterpretation of earlier remarks he made about race misstated the year that Jesse Jackson won the South Carolina primary. It was 1988, not 1998.

A chart with an article in some editions on April 16 about the 2007 tax return of Gov. David A. Paterson of New York and his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson — which listed a single charitable donation of $150 on a combined income of $269,815 — misstated the year that the average deduction for those in the governor’s income range was $8,528. It was 2005, the last year for which such figures are available — not 2007.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Wednesday about the history of corruption in the New York City Buildings Department misstated, in some copies, the location of a construction site where a crane collapse killed seven people last month. The site is on East 51st Street, not East 50th.

An article on Tuesday about John King, the CNN political reporter, misstated the size of the increase in CNN’s prime-time viewership in February. It rose 130 percent — not 15 percent — compared with February 2007. Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the network that presents “Meet the Press,” whose host, Tim Russert, commented on Mr. King. It is NBC — not MSNBC, which rebroadcasts the program.

An article on Monday about Senator John McCain’s recent fund-raising misstated his campaign’s travel expenses for February and March. The campaign spent $1.64 million on travel in February, not $1.8 million. In March, it spent $1.42 million, not $672,000.

The continuation of an article on Sunday about a Pentagon effort to use military analysts to generate favorable news coverage carried 10 paragraphs that were partly obscured in some editions by a chart. The article can be found at nytimes.com/washington.

An article on Wednesday about the Miami Dolphins’ early signing of the first pick for this weekend’s N.F.L. draft referred incorrectly to the St. Louis Rams, the next team slated to pick. The Rams must wait until the draft begins to negotiate and sign a player; they are not free to do so now. (Only the team with the first draft choice has that right, although the league intends to re-evaluate the rule after this year’s draft.).

A report by The Associated Press in some editions on Sunday about the Major League Soccer tie between the Red Bulls and the New England Revolution misstated, in some copies, the amount of time missed by striker Juan Pablo Ángel of the Red Bulls when he aggravated a hamstring strain. It was the entire second half, not the final 30 minutes. The article also misidentified the player who committed the foul that led to a direct free kick for the Revolution that tied the game at 1-1. It was Chris Leitch, not Jeff Parke.
Banning smoking at charity bingo games may have health benefits, but it is proving harmful to earnings.

An article on April 16 about Joe Simon, who helped create Captain America and appeared at the New York Comic Con last weekend, misattributed a character to him and his partner, Jack Kirby. The Sandman was first written and drawn by Gardner Fox and Bert Christman — not by Mr. Simon and Mr. Kirby, who took it over later.
The latest episode of Ozzie, unplugged included the White Sox manager’s musings on everyone from Mike Mussina to Mariano Rivera.
A bitter rivalry that peaked between 1996 and 2002 has a chance to rekindle its intensity Thursday as familiar faces have returned on both sides.
Citing a 5 percent decline in sales last quarter, Starbucks cut its full-year forecast, sending the company’s stock down nearly 11 percent in after-hours trading.
ALBANY — The State Supreme Court justice chosen last month by Gov. David A. Paterson to be his counsel has decided to remain on the bench.
The case of an imam who faces deportation in New Jersey has galvanized support from community figures who fear the prospect of losing a leader they see as an example of Muslim moderation.
Shareholders approved a set of measures to raise capital, namely a rights offer of about $15 billion, and elected two new members to the executive board.
Darrell Rasner, the 27-year-old right-hander who failed to make the cut for the Yankees this season, is quietly dominating the minor leagues.
Many N.F.L. talent evaluators believe that three years is the necessary incubation period to pronounce a draft pick a boom or a bust.
The man accused of slipping secret military documents to the Israeli government during the 1980s appears to have been living a very public life.
A new multiple sclerosis drug helped lift Biogen Idec’s first-quarter profit by 24 percent. Schering-Plough’s reported decline, was less than Wall Street expected.
The two biggest warehouse retail chains, Sam’s Club and Costco Wholesale, are limiting how much rice customers can buy.
Iran is said to have agreed to answer contentions stemming from American and other intelligence reports that it studied how to design nuclear weapons.
Local governance has become one of the most pressing issues in Afghanistan and one that could determine the outcome of the still uncertain war with the Taliban.
The Titans have traded Pacman Jones to the Cowboys, who have to wait and see whether Commissioner Roger Goodell will reinstate the gifted cornerback and returner.
Joe Flacco, who stands about six and a half feet tall, could be the first quarterback from what used to be called Division I-AA to go in the first round of the N.F.L. draft since 1995.
A former Bristol-Myers Squibb executive was charged with making false statements to the F.T.C. about a pact made with a Canadian maker of generic drugs.
A political friend of Karl Rove in Illinois may have tried to use his friendship with Rove seek the ouster of the United States attorney in Chicago, a prosecutor says.
Senate Republicans blocked a measure intended to overturn a Supreme Court decision limiting pay discrimination suits.
The police commissioner in Mount Vernon is trying to find ways to reach out to a fast growing community of Portuguese-speaking Brazilians.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,034 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:.
The Seattle-based Internet retailer reported that net income in the first quarter rose 30 percent to $143 million from the year-ago quarter.
The Grateful Dead will donate a cache of their papers and props to the University of California, Santa Cruz, which plans to use the items in a research center.
As a reward for leading the Washington Capitals to their first playoff appearance since 2003, Bruce Boudreau has been given a contract to stay on as coach.
G.M. said its first-quarter sales fell less than 1 percent, leaving it about 160,000 vehicles behind its Japanese rival, whose sales grew 2.7 percent.
The delay was sought by the New York State Restaurant Association, which lost its challenge of the new rules in Federal District Court in Manhattan last week.
Who says cellphones are good only for talking? Today they are bringing together two unlikely brand names: Nokia and Spike Lee.
General Electric’s chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, delivered a mea culpa to investors and analysts, after its recent earnings report prompted a steep sell-off.
Gen. Michael V. Hayden said he would continue to run the Central Intelligence Agency as a civilian.
Congress seems oblivious as it works on the farm bill, which will do little to address concerns about expenses and turbulence in commodities markets.
Walking in the literal footsteps of President Lyndon B. Johnson, Senator John McCain sought to project himself as a different kind of Republican.
The Australian leg of the Olympic torch relay began Thursday, shortly after minor protests by both supporters and detractors of China’s government.
Each share of Safeco will be exchanged for $68.25 cash, nearly a 51 percent premium to Safeco’s closing stock price of $45.23 on Tuesday.

Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers agreed on Wednesday to extend their current round of contract talks through May 2, they said in a joint statement.
The Rangers’ captain, who spent 11 seasons with the Penguins and left on a sour note, is not expecting a warm welcome when he takes the ice on Friday.
A French lawyer for a Khmer Rouge leader erupted at the judges of Cambodia’s genocide tribunal because thousands of pages of documents had not been translated into French.
Ms. Colledge, an innovative British figure skater, was the youngest athlete to compete in the Winter Olympics and later won an Olympic silver medal.
The carriers, preparing to merge amid a steep industry downturn, reported a combined loss of $10.5 billion.
The teammates said they planned to appeal a decision that stripped them of their Olympic medals because of Marion Jones’s admitted use of performance-enhancing drugs.
Guardians are accusing the investment bank of failing to prevent the estate’s previous manager, David G. Cannon, from draining millions of dollars held at the bank.
The Nike+ SportBand watch consists of a waterproof wristband with a removable base and a small sensor that receives and records information about your run.
The Connecticut women’s basketball coach said his team’s series against Tennessee was canceled because Lady Vols Coach Pat Summitt accused the Huskies of a recruiting violation.
Despite objections from John McCain, the release of the ad injects a potentially divisive racial element into the North Carolina contest.
The House voted to block the Bush administration from cutting federal spending on Medicaid health care for the poor by $13 billion over the next five years.
Love is all you need, Subaru declares in a push for its 2009 models — along with all-wheel drive, a safety pedal system, low emissions and an environmentally correct plant.
The prospective United National Football League would serve as a minor league to the N.F.L., offering a second chance to promising college players.
Russell Read, who joined Calpers in June 2006, is resigning as it chief investment officer.
Mr. Garretson developed the concept of “refereeing the defense” and had a career that included more than 2,000 N.B.A. games and spanned 31 years.

A day after the resignation of the city’s embattled buildings commissioner, the Bloomberg administration announced a $4 million plan Wednesday to hire specialized engineers to inspect “high risk” construction sites citywide and develop new procedures to make the work safer.
The cost is now estimated at nearly $3 billion, a huge jump from the $660 million estimate that was made in 1998.
The mayor of Baker, La., recalls the lessons learned from hosting the largest encampment for hurricane victims run by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

A case in the Supreme Court concerns where the burden of proof lies when an employer adopts policies that put older workers at a disadvantage, given that the policies are based on “reasonable factors other than age.”
Ambac reiterated that it was writing “very little new business,” and said its results wiped out 40 percent of its net worth.
Federal prosecutors said that they would try for a third time to convict six men accused of conspiring to destroy the Sears Tower in Chicago and join the ranks of Al Qaeda.
The nation’s biggest brewer, said Wednesday that its profit slipped 1.3 percent in the first quarter.
McClatchy said it would buy back for cash up to $250 million of its public debt, much of which it took on in its ill-timed 2006 purchase of the Knight Ridder newspaper chain.
Wall Street ended a choppy session with a moderate advance on Wednesday after a better-than-expected profit report at Boeing and a see-saw day in the energy markets.
Ronaldo failed to convert an early penalty kick and visiting Manchester United tied Barcelona in the European Champions League semifinals Wednesday night.
Mr. Feeney crooned “Danny Boy” and other standards for 25 years on “The Lawrence Welk Show.”
EMC Corporation, the top maker of corporate data storage equipment, reported strong revenue growth in both overseas and American markets.
Mr. Wilson had hits in the 1970s including “Show and Tell” and “La La Peace Song.”
What do Russians themselves think about the ties between the Russian Orthodox Church and the Kremlin, or about the rights of Protestants?
Hossein Sabet owns six hotels, a dolphin show and hopes to build the Middle East’s first Disneyland on Kish, one of Iran’s islands on the Persian Gulf.
Yahoo’s oneSearch software offers voice-activated control that lets you speak your keywords out loud to send the browser.
I thought S.M.S. text had to be kept short, but I seem to be able to send out longer messages anyway. Is the 160-character limit a myth?
When I zoom in on a photo using the Google Earth program, the image is sometimes blurry. Is there a way to fix this?
Customers in western Queens can expect to receive about $100 each from Consolidated Edison as compensation for having to sweat through nine days without power in July 2006, according to officials.
A Syrian cabinet minister said Israel’s premier had indicated that Israel would be willing to withdraw from all the Golan Heights in return for peace with Syria.
To the Editor:.
People think I have it easy, but it’s surprisingly difficult being The Guy Who Got Where He Is Only Because He’s Black.
Because of Orthodox Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended today in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.
Senator John McCain visited the site where President Lyndon Johnson declared a war on poverty, but he offered few specific policies.
Designers at the Milan Furniture Fair explored how they can help us navigate recession, environmental crisis and design’s neurosis about its role in a saturated consumer culture.
To the Editor:.

Judgment day is coming for hosts of reality shows. The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences has created an Emmy Award to recognize “outstanding host for a reality or reality-competition program,” The Associated Press reported.

The Metropolitan Opera is replacing its summer parks series with one free mega-concert this year. The soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna, opera’s married power couple, right, will sing a musical bon-bon program of arias and duets in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on June 20, the Met said on Wednesday. Six jumbo screens will be placed in the Long Meadow, which can accommodate 150,000 people. Bank of America will provide 25,000 bus and subway passes for the event. Usually, the Met produces concert performances of entire operas by lesser-known singers in Central Park and the other boroughs in the summer. Peter Gelb, the Met general manager, called the plan an experiment. “We upped the ante, to make it feel more like an event,” he said.

Three weeks after scoring her 18th No. 1 single, Mariah Carey, below, has scored her sixth No. 1 album. “E=MC2” (Island Def Jam) sold 463,000 copies in the United States, Nielsen SoundScan, reported. That was the best sales week for any album yet this year. Last week’s best-selling album, Leona Lewis’s “Spirit” (Syco/J), dropped one spot with 95,000 copies sold, a 54 percent weekly loss. Miley Cyrus’s “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: The Best of Both Worlds Concert” (Disney), now widely available after more than a month as an exclusive offer from Wal-Mart, jumped 28 spots to No. 3, with 47,000. In fourth place is the self-titled debut from the country trio Lady Antebellum, released by Capitol Nashville; it moved 43,000 copies in its first week out. The soundtrack to “Juno” (Rhino) returned to the Top 10, with a 38-rung leap to No. 8; the film was released on DVD last week.

On doctors’ orders, Roger Ebert, below, will have to forgo a trip to Urbana-Champaign, Ill., for the 10th annual Ebertfest film festival, which began on Wednesday and continues through Sunday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ebert wrote in his blog on The Chicago Sun-Times Web site (suntimes.com) that doctors had told him to remain in a Chicago hospital, where he is recovering from hip surgery after a fall. A Sun-Times film critic for more than four decades, Mr. Ebert, 65, has had a series of operations for cancer in recent years.
A new London musical version of “Gone With the Wind” doesn’t seem destined for a long run.

Dormant for 16 years but still influential, the British rock band My Bloody Valentine will embark on an American reunion tour this fall, according to the Web site The Daily Swarm (thedailyswarm.com). The group, led by Kevin Shields, is preparing a program and will play at an American edition of the British festival All Tomorrow’s Parties (atpfestival.com), from Sept. 19 to 21 in Monticello, N.Y. It will also release a new album this year. ... The reunion docket this summer includes the Feelies, a New Jersey new-wave group that was one of the most beloved local underground acts of the early 1980s. The Feelies will be at Maxwell’s in Hoboken, N.J., on July 1 and 2 as part of that club’s 30th-anniversary festivities, and will also open for the Sonic Youth free concert in Battery Park on July 4.

The Mount, Edith Wharton’s house in Lenox, Mass., which has been in financial trouble for months, has been given another reprieve. In February a local bank that had been lending money to the Edith Wharton Restoration, the organization that owns and maintains the house, to cover operating expenses, threatened to begin foreclosure unless the Mount raised $3 million by March 24. The deadline was later extended to April 24, and Hannah Burns, one of the trustees, said on Wednesday that it had been pushed back yet another month, to May 24, which means that the house will now be able to open for visitors as scheduled on May 9. So far more than $800,000 of the needed sum has been raised.

Singing, dancing and cooking topped the ratings on Tuesday as reality series on Fox and ABC attracted the most viewers for the night. Fox’s “American Idol” dominated the competition as usual, drawing 24 million viewers at 8, Nielsen reported. At 9, the results episode of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” led its time slot with 17.5 million viewers, but Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” (11.6 million) managed to earn higher ratings in the hour among adults 18 to 49. Fox easily finished first for the night, followed by ABC, which struggled during the 8 o’clock hour with two episodes of “According to Jim,” averaging 4.2 million viewers. ABC’s “Boston Legal” drew 10.5 million viewers at 10. CBS was third, faring well at 8 with “NCIS” (14.1 million) but struggling with “Big Brother” at 9 (6.7 million) and “48 Hours” at 10 (4.8 million). NBC finished fourth in total viewers while edging past CBS for third place in the 18-to-49 set, largely because it topped the 10 o’clock hour with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (11.5 million).

The 61st Cannes Film Festival will present films by Clint Eastwood and Steven Soderbergh in a main competition that will be reduced to 20 films this year from 22 in 2007, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Eastwood will be represented by “Changeling,” a mystery set in the 1920s in Los Angeles starring Angelina Jolie as the mother of a kidnapped child. Mr. Soderbergh will present “Che,” a four-hour film about the Argentine revolutionary Che Guevara. Other films in the competition will come from Belgium, Turkey, France, Argentina, Brazil and Italy. Eight of the directors have never previously appeared in the main competition. Woody Allen’s “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” and Steven Spielberg’s “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” will be shown out of competition. The festival, its opening and closing films yet to be announced, will run from May 14 through 25.

Merson, President Boca Rio Golf Club BALL--Jerome E., passed away Tuesday, April 22nd at JFK Medical Center in Lake Worth, Florida. He was 72. The cause of death was complications due to heart surgery. A devoted husband, father, brother and grandfather, Jerry is survived by his wife Renee, his children Steven and Michelle, and four grandchildren, Samantha, Theo, Jonah, and Isabella. Jerry Ball was Chairman of Forward Industries, Inc. in Pompano Beach, Florida, since 1999, and served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of George Arzt Communications, Inc. in New York since 1996. A graduate of St. Lawrence University, Mr. Ball had an extensive and successful career in the textile industry beginning in 1958 with Harry Ball & Son, a family owned business. The company was a major weaver and converter of synthetic fabrics, catering to the menswear industry. In 1961, Mr. Ball became President of Thermofab, Inc. and later purchased the Roje Quilting Company, a division of Thermofab. In 1963, these companies merged with Balson Industries, the successor of Harry Ball & Son, to form one of the largest suppliers to the menswear and industrial textile markets. Mr. Ball was named President of Balson Industries in 1974. During his tenure, Balson acquired several companies with similar core businesses. In 1985, Balson merged with Leiberman Hercules to form the Balson Hercules Group. In 1992, Balson Hercules was sold to Consoltex Group, Inc., a fully integrated Canadian textile company. Mr. Ball served on Consoltex's management committee for Balson Hercules. Later he was named Director of Corporate Development for Consoltex Group, Inc., and was appointed to the board of directors of Consoltex Group USA, Inc. until he left the company in 1996. Before Mr. Ball became Chairman of Forward Industries, he served as the company's Vice Chairman in 1998, and served as Forward's Chief Executive Officer from 1998 until 2007. He was also appointed Secretary of Forward in 2005.

HEHER--Dr. Roger J., 79, a White Plains resident and dentist for over 40 years, died on April 23, 2008. Born on July 10, 1928 in Queens, NY. In 1977 he married Mary Alice Ross at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Dr. Heher attended Georgetown College and graduated from Georgetown Dental School in 1950. He retired in January 1997. He was a parishioner of Our Lady of Sorrows Church, past president of the White Plains Dental Forum, member of Westchester Country Club and played bridge at the Hartes Club in White Plains. Visitation Friday, April 25 from 9 to 10:30am at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605. Funeral mass 11am at Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 920 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains. Donations to Our Lady of Sorrows Developmental Fund in Roger's name.

A new London musical version of ''Gone With the Wind'' doesn't seem destined for a long run after many critics took their cue on Wednesday from Rhett Butler's parting words of disdain, Reuters reported. ''Frankly my dear, it's not up to too much,'' Quentin Letts wrote in The Daily Mail. ''Frankly, my dear, it's a damn long night,'' Charles Spencer of The Daily Telegraph wrote of the show, which runs more than three and a half hours at the New London Theater in the West End. ''Frankly this show is damned,'' The Evening Standard asserted. ''Oh for the fire and passion of Gable and Leigh,'' said Benedict Nightingale of The Times of London, recalling the stars of the classic 1939 film adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning 1936 Margaret Mitchell novel. Directed by Trevor Nunn, renowned for his staging of ''Cats'' and ''Les Misérables,'' the musical has a book, lyrics and music by Margaret Martin, a novice. It stars Darius Danesh, a British television talent show discovery, as Rhett Butler, and Jill Paice as Scarlett O'Hara.

LESHOWITZ--Edward, died peacefully on April 21st, 2008. He leaves behind a daughter, Susan Sandson, a niece Terry Singer, two sisters, Ethel Singer and Sylvia Leshowitz, three grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his wife Esther and his son Jed. He was born on April 12th, 1915 and grew up in Passaic, New Jersey. He graduated from Montclair State University, became a high school teacher and served in the army in World War II. After the War, he and his partners, John and Angelo Cali, created vocational schools for WWII veterans and then created Cali Associates, a construction business, building homes and office buildings in New Jersey and the greater New York area. It later became Cali Realty and then Mack-Cali Realty. Edward was a successful entrepreneur and a generous benefactor. He was a loving and giving father, grandfather, brother and uncle. He had a great sense of humor and strong opinions about politics. He traveled the world and loved to tell storiesabout his travels, his youth, his days in the army and in the classroom. He will be greatly missed. There will be a memorial service at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Ave at 81st St., on Thursday May 1st at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Parkinson Foundation. LESHOWITZ--Edward. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted congregant Edward Leshowitz. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President

KATZ--Rosalyn. Died of natural causes on Wednesday, April 23, 2008 in Arlington, VA. She was 92. She was born in the Bronx, the daughter of Samuel and Ethel Rossoff. After graduating from Hunter College in 1935, she became a gym and health education teacher in the New York City schools. Her first assignment was in Red Hook, Brooklyn. When she retired she had been at Francis Lewis Junior High School for many years. She was also gifted in many other fields, including modern dance, piano (and later the organ), French, and Hebrew. She and her husband, Jerome Katz, met playing handball at Castle Hill Pool in the Bronx. The married in 1940. He passed away in 2000, less than a month before what would have been their 60th wedding anniversary. in 1953 the couple moved with their two young children from the Bronx to Great Neck. Ros became active in the Sisterhood at Great Neck's Temple Emanuel and taught Hebrew there. In 1981 she joined Friends of the Helen Keller National Center in Sands Point, NY, and volunteered unstintingly. Applying her culinary expertise, she provided recipes for students entering independent living. She also learned to use a Braille typewriter, and put countless materials into Braille over the years. In 2001, she received the Center's Angel award for 20 years of service. She celebrated her 90th birthday in the house she'd loved for over half a century, then moved to Arlington to live with her son and daughter-inlaw, Joel Katz and Mary Detweller. She is also survived by her daughter Harriet Katz O'Brien of Los Angeles, her brother-in-law Irving Katz, sisters-in-law Ruth Katz, Shirley Katz, and Ethel Mae Rossoff, and many beloved nephews and nieces. We will always cherish our memories of her warmth, whimsy, wit, and wisdom. Funeral services will be held Friday, April 25, 2008 at 11:30am at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY 11024. in lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Friends of the Helen Keller National Center, 141 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY 11050.
