FLUHR--Edward T., 77, of Tinton Falls, passed away Tuesday April 22, 2008 at Renaissance Gardens, Seabrook Village, Tinton Falls. He was born in Teaneck, NJ, lived in City Island, the Bronx, NY, and later in Westfield, NJ for more than 35 years before moving to Tinton Falls. He was a graduate of Mount St. Michael Academy in the Bronx, 1948, and received his Bachelors Degree from Manhattan College in 1955. Edward served in the US Army during the Korean War. He was owner and president of Brookfield Research and Management Co. from 1985 to 2008. He is survived by his wife of 39 years, Mary Martha Fluhr of Tinton Falls, his son Edward M. Fluhr and his wife Michelle of Silver Spring, MD, and his grandson Ryan. Funeral services will be held on Friday April 25, 2008 at the Church of the Holy Innocents in Neptune, NJ.

ANATOLE--David, October 14, 1909 -April 20, 2008, of Greenwich, CT and formerly of Egremont, MA and Lawrence, NY died after a short illness, but a long and very rich life. Devoted husband for 66 years to the late Babs Anatole. Loving father of Amy Schwab and her husband Jim, and Mark Anatole and his wife Jodi. Proud Poppy to Kate and Joanna Schwab and Emily and Carter Anatole. ''Tolia'' as he was known to his old ''China hand'' friends and family, was born in Kiev, Russia. His 98 years were Horatio Alger-like. David's formal education ended when he left school at age 12 to support his mother and sisters. As a young adult he lived in China where his experiences were the stuff that Hollywood scripts are made of: his travels via caravan to Mongolia to buy wool for British colonials (he was typically the first Caucasian the locals had seen), marriage solicitations from Asian royalty, assisting cavalry escorts fighting bandits in the Gobi Desert before being kidnapped and on and on. David came to the U.S. at age 26 with broken English... and a letter of business introduction. Over the next four decades and throughout his business career, he traveled throughout Europe, Asia, and South America as President of the textile division of a U.S. conglomerate, and later his own company, Haroco, Inc. David was blessed with a lifelong passion, horseback riding and jumping and the hunt, that extended from childhood to his early 90s. His beloved horses, from Adventurer to Captain George all too often gave Babs competition for weekend quality time. At age 90, David wrote his memoirs, ''Ma Chu'', which will remain a wonderful legacy to his family and future generations. Poppy, as Babs always reminded the family, ''Happy Times.'' Donations to the Humane Society (hsus.org) and the Alzheimer's Association, (alzheimersassociation.org)

The Metropolitan Opera is replacing its summer parks series with one free mega-concert this year. The sopranoAngela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna, opera's married power couple, right, will sing a musical bon-bon program of arias and duets in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on June 20, the Met said on Wednesday. Six jumbo screens will be placed in the Long Meadow, which can accommodate 150,000 people. Bank of America will provide 25,000 bus and subway passes for the event. Usually, the Met produces concert performances of entire operas by lesser-known singers in Central Park and the other boroughs in the summer. Peter Gelb, the Met general manager, called the plan an experiment. ''We upped the ante, to make it feel more like an event,'' he said.

WALKING is the Rodney Dangerfield of the fitness world: It gets no respect. Consider walking shoes, historically the clunky, unattractive stepsiblings of running shoes. But walking is the top fitness activity in the United States, with more than 89 million Americans taking part, according to the National Sporting Goods Association. Not only has the number of race-walking events increased -- the number listed on active.com was 23 percent higher in the first quarter of this year over the same period last year -- but more people are participating, inspiring athletic shoe manufacturers to take walking more seriously. Many walking shoes now use running-shoe technologies, namely lighter material and super-breathable fabrics. While many people do walk in running shoes, experts say they shouldn't. Shoes designed for fitness walking have lower heels than running shoes, ''which is better for preventing shin splints,'' said Dr. Douglas Richie, a past president of the American Academy of Podiatric Sports Medicine.

Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Charles Miller, President Steven Tolman, Secretary

The 61st Cannes Film Festival will present films by Clint Eastwoodand Steven Soderbergh in a main competition that will be reduced to 20 films this year from 22 in 2007, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Eastwood will be represented by ''Changeling,'' a mystery set in the 1920s in Los Angeles starring Angelina Jolie as the mother of a kidnapped child. Mr. Soderbergh will present ''Che,'' a four-hour film about the Argentine revolutionary Che Guevara. Other films in the competition will come from Belgium, Turkey, France, Argentina, Brazil and Italy. Eight of the directors have never previously appeared in the main competition. Woody Allen's ''Vicky Cristina Barcelona'' and Steven Spielberg's ''Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull'' will be shown out of competition. The festival, its opening and closing films yet to be announced, will run from May 14 through 25.

An article on Tuesday about John King, the CNN political reporter, misstated the size of the increase in CNN's prime-time viewership in February. It rose 130 percent -- not 15 percent -- compared with February 2007. Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the network that presents ''Meet the Press,'' whose host, Tim Russert, commented on Mr. King. It is NBC -- not MSNBC, which rebroadcasts the program.

MURPHY--Daniel Russell, of Bradenton, Florida, and Corofin, County Clare, Ireland, on April 21, 2008. Dan was born in Scarsdale, NY on November 3, 1930, the son of Lillian and Peter J. Murphy. He graduated from The Lawrenceville School and Georgetown University, and earned an M.B.A. from New York University. With a brilliant mind for financial analysis, Dan had a distinguished career in finance, which began at Bankers Trust. He was then a partner in Faulkner, Dawkins & Sullivan, Executive Vice President of William D. Witter, Inc., Executive Vice President of E.F. Hutton & Co., a co-founder of Finstat, and a board member of DNA Science Inc. Dan was a devoted and beloved husband and father, and a passionate lover of opera and of all things Irish. He is survived by his wife, Karin Hackett Murphy, his daughters, Deirdre Murphy Bader and Sarah Murphy Kelleher, his grandson, Ethan Russell Bader, and his sonsin-law, Lawrence S. Bader and Thomas J. Kelleher. He is also survived by his stepchildren, Deborah Taube and David Hackett, and six stepgrandchildren. Donations in Dan's memory may be made to The Lawrenceville Fund in memory of Daniel R. Murphy, P.O. Box 6125, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648. No funeral is planned, as Dan wished to be returned to his home in Corofin, County Clare.

FREEDMAN--Milton, on April 22, 2008. Beloved husband of the late Ida, loving father of Helene Stoller, brother Stuart Freedman and father-in-law of Larry Stoller and Carla Craig. Cherished grandfather of Heather Stoller, David and Anna Freedman. Longtime resident of Bloomfield Township, Michigan and a New Yorker since 2005. Milton was a determined yet extraordinarily generous man devoted to his family, especially his beloved wife of 58 years, Ida. Milton doggedly overcame numerous illnesses to reach almost 89 years. He was a passionate gardener. Services Thursday, April 24, 10am at the ''Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens.

Novelty as cause for celebration! In ballet, an art so often stuffed with the same old chestnuts, it takes real courage to promote creativity rather than conservation. Diaghilev remains the exemplar here, but in this regard the United States has led the world for several decades. The concept of presenting a multiple-program bonanza of new choreography goes back to the 1972 Stravinsky Festival of New York City Ballet. That event included old works too, but its wealth of innovation became the stuff of legend. At least four of the new works choreographed then have gone into international ballet repertory. One of that festival's dancers was Peter Martins, who now runs City Ballet. In 1988 he staged its American Music Festival along the same lines, and then, starting in 1992, he began a series of occasional, somewhat festival-like spring Diamond Projects, each of which has produced multiple new works within weeks. Another of those 1972 dancers was Helgi Tomasson. Since 1985 he has run San Francisco Ballet, which is now reaching the climax of its 75th-anniversary season by presenting a New Works Festival that bids to rival City Ballet in the new-choreography stakes.

SPOTNITZ--Hyman, Dr. Our condolences to the Spotnitz and Goldberg families. Dr. Hyman Spotnitz, our Honorary President, gave so much to his profession, his patients, his colleagues and his students. He taught us to believe in our abilities to cure the narcissistic neuroses. We celebrate his life and his hopeful impact on the field of Psychoanalysis. Directors, Faculty, Students The Academy of Clinical & Applied Psychoanalysis Livingston, NJ

We extend deepest heartfelt condolences to Harris, Dr. Goldstein's husband and their three children, and the entire family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Clarifying statement: You may be one of the readers who asked if this column was being subjected to, as one put it, "a new kind of censorship" after last week's Petraeus/Crocker piece. The correct answer is "No." It was a case of your comments coming in so fast and in such quantity that the method of processing them and "putting them up" was temporarily overtaxed at around 200 and again at about 480. Nobody got censored, and no comments were misplaced, but some might have been briefly lost in the glut, so to speak. (What a lovely title for a song. "Lost in the Glut"...)

The best part of the Berlin Jewish Museum's newest exhibit on cultural stereotypes comes right at the beginning. On a white screen, a projector beams a graphic montage of advertisements for everything from tobacco to cleaning products employing imagery or characters based on cultural clichés. I was happy to see the ads, only a few years old, for the cigarette brand West. I remember scratching my head at the blatant insensitivity of some of the ads when they first started appearing. Under the claim "Test it", the ads featured odd couples, like a slim blond woman looking coyly at a muscular black man dressed as a pirate and holding a parrot. Another featured a yuppie-ish looking white guy standing next to an African woman in traditional dress, her neck ring seemingly stretched to exaggerated proportions.

Let's face facts: the Web, after nearly 20 years, has failed to uncover new masters of noble art forms like poetry, sculpture and the airport thriller. But it has engendered - for good or ill - new forms of creative expression. Blogs and viral videos are only the most obvious. Fan fiction, wikis, Flash animation and Second Life avatars are a few more. People don't upload to the Web words and images they had fashioned apart from the Web; they fashion their stuff specifically for online platforms and audiences.

In the latest installment of the Clear Channel Communications buyout saga, Citigroup and five other banks Thursday asked a New York judge to throw out a lawsuit by the company's private equity buyers accusing them of illegally refusing to fund the $19.5 billion acquisition.
Geezeo, a site that helps you manage credit cards, loans, checking and savings accounts and more, has raised $1.2 million from investment site TheStreet.com.

Two days after Harbinger Capital Partners' nominees were elected to the board of The New York Times Company, the activist hedge fund scored another victory when its three nominees won seats on Media General's nine-member board Thursday.

The Senate Banking Committee held a hearing this week to beat up on the credit rating agencies and to push the Securities and Exchange Commission to impose tough regulations on them as quickly as possible.

Silverpop, an on-demand marketing technology firm, on Thursday said it took $15 million in funding which it will use to acquire companies with complementary technologies in the hosted services market.

Merrill Lynch is holding high-level talks with TPG that could see the private equity group take a stake in the investment bank if it needs additional capital, according to The Financial Times.

Paine & Partners, a private equity firm based in San Francisco and New York, has hired two operating directors to boost its expansion in the Nordic region and seafood, energy and financial services in particular.

The chief executives of Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines sought to reassure Congress on Thursday that their planned merger would not hurt service, cut jobs, or blunt competition.

Digital Domain, the Hollywood special-effects studio that had planned its initial public stock offering for this week, looks like it's having trouble closing the deal -- at least at the price it wants, The Los Angeles Times said.

Budget airline JetBlue Airways hired a financial adviser to explore strategic alternatives for LiveTV, its in-flight entertainment subsidiary, the company announced in its earnings statement Wednesday.

The aluminum tycoon Oleg V. Deripaska said Thursday that he had bought 25 percent of the Arctic mining company Norilsk Nickel, a deal that furthers Mr. Deripaska's quest to consolidate the Russian metals and mining industry.

Luxury sports car manufacturer Porsche, which has a 31 percent holding in Volkswagen, said it expected to achieve majority control of the automaker by autumn, once regulatory clearances had been obtained.
Irate Washington Mutual shareholders calling for a recount of last week's board of director elections, The New York Post reported.
A private-equity consortium is being formed to examine a possible offer for the insurance arm of Royal Bank of Scotland, put up for sale earlier this week, The Financial Times reported.

A divided appeals court ruled Thursday that Kenneth G. Langone, the former chair of the New York Stock Exchange's compensation committee, must face trial to determine if he breached his fiduciary duty to the exchange by misleading board members about deferred compensation for then-Chairman and Chief Executive Richard A. Grasso, in connection with his hotly disputed $187.5 million compensation package.

In an effort to win points with disgruntled shareholders, Merrill Lynch's board may adopt a measure that would make the directors more vulnerable to future efforts to oust them, The New York Post reported.

Big Brown sizzled in his last serious work before the Kentucky Derby, he went five-eighths in 58.6. He is tentatively scheduled to ship from Florida to Kentucky on Monday and have a final three-eighths sharpener breeze two days before the Derby.

He couldn't get a mile and a quarter in the back of a pickup truck, I assured Joe.

The Kansas and the North Carolina men’s teams, regulars at the top of the national poll, were recognized on another list. The Ivy League had 150 men’s and women’s teams on the list. The Patriot League was second with 89 and the Big East third at 47.

Roger Federer beat Gaël Monfils of France, 6-3, 6-4, on Thursday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Monte Carlo Masters. The top-ranked Federer will play sixth-seeded David Nalbandian, who routed No. 12 Tommy Robredo, 6-1, 6-0. The three-time defending champion, Rafael Nadal, beat Juan Carlos Ferrero, 6-4, 6-1; third-seeded Novak Djokovic of Serbia topped No. 14 Andy Murray, 6-0, 6-4; No. 4 Nikolay Davydenko of Russia defeated No. 16 Philipp Kohlschreiber, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2; and Sam Querrey of the United States upset No. 7 Richard Gasquet, 2-6, 6-4, 6-3.

Joy is usually the emotion felt when a $90,000 mural turns out to be valued at $15 million. Not so in the case of the art-rich, cash-poor Port Authority of Allegheny County, The Associated Press reported. In 1984 the agency installed in the Pittsburgh subway system a 60--by-13-foot tile mural, “Pittsburgh Recollections,” above, by Romare Bearden, who was paid $90,000. The station that housed the mural is to be demolished in an extension of the system, and the authority wanted to know the mural’s value before taking it down. The authority found out, and also learned that it would cost more than $100,000 a year to insure the work. “We don’t have the wherewithal to be a caretaker to such a valuable piece,” said Judi McNeil, a Port Authority spokeswoman. The agency is looking for an organization to pay for removing, restoring and maintaining the mural.

The rapper Snoop Dogg has come up a winner in the latest round of his battle with Britain, The Guardian of London reported. Last year the entertainer, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was refused a visa for a tour after he and five members of his entourage were arrested during a reported melee at Heathrow Airport in 2006. In January an immigration judge, Nehar Bird, said he had found no evidence that Snoop Dogg was responsible for any public disorder. A video recording of the incident showed that at one point he was entertaining young children; he was twice pushed by a police officer and did not retaliate; he complied with an instruction to lie face down; and he did not resist when handcuffed. The Home Office appealed. On Wednesday a senior immigration judge, George Warr, upheld the January decision. The Home Office has until Wednesday to decide if it will appeal again. Snoop Dogg’s lawyer, Phillip Trott, said, “It has been an appalling waste of public money to pursue this man.”.

A multilayered cake named for a remote island in the Chesapeake Bay has become part of Maryland history. Gov. Martin O'Malley signed legislation designating the Smith Island cake the official state dessert. Traditionally served as 8 to 10 thin layers of yellow cake separated by chocolate fudge icing, the confection is seen by some as having potential to spark economic rejuvenation on the small island, where state restrictions on crabbing and oyster harvesting have hampered the work of watermen. The cakes cost about $20. The legislation takes effect Oct. 1.

Mystery solved. The so-called Abercrombie boys who showed up behind Senator Barack Obama during his speech Tuesday night in Evansville, Ind., were just random Obama fans. They had been asked by the Obama campaign to join the crowd behind the candidate. Because they were all wearing T-shirts from Abercrombie & Fitch, they stood out in the crowd, even receiving cellphone calls from friends who had spotted them on television. Soon the news media mentioned them, wondering whether they were part of an advertising campaign, a shrewd bit of product placement by the retailer, which is geared toward the same young crowd attracted to Mr. Obama's candidacy.

Congress approved a one-week extension of the current farm legislation as lawmakers acknowledged that they could not meet a Friday deadline for completing new bill before the current law expires. The House and the Senate have been struggling to reconcile versions of the bill, which includes subsidies for farmers as well the food stamps program. Lawmakers have been stuck on how to pay for as much as $10 billion in additional spending above the base budget allocation for the bill. ''We want to finish up the good bill that we have before us,'' Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa and chairman of the Agriculture Committee, said. ''I urge the president not just to sign that extension, but to begin to show constructive leadership in helping us to get this bill done.''

YOUNG PEOPLE'S CHORUS OF NEW YORK CITY Most composers lust after commissions from orchestras, opera companies and string quartets. Fewer have children's choirs high on their wish lists. But Francisco J. Núñez hopes to change that with his remarkable Young People's Chorus of New York City, above, and its Transient Glory series, which continues on Sunday at the Miller Theater. Mr. Núñez founded the choir in 1988 with kids of diverse economic and ethnic backgrounds. In 2001 he inaugurated Transient Glory (named after the fleeting beauty of developing voices) to expand the serious repertory for children's choirs and to encourage composers to write for the medium. Since then the ensemble has commissioned dozens of works by an eclectic range of notable composers, including Steve Reich, George Crumb, Judith Weir, Bright Sheng, Milton Babbitt and David Del Tredici.

KLEIN--Jeffrey P. -The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn with a heavy heart the passing of Jeffrey P. Klein, our beloved Board member of 28 years. No organization could have a more devoted friend; for three generations, the Y was privileged to serve as the Klein family's community and cultural center. Jeff's father Seymour M. Klein was the Y's president from 19721975 and a long-standing Board member. Jeff's grandmother, Bertha ''Bertie'' (Mrs. Isaac) Liberman, was also a long-standing Y Board member who joined the Board of the Young Women's Hebrew Association in the 1920s and joined the 92nd Street Y Board in 1945. A longtime major benefactor of the 92nd Street Y, Jeff truly believed in the Y's mission and vision to continue serving the community well into the 21st Century. We will deeply miss Jeff's passion, particularly his ardent support of the 92nd Street Y's performing arts programs through its Tisch Center for the Performing Arts, and the 92nd Street Y's Makor/Steinhardt Center, where he championed its new facility at 200 Hudson Street. Our hearts and prayers are with his wife, Michele. May she and all of Jeff's friends and family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. We are in a new gilded age, though this is not a good time to remind us how the first one ended, and the weddings have blossomed to match. There was no better place to witness that phenomenon than at the Wedding Salon, a luxury bridezilla convention that was founded by Tatiana Byron and held at Gotham Hall on Monday. The entrance fee was $75, but women (almost all were women) lined up around the block in Manhattan. By the end of the day, about 2,800 people had marched through to talk with florists, caterers and honeymoon specialists.

RUNWAY SAFETY Despite efforts by the Federal Aviation Administration to increase safety on the ground, aviation specialists say that runway incursions remain a problem. Dallas air traffic controllers systematically hid their involvement in safety incidents in which planes came too close together, federal officials said. [C4.]

'THE HUMAN FACE IS A MONUMENT' Titled after a 1965 movie by the underground filmmaker Stan VanDerBeek (1927-1984), ''The Human Face Is a Monument'' is a lively group show at Guild & Greyshkul that could be subtitled ''And Glossy Magazines Are a Feminist Gold Mine.'' May Wilson (1905-1986) is represented by several little-known collages from the late 1960s, whose latticelike layering of images create a kaleidoscopic mix of voyeurism, patterning and interior. In Sarah Charlesworth's ''Figure Drawings,'' a work initiated 20 years ago, 40 small, individually framed figurative silhouettes -- mostly sculptures -- catalog poses, gestures and meanings.

Loan Problem Is a Benefit for Some Investment bankers may be worried about layoffs, but it looks as if an awful lot of lawyers stand to benefit from the subprime mortgage crisis. A study released by Navigant Consulting found that nearly as many subprime-related federal lawsuits were filed in the first quarter of 2008 as in the last six months of 2007: 170 in the three months ended March 31, compared with 181 in the six months ended Dec. 31. Those numbers may well understate the total, because they do not include claims filed in state courts.

NORA CHIPAUMIRE New York is filled with strong, gorgeous dancers who can pour themselves into a piece, disappear in it almost, to become anonymous embodiments of a choreographer's vision. Nora Chipaumire, above, is not one of those dancers. She is gorgeous, certainly, and plenty strong: statuesque and muscular, with a shaved head, this striking Zimbabwean-born dancer is a fierce, riveting force who holds the stage as if she is holding desperately fought-for ground.

'KITE FLIGHT: PLASTIC PLAY' Miwa Koizumi and Marco Scoffier think they have found the perfect way to dispose of all those plastic shopping bags that accumulate in landfills (not to mention households): just send them into the atmosphere. Although this may sound like a solution that would make environmentalists blanch, Ms. Koizumi and Mr. Scoffier have no intention of polluting the air. Their plans involve barbecue skewers, packing tape, string and, most important, enthusiastic children. As artists, they have devised a way to turn two or more plastic bags into a modified box kite, and they will demonstrate on Sunday as part of ''Kite Flight: Plastic Play,'' a workshop sponsored by Socrates Sculpture Park and the Noguchi Museum in Queens.
Where we are most vulnerable at this moment is on the ground. To me, this is the most dangerous aspect of flying. MARK V. ROSENKER, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board. [A1]

DALY--Robert P., Sr. April 27th, 1921 April 19th, 2008. Longtime resident of Manhasset, LI passed away peacefully after a long struggle with lung cancer. Predeceased in 1996 by his beloved wife of 42 years, Evelyn (nee Huisking). Survived by his son Robert and daughter - in - law Frances (Murray) Daly of South Norwalk, CT, by his daughter Margaret (Peggy) McCrary of Tallahassee, FL; also by his six cherished grandchildren: Laura, and triplets Ava, Ilsa and Ingrid McCrary, and by twins Robert and Peter Daly. He was also predeceased by his son-in-law, John McCrary. Only child of New York Supreme Court Justice Peter M. and Marion (Crawford) Daly, he was raised in Astoria, NY and Huntington, LI. Attended Xavier High School in NYC, and graduated from Georgetown College. After war service he received an LLB degree from Georgetown's Law School, later serving as national Vice President for the university's law alumni association. Proud World War II veteran, he served as communications officer, grade of lieutenant, aboard aircraft carrier USS Wasp in the Pacific Theater; awarded the Combat Action Ribbon, Navy Unit Citation and authorized to wear eight battle stars on the Asiatic-Pacific campaign medal and two battle stars on the Philippine Liberation medal. For the remainder of his life he faithfully attended his ships reunions all over the U.S. Admitted to the bars of New York and the District of Columbia, he maintained a law practice in LI City for many years, and was honored in 2000 by the Queens County Bar Association on the 50th anniversary of his admission. He held office as President of the St. Patrick's Society of Queens and of the LI City Lawyers Club, also served on the Emerald Society of the Archdiocese of NY. For many years until his death he was Vice President and a director of the charitable Huisking Foundation, and also served many years on the board of directors of Glyco Corp. Member North Hempstead Country Club; life member, Huntington Yacht Club, where he served many years as Flag Secretary and as Legal Officer, and where he maintained his boats until his wife's illness. He was an award-winning amateur photographer, talented artist, author of several magazine articles, and his eclectic interests included woodworking, electronics and shortwave radio, cryptography, history, travel, model railroading, yachting and astronomy. He chose not to pursue a promising early career in politics because he wished to spend a private life with his family. Outgoing and friendly, he could converse with and show genuine respect and interest in people from every walk of life. He will be greatly missed. Visiting at Fairchild Sons Inc. of Manhasset, Sunday April 27th, and Monday April 28th, 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, Tuesday, April 29th, 11am, St. Mary's Church, Manhasset, where he was a parishioner for over 40 years. Private interment for family and close friends, St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington, LI.

CHRIS ROCK When Senator Barack Obama made a speech about race last month, the consensus from commentators was that it was rare to hear such a frank meditation on the topic. Well, candor about race may not be a common practice for politicians on the stump, but it's nothing new to comedy clubs, where black comedians have often held the spotlight by refracting the lens to illuminate issues of race in America. No one is better at this than Chris Rock, above. Following in the tradition of Richard Pryor and Eddie Murphy, Mr. Rock's jokes -- if they can be called that -- would be heartbreaking if they weren't delivered in a voice ready to start a fight and paired with comedic timing ready to dispel one. Mr. Rock brings his own meditation on race, and class, to Madison Square Garden for five nights starting on Wednesday. The appearance, with Mario Joyner, is a return for Mr. Rock, who opened his appropriately named ''No Apologies'' tour with a sold-out show at the Garden on New Year's Eve. Since then he has crisscrossed the country at a pace rivaling that of a political campaign, and this year's election hasn't been far from his mind. In January he gave Mr. Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton a good ribbing, although he reserved his most blistering words for Mrs. Clinton. Challenging her campaign message, that she has more experience, he said, ''You get on a plane tomorrow, you want the pilot's wife flying you?''
BAKER--Florence,. 4/25/94, We miss you so much. Love Paula, Beau & Bobby

THE MONT ALTO MOTION PICTURE ORCHESTRA We are lucky enough in New York City to have a handful of highly talented pianists who are experts in the subtle, self-effacing art of providing accompaniment to silent films. But it's a particular pleasure to hear silent-film music as it was actually performed in most of the first-run theaters of that era -- which is to say, by an orchestra. The five-member Mont Alto Motion Picture Orchestra, based in Louisville, Colo., and led by Rodney Sauer, can be heard on several silent-film DVDs, but the group will offer its first live performance in Manhattan on Friday at Lincoln Center, accompanying two films of high interest in themselves: Harold Lloyd's 1927 comedy ''The Kid Brother'' (6 p.m.) and William A. Wellman's rarely screened 1928 social drama ''Beggars of Life'' (9 p.m.), with Louise Brooks (above, with Richard Arlen) as a young woman who kills her abusive stepfather and, to escape the police, disguises herself as a boy and joins a group of tramps.

Samir A. Vincent, an Iraqi-American businessman who was ensnared in -- and eventually cooperated with -- the sprawling investigation into improprieties in the United Nations' oil-for-food program was sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan to three years of probation. Mr. Vincent pleaded guilty in 2005 to working secretly on behalf of the Iraqi government to lobby American and United Nations officials about the oil-for-food program. In exchange for his efforts, he received millions of dollars in concessions to sell Iraqi oil. Mr. Vincent avoided prison time largely because of the substantial cooperation he provided to prosecutors. He was the chief government witness in the trials of Tongsun Park, a South Korean businessman who was sentenced to three years in prison on charges of illegally trying to influence United Nations officials, and of Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., a Texas oil tycoon sentenced to a year and a day in the case.

O.K., Jets fans, your turn. You made a lot of noise at Radio City. Commissioner Roger Goodell could hardly get out a word starting with J without a roar starting. Even the most fleeting image of the Patriots on the video screens brought out robust boos. The Jets' first pick, Vernon Gholston, was serenaded by chants before he was even drafted. Then when the Jets traded up to get a second first-round pick, the crowd, a bit moribund as the round dragged on, was brought back to life. With the Giants now selecting after the Jets, the atmosphere at Radio City was electric, with dueling chants and people on their feet waving their colors in the mezzanines.

Sergei Movsesian of Slovakia, the top seed and No. 25 in the world, and Emil Sutovsky of Israel are the leaders of the men's European Championships after six rounds. Each has 5.5 points. Viktorija Cmilyte of Lithuania, Anna Ushenina of the Ukraine and Ekaterina Kovalevskaya of Russia, who each have 5 points, are tied for the lead of the women's championship which is running concurrently in Plovdiv, Bulgaria's second-largest city. The Web site for the tounaments includes standings, lists of participants, games and results of previous championships.

Greeting from Radio City, football fans! We're finally up and running after some Internet connectivity issues, the worst kind for a blogger. I have a seat behind the Jaguars representatives and in front of the NFL Network crew. Come to think of it, my seat is quite near where I was the last time I was here, for the Christmas Spectacular. I thought it would be cheesy, and it was, but it was also awesome because the Rockettes are a world wonder. I'm sure five hours from now, when the Giants finally make the last pick of the first round, I'm going to be wishing Roger Goodell was dressed in a bear costume dancing to "The Sugar Plum Fairy."

Mike Bossy, the former New York Islanders star, recently completed his second season with the NHL team as the executive director of its business club, a networking job involving sponsors, suite holders and season-ticket holders. Bossy was recently in Calgary to help promote a fund-raising street hockey tournament headed by former Canadian national women's team captain Cassie Campbell and Slap Shot sat down with the four-time Stanley Cup champion to discuss his views on the game. Here is an edited transcript of the interview.

SOUTH BEND, Ind. -- Senator Hillary Clinton began her campaign speech at a minor league stadium here by brandishing a baseball bat and promising to hit balls out of the park. She ended it by challenging Senator Barack Obama to a different sort of contest.

Off the Triple Crown front, Peppers Pride, the Pride of New Mexico, is going for her 16th consecutive victory this afternoon. If she is successful in the $75,000 Russell and Hellen Foutz Distaff Handicap at SunRay Park, she will equal the modern-day record.

It's becoming increasingly obvious that the "Save Darfur" movement needs to expand to try to "Save Sudan." That's because the international community's failure to respond adequately to Darfur is also leading the fragile north-south peace agreement in Sudan to unravel. If the north-south war resumes, as seems increasingly likely, the death toll will be measured in millions. Andrew Natsios, the former U.S. special envoy for Sudan, makes that case in an important article in the latest Foreign Affairs. Andrew argues that we need to engage Sudan and offer carrots, and I agree with him on that; he also argues against threats and sticks, and I disagree with him on that. My bet is that we need to have more credible sticks and carrots alike to get the Sudanese government to stop slaughtering its people, but Andrew knows his stuff and his article is well worth reading.

The crowd went absolutely nuts as Fernando Alonso appeared out of nowhere and grabbed provisional pole position for a few seconds before Kimi Raikkonen crossed the finish line a tenth of a second faster than him. So much for Pat Symonds downplaying Renault's strength this weekend yesterday. Still, with that crowd behind him, Alonso may have found that half second at home that Nigel Mansell spoke about with his home races - Nelson Piquet Jr., Alonso's teammate, was in 10th position nearly a second behind. The Spanish crowd knew what an achievement this was for their star driver and they rose to their feet and stayed there for several minutes cheering.

The Rangers were eager to move on Saturday from Friday night's Game 1 debacle against Pittsburgh, but Penguins Coach Michel Therrien was not ready to let go of the conversation about the interference call on Rangers forward Martin Straka against Penguins center Sidney Crosby that the Rangers found so egregious.
Odds and ends from a slow morning in the clubhouse -- Willie Randolph told players they did not have to report until 11:30 a.m., and many took advantage.

A few weeks ago, my wife passed on her copy of "Oryx & Crake" by Margaret Atwood. It's a horrifying sci-fi novel about a near future where genetic engineering has gone amok, global warming has made North America baking hot with daily torrential downpours and a human-engineered virus has wiped out just about everybody on earth.

When former President Bill Clinton called a Guam radio show on Thursday morning to talk up his wife, it was described as a historic first. The same was said of Senator Barack Obama's decision to open a campaign office in Hagatña, the territory's capital.

Re "Change Can Be Painful, but This One Shouldn't Hurt" (April 6):I'm one of those "passionate" readers who love the printed paper. I do like the slimmer version - in part because it helps the environment, as well as The Times's purse. The newest change was, I admit, quite irritating at first.But at my advancing age of 77, I don't trust myself to accept habits and customs with sufficient grace. So I forced myself, and after a couple of days I scanned the pages and sure enough found references to which I immediately turned.I do read the whole paper, so it's overkill for me, but it can be handy. I agree that two full pages is a bit much. I'm glad to note that it will be pared down some. Onward and upward.Nadia KoutzenToms River, N.J., April 6, 2008

Aired Friday night on NBC: Last night, we had Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger on the show. You know, I always like having him on, because after we tape the show, I like to go home and watch the closed captioned version so I can find out what he said.

Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are each making two campaign stops in Indiana today, but that's a cakewalk compared to what Bill Clinton's got on his agenda -- six rallies in Oregon.

Chelsea pushed its unbeaten streak to 19 games in the English Premier League on Saturday, beating the defending league champion Manchester United, 2-1, at Stamford Bridge to draw even in points (81) with the Red Devils with two regular-season games to play. United could have virtually clinched the title with a victory or a draw.

One of George W. Bush's lesser but still important talents is his uncanny ability to destroy peoples' reputations: from John DiIulio to Michael Mukasey, well-regarded figures have entered the Bush administration's doors, only to reemerge soiled and diminished.

Alexander Grischuk of Russia and Wang Yue of China are tied for the lead of the first Grand Prix tournament with 3.5 points after five rounds. Four players are a half point back. Standings, games and video interviews with the players are available on the tournament's official Web site. Today is the first rest day of the tournament; it resumes tomorrow.

In Game 3 of the Suns’ first-round playoff series against the Spurs, Tony Parker exploded for a career-high 41 points to lead San Antonio to a 115-99 victory.

With the arrival of the comically exuberant action-adventure-romance “Tashan” in theaters on Friday, the Great Bollywood Bikini Question of ’08 — will she or won’t she wear one? — was finally answered. Readers, she did.
Vesna Vulovic, who survived a 33,300-foot plummet from a plane explosion 36 years ago, fears that it is the current political situation in her native Serbia that will kill her.

Hundreds of men prayed in Baghdad's Sadr City on Friday alongside flags said to bear the names of people killed in fighting with the United States military and Iraqi troops. In a statement read at the prayers, the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers unite with all Iraqis and focus their firepower on driving out the "occupation forces."

An eighth-grade soccer player was shot and wounded during a game at a school in Omaha, around the same time gunfire was reported at a nearby elementary school.
Nearly two dozen others were injured on the street-level waiting area of the elevated train station during the evening rush hour.

Morgan Hamm’s petition to the United States championships was approved, keeping alive his quest to make a third Olympic squad. Hamm dropped out of a qualifying meet Wednesday because of an allergic reaction that made breathing difficult. His withdrawal forced him to file a petition to gain a spot in next month’s nationals.

After years of battling the effects of Parkinson’s disease, the former cycling star Davis Phinney got some long-awaited relief. Doctors in Palo Alto, Calif., activated a pacemaker that was embedded earlier this month into his brain, and after several hours of adjusting the settings of the device, Phinney, 48, had no detectable tremor on the left side of his body and was walking with far more ease than usual.
The Mets’ poor hitting and fielding continued as the team lost for the fifth time in six games on Friday to drop to 11-11.
Andy Pettitte let an early lead slip away in a four-run fifth inning, and the Indians spoiled Alex Rodriguez’s return.
Game 1 of their second-round playoff series against Pittsburgh was electrifying in the way the Rangers did not want it to be — a frenetic offensive show.
Nathan Haynes singled with no outs in the 11th inning, driving in Carl Crawford from second and giving the Tampa Bay Rays a 5-4 victory over the visiting Boston Red Sox.
Shares in the wireless equipment maker Ericsson surged after the Swedish company surprised investors with better-than-expected results in the first quarter despite a 55 percent drop in earnings.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company posted a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit, driven by price increases, the sale of more expensive tires and favorable foreign exchange rates.
Nomura Holdings, Japan’s largest securities business group, posted a net loss of $1.48 billion Friday for the January-March quarter, largely because of ties to bad United States debt.

After hearing testimony from patients whose vision was impaired by laser surgery, a Food and Drug Administration panel said Friday that the agency should do a better job informing patients of the surgery’s risks.
Daniel L. Sparks, head of Goldman Sachs’s mortgage division, is leaving after a successful bet on the declining value of subprime home loans helped the company produce record earnings last year.
Chris Coste had three hits and three runs batted in, and the Phillies’ bullpen pitched more than five innings of effective relief in a 6-5 victory against the host Pittsburgh Pirates.
On the surface, it is a simple real estate conflict. But to some members of the greater Brearley School community, what is happening suggests an identity crisis.
A former teacher at a Muslim school in Maryland was again sentenced to 15 years in prison for providing support to a Pakistani terrorist group.
A shark believed to be a great white killed a 66-year-old swimmer with a single giant bite across both legs in Solana Beach, authorities and witnesses said.
Former Representative Craig Washington said he was innocent of a charge that he fired a gun at an 18-year-old’s car in downtown Houston.
A pregnant teller shot in a bank robbery in Indianapolis has lost the twins she was carrying, and the police continued to search for the gunman.
The Episcopal Church filed suit against a breakaway diocese in central California over ownership of property and assets.
Tony Stewart, Nascar’s two-time champion, is back on top as a highly coveted free agent who has triggered a bidding war that could lure him away from Joe Gibbs Racing.
A project known as Esperanza planned for Asbury Park has stalled because of the downturn in the economy, returning an unwelcome familiarity to the community.
The police said four people in Tokyo and Yokohama had killed themselves Friday by inhaling hydrogen sulfide gas they produced by mixing detergent and a bath lotion.
A Seoul court handed down a 10-year prison term to a 70-year-old man who set the fire that destroyed the country’s most prominent landmark in February.

Leftist politicians said they would end their takeover of Congress, which had shut down legislative business for 16 days as they protested President Felipe Calderón’s plan to overhaul the state’s oil monopoly.
Parliament’s lower house gave initial approval to a bill that would allow courts to close media outlets that disseminate libelous or slanderous material.
In his final start for the Mets, Tom Glavine got one out and gave up seven runs in a loss that cost the team a chance for the playoffs.

Ryan Moore, playing for only the third time in 10 weeks, shot a three-under 67 Thursday, sharing the lead with Eric Axley and Mathew Goggin at the EDS Byron Nelson Championship in Irving, Tex. Only 24 of the 156 players in the field broke par in the first round played on the redesigned TPC Four Seasons course.

Tom Watson and Andy North teamed to birdie the first seven holes en route to a better-ball 13-under 59 for a three-shot lead after the first round of the Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf tournament at The Club at Savannah Harbor in Savannah, Ga. The teams of R. W. Eaks and Bob Gilder, Keith Fergus and Wayne Levi, Morris Hatalsky and Don Pooley, and John Cook and Joey Sindelar were 10 under.

Annika Sorenstam shot a four-under-par 67 at the Stanford International Pro-Am in Aventura, Fla., drawing her within one shot of Young Kim at the midway point of the inaugural event, being contested at Turnberry Isle. Kim also shot a 67, matching her first-round score on Turnberry’s Miller track. Paula Creamer (71) and Angela Stanford (70) were both at two under.
Rutgers Athletic Director Robert Mulcahy III said talks about a long-term series between the Scarlet Knights and Notre Dame broke down over where the Rutgers home games in the series would be played.

Tiger Woods reported Friday that he was no longer on crutches since surgery last week on his left knee but added in his monthly newsletter that he did not know when he would return. “I knew a couple of months ago I was going to have the surgery,” Woods said. “The knee has been bugging me for a while. The only decision was do you miss the Masters or play in the Masters? I decided to play. Even if I had won, I still would have had the surgery.”.

Brett Favre became the first retired player to have his picture on the cover of the Madden NFL ’09 video game. And yes, he is retired — the Packers filed papers with the league to make it official. Favre said he did not play the game, which is in its 20th year.
John McCain was right to demand that Republican Party leaders in North Carolina take down a new television ad that attacks Barack Obama.

The Pentagon said it was halting briefings and all interactions with retired military officers who appear as analysts in the media, pending an internal review.
A tentative agreement would increase spending on food stamps and other nutrition programs while mostly maintaining existing farm subsidies.

John McDonnell, who has been cross-country coach at Arkansas since 1972 and men’s track coach since 1977, will retire in June, after the N.C.A.A. championships.

Although this year’s N.F.L. draft is marked by superb depth, there are no slam-dunk superstars.

The Dow ended its second straight winning week with a moderate advance Friday, as investors put aside concerns about consumer confidence and inflation. Broader stock indicators were mixed.

The time could not be worse for an epidemic of stem rust in the world’s wheat crops. Yet millions of wheat farmers face this spreading and deadly crop infection.

The host Sixers added one more surprise victory in a season stuffed with them by completely thrashing the playoff-tested Detroit Pistons on Friday.

Joe Clark  is retiring from the Metropolitan Opera after a 31-year career as one of the critical behind-the-scene figures at an opera house that puts on more than 200 performances a year, involving several dozen productions.

John Selya has gone for broke with “La Voix,” an updating of “La Voix Humaine,” the one-character play by Jean Cocteau in which a woman falls apart emotionally and physically during a telephone conversation with the lover who is abandoning her.
You hear constantly that China is a country of young people, but you really see it in business, where a whole generation of young entrepreneurs has gone from rags to riches.
Jérôme Kerviel, the Société Générale trader who used his knowledge of the bank’s electronic risk controls to conceal billions in unauthorized bets, has a new job — at a computer consulting firm.
Over the last week, the jazz world has been reeling from the announcement that the International Association of Jazz Educators, a de facto trade organization, is going out of business.

The Argentine poet Juan Gelman received the Cervantes Prize, the Spanish-speaking world’s highest literary honor, from King Juan Carlos of Spain on Wednesday in Alcalá De Henares. Mr. Gelman, 77, lost his son and daughter-in-law during the Argentine dictatorship and has written of it in poignant verse. ... “Adding Machine,” the musical adaptation of Elmer Rice’s 1923 play, will extend its run at the Minetta Lane Theater through August 31. ... Carol Fishman will become the general manager of Playwrights Horizons, the company said, replacing William Russo, who will become the managing director of New York Theater Workshop. ... A 9-year-old Australian actress, Jordana Beatty, was chosen from among 4,000 auditioners to play Eloise in “Eloise in Paris,” a film based on Kay Thompson’s book about a girl who lives at the Plaza Hotel. Uma Thurman will co-star. ... Lawrence Rinder has been named the director of the Berkeley Art Museum/Pacific Film Archive, succeeding Dr. Jacquelynn Baas, the interim director.

Jim Lehrer, the longtime anchor of “The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer,” PBS’s evening newscast, underwent successful heart valve surgery on Wednesday. “Jim plans to be back at full speed and on the program within a few weeks,” the network said on Thursday. A spokeswoman for Mr. Lehrer said he first felt ill on April 18 and checked into the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Substitute hosts will fill in on the show while he recovers.

Guillermo del Toro, right, will direct “The Hobbit,” the much-anticipated two-part film adaptation of the book by J. R. R. Tolkien, Variety reported. Mr. Del Toro is moving to New Zealand for the next four years to work on the movies, whose events precede those of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy. The films are being produced and financed by New Line Cinema and MGM. The hiring of Mr. del Toro comes four months after New Line settled a lawsuit with Peter Jackson, the director of the “Lord of the Rings” movies and co-executive producer of “The Hobbit,” over profits from the trilogy. Mr. Del Toro’s new film, “Hellboy 2,” is due out in July. His previous film was “Pan’s Labyrinth.”.

Paul McCartney, below, will give a free concert on June 14 that is expected to draw more than 100,000 people to Independence Square in Kiev. Victor Pinchuk, a Ukrainian businessman and philanthropist whose foundation invited Mr. McCartney to perform, said, “For the first time we have the opportunity to hear the songs that changed the world and created a new culture.” The foundation will also exhibit 40 of Mr. McCartney’s paintings at the Pinchuk Art Center.

Tom Cruise is scheduled to return to “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” nearly three years after an appearance that spawned countless YouTube parodies and jokes, The Associated Press reported. The two-part show will coincide with the 25th anniversary of Mr. Cruise’s film “Risky Business.” Ms. Winfrey will interview Mr. Cruise from his home in Telluride, Colo., for the first show on May 2, her production company said. On May 5 he will appear in Ms. Winfrey’s Chicago studio. Mr. Cruise became the butt of jokes after a May 2005 appearance on her show where he repeatedly jumped on her couch, saying that his love for his girlfriend, and now wife, Katie Holmes, was “beyond cool.”.

The fiercely independent and self-governing musicians of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra have given a vote of confidence to their conductor, Simon Rattle, below, in favor of “continuing to work with Sir Simon after the end of his contract,” which expires in 2012, said Stefan Stahnke, an orchestra spokesman. “It’s just a first step,” he said, and the two sides will begin discussing details of a new contract. Mr. Rattle’s contract began in 2002.

The singer Amy Winehouse, right, was arrested on suspicion of assault after reports that she scuffled with two men during a wild night out, The Associated Press reported, citing Sky News television. Ms. Winehouse, 24, was at a London police station to answer questions relating to the incident, her representatives said. She said nothing to a crowd of photographers and cameramen as she walked into the Holborn station late on Friday afternoon. The police said only that a 24-year-old woman was being held on suspicion of assault, but a man was quoted in newspapers as saying that Ms. Winehouse hit him in the early hours of Wednesday morning when he got in her way while she was playing pool at a bar in the Camden neighborhood of London. The man said she then head-butted another man, who was trying to hail her a cab.
In hopes of improving customer service at state agencies, new personnel rules backed by Gov. Ted Strickland will require most state employees to work 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

On the first night of the May sweeps period, new episodes of “Ugly Betty” and “Grey’s Anatomy” gave ABC the ratings lead on Thursday among adults 18 to 49, Nielsen estimated. Both shows were down some 20 percent in that demographic compared with their previous season averages. CBS’s “Survivor” (13 million) and “CSI” (16.7 million) drew the largest audiences at 8 and 9 p.m., and CBS’s “Without a Trace” did at 10 (13.5 million), opposite ABC’s “Lost” (12.4 million). That ABC drama was second to “Grey’s Anatomy” in the 18-to-49 age group. NBC placed third, and Fox fourth.

A world premiere of a play based on Dostoevsky’s “Notes From Underground” will be among the works in Yale Repertory Theater’s 2008-9 season. The play, “Underground,” was written by Robert Woodruff, who will direct, and Bill Camp, who will star. The season also includes “Lydia,” a new play by Octavio Solis; “Passion Play” by Sarah Ruhl; “Rough Crossing” by Tom Stoppard; and “Death of Salesman” with Charles S. Dutton.

The Smithsonian Institution’s catalog and online store have suspended operations but plan to be back in business by the end of the summer, the Smithsonian said on Friday. In 2002 the two operations were turned over to an outside vendor, the AB&C Group, a West Virginia subsidiary of BlueSky Brands. AB&C Group’s closure on March 14 caused the Smithsonian to suspend sales. The suspension was reported on Friday in The Washington Post. The Smithsonian is now searching for a replacement, said a spokeswoman, Linda St. Thomas, who added that AB&C had handled as many as 300,000 orders a year for the museum.

Dr. Jon M. Hanifin of the Oregon Health & Science University in Portland was a leader in establishing the criteria for diagnosing chronic eczema, or atopic dermatitis, in 1980. If patients stick to a proper skin care regimen of baths, corticosteroid ointment and moisturizers, said Dr. Hanifin, a dermatologist, “we can almost always get them really in good control.” Here are five things he believes every chronic eczema patient should know.

I am curious about the Falcons' choices. Let's assume that defensive end Chris Long (Virginia) and defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey (L.S.U.) are gone by the time Atlanta makes the third overall pick. Do the Falcons really need to draft a quarterback that high? There is no team in the draft more in need of a safe pick than the Falcons. And the safe pick is Matt Ryan of Boston College. He is considered to have the greatest potential to be a franchise quarterback. So that would seem like a no-brainer, except some might prefer Dorsey.

We have heard from horsemen and handicappers about synthetic surfaces, but bettors may be making the loudest statement of all: Keeneland's 16-day spring meet concludes Friday, and average daily betting is down by 12.7 percent. Through Thursday, bettors placed $133.5 million in wagers over 15 days, compared with $142.7 million over 14 days last year, when the track was closed for Easter Sunday. The average daily handle dropped to almost $8.9 million a day, from $10.2 million.

When former President Bill Clinton called a Guam radio show on Thursday morning to talk up his wife, it was described as a historic first. The same was said of Senator Barack Obama's decision to open a campaign office in Hagatña, the territory's capital. With four delegates up for grabs in caucuses on May 3, Guam is a player in the Democratic primaries for the first time. Though island residents cannot vote in the general election, they can help choose a presidential nominee. In fact, Guamanians need not be registered voters to participate. While the caucuses are open only to registered Democrats, people can sign up on site.

Klein, our beloved Board member of 28 years. No organization could have a more devoted friend; for three generations, the Y was privileged to serve as the Klein family's community and cultural center. Jeff's father Seymour M. Klein was the Y's president from 19721975 and a long-standing Board member. Jeff's grandmother, Bertha ''Bertie'' (Mrs. Isaac) Liberman, was also a long-standing Y Board member who joined the Board of the Young Women's Hebrew Association in the 1920s and joined the 92nd Street Y Board in 1945. A longtime major benefactor of the 92nd Street Y, Jeff truly believed in the Y's mission and vision to continue serving the community well into the 21st Century. We will deeply miss Jeff's passion, particularly his ardent support of the 92nd Street Y's performing arts programs through its Tisch Center for the Performing Arts, and the 92nd Street Y's Makor/Steinhardt Center, where he championed its new facility at 200 Hudson Street. Our hearts and prayers are with his wife, Michele. May she and all of Jeff's friends and family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. From Jake Long first to David Vobora as Mr. Irrelevant, and with 250 picks in between, the N.F.L. draft has come and gone more quickly than ever before, making the real winners the fans who want to watch the draft without allowing it to consume every waking hour of a weekend.

ROUND: 1 (6th OVER ALL)Vernon Gholston DE, Ohio StateHeight: 6-3 Weight: 264Gholston is defined by numbers that defy description. Where to start? Gholston weighs 264 pounds, up from the 238 he weighed at the start of college. Off the field, he ran a 4.56-second 40-yard dash, bench-pressed 455 pounds and squatted 405 pounds 20 times. On the field, he racked up 87 tackles, 22½ sacks and 30½ tackles for loss in his career at Ohio State, including a school-record 14 sacks his junior season.

ROUND: 1 (31ST OVER ALL)Kenny Phillips S, MiamiHeight: 6-2 Weight: 213Phillips is what General Manager Jerry Reese called a "clean" pick. Not only is he a skilled athlete out of a program that produces many defensive back difference-makers, but he has few question marks. The Giants were not even in contact with him during the off-season except for at the combine and Phillips's pro day at Miami. Primarily a free safety in college, he also played strong safety and cornerback. He is a smart player with experience in man and zone coverages. Coach Tom Coughlin said he would contribute on special teams right away if nothing else.

Caleb Campbell, a safety from West Point, was selected in the seventh round by Detroit. In 1952, when McCarthyism was at its height, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas labeled the investigative techniques of the junior senator from Wisconsin "guilt by association" (Adler v. Board of Education). Douglas added that McCarthyite tactics were "repugnant to our society" because, despite the absence of any overt wrongdoing, the pasts of those attacked were "combed for signs of disloyalty" and for utterances that might be read as "clues to dangerous thoughts."

John Eisenberg is an author and sportswriter who worked in newspapers for 28 years, mostly at The Baltimore Sun, where he was a columnist until June 2007. He has written five books, including "Native Dancer, the Grey Ghost: Hero of a Golden Age," and "The Great Match Race," about the first major sports event in American history, a North-South horse race in 1823. He co-wrote his most recent book, "My Guy Barbaro," with jockey Edgar Prado.

For the longest time on Saturday, it seemed as if the Philadelphia Eagles were never going to make a pick. Eagles fans, who are always one of the loudest contingents in the Radio City crowd, would rise to their feet and cheer when their team was on the clock. At No. 19, the Eagles traded the pick to Carolina, and their fans sat down -- only to get up and cheer when they learned Philadelphia had gotten a first-rounder next year in return. The Eagles (and their fans) were up again at No. 43, acquired in the Carolina deal, but they traded that one, too. So their fans sat back down.

Less than a week after her first IndyCar victory, Danica Patrick put away her smile and went back to work, qualifying third for the I.R.L. race at Kansas Speedway. Scott Dixon and Dan Wheldon swept the front row in qualifying on the mile-and-a-half oval. Dixon took the top spot with a four-lap average of 213.956 m.p.h. Patrick nearly knocked him off with a consistent run of 213.225, but was bumped to the second row by Wheldon (213.641).

Tony Stewart appeared to lock down the pole position at Talladega Superspeedway with a stout qualifying lap. Joe Nemechek, the 46th of 47 drivers to make a qualifying attempt for Sunday’s Aaron’s 499, stole his thunder, knocking Stewart off the pole with a lap of 187.386 miles per hour, to better Stewart’s 186.896. It was his first pole since 2005.

Dario Franchitti injured his ankle in a crash on the 10th lap of the Nationwide Series race at Talladega, sending him and driver Larry Gunselman to a hospital for observation. Franchitti had qualified for Sunday’s race, but he will be replaced by David Stremme.
Tom Watson and Andy North combined for a better-ball 62 at the Legends of Golf in Savannah, Ga., for a four-stroke lead heading into the final round of the Champions Tour event.

Annika Sorenstam struggled with her putting but shot a one-under-par 70, taking a one-shot lead over Paula Creamer at the Stanford International Pro-Am in Aventura, Fla. Sorenstam, seeking her 71st L.P.G.A. Tour victory, has won five consecutive events when she has taken a one-shot lead into the final round.

Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal will meet in the Monte Carlo Masters final on Sunday for the third straight year. Federer advanced after Novak Djokovic retired, trailing, 6-3, 3-2. Nadal beat Nikolay Davydenko, 6-3, 6-2, reaching his fourth straight final.

Adam Scott made two front-nine bogeys but shot a three-under 67 to get to eight-under 202 and a three-stroke lead heading into the final round of the PGA Tour’s Byron Nelson Championship in Irving, Tex.

Offensive tackle Michael Roos agreed to a contract with the Tennessee Titans that guarantees him $15 million. The total value of the deal is $43 million if he completes the contract’s six-year term, which makes Roos the third-highest-paid left tackle in the N.F.L. behind Orlando Pace and Walter Jones.

Tiffany Snow scored her fifth goal of an Olympic qualifying tournament as the United States remained undefeated with a 3-1 victory against the Netherlands Antilles in Kazan, Russia. The Americans (5-0) face Belgium (3-1-1) in the championship Sunday.

Carlos Sainz won the Central Europe Rally in a Volkswagen Touareg in Veszprem, Hungary. The Nascar driver Robby Gordon was on a team that finished 10th. Sainz and his co-pilot, Michel Perin, completed the seven-day, 1,670-mile event in 11 hours 18 minutes 8 seconds. Stephane Peterhansel was second and Deiter Depping finished third. The Central Europe Rally is the first event of the Dakar Series, started by the organizers of the Dakar Rally, which was canceled this year because of terrorism threats.

Sam Vincent was fired by the Charlotte Bobcats after one turmoil-filled season as coach. Vincent struggled to find a consistent rotation and clashed with his players while leading the Bobcats to a 32-50 record. Vincent, a former first-round pick of the Boston Celtics who played with Jordan in Chicago, had worked for one year under Avery Johnson with the Dallas Mavericks, his only N.B.A. coaching experience.
The international governing body for basketball announced two rules changes that might make international basketball look more like the N.B.A.

Offensive tackle Michael Roos agreed to a contract with the Tennessee Titans that guarantees him $15 million. The total value of the deal is $43 million if he completes the contract’s six-year term, which makes Roos the third-highest-paid left tackle in the league behind Orlando Pace and Walter Jones. The 6-foot-7, 315-pound Roos has started 48 consecutive games.

The 36 Hours column last Sunday about London misidentified the member of the Beatles who scrawled on a piece of paper the first lyrics to the song “Help!,” part of the collection at the British Library Reading Room. It was John Lennon, not Paul McCartney. The column also misstated the years during which Samuel Johnson worked on his famous English dictionary. It was published in 1755; he did not work on it in the mid-1800s.

To the Editor: I was delighted, and envious, to read that on her return to Florence (“Florence, Italy: Cammillo Trattoria,” April 13), Mimi Sheraton found Cammillo warm, welcoming setting and flavorful cuisine relatively unchanged.

To the Editor: While “Waging the Battle of the Overhead Bin” (March 30) in the Practical Traveler column is already a reality, imagine the increased demand for the limited overhead bin space with airlines charging for a second piece of checked luggage!.

To the Editor: Having been to Chiang Mai myself, I was surprised the article “36 Hours in Chiang Mai, Thailand” (April 13) did not mention the incredible nightly market. True, it can be somewhat of a tourist trap, but it is a wonderful experience and I still kick myself over things I didn’t buy there as I thought I would find more and better things in Bangkok or Malaysia. It is well worth a visit. Linda Pennington.

JESSYE NORMAN, the distinguished American soprano, has been less visible in New York during the last few seasons. She returns on Thursday to Carnegie Hall with the pianist Mark Markham, in a lineup that interweaves Europeans like Brahms, Mahler, Wolf and Richard Strauss (there are more) with American and trans-Atlantic popular songs by Harold Arlen, Gershwin, Weill and Vernon Duke. Ms. Norman realizes that the classical art song and the American song literature written before and after World War II are closer cousins than some people want to think. I think she has the right idea.

DAY--James. The CUNY TV Advisory Board, Foundation Board members, and the CUNY TV staff, mourn the passing of James Day. As we mourn, we celebrate the life of this extraordinary man: public television pioneer, creator of acclaimed and pacesetting public television programming, television interviewer, professor, mentor and great friend to us all. He was always a gentleman. Jim was modest about his role as the creator in 1954 of San Francisco's acclaimed public television station KQED that won a worldwide reputation for his imaginative and bold programming. In 1969 Jim became the president of NET, the predecessor to PBS. When NET merged with New York's WNDT/Channel 13, Jim became president of the channel, renaming it WNET. Jim served on the establishing boards of PBS and Children's Television Workshop. From 1976 until 1988 Jim was Professor of Television and Radio at The City University of New York (CUNY) Brooklyn College. Jim's generosity as a teacher and mentor enabled the careers of many working in television today. In 2000 Jim honored CUNY TV by agreeing to be the Chair of the Advisory Board and in 2003 a member of the CUNY TV Foundation Board. We offer our condolences to Jim's sons Douglas, Alan, Ross and their families, and to Jeanne Alexander, his partner for the past fifteen years. We are proud to have had Jim's guidance and friendship. We will always cherish him and all he did for CUNY TV. Robert Isaacson Executive Director DAY--James, April 24, 2008. A pioneer in public television for over five decades. Husband to the late Beverley, beloved father to sons Douglas, of San Jose; Alan, of Sunnyvale, CA; and Ross, of New York City, and late daughter Meredith of New York. No funeral service; contributions can be made to Meredith Day Johnson Fund, San Francisco Foundation, 225 Bush St., Ste. 500, San Francisco, CA 94104. A memorial service is planned for December.

ON a fine September night in 1946, in a ballpark out on the marshy edge of Newark's East Ward, the Newark Eagles -- one of the two professional baseball teams, one black and one white, that shared Ruppert Stadium -- trotted onto the field in jerseys so new and bright they looked almost incandescent under the lights. The players were black, the uniforms white. The team's co-owner, Effa Manley, had just spent $700 on a new set, about as much as she paid her best players each month. It was the Eagles' first time in the Negro World Series, and she wanted them to look the part of champions.

An article last Sunday about local opposition to a luxury hotel and restaurant planned in the West Village misidentified the historic district within which the building will be built. It is the original Greenwich Village Historic District, designated in 1969, not the 2006 extension of that district.

A review of Adam Green in the Playlist column last Sunday misstated the label that released his album ''Sixes & Sevens.'' It is Rough Trade -- not Matador, which is owned by the same umbrella company as Rough Trade but is a separate label.

MAREI von SAHER stood in the offices of the Bruce Museum here a few weeks ago in front of ''The Sacrifice of Iphigenia'' (1671), an old master painting by the 17th-century Dutch artist Jan Steen. Mrs. von Saher, a coach at the Greenwich Skating Club and a former professional figure skater, said she was still in ''a little bit of shock'' that the painting, which had been hanging in the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam until February 2006, had come into her possession.

Before her spiritually earnest recent guest appearance on ''American Idol,'' DOLLY PARTON was lying low, having ducked out of a major tour. She cited back strain as the cause, a bit colorfully. (As Reuters put it, in a widely carried headline: ''Dolly Parton postpones tour, blames breasts.'') Now Ms. Parton, the world's most effervescent country star, is playing her rescheduled dates, barring any further setbacks. Her proud new album, ''Backwoods Barbie'' (Dolly), which briefly cracked the Top 20, takes a brightly self-conscious approach to her plasticized image, notably on the title track: ''Don't let these false eyelashes lead you to believe/That I'm as shallow as I look, 'cause I run true and deep.'' That much should be obvious, but Ms. Parton can hardly be faulted for making the case every now and again. Thursday at 8 p.m., Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171, radiocity.com; $49.50 to $100. Saturday at 8 p.m., Borgata Casino, Atlantic City, (866) 692-6742, theborgata.com; $65 to $125. Another female pop polymath known for messing with notions of glamour -- besides the obvious one, who appears on the cover of this section -- is the singer-songwriter Allison Goldfrapp, namesake of the British electropop duo GOLDFRAPP. ''Seventh Tree'' (Mute), the group's fourth proper album, leans somewhat surprisingly in the direction of languorous folk-pop, rather than fluorescent dance music. There's no telling which side the breathy Ms. Goldfrapp will emphasize at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday; maybe, like Ms. Parton, she can have it both ways. At 8 p.m., 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070, beacontheatre.com; $35 to $55.

STRIKING A POSE IN OLD HAVANA, DEC. 19, 2007 Lydia Wong, 21, standing, a student at York University in Toronto, on vacation with, left to right, Nicole Ng Yuen, Sarah McInnes, Julia Rourke and Sofiya Osipov, fellow Canadian students. ''We thought it would be a great time to just relax because our exams had just finished, so we decided to go to Cuba because it was one of the cheapest flights down to a hot place. We went horseback riding, diving, snorkeling; we went on a catamaran. I'd been before, so when I went back, I thought it was going to be not as fun. But it ended up being a lot more fun because I knew some of the things to do and things not to do. Before I went, I had some doubts because my parents and my friends were like, 'You shouldn't go there because it's a Communist country,' and all that stuff. But it was actually really friendly, and really safe.

KOTUR--Robert Karl, of New York, NY, and Ashley Falls, MA, on April 20th in his 72nd year after a valiant battle with a bone marrow disease. Robert is also survived by his four grandsons, Robert, James, George and William Marin. A graduate of Ohio University, and a veteran of the US Navy, Robert settled in New York where he established his career in market research until his retirement in 2000. Known for being a true gentleman and devoted family man, Robert was adored by all. ''It is the nakedness of drawing that I like,'' Philip Guston once said. Drawing, part of a back-to-basics ethos, helped him to negotiate the transition from Abstract Expressionism to a more figurative style. During his most restless and embattled period, from 1966 to 1968, he abandoned painting entirely and made hundreds of drawings, some as simple as a commalike swipe of an ink brush on an otherwise blank piece of paper. ''PHILIP GUSTON: WORKS ON PAPER,'' opening on Friday at the MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM, is the first retrospective of his drawings in two decades. The show was organized by the Kunstmuseum in Bonn and the Staatliche Graphische Sammlung in Munich. The Morgan is its only stop in the United States.

THE NEWS Pirates operating in the Gulf of Aden off the coast of Somalia hijacked a Spanish tuna boat and a ship from Dubai carrying food and also fired on a Japanese oil tanker. BEHIND THE NEWS The attacks were the latest in a series by well-armed pirates in the lawless gulf and provoked international demands for action. The United States and France are drafting a United Nations resolution that would allow countries to chase pirates into territorial waters. Pirate attacks globally were up 20 percent between January and March over the same period last year, the International Maritime Bureau said, and noted: ''Waters around Somalia continue to be notorious.''

The Northwest Boys and Girls Club of Hartford may seem an unlikely place for President Bush to commemorate Malaria Awareness Day. GRAHAM--Robert H. Fairway Regulars are stunned by his death. He advised them on cheese, calmed restless children. Always smiled. Our neighborhood mourns. GRAHAM--Robert Harold. The owners, management and employees of Fairway Markets are profoundly saddened by the sudden passing of Bobby. A valued and esteemed employee of the downtown store for 25 years. His warmth and intelligence made an invaluable contribution to our success. The kindness he demonstrated to everyone fills our now aching hearts. We extend our deepest condolences to beloved daughters, Niaja and Mya and his entire family.

Youth has not been wasted on any of the young dancers performing in the 1 2 3 FESTIVAL, opening on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. The dancers are members of three second or junior companies attached to the Alvin Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, American Ballet Theater and the Paul Taylor Dance Company. All three will perform on opening night. Such ensembles were once primarily a way of training new senior company members, often on the road in theaters too small to present the larger and more established troupes to which they were attached. And audiences certainly got their money's worth in programs that combined expertise with a hunger for the work at hand that made for exhilarating dance. In recent years the second companies have also served as crucibles for new pieces by choreographers ranging from familiar to unknown. AILEY II(also performing Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., May 3 at 2 p.m. and 8 p.m., May 4 at 2 p.m., May 7 at 7:30 p.m. and May 8 at 8 p.m.; $44) has perhaps the most adventurous program, with premieres by Troy Powell, Christopher L. Huggins and Stephane Boko. The Board of Trustees, the Headmaster, Faculty, Staff, and the entire Collegiate School community mourn the loss of our loyal and accomplished alumnus, former President of the Board of Trustees, and former President of the Alumni Association (1976-1979), Jeffrey P. Klein 1961. A charming and respected man dedicated to his family and friends, to the children of New York City, and especially to the boys of Collegiate School, Jeff will be sorely missed. With his commitment to service as his beacon, Jeff gave of himself ably and selflessly during his long service on the Board of Trustees, serving as President of the Board from 1994-1998. During that time, Jeff's leadership, forwardlooking vision, generosity, and tireless work with the Collegiate community enabled the School to greatly improve and expand its physical plant; his devotion to learning enabled him to be an effective steward in the realm of scholarships; and his focus, creativity, and clear sense of purpose enlarged the number of alumni actively engaged with the School and encouraged them to support Collegiate's students, service initiatives, and the values and ideals on which the School was founded. In 2001, the Alumni Association conferred on him the honorific of Distinguished Alumnus. A warm and gracious man, Jeff will be greatly missed; he has left an unassailable legacy to our School. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Michele Gerber Klein. Lee M. Levison Headmaster George R. Bason, Jr. 72 President, Board of Trustees

HEADING HOME In 2005, with one week remaining at the New York Yankees' spring training camp, Manager Joe Torre and General Manager Brian Cashman called me into the visiting team locker room office after a game against my former employer, the Philadelphia Phillies. I knew I wasn't standing on solid ground, since it hadn't been the best spring training of my career. But it wasn't my first rodeo, either. I had been brought in by the Yankees as a hired gun to support an oft-injured outfield and to provide the sort of depth where, should one of their star outfielders need a day off, the team wouldn't be losing that much in leadership. But after all was said and done, here I was in a 6-by-8 makeshift conference room about to get my pink slip.
