Ever since Christopher Hampton adapted ''LES LIAISONS DANGEREUSES'' for the stage in a Royal Shakespeare Company production in 1985, the story of sexual warfare among French aristocrats has become the Britney Spears of 18th-century epistolary novels: a bosom-heaving entertainment that never goes away. The hit play transferred to Broadway and quickly became a Hollywood movie starring Glenn Close and John Malkovich. Several film versions based on the novel followed, including Milos Forman's ''Valmont'' and the guilty pleasure ''Cruel Intentions,'' which updated the story to the cutthroat world of Manhattan prep schools. The novel, first adapted into a film in 1959 in a version starring Jeanne Moreau, has also been turned into a television mini-series, an opera, a ballet and even a pornographic film. So, one might wonder, why is the Roundabout Theater reviving this war horse (in a period production staged by Rufus Norris) yet again? I'm sure there are many answers, but for me the most compelling might be the opportunity to see the great LAURA LINNEY stretch herself as the conniving, seductive Marquise de Merteuil.

All it takes to be part of the celebration of spring is to fling yourself into a colorful scarf. With beds of tulips and rows of cherry trees on Park Avenue, the city is ablaze with color. The trees in Central Park are a lacy web of fresh spring green. The perfume of nearly 20 varieties of narcissus, shown here, wafts over the Conservatory Garden at 105th Street and Fifth Avenue, with their sumptuous allies of flowering apple trees. Women all over the city have been brightening the fashion picture with their colorful scarves, both day and evening (below), but the prize for the most original was the woman seen on Third Avenue at 93rd Street. Her stole, which she found on the Web, was made from felt hats cut in half and riveted together, proving there is no old hat in fashion. Just uncontrolled imagination.

THE plug-in hybrid will move one step closer to commercial reality this week with the release of a secondary battery package that its maker, A123 Systems of Watertown, Mass., calls a range extender module. Designed to give a Toyota Prius enough power to drive 30 to 40 miles on electricity alone, the battery is the main component of a conversion package that fits in the well normally occupied by the spare tire, with a charging port on the back bumper. The module costs $10,000 and the conversions will be done by six approved installer companies.

SPOTNITZ--Hyman. The Board of Trustees, students, faculty, staff and alumni of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies mourn the loss of Hyman Spotnitz who inspired the ground breaking form of treatment known as ''modern pyschoanalysis''. His techniques revolutionized the non-drug treatment of schizophrenia and other narcissistic disorders and had a profound effect on clinicians in agency settings and private practice. CMPS was the first of many institutes founded to teach his theories and techniques and to provide ''talking treatment'' for the entire range of emotional disorders. Through his work as a psychoanalyst he touched many people's lives. He will be missed though he lives on in those people whose lives he affected, the institutes he inspired, and the many faculty who keep his thinking alive, vital, and relevant.

MURPHY--Daniel Russell. Of Bradenton, Florida, and Corofin, County Clare, Ireland, on April 21, 2008. Dan was born in Scarsdale, NY on November 3, 1930, the son of Lillian and Peter J. Murphy. He graduated from The Lawrenceville School and Georgetown University, and earned an M.B.A. from New York University. With a brilliant mind for financial analysis, Dan had a distinguished career in finance, which began at Bankers Trust. He was then a partner in Faulkner, Dawkins & Sullivan, Executive Vice President of William D. Witter, Inc., Executive Vice President of E.F. Hutton & Co., a co-founder of Finstat, and a board member of DNA Science Inc. Dan was a devoted and beloved husband and father, and a passionate lover of opera and of all things Irish. He is survived by his wife, Karin Hackett Murphy, his daughters, Deirdre Murphy Bader and Sarah Murphy Kelleher, his grandson, Ethan Russell Bader, and his sonsin-law, Lawrence S. Bader and Thomas J. Kelleher. He is also survived by his stepchildren, Deborah Taube and David Hackett, and six stepgrandchildren. Donations in Dan's memory may be made to The Lawrenceville Fund in memory of Daniel R. Murphy, P.O. Box 6125, Lawrenceville, NJ 08648. No funeral is planned, as Dan wished to be returned to his home in Corofin, County Clare.

EDERSHEIM--Mark. The members of the Women's Health Symposium Executive Steering Committee extend our deepest sympathy to our friend and devoted member Claire on the loss of her husband and loving companion, Mark. Our thoughts and prayers are with Claire and the other members of the Edersheim family. Myra Mahon and Joan Weill Co-Chairs EDERSHEIM--Maurits Ernst, beloved husband of Claire, father of Peggy, Judith, Terri, Ellen, Steven, Leo and Arthur. Loving grandfather of ten grandchildren, brother of Hans, brother-in-law of Helen, uncle of Kathy. Born 1918 in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, he emigrated to New York in 1940, interrupting his studies at the Haute Ecole des Sciences Politique, in Paris. Shortly thereafter, he joined the US Army, and was assigned to the OSS. After WWII, he embarked on a long and successful Wall Street career, where he was among the first Fund Managers to emphasize the benefits of International Investing, eventually becoming Deputy Chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, and subsequently a Deputy Chairman of Smith Barney Asset Management. Among the many awards he received, he was appointed a Member of the Order van Oranje-Nassau, and a recipient of the Peter Stuyvesant Award from the Netherlands-America Foundation, and of the Half Moon Trophy from the Netherlands Club of NY. Throughout his life, he remained devoted to Dutch causes, trains, and his charitable pursuits. He was also instrumental in the creation of the Erasmus Chair of Dutch History and Culture at Harvard University. An ardent reader with a phenomenal memory, an infectious sense of humor and boundless energy, his love, guidance and generous spirit will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: The NetherlandsAmerica Foundation, 82 Wall Street, Suite 1101, NY, NY 10005.

GURLEY--Henry Fraser, 82, died in Durham, NC on April 15, 2008. A service will be held at St Paul's Chapel, in NYC, on May 3rd at 10:00 AM followed by a burial at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Mr. Gurley was born on September 27, 1925 in Brooklyn, NY to Henry F. and Melene M. Gurley. He served in the U.S. Army during WW II and received the Purple Heart for injuries sustained at the Battle of the Bulge. After the war, he attended the University of Virginia and graduated in 1950. Mr. Gurley worked for Sperry Rand Corp. and retired in 1987. During his retirement, he enjoyed sailing, restoring cars, and family genealogy. He was a member of the Sons of the Revolution, the St. Andrew's Society, Sewanhaka Yacht Club, and a UVA life member. He is survived by his three sons, Henry (Jay), Bruce, and Robert, their families including seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his brothers, John and Andrew.

9 P.M. (13, 49); 11:30 P.M. (21) CARRIER The U.S.S. Nimitz is 24 stories high, as long as three football fields and home to more than 5,000 Navy personnel and 85 aircraft, one of which is shown at left. Culled from 2,000 hours of high-definition video filmed over six months in 2005, this five-part documentary series, to be shown two hours nightly through Thursday, follows those aboard -- from an admiral to the youngest sailors -- as they deal with duty, family and the war on terror during a deployment to the Persian Gulf, three months of which were spent in combat on the ground. 7 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION Gerald Martinez, an Albuquerque pastor, has used his church and his own duplex as havens for the homeless. But the influx of people, as well as financial difficulties -- the Martinezes charge no rent -- has left the family in nearly as bad shape as those they take in. In this two-hour episode Ty Pennington and his crew give them a new home, complete with a kitchen and privacy.

Last Thursday night at 6:30 p.m., I joined a group of female entrepreneurs determined to learn the secrets of eliminating stress from our lives. It was smack in the middle of rush hour and few of us arrived right on schedule. The remainder trickled in over the next half hour, with each latecomer exuding a look that said, "My life is so busy that it is hard to be punctual even for a destressing workshop." We filed into the conference room at In Good Company Workplaces and then Jennifer Edwards, a "stress reduction educator" with a background in dance, meditation and yoga, asked us to go around the table introducing ourselves along with a statement about why we think we were all so stressed. It went something like this:

"He's risking heart failure, brain damage . . . even death. Paramedics are standing by . . . you'll have to see it for yourself!"Ah, nothing like daytime television when it comes to sober presentations of science. "The Oprah Winfrey Show" is promoting David Blaine's appearance this Wednesday as a death-defying feat, which is not quite the way scientists (or Mr. Blaine) see his attempt to break the world record for breath-holding. Underwater breath-holding can lead to fatal blackouts if you do it without proper supervision, but Mr. Blaine will be carefully observed. Experts like Ralph Potkin, the pulmonologist who monitored Mr. Blaine during his training (which I described in my Findings column), say that prolonged breath-holds don't appear to cause harm to the body -- at least not in the short term.

Yohji Yamamoto's recent show at Beijing's Forbidden City was one attempt at healing the cultural wounds, and the after the show, the collection the designer trotted out was auctioned off to benefit the Yohji Yamamoto Fund for Peace, a scholarship sending a Chinese designer west to learn the rag trade.

"The Supreme Court on Monday upheld Indiana's voter-identification law, declaring that a requirement to produce photo identification is not unconstitutional and that the state has a 'valid interest'' in improving election procedures as well as deterring fraud," reports The Times's David Stout. "In a 6-to-3 ruling in one of the most eagerly awaited election-law cases in years, the court rejected arguments that Indiana's law, probably the strictest in the country, imposes unjustified burdens on people who are old, poor or members of minority groups and less likely to have driver's licenses or other acceptable forms of identification."

"Quiet, gemlike, perfect" or "tumultuous and raw"? Surely "Housekeeping" is both, and the magic of Robinson's craft is that she under-paints every scene with so many conflicting emotions that we are scarcely aware, on first reading, of the tumult roiling beneath the surface of the prose - akin to the horrors of death and decay beneath the calm surface of the glacial lake at the center of the novel.

When the city closed the Fulton Fish Market in 2005, moving it to the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, it marked the end of a 183-year tradition of working-class life on the Manhattan waterfront. A new exhibition of photographs at the South Street Seaport Museum, by a photographer who devoted years to documenting the lives of the men who worked along the piers, pays tribute to that tradition, not long gone yet seeming already to be an element of the city's mythic past.

If there is one concept most non-Koreans associate with Korean food, it is grilled marinated beef. At many Korean restaurants, short ribs are stripped off the bones, marinated in a soy-based sauce and grilled at the table; the hot meat is then wrapped in cool lettuce and eaten with the hands. Here's a way to replicate the dish at home.

Growing up in the Scottish countryside I had a very real sense of history - from Roman forts to old potato drills - being buried in the land, and one of my first and strongest reactions as I came to know America was that this wasn't true here. Rereading "Housekeeping" reminded me, all over again, that I simply hadn't known how to read the signs. From the opening sentence, with its litany of names, Robinson makes clear that this is a novel in which the past is present, sometimes almost overwhelmingly so, and that it takes a major act of will - like Lucille's - to escape its thrall.

Early in 2007, The Times published an article by a freelance writer, John Collins Rudolf, recounting a visit to a newly identified island off the east coast of Greenland, dubbed Warming Island by Dennis Schmitt, an Arctic adventurer, composer and linguist from Berkeley, Calif. The island had long been presumed to be a peninsula, until a sheath of ice, retreating under the influence of recent Arctic warming, pulled back to reveal it was unconnected to the main mass of Greenland. Last year, Mr. Schmitt told Mr. Rudolf that he hoped the island would become an international symbol showing how global warming was transforming the world.

Since the beginning of the year, we have been inundated with the gas, food, sub-prime, market turmoil stories. (Is there any good economic news anymore?) Looking to history for clues, Patrick McGeehan of The Times suggests that New York would suffer more in a recession that started in the financial markets than by one that began in manufacturing (when was the last time the United States had a manufacturing recession?).New York, more dependent on Wall Street and more closely linked to the global economy than the rest of America, feels Wall Street job losses more acutely, since many of those positions are so high-paying jobs and have a ripple effect through the city. New York suffered longer in the the last two recessions, in the early 1990s and after the dot-com collapse.

Buyout group Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has closed its European fund at about 6 billion euros ($9.4 billion), a third more than its previous vintage but less than the initial 8 billion euro target, Financial News reported.

Xunlight, a developer of cheap, flexible thin-film silicon solar modules, has capped off a $22 million second round of funding, led by Trident Capital, Emerald Technology Ventures and NGP Energy Technology Partners.

Has Continental Airlines turned out the lights at the airline merger party? Its decision Sunday to end merger talks with United Airlines and stay independent has left few options open for another Delta/Northwest-like merger.

HBOS's board will meet on Monday to discuss a possible 4 billion pound ($7.9 billion) rights issue ahead of the British banking group's annual investor meeting on Tuesday, according to British press reports.

A proposal by Blockbuster to acquire the consumer electronics retailer Circuit City may provide an opportunity to see if two wrongs can make a right. Both companies are struggling to turn a profit as they try to update business models that seem stuck in the 1990s.
The Wachovia Corporation agreed on Friday to pay as much as $144 million to end an investigation that accuses the bank of allowing telemarketers to use its accounts to steal millions of dollars.

Wachovia is being investigated by federal prosecutors as part of an inquiry into alleged laundering of drug proceeds by Mexican and Colombian money-transfer companies, The Wall Street Journal reported.

How on earth did the credit crisis on Wall Street become such a catastrophe, Ben Stein wonders in his latest column for The New York Times? How, he asks, did all of the mechanisms operated by the mind-bogglingly well-paid men and women of the Street go so wrong that we saw a major investment bank, Bear Stearns, essentially disappear?

Bear Stearns's former chairman and chief executive, Alan C. Greenberg, is planning to give $360,000 to some of the firm's lowest-paid workers, who may lose their jobs when Bear merges with JPMorgan Chase, The New York Times reported.
Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest securities business group, posted a net loss of $1.48 billion Friday for the January-March quarter, largely because of ties to bad United States debt.
Rackspace, a profitable computer services firm, filed late Friday to raise up to $400 million in an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Kushner Companies is selling a 49 percent stake in the retail portion of 666 Fifth Ave. to the Carlyle Group and Stanley Chera's Crown Acquisitions for $525 million, The New York Post reported.
Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is putting Al Gore to work, after taking on the former vice president as a partner ocusing on clean-technology investments in November.
The Pacific Investment Management Company plans to open the first fund managed by Mohamed A. El-Erian since he rejoined the company after quitting as the head of Harvard University's endowment.

Austin Ventures said Monday it has set aside $50 million for a new corporate social-networking software and services company, which will be led by Jeffrey Dachis, the co-founder of the technology consulting business Razorfish.

Jérôme Kerviel, the Société Générale trader who used his knowledge of the French bank's electronic risk controls to conceal billions in unauthorized bets, has a new job - at a computer consulting firm.

Telemar Participacoes, owner of Brazil's largest telephone company, agreed to buy the parent of Brasil Telecom Participacoesor 5.86 billion reais ($3.5 billion), creating a carrier that controls almost two-thirds of the country's land lines.

Mars, the maker of M&M's, said early Monday it had agreed to acquire Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the chewing gum concern, for $23 billion. In an unusual twist, the deal includes financing from Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company run by Warren Buffett.
Freenet agreed to buy rival Debitel for 1.63 billion euros ($2.6 billion), forming Germany's third-largest mobile-phone company and fending off a takeover from United Internet.

As the fan base for music-related social networking sites continues to grow and venture fund investors pile tens of millions of dollars on such start-ups, The Deal.com takes a look the growing debate surrounding the future of these sites.

Summit Partners, the Boston-based private equity group, will on Monday announce that it has raised a maiden 1 billion euro ($1.56 billion) European fund to finance investments in mid-sized buyouts and growth capital investments in the region.
President Hugo Chávez is threatening to expropriate Venezuela's largest steel maker, Sidor, because he says shareholders are demanding excessive compensation for the company's nationalization.
Chrysler is seeking buyers for two Michigan axle plants as it tries to back away from producing auto parts in-house, The Wall Street Journal reported.

In one of the biggest such deals in years, a Japanese company has agreed to pay CoMentis up to $760 million for a stake in an Alzheimer's disease treatment the South San Francisco company is developing.

Ashley Force beat her father, John, in the National Hot Rod Association’s Southern Nationals in Commerce, Ga., becoming the first woman to win a national Funny Car event. “I think Dad’s done this enough years that he has the same routine and doesn’t care who’s next to him, whether you’re related to him or not,” she said.
The crash killed dozens and injured hundreds more, a state news agency reported, making it one of the deadliest rail accidents in recent years.
A listing of credits on Friday with a film review of “Then She Found Me,” using information from the distributor’s Web site, misspelled the surname of a producer. She is Pam Koffler, not Koeffler.
NATIONAL.

An article on Thursday about arguments before the Supreme Court in a pay discrimination case misidentified the employer in the case. It is KAPL Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Lockheed Martin Corp. — not the Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory, which is owned by the United States government and operated under contract by KAPL.

An article on Friday about criticism of Bill Clinton for statements he has made during the presidential campaign, including likening Barack Obama’s victory in the South Carolina primary this year to Jesse Jackson’s win there in 1988, misidentified the type of nominating contest the state held in 1988. It was a caucus, not a primary. The same error appeared on Thursday in a correction about the year Mr. Jackson won and in an article on Jan. 29 about support for Mr. Clinton in Harlem.

An article on Friday about the New York Botanical Garden’s re-creation of Charles Darwin’s garden referred incorrectly to palm trees in citing some current botanical research. While they resemble cycads, a kind of evergreen plant found in warm regions, they are botanically distinct.

The Critic’s Choice column on Tuesday, about new DVDs including a collection of Shirley Temple films, referred incorrectly to the song “On the Good Ship Lollipop.” It is about an aircraft, not a seagoing ship. (The reference comes in the seldom-heard opening lyrics: “I’ve thrown away my toys./Even my drum and train./I wanna make some noise/with real live aeroplanes./Some day I’m going to fly./I’ll be a pilot too./And when I do, how would you/like to be my crew.”).

An article on Thursday about American debt collection companies that are outsourcing the work to other countries misidentified, in some editions, the employer of Rajinder Singh, who commented on the trend. He works for Genpact, which employs thousands of debt collectors in India and other countries — not GenTech.

Danica Patrick, who last week became the first woman to win an IndyCar race, was never in contention in the RoadRunner Turbo Indy 300 in Kansas City, Kan., and was knocked out with a broken wheel hub after 156 laps. Patrick started third, but finished 19th. Dan Wheldon held off Tony Kanaan to win his second consecutive I.R.L. IndyCar Series race at Kansas Speedway.

The United States women’s field hockey team is headed to the Beijing Olympics after defeating Belgium, 3-1, on Sunday in the final of the qualifying tournament in Kazan, Russia. Kayla Bashore, Tiffany Snow and Kate Barber scored for the Americans.

Kanstantin Sivtsov of Belarus won the Tour de Georgia by 4 seconds over Trent Lowe of Australia and by 14 over Levi Leipheimer of the United States. Sivtsov took the overall lead in Saturday’s climb up Brasstown Bald Mountain.

U.C.L.A.’s Josh Shipp, a junior guard/forward, declared his intention to enter the N.B.A. draft. He will not hire an agent, leaving him the option of returning to the Bruins. Shipp is the fourth U.C.L.A. starter to enter the June draft, with the freshman Kevin Love, the sophomore Russell Westbrook and the junior Luc Richard Mbah a Moute.

Connecticut center Hasheem Thabeet says he will return for his junior season instead of entering the N.B.A. draft. Thabeet, a 7-foot-3 native of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, was projected as a first-round pick in the draft.

Kimi Raikkonen drove Ferrari to its third consecutive Formula One victory, winning the Spanish Grand Prix in Barcelona. Raikkonen is 9 points ahead of McLaren’s Lewis Hamilton atop the drivers standings.

Iran's prosecutor general railed on Sunday against the invasion of Barbie, Batman, Spider-Man and Harry Potter and demanded that the country's young be protected against them, Agence France-Presse reported. Urging measures to safeguard ''Islamic culture and revolutionary values,'' the prosecutor, Ghorban-Ali Dorri Najafabadi, was quoted by the ISNA news agency as saying: ''Promoting figures like Barbie, Batman, Spider-Man and Harry Potter and the uncontrolled import of CDs of video games and films should alarm all the country's officials. We need to find substitutes to ward off this onslaught, which aims at children and young people whose personality is in the process of being formed.'' Although officials in Iran regularly denounce Western culture, Western toys have been popular there, and affluent parents often indulge their children with them. The prosecutor said, ''These toys, which do not respect the required norms, present dangers for the health of children and affect the survival of toy factories in this country.'' In July 2007 ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows'' went on sale in Tehran. Two years ago the police raided toy shops and put black stickers on the packaging of Barbie dolls to hide their bodies. Barbie contravenes Iran's rule that women must cover all bodily contours. Iran's rivals to Barbie and her partner, Ken, are Sara and Dara, who respect Islamic rules but do not enjoy Barbie's popularity.

Akram Khan continued his engagement at City Center on Friday night with ''zero degrees,'' a work for himself and the Flemish-Moroccan choreographer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui. Like ''bahok,'' performed earlier in the week, the duet deals with cultural identity, anger, humiliation and frustration. The intimate dance recounts a harrowing train journey that Mr. Khan and his cousin experienced on their way from Bangladesh to India, as told in unison by both performers. As they describe the soulless eyes of the guards who confiscated their passports, the dancers punctuate their words with a flurry of matching hand gestures.

Pamela Rosenberg, below, the first woman and the first American to become the administrative director of the Berlin Philharmonic, plans to leave the job when her contract expires in 2010, Bloomberg News reported. ''Pamela Rosenberg has decided she no longer wants to be attached to an institution and wants to spend her time on individual projects,'' Stefan Stahnke, the orchestra's spokesman, said in a telephone interview. ''That means she won't go to any other institution, like an opera house, either.'' Before joining the Berlin Philharmonic in 2006 as intendant, as the orchestra calls the administrative post, the Los Angeles-born Ms. Rosenberg, now 63, was the general director of the San Francisco Opera. She has spent much of her career in Europe. News of her plans came as the orchestra prepared to discuss details of a new contract with its conductor, Simon Rattle. That agreement expires in 2012.

RAVEN-SYMONé (Hollywood Records) Though she's a Disney Channel star, Raven-Symoné will probably never release a sexy record to prove she's not a Mouseketeer -- the way Christina Aguilera and Britney Spears did to prove they were all grown up. Instead this 22-year-old from Atlanta seems to age in reverse. Almost two decades have passed since she played sassy Olivia Kendall on ''The Cosby Show,'' lip-syncing to the bawdy blues anthem ''I'm a Woman'' on screen. But on her latest, upbeat pop album her voice is higher and more childlike than ever. ''I'm a girl,'' she insists, ''one hundred percent girl.''

The seven accomplished dancers in the Dutch duo Leine & Roebana's ''Sporen'' (or ''Traces'') had been putting themselves through the paces for quite a few minutes Friday night when something magical happened: One of them smiled, the kind of unconscious, exalted smile people sometimes make while pushing their bodies past their limits. Apparently he had forgotten what a Very Serious Dance he was engaged in at Danspace Project, where ''Sporen'' had its New York premiere. Would that there had been more such human lapses in this sleek work, which according to program notes, investigated a variety of movement problems in seeking to answer how ''we relate to our bodies in a technologically mediated society.''

I was rolling through the neon deluge of a place very like Times Square the other night in my Landstalker sport utility vehicle, listening to David Bowie's ''Fascination'' on the radio. The glittery urban landscape was almost enough to make me forget about the warehouse of cocaine dealers I was headed uptown to rip off. Soon I would get bored, though, and carjack a luxury sedan. I'd meet my Rasta buddy Little Jacob, then check out a late show by Ricky Gervais at a comedy club around the corner. Afterward I'd head north to confront the dealers, at least if I could elude the cops. I heard their sirens before I saw them and peeled out, tires squealing.

Caleb Campbell, a safety from West Point, was selected in the seventh round by Detroit. The Lions' secondary can certainly use the help, and has a chance to get it immediately because a new rule implemented at the United States Military Academy will allow Campbell to play football now instead of serving in the military. Campbell is the first player from a service academy to be drafted since 1999. He will probably play linebacker in the N.F.L. And his new head coach, Rod Marinelli, is a Vietnam veteran. JUDY BATTISTA

PHILLIPS--Betty, a life-long resident of New York City passed away on April 25th, 2008. She was 99 years old, just weeks from her hundredth birthday. Betty was born on July 17th, 1908. She is preceded in death by her husband, Jack Phillips and her son Bobby. She is survived by her son David, her daughterin-law Carlin, her granddaughter Rachel, her grandson Ben, and her great-grandchildren Louise and Julianna. Betty was a longtime executive secretary at ACRMD (now Lifespire), an organization helping retarded children. Betty attended the City College of New York and, with her husband Jack, was a founding member of East End Temple. Betty was deeply loved by her family and friends and will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Funeral Services will be held at East End Temple, 245 East 17th Street in Manhattan, on Monday, April 28th at Noon 212-477-6444.

Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' is going for a ride. More than 200 years after it was first performed in Vienna, the opera -- updated for the 21st century by the avant-garde director ChristophHagel -- is being performed in a subway station in Berlin, Agence France-Presse reported. The production is intended to draw attention to the unopened Bundestag station, designed by the architects Axel Schultes and Charlotte Frank, that is a final piece in a two-decade project, to construct a line linking the Brandenburg Gate with the new Hauptbahnhof main station. In Mr. Hagel's production, the bird catcher Papageno is transformed into a homeless bohemian on welfare who is played by Jan Plewka, former frontman of the German rock band Selig. The hero, Tamino, is chased by a train, not a serpent; and his love object, Pamina, cast as a typical Berlin student, is arrested for not having a ticket. Other characters wear baseball caps and ride skateboards. The production will run through May 25.

When David Robertson first conducted at the Metropolitan Opera in 1996, he had the distressing experience of leading a performance of Janacek's ''Makropulos Case'' in which a tenor died onstage. Things went more smoothly on Saturday night, his first appearance at the house in a decade, leading Mozart's ''Entführung aus dem Serail'' (''The Abduction From the Seraglio''). In the current political climate the genial ending of Mozart's comic singspiel, in which misunderstandings between Muslims and Christians are cheerily smoothed over and peace made, seems depressingly remote. John Dexter's low-budget production from 1979, with its tired looking cutout sets, also seems dated.

STANLEY JORDAN ''State of Nature'' (Mack Avenue) It has been more than a decade since the guitarist Stanley Jordan released a proper album. Mr. Jordan, one of the few jazz musicians with a gold record to his name (''Magic Touch,'' his 1985 Blue Note debut), has devoted most of that time to reflective pursuits like music therapy. His last specialty release was called ''Relaxing Music for Difficult Situations, I.''

Less than three weeks before this year's Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, still the country's banner festival of alternative rock, Prince joined the bill in the most prominent slot. He was Saturday night's final main-stage show, at the end of a day including important sets by Portishead and M.I.A. The addition seemed like a last-minute attempt to increase ticket sales, but it also raised the question: What does Prince signify these days to alternative-rock America? We know what he means in the physical world, even in the California desert here. But what about in the state of mind that is alternative culture; what does he mean in Indie-O? And what would he do to address the credibility issue, the chimerical question that hangs over just about every performer here? On Saturday he played his Fender Telecasters and Stratocasters whenever he possibly could, through a nearly two-hour set. Extra helpings of guitar, side dishes, desserts, groaning tables of guitar. And he just declared credibility outright. ''You are in the coolest place on earth right now,'' he told the crowd in his opening remarks.

RITTER--Wendy Zuckerwise, age 53, passed away Saturday April 26, 2008. Wendy had a joie de vivre that was apparent in her remarkable career as a consultant for renowned fashion designers and in her daily life both here in New York and in Dayton, Ohio. She had wonderful friends throughout the world. Her family meant everything to her as well. Wendy loved life. The world has lost a ray of sunshine that can never be replaced. Wendy is survived by her beloved family, including her loving husband, Nathaniel; mother, Ruth Zuckerwise; sister, Phyllis Sterne; and nephew and niece, David and Ashley Sterne. She was predeceased by her father Walter Zuckerwise. Wendy will be missed by all who where touched by her radiance. Funeral and interment will be held in Dayton, Ohio on Tuesday at Temple Israel. The family has endowed the Wendy Zuckerwise Ritter Endometrial Cancer Research Fund and would appreciate contributions to it via the OSU Foundation Fund #

She will be buried in a family plot on Wednesday, April 30, at 12:15pm at the Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens, NY.

The Miami City Ballet danced a smartly chosen program on Friday at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts in Greenvale, N.Y. Three bonbons showed off the company's precise and joyful way with movement, followed by the dance equivalent of a belt of single-malt Scotch that suggested this was a troupe that could probably do just about anything thrown its way. But the stars of the program were not its choreographers, George Balanchine and Twyla Tharp. It was a night to savor the individualistic members of this model of ensemble dancing. And Edward Villella, the former New York City Ballet principal dancer who directs the Miami company, was back in New York, where many in the audience seemed to feel he belonged.
TAKACS QUARTET Zankel Hall

PISNI--Stephen Alexander, of NYC and Roxbury, CT, died unexpectedly in his sleep Sunday night, April 20, 2008. Born in Toronto, Canada to Stephen and Sadie Pindur Pisni on June 8, 1931. Steve came to New York in 1959 as a ticket agent for Air Canada. He remained with Air Canada in increasingly responsible positions and retired as public relations director in 1982. He then founded his own public relations firm, Stephen A. Pisni Public Relations, with Air Canada as his main client and retired finally in 1996. A longtime associate member of the Society of American Travel Writers, he received two presidential awards from the Society. Steve was a lover of opera, operetta (especially Hungarian operetta), music in general and show business. He is mourned by his life partner, Jerry Allford, a sister Mary Gatti; a niece, Carole Ingham; and nephews John Gatti, Paul Gatti and Michael Pisni; and many friends, including Barbara Gillam. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to TheatreWorks New Milford, P.O. Box 836, New Milford, CT 06776 or the website, www. theatreworks.us

Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet's new ''Glassy Essence'' is one of those installation works that keep the audience on its feet -- literally. When faced with multiple viewing points and no seating, it's helpful to recall a hockey truism: Don't chase the puck; it will come to you. ''Glassy Essence,'' choreographed by Cedar Lake's artistic director, Benoit-Swan Pouffer, may pose certain challenges for its audience, but it is not a challenging work. Performed in Cedar Lake's exposed-brick theater on Thursday night, the contrived production proposes to bridge the gap between the audience and its 16 dancers.

STONE--Allen. Happy Birthday dearest brother. Loved and remembered forever. Cynthia

RAVEN-SYMONé (Hollywood Records) Though she's a Disney Channel star, Raven-Symoné will probably never release a sexy record to prove she's not a Mouseketeer -- the way Christina Aguilera and Britney Spears did to prove they were all grown up. Instead this 22-year-old from Atlanta seems to age in reverse. Almost two decades have passed since she played sassy Olivia Kendall on ''The Cosby Show,'' lip-syncing to the bawdy blues anthem ''I'm a Woman'' on screen. But on her latest, upbeat pop album her voice is higher and more childlike than ever. ''I'm a girl,'' she insists, ''one hundred percent girl.''

BRODY--Minnie, of Brookline, MA formerly of Brooklyn, NY on April 26. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother of Susan and Ruth, dear grandmother of Josh, David and Emily, sister of Anne Schlussman and the late Beatrice Ruskin and Gilbert Schlussman. Longtime librarian at the Brooklyn Public Library. Services in Boston. Services by BrezniakRodman 800-554-2199.

The latest brush with the law for the Grammy-winning singer Amy Winehouse, below, ended on Saturday when the police issued her a formal waning, known as a caution for assault and released her without charge after she spent a night in custody, The Associated Press reported. The caution means that the matter will remain on her record and could count against her should she be charged with a similar offense. Her spokesman, Chris Goodman, said Ms. Winehouse, 24, had admitted to a common assault by slapping a man with an open hand and accepted a caution. The statement said, ''Amy was fully cooperative and apologized for the incident.'' She was arrested on suspicion of assault after reports of a scuffle with two men during a wild night out. Ms. Winehouse and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were arrested in Norway in October on charges of drug possession. Ms. Winehouse was arrested in London in December on suspicion of attempting to interfere with a court case involving her husband, who is in jail awaiting trial on charges of perverting the course of justice in a case in which he is accused of assaulting a barman.

BOSBOOM--Herman D., son of Rebecca and David, passed away April 25, 2008 in Oyster Bay, NY, in his 81st year. Beloved husband of Barbara and loving father of David (Lillian), Jeffrey and Lisa Gordon (Laurence). Grandfather of Evan, Jared, Ilona, Anjelica and Joshua. Herman was a remarkable man, born in Amsterdam, who then immigrated to New York City. He touched many people's lives in so many ways. For many years, he coowned H. Roth & Son, a gourmet food business located in Manhattan. He was there for so many and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held Monday, April 28 at 10:30am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797, followed by a graveside service at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

Pamela Rosenberg, below, the first woman and the first American to become the administrative director of the Berlin Philharmonic, plans to leave the job when her contract expires in 2010, Bloomberg News reported. ''Pamela Rosenberg has decided she no longer wants to be attached to an institution and wants to spend her time on individual projects,'' Stefan Stahnke, the orchestra's spokesman, said in a telephone interview. ''That means she won't go to any other institution, like an opera house, either.'' Before joining the Berlin Philharmonic in 2006 as intendant, as the orchestra calls the administrative post, the Los Angeles-born Ms. Rosenberg, now 63, was the general director of the San Francisco Opera. She has spent much of her career in Europe. News of her plans came as the orchestra prepared to discuss details of a new contract with its conductor, Simon Rattle. That agreement expires in 2012.

PROPP--Mortimer. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a distinguished Jewish communal leader who, with his beloved wife, Eugenie, and his brothers, Ephraim (and Gail) and the late Seymour Propp, and his wife Gabrielle, is a YU Guardian, having jointly established the Propp Brothers Scholarship Fund at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) in memory of their parents, Morris and Anna Propp, who are also Founders of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine and supported many other projects within YU and the Yeshiva University Women's Organization (YUWO), where all three sisters-in-law, Eugenie, Gabrielle, and Gail, are members of the Executive Council. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Eugenie, and to their children, Helen Heller and Morris Propp, to his brother Ephraim, and all the members of the Propp family. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower National Chairman, YUWO Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

DAY--James. The City University of New York mourns the passing of James Day, television innovator, educator and friend of the University and CUNY TV. A pioneer in public television, James played important roles in establishing PBS and the Children's Television Workshop. For more than a decade he was a professor at Brooklyn College, where he taught and mentored students. He served as chairperson of the CUNY TV Advisory Board and was a member of CUNY TV's Foundation Board. His encouragement, support and wisdom will be missed. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr. Chairperson Matthew Goldstein Chancellor

A memorial service will be held at Trinity Pawling Chapel on Saturday, May 10 at 2:00pm. Contributions can be made to J. Rupert Winters Journalism Award Fund, Lake Placid Central School District Office, Attn: Ernest H. Stretton, Superintendent, 50 Cummings Rd., Lake Placid, NY 12964.

EDERSHEIM--Maurits Ernst, beloved husband of Claire, father of Peggy, Judith, Terri, Ellen, Steven, Leo and Arthur. Loving grandfather of ten grandchildren, brother of Hans, brother-in-law of Helen, uncle of Kathy. Born 1918 in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, he emigrated to New York in 1940, interrupting his studies at the Haute Ecole des Sciences Politique, in Paris. Shortly thereafter, he joined the US Army, and was assigned to the OSS. After WWII, he embarked on a long and successful Wall Street career, where he was among the first Fund Managers to emphasize the benefits of International Investing, eventually becoming Deputy Chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, and subsequently a Deputy Chairman of Smith Barney Asset Management. Among the many awards he received, he was appointed a Member of the Order van Oranje-Nassau, and a recipient of the Peter Stuyvesant Award from the Netherlands-America Foundation, and of the Half Moon Trophy from the Netherlands Club of NY. Throughout his life, he remained devoted to Dutch causes, trains, and his charitable pursuits. He was also instrumental in the creation of the Erasmus Chair of Dutch History and Culture at Harvard University. An ardent reader with a phenomenal memory, an infectious sense of humor and boundless energy, his love, guidance and generous spirit will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: The NetherlandsAmerica Foundation, 82 Wall Street, Suite 1101, NY, NY 10005. EDERSHEIM--Maurits. We are very saddened by the loss of Marc, our dear friend of almost 40 years. A remarkable man of wisdom and kindness, he will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Our sincerest condolences to Claire and the entire family. Bobby and Maurie Deane

MySpace has long been known as a home for musicians and other performers, who use the site as a way to reach fans. Now they're going to reach a different audience: the judges of ''America's Got Talent.'' NBC, FremantleMedia and MySpace are expected to announce on Monday a partnership that will treat the social network as a ''virtual audition city'' for the third season of the summer reality show. The show's producers have held auditions in Nashville; Orlando, Fla.; and other cities. Now the producers will hold auditions on the Internet as well. One episode of the variety show will be devoted to the submissions of MySpace.com users. ''People are uploading music videos, tricks and stunts to MySpace all the time,'' said Josh Brooks, MySpace's vice president for marketing and content development. For NBC the partnership will tap into the talent that exists online, said Jared Goldsmith, the network's director of digital promotion strategies.

I had planned on sparring with my favorite sportswriter, Joe Drape, on our annual disagreement on the East Coast slant to the Derby. Last week, when looking for a yoga studio in my neighborhood, I checked out Yelp.com, a Web site I often visit to see what other people are recommending. I like that the reviews come from people who walk the same streets I do. And when I read a review, I usually check out other reviews the reviewer has written before deciding whether to rely on it. I'm not the only one. According to Yelp, the site had an average 9 million unique visitors in March.

The number of people arrested for small amounts of marijuana in New York City has increased tenfold in the past decade, with most of the arrests occurring after the police either searched suspects or pressured them into emptying their bags or pockets and displaying the drug during a stop-and-frisk, a report [pdf] said on Tuesday.The report, released by the New York Civil Liberties Union, was based on government statistics, interviews with lawyers, people who were arrested, and former and current law enforcement officials. The civil liberties group also took into account observations in criminal court. A Police Department spokesman criticized the findings as flawed.

ALBANY -- Shortly after Eliot Spitzer was elected governor, one of his first orders of business was to sit down with government groups advocating change. But these days the change advocates are finding that the new governor is a little harder to pin down. Tuesday in Albany was Reform Day, a time each year when the so-called good-government organizations converge on the capitol to make their case for causes like campaign finance reform and more transparent public information laws.
"There are many roads to Rome," Leon Black, the co-founder of Apollo Management, said here in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

I've been on the road (actually doing a public dialog with Barney Frank on financial reform), so I'm just catching up. Anyway, John McCain has a really bad idea on gasoline, Hillary Clinton is emulating him (but with a twist that makes her plan pointless rather than evil), and Barack Obama, to his credit, says no.

The International Toy Center always sounded like just about any child's definition of heaven. But very few children - and not that many more grown-ups - ever got inside the two great fortresslike showroom buildings on the west side of Madison Square Park.Young David W. Levinson was an exception. In the late 1950s, he was taken to the annual fairs at the Toy Center by his father, Herman, the proprietor of the Artcraft Hobby Shop on Union Turnpike in Queens. The younger Mr. Levinson grew up surrounded by Lionel, American Flyer and Tyco trains. (One disadvantage: he and his father had to work on Christmas, even though the shop was nominally closed that day, because so many families were calling for help in setting up their new floor-level railroads.)Now Mr. Levinson, chairman of L&L Holding Company, is an owner of the former toy building at 200 Fifth Avenue. This 15-story structure, originally called the Fifth Avenue Building, was designed by Maynicke & Franke and completed 99 years ago. It sits in the Ladies' Mile Historic District. Its sidewalk clock is an individually designated city landmark.

I have long felt that tequila is one of the world's greatest and most undervalued spirits. The lack of respect for tequila is no surprise, really. Most people are introduced to bad tequila and never really make the leap to 100 percent blue agave tequila, which has the sort of depth, purity and complexity that you won't find in the less expensive mixto tequilas, the staple of frozen margaritas and the like.

Yes, I've been bad, to paraphrase Ms. Winehouse. As some of you surmised from my stony silence, I was taking a little vaca. A spring break! Oh, it was heaven. Nuttin' to do except holler at the turkeys. Every evening they come, four or five of them, across my lawn to pick up the grass seed I just put out, their skinny necks bobbing, while the big male feathers up on the ridge. Then I open the front door and shout. Toby the Lab gets excited and bolts for the window to see the turkeys trot and bob toward the woods. A turkey moves at a speed that is surprising and hilarious, and I think, What if I hitch up a harness and a little wagon to one? I mean, if Stuart Little could have a car .

TAMPA - Senator John McCain plans to offer more details here Tuesday about how his health care plan would work for people with pre-existing health problems, an area where he has stark differences with the Democratic candidates.

New York City is paying $81 million over two years in salaries and benefits for teachers without permanent teaching jobs, according to a report scheduled to be released today. The teachers are part of the so-called reserve pool, which holds teachers whose positions have been eliminated, but who have yet to secure a new permanent teaching position at another school. Since 2006, when the contract took effect, more than 600 teachers have been placed in the reserve after failing to find new positions.The reserve is an outgrowth of the city's contract with the teachers' union, which ended seniority rights in staffing decisions as well as the automatic transfer of teachers who had been cut because of shrinking enrollment, the closing of large schools or the elimination of particular programs. At the time, the schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, said that he would rather absorb the cost of the teachers in the reserve pool than saddle principals with teachers they did not want.

As the credit markets have seized up, some on Wall Street have drawn a line from the current crisis back to Michael R. Milken, once known as the "junk bond king" of Drexel Burnham Lambert. But did the junk bond and the slicing and dicing of debt -- both of which Mr. Milken clearly helped popularize -- lead to the mess we are in today? Absolutely not, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times. Such criticism is akin to blaming the inventor of paper money, he says.

Today marks what would have been Barbaro's fifth birthday. Fans of Barbaro (FOBs) celebrated Barbaro's fourth birthday in style, attending racetracks across the country to honor their champion. At Delaware Park, where many of Barbaro's connections were in attendance, including his owners Roy and Gretchen Jackson, more than 700 people celebrated Barbaro's life. During the festivities about $20,000 was raised for Throughbred Charities of America and awareness was further raised about the need to rescue horses from slaughter.

It's a bit funny that in Manchester, the team manager who is reportedly getting the axe is sanguine while the one who is on the verge of extending his estimable legacy is on edge. But that's the nature of competition at the top of European soccer: there's nothing more nerve-racking than an uncertain fate.
John McCain is set to spend the bulk of this week talking up his health care reform plan -- he'll speak at a cancer center in Tampa this morning -- and he also has a new ad to push his message.

I'm not sure there's ever a good time to hear Whitney Houston belting out, "And I-e-I-e-I will always love you," but 5:45 a.m. at the Cleveland airport is probably not it. Nonetheless, I'm very happy to be headed home, and so are the Yankees.
Barack Obama hasn't requested any federal earmarks for 2009. John McCain, in fact, hopes to banish all earmarks forever.

"The CW is down 27% this year in its target demographic, adults aged 18 to 34. Its fall shows were well received but have barely treaded water in the Nielsens. Most worrisome: The return of the network's reliable reality performers "America's Next Top Model" (down 29%) and "Beauty and the Geek" (off 54%) dropped sharply this spring."

Wall Street Journal: "Blockbuster Inc. is in talks about taking a stake in the new Viacom Inc.-led premium television channel that plans to compete with HBO, Showtime and Starz, according to people familiar with the situation."

Macquarie has more of its shares on loan than any other Australian-listed company in a sign that short sellers have taken a big gamble that the investment bank's share price will tumble, The Financial Times reported.

Deutsche Bank suffered its first quarterly loss in five years on Tuesday as global financial turmoil heaped 2.7 billion euros ($4.2 billion) in write-downs on Germany's biggest listed bank.
HBOS, the British bank, announced a 4 billion pound ($7.9 billion) rights issue alongside plans to cut its dividend to shore up its balance sheet after additional write-downs on troubled assets.
Fred R. Buenrostro Jr., the chief executive of California's public employee pension system, is stepping down to pursue what he calls exciting opportunities in the private sector.

Criminal action video game "Grand Theft Auto 4" won near-perfect praise in early reviews on Monday, boosting the shares of publisher Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. as much as 3.4 percent ahead of the game's midnight launch.

All this week over at our City Room blog, Carol E. Murphy, someone who has struggled for years to make New York City even more energy thrifty than it already is, is answering questions from readers. I encourage you to chime in.

Visa, the world's largest credit-card network, said profit rose 28 percent in the company's first earnings report since its record $19 billion initial public offering last month. The shares fell 7 percent after the results didn't meet the most optimistic predictions.
BlackRock Chairman and Chief Executive Laurence Fink received $41.87 million in compensation in 2007, a 27 percent increase from the prior year, according to a regulatory filing on Monday.
Clear Channel Communications said a Texas court on Monday dismissed a request by a group of banks to delay a trial over the funding of the $20 billion buyout of the radio station operator.

The big winner in Freenet's 1.63 billion euro ($2.55 billion) deal to buy Debitel, it seems, is London private equity firm Permira, which stands to make more than 3 times its money on the German takeover, according to The Deal.com.

InvenSense, which makes motion sensing solutions for mobile applications, has taken $19 million Series C in a round led by Sierra Ventures, with previous investors Artiman Ventures, Partech International and Qualcomm Ventures also participating.

Most forests are considered net sinks of carbon dioxide, meaning they store more carbon than they give up, but natural events can upset the equation.

Researchers reported that the nutritional content of tomatoes improves when the plants are irrigated with diluted seawater.

Oakland released running back Dominic Rhodes, two days after using its top draft pick to take Darren McFadden. Oakland had a glut at running back after the draft, with LaMont Jordan, Justin Fargas and Michael Bush.
After defeating the Indians Monday night, the Yankees flew home at last with a record of 14-13 despite an opening month that would test any new manager.
A top drug prosecutor, Ronald L. Rodgers, has been named to lead the Justice Department office that recommends presidential pardons.

Twelve groups sued the federal government in Federal District Court, seeking to restore endangered species protections for gray wolves in the Northern Rockies.
Fred R. Buenrostro Jr. is the second top executive to announce his departure from California’s public employee pension system in recent weeks.

Schedule information with a theater review on Monday about “The Castle,” at New World Stages on West 50th Street, misstated the scheduled length of the play’s run. It is open-ended; it is not scheduled to close on May 18. The review, using information provided by a publicist, also misstated the surname of an actor who also collaborated on the script. He is Kenneth Harrigan, not Harrington.

A headline and an article on Monday about a Vanity Fair photograph showing the actress Miley Cyrus in a suggestive pose left the incorrect impression that she was bare-breasted. While the pose was indeed revealing, she was wrapped in what appeared to be a bedsheet; she was not topless.
A music review on Monday about a recital by Bryn Terfel, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the first word of a Mozart aria he performed. It begins “Io ti lascio,” not “Lo ti lascio.”.

An article on Friday about the Pittsburgh Penguins’ star-powered success this season attributed an erroneous distinction to the outdoor game the team played against Buffalo in January. It was the second regular-season N.H.L. game to be played outdoors — not the first, which was in Edmonton, Alberta, in November 2003.
BUSINESS DAY.
Romano Prodi, Italy’s departing prime minister, declined an offer from Russia’s Gazprom to become chairman of a new Russian-Italian natural gas pipeline.
Freenet, agreed to buy a rival, Debitel, for 1.63 billion euros ($2.5 billion), forming Germany’s third-largest mobile phone company.
The $471 million purchase will increase Total’s holdings in Canada’s oil sands region and end Synenco’s yearlong search for a buyer.
The contract, to build 126 multirole fighter jets, is potentially worth more than $10 billion.
Blackstone Real Estate Partners said it would invest $18 million for a minority stake in a construction-management company in India.
There is growing concern among developers, builders and unions that the city’s safety crackdown will cause delays and layoffs at major construction sites.
The settlement comes nearly two years after state auditors discovered problems with contracts for radio systems for three state departments.
Terrell Owens was sued by the Eagles, who said he owed almost $770,000 in bonus money he failed to repay after his suspension from the team. Drew Rosenhaus, Owens’s agent, declined to comment.

The sprinter Oscar Pistorius, a double amputee, takes his case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport on Tuesday in a bid to win the right to compete at the Beijing Olympics. Pistorius, a 21-year-old South African, is seeking to overturn a ruling by the International Association of Athletics Federations in January that barred him from racing against able-bodied runners because it said his prosthetic blades gave him a competitive advantage. The hearing is expected to last two days.

Asafa Powell, the world-record holder in the 100 meters, has canceled plans to compete until late June because of a pulled muscle in his chest, his manager said. The move was precautionary and was not expected to affect his preparations for the Beijing Olympics in August. His first race back is expected to be the Jamaican championships in late June.
The player who had the most exuberant touchdown celebration of the season for the Jets last year is no longer with the team.

Tuesday is the 25th anniversary of the expletive-filled tirade against Chicago Cubs fans that nearly led Lee Elia’s firing as the team’s manager. Elia has a new rant for Chicago. Working with a memorabilia company, he is selling an autographed baseball in a case with an audio chip that plays a salute to Cubs fans far different from his words in 1983. He said he hoped to raise money for the Chicago Baseball Cancer Charities.
Although rival carrier Continental Airlines abandoned merger talks, United will keep looking for a partner, its chief executive, Glenn F. Tilton, said.
A former asylum housed in a medieval-style stone castle gets a face-lift and a new purpose: an educational training center for physician assistants.
Malaysia’s newly elected lawmakers took the oath of office to join a revamped Parliament that for the first time in 40 years has a huge opposition presence challenging the government’s power.
Spain’s National Court has decided against extraditing the former Argentine president María Estela Martínez de Perón, 77, to Argentina.
Russia is doing too little to reverse a critical decline in its population driven by increasing alcohol abuse, poor diet and social change, a United Nations report said.

The former police narcotics unit leader was sentenced to more than three years federal in prison for bribery and theft.

Martin Biron stopped 32 shots and the Philadelphia Flyers scored three goals in the second period Monday night in a 3-2 victory over the visiting Montreal Canadiens.
Colonel John, who won the Santa Anita Derby, looked no worse for wear a day after turning heads with a fast five-furlong breeze of 57.80 seconds on Sunday.
The president of West Virginia University accepted the resignations of two top university officials over the awarding of a master’s degree to the governor’s daughter.
The senior senator of Nebraska’s unicameral Legislature is going out the way he came in: obstinately, and with a whole lot to say in his T-shirt and jeans.

Closing arguments will begin in Anthony Pellicano’s Hollywood wiretapping case after a federal judge rejected a defendant’s call for a mistrial.
The food distributor posted net income of $240.9 million for the 13-week period that ended March 29, compared with $221 million a year earlier.
The word “unconscionable” has become one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s favorite verbal jabs. Here are some examples.
The surprising Atlanta Hawks overcame two double-digit deficits Monday night to beat the visiting Boston Celtics, 97-92, evening the best-of-seven series.
Jorge Posada left the Yankees on Monday to visit a orthopedic surgeon in Birmingham, Ala., and it could be a long time before he rejoins the active roster.
The health insurer Humana reported a rise of more than 12 percent in first-quarter profit Monday, surpassed analysts’ expectations.
The bank said it would modify at least $40 billion in problem loans from at least 265,000 borrowers over the next two years.
The consumer electronics retailer said its profit fell to $38.8 million on sales of $949 million, down from $42.5 million on sales of $992 million a year earlier.
Questions have been raised about whether eventing — a three-phase competition encompassing dressage, show jumping and a cross-country obstacle course — is too dangerous.
Merrill Lynch said on Monday that it had hired Thomas Montag, the former co-head of global securities trading at Goldman Sachs.
Ms. Wilson’s performances with American Ballet Theater during the 1960s and ’70s established her as one of America’s finest dramatic ballerinas.
A session of modest moves came despite one of the most active days for acquisitions in almost three months and ahead of a widely expected interest rate cut by the Fed.
The federal government began issuing electronic tax rebates under a $168 billion program to bolster the economy.
A Senate subcommittee plans to investigate whether mortgage lenders are deepening the foreclosure crisis by levying dubious fees on troubled borrowers.
One of the Middle East’s wealthiest ruling families has a new asset: The National, a newspaper that promises independence from its royal owners.
The launch of TheWB.com and KidsWB.com is part of TimeWarner’s “digital destination” strategy to tailor Web sites to specific audiences.

An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, on executions, misstated the status of Chief Justice John Roberts’s opinion in a recent Supreme Court capital punishment case, Baze v. Rees. His opinion, joined by two other justices in the seven-justice majority, was the plurality opinion. It was not the majority opinion.
The current housing and credit troubles do not present a sufficient basis for reforming the entire financial regulatory system.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
American Airlines plans to join the competition May 12 and start charging $25 for a second checked bag.
“Indie cred” is a shell game, and the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival keeps moving the shells around.

In a twist on the recent string of sex tapes of Hollywood’s young stars, Vivid Entertainment plans to release what it says is a film from the vaults of classic rock: a sex film supposedly of Jimi Hendrix.

ABC proved unbeatable in the ratings on Sunday, as new installments of “Desperate Housewives,” right, with Eva Longoria, “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Brothers & Sisters” led all four hours of prime time. Nielsen reported that “Desperate Housewives” earned the largest audience over all, drawing 16.2 million viewers during the 9 p.m. hour. Preceding it a two-hour edition of “Extreme Makeover” delivered 9.6 million viewers from 7 to 9, while at 10 “Brothers & Sisters” attracted 11.6 million, easily outpacing a “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” repeat on NBC and “Dexter” on CBS, both of which averaged 6.5 million viewers. CBS finished second for the night, drawing 6.7 million viewers at 8 p.m. for “Big Brother 9.” CBS fared better both before and after the reality show’s finale, earning 9.7 million viewers for “60 Minutes” at 7 p.m. and 11.5 million for “Cold Case” at 9. Meanwhile Fox, led by “Family Guy” at 9 (8.5 million) and “The Simpsons” at 8 (7.7 million), finished third in total viewers but second among adults 18 to 49, well ahead of CBS. NBC was fourth for the night.

Australian television comics escaped punishment on Monday when a prosecutor dropped charges lodged against them for bringing an Osama bin Laden look-alike, above, through security at the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Sydney in September, Agence France-Presse reported. The team from the show “The Chaser’s War on Everything” came within yards of a hotel where President Bush was staying when they posed as part of a Canadian motorcade and their three-car convoy was waved through security checkpoints. They were halted after one of the comedians from the show emerged dressed as Mr. bin Laden from a car. The 10 men and one woman working on the show were charged with entering a restricted area without justification. Nicholas Cowdery, the director of public prosecutions for New South Wales, said that the circumstances were unusual, and that the charges had been dropped. He noted that the comics, driver and crew, carrying fake security passes, had been waved into the secure zone by the police. He said, “Police permission in fact constitutes special justification for entry.”.

James Frey, below, the best-selling author of “A Million Little Pieces” who was publicly shamed after admitting he made up or exaggerated details in his memoir of drug addiction and recovery, said in a new interview that he had always made it very clear to his editor and agent that the book began as a novel, and that, as such, he had fudged some particulars. In an exclusive interview with Mr. Frey in Vanity Fair that will be on newsstands Wednesday in New York and Los Angeles, Evgenia Peretz quotes an author’s questionnaire that Mr. Frey filled out for his publisher, Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, a Random House Inc. imprint, in which he described the book as “more a work of art or literature” than “a work of memoir or autobiography.” Ms. Peretz also refers to two unidentified publishing sources who say that Sean McDonald, Mr. Frey’s editor, “aimed at heightening the drama, without questioning the veracity of the text.” Mr. Frey, who is preparing for the publication of his novel, “Bright Shiny Morning,” did not return a phone call seeking comment. Through a spokeswoman Mr. McDonald, who is now an editor at Riverhead Books, a unit of Penguin Group, declined to comment.

The board of the Wagner Festival in Bayreuth, Germany, will meet on Tuesday after receiving an outline from two daughters of the 88-year-old chief, Wolfgang Wagner, of their plan to lead the annual event jointly, The Associated Press reported. Peter Emmerich, a spokesman for the festival, said on Monday that the proposal by Eva Wagner-Pasquier, Mr. Wagner’s daughter from his first marriage, and Katharina Wagner, from his second, was in the hands of the Richard Wagner Foundation, which supervises the festival. Wolfgang Wagner, the composer’s grandson, has led the festival since 1951, first with his brother, Wieland, then by himself after Wieland’s death in 1966. He had previously rejected the appointment of Ms. Wagner-Pasquier, who is supported by the foundation, and insisted he would step aside only if Katharina were allowed to succeed him.

Memorabilia from James Brown is being prepared for an exhibition to take place by midsummer at South Carolina State University, The Associated Press reported. Leonard McIntyre, the interim president of the university, in Orangeburg, told The Post and Courier of Charleston, S.C., that through Brown’s estate he had secured rights to display items including sheet music, awards, clothing and furniture at the university’s I P Stanback Museum & Planetarium. Brown, known as the “Godfather of Soul,” died at 73 on Christmas Day 2006.
Sam Waterston and Lauren Ambrose will join the cast of “Hamlet” in this year’s production at the Delacorte Theater.

“Burn After Reading,” a dark comedy by Joel and Ethan Coen, above from left, that stars George Clooney, John Malkovich, Brad Pitt, Frances McDormand and Tilda Swinton, will open the 65th Venice International Film Festival, The Associated Press reported. Organizers announced on Monday that the film, about an ousted C.I.A. official whose memoir falls into the hands of two gym employees, will have its world premiere on Aug. 27. The Coen brothers won an Oscar this year for their direction of “No Country for Old Men,” which also won Academy Awards for best film and for their adapted screenplay. The festival will run through Sept. 6. The festival’s official lineup is to be announced in late July.

Aaron Brown, below, a former anchor for CNN, will return to television after an absence of more than two years when he joins the PBS “Wide Angle” series, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown said that his new job as anchor of “Wide Angle,” a weekly public affairs series with a global focus, offered an opportunity “to work in an environment where people just think about making good TV and good journalism.” The series begins its seventh season on July 1. Mr. Brown, 59, left CNN in November 2005 during a shakeup that gave his time slot to the rising star Anderson Cooper. Mr. Brown said he was contractually barred from working in television until last June. He has been teaching at Arizona State University as its first Walter Cronkite professor of journalism.

Bob Dylan, below, has joined the lineup of the Third Annual Virgin Mobile Festival at the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore on Aug. 9 and 10. The indie-alternative rock, hip-hop and electronic music show will also include Iggy & the Stooges, Chuck Berry, Cat Power, Wilco and the Swell Season, as well as Foo Fighters, Jack Johnson, Kanye West, Stone Temple Pilots and Nine Inch Nails, according to an announcement from Richard Branson, the founder and chairman of the Virgin Group. In addition to the two main stages the setting will include a dedicated dance tent featuring electronic music by Moby and others.

Free music for fans of the English band Coldplay will be available for a week beginning Tuesday when it offers a download of “Violet Hill,” the first single from its new album, “Viva la Vida,” The Associated Press reported. The music, as well as preliminary information about Coldplay’s free shows at the Brixton Academy in London on June 16 and at Madison Square Garden on June 23, will be available on the band’s Web site, coldplay.com. The band also announced on Monday that the British release of “Viva la Vida” has been advanced four days, to June 12, when the album will be released in much of the world.

Iran’s culture minister reacted on Monday to publishers’ criticisms of the country’s evaluation process by urging writers to censor their own books if they hoped for publication in the Islamic republic, Agence France-Presse reported. At a news conference the minister, Mohammad Hossein Safar, said: “This is what we ask publishers and writers, ‘You are aware of the vetting code, so censor pages which are likely to create a dispute.’ ” Declaring that publications should conform to the system’s “religious, moral and national sensitivities,” he warned against graphic descriptions of relationships or sex, saying, “It is a clear violation of the law to give an excessive portrayal of a man and woman’s private relationships” and to “subject our youth and adults to descriptions of intercourse,” adding that “if anyone makes fun of religion, be it Islam or Christianity,” the country “should not allow opposition to God to be reflected in the media.” All publications in Iran must be approved by the Culture Ministry. Publishers have complained of tighter censorship of new books since Mahmoud Ahmadinejad became president in 2005. The culture minister made his remarks in reply to a recent letter from the Tehran Publishers Association complaining that the ministry employed a prolonged and arbitrary vetting process. The letter said, “It has been frequently seen that an issue which has resulted in a book being banned is abundant in another one that is published.”.

Dr. Natanson was a World War II army veteran and Professor of Philosophy at the College of Staten Island of the City University of New York where he taught from 1958 until his retirement in 1986. ''Burn After Reading,'' a dark comedy by Joeland Ethan Coen, above from left,thatstars George Clooney, John Malkovich, Brad Pitt, Frances McDormand and Tilda Swinton,will open the 65th Venice International Film Festival, The Associated Press reported. Organizers announced on Monday that the film, about an ousted C.I.A. official whose memoir falls into the hands of two gym employees, will have its world premiere on Aug. 27. The Coen brothers won an Oscar this year for their direction of ''No Country for Old Men,'' which also won Academy Awards for best film and for their adapted screenplay. The festival will run through Sept. 6. The festival's official lineup is to be announced in late July.

An article on Monday about Continental Airlines' decision to end merger discussions with United Airlines misstated the first-quarter loss of UAL Corporation, United's parent, in some editions. It was $537 million, not $357 million.

SERRELL--Margarita Noble, passed away at her home in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 25, 2008. She was born in Montclair, New Jersey on July 15, 1917, the daughter of Robert P. and Meta B. Noble. She attended Greenwich Academy and was a graduate of the Ethel Walker School. Migi was an extraordinary lady of many talents. She was an acclaimed equestrian, a nationally known flower arranger, lecturer and judge, an author, artist, entrepreneur and a devoted mother of four children. She was the founder of the American Dressage Institute of which she was President for six years and in 2004 she was awarded their Lifetime Achievement Award. Migi was a sixty-year member of her beloved Hortulus garden club. She was awarded two Fenwick Medals for flower arranging and devoted much of her time judging and lecturing on the art of flower arranging throughout the United States on behalf of the Garden Club of America. Her daughters, Patricia Schmeltzer of Greenwich and Margarita McGrath of Scottsdale, Arizona, and her son, Howard Paul Serrell, Jr, of Greenwich, survive Migi as well as seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held on Wednesday, April 30, 2008 2:00 pm. Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT.

Bob Dylan, below, has joined the lineup of the Third Annual Virgin Mobile Festival at the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore on Aug. 9 and 10. The indie-alternative rock, hip-hop and electronic music show will also include Iggy & the Stooges, Chuck Berry, Cat Power, Wilco and the Swell Season, as well as Foo Fighters, Jack Johnson, Kanye West, Stone Temple Pilots and Nine Inch Nails, according to an announcement from Richard Branson, the founder and chairman of the Virgin Group. In addition to the two main stages the setting will include a dedicated dance tent featuring electronic music by Moby and others.

BRANT--Henry. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of this esteemed composer. His loss will be deeply felt. BRANT--Henry. Carl Fischer Music, his principal publisher, mourns the passing on April 26 of the distinguished and innovative composer Henry Brant, winner of the 2002 Pulitzer Prize for Music. Brant took the idea of spatial music to a new level of power and grandeur, and his impact on the music of his time is incalculable. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Kathy, his children Joquin, Linus and Piri, and his many friends and admirers. F. Hayden Connor, Chairman Lauren Keiser, CEO/President Carl Fischer Music

ZACH--Lillian. Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of a beloved alumna, founding faculty member, and mentor who taught every student in the school psychology and school-clinical child psychology programs during her 45year tenure. Lillian Zach chaired Ferkauf's Dept. of Educational Psychology and Guidance, served as Associate Dean, and was first director of its school psychology program. She created the Ph.D. program in school psychology and developed Ferkauf's National Institute on Mental Health fellowship training program. An early giant in the field of school psychology in New York, she worked with the NYC Board of Education and other school systems. She was a visionary and an inspiration to everyone. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her son, Dr. Jonathan Zach; her brother, Leon Feingold; and all members of the bereaved family. Lawrence J. Siegel, Dean Beth B. Myers, Chair, Board of Governors

Loving father of Brian Larkin, Brendan Larkin, Gerard Larkin, Regina Dunne and husband Sean and Tara Cubberly and husband Jim. Cherished brother of Nancy Rau and James Larkin.
