Visiting Wednesday 7-9pm and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ 07450, 201444-7650. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Brian's memory to the cancer fund of your choice. www.feeneyfuneral home.com

Aaron Brown, below, a former anchor for CNN, will return to television after an absence of more than two years when he joins the PBS ''Wide Angle'' series, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown said that his new job as anchor of ''Wide Angle,'' a weekly public affairs series with a global focus, offered an opportunity ''to work in an environment where people just think about making good TV and good journalism.'' The series begins its seventh season on July 1. Mr. Brown, 59, left CNN in November 2005 during a shakeup that gave his time slot to the rising star Anderson Cooper. Mr. Brown said he was contractually barred from working in television until last June. He has been teaching at Arizona State University as its first Walter Cronkite professor of journalism.

WATERFALL--John (Bruce). We mourn the passing of Bruce Waterfall. We were never more aware of life's joys than in Bruce's presence. He loved life as a husband, father, investor and sportsman. His irreverence could not hide an appreciation of all that life has to offer and we will always be buoyed by the memories of only good times with Brucie. Love forever, Ricki and Robert Conway Doris and Stanley Tananbaum Bryan and Monica Zuriff and family Laurence and Beth Zuriff and family

A report in the Penn Relays Notes on Saturday misstated the winning time for the high school boys mile run by Cory Leslie of Perkins, Ohio. It was 4:12.76, not 412.76.

MCFADDEN--George. Be loved husband of Carol, beloved father of Lisa Melas, Wilhelmina McFadden, and Alexander McFadden, beloved stepfather of Piers and Georgiana Moreton. Adored grandfather of Leon and Pavlos Melas. He died in a plane crash, in the Toledo Bend Reservoir, Texas, at 4pm, April 22nd. He was 67. He was the son of Alexander Bloomfield McFadden and Josephine Cutting Blair. He attended Greenvale School, St. Paul's School, Vanderbilt University and Columbia Business School. He was the Chairman of McFadden Bros. LLC. and had a long career in venture capital. Original, witty, generous, an exceptional sportsman, Mr. McFadden was a Governor of Deepdale Country Club, Trustee of the St Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, of St. Paul's School, and a Director of the Squaw Valley Ski Corporation. Tradition loving, family oriented, and erudite, he will be lovingly remembered. He is survived by his sister Mary McFadden and brother John McFadden, by his half brothers Watson Blair and Wolcott Blair, his stepfather, Watson K. Blair, his former wife Lesley Taylor, and by his many loving cousins. The Funeral Service is to be held on May 8th at 3pm, St. Thomas's Church, 1 W. 53rd St. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to St. Andrews Dune Church, Southampton, or The Alexander B. McFadden Memorial Scholarship, at St. Paul's School, Concord, New Hampshire.

Adored Grandmother of Aaron, Alyson, Karina, David, Marko and Sean. Loved by everybody for her nurturing, her optimism, her joy of life and her extraordinary energy which continued through all 97 years. Funeral service Tuesday April 29th, 1:30pm at I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, NY 11746.

WHALEN--William C., of Westport, CT died April 25, 2008. For over thirty years Whalen covered news, sports and special events for NBC as an Associate Director and Director. His Emmy-winning work included 1969 coverage of the Apollo Moon Landing and RFK's final night in California. Survived by wife Mary (Hoctor), son, William A., daughter, Cynthia W. Keating, four grandchildren, brother Thomas and sisters, Ellen, Ruth and Annette. Donations may be made to Connecticut Hospice, Branford, CT.

KLEIN--Jeffrey P. The Department of Architecture and Design and the Contemporary Arts Council of the Museum of Modern Art greatly mourn the loss of Jeffrey P. Klein. A passionate art lover, Jeffrey was a long standing friend of The Museum and member of The A & D Committee since 1991 and Contemporary Arts Council since 1987. We deeply appreciate Jeffrey's generosity to the Museum, particularly his support of the acquisition and exhibition program. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Michele and his entire family. KLEIN--Jeffrey. Trustees and staff of Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum mark with deep sorrow the loss of Jeffrey, and extend their deepest sympathy to his wife Michele Gerber Klein, our wonderful Trustee.

ROTHSCHILD--Charles J., Jr. The Union for Reform Judaism mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Charles Rothschild, Jr., of Teaneck, Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 1983 to 1987 and, since 1991, an honorary chairman. For more than four decades and in a variety of leadership roles, Mr. Rothschild served the Union with great devotion and distinction. We extend deepest condolences to his children and grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Peter J. Weidhorn, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President

DAY--James. PBS mourns the death of one of the pioneers of public television, James Day. Mr. Day--a past president of WNET in New York and National Educational Television and a founder of WQED in San Francisco and PBS--devoted his life to ensuring public television fulfilled its promise to the American people. PBS is the better for his vision and leadership. John E. Porter Chairman of the Board Paula A. Kerger President and Chief Executive Officer

SHINDER--Jason. With enormous sorrow, family and friends mourn the passing at age 52 of Jason Shinder, poet, editor and director for the Arts & Humanities of the YMCA. Author of Every Room We Ever Slept In and Among Women, a final book of poems is forthcoming. Jason was a beloved teacher in the graduate writing programs of Bennington College and the New School University. Jason founded the Writer's Voice at the West Side Y and took it national with the YMCA of the USA. He also created the Sundance Institute's Writing Program. A legendary wit, devoted brother and uncle, and a beloved friend to many, Jason's zest for life was unyielding and he will live in our hearts forever. Mr. Shinder lived in New York City and Provincetown, MA; he is survived by his siblings, Martin and Nina, and his nieces, Jennah and Jamie Kudler. A service is scheduled for 2pm, April 29th, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. in New York City.

WEISSMAN--Anna J. (Tarasov), 97, of Scott Swamp Road, Farmington, CT wife of the late Eugene V. Weissman, died Monday, April 28, 2008 at John Dempsey Hospital. She was born February 2, 1911 in the Bronx, NY, daughter of the late Alex and Rachel (Lipitz) Tarasov and had lived in Flushing, NY prior to moving to Farmington, CT 18 years ago. She was a member of UJA Federation and Hadassah. She is survived by her daughter Jill of New York City; son and daughter-in-law, Kenneth and Celia of Avon, CT; her brother Morris of Bridgeport, CT and three grandchildren, Allison, Adam and Daniel. There are no calling hours. Private burial will be in Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Vincent Funeral Home, Canton is assisting the family with the services. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to Lions Low Vision Center, 975 Farmington Avenue, Bristol, CT 06010. For online condolences please visit vincentfuneralhome.com

SALZMAN--Esta. We mourn the loss of our beloved Esta, The Grand Lady of the Yiddish Theater. We cherish the delightful memories of her life which brought much joy to many generations of adoring admirers. Max Weintraub, Aviva Weintraub, and Michael Califano

EDERSHEIM--Maurits. We are very saddened by the loss of Marc, our dear friend of almost 40 years. A remarkable man of wisdom and kindness, he will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Our sincerest condolences to Claire and the entire family. Bobby and Maurie Deane EDERSHEIM--Maurits Ernst. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Maurits Ernst Edersheim. Our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary EDERSHEIM--Maurits Ernst. The Board and shareholders of The Worldwide Special Fund mourn the passing of our founder and honorary chairman. The Worldwide Special Fund was conceived by Mark in 1958 in a period when the concept of a global fund was both radical and unique. His guidance, wisdom and investment savvy was remarkable over the last fifty years. Mark guided the fund with a firm and knowledgeable hand through good times and bad. He will be deeply missed by all of us. Our profound condolences to Claire and the Edersheim family. The Worldwide Special Fund Michael E. Gellert, Chairman EDERSHEIM--Maurits E. The directors and members of the Netherland-America Foundation mourn the death of our friend and tireless supporter, Mr. Maurits E. Edersheim. Mr. Edersheim was involved with the NetherlandAmerica Foundation in many leadership capacities for over forty-five years. He was a Trustee of the Netherland Benevolent Society (NBS) from 1960 to 1976, and President from 1976 to 1984. In 1979 he orchestrated the merger of the NBS and the NetherlandAmerica Foundation (NAF). Mr. Edersheim served as Vice President and member of the NAF's Executive Committee and continued as Director until 2001, but remained actively involved in its affairs until 2005. In 2007, Mr. Edersheim was recipient of the NAF's Peter Stuyvesant Award in recognition of his signal contributions to strengthening relations between the Netherlands and the United States. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Claire, and the other members of the Edersheim family. On behalf of the NetherlandAmerica Foundation, Inc., Ennius E. Bergsma, Chairman EDERSHEIM--Maurits Ernst. The Hampton Group at Citi Smith Barney mourns the loss of our founder, mentor, partner and friend. His kindness, encouragement and sense of humor will always be fondly remembered by all of us. Mark was an inspiration to every member of our group, both in his professional and personal life. Our sincerest sympathy to Claire and the entire Edersheim family. The Hampton Group

RITTER--Wendy Zuckerwise, age 53, passed away Saturday April 26, 2008. Wendy had a joie de vivre that was apparent in her remarkable career as a consultant for renowned fashion designers and in her daily life both here in New York and in Dayton, Ohio. She had wonderful friends throughout the world. Her family meant everything to her as well. Wendy loved life. The world has lost a ray of sunshine that can never be replaced. Wendy is survived by her beloved family, including her loving husband, Nathaniel; mother, Ruth Zuckerwise; sister, Phyllis Sterne; and nephew and niece, David and Ashley Sterne. She was predeceased by her father Walter Zuckerwise. Wendy will be missed by all who where touched by her radiance. Funeral and interment will be held in Dayton, Ohio on Tuesday at Temple Israel. The family has endowed the Wendy Zuckerwise Ritter Endometrial Cancer Research Fund and would appreciate contributions to it via the OSU Foundation Fund #

PROPP--Moritmer. We mourn with great sorrow the passing of Mortimer Propp, a man of principle, a great philanthropist, and a scholar of Judaism. Our deepest condolences to the Propp and Heller families, and all who mourn his passing. Vicki and Joseph Tahl PROPP--Mortimer J. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University mourn the passing of an esteemed Jewish Communal leader and one of our generous supporters, Mortimer J. Propp. Mr. Propp was the beloved brother of our longtime American Friends leader and recipient of an honorary doctorate, Ephraim Propp and brother-in-law of our American Board of Trustees member, Gail Propp. We extend condolences to Mortimer Propp's wife, Eugenie, his daughter Helen Heller and son Morris Propp and the entire Propp family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Michael Jesselson, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Mark D. Medin, Executive Vice President and CEO, American Friends of Bar-Ilan University PROPP--Mortimer J. The members of Tahl Propp Equities record with great sorrow the passing of their venerated mentor M.J. Propp. He generously shared with us his knowledge of real estate garnered during his seventy-five years in business. His advice, counsel, energy and good humor will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Enia and the entire Propp and Heller families. Joseph A. Tahl, President PROPP--Mortimer J. We mourn the loss of a true gentleman and dear friend of Shaare Zedek Medical Center for more than five decades. Together with his wife, Eugenie, he was a Founder and a generous supporter. Mr. Propp was renowned for his many gracious, charitable en deavors, and with his brothers Seymour (z''l) and Ephraim, underwrote, in part, the Rabbi Dr. Leo Jung Chair in Medicine and Halacha, established a nursing students' scholarship fund, and contributed to other projects which have helped to make Shaare Zedek a major presence throughout the world in medical research. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Eugenie, to daughter Helen Anne and son-in-law Melvin Heller, son Morris and wife, Marni Propp, his grandchildren, Jack Heller and Adrienne Propp, brother Ephraim and wife Gail, a Women's Division Board Member, and sister-inlaw Gabrielle R. Propp, a Women's Division Board Member. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem PROPP--Mortimer J. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Mortimer J. Propp. Our heartfelt condolences to the Propp and Heller families. Michael and Tamar Propp and family. PROPP--Mortimer. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Mortimer Propp, a beloved leader and cherished friend. He will be remembered for his longstanding philanthropy and esteemed leadership on our Board of Directors and with our Real Estate Division. The commitment and generosity of Mortimer and his dear wife, Enia, strengthened our ability to serve those in need, profoundly impacting the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. The Propp family embraced a philanthropic tradition for decades that continues with the next generation through Mortimer's children and his nieces and nephews. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Enia; his daughter, Helen, and her husband, Melvin Heller; his son, Morris, and his wife, Marni; his brother, Ephraim, and his wife, Gail; his sister-in-law, Gabrielle; his nieces and nephews; his grandchildren; and to the entire family. A North Korean military officer defected to South Korea across its heavily armed border, the first Communist officer to do so in a decade, a South Korean military spokesman said. He said the soldier crossed the western sector of the 2.5-mile-wide Demilitarized Zone on Sunday and added, ''We are investigating the motive of his defection.'' The Yonhap News Agency identified the soldier as a 28-year-old second lieutenant. Although more than 10,000 North Koreans have fled to the South through China in the last decade, few have dared cross the border between the Koreas, which is guarded by barbed-wire fences, mine fields, heavy weaponry and nearly two million soldiers facing off.

DOOLEY--Virginia Susan, of Taos, NM, died on Friday, April 25th, after a prolonged illness. She was a fixture of the Taos art community, having been the longtime companion, publicist, promoter and gallery director for Navajo artist, R. C. Gorman. She is survived by her two brothers, William Paul Dooley of Kent, CT, and Raymond W. Dooley of Belgrade, Serbia. For complete obituary and service information, go to riverafuneralhome.com

I've had time to look at it a bit more closely -- and it's much weaker than the headline number suggests (and MUCH weaker than the previous quarter, even though the growth rate was the same.) It's not just that final sales fell, so that the economy grew only because of inventory accumulation. If you look at consumer spending, purchases of goods actually fell substantially. Only service purchases rose -- and much of that was housing and medical care. As Michael Mandel at Business Week has pointed out, those aren't "really" consumer decisions: housing "consumption" is largely imputed rents on owner-occupied homes, and medical care is mostly paid for by insurance.

Anticipating hefty cuts in the education budget in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's executive budget, which will be announced on Thursday, several City Council members and education advocates lined up on the steps of City Hall today for a demonstration. Warning of slashed after-school programs, tutoring, and English-as-a-second-language lessons, the speakers said that they were protesting the mayor's proposed budget because it contradicted his self-styled reputation as the "education mayor."But despite their fiery oratory, few of the council members were willing to commit to voting against them. Only Robert Jackson, the chairman of the council's education committee, and Charles Barron of Brooklyn, said that they would vote against the budget unless most or all of the education cuts were restored.

Catholic Charities, with Enterprise, a national housing group, and New York City have announced the preservation of 1,000 units of affordable housing for low-income older residents at 10 buildings in Brooklyn and Queens, the groups announced Wednesday afternoon.Thanks to bond financing, tax credit equity, and a $170 million refinancing package, in which mortgages of Catholic Charities properties were reduced to under 6 percent from between 7 percent and 9 percent, buildings in Long Island City, Borough Park, Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, among other neighborhoods, were rehabilitated. Renovations included upgraded boilers, wheelchair ramps, automatic entrances, improved common areas, window replacements and energy efficient lighting. The apartments will house about 1,300 older residents, many of whom moved into the buildings 20 years ago.

Nostrasaurus: I see terrible things in your future. Dinosaur: What? Tell me! Nostrasaurus: I see your skeleton assembled in a large room. There are little creatures - humans, they're called - and they're interested in your skeleton. They're all looking at it and talking about it. Dinosaur: That's horrible! What kind of beasts would do such a thing?! It is one thing to kill for food, but to kill just to stare upon the bones of the victim? That's brutality! Nostrasaurus: Oh no, they have not killed you. But they've found your bones buried deep in the ground, extracted them and put them on display for their whole species to observe. Dinosaur: This -- this is terrible news. Is there a way I can kill them first so I might avoid this horrible future? Nostrasaurus: No. I'm afraid not. Dinosaur: I -- I don't know what to say. I feel so -- so helpless. Nostrasaurus: Wait! I'm getting something -- oh --OH! A vision! Dinosaur: What is it? Will I have my revenge on these creatures? Nostrasaurus: YES! Because of us - all of us, from the smallest creature in the sea to the largest beasts on the land - they will bring untold harm upon themselves! Dinosaur: Tell me more! Nostrasaurus: They will kill each other over us! We will be the cause of their wars and the root of their deepest problems. We will plague them, we will destroy their world and their bodies but they will not be able to purge themselves of our influence. Dinosaur: This is wonderful news! What must we do?Nostrasaurus: We must die. Then we must sink into the ground, experience untold eons of heat and pressure before turning into a flammable, black liquid. Dinosaur: Oh. So the dying is part of it? Nostrasaurus: Yup. Dinosaur: Huh. Well, as long they won't put my bones on display. Nostrasaurus: No, they're still going to do that. Dinosaur: Oh, so we still have to die, then they'll kill each other and they'll still put our bones on display? Nostrasaurus: Correct. Dinosaur: Doesn't seem to be an upside, huh? Nostrasaurus: I guess not. Dinosaur: I wish I had bigger arms. Nostrasaurus: I KNOW, right?!Streeter Seidell is front-page editor of CollegeHumor.com.

Lots of us think about Amy Spindler, the mind of Amy Spindler, and I'm glad people are again discovering her writing. She came to life, I think, in the latter part of her run as fashion critic of the NYT and then again when she became Style Editor of the Magazine. Amy was a good writer and an excellent, tireless reporter who had an energetic mind that sought out new ideas. She loved the nostalgia piece; one of my favorite articles that I wrote for her at the Magazine was a profile of Jacques Tiffeau (a wild, brilliant guy and a lover of Dior's, by the way). She saw the charm and evergreen "news" in those kinds of pieces. But Amy was also someone with strong moral beliefs and maybe that was the source of her contentiousness. She loved catching a fashion exec in a lie, and, of course, there was the heroin chic piece. You felt her rage, her high sense of standards. And she could REALLY yack during a fashion show. Amy would be talking away during a show and you'd be looking at the clothes and going, "Yeah ahum yeah ahum." Somehow, she saw everything. Her deputy at the mag, Andy Port, gave a marvelous speech at Amy's memorial, which was held at the Rainbow Room. Amy had a knack, as Andy said, of persuading people to her side. We all knew that special power of hers pretty well.

Inside Castle Williams, a circular fortress on Governors Island. It was designed and built between 1807 and 1811 under the direction of Col. Jonathan Williams, who was the first chief engineer of the Corps of Engineers, the first superintendent of the Military Academy in West Point, N.Y., and a grandnephew of Benjamin Franklin. Like his uncle, Colonel Williams tested his theories: He had the fort shelled as he stood inside. The walls withstood the pounding, and he was uninjured.

A state appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the Port Authority was liable for damages caused by the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, because it knew about but chose to ignore "an extreme and potentially catastrophic vulnerability that would have been open and obvious to any terrorist who cared to investigate and exploit it."The ruling unanimously upheld a jury's verdict that the agency was 68 percent liable for the bombing and the terrorists were 32 percent liable. In its decision, the court noted that the Port Authority, a bistate New York and New Jersey agency that owned the trade center, did not argue that the bombing was unforeseeable, only that it was unlikely, since its own consultants and an internal study group had predicted "with exact prescience" how an attack could be carried out. Under state rules, because the Port Authority's liability was more than 50 percent, it can be forced to pay all the damages to injured survivors and to relatives of those who were killed.

When I first read "Housekeeping" I was living in a house my maternal grandparents had built in the 1920s in a small town in western South Dakota. Its location had been determined by a railroad company; in 1907 the laying of track for the Milwaukee Road stopped for the winter, and the town was born, as a row of tents and a few ramshackle businesses. By the time my mother was born, 10 years later, people were living in frame houses and had planted trees. When she was a child, nearly everyone she knew was from somewhere else, "back East," all the way to Sweden, Norway or the Russian steppes. But by the time I spent childhood summers there, the place had become densely layered with human history of the sort so vividly depicted in the novel. It is the first place I heard people - the parents of a friend my grandmother disapproved of - described as "shiftless," not likely to remain in the town for long. As I knew my grandmother to be a tolerant and compassionate woman, this got my attention.

New York-listed brewer Anheuser-Busch has begun offering its stock on the Paris arm of transatlantic exchange NYSE Euronext after de-listing its shares from the London Stock Exchange on the back of low trading volumes.

Istithmar World Capital, the private equity and alternative investment arm of the Dubai government-owned investment company Istithmar World, has agreed to purchase a majority stake in U.S.-based corporate credit investor Gulf Stream Asset Management for an undisclosed amount, as the Dubai company seeks to expand beyond alternative investments and into credit markets.

Lehman Brothers said Monday that it has appointed Perry Hoffmeister, who, since 2004, has been co-head of investment banking for Europe and the Middle East, as head of investment management for the two regions.
The Climate Solutions Fund, a venture capital pool headed by Al Gore, has closed on a $683 million fund to invest in early-stage environmental companies, The Financial Times reported.

Manager Joe Girardi never looks good after a loss, but he looked weary after Phil Hughes imploded and the Yankees lost to the Detroit Tigers, 6-4, on Tuesday night. Hughes was pounded for six runs and eight hits in three and two thirds innings.
Boston officials on Tuesday unveiled a $4 million tax-incentive package to convince JPMorgan Chase to remain in Boston.

No special purpose acquisition companies, or Spacs, priced an initial public offering in April, according to investment banking research provider Dealogic. The lull follows the pricing of 7 Spac offerings in January, 4 in February and just one in March.
A "toxic stew" of problems with pilots and other issues at US Airways would imperil any merger between that carrier and United Airlines, the leader of the United pilots' union said on Tuesday.
Citigroup said Tuesday that it would sell $3 billion of new common shares in another effort to shore up its balance sheet.

Softbank, the Japanese Internet services and telecommunications company, said Wednesday it hopes to boost its stake to 40 percent in a major Chinese Internet company for a total investment of 40 billion yen ($385 million), eyeing booming demand in the country.
British gas company BG Group has offered 12.9 billion Australian dollars ($12.1 billion) in cash for Australian electricity retailer and oil and gas producer Origin Energy.
CBS and General Electric's NBC Universal plan to bid for the Weather Channel in the second round, with bids expected to range between $3.5 billion and $4 billion, Reuters reported.
Music blog aggregator MOG has confirmed that it has raised $2.8 million in funding from investors including two of the Big Four record labels.
First Data, a payments processor backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is buying gift and prepay card company InComm for an undisclosed price.

Cox Enterprises, a media company with broad holdings in newspapers, radio and television, said Tuesday that it would pay $300 million in cash for the advertising technology company Adify. The move would put Cox in competition with companies like Google that have built up big online advertising franchises.

The Columbus Symphony Orchestra in Ohio, bedeviled by financial problems that threaten its existence, said late Monday that a board member had made an emergency donation to allow it to finish the season. After the musicians rejected a contract on Friday that would have cut their pay by 40 percent, the orchestra’s management said it might have to suspend operations because revenue was not meeting costs. Management is seeking to cut the $12 million budget to $9.5 million, the most it said Columbus could support through ticket sales and donations. The emergency gift allows the orchestra to go ahead with its remaining concerts in May but, the board said, “defers to another day the inevitable suspension of operations due to a lack of funds.”.

Those poems on the subways are going the way of the No. 9 line — that is, coming to an end after 15 years. Poems may still be posted now and then, but mostly the quotations seen on subways and buses will pertain to a number of different subjects, including history, philosophy, literature and science. “We’re expanding the breadth of the program to include other areas,” said Jeremy Soffin, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. “Fifteen years is a long time. We had an opportunity to diversify things a little.” The content — formerly selected by the Poetry Society of America, which started it in 1992 — will now be determined by the Columbia University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. Alice Quinn, executive director of the Poetry Society, said she would try to find a new sponsor, adding, “We’re going to try to keep poetry in the public eye.”.

Using X-ray technology, art historians at Bristol University in England believe they have found a portrait of Henry Wriothesley, third Earl of Southampton and Shakespeare’s only known patron, the BBC reported. While preparing an oil portrait of Wriothesley’s wife, Elizabeth Vernon, for an exhibition, the historians discovered a ghostly male figure that had been painted over. From his appearance and long auburn hair, they concluded it was her husband. The experts said the find was significant, but they have no plans to chip away at the Vernon portrait to raise the specter.
The senator appears to be in a tighter fight for the Democratic nomination after losing Pennsylvania and the uproar over his former pastor, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

The sale of new common shares was another effort by the banking giant to shore up its balance sheet. The offering was priced at $25.27 a share.
The results are likely to raise questions about the viability of G.M.’s turnaround, particularly after its cross-town rival, Ford, reported a profit last week.
Guard Ben Hansbrough, who helped Mississippi State advance to the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, is transferring to Notre Dame. Hansbrough is the younger brother of Tyler Hansbrough.

A judge has refused to free a former Symbionese Liberation Army member who was sent back to prison days after corrections officials released her by mistake. Judge Thomas Cecil of Sacramento County Superior Court said in a ruling that lawyers for the former radical, Sara Jane Olson, failed to show that corrections officials acted illegally and that Ms. Olson herself should have realized she was being freed too soon. Ms. Olson, 61, was mistakenly paroled on March 17 after six years in prison. She had pleaded guilty to the attempted bombing of Los Angeles police cars and to the killing of a customer during a 1975 bank robbery in suburban Sacramento. She had lived in Minnesota until her capture in 1999.

The Service Employees International Union filed a federal lawsuit in Los Angeles, accusing the president and nine other leaders of its giant health care local in California of breaching their fiduciary duties. The lawsuit accused them of setting up an educational fund that the parent union said was used to spend money for internal political purposes off the books and without proper accountability. The lawsuit comes as Sal Rosselli, the president of the California local, United Healthcare Workers-West, has accused Andrew L. Stern, the S.E.I.U.’s president, of being undemocratic. Jonathan Siegel, a lawyer for the local, said its board had approved the creation of the fund and dissolved it last week and returned all the money, some of which was used to educate the local’s nearly 150,000 members about the push for universal health coverage in California.

Army officials said they were inspecting every barracks building worldwide to see whether plumbing and other problems revealed last week at Fort Bragg, N.C., were widespread. Brig. Gen. Dennis Rogers, who is responsible for maintaining barracks, told reporters at the Pentagon that most inspections were done last weekend but that he had not seen final results. He acknowledged a video shot by the father of an 82nd Airborne Division soldier showing poor conditions at Fort Bragg, including mold, peeling paint and a drain plugged with sewage.

The president of Northern Illinois University has dropped the idea of tearing down the building where five students were killed in February. The president, John G. Peters, originally wanted to demolish Cole Hall and replace it with a new building and a memorial. But he said a survey of the university community showed overwhelming support for keeping the building. In a message posted on the university’s Web site, Dr. Peters said officials were seeking input on three options for renovating the building. It has remained empty since Feb. 14, when a gunman burst into a lecture hall and shot five students before killing himself.

The highest court of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has found that a Northern California minister did not violate denominational law when she officiated at the weddings of two lesbian couples. The ruling by the court, based in Louisville, Ky., overturns a decision against the minister, the Rev. Jane Spahr. A regional judicial committee found Ms. Spahr guilty of misconduct last year and gave her a rebuke, the lightest possible punishment. The church’s high court found that the ceremonies Ms. Spahr performed were not marriages, so she did not violate the church’s constitution. Ms. Spahr, 65, retired last year.
Tensions flared again between Russia and Georgia, its southern neighbor, after both sides accused each other of an improper military buildup related to a disputed border area.
The European Union signed a pre-membership pact with Serbia as a way to help pro-Western forces avoid defeat by nationalists at the polls on May 11.
The government said it was willing to negotiate with a guerrilla group that blew up several oil and gas pipelines last year, a day after the guerrillas offered to suspend attacks.

Third-seeded David Nalbandian rallied to defeat Agustin Calleri, 1-6, 7-6 (2), 6-3, in an all-Argentine matchup in the second round of the Barcelona Open in Spain. The wild-card entrant Mario Ancic beat seventh-seeded Andy Murray, 6-4, 6-4. Rafael Nadal, the three-time tournament champion, opens against Potito Starace on Wednesday. Nadal won his fourth straight Monte Carlo Masters title last week.

Rutgers and Connecticut, the dominant powers in women’s basketball in the Big East Conference, will again play a home-and-home series next season. The conference schedule was announced Tuesday. They split their series last season.

Guard Ben Hansbrough, who helped Mississippi State advance to the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament last month, is transferring to Notre Dame. Hansbrough is the younger brother of North Carolina forward Tyler Hansbrough.

Dathan Ritzenhein, who has claimed a berth on the United States Olympic marathon team, will defend his title in the Healthy Kidney 10-kilometer race in Central Park on May 17. The field also includes the 2006 New York City Marathon champion Marilson Gomes dos Santos of Brazil. Ritzenhein set the Central Park 10K record last year, in 28 minutes 8 seconds.

Top-seeded Vera Zvonareva beat Lucie Hradecka, 6-2, 6-3, in the first round of the Prague Open. Jill Craybas of the United States also advanced to the second round with a 6-4, 6-2 victory against fifth-seeded Karin Knapp.

Three online gambling companies won a ruling against the French Tennis Federation when a Belgian court rejected the organization’s move to block them from taking bets on the French Open. The court ruled that Bwin, Betfair and Ladbrokes do not “encourage corruption” by taking bets on tennis.

Manchester United set up the first all-English final in the history of the European Champions League by defeating visiting Barcelona, 1-0, on Tuesday night. Paul Scholes scored on a 25-yard shot to put United in its first Champions League final since 1999. Manchester United, which played to a 0-0 tie at Barcelona last week, won the home-and-home semifinal on aggregate and will meet Chelsea or Liverpool in the final on May 21 in Moscow. Chelsea plays host to Liverpool on Wednesday after a 1-1 tie at Anfield last week.

The Buffalo Bills will receive $78 million — more than double their calculated operating income for 2006 — to play eight games in Toronto over the next five years. The payment to the Bills was disclosed Tuesday by Rogers Communications, which was part of a consortium that negotiated the deal for the games. The Bills’ first game is Aug. 14 against the Steelers at the Rogers Centre.

After his older brother’s comments made a stire, Hal Steinbrenner said that the team planned to move Joba Chamerlain into the starting rotation.
The phone service provider said its quarterly operating revenue fell to $1.57 billion, from $1.59 billion a year ago, while access lines decreased 7.3 percent.
A former U.C.L.A. Medical Center employee was indicted on accusations that she gained access to the records of dozens of well-known patients and sold the information.
Instead of going to Iraq after graduating from West Point, Caleb Campbell will be allowed to play professional football for the Detroit Lions while remaining on active duty.
I.B.M. increased its dividend payout 25 percent on Tuesday, reflecting the company’s confidence that it can thrive even in an uncertain economy.
Carey Price had an outstanding regular season, but an inconsistent series against the Philadelphia Flyers could land him on the bench.
A nonprofit group is teaching people how to free pets inadvertently caught in traps set legally for wild fur-bearing animals.
Mr. Harison introduced everyone from Ben Hogan to Jack Nicklaus to Tiger Woods in 60 years as the starter on the first tee of the Masters.
Mr. Brant was best known for his spatial music, in which the placement of performers on the stage and at carefully specified places around a concert hall is a crucial element.
The companies said that their drug Rituxan did not achieve any of seven measures of effectiveness in a late-stage patient trial.
The bank, which had won praise in financial circles for seeming to weather the credit storm better than most of its peers, reported a $395 million first-quarter loss.
Mr. Warner was the author of “Beautiful Swimmers,” a study of crabs and watermen in the Chesapeake Bay, which won the Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction in 1977.
Mr. Robinson broke racial barriers as a college basketball coach and discovered talented players as a scout for both professional basketball and football teams.
Wall Street turned in a mixed performance Tuesday as investors traded cautiously ahead of the Federal Reserve’s decision on Wednesday on interest rates.
A rare playoff goal from defenseman Mattias Norstrom helped move the Dallas Stars one victory from the Western Conference finals.

Dr. Gibson developed a safe, highly reliable method to test children for cystic fibrosis, and later helped refine treatments for it.

As I watch Robert Mugabe tighten his 28-year-old stranglehold on Zimbabwe, I can’t help thinking back to a conversation he and I once tried to have about T. S. Eliot.
The Tribeca Film Festival has become more of a local event than a global player.
The Port Authority was found negligent in safeguarding the World Trade Center before the 1993 terrorist attack.

Scott Weiland, the lead singer of the band Stone Temple Pilots, was sentenced on Monday to eight days in jail for drunken driving, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Weiland, 40, right, entered a plea of no contest to a single misdemeanor count, his second conviction in four years for driving under the influence. Besides jail, he was placed on four years’ unsupervised probation, ordered to enroll in an 18-month alcohol program and fined about $1,600, said Frank Mateljan, a spokesman for the Los Angeles City Attorney’s Office.

After a 12-week absence from Fox’s schedule, “House” returned with a new episode, lifting the network to first place in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that the medical drama led the night in that age group while drawing 14.5 million total viewers during the 9 p.m. hour. Fox finished first in the 18-to-49 set despite drawing more modest ratings at 8 p.m. with “Bones” (9.7 million). Fox did trail ABC in total viewers for the night, as ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” remained the night’s most-watched show with 17.9 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. CBS ranked third in total viewers behind both ABC and Fox, but second in the 18-to-49 set ahead of ABC, earning solid ratings from its comedy lineup. CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (13.6 million), which outperformed both ABC’s “Bachelor” (7.8 million) and NBC’s “Medium” (9.6 million). NBC was fourth over all.

After 57 years, Wolfgang Wagner is stepping down as director of the Wagner festival in Bayreuth, Germany, Agence France-Presse reported on Tuesday. “Wolfgang Wagner has announced his resignation,” said Markus Gnad, a spokesman for the Bavarian culture ministry. He added that it was not known who would succeed the 88-year-old Mr. Wagner, grandson of Richard Wagner, or when he would formally leave his post. The announcement came on the day of a meeting of the festival’s board, which received from two of Mr. Wagner’s daughters an outline of their plan for joint leadership of the annual festival. They are the half-sisters Eva Wagner-Pasquier, 63, and Katharina Wagner, 29.

Golden necklaces, daggers, clay statues and pots were among more than 700 antiquities, including the one above, returned this week to the National Museum of Iraq by Syria, where they were seized from traffickers after being looted in the chaos that followed the United States-led invasion five years ago, The Associated Press reported. “This was a positive initiative taken by Syria, and we wish the same initiative to be taken by all neighboring countries,” said Mohammad Abbas al-Oreibi, Iraq’s acting state minister of tourism and archaeology, who led the negotiations with Syria. He said he planned to visit Jordan soon to seek the return of more than 150 items. Dr. Muna Hassan, who heads a committee working to restore the artifacts, said similar discussions were in progress with the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Germany and Italy. Between 3,000 and 7,000 items are believed to be missing, Laurent Levi-Strauss, a Unesco culture official, said last month. Syria said it arrested some of the traffickers but did not provide details. The National Museum, in Baghdad, remains closed to the public as a result of its poor condition and a lack of security.

Gary Snyder was named the winner of the $100,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize on Tuesday. Announcing the award, Christian Wiman, editor of Poetry magazine and chairman of the selection committee, said, “His poetry is a testament to the sacredness of the natural world and our relation to it, and a prophecy of what we stand to lose if we forget that relation.” The San Francisco-born Mr. Snyder, 78, whose poetry collections include “The Back Country” and “Danger on Peaks,” began writing in the 1950s as a member of the Beat movement and won a Pulitzer Prize in 1975 for “Turtle Island.” He is professor emeritus of English at the University of California, Davis. The prize honors a living American poet whose lifetime accomplishments warrant extraordinary recognition.

In 1969, when she was 16, Gail Renard evaded heavy security at the Queen Elizabeth Hotel in Montreal and managed to sneak into Suite 1742, where John Lennon and Yoko Ono were staging their eight-day bed-in for peace. Ms. Renard, now a prize-winning comedy writer and comic, stayed for a week with the couple. On the final night of the bed-in, Lennon led a recording of “Give Peace a Chance,” sung by him and 50 or so guests, including Timothy Leary, Tommy Smothers, Petula Clark and Allen Ginsberg. He also gave Ms. Renard a few mementos, including the lyrics, above, and told her that “one day they will be worth something.” On July 10 the lyrics and some rare photographs will be offered in London by Christie’s South Kensington at a sale of rock and pop memorabilia. A Christie’s announcement said the items were expected to bring $400,000 to $600,000.

The downward trend for the CBS News anchor Katie Couric continued last week as the network’s evening newscast dipped again in the ratings. One week after setting a record low, with about 5.39 million viewers, the newscast attracted about 50,000 fewer people, averaging about 5.34 million. The number is the lowest total for the “CBS Evening News” since Nielsen research introduced its new rating system in 1987. The broadcast was far more popular before that date. Ms. Couric’s ratings have been sliding since reports that she and the top management of CBS have held discussions about her future at the network, although network executives, including the chairman, Leslie Moonves, have expressed faith in her and the program. The race at the top of the newscast competition was closer than the prior week as NBC’s program beat ABC’s by about 227,000 viewers. A week earlier the gap was about 700,000 viewers as ABC faced possible negative fallout from widespread criticism of its presentation of the Democratic presidential debate in Pennsylvania. A 21-year-old London man has been awarded about $5 million to make a feature film after winning a yearlong moviemaking contest sponsored by the Web-based production company Filmaka, Variety reported. The winner, Nuru Rimington-Mkali, is preparing to propose ideas to the Filmaka partners Deepak Nayar, producer of “Bend It Like Beckham” and “Buena Vista Social Club,” and Sandy Grushow, former chairman of the Fox Entertainment group. In the contest, Filmaka challenged nonprofessionals to tackle monthly assignments to produce short films based on a brief idea posted on its Web site, filmaka.com. The judges included Colin Firth, Werner Herzog, Neil LaBute, Paul Schrader and Wim Wenders, among others. Mr. LaBute called Mr. Rimington-Mkali’s final winning short, “And I Refuse to Forget,” a “wonderfully impressive paranoid thriller that was told with great economy and vivid imagery.”.

Beginning next month, kidney transplants will be halted for almost all foreigners, as part of a government crackdown on an illicit but growing trade in human organs bought from the poor. Foreigners who violate the ban, as well as middlemen in the transactions, can be imprisoned for up to 20 years. Foreigners related by blood to Filipino citizens are exempted. According to the health secretary, Francisco T. Duque III, kidney transplants for foreigners increased by more than 60 percent from 2002 to 2006; 500 were performed on foreigners last year alone. Organ transplants are among the services under a government medical tourism program aimed at foreigners, with a typical kidney transplant costing about $95,000. As a result of the thriving trade, many Filipinos have been willing to sell a kidney for $2,000 to $10,000.

LESHOWITZ--Edward, died peacefully on April 21st, 2008. He leaves behind a daughter, Susan Sandson, a niece Terry Singer, two sisters, Ethel Singer and Sylvia Leshowitz, three grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his wife Esther and his son Jed. He was born on April 12th, 1915 and grew up in Passaic, New Jersey. He graduated from Montclair State University, became a high school teacher and served in the army in World War II. After the War, he and his partners, John and Angelo Cali, created vocational schools for WWII veterans and then created Cali Associates, a construction business, building homes and office buildings in New Jersey and the greater New York area. It later became Cali Realty and then Mack-Cali Realty. Edward was a successful entrepreneur and a generous benefactor. He was a loving and giving father, grandfather, brother and uncle. He had a great sense of humor and strong opinions about politics. He traveled the world and loved to tell stories about his travels, his youth, his days in the army and in the classroom. He will be greatly missed. There will be a memorial service at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Ave at 81st St., on Thursday May 1st at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Parkinson Foundation.

BACK in the early '80s, when I had just begun to write about cooking, I used to hang around in the kitchen of a man named Peter Chang. Mr. Chang ran a one-man-show of a Chinese restaurant in New Haven, and was kind and patient enough to teach me some of what he knew. Mr. Chang's efficiency was questionable: he'd start grinding the meat and shredding the cabbage when someone ordered dumplings, and often began a batch of stock only when the first patron asked for hot-and-sour soup.

ASHLEY--Carleton, 89, died peacefully, April 26 in Scarborough, ME. He is survived by his devoted wife of 65 years, Marilyn, three children, C. Allen (Anne), Frances (Paul Rubacha), and Julia Lynn (Phil Hocking), and five grandchildren, Teryn, Carleton, Ali, Chris, and Elizabeth. Born in Bronxville, NY, ''Ash'' was a graduate of Berkshire School (1937) and Yale University (1941), a member of Saybrook College, Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity, and Scroll and Key. He spent five years in the U.S. Army as a Major in the Military Intelligence Service, Latin American. He enjoyed a successful career in international business with executive positions at Coca-Cola Export Corp, E.R. Squibb & Sons, and Carter Wallace Inc. retiring as President, Carter-Wallace International. He lived for many years in Bronxville, NY, Princeton, NJ, and Castine, ME, as well as Uruguay, Argentina, Philippines, Spain and France. He was an avid outdoorsman, athlete, cook, sports fan, polyglot, and history buff. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made in his name to the Castine Historical Society, 17 School St., Castine, ME 04412.

Energy-hungry India hosted President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran for a brief but symbolic visit. Mr. Ahmadinejad met in New Delhi with the president, the prime minister and several cabinet ministers, and used the occasion to condemn the efforts of ''bullying powers'' to contain what he called Iran's right to develop nuclear energy. He spoke glowingly of longstanding ties between India and Iran. The visit produced no path-breaking bilateral deals, nor did it iron out the kinks in a proposed 1,600-mile-long natural gas pipeline. But it brought the Indian government a chance to show that it is willing to buck pressure from the White House and shake hands with a man Washington reviles. The government of Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is under pressure at home to assert its independence from the United States, even as that pressure has stalled a landmark nuclear accord initiated by the Bush administration that would allow India access to nuclear technology on the world market. SOMINI SENGUPTA

Senator Barack Obama broke forcefully on Tuesday with his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., in an effort to curtail a drama of race, values, patriotism and betrayal that has enveloped his presidential candidacy at a critical juncture. At a news conference here, Mr. Obama denounced remarks Mr. Wright made in a series of televised appearances over the last several days. In the appearances, Mr. Wright has suggested that the United States was attacked because it engaged in terrorism on other people and that the government was capable of having used the AIDS virus to commit genocide against minorities. His remarks also cast Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, in a positive light.

Just one day after thousands of workers gathered to mourn the loss of the 13 people killed in construction accidents in New York City this year, a steel worker was critically injured on Tuesday when he fell 25 feet from a building under construction on East 29th Street in Manhattan. The authorities said the worker, Christopher Gunn, 28, was trying to maneuver a 20-foot steel I-beam being hoisted into place by a crane about 8:30 a.m. when he slipped and fell from the second story of the building, which is under construction between First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

WATERFALL--John Charles (Bruce), 70, of New York and Wainscott died on April 28th, 2008 after a 20-year battle with Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia. It took more time than it should have, but on Tuesday Barack Obama firmly rejected the racism and paranoia of his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah Wright Jr., and he made it clear that the preacher does not represent him, his politics or his campaign. Senator Obama has had to struggle to explain this relationship ever since a video surfaced of Mr. Wright damning the United States from his pulpit. Last month, Mr. Obama delivered a speech in which he said he disapproved of Mr. Wright's racially charged comments but said that the pastor still played an important role in his spiritual life.

Americans' confidence in the economy plunged again this month, and their homes lost value at the fastest rate in two decades, according to two reports released on Tuesday. The data ratcheted up pressure on the Federal Reserve to take further steps to stave off a prolonged slowdown, even as inflation remains a threat. The central bank is widely expected to lower its benchmark interest rate by a quarter-point when it concludes its policy-setting meeting on Wednesday.
Excerpts of prepared remarks made by Senator Barack Obama on March 18 in his speech on race, addressing the sermons of his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.:

Yet another proposal to resolve the mess arising from Michigan's too-early primary has been floated, this time by a group of prominent Democrats. This latest plan would split the difference between the positions of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. Mrs. Clinton insists that the state's 128 pledged delegates be seated according to the result of the Jan. 15 primary, which she won although the national Democratic Party declared the contest illegal in advance and Mr. Obama's name was not on the ballot. That would give her a 73 to 55 advantage in delegates.

NEW YORK has long been a city of stand-up eaters, but that doesn't mean people aren't picky. To make it here, a sandwich has to work overtime, being portable, filling, interesting and tasty. ''What's better than a really great sandwich?'' said Alexandra Raij, the chef at Tía Pol and El Quinto Pino, who is hosting a sandwich potluck for friends at her apartment next week. ''Nothing that I've ever made.''

Tony Horwitz's new book, ''A Voyage Long and Strange,'' is about the American history most Americans never learned, including the story of the short-lived, early-17th-century colony established on this windswept island eight miles west of Martha's Vineyard. The book starts with the Viking discovery of North America, dispels a number of myths about Columbus (a much lousier navigator than we were taught) and then traces the various Spanish and French explorations of America before turning to the English settlements at Jamestown and Plymouth.

9 P.M. (CW) FARMER WANTS A WIFE Matt Neustadt is a third-generation farmer in Portage des Sioux, Mo. In high school he played football and baseball, was crowned prom king and voted ''most desired.'' And yet Mr. Neustadt is single -- a result, he says, of long days spent hauling grain, milking cows and balancing the books. The 10 city women in this new dating series, above, are out to end his bachelorhood, but first they'll have to prove that they can get up with the roosters and lie down with the chickens, while tending to chores in between. ''Finding out a little bit about what their goals are in life, what their personality is, that's more beautiful than anything,'' Mr. Neustadt says. Does that include the personality of the self-described beauty Josie, whose first question is, ''Is there gonna be a maid?'' 8 P.M. (13, 49) ESCAPE FROM AUSCHWITZ By 1944 some 12,000 Jews were being murdered each day inside Auschwitz, Hitler's largest death camp. As record keepers for Nazi guards, Rudolph Vrba and Alfred Wetzler, both Slovak Jews, were allowed to see details of deportations and executions unknown to outsiders. In April 1944 they escaped from the camp and trekked to the Jewish Council headquarters in Zilina, Slovakia, to inform the Allies of the atrocities. This ''Secrets of the Dead'' episode traces Vrba and Wetzler's journey, which, despite unforeseen obstacles, helped save 120,000 Hungarian Jews.

McFADDEN--George, Trustee. For twelve years, a Trustee of St. Andrew's Dune Church, where he worshipped every summer for sixty years. His great association in such service will be missed by his many friends. May his rest match the gift of his serving so well as the 66th Dune Church Trustee since 1879. The Trustees St. Andrew's Dune Church Southampton, NY McFADDEN--George. We record with great sadness the untimely death of much admired businessman and sportsman George McFadden, husband of our co-chairman, Carol McFadden, who, with his steadfast and generous support, has so inspiringly and energetically led initiatives to preserve the architectural and contextual integrity of historic Carnegie Hill. Our deepest condolences to the entire family. CitiNeighbors Coalition of Historic Carnegie Hill Jurate Kazickas Jane Parshall Co-Chairmen McFADDEN--George. Be loved husband of Carol, beloved father of Lisa Melas, Wilhelmina McFadden, and Alexander McFadden, beloved stepfather of Piers and Georgiana Moreton. Adored grandfather of Leon and Pavlos Melas. He died in a plane crash, in the Toledo Bend Reservoir, Texas, at 4pm, April 22nd. He was 67. He was the son of Alexander Bloomfield McFadden and Josephine Cutting Blair. He attended Greenvale School, St. Paul's School, Vanderbilt University and Columbia Business School. He was the Chairman of McFadden Bros. LLC. and had a long career in venture capital. Original, witty, generous, an exceptional sportsman, Mr. McFadden was a Governor of Deepdale Country Club, Trustee of the St Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, of St. Paul's School, and a Director of the Squaw Valley Ski Corporation. Tradition loving, family oriented, and erudite, he will be lovingly remembered. He is survived by his sister Mary McFadden and brother John McFadden, by his half brothers Watson Blair and Wolcott Blair, his stepfather, Watson K. Blair, his former wife Lesley Taylor, and by his many loving cousins. The Funeral Service is to be held on May 8th at 3pm, St. Thomas's Church, 1 W. 53rd St. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to St. Andrews Dune Church, Southampton, or The Alexander B. McFadden Memorial Scholarship, at St. Paul's School, Concord, New Hampshire.

ON a visit to Papantla, a small city in Veracruz, Mexico, Zarela Martínez visited a club of retired women, each 65 or older, or what the locals call ''people of the third age,'' she said. The women kept local traditions in cooking, dancing and needlework alive, and introduced them to outsiders. Ms. Martínez, the New York restaurateur and cookbook author, was offered a plate of chicken legs browned and simmered in a glossy sauce flavored with orange juice, a bit of vinegar, garlic, chilies and vanilla.

AT one long-running Hudson River shad festival this spring, the part of the shad will be played by farmed Atlantic salmon. For the past few years, Riverkeeper, the Hudson River conservation group, has been easing the fish off the menu of the festival it stages in Garrison, N.Y. This year's event, on May 18, will be completely shad-free.

Dr. Natanson was a World War II army veteran and Professor of Philosophy at the College of Staten Island of the City University of New York where he taught from 1958 until his retirement in 1986. He was the son of the late Kate and Charles Natanson and was predeceased by his dear wife, Rose Brandel, and his brother Maurice and a sister. He is survived by nephews, Noel, Harold and Martin Brandel and nieces Lisa, Carla and Dana Lubow. A dear, kind and thoughtful friend, Harvey will be missed forever.

DNA tests confirmed that Josef Fritzl, the 73-year-old man accused of keeping his daughter imprisoned in a basement dungeon, was also the father of her six surviving children, according to the police. Investigators continued their inquiries into the case, but the head of the criminal investigations unit in the province of Lower Austria, Franz Polzer, called the DNA tests ''decisive evidence'' at a news conference. Mr. Fritzl was taken before a judge and placed in custody for at least two weeks before a mandatory review of his status.

We are especially grateful to our Dad, John Hayes, for his extraordinary support during Mom's time of need. Mom, formerly of West Babylon NY, grew up in Brooklyn and Point Lookout with siblings Eileen Bolkcom, (predeceased), Sr. Mary Cunningham, brother William Cunningham. Balla Tounkara, a player of traditional music from the West African nation Mali, came to New York several years back to spread his country's sound to the world. He had been taught as a boy by his grandfather, who lived to age 117, how to make, then play, the kora, a 21-string instrument fashioned from a giant gourd wrapped in cowhide, with a wooden neck and handles. He has recorded several CDs, teaches kora to a diverse range of young people, and plays concerts across the country.

It's easy to miss the brilliant understated comedy of Robinson's Keaton-like deadpan. I admire how only three objects float to the surface after the train wreck. One of them? "A lettuce." Paterson told the audience of schoolchildren, environmental professionals and reporters that she would carry out an initiative started by the former first lady, Silda Wall Spitzer: The drafty old governor's mansion would be outfitted with solar panels and equipped with other energy saving technology to make the place more environmentally friendly.As substantive as Mrs. Paterson's talk was, one couldn't help but notice beneath her well-polished exterior -- she was wearing leopard print high heels and matching trim on her cream-colored jacket, and a string of pearls around her neck -- a bit of nervousness was spotted.

On my train ride home one evening last week, I sat across from a woman whose young daughter was dressed all in pink. To many graying baby boomers coping with joint or muscle pain, painkillers like rofecoxib (Vioxx) and celecoxib (Celebrex) once seemed a godsend. The advent of these inhibitors of the COX-2 enzyme held the hope of pain relief with less damage to the stomach than aspirin can cause, a possibility borne out to some extent by clinical studies. Many patients found them more effective than traditional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or NSAIDs.

The personality of the man or woman whose name is on a perfume bottle is rarely captured in the personality of the liquid inside. Red Roses Cologne by Jo Malone is an exception. In person, Malone is a crisp, practical, straightforward, delightful Englishwoman, and when she was directing her perfumers in the creation of her scents - she left her eponymous house in 2006; Jo Malone Ltd. is now owned by the Estée Lauder Companies - she established an artistic olfactory style that was, at its best, equally direct and delightfully English (the latter a relative rarity quality in a business dominated by the French and the Americans).

We'll begin today with No. 120 and reveal one each day until we get to No. 1. In addition to ranking the teams, we'll provide plenty of relevant on-the-field facts as well as some fun off-the-field tidbits that you can use to impress your friends. In any case, here to kick the festivities off is No. 120.

Somehow we don't think that Andrew Stern, the president of the Service Employee International Union, is planning his next vacation amid the soulless skyscrapers and palm-shaped artificial islands of Dubai. After all, Mr. Stern's union, which represents 1.9 million workers, has been a harsh critic of the human rights record of the United Arab Emirates, of which Dubai is one. In fact, his union has highlighted connections between the emirates and firms such as Carlyle Group as part of its very public critique of the private equity business.

Yesterday afternoon I finished rereading "Housekeeping" on the subway - a real train would obviously have been more appropriate - and after I had read and gazed at the last poignant sentences I looked around the car, it was 5 p.m. and filled with commuters and young people, and wondered how many of them had or would read the book. And if so what their reaction would be to the almost utter absence of sex.

Milton Gendel, born in New York City in 1918, has his first photographic exhibit in the United States, at Verdura on Fifth Avenue. There are, perhaps, several reasons for this delayed happening. Gendel is primarily a writer; living in Rome since 1950, he has been a correspondent for Art News and a consulting editor for Art in America, as well as the editor of the "Illustrated History of Italy." Photography is essentially a pastime, in spite of producing many, many albums and a dozen or so exhibits in Europe. Gendel's friendships span the worlds of artists, writers, and aristocrats, and they are the subjects of his candid, unaffected photographs, taken over the last half century.

How much do you make? How surprised would you be to learn that your magic number had been posted on the Internet by the government? And that it was not by mistake, as in other recent breaches of privacy.

BRIEFS Northern Illinois University decided against bulldozing the building that was attacked by a gunman earlier this year after a public outcry, but Rome's new right-wing mayor is not exhibiting the same kind of attachment towards a museum designed by Richard Meier. Mayor Gianni Alemanno plans to remove the contemporary structure, which critics fault for clashing with the city's ancient beauty. [New York Times]

BRIEFS For the second time this month, Lonely Planet is addressing criticism of its guidebooks. First, it was faced with a former author's admissions about sex, drugs and tips-he-stole. Now, the company is defending a volume on Myanmar, the site a brutal crackdown last year. "I am not going to be an ad agency for Burma, but going there is doing more good than bad," Tony Wheeler, the travel publisher's founder, told the Associated Press. [Newsvine]

The Milken Institute's Global Conference in Los Angeles ended Wednesday after three days of newsmakers sweeping through the halls of the Beverly Hilton.

More decontamination and abatement workers will be reporting for duty at the ravaged former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said, after the city Department of Buildings lifted a prohibition on Wednesday that had been in force since a deadly fire in the tower last summer.

The use of a car - gas and insurance included - is one of the benefits of being a member of the House of Representatives. In a front-page story, Ray Rivera notes that 42 representatives from New York and New Jersey, at least a dozen lease cars on taxpayer money, and their choices run the gamut.Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, drives a 2008 Chevrolet Impala, leased for $219 a month. Representative Michael R. McNulty, a Democrat from the Albany area, gets around in a 2007 Mercury Mariner hybrid, a sport -utility vehicle, for $816 a month. Jim Saxton, a Republican of New Jersey, leases a 2004 Chevy TrailBlazer at $310 a month. Gregory W. Meeks, a Queens Democrat, leases a 2007 Lexus LS 460 at $998 a month. And Charles B. Rangel, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, leases a 2004 Cadillac DeVille for $777.54 a month. The car is 17 feet long with a 300-horsepower engine and seats five comfortably. "It's one of the bigger Cadillacs," Mr. Rangel, of Harlem, said cheerfully this week. "I've got a desk in it. It's like an airplane." (See related graphic.)There are few restrictions on what kind of car the members can choose, and there is no limit on how much they can spend. But the benefit can be politically sensitive, given the growing concerns about automobile emissions and an economy that has left many people struggling to pay for the rapidly rising cost of gas, which was averaging $3.63 a gallon nationwide this week.
The world's data centers are projected to surpass the airline industry as a greenhouse gas polluter by 2020, according to a new study by McKinsey & Co.

Saturday’s Kentucky Derby launches this year’s Triple Crown series, with a reputedly weak field and no credible candidate to sweep all three races. That leaves us to fall back on memory, to 30 years ago, when Affirmed became the last horse to accomplish racing’s greatest feat. He did it in breathtaking fashion, outdueling his great rival Alydar by the thinnest of margins in all three races. None of the victories was more exciting than the final leg at the Belmont Stakes, a race that, as Steve Cady reported for The Times, was “the kind of close-combat struggle that demonstrated why humans have been so fascinated by thoroughbred race horses for centuries.”.
For a system originally designed to produce a definitive winner, the Bowl Championship Series can’t win.

Paying $2,000 to $20,000 for custom-fit bikes is no longer enough for dedicated amateur cyclists. As The Times reports today, these enthusiasts are traveling hundreds or thousands of miles to find a specialty-fit shop. “Now, to fully appreciate the magnificence of their new toys, those athletes must also be able to tell of flight miles logged and far-off bicycle gurus consulted,” The Times says. “Feeding the fire is the fact that high-end bike shops like Fit Werx and Wheat Ridge are courting buyers, not just with travel discounts and refunds but with more personal touches like dinner reservations.”.

Athletes are often stricken by colds, due in part to the stress of hard training. But a recent study published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine suggests that high does of probiotics, the "good bacteria" found in yogurt and some supplements, may protect against these annoying infections.

Serena Williams will be the best-known player for the newest team in World TeamTennis, the Washington Kastles. Williams, who has won eight Grand Slam singles titles, will play in only four of the Kastles’ 14 regular-season matches and only once in Washington, against the Boston Lobsters on July 8. The Kastles will play their home matches in a 2,020-seat temporary stadium set up in a parking lot where the city’s convention center used to stand.

FRONT PAGE.

A music review on Tuesday about a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which included three works by the composer Joan Tower, misstated the name of the town where she lives and was recuperating from an injury instead of taking part in a preconcert conversation. It is Red Hook, N.Y., not Red Bank.

Schedule information on Friday with a film review of “Standard Operating Procedure,” using information from a publicist, misstated the date the film opens in Los Angeles. It is this Friday; it did not open last Friday. (That is when it opened in New York.).

An article on Friday about criticism of West Virginia University for awarding the daughter of the state’s governor a master’s degree she did not earn misattributed quotations suggesting that the university’s president “accept responsibility for errors in judgment” and inform the governor’s daughter “of the panel’s recommendation and of the decision that her degree was inappropriately granted.” The quotations were from a statement by the university’s board of governors, not from a report by an independent panel investigating the incident.

A theater review on Monday about “The Country Girl,” at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, misidentified the singer in one of the recordings played between scenes. The singer is Perry Como — not Bing Crosby, who starred in a film version of the play.

The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday, about a football scheduling dispute between Rutgers and Notre Dame, referred incorrectly to Air Force and Navy, which joined Rutgers and some private universities among the football leaders in a recent N.C.A.A. academic report. They are public institutions, not private.

An article on April 22 about the rising financial risks facing farmers misstated the length of time that certain futures contracts have been available on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn futures contracts were first listed in 1877 and soybean futures in 1936; the futures contracts were not introduced in 1959 .

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about a court ruling that dismissed the board of a Montana museum misspelled the surname of the man for whom the museum is named. As the article correctly noted, he is Charles M. Bair, not Blair.

An article on Monday about World Wrestling Entertainment’s comeback efforts misidentified the employer of Chris McCumber, who commented on the company’s cable show “W.W.E. Raw,” and a correction in this space on Wednesday misstated his title. He works for USA Network, not World Wrestling Entertainment, and he is executive vice president — not senior vice president — for marketing, digital and brand strategy.
An article on Wednesday about a genetic drug doping study in Sweden misspelled the surname of one of the researchers. He is Dr. Anders Rane, not Rhane.
A state commission is recommending a sweeping consolidation of water services, school districts and other local government agencies across New York.

The wife of a Texas Supreme Court justice was indicted for a second time on charges connected to a fire that destroyed the couple’s suburban Houston home last summer. The woman, Francisca Medina, was indicted on three charges: felony arson, felony criminal mischief and state jail felony criminal mischief. In January, Ms. Medina and her husband, Justice David Medina, were indicted on charges related to the fire. But the indictments were thrown out a day later by Charles A. Rosenthal Jr., who was the Harris County district attorney at the time.

The Food and Drug Administration said it would hire more than 1,300 biologists, chemists, medical officers and others over the next several months. The announcement comes as consumer advocates and lawmakers accuse the agency of lax oversight. The agency, which has more than 10,000 employees, plans to make the hires by October. The agency wants to fill more than 600 new positions and refill more than 700 others. A spokesman said 400 new positions would focus on drug review, while 150 others would inspect drugs, food and other items.
A board set up to review construction of the spaceship to return astronauts to the Moon is loaded with employees of the contractors it is supposed to scrutinize, a government watchdog says.
President Bush will sign legislation aimed at shoring up the $85 billion student loan industry once the House passes a version approved by the Senate, the White House said.
A bankruptcy judge approved a $37 million settlement between the Roman Catholic Diocese of Davenport and more than 160 people who say they were sexually abused by its priests.

The state police have removed three children from an apocalyptic church whose leader claims to be the Messiah and acknowledges having sex with some of his followers. The children, two girls and one boy, all younger than 18, were taken from a northeastern New Mexico compound after an April 22 investigation following accusations of inappropriate contact between minors and the adult leader of the Lord Our Righteousness Church, said Romaine Serna, spokeswoman for the State Children, Youth and Families Department. No charges have been filed, she said. The leader, Wayne Bent, 66, above, who is known in the church as Michael Travesser, established it at a rural site called Strong City, north of Clayton. He said God anointed him Messiah in 2000.

The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court approved a record number of requests to search or eavesdrop on terrorism and spying suspects last year, the Justice Department said. The court approved 2,370 warrants last year against people in the United States believed to be linked to international terror organizations. That figure is a 9 percent increase over 2006. The court denied three warrant applications in full and partly denied one, the Justice Department said.
Terrorist attacks against noncombatants more than doubled in Pakistan from 2006 to 2007, in part reflecting the growing violence in the country’s turbulent tribal areas .

The former Indy 500 winner Buddy Lazier will drive for the Hemelgarn Johnson team in a bid for his 16th start at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Lazier, who won the 1996 Indy 500 with the car owner Ron Hemelgarn, has not driven in the I.R.L. since he finished 19th at Indianapolis last year for Sam Schmidt Motorsports, his only race of the season.

The College World Series will be played in Omaha at least through 2030, under an agreement reached by the city and the N.C.A.A. A long-term contract had been in the works for months, with much of the discussion centered on the construction of a new downtown ballpark to replace 60-year-old Rosenblatt Stadium. The Division I baseball championship has been held in Omaha every year since 1950. Omaha’s strong support for the event is a point of civic pride.

Chelsea advanced to the European Champions League final for the first time, with Frank Lampard returning after the death of his mother to score the go-ahead goal Wednesday in a 3-2 overtime victory over Liverpool. Didier Drogba scored twice for the Blues, who won the home-and-home series by 4-3 on aggregate. They will meet Manchester United at Moscow on May 21 in the first all-English final in the competition’s 52-year history. Lampard, whose mother died of pneumonia at age 58 last Thursday, converted a penalty kick in the eighth minute of overtime after Michael Ballack was fouled.

The N.C.A.A. approved applications for 34 bowl games for 2008, including 32 existing bowls and two new games in Washington and St. Petersburg, Fla. It also turned down a request for a proposed Rocky Mountain Bowl in Salt Lake City. The new bowl games for next season will be the Congressional Bowl in the nation’s capital and the St. Petersburg Bowl, which will be played at Tropicana Field between Dec. 20-23 and feature teams from the Big East and Conference USA. The Big East will no longer face a Conference USA opponent in the PapaJohns.com Bowl in Birmingham, Ala. Instead, the Southeastern Conference will provide the opposition.
