The first ones lined up at 10 a.m. Monday. They brought Madonna memorabilia and warm clothes. Some had candy earrings in tribute to their heroine’s new album, “Hard Candy” (Warner Brothers), which went on sale Tuesday. They were outside the Roseland Ballroom on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and the lucky ones would get free tickets to Madonna’s promotional show there. For this event Roseland had a capacity of 2,200, which by Madonna’s standards is as intimate as a basement club. At 6 a.m. on Wednesday 750 fans received wristbands entitling them to free tickets that night. But by noon a hundred or so still had not left; they just had to be the first to walk inside. “I told my bosses I was going to take four days off,” said Juan Romani, 34, of Pawcatuck, Conn., who was near the front of the line. “When I told them what I was doing, they thought I was crazy. But it’s Madonna.”.

Mariah Carey’s new “E=MC2” (Island Def Jam), lost 61 percent of its sales in its second week out, but it’s still the No. 1 album in the country. It moved 182,000 copes, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its two-week total to 645,000. Leona Lewis’s “Spirit” (Syco/J) holds at No. 2 with 96,000, and the next three spot holders on the Billboard chart are new. The New Zealand musical-comedy duo Flight of the Conchords is No. 3 with its self-titled album on Sub Pop, which sold 52,000; Ashlee Simpson’s third record, “Bittersweet World” (Geffen), is fourth with 47,000; and the alternative hip-hop duo Atmosphere had the best sales week of its more than decade-long career, reaching No. 5 with 36,000 sales of “When Life Gives You Lemons ...” (Rhymesayers). Down the chart, the country singer Phil Vassar bowed at No. 10 with 27,000 sales of “Prayer of a Common Man” (Universal South).

The 12-day Cannes Film Festival will open on May 14 with “Blindness.” Directed by the Brazilian Fernando Meirelles (“City of God,” “The Constant Gardener”), the film stars Julianne Moore as the only sighted person in a town where everyone else is mysteriously struck blind.

In his first news conference as Rome’s newly elected mayor, Gianni Alemanno announced on Wednesday that he would tear down a museum designed by Richard Meier. Built to showcase a first century B.C. altar that honored the military triumphs of the Roman emperor Augustus, the Ara Pacis Museum, below, opened in 2006 to considerable criticism. (The New York Times’s architecture critic, Nicolai Ouroussoff, called the building a “flop” and a “major disappointment.”) Mr. Alemanno said that getting rid of the large structure “was not a top priority,” but that his administration would review all the recent architectural projects in Rome. Built mostly in glass and travertine, the museum was the first important civic building completed in central Rome since Mussolini’s time. Mr. Alemanno had promised to dismantle the imposing structure if elected.

Saturday is Free Comic Book Day, the annual industry promotion that allows visitors at participating stores to pick up a variety of comic books at no cost. The titles run from “Jughead” and “All-Star Superman” to “X-Men” and “Sonic the Hedgehog.” Dark Horse Comics is offering “Hellboy/B.P.R.D.,” which looks into the nightmares of the title hero as well as the background of the Bureau for Paranormal Research and Defense. Virgin Comics, in collaboration with the Sci Fi Channel, is giving away “The Stranded,” about aliens secretly embedded with human families. It is being developed into a pilot for the network. Information is available at freecomicbookday.com, which gives a store locater, a list of free titles and a schedule of appearances by creators. In other comic book news, the Flash, who died in 1985, is alive again. He was resurrected on Wednesday in DC Universe No. 0, a 50-cent comic, which is a primer for “Final Crisis” — the latest big story line that will affect Superman, Wonder Woman, Batman and other DC heroes.

John R. Gambling, who left WOR radio in New York in 2000, will return to the station with a morning show beginning at 5:30 on Monday, The Associated Press reported. His grandfather John B. Gambling began morning broadcasts on WOR shortly after the station went on the air in 1922, and his father, John A. Gambling, hosted the morning program until 1985, when John R. succeeded him before moving to WABC. WOR said the current morning hosts, Joe Bartlett and Donna Hanover, would remain at the station. Mr. Bartlett, as news director, will deliver the news on weekday mornings; and Ms. Hanover will serve as a film critic and substitute host. ... Randi Rhodes is rejoining the liberal radio network Air America. “Randi Rhodes Show” will be broadcast weekdays, beginning on Monday, from 3 to 6 p.m. on XM 167. Ms. Rhodes ended her employment with Air America last month after she was suspended when a video of her making disparaging remarks about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton surfaced on YouTube. In other radio news the Internet blogger and television personality Perez Hilton will deliver celebrity gossip when he joins “Miss Jones in the Morning” next week on the hip-hop radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM in New York), AllHipHop.com reported. The one-minute segments will be heard at 8.

Aliza Shvarts, the Yale University student whose senior art project created a frenzy last month has submitted a different work to the senior thesis exhibition, The Yale Daily News reported. Ms. Shvarts’s original work supposedly included documentation of repeated artificial inseminations and induced miscarriages. The university has said that it found no evidence to back up Ms. Shvarts’s story. It also would not allow her to show that work in a campus art exhibition unless she admitted that it was a fiction, which she did not do.
Avery Johnson, who guided the Dallas Mavericks to the 2006 N.B.A. finals but failed to win a playoff series since, was fired as head coach on Wednesday.

Pizza night on “Hell’s Kitchen” and the start of Neil Diamond week on “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. Nielsen estimated that 24.4 million viewers tuned in to watch the five remaining “Idol” contestants square off at 8 p.m. After “Idol,” Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” delivered 12.3 million viewers, the largest audience ever in the series’ three-year history. The cooking competition led the 9 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” in total viewers in the hour (16.7 million). Despite its edge at 9, ABC ranked third over all, struggling early in the night with two episodes of “According to Jim,” each averaging around 4 million viewers. CBS won second place, thanks to “NCIS” at 8 (14.6 million) and “Shark” at 9 (10.3 million). NBC was fourth for the night, despite leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (12.1 million), which easily outpaced both ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” on ABC (8.1 million) and a rerun of “CSI” on CBS (7.6 million).

GRANT--Robert, on April 21, 2008. Scholar, humanist and author of, ''American Ethics and the Virtuous Citizen.'' Memorial: May 3, 2008 2:00pm. Ethical Cultural Society of Westchester 7 Saxon Wood Rd, White Plains 914-948-1120.

ROTHSTEIN--Ruth, died peacefully in the company of her family on April 29. Ever the New Yorker, Ruth spent her adult life in the heart of the city. She left New York only for a move to Washington, DC in her younger years to help with the war effort and in her later years to be close to her nephews in Madison, WI. She was a woman ahead of her times. She graduated from Hunter College at the age of 19. She was well travelled and a business executive. Throughout her life, Ruth was especially loving to her nephews, Harvey Dym, Stuart Dymzarov, and Robert Sunshine. Viewing Guttermans Funeral Home, Woodbury on May 1st.

BRAUNSTEIN--Doris. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved mother, grandmother, aunt and friend. She died peacefully at home on Wednesday, April 23, in Santa Fe, NM. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 3, 3pm at McGee Memorial Chapel in Santa Fe. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Santa Fe Animal Shelter or the Wheelwright Museum.

An article on April 23 about the resurgence of coal-fired power plants referred incorrectly to the number of countries that export coal. It is in the dozens -- not hundreds -- and of those, 10 account for 94 percent of coal exports. (They are Australia, Indonesia, Russia, South Africa, China, Colombia, the United States, Canada, Kazakhstan and Vietnam, according to the International Energy Agency.)

GOODMAN--Anita (nee Friedman), on April 29th, 2008. Very beloved wife of Samuel Seymour Goodman. Devoted and beloved mother of Jeffrey Stephen Goodman. May she rest in peace -her smile will shine forever.

WATERFALL--John (Bruce). The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the passing of Bruce Waterfall, husband of fellow member and past club Governor, Susan Waterfall. We extend our sincere condolences and heartfelt sympathy to Susan, their children, Jane and John, Susan's son Scott, and Bruce's extended family. David M. Silfen, President Harvey L. Radler, Secretary WATERFALL--Bruce. We will always remember our dear friend Bruce Waterfall for his loving warmth, canny insightfulness, and his love of life. He brought wisdom, humor, and laughter into our lives which we will always cherish. His positive attitude and bravery during his illness has been an example for all of us. Family and friends will miss him dearly. Bob E., Susan, Jeffrey, Allyssa and Andrew Klein.

WHITE--McKay Payne, age 77, passed away in Fairhope, AL on Sunday, April 27, 2008. McKay retired as Senior Vice President of Compliance Data Center in 1995 as one of Wall Street's most well respected and innovative women of all time. She will be sorely missed by her children, grandchildren, greatgrandchildren and friends. Memorials in her name may be made to the Home of Grace Women's Recovery Center, 23790 US Hwy. 90, Robertsdale, AL 36567. Online condolences may be made at: hughescremationcenter.com

LEVY--Alice Rush. The many friends and family of ''Aunt'' Alice, who died peacefully on April 17 at age 95, are invited to celebrate her life on Wednesday, May 7, 3:30pm in Central Synagogue's Pavilion on 55 Street at Lex Ave, Ramp Entrance. Enthusiastic about life and its many challenges, she believed that the cup is always half full, not half empty. A woman of ideas, she believed that the fundamental fulfillment of life rests in relationships, not things. Donations in her memory may be made to F.E.G.S. Health and Human Services System, 315 Hudson Street, New York, NY 10013 or UJA/Federation of New York, 130 East 59 Street, New York, NY 10022.

WILLIAMS--Dorothy Downes of New York City, wife of the late Richard H. Williams, died in Washington, DC on April 27, 2008. She was the daughter of Olin Downes, former music critic of The New York Times, and Marion Downes. She is survived by her daughter Catharine Williams Keatley of Washington, DC, her son-in-law, Robert Keatley, her granddaughters, Heather and Eva Keatley and her step-grandson, Eric Keatley.

THE boldest of adventure-sports mavens are the most enthusiastic consumers of a new generation of helmet-mounted video cameras -- once prohibitively expensive, or clunky, or both -- because they free the wearer's hands for maneuvers like pulling a parachute cord or steering a bike or kayak out of harm's way. Thanks to recent advances in miniaturization, durability and resolution, the cameras, which can also be mounted on handlebars, are finding favor with weekend warriors who like to share their adventures online.

VALLET--Pierre (Peter) R., 85, passed away on April 24, 2008. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY he lived in Palm City, FL. A lifelong insurance executive and devoted husband of Muriel and Jackie both who preceded him in death. Peter is survived by his daughters, Maureen, Patty and Dana Lyon and grandchildren, Samantha Mandel and Cole Barris. Interment will be at Hawthorne's Gate of Heaven on May 2 at 2pm.

WARSH--Tanya, peacefully after a long and courageous battle with cancer on Tuesday, April 29, 2008 at Mt. Sinai Hospital, Toronto, Canada. Tanya Warsh, beloved wife of Marvin. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Bonnie and Michael Fuller of New York, Judy Hurowitz, Steven Hurowitz and Diane Osak, Beverley Basen, Douglas, and Robert. Dear sister and sister-in-law of Lionel and Suzanne Rubinoff, Ronald and Dorothy Rubinoff, Beverly and Marvin Zarnett, and the late Rita Ritchie. Devoted grandmother of Noah, Sofia, Leilah, Sasha, Matthew, Lisa, Samara, Julia, Jennifer, Alexandra, Matthew, and Carolyn. At Holy Blossom Temple, 1950 Bathurst Street for service on Friday, May 2, 2008 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the Tanya Warsh Memorial Fund for Research in Renal Cell Carcinoma at Sunnybrook Hospital c/o the Benjamin Foundation, 3429 Bathurst Street, Toronto, M6A 2C3, 416-780-0324, or www.benjamins.ca. To her family and friends she was devoted, inspirational, beautiful, and a pillar of strength, who will be deeply missed.

THE season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors. This year's tours include apartments crammed with antique English furniture and African art, and modern houses with steel-and-stone kitchens. There are rambling gardens on country farms and ribbon gardens down city streets. Green design and organic gardening are popular this year, and several organizations are adding podcast narration. Unless otherwise noted, tours are self-guided.

An article on Tuesday about Chinese students in the United States who have to deal with negative images of their home country misspelled the family name of a doctoral student at the University of Southern California who said the Western news media were biased against China. And a correction in this space on Wednesday gave another incorrect spelling. He is Chao Wu -- not Chou Wu or Chau Wu.

LEIGHTON--Mariana. The Gillen Brewer School community mourns the passing of our trustee, Mariana Leighton. Since 2003, Mariana served as a member of the Board of Trustees of New York City's Gillen Brewer School, which serves a wide variety of children with language, emotional, developmental, learning and health related disabilities. In addition she served as a mentor and advisor to the Head of School. At all times, Mariana recognized the need for quality education for all children. The school thrived under her guidance and unending dedication, commitment and passion for education and children. Mariana held the highest standards for educating children and was a pillar of strength in the advocacy for creating better schools. Henry Schacht, Chairman Laura Bilicic, Founder Donna Kennedy, Head of School LEIGHTON--Mariana. The Park Avenue Methodist Day School community mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Mariana Leighton. Mariana's integrity, generosity and gentle spirit will be greatly missed. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family.

ROGERS--Harry, beloved husband of Carla for 62 years, passed away peacefully April 28th. He will be sorely missed by his entire family. Interment Thursday May 1st, 1pm at the Sanctuary at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.
BRANT--Henry. Dear Henry, without you I would never have become the person or the composer that I am. Liz Swados

KELLER--Edward James. With sadness we mark the passing of Ed Keller, father of our beloved friend and author Thomas Keller, on April 28, in Yountville, CA. Ed was larger than life--a Marine Corps officer and WWII veteran, who also served in Korea and as an adviser during the Vietnam War. A raconteur, a man of great charm, and a very proud father--it was a pleasure to know him. Our love to Thomas and his family. Artisan Books and Workman Publishing

EDERSHEIM--Marc. Marc was a great friend with wisdom and humor, with an abiding faith in good quality stocks. We, his partners and colleagues at Drexel Burnham Lambert, will miss him. We extend our sympathy to Claire, his family, all the children and grandchildren.

SOLOMON--Philip, beloved husband of Sheila, beloved father of Nina and father-inlaw of John, adored grandfather of Sarah, beloved brother of Mark, cherished son of Natand Betty, died at home at age 69 on April 30, 2008. Phil was a Distinguished Professor of Astronomy at SUNY Stony Brook, and will be remembered for his groundbreaking work on interstellar matter and his ongoing atmospheric research on the ozone layer. A memorial to be announced at a later date.

McCALLUM--Serena Van derbilt Van Ingen, died on April 27, 2008 at her home in Tiburon, CA, age 55. She is survived by her daughters Consuelo Costin and Alexandra and Olivia McCallum, her eternal life partner Walter Terry, by her brother Peter Van Ingen and half brother and sisters William Van Ingen, Helen Paine Engelhardt, Harriet Love and Jacqueline Russell Williams and by her grandmother Consuelo Vanderbilt Earl and eleven beloved nieces and nephews. A professional photographer who delighted in capturing candid expressions of children and families best, her zest for life, her gratitude, her courage and great humor, remarkable especially throughout her long illness, will forever inspire her family she so cherished, and the many friends to whom she was devoted. The funeral will be at 2pm on May 10th at St. John's Episcopal Church in Ross, CA. Contributions to Ovarian Cancer California, P.O. Box 40035, Studio City, CA 91614 would be appreciated.

8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE Tom Welling, above, steps behind the camera to direct the 150th episode of this series, in which his character, Clark, learns what Earth would have been like without him. For starters Jonathan (John Schneider) would still be alive, Lex (Michael Rosenbaum) would be president, Kara (Laura Vandervoort) would have grown up in the Luthor household, Lana (Kristin Kreuk) would have tied the knot, and Chloe (Allison Mack) and Lois (Erica Durance) would be ace reporters. All of which will come to be if Brainiac (James Marsters) has his way. 7 P.M. (Sundance) SMALL FACES (1996) A 13-year-old (Iain Robertson) in 1968 Glasgow is drawn into a world of violence after he accidentally shoots a gang leader (Kevin McKidd) in the eye during a prank. Gillies MacKinnon (''Hideous Kinky'') directed and wrote, along with his brother Billy, this semi-autobiographical film.

AVLON--Alexander (Avlonitis), 76, on April 28, 2008. Business, family and cooking were his passions. Devoted to his wife, Helen, since they met in childhood. Father to Katherine, Evangeline, Alexandra, Elizabeth, Alex, Jr. and Irene. Grandfather to Christopher, Cassandra, Anthea, Daniel, Anastasia and Alexander. They meant the world to him. Private funeral. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087.

THE 2008 Kips Bay Decorator Show House, open through May 22, is a good source of inspiration, even for those on a modest budget. Although most of the designers used expensive materials and accessories, an enterprising shopper could adapt many of the looks for a reasonable price. Some decorators juxtaposed unexpected styles and materials, pairing a 1960s modern chair with a traditional ottoman, for example, or upholstering a 19th-century French armchair in African cloth. One way to adapt this idea is to combine pieces you already own but never thought of using together, or to forage through thrift shops and yard sales for items from different eras instead of shopping for new ones.

NICHOLS--Jarvis Gilbert, age 88, died April 27, 2008 in Providence, RI. Loving wife of the late John Slocum Nichols, mother of Elizabeth N. Troy, John S. Nichols, Jr., Grosvenor G. Nichols, Sarah K. Nichols, and the late Floyd G. Nichols. Grandmother of ten grandchildren. Sister of Cass Gilbert, III. Predeceased by brothers Grosvenor, Farnham and Stephen. Granddaughter of Cass Gilbert, architect. Before moving to Rhode Island, a 56 -year resident of Long Island. Member of The Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, where she won numerous tennis championships. Former member of The Colony Club, NYC. Memorial service Saturday, May 24 at 11am at St. John's Church, Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Interment to follow at The William Floyd Estate, Mastic, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Hattie Ide Chaffee Home, 200 Wampanoag Trail, E. Providence, RI 02915, or to St. John's Church.

Investors in Berkshire Hathaway had expected some disappointing news from the holding company’s chief, Warren E. Buffett. But perhaps they didn’t expect the Sage of Omaha’s investment vehicle to be so badly wounded by what he once called “financial weapons of mass destruction.”

Warren Buffett and baseball go way back. When he was 8 years old, in 1939, his grandfather took him from Omaha to Chicago to see the Cubs play the Brooklyn Dodgers. He has owned a quarter-share of the Kansas City Royals’ Pacific Coast League affiliate for 10 years. He says he has even been approached about buying the Cubs — but apparently he didn’t bite.
Few 77-year-olds could hold thousands of people in rapt attention for five hours. Sean Connery, maybe; Clint Eastwood, perhaps. Warren E. Buffett? Definitely.

One of my favorite evenings of the year is when I finally get around to opening the bottle or two of the latest vintage of chenin blanc from Paumanok Vineyards that I've managed to accumulate. In his life, the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen often stirred strong feelings with his avant-garde works. After 9/11, he stirred outrage by calling the attack on the World Trade Center "the greatest work of art that is possible in the whole cosmos." Now one of his pieces is being performed near the very scene of that catastrophe. The new-music group Bang on a Can has programmed his "Stimmung" as the culminating piece of a 12-hour marathon ending early on the morning of June 1 at the World Financial Center Winter Garden.

Investors are clearly skittish about BHP Billiton's $162 billion hostile bid for rival mining monster Rio Tinto. Rio Tinto's market value has sunk relative to BHP's in recent days, giving back much of the premium investors had originally pumped into Rio Tinto's shares. Regulatory concerns are a major issue. But a growing valuation gap may also be working against this deal, which, if completed, would rank among the largest takeovers in history.

Gov. David A. Paterson shed some new light this morning on why he disclosed his marital infidelity only a day after he took over for a governor who resigned amid his own sex scandal. During an interview on the sports radio station WFAN-AM (660), the governor said that as he was preparing to replace Eliot Spitzer, he was already aware that many rumors were circulating about his personal life. Knowing some of those rumors to be untrue, Mr. Paterson said he decided he wanted to get out ahead of the story as quickly as possible.

I'm back in court today. The process of actually selecting a jury is pretty arcane. Every once in a while in Room 452 at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, a clerk put the names of the entire pool in a wheel and spins it around, then chooses 40 randomly. I was among the ones called late Thursday morning, my second day of jury duty.We marched downstairs. The judge went over some of the basics of the case: the names of the defendant and plaintiffs, the witnesses to be called in case any of us knew any of them. Eight of the 40 raised their hands to claim some sort of conflict. After meeting one by one with the lawyers and the judge in the judge's chambers, all eight were dismissed while the rest of us wondered why.

If you are in Madrid this weekend you will certainly become familiar with a defining event in Spanish history, that -- if you live outside of Spain -- you've probably overlooked before: the 1808 popular Spanish uprising against Napoleon Bonaparte's occupying forces. On May 2 that year, the people of Madrid rebelled against the French, sparking fighting in which hundreds of people were killed. The next day, in a harsh backlash against the revolt, the French forces executed hundreds of suspected Spanish rebels.
“The Favor,” a dreary, interminable drama written and directed by Eva Aridjis, is exactly one-third of a good movie.
The moody, surreal “XXY” explores the world of Alex, an intersex teenager navigating the treacherous emotional and hormonal rapids of uncertain gender.
“Viva” is a startlingly pitch-perfect reproduction of the kind of gauzy sex movies from the 1960s and early 1970s that preceded the hard-core revolution.
“As Tears Go By,” Wong Kar-wai’s first feature film, heralds a new vision not yet in perfect focus.
“Son of Rambow” is a likable, lightly sticky valentine to childhood, the 1980s and the dawning of movie love.
“Mister Lonely” is enigmatic, its moods and meanings sometimes elusive, but nearly every frame is an image of arresting clarity and beauty.
“Iron Man” is an unusually good superhero picture. Or at least — since it certainly has its problems — a superhero movie that’s good in unusual ways.
The romantic comedy “Made of Honor” adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush.
For a tale spiked with so much torment, “Fugitive Pieces” feels remarkably soothing.
A welcome entry in the constituency-cinema canon, “Hollywood Chinese” surveys a century’s worth of Chinese-American entertainers.
“Redbelt” is a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B-movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy.

The former Olympic star Tim Montgomery has been indicted on heroin distribution charges weeks before he is to be sentenced in a scheme to cash millions of dollars in stolen or forged checks. Montgomery, 33, once dubbed the fasted human on Earth, was arrested Wednesday, accused of dealing more than 100 grams of heroin in Virginia over the past year. Montgomery’s former companion, the Olympic goal medalist Marion Jones, currently is serving a six-month prison term for lying to investigators about her role in the check scam and using performance-enhancing drugs.

Marion Jones’s former relay teammates have appealed a decision by the International Olympic Committee to strip them of their gold medals with the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland, their lawyer, Mark Levinstein, said. The International Olympic Committee ruled in April that the teammates who won gold in the 4x400 meter and bronze in the 4x100 meter for the United States at the 2000 Sydney Games were disqualified because Jones admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs during that period.

A nonprofit group that handed out the Butkus Award to the nation’s top linebacker will stop presenting it after a yearlong legal battle with Dick Butkus. He sued in Los Angeles federal court in 2007, demanding the Downtown Athletic Club of Orlando relinquish control of the award, which it had given out for 23 years and trademarked in 1987. He said the club did not raise enough money for charity and in April won a summary judgment. Butkus’s family will begin presenting the award in January in Chicago, where he grew up and played eight Pro Bowl seasons for the Bears.

Experts debate how, and even whether, male infertility should be treated.

1. Get a full evaluation by a urologist, said Tracy L. Rankin, program director of male reproductive health at the National Institutes of Health. Most fertility centers request a semen analysis to identify men with low sperm count and other sperm problems. A urologist can screen for cancer, since the risk of testicular cancer is up to 30 times higher in men with severely low sperm counts.

MORROW--Robert P., Jr., 87, died April 27, after a short illness. He lived in Buffalo and Holloway Bay, Ontario. Surviving are his four children: R. Peter, III (Suzanne) of Buffalo, David G. Morrow (Sue Anne) of Lawrenceville, NJ, Rebecca O. Morrow of NYC, and Daniel J. Morrow (Victoria Saxon) of Buffalo. His wife of 48 years, the former Mary Galvin, died in 1992. He is also survived by ten grandchildren: Robert P., IV and Harry; Jacob, Samuel and Ruth; Connor and Graham Puleo; and Jean, John and Anne Morrow. He founded R. P. Morrow Associates, P.C., the oldest consulting engineering firm in Buffalo. A graduate of Canisius High School and Cornell University, he served in the U.S. Navy during WWII in the South Pacific. He was one of the first American officers to visit Nagasaki after the Japanese surrender. At the age of 40 he learned to fly. He was a certified commercial, multiengine and glider pilot and flight instructor. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 10:00am in St. Mark's Church, Buffalo, NY on Saturday, May 3. A viewing is planned for Friday, May 2, from 4:00pm to 8:00pm at the Amigone Funeral Home, Delaware Avenue near North Street. Burial will be in Forest Lawn Cemetery.

WATERFALL--Bruce. We are only a few that will mourn the loss of Bruce. There was always a smile on his face, a twinkle in his eye and a kind word for all. Our deepest sympathy to Susan, Jane, John, Scott and Sara. Lyn Silfen Carol Lederman Paula Gleacher Janice Bayer WATERFALL--John (Bruce). Bruce loved life and appreciated the solitude and beauty of Nature as a source of personal fulfillment. His devotion and love of his family was mirrored in their love for him. Andrew and Dorothy, Zoe, Jo Beth, and Tanner

HAIMSON--Joann, 85, died April 29 at her home in Manhattan. She is survived by her children, Maud, Leonie, and Joshua, her grandchildren, Chloe, Nathaniel, Jeremy, Anna, William and Daniel, and by her former husband, Leopold Haimson. She was predeceased by her partner of 34 years, Sydney Morgenbesser. Joann graduated from the Dalton School and Bennington College. She was a brilliant artist, unsurpassed mother and grandmother, and wonderful friend. After college, she directed theater, including at the Provincetown Playhouse. Her creativity subsequently expressed itself in many other media: poetry, painting, collage, and photography. Perceptive and unconventional in her outlook, she was acutely engaged, both personally and politically, and ceaselessly empathetic. All who knew her will deeply miss the generous magic of her conversation and company. Any donations should go to help endow the Morgenbesser Chair of Philosophy, c/o Philosophy Dept., 1150 Amsterdam Ave., Columbia University, NYC 10027.
VAN THIEL--Albertine, on April 30th at age 96, she died peacefully at home. A fiercely independent lady, she lived her life to the fullest and will be lovingly remembered by those who knew her.

'PRINCESS PHOOEY' Few would argue that middle school is like a fairy tale. But at least one fairy tale is like middle school. That's ''Princess Phooey,'' a world premiere musical from Tada! Youth Theater, which portrays the royalty of imaginary kingdoms as close kin to the queen bees of real eighth grade. Lisa Diana Shapiro, who wrote the book and lyrics, has centered her plot on the recently awakened Sleeping Beauty -- here Princess Elessia -- and her little sister, Ermengarde (the Phooey of the title). But Elessia (Jasmine Perez, above center, with Mary Claire Miskell and Christopher Broughton) is nothing like Disney's pure-hearted Aurora (she's an insufferable snob), and the three beneficent fairies are essentially simpering mean girls brandishing wands instead of cellphones. As for poor Ermengarde (Ms. Miskell and Katie Lerner Lee alternate in the role), she's not princess material. A rebel who climbs trees and plays with the servants, she says phooey to pink frills and handsome princes like the one played by Mr. Broughton.

RAPPAPORT--Dr. Alfred, beloved husband of Patricia, beloved father of Paul and Jennifer, loved father-in-law of Susan and Peter, adored grandfather of Jake, Riley, and Sophia, died at age 80 on April 30th, 2008. Dr. Rappaport was an optometrist who practiced and pioneered visual training for children, and made significant differences in the lives of his patients. He was active in many educational organizations, and served as President of the Nassau County Optometric Association. He was also an Associate Clinical Professor of Visual Training at the SUNY College of Optometry. All who had the privilege of knowing him were touched and enriched by his graciousness and warmth. He was deeply admired for his intelligence, sense of humor, story telling, and charm. He was a true gentleman. He will be sorely missed and never forgotten by family, friends, patients, and his beloved dogs.

The 1964 Gallery of Modern Art at 2 Columbus Circle is being transformed into a new space for the Museum of Arts and Design. Almost everything about the building has changed, but the original ''lollipop'' columns persist. New York may not be able yet to place the name, but the lollipops will certainly be familiar. So will the shape and the pale color of Edward Durell Stone's Gallery of Modern Art, built at 2 Columbus Circle in 1964 to house Huntington Hartford's art collection. Almost everything else has changed, however, with the transformation of the building into the Museum of Arts and Design (formerly known as the American Craft Museum), designed by Brad Cloepfil of Allied Works Architecture. Stone's design, initially disparaged, gained admirers in recent years, including Tom Wolfe; the architectural historians Vincent Scully and Robert A. M. Stern; and Herbert Muschamp, former architecture critic of The New York Times. Their pleas could not move the Landmarks Preservation Commission to hold a hearing on whether to designate the building. So the transformation went ahead. Though the museum is four months from opening, the new facade has now emerged from its construction cocoon. Some viewers discern the word ''HE'' in the facade. It is the inadvertent result of a late design revision calling for a band of glass where a restaurant will be. That created a crossbar, making an H. Once one sees it as a letter form, it is hard to ignore.

GRAFFITI SEASON Technically there's probably not a ''season'' for graffiti. But springtime is close enough. ''You definitely see more names start to show up on the wall once it starts to warm up,'' said Evan Roth, a tagging connoisseur and a founder of Graffiti Research Lab. His group takes a more high-tech approach than popping open a can of spray paint: in one recent project it used lasers to tag structures, including the Brooklyn Bridge, above, remotely (and erase-ably). Other works include projectile LEDs and mobile street furniture; all are documented on its Web site, graffitiresearchlab.com, so others can copy its ideas. ''We fit into the open source credence of belief,'' Mr. Roth said. ''We're trying to come up with methods that are cheaper and easier for nonnerds to create.'' On Sunday, at the PopRally series at the Museum of Modern Art, the group will screen its first film, documenting its creation. Mr. Roth, a former Web designer and architect, started it with James Powderly, a robotics engineer, in 2005, when both were fellows at the Eyebeam Institute. Several of the artists featured will speak afterward, and the band Javelin will play at the after-party. There will be a slew of street art-related happenings in the coming weeks too.

'STRETCH (A FANTASIA)' It was a most implausible explanation. Rose Mary Woods, President Richard M. Nixon's secretary, made the cover of Time magazine in 1973 after claiming that she had inadvertently pressed the wrong button on a tape recorder and then simultaneously kept her foot on a pedal control for the device while making an impossibly long stretch across her desk to answer a telephone. This gymnastic accident, she said, caused her to erase part of a tape famous for having an 18 1/2-minute gap: a crucial conversation between her boss and his chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman. In the June 20, 1972, conversation, the men were thought to have discussed the Watergate break-in, which occurred three days earlier, so theirs was a chat that the special counsel was eager to hear. Ms. Woods faded from the national scene. In 2005 she died at 87, in an Ohio nursing home, just after President Bush took office for a second term in the wake of accusations of voting irregularities, especially in Ohio. In ''Stretch (A Fantasia),'' her new political comic drama, Susan Bernfield has imagined Ms. Woods, played by Kristin Griffith, above, observing the 2004 presidential election, meshing past and present from the hazy viewpoint of an old woman who epitomized loyal servitude. ''I sort of feel like the point of the play is that politics goes in cycles,'' Ms. Bernfield said in a telephone interview.

BRADY--Mary Filardi, died on April 29, 2008 after a short illness, having survived her late husband, John F. Brady, former Executive Director of the Industrial Home for the Blind. Mary, known to many of her friends as Mickey, is survived by her four devoted children and their spouses and partners. They are her daughters: Roseanne Saalfield and her husband, Jim Saalfield; Peggy Brady and her partner, Deb Winsor; Patricia Corbett and her husband, John Corbett, and her son, John Brady and his wife, Alyce Brady. Also surviving are her eight beloved grandchildren, Peter, Meaghan, Jonathan, Sam, Ian, Lauren, Clara and Jack. Mary will be remembered as a proud women of strong opinions, which she did not hesitate to share with a quick wit and sometimes sharp tongue. She mothered many, not just her children and grandchildren, with a heartfelt warmth and generosity. She will be missed by all of us who know we were lucky to have shared our lives with her. A memorial reception will be held on May 31st from 2-4:00pm at the home of her daughter, Patricia Corbett, 124 Furhman Ave. Ramsey, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to The Maple Street School Scholarship Fund, 21 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, New York 11225, supporting early childhood education or The Town of Harvard Public Library, Massachusetts Avenue, Harvard MA 01451 where a crossword puzzle corner was dedicated in her honor.

LEE CHANG-DONG, A RETROSPECTIVE Compared with his South Korean colleagues Park Chanwook (''Oldboy'') and Hong Sang-soo (''Woman on the Beach''), the director Lee Chang-dong seems like an invisible man; he scrupulously keeps himself out of his own movies, declining formalist flourishes in favor of a deceptively simple, observational style. In ''Secret Sunshine'' (2007), his best film to date, Mr. Lee takes his time, drawing out the sociological and psychological details embedded in his story of a young widow, Shin-ae (Jeon Do-yeon, above), who, with her young son in tow, has moved to the provincial hometown of her late husband. The residents of the town, Miryang (which translates to ''secret sunshine''), are cold and suspicious, and the only real attention she manages to attract comes from an unwelcome source: Jong-chan, a tubby, good-hearted auto mechanic (the immensely likable Song Kang-ho, of ''The Host'') ,who sees in her his last chance for marriage. But then something transcendently awful happens, which Mr. Lee records with no more emphasis than he gives to the petty annoyances and disappointments that otherwise define Shin-ae's life, and the film's subject snaps into focus: the arbitrariness of suffering, the indifference of the universe.

8 P.M. (ABC) 20/20: SECRETS OF THE SISTINE: MICHELANGELO'S MYSTERY Move over, Leonardo. New reports say that Michelangelo may have inserted coded messages into figures in his frescoes on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in Rome, painted between 1508 and 1512. Martin Bashir, above, interviews Benjamin Blech and Roy Doliner, the authors of ''The Sistine Secrets: Michelangelo's Forbidden Messages in the Heart of the Vatican,'' about their theory. 6 P.M. (Sundance) CHARGING THE RHINO (2007) The Sundance Channel marks Holocaust Remembrance Day with three documentaries, starting with Simcha Jacobovici's exploration of his Romanian family's history, including that of his father, who was rounded up with relatives in 1941 for a mass execution but survived with a bullet lodged near his heart. The evening continues at 7 with ''Multiply by Six Million: Portraits and Stories of Holocaust Survivors,'' and at 7:30 with ''As Seen Through These Eyes,'' in which Hilary Helstein presents the experiences of artists in concentration camps, and Maya Angelou narrates.

ASHLEY--Harmon, August 22, 1920-January 26, 2008. A graduate of Princeton University Class of 1941. Served as officer in U.S. Navy 1942-46. Upon graduation from Columbia Law School 1950 Ashley was retained as Legal Researcher to Sidney Schreiber Esq. and Jack Valenti respectively General Counsel and President of Motion Picture Association of America. He also assisted attorneys across the U.S. in their representation of motion picture companies. In addition to his legal scholarship, Ashley devoted himself to the study of history, language, literature and religion. He was widely respected for his learning, prodigious memory and use of language. Both colleagues and personal friends will also remember him for his limitless generosity and his ever present humor. David Fallick Jane Goldman Georgiana Morrison Gerald Phillips Eliza and Enes Radoncic Bernard Sorkin

FATZER--Ninon Ballantyne Towns, 84, of New York City, died April 28, 2008 after a courageous battle with both Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Diseases. Born in New York City in 1923 to Day Masset Ballantyne and Joseph Earl Ballantyne, she soon moved with her family to Scarsdale, NY. She excelled in high school and was elected valedictorian of her graduating class. She attended Barnard College, then met and married Edward Ros Towns of New York City and had her loving daughter Victoria Towns. Ninon went on to a shining career in the fashion industry, eventually landing at Milliken as their Eastern Regional Director and Vice President. She left Milliken to work as Administrative Assistant to the President of Standard & Poors, where she stayed happily until age 71. In the meantime she met and married the love of her life, Jean-Pierre Fatzer. She also built upon the antique fan collection she had inherited from her mother, and become so knowledgeable about the subject of antique and vintage fans that she was eventually elected President of FANA, the international association of fan collectors. She is survived by her loving daughter Victoria Towns, her loving son-in-law Alan Kupferberg and her very loving grandson Joel Kupferberg. Memorial services will be held at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Thursday May 8, 2008 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America and/or The Parkinson's Disease Foundation in her name would be appreciated.

TILLY--Charles. One of the world's preeminent sociologists and historians, University Distinguished Professor and Director of the Center for Studies of Social Change at The New School for Social Research between 1984 and 1996, one of the founders in 1984 and the intellectual leader for twelve memorable years of the Committee on Historical Studies at The New School, member of the editorial advisory board of Social Research, Charles Tilly was a towering presence in every academic institution he was affiliated with throughout his long and distinguished career. His scholarship was unsurpassed, his humanity of the highest order, his spirit unwavering. He will be deeply missed by his New School colleagues and former students. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Philip Scaturro, Chair, Board of Trustees Michael Schober, Dean, The New School for Social Research

RACHID OURAMDANE This week the Zimbabwean-born choreographer Nora Chipaumire is at Dance Theater Workshop, presenting a memoir of survival during war in her solo ''Chimurenga.'' Next is ''Far ...,'' a solo by the French choreographer Rachid Ouramdane, above. He will trace his own history of identity and war, drawing on the diary his Algerian father kept while serving in the French Army during the occupation of Algeria, and later in Vietnam, in the years leading up to the war there. The terrain is similar, at least in outline. But Mr. Ouramdane is a conceptual creature, heady and cool and far removed from the earthy heat that Ms. Chipaumire inevitably brings to the stage; it should prove a fascinating contrast of ways and means.

WAYNE THIEBAUD: 'THE FIGURE' In the 1960s Wayne Thiebaud reanimated the traditional still life. His thickly painted pictures of pies, cakes and other food products in cafeteria-style order had terrific visual snap, and they subtly satirized the mechanization of modern life. Mr. Thiebaud did something similar with figure painting, as this excellent show of paintings and drawings dating from 1963 to 1992 demonstrates. The drawings are mostly in pencil, and most are coolly libidinous studies of nude female models. A few portray clothed men sitting on chairs, like ''Man Reading,'' right. All are compelling for their skillful draftsmanship and their detached yet affectionate attentiveness.

My Sunday column is about the remaining 270 prisoners at Guantanamo, which is a national disgrace. One reason is simply the injustice of keeping innocent people in abusive conditions -- a far harsher regime than that faced by convicted murderers in the United States. The inmates at Guantanamo haven't had visits or phone calls with family members for more than six years of confinement, and the authorities constantly play games with them. For example, one of those I mention in the column is al-Ghizzawi, a Libyan who is suffering from extreme health problems. The authorities boasted of giving him glasses. But, according to his lawyer, the glasses are distance glasses, when he is in confined to a tiny cell. What he desperately wants is reading glasses.

Eight Belles ran a terrific race to finish second to Big Brown. She beat the third horse, Denis of Cork, handily. She encountered traffic trouble but nothing got in her way. Galloping out she went down quickly. It was over. Two fractured ankles, likely one fractured and the other followed with a shift in weight. Speculation. But the reality is, we lost a terrific horse doing what we wanted her to do, run in the biggest race of the year.

The equation for Mets success is as simple as this: Jose Reyes hits = Mets win. Doesn't take Einstein to figure that out, but we all saw during last night's 7-2 victory against the Diamondbacks how scary this team looks when Reyes is wreaking havoc at the top of the order. Four hits, including two triples, three runs, a stolen base. Reyes has had nine multihit games this season. Care to guess how many of them the Mets have won? I'll make it easy for you: eight. That's a pretty good ratio.

Leo, who had five children from a previous marriage and loved horses, had the idea of going to Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky., an easy drive from their home in Cincinnati, for the spring meet. Sadie, who had three children, was hesitant.

To hear critics tell it, proposals from John McCain and Hillary Clinton to declare a federal "tax holiday" on gasoline and diesel fuel during the summer driving season will, simultaneously, bring no relief to consumers while bringing doomsday to government. A gas tax holiday is not a fantastic idea, but it doesn't deserve such controversy either.

Senators John McCain and Hillary Clinton both propose to suspend the 18.4-cents-per-gallon federal excise tax on gasoline between Memorial Day and Labor Day this year. For a moment, forget about whether encouraging fossil fuel burning makes sense during a time of global warming, whether we should raid the highway trust fund when bridges are collapsing for lack of maintenance, or the disconnect between the proposal to cut gasoline taxes and all three candidates' endorsement of "cap-and-trade" pollution limits that would raise gasoline prices.

Senator John McCain described it as "a cultural and pharmaceutical event." He was not there, of course; as he pointed out in a Republican debate last October in Florida, he was "tied up at the time," a sly reference to his time as prisoner of war in North Vietnam.

There's a new report out from the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation on broadband. It confirms the fact that the United States is lagging in broadband adoption, both in overall penetration and in other aspects including speed and price. Part, but only part, of this may be due to bad policy -- basically, the United States failed to enforce effective competition.

A listing of medications on April 22 with the Personal Health column about hypertension misstated the chemical in the blood whose production is affected by the medications known as ACE inhibitors and ARBs. It is angiotensin II, not acetylcholine esterase.

An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about higher retail rents on the Lower East Side of Manhattan gave an incorrect name for one of the new hotels that is helping to improve the neighborhood’s image. An 18-story hotel where rooms will start at $375 a night is to be called Thompson LES, not the Allen Hotel. The article also misstated the name for retail space at Avalon Bowery Place. It is Extra Place, not Exit Place.

A theater review on Friday about a revival of “Les Liaisons Dangereuses” by Christopher Hampton, at the American Airlines Theater, misstated the year that the play, Mr. Hampton’s adaptation of the novel of the same title, was first produced. It was 1985, not 1986.

An article on Page 3 of the Travel section this weekend about lighthouses on Croatian islands that take guests gives an outdated name for the home country of some visitors to one lighthouse. It is the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia.
Because of a transcription error, a film review on Friday about “Redbelt” referred incorrectly to the character Sondra, played by Alice Braga. She is mouthy, not mousy.

A chart with an article on Wednesday about legislation to overhaul federal patent laws omitted a unit of measurement. The figures for the number of patent applications for the last 20 years were in thousands. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/business.

Reggie Bush will testify June 23 about whether he took cash and gifts while attending Southern California on an athletic scholarship, a San Diego Superior Court judge ruled. Bush, a running back for the New Orleans Saints, is being sued by Lloyd Lake, who says he lent Bush and his family nearly $300,000 in a business deal that fell apart. Bush has denied the charges. The judge, Joan B. Lewis, set the trial for March 13, 2009.

Indianapolis receiver Marvin Harrison was interviewed by the police about a shooting near his North Philadelphia bar on Tuesday. Lt. Frank Vanore said the investigation was continuing. Harrison has not been arrested or charged.

Bob Huggins, the West Virginia men’s basketball coach, signed an 11-year contract that will keep him at his alma mater until he is 65. The deal will pay him $1.5 million a year, plus incentives. He was paid $800,000 last season, his first with the team.

A measles outbreak in Tucson has led Pima County to declare a state of public health emergency and begin setting up free immunization clinics in an effort to contain the illness, one rarely seen in the United States. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Walker Art Center mourn the passing of their Honorary Trustee and former President and Chairman of the Board, whose intelligent care, enormous commitment, and unwavering passion for the Walker touched all of us. ROGERS--Barbara M. It is with deep regret that the Manhattanville community announces the passing of Barbara M. Rogers, Class of 1945. The recipient of the Manhattanville Distinguished Alumni Award in 1990, she is the past President of the Manhattanville Alumni Association. She is the mother of seven children, three of whom, Sally Rogers 1972, Barbara Rogers 1974, and Nancy Rogers 1978 graduated from Manhattanville. Sally and Barbara (RSCJ) currently serve on the school's Board of Trustees. Richard A. Berman, President and the Board of Trustees of Manhattanville College

TIDMARSH--Patricia (Patty) Carman, 81, died on Thursday, April 3, 2008 at 11pm at Kateri Residence in New York City. She was born on September 2, 1926 at Portland, Oregon to Patrick and Helen (Carman) Tidmarsh. When she was about 18 months old the family relocated to Tucson, Arizona so her father could help his brother manage the Tidmarsh Engineering Co., the family business. She attended Tucson Senior High, then later the former Anna Head High School at Berkeley, CA, now the Head-Royce High School at Oakland, CA. and graduated with the class of 1944. She then attended Smith College at Northampton, MA. She studied for one year in Mexico City and graduated in 1948 with a major in Latin. In 1948 Patty moved to New York City. She taught in the New York public school system for many years, but eventually got a job at the ABC News Payroll Dept. where she worked for 15 years. She retired in 1997. Patty had many interests including genealogy, astronomy, theology, and history. Patty will always be remembered as a very bright, kind, generous individual to her family and friends. She will most mostly be remembered for her keen, droll sense of humor. Surviving Patty are her brother Peter A. Tidmarsh of Moraga, CA.; her two nephews: Matthew A. Tidmarsh of Walnut Creek, CA, and Patrick G. Tidmarsh of Moraga, California; her niece and nephew-in-law: John R. and Elizabeth A. (Tidmarsh) Conely of Lafayette, California; one grandniece: Stephanie C. Duarte of Walnut Creek, CA.; two grandnephews: Matthew and Michael Conely of Lafayette, CA. A memorial service for Patty will be held on Friday, May 9th at 11am at Christ and St. Stephens Episcopal Church, 120 West 69th St., New York, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to: Smith College, c/o Donor Services, 33 Elm St., Northampton, MA, 01063; or to: Head-Royce School, c/o Betsy Ringrose, 4315 Lincoln Ave., Oakland, CA, 94602. Memorial contributions will be placed in the Anna Head Memorial Scholarship Fund.

HELMS--Bill. Loving husband of Carol, father of Cherie and Erica, father-in-law of Ken Perkins and Andrew Krause, stepson of Kate, died at home in Manhattan on May 2, age 81. A professional photographer, Bill began his career during WWII aboard the USS Yorktown, where he specialized in flight deck combat photography. For his work during WWII, he received a U.S. Navy Photographic Institute citation issued by Edward Steichen. A graduate of Art Center College of Design, he was considered a leader in food, interior design and travel photography. His editorial work was featured in ''House & Garden'', ''House Beautiful, Metropolitan Home'', ''Better Homes & Gardens'', the ''New York Times Entertaining'' magazines, ''Los Angeles Magazine'' and ''Los Angeles Times'' special sections. His book credits include Time Life's ''Foods of the World'' series and Metropolitan Home's ''The New American Cuisine''. In recent years, Bill was passionate about fine art digital photography. A memorial celebration will be announced at a later date. Donations in Bill's name may be made to Art Center College of Design, 1700 Lida Street, Pasadena, CA 91103, Attn: Amy Swain.

(Hallmark) THE SHELL SEEKERS (2006) Vanessa Redgrave, above, plays Penelope Keeling, the 64-year-old daughter of a famous artist (Maximilian Schell), who decides to reassess her life, in this adaptation of the Rosamunde Pilcher novel. ''The Shell Seekers'' is also a painting by her father whose fate is of great interest to her children, Olivia (Victoria Smurfit), Noel (Charles Edwards) and Nancy (Victoria Hamilton). The action moves from the English countryside to Ibiza to the Cornish coast, and back and forth between World War II and the present day (which in this case is 1982). 8 P.M. (ABC) THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE LION, THE WITCH AND THE WARDROBE (2005) In Andrew Adamson's adaptation of the C. S. Lewis novel, a group of children find themselves transported from World War II England to mystical Narnia, where they join the noble lion Aslan (the voice of Liam Neeson) to free the land from the clutches of an evil white witch (Tilda Swinton).

Thousands of mainland Chinese and Hong Kong residents cheered the Olympic torch through the streets on Friday during the largely peaceful first leg of its three-month trip through greater China. A small crowd jeered, threw eggs and physically blocked a march by about 20 activists who tried to follow the torch relay while calling for human rights and democracy in China. A college student from Hong Kong who tried to wrap herself in a Tibetan flag, in protest of the recent Chinese crackdown on unrest in Tibet, entered an argument with a defender of China, and both were bundled away by the police, who did not file charges.

This primary season campaign souvenirs are cropping up like kudzu. Retail stores on each of the candidates' official Web sites offer copious merchandise from lapel pins and mousepads to hoodies and onesies alongside the requisite buttons and bumper stickers. Given the ease with which a logo or slogan can be stamped on any product, the sheer quantity of retail campaign stuff is possibly greater than at any other time in history, albeit a lot less campy than during other elections.

Six years ago my wife and I traded in two cars for two new-used ones. Twice in a few weeks, one of us drove an old car up a ramp to the cavernous second floor of the dealership and just left it there. Well, not quite, for later we reported to each other the same experience. Each of us walked away, but then looked back, realizing that this familiar friend would be gone from our lives forever and, more poignantly, that we were abandoning a faithful, if increasingly troublesome, retainer.

One thought that I could not get into today's article: I'd say that, by this point, Nelson Figueroa has supplanted Mike Pelfrey as the Mets' No. 4 starter. Right now, Pelfrey's spot in the rotation is safe as long as Orlando Hernandez and Pedro Martinez are non-entities and Claudio Vargas is gaining arm strength at Class AAA New Orleans. But Willie Randolph loves Figueroa's rubber arm, and if Pelfrey continues to struggle in his next few starts, the Mets may have to start exploring internal options. I could also see a situation in which Figueroa moves to the bullpen as the long man, replacing Jorge Sosa (who has options), but that's a little further down the road.

Welcome to our coverage of the 134th Kentucky Derby. We'll be getting updates from Joe Drape and our other contributors throughout the day. I'll be "live" blogging the entire spectacle. I use live lightly because I am not in Louisville. Instead, I am at the Times's headquarters in New York. But I will be here with you until we have a winner. So while I wish I was sipping a mint julep underneath a wide-brimmed hat at Churchill Downs, I'm happy to be here with you. Send in some questions. Add your comments.

Top-ranked Penn State won its first N.C.A.A. men’s volleyball championship in 14 years, rallying for a 27-30, 33-31, 30-25, 30-23 victory over second-ranked Pepperdine in Irvine, Calif. Matt Anderson had 29 kills for the Nittany Lions (30-1), who beat U.C.L.A. in 1994 for their last title.

Paula Creamer made two long birdie putts to pull away from the field at the SemGroup Championship in Broken Arrow, Okla., only to drop two shots on the closing holes for the third straight day to give her challengers a chance. A three-putt on the 16th and a bogey from the bunker on the 18th gave Creamer a two-under-par 69, good enough for a two-shot lead over Juli Inkster.

First-place Manchester United played with 10 men for most of the game and beat West Ham, 4-1, behind two goals from Cristiano Ronaldo. The victory put further pressure on second-place Chelsea in the Premier League race. United has 84 points and is 3 ahead with a game left. Chelsea, United’s only rival for the title, has a game in hand and plays Newcastle on Monday.

Larisa Ilchenko of Russia successfully defended her title at the 10-kilometer open-water world championship in Seville, Spain, and qualified for the Beijing Olympics. Ilchenko swam the four loops of the Guadalquivir River course in 2 hours 2 minutes 2.7 seconds. The event is making its debut at Beijing.
Bengie Molina singled in the go-ahead run in the 10th inning to lift the visiting San Francisco Giants to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies on Saturday night.

Giro d’Italia organizers have invited the Astana team to compete in the race, reversing an earlier decision to ban it because of doping scandals. Astana officials confirmed they are hurrying to get the elite American rider Levi Leipheimer from California to Palermo, Sicily, for the start of the three-week race on Saturday. The team had been shunned by cycling’s biggest events this year for involvement in doping scandals. Astana’s rebuilding work was rewarded late Friday, when Giro organizer RCS Sport offered the team a place.
Ignacio Garrido of Spain shot a par 72 to take a three-stroke lead into the final round of the Spanish Open. Garrido led Miguel Ángel Jiménez (67) with a 15-under total of 201.

Top-seeded Vera Zvonareva reached her fourth final of the year by defeating Katarina Srebotnik, 6-2, 6-4, in the Prague Open. Zvonareva will face third-seeded Victoria Azarenka on Sunday. Azarenka defeated Klara Zakopalova, 6-3, 6-2.

Fernandez González of Chile reached the BMW Open final in Munich with a 3-6, 6-4, 6-3 victory that ended the run of Younes el-Aynaoui, the oldest semifinalist on the ATP Tour since Jimmy Connors 15 years ago.

Julio Franco, the oldest player to hit a home run in the majors, has announced his retirement from baseball after a 23-year career in the major leagues and stints in his native Dominican Republic, Korea, Japan and Mexico. “It was the hardest decision in my life,” Franco said in an interview published Saturday by the Mexican sports daily Record.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the perks and powers enjoyed by the majority party in the New York Senate referred incorrectly to the rules regarding constituent newsletters distributed by Senate Democrats, who are in the minority. The Democrats are allowed to use one color in addition to black and white; they are not limited to black and white alone. (Republicans are allowed to use multiple colors.).

A brief item on April 13 about developments in homeland security gave a misleading figure for the number of Americans who subscribe to a mobile phone service. The number of subscribers was recently estimated by M:Metrics, a research firm, at about 226 million, not more than 255 million. The higher figure is used by the International Association for the Wireless Telecommunications Industry to estimate the number of subscriptions. A subscriber can have more than one subscription.

Just one word: plastics. The Japanese industrial-design star Tokujin Yoshioka was born in 1967, the year “The Graduate” had its premiere. The movie must have been an omen for him. After working with Shiro Kuramata and Issey Miyake, Yoshioka became strongly influenced by structure, transparency and the use of synthetics. His origami-like Honey-Pop chair from 2001, made for the Italian company Driade, is composed of 120 sheets of glassine paper that are compressed, cut and then spread open. His 2006 limited-edition Pane chair is made of polyester fibers baked like Italian bread. This month, the Museum of Modern Art Design Store is presenting “Destination: Japan,” a retail exhibition that includes home accessories. Slit Bag (above), a woven vinyl bag that has the illusion of depth even when flat, was originally designed by Yoshioka for the cover of a monograph of his work, which was published by Phaidon. MoMA decided it would be the perfect tote for the design-obsessed shopper — and, at $33, a bargain. MELISSA FELDMAN.

Design Research was having a sale. It was 1978 or so. “Buy this,” my sister said. “It is a must.” So I listened to my sister, and have not been without one (or a number) ever since. If it chips or breaks (not easily), you buy another. It has a life of its own, so it takes a while to get the flowers to fall into place. But once they do, it is a perfect thing. Lyrical and simple. This vase of flowers, joined with a Friday afternoon spent listening to “St. Matthew Passion,” meditating over a slice of lemon pound cake — it is a must. MAIRA KALMAN.

assemblage / (ä´ sem bläzh’) / n. / a group of persons or things gathered together; a posh, Frenchified word for assembly, e.g., “Christopher Kane put together quite an assemblage for his little hoedown at Shoreditch House”; a form of art involving the assembly and arrangement of unrelated objects and materials, as in, “Their bookshelves were such a breathtaking assemblage that they looked like a Joseph Cornell.”.

When a skinny woman with a big appetite and a hefty man on a diet are seated among the guests at your table, the S-XL Cake pan saves them from asking for a slice “just a little bit bigger/smaller.” Designed by Ding3000 and produced by Konstantin Slawinski (both based in Germany), the flexible silicone mold features built-in portions of varying sizes. S-XL’s one setback: limited small.

How did an English garden center become a social hub and foodie destination? At Petersham Nurseries near Richmond, Surrey, a 15-minute train ride from central London, city folks longing for a country home — or perhaps a glimpse of Stella McCartney — roam the grounds while posh suburbanites from nearby Kew shop for garden supplies and make impromptu play dates around the communal table in a teahouse. The setting is quintessential shabby chic, with rambling greenhouses filled year-round with lush plants, garden antiques and design objects both exotic and familiar. In the main greenhouse, rickety tables hidden among plants form the setting for the chef Skye Gyngell’s lunch-only cafe, with an inspired menu featuring local and seasonal ingredients. (Reservations are mandatory.) A nearby toolshed has been converted into the teahouse, an inviting space for a cup of coffee, tea cakes or a bowl of soup served with Poilâne bread and farmhouse butter — the best way to battle the perpetually damp London air. Church Lane, off Petersham Road, Petersham, Surrey; 011-44-20-8940-5230; petershamnurseries.com. PIM TECHAMUANVIVIT.

Hungry? Good. The dinner bell is ringing for you and your pals. A Japanese tapered brass beckoner has a certain Brancusi-esque appeal ($75 at Turpan, Santa Monica, Calif.; 310-451-9500). Olof Kolte’s Ring My Bell, with its lacquered handle and silver-plated clapper, is a sweet example of Salvation Army chic (from $103 at Vessel, London; vesselgallery.com). And the brothers Campana (the Italian word for “bell”) have teamed up with Venini to create a series of limited-edition mouth-blown campane for Moss. N° 1956 has a branch handle and a metal hook for sound ($1,900 at Moss; mossonline.com). CHARLOTTE DRUCKMAN.

As the former sommelier at Daniel and the current owner of Le Dû’s Wines in the West Village, Jean-Luc Le Dû has sipped, swirled and spat some of the most coveted hooch in the world. So please excuse him if he appears something of a perfectionist. “There are two things that always make me cringe: a bottle being stored standing up, or a bottle stored in too warm of a temperature,” says the Brittany-born New Yorker. When it comes to his own wood-paneled, climate-controlled booze boutique (above), Le Dû doesn’t mind raising a glass to himself: “It is as close to a perfect wine shop as possible.” Or it will be when he finally hunts down a one-of-a-kind eau de vie. “I’m trying to find the absolute best bottle to import,” he says. “I’m not giving up.” We’ll drink to that. ALEX HAWGOOD.
What better weekend house for a writer and his family than one with a literary pedigree?

John Lautner apprenticed with Frank Lloyd Wright, designed Bob Hope’s Palm Springs mansion and unwittingly spawned Googie, the futuristic style of Left Coast architecture based on a coffee shop of the same name. For more than 55 years, the architect created dwellings so site-specific they seemed to spring from the Los Angeles hills (the Sheats/Goldstein house) or touch down from a distant galaxy (the Marbrisa house, seen at right, or the Chemosphere house). His glass-and-poured-concrete masterpieces have co-starred in films, TV shows and even a video game. This summer, Lautner’s cult status gets an institutional imprimatur with the opening of the exhibition “Between Earth and Heaven: The Architecture of John Lautner” at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, from July 13 to Oct. 12. (The accompanying catalog, from Rizzoli, is available for $60.) Meanwhile, make like Vincent Gallo and Kelly Lynch and buy a Lautner original at architectureforsale.com. The 1949 Schaffer residence in Glendale, Calif., is on the market for just under $2 million. SARAH VERDONE.
At her new London Store, Priscilla Carluccio mixes the classic and the quirky.

For the Manhattan event planner David Monn, organizing a dinner party on the beach usually involves a tent, sofas and a dance floor. When entertaining in his own Sag Harbor, N.Y., backyard, however, things get a little less complicated. “For me, it’s the opposite of a large production,” says the man who’s orchestrated everything from the Met’s Costume Institute gala to the Plaza Hotel’s coming Grand Reopening Celebration and other intimate soirees. In either case, he first creates what he calls “imaginary architecture,” using torches, hurricane lanterns on pillars or lights strung in trees to make guests feel safe. Next he chooses one color element. “Constancy is where we derive our power image,” he notes. Can Monn purchase power among the offerings of CB2, Crate and Barrel’s cheap-and-cheerful offshoot? No problem. He quickly struck upon his color: “Live chartreuse green” — or Olivine, in CB2-speak — which works outdoors as a “continuation of what the eyes are already seeing.” In fact, he liked the textures and ease offered by CB2 so much, guests at one of the three beach weddings he’s organizing this summer should keep a (green) eye out. CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

One reason to move to the Bay Area: the Boccalone Salumi Society. Twice a month, members pick up Happy Meal-style boxes of Boccalone meats, made by the Incanto chef Chris Cosentino and his team. The week’s haul might include fresh breakfast sausage, mortadella, orange and wild fennel salame, lardo and other porky items, with prices starting at $174 for three months. It’s like a charcuterie C.S.A. (community-supported agriculture) box, except you won’t have to worry about what to do with all that soppressata. The rest of us can order à la carte at boccalone.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

Part treehouse, part oversize closet, the lollipop studios for one, known as Single Hauz, was dreamed up by Pawel Kobrynski, Wojciech Krawczuk and Marcin Sakson, a trio of Polish architects. Each elevated prefab is 6 feet by 20 feet; sliding French doors open into the main living area, with a kitchenette and enough room for a bed and a single chair; and a tiny bathroom is shoehorned into a windowless nook. It can be erected on almost any terrain, even on a lake. “The Single Hauz is a kind of architectural-social manifesto about single people,” Kobrynski says. But it can also provide a refuge even for the happily married, “because every one of us sometimes needs a place where we can be alone.” The Single Hauz has not yet found a manufacturer; for more information, go to frontarchitects.pl. MARK ELLWOOD.

With the opening of the Thompson LES hotel next month, Lee Friedlander will bring new meaning to the term “artist in residence.” Over each of the 141 beds in this downtown Manhattan hotel, a wall-mounted light box will illuminate black-and-white photographs from Friedlander’s apple and olive tree series, seven variants in all (including the one above). “Our approach was to integrate the work in an architectural context rather than treat it as an applied afterthought,” says the hotel’s interior designer, Jim Walrod. The photographer is in good company: the lobby features a giant color-field painting by Peter Halley, and at the bottom of the outdoor pool, Andy Warhol gazes up from a Gerard Malanga filmstrip that has been acid-etched into the tiles. So, while a handful of locals might bemoan the continuing gentrification of the Lower East Side, few can complain about the hotel’s artistic pedigree. BILL POWERS.

When the 25-year-old fashion designer Christopher Kane first considered giving a dinner party for a few of his friends, he knew, without question, that it was not going to be at home. Kane spends most of his time working with his older sister, Tammy — who is also his accomplice, business partner and fit model — in a spacious but grungy East London loft that is best suited for sandwich deliveries. “My studio is so messy,” said Kane, rolling his eyes. “I have magazines and piles of stuff everywhere because I often start working on projects and don’t finish them. We would have had to eat on the floor.”.
It’s hot in the city, when everything tastes better with relish. Plus: an exclusive video by the photographer Marcus Gaab.

Matthijs Vogels was frustrated by the amount of food people throw away after meals. So, for part of his masters thesis at the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, the 27-year-old designer put his frustrations to work: he created a zero-waste restaurant installation. The temporary, small-scale project espoused the “cradle to cradle” philosophy, which embraces ecologically intelligent design as a means of turning waste into new products. “I did several crazy experiments,” Vogels says, and not everything worked out. But he did succeed in creating a series of bowls and plates called Waste-Ware that were hand-pressed out of left-over coffee grounds and herbs. Each biodegradable set doubles as a container; the coffee version is perfect for storing chocolates. To purchase, go to studiohergebruik.nl. S. KIRK WALSH.

An article on April 20 about Rome at night misidentified the figure from mythology represented in the centerpiece sculpture of the Trevi Fountain. It is Oceanus, the Titan who the ancient Greeks believed ruled the watery elements — not Neptune, the Roman god of the sea. (The error has appeared for years in travel guides about Rome, is found extensively in Internet references, and has infiltrated at least five other articles in The Times since 1981.).

An article on April 13 about the Marquesas in the South Pacific misidentified one of the countries that make up the so-called Polynesian Triangle and the Polynesian island that is the farthest from Tahiti. In addition to Hawaii and Easter Island, the triangle includes New Zealand, not Tahiti. And Easter Island, not the Marquesas, is the farthest from Tahiti.

YOU might presume that Graham Kirkham, the London collector and founder of the retail chain DFS Furniture, decided to sell Munch's ''Girls on a Bridge'' because he thinks he can get a good return. But some wonder how high collectors will be willing to go. Consider this: In 1980 Wendell Cherry, a founder of the Humana health-care corporation, bought the painting at Christie's for $2.8 million. In 1996 Mr. Cherry's widow put it on the block at Sotheby's, where Mr. Kirkham bought it for $7.2 million. Now Sotheby's predicts this boldly colorful canvas, depicting a group of young women huddled together, will fetch $24 million to $28 million. ''Munch is one of those artists that people are finally recognizing for his position in the development of modern art,'' said Simon Shaw, head of Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department in New York.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Notre Dame vs. Rutgers: Playing Holier Than Thou,'' April 29: In this era when the better side of human nature is pleading for an end to divisiveness and narrow sectarian attitudes in our society, and for a greater respect for all of those who make up the great diversity that is America, it was appalling to read some of Harvey Araton's comments about Notre Dame in the negotiations with Rutgers regarding the conditions under which they would agree to play football. Araton has a right to take sides in this controversy, but his injecting snide references to the religious tradition of Notre Dame in a sarcastic tone is just plain ugly. John M. McDonagh
BALSAMO--William . Born in Brooklyn, NY, died after a brief illness in Himeji, Japan. His legacy as a humanitarian and philanthropist will be remembered. william-bill-balsamo.virtual-memorials.com

CATALOGS are brimming with interesting sculptures this spring. The medium has been a particularly popular market choice lately, and experts are betting the trend has far from peaked. ''Getting great pictures is expensive, but sculptures are less so,'' said Simon Shaw of Sotheby's, whose Impressionist and Modern sale on May 14 includes sculptures by Julio González and Giacometti as well as a rare painted Picasso bronze. ''These sculptures make an instant impact,'' he said. Christie's will serve up an exceptional group of Giacomettis from various periods on May 13, including a plaster from his Surrealist period.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Vegetarian Slugger in the Land of Brats,'' April 27: I would add one thing to Alan Schwarz's otherwise balanced and delightful article about Brewers first baseman Prince Fielder's recent conversion to vegetarianism and the buzz it has caused in the baseball world: assurance to bratwurst-loving Milwaukee fans that embracing a meat-free diet by no means necessitates swearing off sausage.

Wonderful grandmother to Jennifer (Ben), Scott (Caitlin), Carla (Ted), Ilana (Jim), Robert (Lisa). Special great-grandma to Julia, Eleanor, Aidan, Lucy, Sarah and Mary. Cherished sister and aunt. At age 95 she read biographies and watched her favorite sport teams on TV. An incredible baker (knishes) and reader. She will be missed by all who loved her. Shiva at the home of the Goldsmiths 7pm Sunday and Monday.

9 P.M. (13, 49) CRANFORD Casting call! Judi Dench, Eileen Atkins, Michael Gambon, Francesca Annis and Imelda Staunton star in this three-part ''Masterpiece'' production, based on the Victorian-era writings of Elizabeth Gaskell, about a drowsy 1840s British village that springs to life with gossip, parties, romances, sudden death and bankruptcy as a railway approaches. At its center are the spinster sisters Matty and Deborah Jenkyns (Ms. Dench, above, second from right, and Ms. Atkins, second from left, with, from left, Lisa Dillon and Ms. Staunton). One is a strict enforcer of the town's decorum, the other a contented participant in its changes. Parts 2 and 3 will be shown on May 11 and 18 at 9 p.m. 8 P.M. (13, 49) SUPERFISH In this ''Nature'' episode the filmmaker and biologist Rick Rosenthal takes to the seas to examine the life cycles of the highly prized billfish -- marlin, sailfish, spearfish and swordfish -- with stops at nurseries and secret undersea canyons along the Baja Peninsula of Mexico and the Great Barrier Reef off Australia. He also searches for an elusive thousand-pound ''grander,'' one of the female marlins immortalized by Hemingway in ''The Old Man and the Sea,'' which can slice through the water at 60 miles an hour on migrations that span 9,000 miles.
