Diana Taylor, far left, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's frequent companion and the unofficial first lady of New York City, on her way to a business lunch with a thousand Asian businesspeople, looked every bit the 21st-century executive woman. It has been cool in New York, and like many women she wore a perfectly tailored spring coat with trousers, a shirt and most important, low-heeled shoes -- but not ballet slippers, which are currently the rage in some quarters. These elegant women remind you of Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, top left, the wife of the French president. On a recent state visit to England, her clothes, from Dior, were not headline grabbers. They were the real thing, topped by a purple spring coat, flawlessly fitted.

AT LA RÉSIDENCE PHOU VAO HOTEL, LUANG PRABANG, Feb. 27. 2008 Laurent Caraux, 58, of Paris, who runs a Mexican restaurant chain in France. ''My wife, Marianne, and I stayed there while we were enjoying a 10-day vacation in Vietnam and Laos. In the water, I was thinking that I was a lucky guy. It was freezing in Paris! This photograph gives a good feeling of the peaceful country we found in Laos -- charming inhabitants, beautiful countryside and the majesty of the Mekong River. We had arrived from Hanoi, which is exactly a town with an opposite atmosphere: noisy, polluted. There are not so many countries that can offer you the charm and the permanent delicate attention that you find in Laos. It really is the country to go to if you want to retire from the furor of the world.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

McFADDEN--George . Be loved husband of Carol, beloved father of Lisa Melas, Wilhelmina McFadden, and Alexander McFadden, beloved stepfather of Piers and Georgiana Moreton. Adored grandfather of Leon and Pavlos Melas. He died in a plane crash, in the Toledo Bend Reservoir, Texas, at 4pm, April 22nd. He was 67. He was the son of Alexander Bloomfield McFadden and Josephine Cutting Blair. He attended Greenvale School, St. Paul's School, Vanderbilt University and Columbia Business School. He was the Chairman of McFadden Bros. LLC. and had a long career in venture capital. Original, witty, generous, an exceptional sportsman, Mr. McFadden was a Governor of Deepdale Country Club, Trustee of the St Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, of St. Paul's School, and a Director of the Squaw Valley Ski Corporation. Tradition loving, family oriented, and erudite, he will be lovingly remembered. He is survived by his sister Mary McFadden and brother John McFadden, by his half brothers Watson Blair and Wolcott Blair, his stepfather, Watson K. Blair, his former wife Lesley Taylor, and by his many loving cousins. The Funeral Service is to be held on May 8th at 3pm, St. Thomas's Church, 1 W. 53rd St. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to St. Andrews Dune Church, Southampton, or The Alexander B. McFadden Memorial Scholarship, at St. Paul's School, Concord, New Hampshire.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

A review on April 20 about Elizabeth Strout's ''Olive Kitteridge,'' using information provided by the publisher, carried an incorrect picture credit. The author photograph was by Andrea Sperling, not Jerry Bauer.

THE welcome is warm, the service helpful and unceremonious at the Red Lobster in Nanuet, N.Y., a seafood restaurant clearly accustomed to serving families with young children. These fill the sprawling dining room in early evening; adults come in later to the roomy bar and lounge area with its more intimate aura. The dining room is unexpectedly sophisticated. No bright yellows and oranges startle the eyes here; instead, there are soft upholstered banquettes and mellow lighting in a luxury of space -- a subdued harbor feel without the phony weathering. Even the restrooms were clean and tidy despite a good-size crowd.

Big Brown reacts to the sound of the crowd on his right as he leaves the gate but is untouched and cruises the front stretch about six wide and in fifth place, with no one kicking dirt in his face. Pyro is squeezed back by Visionaire and Colonel John and is not heard from again. Bob Black Jack makes the lead. Kent Desormeaux has Big Brown five wide on the first turn as the stampede starts to thin out. Bob Black Jack stays in front, but the other speed horses - Cowboy Cal and Recapturetheglory - press the pace. Eight Belles is behind horses in fifth, while Cool Coal Man saves ground on the rail. Big Brown makes a powerful move on the turn while still four wide. The front-runners have no response. Desormeaux takes Big Brown to the lead and angles in front of Recapturetheglory while moving to the rail. Eight Belles has to be checked when she is blocked while jockey Gabriel Saez looks for room to race. Big Brown is unchallenged, and Desormeaux only shows him the whip and then starts to celebrate. Eight Belles is game to the wire before collapsing with two broken front ankles while galloping out. Denis of Cork, coming from dead last, has no challenge for the leaders but holds on for third over Tale of Ekati, who was very wide entering the stretch.

WHITE--Lawrence , innovative early producer of programming on radio and television, died on April 27, 2008 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Evelyn, their children Joshua, Deborah and Rebecca and grandchildren Mathew and Sarah Barnett. His long career in media arts began as an assistant to the legendary manager/producer Leland Heyward. Soon White was representing artists on his own including Walter Huston and Charles Laughton. Eventually he began to produce independently. He had the original idea of producing weekly radio series based on classic detective fiction like that of Dashiell Hammett. His first success was Sam Spade based on the detective in the book and movie, The Maltese Falcon. Sam Spade was quickly followed by a another series called ''The Fat Man'', in which an original detective in the Hammett style was successfully created. Both series ran for many years on CBS Radio. In the early fifties, White moved to the growing medium of television. He was the creator and sole producer of The Pinky Lee Show. At the height of its popularity, The Pinky Lee Show was broadcast six hours a week live on NBC. The legendary studio in Burbank currently occupied by The Tonight Show was built for Pinky. At the same time and in partnership with Leland Heyward he produced the ground breaking Ford 50th Anniversary Show, one of the very first ''specials'', which starred Ethel Merman and Mary Martin and was directed by Jerome Robbins. At the time, the show was so important that two networks, NBC and CBS both carried it live. Later, White was active in bringing Jazz to a huge audience by producing a series of classic Jazz Shows on Television sponsored by Timex watches. He also pioneered using Videotape at classic circuses in Europe, bringing them to America as ''International Showtime,'' a long running series hosted by Don Ameche on NBC. He is remembered for his originality, creativity and intelligence. Final services are incomplete.

I WAS a townie living very close to Harvard Square. I must have been around 19. The Harvard Square Theater was a revival house very much like the old Theater 80 St. Marks in Manhattan. It showed classic double features that changed daily. In those days the entrance to the theater was off Mass. Ave., and there was a long, narrow lobby with a decorative planter that ran down the center like a median strip. At some point the planter, which was filled with sand, had been adorned with plastic greenery, but by 1981 it had devolved into a giant ashtray. I was young and stupid and smoking cigarettes at the time. It was very early summer or late spring. It was humid and drizzling, and I was there to see ''Last Tango in Paris'' -- and I was alone.

MY teenage daughter is a fan of spicy food, so she was enthusiastic about a visit to Chili's in East Haven, Conn., with a couple of friends. She was not disappointed, and I was pleasantly surprised with a few of the dishes. The place was comfortable and well managed (despite being very full on a Sunday night) and our waitress was terrific.

To the Editor: Grazie to Ian Fisher for his poetic ode to the most fascinating of cities, Rome, in his ''Rome at Night'' (April 20). The article lovingly evokes the enchantment of Rome on a grand but human scale. Strolling through Trastevere, the Tiber Island, the magnificent Campidoglio, and the cobblestoned streets, with both Romans and non-Romans, to soak in the eternal treasures of the city is the pinnacle of pleasure. Having lived in Rome for five years, although it was a long time ago, I still consider it to be my second home. Every time I return and stroll though my favorite haunts, I experience the thrill of the first time. I appreciate Mr. Fisher's reference to Georgina Masson, as her book ''Companion Guide to Rome'' was my companion in the late 60s.

Her West Village, NYC home was a hub for a broad range of artists, musicians, writers, intellectuals, and activists at the heart of numerous movements. She was a leader in the fight for justice and inspired others to believe in themselves, each other, and their dreams. Memorial: 6:30pm, May 11, Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow St. No flowers; please give to cancer research by Dr. Herbert Chen, information: gastrinoma@aol.com, 608-263-2434. Vote Obama!

RECENTLY, an old friend was lamenting his thrift. He owns a Mini Cooper S, which he bought in 2006, and was beating himself up over not splurging for the GP Kit model, which was available that year in limited numbers. ''It was $31,000 or something like that,'' he said (actually, it was $31,150). ''The S that I got was around $23,000. Now people are selling the GP for around $41,000.''

and I do mean loosely -- on the first book of T. H. White's marvelous Arthurian epic, ''The Once and Future King,'' ''The Sword in the Stone'' was released in 1963, long after the 1930s and '40s glory days of the Disney animation studios. Even so, it does capture some of the sly humor of White's book, and offers the same confident assurance that the gangly uncertainties of childhood can be whisked away by magic. Wart, an orphan and servant boy, is really the young King Arthur -- he just doesn't know it yet. Under the tutelage of the wizard Merlin he learns the most important things about being a future king; Merlin transforms him into various forest creatures -- a fish, a squirrel, a bird -- so he can experience life outside his own skin. This restored version is lovely to look at -- even the requisite dancing Disney sugar bowls somehow look fresh and sparkling. And it does justice to one of the great unsung animated sequences, in which Wart, in squirrel form, is pursued by a cheerful, chattering redheaded squirrelette. She has fallen madly in love with him, at first sight, but for obvious reasons he rebuffs her. When she sees he's not the squirrel for her -- he's not even a squirrel at all -- the disappointment on her face casts a pall, momentarily, on the entire magical forest. The camera pulls back to show her as a tiny forlorn figure, alone at the top of a tree, as Merlin explains to Wart that love is the most perplexing and complicated of all human emotions. Maybe that goes double for squirrels. (Walt Disney Video, June 17, $29.99) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

MALMUTH SINGER-Cynthia , also known professionally as Roxanne Winchell passed away in her Manhattan home on Monday, April 28th after a courageous battle with cancer. She was born Cynthia Wapner to Charles and Lillian Wapner in Brooklyn, New York, on August 4th, 1937. A gifted food and travel writer, journalist, photographer, and publicist, Cynthia was an integral part of the New York City social scene where she will be remembered for her journalistic talent and glamorous style. Cynthia was the editor of numerous publications and the creator of six highly visible newspaper and magazine columns. She was a member of the International Food, Wine and Travel Writers Association for fifteen years and a board member of the American Cancer Society where she helped promote life-saving campaigns. She covered innumerable social events and interviewed many celebrities and high-profile personalities. As a publicist, Ms. Malmuth represented many prominent businesses both locally and internationally. Cynthia is survived by her son Evan, daughter Valerie, granddaughter Francesca, brother Gerald, daughter-in-law Katherine, nephew Kenny and niece Erica. Cynthia was married to Ronald Merians, film director Bruce Malmuth, and Richard Singer. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

ONE look around Bertucci's in Darien, Conn., and it was obvious that it was family oriented. It was a Sunday night, and ours was the only table without children. But the crowd was as ethnically diverse as a city block, and the décor relatively homey for a chain, with the dining area divided into a number of small rooms. Our first real surprise, though, was the beer list, which included several offbeat microbrews on tap. The second was the wine list, featuring some interesting Italian, California and Washington State choices, well priced from $24 to $38 a bottle, or $4.99 to $9.50 by the glass.

HECHT--Imre H. , 98, died on May 1st, 2008. Born in Budapest, Hungary in 1910, Imre won his way to freedom in America after escaping forced labor camps during the war. Having survived the atrocities of the Holocaust, Imre had his mind and heart open to those less fortunate than himself. Imre was a humble and great man who, along with his wife Vera, generously supported many causes and reached out to children of all creeds. Together with his wife Vera, he helped to establish the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Manhattan and founded the Hecht School of Music in Sarasota, Florida. Imre and Vera also created the Vera and Imre Hecht Foundation to pursue these ideals and to continue his dream of creating a world filled with equality and without prejudice. Imre will be deeply missed by his daughter Izabela, his grandson Konrad and his extended family and friends. Service at 11:15am Sunday, May 4th, 2008 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th Street, in Manhattan. HECHT--Imre. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage--A Living Memorial to the Holocaust are saddened by the passing of our esteemed Trustee, Imre Hecht. Predeceased by his beloved Vera in January, Imre, a Hungarian Holocaust survivor, lived a creative and rich life, and earned the love of many in the course of his 98 years. Our sympathies to Izabela and the rest of the family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair David G. Marwell, Director
Art Roberta Smith

R ICHARD PRINCE, whose retrospective last year at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York won critical acclaim, is still considered a hot commodity. Yet it seems surprising that so many Princes have surfaced on the market recently, privately as well as at auction. Sotheby's and Christie's are both selling paintings from Mr. Prince's popular nurse series, images inspired by the covers of erotic pulp fiction of the 1940s. Some experts say the private sellers are hedge-fund managers who have supported Mr. Prince but are now facing tough times and need cash. Other collectors received overtures from auction houses they simply couldn't refuse. One of the nurse canvases belongs to Peter Brant, who has a large collection of Prince works, including other nurse paintings. Sotheby's is selling his ''Millionaire Nurse,'' depicting a blonde wearing a surgical mask. It is estimated to fetch $3.5 million to $4.5 million.
BLOCK--Cy . Happy Birthday, my darling. Forever, Y. P. C.

Each month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics gathers 84,000 prices in about 200 categories -- like gasoline, bananas, dresses and garbage collection -- to form the Consumer Price Index, one measure of inflation. It's among the statistics that the Federal Reserve considered when it cut interest rates on Wednesday. SKERRETT--Dr. Philip Vincent , died peacefully in Montgomery, Alabama on April 28, 2008. He was 84 years old. Philip, the seventh child of Emma V. Crawford and William Davenport Skerrett was born in the Village of Lincoln University, PA where he attended grammar school, Oxford High School and Lincoln University (BA 1947). After serving in the U.S. Army, WWII - New Guinea (1943 -1946), Philip entered Meharry Medical College in Nashville, Tennessee to become a physician. Following receipt of his M.D. degree (1951), he completed his internship and pathology training at the Mercy Douglas Hospital, Albert Einstein Medical Center, and the Veteran's Hospital in Phila, PA. Shortly afterwards began his lifelong career of 46 years of dedicated physician service at the Veteran's Administration Hospitals in Coatesville, Pittsburgh, and Phila, PA, Dublin, GA, and lastly in Montgomery, AL. Philip was a scholarly physician who pursued countless postgraduate educational courses and taught medical students and resident physicians while on faculty at the University of Pennsylvania and the Medical College of PA. He was a member of Kappa Pi Honorary Society, Beta Kappa Chi National Scientific Society, and Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity. Philip, a kind, loving, and dutiful family man leaves behind his wife, Dolores Barksdale Skerrett of 55 years, his children Philip, Donna, and Stephanie, grandchildren Lauren Emile and Meredith Ariel, and siblings and a host of extended family and friends. To many, he will be especially remembered as a chef and an avid reader who loved poetry and had a gift for recitation. He will be greatly missed. The Funeral Service will be held on May 5, 2008, 11:00am CST following family visitation at 10:30am, at the Church of the Ascension in Montgomery, AL. Interment private.

MATT DAMHAVE, the onetime Imitation of Christ designer who famously scrawled ''Bring me the head of Tom Ford'' across a vintage Yves Saint Laurent shirt, could talk your ear off about the moral decline of the arts. Instead, he has chosen to illustrate it. His richly layered collages, now hanging at Half Gallery, a month-old Lilliputian space owned by Andy Spade, Bill Powers and James Frey, address, often comically, all sorts of societal ills: the inflated value of art, the nonprogression of music, the absurdity of certain brands of streetwear. ''Grown men are walking around wearing baby blankets with hoodies,'' bellowed Mr. Damhave, who, for his part, is trying to correct the problem: This fall he will introduce Ahaha, a line of tailored active wear for men. Or, as he put it, ''smart clothes for radicals.''

YOU'VE probably heard the slogan: ''When you're here, you're family.'' We were literally family, three generations out to put the Olive Garden to the test in Massapequa, N.Y. Could this chain that sets the standard for Italian restaurants in some parts of the country compete in the New York metropolitan area, with its wealth of good Italian places? The answer was a qualified yes. Compared with other spots in a similar price range (all entrees were under $20), it is a contender, if not in the league of the best Italian restaurants.

IN case you haven't heard, superhero is the new floral. Faster than a speeding bullet, it has become the fashion industry's springtime obsession. Webby has replaced wispy. Latex has overtaken Liberty print. All things sleek, space-age and cartoonishly colorful are having a major moment. Much of it has to do with the Costume Institute's spring exhibition, ''Superheroes: Fashion and Fantasy,'' which kicks off tomorrow night with a gala hosted by Batman (by day, George Clooney). But, in looking at the exaggerated silhouettes, high-tech fabrics and rather intimidating details in many of this season's collections -- Balenciaga, Alexander McQueen, Martin Margiela, Givenchy -- it appears the superhero fantasy, or the idea of being transformed into a bigger, better, more magical version of oneself, has been in the air for a while.

IF I hadn't already set my sights on being rebellious with my ''favorite summer movie'' choice (and had said choice limited to one), I would've undoubtedly picked Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' a film that expertly captures the cruel, sweet insanity of a sweat-soaked Brooklyn during a heat wave. In that movie Mr. Lee got something more right than anybody ever had before: pure, raw heat. The only thing more pleasing, however, than a film that really feels like summer is one that is completely the opposite, but viewed during those blistering months. For a perfect summer moviegoing experience I would choose a brand-spanking-new print of David Lean's ''Dr. Zhivago,'' playing for one week only at Film Forum -- the Ziegfeld would be something else, but this isn't meant to be science fiction -- and only I and a few close friends (since I have only about six in the entire world) would know about it.

BENNETT--Dorothy Becker , 82, of Greenwich, CT, co-founder of Caldor, Inc., passed away peacefully at home surrounded by her family on May 2, 2008 after a courageous battle with Lewy Body Disease. The daughter of Max Becker and Esther Genin Becker, Mrs. Bennett was born in Norwalk, CT and grew up in Forest Hills, NY. She married Carl Bennett in 1951 and they settled in Stamford, CT. The couple founded Caldor, Inc. in Port Chester, NY and built the chain up to 100 stores until they sold it to Associated Dry Goods in 1981. Mrs. Bennett served on the board of the Boys & Girls Club of Stamford and Fairfield University, and was active in organizations including Congregation Agudath Sholom and the Easter Seals Rehabilitation Center in Stamford, where she founded the Neat Place to Eat Restaurant. She and Carl also supported Yeshiva and Fairfield University, the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, and both Stamford and Greenwich Hospitals. In addition to her beloved husband of 57 years, Mrs. Bennett is survived by two sons, Marc (Katy Meyers) of Stamford, Bruce (Jennifer) of Rochester, NY, and daughter, Robin (Joseph) Kanarek of Greenwich; five grandchildren, Lauren and Zoe Bennett, Naomi and Gabriel Bennett, Sarah Kanarek; and one sister, Florence Caplan of Williams Island, FL. She was predeceased by her parents, her sister Sylvia Weinstein of Bayside, NY and her grandson, David Bennett Kanarek. The funeral service will be held at Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Ave. in Stamford on Sunday, May 4 at 3pm, with burial following at Temple Sholom Cemetery on Memory Lane in Greenwich. Shiva to be announced. The family requests that donations in her memory be made to: The Carl & Dorothy Bennett Cancer Center (Stamford Hospital Foundation), 9 West Broad St., 9th Floor, Stamford, CT 06902; Visiting Nurse & Hospice Care of SW CT, 1029 East Main St., Stamford, CT 06902, or Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Ave., Stamford, CT 06902.

THE British jeweler Stephen Webster is quick to point out that his new silver collection, which ranges in price from $300 to $2,500, is not a poor man's version of his fine jewelry line. ''Each piece is a piece of substance,'' said the self-proclaimed ''diamond geezer,'' perhaps best known for making Madonna and Guy Ritchie's wedding bands. Indeed, his sterling silver mosaic rings, inlaid with gemstones like hematite, goldstone and coral to resemble graphic shards of stained glass, pack a mighty punch. Quite literally, if you believe Mr. Webster. ''My wife wears them,'' he said. ''So I'm on the receiving end.'' Mosaic rings, $550 to $850 at Bergdorf Goodman.

WATCHING ''Brewster McCloud'' at a Texas drive-in blew my teenage mind during the summer of '71. Living on the wrong side of the tracks (the dry part of town) in South Dallas, a late Saturday night could only mean a double or triple bill at the Astro Drive-In. We threw the lawn chairs in the trunk of the car, as well as a teenager or two, and arrived just before dusk to see the main feature. The second and third movies were repeats of past drive-in favorites, like ''Kelly's Heroes,'' which played there so often I'm convinced the theater must have held on to the print for years and never returned it. ''Brewster McCloud'' was highly anticipated in Texas because it was the first movie made in the Astrodome, that great modern Texas landmark. The trailer also promised some action, some comedy, a little sex and a slam-bang ending. ''Brewster McCloud'' had all that, but oh, so much more.

To the Editor: The Check In/ Check Out column (April 13) about Prague twice referred to Prague as being in Eastern Europe.'' The countries of the old Austrian Empire -- the former Czechoslovakia, along with Hungary, Poland and Austria itself -- make up Central Europe. They use a Western alphabet; if Catholic, they are Roman rather than Orthodox; and they looked west for cultural leadership instead of east to Moscow. In fact, Prague lies farther to the west than Vienna. Over 40 years of communism may have left Prague within the realm of Russia, but it did not make it Eastern Europe. Ludmila Schwarzenberg Hess

To the Editor: Re ''The Spirit of '68'' by A. O. Scott [April 27]:

Just before Valentine's Day this year, Sunday Styles did something very unromantic: we asked college students nationwide to tell the plain truth about what love is like for them. We weren't sure what to expect, but we thought we wouldn't receive many essays about red roses and white tablecloths. When the contest deadline passed seven weeks later, more than 1,200 essays had arrived, from 365 schools in 46 states and Puerto Rico. In perhaps typical collegiate fashion, nearly 700 poured in on the last day, 400 over the final hour. We counted only three red roses among them, and one was bestowed in a laundry room.

They are her daughters: Roseanne Saalfield and her husband, Jim Saalfield; Peggy Brady and her partner, Deb Winsor; Patricia Corbett and her husband, John Corbett, and her son, John Brady and his wife, Alyce Brady. Also surviving are her eight beloved grandchildren, Peter, Meaghan, Jonathan, Sam, Ian, Lauren, Clara and Jack. Mary will be remembered as a proud women of strong opinions, which she did not hesitate to share with a quick wit and sometimes sharp tongue. She mothered many, not just her children and grandchildren, with a heartfelt warmth and generosity. She will be missed by all of us who know we were lucky to have shared our lives with her. A memorial reception will be held on May 31st from 2-4:00pm at the home of her daughter, Patricia Corbett, 124 Furhman Ave. Ramsey, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to The Maple Street School Scholarship Fund, 21 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, New York 11225, supporting early childhood education or The Town of Harvard Public Library, Massachusetts Avenue, Harvard MA 01451 where a crossword puzzle corner was dedicated in her honor.

Little known outside his native Quebec, Claude Jutra was a spiritual brother of the great humanist filmmakers Jean Renoir, Vittorio de Sica and Satyajit Ray. Like them, he achieved the invisible technique that only master directors do, and he used that technique to erase the barriers between the audience and the people on screen, even the most appalling of them. Perhaps Jutra is so little known because of his aborted body of work. Trained as a doctor, he recognized in himself the symptoms of early-onset Alzheimer's and, in 1986 at the age of 56, drowned himself in the St. Lawrence River. His body was not found until the following spring.
To the Editor: Re ''Roger Ebert, the Critic Behind the Thumb'' by A. O. Scott [April 13]:

Last fall offered the theatrical release of ''Control,'' Anton Corbijn's austere and deeply moving biopic about Ian Curtis, the lead singer of the revered Manchester, England, post-punk band Joy Division. Mr. Curtis killed himself in 1980, just as the group was about to embark on an American tour. He had been distressed by marital problems, and he suffered from epilepsy, which had only recently been diagnosed. It's a shame that the documentary ''Joy Division,'' directed by Grant Gee, couldn't have been released simultaneously with ''Control.'' The two pictures dovetail beautifully: Mr. Gee interviews the major players in Joy Division's story -- among them Tony Wilson, the television host (and founder of the seminal Factory Records, to which Joy Division was signed) who helped put the band on the map, as well as the group's three other members, who went on to form the more successful (and long-lived) band New Order. What Mr. Gee comes up with perfectly complements Mr. Corbijn's somewhat fictionalized take.
Film Mike Hale

OH, HOW FAR SUPERHEROS have come. Born of tragedy (Batman), freak accident (Spider-Man), mythology (Wonder Woman) and mutant genes (the X-Men), these champions of justice have gone on to inspire cartoons, toys, video games, novels and films. *Now comes proof that superheros--from their color palettes to their insignias to their impossible physiques--have also played muse to fashion's biggest designers. This week, the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will present ''Superheroes: Fashion and Fantasy'' (May 7 through Sept. 1), which spotlights more than 500 ensembles--from sportswear to haute couture to film costumes--that reflect a heroic ideal. * But the relationship between the worlds of fashion and cartoon avengers is hardly one-sided. In 1987, Mary Jane Watson married Peter Parker (Spider-Man) in a dress designed by Willi Smith. A decade later, costumes designed by Jean Paul Gaultier were used in the geek-friendly sci-fi adventure film ''The Fifth Element.'' Donna Karan recently hired Paul Pope, a critically acclaimed comic-book artist, to design for DKNY Jeans. And that's not all. The desire to right wrongsin hot-looking outfits inspired the eight new heroines pictured here. It goes without saying that their clothes, all from the fall 2008 collections are, well, Super. Or, in the words of Edna Mode, the cartoon designer in the ''The Incredibles'' and noted hater of capes: ''Superheroes are easy, darling. Mediocrity is much more difficult to work with.'' -- GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

S OME dealers must have gulped when they saw that the most expensive painting in Christie's May 6 Impressionist and modern art auction is a Monet, not a modern work. In a sense Christie's seems to be swimming against the tide. (The most expensive work in Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art is a 1912-13 Léger, ''Étude Pour 'La Femme en Bleu,' '' which carries a $35 million to $45 million estimate.) Yet the Monet, ''Le Pont du Chemin de Fer à Argenteuil,'' depicting two puffing locomotives, was considered unabashedly modern in its time. In 1988 Stavros Niarchos, the Greek shipping magnate, sold it for $12.6 million at Christie's in London to the Nahmads, dealers with galleries in New York and London. Defending the house's decision to give this painting a starring role, Guy Bennett, co-head of Impressionist and modern art at Christie's worldwide, said the work was a seminal one for Monet. He said Monet produced only three other comparable paintings of the subject. One is in the National Gallery of Art in Washington, another in the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the third in the Musée d'Orsay in Paris. ''I still believe there are buyers for top Impressionist paintings,'' he added.

IN an overture to Russia's new rich, Sotheby's sent highlights of its big spring sale of contemporary art from New York to Moscow this year for the first time. Sotheby's also has works that should appeal to new collectors in other emerging markets. Curiously, fewer examples of today's hot Chinese contemporary artists are on offer than a year ago, but Sotheby's contemporary sale on May 14 includes examples by two of today's most sought-after artists from Russia and India. Erik Bulatov, a Russian born in 1933, is being represented for the first time with his painting ''New York.'' And the auction also includes a 2003 painting by the Indian artist Subodh Gupta, ''Across the Seven Seas,'' which depicts a bustling airport. Its $500,000 to $700,000 estimate isn't cheap, but Mr. Gupta, 44, is considered one of the hottest artists of his generation in India. His work has been exhibited in high-profile shows like the 2005 Venice Biennale.

TALALAY--Marjorie Freedman , 87, of Cleveland, Ohio, and New York, died on May 1, 2008. She was born in New York City on February 15, 1921, and attended Goucher College. She married Anselm, an inventor and research chemical engineer, and had three children. Marjorie spent her early married life in New Haven, CT, where she was co-director of the Ross-Talalay gallery, with her lifelong friend Fernande Ross. In 1967, she and her husband, who worked for B.F. Goodrich, moved to Cleveland, Ohio, where she and Nina Castelli Sundell started the New Gallery, precursor to MOCA Cleveland, now one of the finest contemporary art centers in the Midwest. Marjorie is survived by her three daughters, Nina Talalay Callahan (Edward) of Plymouth, MA, Dr. Lauren Talalay (Dr. Steven Bank), of Ann Arbor, MI, and Kathryn Talalay (Frank Ponzio) of New York; her sister, Dorothy Cullman and brother-in law, Lewis Cullman; her brother-and sister-in-laws Drs. Paul and Pamela Talalay; and many beloved nieces and nephews. Marjorie was an extraordinary mother, mentor, and creative force. She had an enormous impact on so many people, especially in the art world. She was so very deeply loved by her three daughters. It is impossible for them to imagine a world without her. Even after the children spread their wings, they still talked to their mother many times a day seeking her wise counsel on all matters great and small. She was an exemplar of strength, humor, beauty, and incredible insight. Mother, we love you forever. You will be with us in this life and beyond. Nina, Laurie and Kathy

BRAD LIDGE, the closer for the Philadelphia Phillies, seems determined to prove that F. Scott Fitzgerald was wrong when he said there were no second acts in American lives. Once considered among the best relief pitchers in baseball, Lidge gave up a dramatic gameending homer to ALBERT PUJOLS in the 2005 National League Championship Series, and from that point seemed to lose his ability to close out big games. In 2006, he had 32 saves, but his earned run average rose to 5.28 from 2.29 the season before. Then in 2007, he lost his job for part of the season and blew 8 of 27 save opportunities. But Lidge has looked as dominant as ever since being traded to Philadelphia in November. He had pitched in 13 games through Friday and had not allowed an earned run. He was striking out nearly a batter per inning and was 7 for 7 in save opportunities. The only problem he has had this season is that he began it on the disabled list. Joining Lidge in the small group of pitchers still carrying a 0.00 E.R.A. is another player clearly in his second act, 38- year-old TROY PERCIVAL of the Tampa Bay Rays. Percival had made 10 appearances and was 6 for 6 in save opportunities despite having been retired for the 2006 season and pitching 34 games in middle relief for the St. Louis Cardinals last season. CHUTZPAH pays at P. F. Chang's China Bistro. Arriving without a reservation on a Saturday night (they are accepted for only half the tables), our party of eight was told by the chipper hostess that we could expect to wait up to two hours. So two of us slipped inside and claimed a seat at the bar. Moments later, another one opened three seats down. I looked beseechingly at a woman sitting between our seat and the vacant one and said, ''Please...'' She raised her eyebrows; I thanked her profusely in advance. When she answered, I heard a Russian accent. By the time our pager signified a table 35 minutes later, we had five seats at the bar, an order of ginger-scented fried pork dumplings that portended a good meal and a new friend's recipe for borscht.

If it's possible to make an elegant movie about suicidal depression, Louis Malle did it with his 1963 ''Fire Within.'' Maurice Ronet plays an alcoholic who has taken the cure, successfully, it seems, although almost from the start we know something's not right: he makes references to an estranged wife, and there's a strange date, July 23, written on his mirror in loopy script, a runelike reminder to himself that he sees every time he looks at his own face. With Erik Satie on the soundtrack -- the score shimmers through the movie like an invisible question mark -- Ronet drifts around Paris on his last day alive, reconnecting with old friends and lovers. One of these is Jeanne Moreau, so full of life when we first see her (in a bobbed haircut and almost comically heavy-rimmed glasses) that it's a jolt to us -- as it seems to crush Ronet -- when we watch her losing herself to the effects of opium.
Vertical Gardens . . . Dinner Bells ... Meat-of-the-Month Club . .. John Lautner . .. Art in Bed.

FOR me the quintessential summer day involves a nice beach, a crackling cold glass of pinot grigio and a great movie -- always a comedy. In the winter I wade through Academy fare that is becoming increasingly dark and depressing. I don't look forward to spending time with crazed killers and nutty oilmen. I've had enough of that living through the Bush years. No, I wait for summer to kick back with what is fast becoming an endangered species: the smart adult comedy. Over past summers I've revisited the Preston Sturges and Billy Wilder classics, the Hepburn-Tracy oeuvre, my beloved ''Annie Hall'' and ''Tootsie.'' This summer I'll be watching, for the umpteenth time, ''The Graduate.'' I was a sophomore in college when ''The Graduate'' was released in 1967. The Vietnam War was escalating, and campuses were on simmer approaching boil. And here comes Benjamin Braddock, a newly minted college grad, re-entering life in suburban Los Angeles without any idea of what to do with his future. What kind of hero was this? Short, dark, not-so-handsome and totally conflicted? What kind of storytelling was this, taking us from brilliant satire to broad comedy to heartbreak, sometimes in the same scene? Suddenly my plan to graduate with a degree in education because it was ''a good and stable occupation for a woman'' seemed wrong. The ground was shaking under everyone's feet, and everything was fair game for questioning.

PETER Brant, the Greenwich, Conn., newsprint magnate, is emerging as the season's craftiest seller. Seeking to raise money to buy another paper mill, he hit up both Sotheby's and Christie's for substantial guarantees. Experts familiar with the deals say Sotheby's came through with between $70 million and $80 million in exchange for various paintings and sculptures. Christie's got a share of art too, providing Mr. Brant with a reported $35 million. Mr. Brant's collection boasts hundreds of works by artists like Andy Warhol, Jean-Michel Basquiat, John Chamberlain, Richard Prince and Jeff Koons. It may appear that he is unloading the bulk of what he owns, but the art being sold now amounts to only a fraction of his holdings. Among the best for sale is Lichtenstein's ''Ball of Twine,'' a 1963 painting. Mr. Brant bought it in 2001 at Sotheby's for $4 million, the highest price paid for a work in that sale. Now it is estimated at $14 million to $18 million.

WATERFALL--John Charles (Bruce) , 70, of New York and Wainscott died on April 28th, 2008 after a 20-year battle with Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia. Beloved husband of Susan; devoted father to Jane and John Waterfall and Scott Straus; loving son-inlaw of Beatrice and the late Sidney Solomon; adoring father-in-law to Sara Guyer and grandfather to Sadie Straus. Born in New York City, he was the only child of the late Charles and Alice Waterfall. Bruce was a founding partner of Morgens, Waterfall, Vintiadis & Company. An incisive investor and passionate outdoorsman, Bruce will be remembered for the wisdom and perspicacity that he shared with his family, business associates, and friends. The family would like to give special thanks to the Weill Cornell doctors and nurses who cared for him. A private burial was held in Wainscott, NY on Thursday, May 1st to be followed by a Memorial Celebration in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Weill Cornell for the Waterfall Center for Waldenstrom Research, c/o Allyn Rose, Weill Cornell Development Office, Box 123, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10065.

In 1967 young audiences could see ''The Graduate,'' which encouraged them to sneer along with its callow hero at the very bourgeois luxuries that made their rebellion possible, or they could see Jean-Luc Godard's still startling ''La Chinoise,'' which may have been even more on their side -- but which spared them nothing. The Parisian student revolutionaries of Mr. Godard's terrifying political comedy have established their Maoist cell in a welcoming, tastefully appointed flat that one of them has borrowed from her relatives for the summer. We watch as they study the sacred texts (particularly Mao's little red book, stacks of which decorate the apartment), argue theory versus direct action, declaim the necessity of closing the universities, and graduate into murder and terrorism.
Theater Ben Brantley
INTERNATIONAL SOCCER STAR PUSHES LIMITS

TIDMARSH--Patricia (Patty) Carman , 81, died on Thursday, April 3, 2008 at 11pm at Kateri Residence in New York City. She was born on September 2, 1926 at Portland, Oregon to Patrick and Helen (Carman) Tidmarsh. When she was about 18 months old the family relocated to Tucson, Arizona so her father could help his brother manage the Tidmarsh Engineering Co., the family business. She attended Tucson Senior High, then later the former Anna Head High School at Berkeley, CA, now the Head-Royce High School at Oakland, CA. and graduated with the class of 1944. She then attended Smith College at Northampton, MA. She studied for one year in Mexico City and graduated in 1948 with a major in Latin. In 1948 Patty moved to New York City. She taught in the New York public school system for many years, but eventually got a job at the ABC News Payroll Dept. where she worked for 15 years. She retired in 1997. Patty had many interests including genealogy, astronomy, theology, and history. Patty will always be remembered as a very bright, kind, generous individual to her family and friends. She will most mostly be remembered for her keen, droll sense of humor. Surviving Patty are her brother Peter A. Tidmarsh of Moraga, CA.; her two nephews: Matthew A. Tidmarsh of Walnut Creek, CA, and Patrick G. Tidmarsh of Moraga, California; her niece and nephew-in-law: John R. and Elizabeth A. (Tidmarsh) Conely of Lafayette, California; one grandniece: Stephanie C. Duarte of Walnut Creek, CA.; two grandnephews: Matthew and Michael Conely of Lafayette, CA. A memorial service for Patty will be held on Friday, May 9th at 11am at Christ and St. Stephens Episcopal Church, 120 West 69th St., New York, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to: Smith College, c/o Donor Services, 33 Elm St., Northampton, MA, 01063; or to: Head-Royce School, c/o Betsy Ringrose, 4315 Lincoln Ave., Oakland, CA, 94602. Memorial contributions will be placed in the Anna Head Memorial Scholarship Fund.

LYON--Wendi (Wendy) Lee , 53, of Atlantic Highlands, Middletown, New Jersey, died on Thursday, April 24, 2008; the cause of death was lung cancer and exposure to 9/11 toxins. Wendi Lee grew up in West Caldwell, New Jersey. She attended Douglass College (Rutgers University) and graduated in 1977 with a BA in English and Theater Arts; she also earned a certificate in Women's Studies. Her career was spent in the paralegal profession; she had been employed since 1990 by Smith Mazure Law Firm in New York City. She was predeceased by her mother, Olivia (Jesse) Albertson Lyon, and is survived by her sister, Bradford Gail Lyon, of Hopewell, New Jersey, her father, Andrew Canfield Lyon, of San Diego, California, as well as by numerous friends and her beloved pets. Wendi Lee enjoyed traveling, cheering for the Yankees, spending time with friends and debating the finer points of many subjects. Her generous, exuberant and outspoken spirit will be remembered by many.

THE movie ''Speed Racer'' doesn't open until Friday, but the stars -- Emile Hirsch as Speed, Christina Ricci as Trixie and Matthew Fox as Racer X -- are on a premiere tour. This weekend, the movie is being shown at the Tribeca Film Festival in New York. The television show ''Speed Racer'' was first broadcast in Japan in 1966 and appeared in the United States a year later. The show disappeared from television during the 1980s, and it wasn't until the 1990s that ''Speed Racer'' reruns returned.

Jethro Bodine himself, Max Baer Jr., stars in the drive-in classic (and surprise hit) ''Macon County Line'' (May 6). A collection of James Stewart westerns (May 20) includes ''Destry Rides Again'' and Anthony Mann's ''Winchester '73.'' A beloved grindhouse subgenre gets a workout in the exquisitely titled ''Women's Prison Massacre'' (May 20), starring the sleaze film staple Laura Gemser. That same day sees the release of John Irvin's underrated Vietnam drama, ''Hamburger Hill.'' King Hu's wonderful martial arts drama ''Come Drink With Me'' (which some might say was lifted for ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon''), starring the great Cheng Pei Pei, receives its first American release (May 27). Also that day a box of films by the Italian horror master Dario Argento includes ''Phenomena,'' which stars Jennifer Connelly and a razor-wielding monkey. Criterion releases the deluxe fantasy ''The Thief of Bagdad'' (May 27), starring Conrad Veidt and Sabu. The ferocious Asia Argento is the jittery center of Olivier Assayas's knockout globe-trotting thriller ''Boarding Gate'' (June 3). On June 17, Criterion releases an early (and uncharacteristic) Claude Sautet film, the noir ''Classe Tous Risques,'' with a superb performance by Lino Ventura.

EDERSHEIM--Maurits Ernst . The Board of Directors, officers and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Maurits Edersheim. Mark's philanthropic inspirations were far-reaching, and included a genuine commitment to the State of Israel and to expanding the field of neuroscience. His generous support for Tel Aviv University's Levie-Edersheim-Gitter Institute for Functional Brain Imaging is advancing brain research that will touch the lives of many in years to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Claire, and to the entire family. William F. Cohen, Chairman Roni Krinsky, President

FILLED with behind-the-scene photographs and memorabilia, the rock 'n' roll books of Genesis Publications have long been collector's items for music fans. More recently, they've become big with the fashion crowd. ''For a designer, like me, with a rock 'n' roll leaning, there is no better source of inspiration,'' said John Varvatos, who was given the Jimi Hendrix book as a gift and now sells several of the beautifully hand-bound monographs in his new Bowery Street boutique. As does Marc Jacobs, who stocks the Queen and Elvis Presley editions in his Los Angeles store; and Paul Smith, who last fall hosted a launch party for the David Bowie book ''From Station to Station'' in his Fifth Avenue outpost. ''Pages from the Ziggy Stardust book always seem to end up on my image board,'' the designer Sue Stemp said. ''Nothing tops it for some glam rock inspiration.''

New York likes to bill itself as the entertainment capital of the world. But it apparently has a more nefarious distinction among people in the film industry: the piracy capital of the world. To fight the flourishing underground movie-counterfeiting operations in the state, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has proposed stiffening the penalties for illegally recording a movie. He is also adding a special assistant attorney general to coordinate antipiracy law enforcement. The proposal would also broaden the current law to include recordings of concerts and Broadway shows. (See Mr. Cuomo's news release.)

A subsidized ferry route from Rockaway to Lower Manhattan, via Brooklyn, will begin next week as part of the city's plan to expand water service, the mayor and City Council announced this afternoon.While tourist service has been profitable, the companies have long struggled with the economics of commuter ferry service, especially with the escalating cost of fuel. Ferry companies have long complained that despite the number of the city's waterways, intracity water services -- with the exception of the Staten Island ferry -- gets nowhere near the level of city subsidies that the subway and bus systems receive.

One of the great things about this novel is that it matters so little whether or not one recognizes a "parturition theme" near the end of Chapter 8, or cares to examine correspondences between Ruth and Melville's Ishmael as narrators. Such insights, and the wonderful "allusions" to 19th-century writers provided by Steve, do enhance my enjoyment of the book. But as slight as it is, this book seems inexhaustible, always welcoming further exploration. Robinson is a hospitable writer, even if her work demands an attentiveness that is increasingly hard to come by, not only for the iPod kids but for older adults who are often too harried and distracted to sit and read. Turning off the television can help, but it's not enough. C.S. Lewis discouraged even the reading of periodicals, as he felt that they had a bad effect on our capacity to pay attention, to take the long view.

I've been skeptical of some of the alleged evils of petroleum, but I bought into the recently popular idea among development experts that reserves of oil and other natural resources are a curse to many countries. What I saw while reporting in Iraq jibed with academic studies concluding that a wealth of natural resources did a country more harm than good. It was an appealing and clever counterintuitive idea -- but perhaps too clever by half.
The Chicago Symphony Orchestra has lured Riccardo Muti, one of a dwindling band of podium eminences.
Kevin J. O'Brien reports:
ABC has canceled the two-year-old dramedy "Men in Trees," TV Guide reports. The final episodes will begin airing May 28.

Broadcasting & Cable: "Warner Bros. Domestic Television Distribution will supply programming for The CW's 3 p.m. to 5 p.m. weekday block, according to a pending deal between the corporate cousins." The network will show "Judge Jeanine Pirro" (left) from 3 to 4, followed by a comedy block featuring "The Wayans Bros." and "The Jamie Foxx Show."
It's the last day of campaigning before the primaries in Indiana and North Carolina, and both Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama are splitting their days in both states.
Researchers created a map linking different diseases to the genes they have in common.

The federal government released a list of 66 people who have died in immigration custody from January 2004 to November 2007, Nina Bernstein of The Times reports. The list came in response to a freedom of information request filed by the paper.

Bank of America is likely to renegotiate its deal to buy Countrywide Financial down to the $0 to $2 level or completely walk away from it, said Friedman, Billings, Ramsey, which downgraded Countrywide to "underperform" from "market perform," according to Reuters.

Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, walked away from a Yahoo deal on Saturday still looking for an answer to his company's fundamental problem: its time-tested recipe for success isn't working against Google, the leader in the current wave of Internet computing.
The Rangers' season is over, but rather than lament the end, here's your chance to comment on it.

Yahoo's chief executive, Jerry Yang, and his team, were reportedly exchanging high-fives when they learned of Microsoft's decision to withdraw its offer to buy Yahoo for $33 a share, or approximately $47.5 billion.

Rupert Murdoch does not plan to raise his bid for Newsday in an attempt to match a higher offer from Cablevision, while Mortimer B. Zuckerman has not signaled whether he will increase his offer, The New York Times reported.

Editor's Note: Deutsche Telekom has not held any discussions with Sprint Nextel and people close to the company say the chances of it bidding for it are low. They cited the two companies' differing technology -- GSM (T-Mobile) vs CDMA(Sprint) -- and Sprint's own troubles as reasons Deutsche Telekom may not pursue an offer.

Prosecutors in the Eastern District of New York in Brooklyn are stepping up their scrutiny of players in the subprime mortgage crisis, focusing on Wall Street firms and mortgage lenders, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Warren E. Buffett is about to make a whirlwind tour of Europe looking for large family companies that might want to become part of the $120 billion Berkshire Hathaway empire.
Getty Images' shares rose Friday, as investors seemed to grow more confident that it will clear the financial hurdles for its $2.4 billion buyout by Hellman & Friedman.
While it's still unclear how Yahoo shareholders will react to management's decision to spurn Microsoft's sweetened $33 per-share bid, Alibaba.com shareholders have already made their feelings clear.

Sprott Asset Management's initial public offering this week will make a billionaire of the hedge fund company's founder, spurring speculation Canada's decade-old commodities boom is ending, Bloomberg News reported.
A judge on Friday tossed out retailer Charming Shoppes' effort to block two hedge funds from running for board seats next week.
Barclays has held secret talks with an investment fund backed by the Korean government as it explores potential options for raising billions of pounds in fresh capital, The Telegraph reported.
Drug developer Bristol-Myers Squibb said Friday it would sell its therapy and surgical care unit for $4.1 billion to two private equity firms.
JPMorgan Chase does not expect the U.S. financial crisis to end soon and will remain very cautious, its chief executive told German weekly Welt am Sonntag.

The Minneapolis Star Tribune said Sunday that it has hired the Blackstone Group to evaluate its finances, following a report in The New York Post that the newspaper is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy and its creditors may take control.

This week, my Shifting Careers column for The Times's online Small Business section is a conversation with Alison Link, an academic and consultant who works with people to improve the leisure aspects of their lives. While leisure might conjure up images of foamy drinks with umbrella straws and visits to day spas, Ms. Link spends much of her time studying about and working with incarcerated or formerly incarcerated people and at-risk youth.

Cellulosic ethanol producer Range Fuels has heaped more than $50 million extra onto a $100 million round, picking up the support of Passport Capital, Morgan Stanley Capital Group and others, VentureBeat reported.

The largest lender in Malaysia, Malayan Banking, also known as Maybank, has bought a strategic stake in MCB Bank of Pakistan for $680 million, betting on a brighter economic future for the troubled frontier state.
Colony Capital and Eurazeo said they plan to increase their stake in Accor, Europe's biggest hotel owner, to 30 percent.

Two big Clear Channel Communications shareholders are injecting themselves into the heated dispute between six Wall Street banks and the private-equity firms that agreed to buy the radio giant for $27 billion, The New York Post reported.
Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley are seen as front-runners for being appointed global coordinator of the initial public offering of German rail operator Deutsche Bahn, Handelsblatt reported.
Iamba Networks has raised $7 million in in funding to expand its business of making chips and software for telecommunications companies.

The Italian dairy group Parmalat will pay out stock worth about 24 million euros to settle a U.S. class-action lawsuit stemming from its collapse in the biggest bankruptcy in Europe, the company said Friday.

A court ruling Friday requiring AOL, Yahoo and RealNetworks to pay as much as $100 million in licensing fees to the American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers could impose new financial costs on online music start-ups, The Deal.com said.

Perhaps you may have noticed that the thoughts, observations and quotations of Rick Peterson, the Mets' pitching coach, have been appearing less frequently in articles, both in The Times and in other publications. He has always been a reliable source of information - on the art of pitching and in general - but Peterson is the only uniformed member who does not directly grant interviews. All requests must go through Jay Horwitz, the Mets' PR honcho.

Now that he has been traded to the Dallas Cowboys, the former Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones has put his house in Franklin, Tenn., on the market. According to this Associated Press report and this story on a Nashville television station's Web site, the 30-acre property has a 3,000-square-foot home, a two-acre lake stocked with fish, two barns and a garage.
The death last week of Albert Hofmann, the discoverer of LSD, brings several flashbacks to mind.
The Target Corporation said that it had struck a deal to sell an interest in credit card receivables to JPMorgan Chase for an initial investment of $3.6 billion.
General Motors workers who build one of the company’s most popular and important vehicles at a plant in Kansas went on strike after they were unable to reach an agreement on local work rules.
U.S. service industries suffered a slowdown in activity in April, but service companies also appeared to add jobs, the first time this year that their payrolls expanded, a survey showed.

Phil Kessel had a hat trick and the United States scored three power-play goals in a 5-1 win over Slovenia in a preliminary round game at the world championships Sunday night in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Next up for the United States is a matchup Tuesday with Canada, which beat Latvia, 7-0. Both are 2-0, and the winner will get the top spot for Group B.
An explosion at an International Paper Company mill in Redwood, Miss., was the first accident “of its kind in the mill’s 40-year history,” the company said.
In Newark’s South Ward, where urban decay is going head to head with rejuvenation efforts, a double killing elicited little more than weary shrugs from some residents.

Dany Heatley had a goal and three assists to lead Canada to a 7-0 win over Latvia in a preliminary-round game of the world championships Sunday in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Heatley moved past Steve Yzerman as Canada’s top career scorer at this event in the modern era. He has 40 points in 36 world championship games.

Fernando González captured his 10th career title and second of the year at the BMW Open in Munich by beating Simone Bolelli, 7-6 (4), 6-7 (4), 6-3. The second-seeded González wasted two match points while leading, 5-4, in the second set in the clay-court match. He went on to win after breaking Bolelli’s serve for the first time at 2-2 in the final set.

CSKA Moscow won its sixth Euroleague championship, as Trajan Langdon, the most valuable player, scored 21 points in a 91-77 victory over Maccabi Tel Aviv in Madrid. CSKA beat Maccabi in the final for the second time in three years and is two titles behind Real Madrid, which has eight.
Real Madrid and Bayern Munich won their respective league titles despite less-than-stellar performances.

Denis Watson birdied the final hole to win the FedEx Kinko’s Classic, taking advantage of Nick Price’s back-nine errors in Lakeway, Tex. Watson, from Zimbabwe, closed with a three-under 69 to finish at 10 under. He earned $240,000 for his second victory of the year and fourth over all on the Champions Tour.

Rafael Nadal won his fourth straight Barcelona Open title with a 6-1, 4-6, 6-1 victory over second-seeded David Ferrer. Nadal’s 21st straight win at the tournament improved his record to 20-1 in clay-court finals, including 4-0 at Barcelona. The second-ranked Nadal has won 103 of his last 104 matches on clay. Nadal, the three-time French Open champion, will go for a fourth straight Masters Series title in Rome, starting Monday.

The Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt ran the second-fastest 100 meters ever, finishing in 9.76 seconds at the Jamaica International Invitational in Kingston. Bolt’s time at the National Stadium on Saturday was 0.02 off Asafa Powell’s world record. “I was definitely surprised when I saw the time,” Bolt said. “I was in shape for a 9.85.”.

BENNETT--Dorothy. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of a cherished, distinguished leader of the communities of Greenwich and Stamford, CT, and beyond, who played an important role together with her husband and partner in life and business, Carl Bennett, and as Yeshiva University Benefactors. They established the Carl and Dorothy Bennett Chair in Pastoral Psychology in honor of Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz at our Wurzweiler School of Social Work, as well as a major scholarship in their names at our Sy Syms School of Business. Heartfelt condolences are extended to our longtime friend Carl Bennett and to their children, Marc (and Katy Meyers) Bennett, of Stamford, and Bruce (and Jennifer) Bennett, of Rochester, NY, and Robin (and Joseph) Kanarek, of Greenwich, their five grandchildren, and Dorothy's sister, Florence Caplan, of Williams Island, Florida. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees

MARCIN WASILEWSKI TRIO ''January'' (ECM) These days an advanced jazz musician can have listened to ECM records since the womb. That label hangs imposingly over jazz, not just for its nearly 40 years of back catalog, but as one current ideal of contemplative improvised music: the deep echo and churchly silences of its records.

HOFFMAN--Philip. The Yeshiva University family joins in mourning the loss of a respected member of the Columbus, Ohio Jewish community. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Sonia, her children and family, to his sisters, Mildred and Annette Hoffman, and to our longtime esteemed Benefactors, his brother and sister-inlaw, Martin and Geraldine Schottenstein Hoffman, and their family. May all their loved ones be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees

HILL--David N., 73, passed away on May 4th, defying all odds for four years. He was a pillar of strength to all who really knew him. Cherished husband, best friend and business partner of Pat, loving father of Jean and Douglas. Graduate of the US Merchant Marine Academy, he was an engineer who fell in love with designing and manufacturing costume jewelry. In 1979 he merged his company with 115-year-old Ciner Fashion Jewelry, the last of the oldtime jewelry manufacturers to continue today as a family business. He was an avid golfer who never stopped searching for that perfect swing. His sisters Carol and Joanne and brother Curtis survive him. Family will be at home Tuesday evening.
COLEMAN--Janet M., May 5, 2007 and Martin S., May 24, 2000 -always in our hearts

GROSSMAN--Dr. Marvin (Marc), 88, of New Bern, North Carolina and Venice, Florida, formerly of New York City, died May 2, 2008. Beloved husband of Joanne; father to David, Howard, Laurie and Maria; grandfather to Peter, Robin, Jae, Sarah, Joshua, Robert, Daniel, Olivia, Corey, Harrison, Samuel and Justin; great-grandfather to Benjamin, Zoe and Jackson. Dentist for 64 years, trusted and adored by his patients and colleagues, veteran of Army Air Force, WWII, poker player extraordinaire, cherished friend, lover of life. Most of all, head of our family, our idol and our rock. We will miss him so. Service at 1:00, Tuesday, May 6, 2008, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

Frank Whiteley Jr., the thoroughbred racing Hall of Famer who trained the brilliant but ill-fated filly Ruffian, died Friday in Camden, S.C. He was 93. His death was announced by the New York Racing Association.

Polls conducted in late April showed a very tight race between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama in Indiana, and a tightening contest in North Carolina. Both states hold their primaries Tuesday. In North Carolina, two polls conducted last week showed Mr. Obama with a seven-point edge. A poll conducted in the state earlier in the month by The Los Angeles Times had found Mr. Obama with a lead almost twice as large. A poll conducted April 23-24 by Research 2000 for clients in Indiana found likely Democratic primary voters evenly divided between the candidates. That is essentially unchanged from their poll earlier in the month.

PFLUGER--Leonard C., of Long Beach, NY on May 2, 2008. Loving father of Leonard Jr. (Claudia) and George (Crystal). Adored grandfather of Shannon, Shane, Chase. (Sundance) FLYING: CONFESSIONS OF A FREE WOMAN (2006) In this six-part documentary, Jennifer Fox, above, weaves together experiences from her own life over three years -- ages 42 to 45 -- with those of female friends around the world. The result is a series of conversations with women in 17 countries, among them South Africa, Russia, Cambodia, Pakistan, France, Britain and Germany, during which a camera is passed back and forth amid candid discussions of love, sex, relationships, expectations and desires. The series will be shown two episodes at a time on Mondays, beginning with ''No Fear of Flying,'' a frank analysis of the permutations of sex, and at 10, ''Test Piloting,'' an examination of motherhood. 8 P.M. Traffic to Web sites for musicians rises and falls with news and releases. On April 29 Coldplay, with singer Chris Martin, above, was on top. On April 30 it fell to No. 4. The popularity of Def Leppard on April 29 revolved around ''Nine Lives,'' which was released through the video game Guitar Hero III. New Kids on the Block rose because the band announced a reunion and concert tour. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The British border agency is appealing for a second time to keep the rapperSnoop Dogg, below,out of the country, the BBC reported. The agency maintains that ''a material error in law'' was made at Snoop Dogg's hearing in January, when he was cleared to enter Britain by an immigration judge who said he found no evidence that Snoop Dogg was responsible for any public disorder. Last month the agency lost its appeal of that ruling. In announcing its decision to appeal once more, a representative said, ''We will continue to oppose the entry to the U.K. of individuals where we believe there may be a risk to the public.'' The case began when Snoop Dogg, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was refused a visa for a tour after he and five members of his entourage were arrested during a reported melee at Heathrow Airport in 2006.

McFADDEN--George. Be loved husband of Carol, beloved father of Lisa Melas, Wilhelmina McFadden, and Alexander McFadden, beloved stepfather of Piers and Georgiana Moreton. Adored grandfather of Leon and Pavlos Melas. He died in a plane crash, in the Toledo Bend Reservoir, Texas, at 4pm, April 22nd. He was 67. He was the son of Alexander Bloomfield McFadden and Josephine Cutting Blair. He attended Greenvale School, St. Paul's School, Vanderbilt University and Columbia Business School. He was the Chairman of McFadden Bros. LLC. and had a long career in venture capital. Original, witty, generous, an exceptional sportsman, Mr. McFadden was a Governor of Deepdale Country Club, Trustee of the St Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, of St. Paul's School, and a Director of the Squaw Valley Ski Corporation. Tradition loving, family oriented, and erudite, he will be lovingly remembered. He is survived by his sister Mary McFadden and brother John McFadden, by his half brothers Watson Blair and Wolcott Blair, his stepfather, Watson K. Blair, his former wife Lesley Taylor, and by his many loving cousins. The Funeral Service is to be held on May 8th at 3pm, St. Thomas's Church, 1 W. 53rd St. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to St. Andrews Dune Church, Southampton, or The Alexander B. A Norman Rockwell painting depicting three umpires looking skyward as raindrops begin to fall has sent the Curtis Publishing Company in search of a favorable call from the United States District Court in Manhattan, The Associated Press reported. The company has filed suit against ESPN, seeking to bar it from rebroadcasting its television series ''The Bronx Is Burning,'' about the 1977 New York Yankees, until it withdraws its use of the painting, ''Bottom of the Sixth.'' In an e-mail message Curtis notified lawyers that ESPN did not have a license to use the painting and was committing willful copyright infringement, the lawsuit said. Court documents said that the painting was shown full screen in the second episode, ''Team in Turmoil,'' and that the series had since been sold in DVD and VHS format. Lawyers for ESPN did not immediately return calls seeking comment. The painting, one of more than 300 created by Rockwell for The Saturday Evening Post, first appeared in the April 23, 1949, issue and was donated to the National Baseball Hall of Fame & Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y.

When I wrote earlier about my travails of trying to drive the queen down to the bottom of the stack of hive boxes so she could lay her eggs in the "proper" spot, I heard the voice of my mentor: "Oh, come on! Find the queen, brush her in to the lowest box, slap a queen excluder on, and be done with it!" Besides a lifetime of experience handling bees, my mentor, who retired and moved from New Jersey to North Carolina a couple of years ago, has two things that I don't have: fearlessness when handling his hives and an ability to find the queen. Look as I might, even with my 1.50 magnifying glasses on under my bee veil, I cannot find the queen.

Recipe writers sometimes tell you to add oil to butter when sautéing to "keep the butter from burning." I never quite understood how the addition of oil would prevent the milk solids in the butter (which are what burn at low temperatures) from blackening and tasting nasty; it certainly never worked for me, and I abandoned the practice years ago. I finally looked this up in Harold McGee's "On Food and Cooking" and, well, it doesn't work: whatever is going to burn at about 250 degrees will still burn at about 250 degrees. McGee also tells us that clarified butter -- butter without the milk solids or water, hence more or less pure fat -- doesn't burn until a good 400 degrees, a far more useful temperature for frying.

Despite criticism about aggressive policing, New York City police officers stopped more people on the streets during the first three months of 2008 than during any quarter in the six years the Police Department has reported the data, Al Baker reports. The 145,098 stops from January through March - up from 134,029 during the same quarter a year earlier - led to 8,711 arrests and put the Bloomberg administration on course for the highest annual total. The numbers also reflect an increased reliance on a practice that has become an emotional flashpoint, particularly after the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell in 2006.

Senator Barack Obama and his interviewer on ''Meet the Press,'' Tim Russert, were a much bigger draw in Indianapolis on Sunday than were Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her interviewer on ''This Week,'' George Stephanopoulos. According to data from Nielsen, ''Meet the Press,'' on NBC, was viewed in 91,000 households there, a fifth of all of those watching television at the time. ''This Week,'' on ABC, was watched in 14,000 households, just 4 percent of those watching television. The margin of victory for Mr. Russert, above, over Mr. Stephanopoulos was larger than usual in Indianapolis.

WHEN I got around to reading the fine print on my most recent car rental contract, I saw that I had given my rental company the right to plead guilty to any traffic ticket I might receive, and to bill me for the cost later -- without my having any say in the matter. Here is the relevant language in the Avis contract, outlining a provision that is similar to those imposed by other car rental companies: ''You may bill all charges, parking/traffic tickets included, to the card I use for payment, without any additional signature by me on a voucher.''
Well From Tara Parker-Pope's blog, nytimes.com/well.

KLEIN--David Charles, 88, on May 4th. Beloved husband of Judy Staudenmaier, who will miss him beyond all measure, but has already started to discard his ''precious'' possessions. Also survived by daughter Kelly Klein and her partner Martha Villada, brother Paul Lincoln Klein and his wife Francene. Lifelong resident of NYC with a commitment to service and the common good. Served his country in WWII (earning 13 military decorations, including a silver star and purple heart, and retiring as Lt. Colonel) and his city through many organizations, including 25 years as chair of the Citizens Union Local Candidates Committee and DAV Commander of both Chapter 126 and NY County. He worked as an aide to U.S. Senator Robert F. Wagner and for WABC-TV as an election night commentator. As a lawyer in private practice, he did it ''his way'' for over 60 years. He leaves behind a rich legacy of love, laughter and friendship. Donations in his memory may be sent to Cornell University, P.O. 2600, Ithaca, NY 14851 for the Janet Frisch Klein Scholarship Fund (his mother). Memorial TBA. Good night, sweet prince, and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.

When Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center reopens in February after a $159 million, 22-month renovation, it will have a gleaming, three-story glass lobby; custom-made seats; and a mechanized stage extension that will allow musicians to get closer to the audience. It will also show off what it always has: a variety of music from Lincoln Center's constituent companies.

MISHKIN--Esther, nee Rubin, 84, died Sunday. Beloved wife of the late Professor Eli Mishkin, she is survived by sons Jonathan and Arnon, grandchildren Allison, Benjamin, Naomi, Pamela and Sarah, daughter-in-law Susan Fine, nephew Yoav Rubin and niece Leora Meridor. Born in Lithuania, she was held in the Kovno Ghetto during World War II. After the Shoah, she escaped through Europe to Palestine where she married and saw the birth of the State of Israel. In 1953, she and her husband moved to the US where they raised their family. She spent her career as a social worker and director of the Washington Heights office of Selfhelp Community Services. Following retirement, she volunteered in the archives of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, May 6 at 9:30 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Selfhelp Community Services or the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research. MISHKIN--Esther. The Board and staff of Selfhelp Community Services, Inc., deeply mourns the passing of our dear friend and past employee. For 26 years Esther assisted victims of Nazi persecution with professional expertise and an abundance of warmth and love. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family.
To the Editor: The pressure on students to get into an elite college (Well, April 29) extends all the way to middle school.

The area worst affected by the cyclone that struck Myanmar on Saturday is a vast and populous delta crisscrossed by canals and inlets, qualities that are likely to make the damage extensive and delivering aid extraordinarily difficult. Many villages in the delta of the Irrawaddy River are accessible only by boat or helicopter. Much of the region, former swampland that was converted during British colonial times into one of the world's largest rice-growing areas, is exceptionally fertile but difficult to traverse.
THE POST-AMERICAN WORLD By Fareed Zakaria

With sleeves rolled up and folksy on his mind, Barack Obama stepped into the Evansville Labor Temple -- a highbrow name for a barlike haunt where the walls are adorned with photos of Nascar drivers, basketball schedules and a poster celebrating the 75th anniversary of the end of Prohibition. Mr. Obama slapped backs and ambled over to a mountainous breakfast buffet long on grease. ''I've been losing weight on this campaign,'' he announced. ''I hope there are some biscuits and grits.''

He lived his life the way he designed his costumes: with grace, elegance, wit, and great humor. We are blessed to have had him in our lives.

MARZULLI--Vincent F. M.D. Jamaica Hospital Medical Center mourns the loss of our Board member, former Chairman of the Department of Surgery and former President of the Medical Staff, Vincent F. Marzulli, M.D. Widely respected as the ''go to'' surgeon, he trained a generation of Cornell surgical residents. Dr. Marzulli was adored by the entire hospital staff, and his calming influence and wisdom will be sorely missed.
