PFLUGER--Leonard C., 92, of Long Beach, New York, formerly of Sag Harbor, passed away May 2, 2008, from complications after hip surgery. Mr. Pfluger was born on December 24, 1915, in NY, New York, the son of Charles and Anna Pfluger. He married the former Irene Duggan in 1945. A veteran of World War II, Mr. Pfluger enlisted in the US Army Air Corps and proudly served his country as a tail gunner, defending his aircraft against attacks from the rear during numerous missions over Germany. A long-term interest in opticianry led him back to New York City, where he embarked on a distinguished career as a licensed optician. In 1952, Mr. Pfluger became the proprietor of Keenan & Buck Opticians, a venerable Manhattan business in operation since 1898. His reputation for excellence, accuracy, and trustworthiness helped him build and maintain a loyal customer base. Moreover, he was a dapper and charming gentleman who always had a kind word for everyone. As a result, many of Keenan & Buck's customers became long-lasting friends for almost 40 years. Upon Mr. Pfluger's retirement in 1990, his son Leonard took over at Keenan & Buck and continues to uphold the same quality standards his father had championed. Mr. Pfluger was predeceased by his wife Irene who passed away on May 25, 2007. He is survived by son George, a prominent NYC attorney, son Leonard and daughter-in-law Claudia, both licensed opticians, three grandchildren, Shannon, Shane, and Chase Pfluger, and two sisters, Helen Rice and Dorothy Pratt many beloved nieces and nephews. Calling hours are Monday and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, New York. A memorial service will be held at Macken Mortuary Wednesday at 10am, followed by burial at Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, NY.

KNUDSON--Rozanne, 75, of Sea Cliff, NY and St. Petersburg, FL died on May 3, 2008, after a brief illness. Graduate of BYU, University of Georgia, and Stamford, and teacher for 13 years. Long-time companion and literary executor of poet May Swenson. R.R. Knudson, or ''Zan,'' as she was called, was an athlete and author of over 40 books on sports and fitness, including sports novels for girls. Also co-author with Franco Colombo on weighttraining books for women and water workout manuals with Lynda Huey. In 1988, Knudson and Swenson collaborated on the anthology American Sports Poems, named as one of the top 100 best books for young adults. After Ms. Swenson's death in 1989, Dr. Knudson published two collections of Swenson's poetry. Beloved partner of Carole Berglie and loving sister to Alice Mergler, Melanie Wall, and Ellsworth and Homer Knudson.
KALLIR-FRANK--Lilian, May 6, 1931-Oct. 25, 2004. We miss you, love you, and celebrate your memory with smoked salmon and chocolate pudding. Happy 77th Birthday

ECKSTEIN--Samuel, 91, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Garden City, NY, on May 4, 2008. Known as ''Echo'' to those he grew up with as a member of the Celtics basketball club at Bronx House, he was a proud WWII veteran, avid golfer, amateur stock trader and ardent Democrat. He was a past president of the Mens Apparel Club of NYC and, as a career-long salesman for Dee Sportswear, he was trusted and admired by his colleagues and customers. Supporter of Jewish causes, Sam was an early and sustaining member of the Garden City Jewish Center. Graveside services, Wednesday, May 7, 2008 at 1:30pm, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

At least five police officers were killed in Chechnya on Sunday when a makeshift remote-controlled bomb exploded in Grozny, the capital, the authorities and local news agencies said. A separate ambush on Sunday killed a police officer riding in a convoy in the mountainous district of Vedeno. Two other servicemen were killed Saturday in a gun battle between Russian forces and as many as 30 insurgents in the Chechen village of Urus-Martan. The pace and intensity of fighting in Chechnya have declined since 2004, after the killings of prominent insurgent leaders and the consolidation of power under Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the republic's pro-Russian president. But sporadic small-scale attacks and bombings continue.

Both the prosecution and the defense rested in the trial of Antoin Rezko, a businessman and former political fund-raiser who was an adviser to Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois. While federal prosecutors spent about eight weeks building their case, the defense declined to call any witnesses. ''We do not believe the government has met their burden of proving the charges against Mr. Rezko, plain and simple,'' Joseph J. Duffy, Mr. Rezko's chief lawyer, said outside the courtroom. Among the government's final witnesses was Ali Ata, a former high-ranking state official who provided testimony after pleading guilty to lying to the F.B.I. in another case. Closing arguments in Mr. Rezko's trial are scheduled for next Monday. CATRIN EINHORN

Former President Bill Clinton had no time on Monday for his usual leisurely hourlong sessions pressing the flesh on the rope line, or for a meandering speech that could run on just as long. ''We are doing nine cities today,'' said Mr. Clinton, punching out each word as he surveyed the small crowd gathered on an airport tarmac here, just yards from where his private plane had landed minutes before. Less than an hour later, he was back on the plane, headed to Jacksonville, about 35 miles to the southwest.

KINSBRUNER--Florence, age 98, died on Saturday, May 3rd in Thousand Oaks, California, after a fall. The daughter of Samuel and Rose Reitman. Loving wife of the late Mac Kinsbruner, St. John's Wonder five, NYC Basketball Hall of Fame, General Manager of the Concord Resort Hotel. The Concord was her home for 50 years. Cherished mother of Mickey (Donna), the late Dr. Jay Kinsbruner (Karen), Susan Pashkow (Paul), beloved grandmother of Jodi Greenberg (Damian), Randy Kinsbruner (Marla), Marc Longberg, Jennifer Bush (Jeff), Mieca Kinsbruner. Great, as they called her, to Max, Emily, Jacki, Chase, Ashton and twins; Kinsey and Emma. They were her everything. She was a Montessori teacher. Survived her four younger loving brothers, she was truly the Matriarch of the family. Surviving are much loved nieces, nephews, sisters-inlaw and friends. Forever in our hearts by everyone who was touched by her. Funeral services Wednesday, May 7th at 12:30pm at the Joseph Garlick Funeral Home, 388 Broadway, Monticello NY. Burial at the Temple Shalom Synagogue Cemetery, Bridgeville NY.

To the Editor: In ''Noble Eagles, Nasty Pigeons, Biased Humans'' (Basics, April 29), Natalie Angier does an incisive job of demonstrating how fickle we are in our perception of the behavior of nonhuman animals. One thing is certain: once we label an animal a pest, be it pigeons, coyotes or Canada geese, the creatures will be unmercifully hunted, poisoned or gassed. And worst of all, when we label them as livestock, we slaughter them by the millions.

WHEN I was a little boy, my mother wanted to take my sister and me to Florida. Unfortunately, we missed our plane. It was one of those profound psychological moments that followed me into adulthood. I don't remember whether she cried, but I do know that ever since I have been interested in, and some say obsessed with, flying. When I travel, I always have work-related stuff to review. But I also am never without the O.A.G., the Official Airline Guide.

To the Editor: The evolutionary biologist and former priest Francisco J. Ayala (Scientist at Work, April 29) is one of many who claim that ''science and religion concern nonoverlapping realms of knowledge.'' But scientific and religious worldviews have been in conflict for centuries. The assertion that the two can be compatible stems from theology, not science.

With the possible exception of a few hedge fund billionaires, is anyone in America not worried about money, as the stock market settles into a state of permanent hysteria, the economy lumbers, and the cost of living leaps? So the two new plays at the center of the 11th annual Pacific Playwrights Festival here opened in a naturally sympathetic atmosphere. Both ''The Injured Party,'' by Richard Greenberg, and ''What They Have,'' by Kate Robin, consider how far men and women will push themselves -- or each other -- to get the money for what they want (or what they think they need), whether it is a house in the country or the medical treatment necessary to conceive a child.

Giant Moon completed his last major work for the Preakness this morning at Belmont Park. He went five-eighths in 1:01.04. He worked in company, and it was the sixth-fastest work of 26 at the same distance. He will have one more, lighter work at Belmont before shipping to Pimlico.

My Thursday column argues that Senator Clinton has virtually no chance of winning the Democratic nomination if she stays in the race, but a significant chance of helping Senator McCain. I'm particularly troubled by the latest exit polls in which a majority of her supporters say they will not vote for Senator Obama in the fall if he is the nominee. How seriously should we take that? Any of you Clinton fans out there who are so angry at Obama fans that you would vote for McCain -- and if so, you want to explain why?

It has been quiet at Shifting Careers this week because I took an unexpected trip to Florida for a death in my family. I was only gone three days. But because I left suddenly, I have returned to a personal and work life in chaos. Meetings and appointments missed need to be rescheduled. Deadlines that were comfortably far away are now looming. E-mail and phone messages have piled up. And since I left Florida long before processing the loss, I am trying to get back into work when my mind is still down there with my mourning relatives.

I don't want to rehash the discussion here, except to say that the column takes off from those posts to ask both whether anybody can really know what goes on in the minds of wine consumers, and whether it's really beneficial to try to strip away the context so that wine can be judged solely by what's in the glass. With all the recent talk (and writing and blogging and sermonizing) about localism -- generally speaking, an emphasis on fresh, local ingredients in cooking with an eye toward environmental conscientiousness -- it's nice to know that it's not all just chatter. And though spots like Blue Hill at Stone Barns in New York and, more famously, Chez Panisse in northern California, have cult localist followings, it's not just being preached and practiced in the coastal states. In Amsterdam, a restaurant called De Kas, in its eighth year, is turning out quality food using herbs, fruits and vegetables from its on-site nursery; meat from a local purveyor; and fresh fish caught in the nearby Wadden and North Seas.

In 2004, Zach Greinke made his major league debut at the age of 20, becoming one of the youngest players in Royals history. Selected sixth overall in the 2002 draft, he was considered a can't-miss prospect, but he never quite fit in. He soon became withdrawn and unhappy. It all came to a head in 2006 during spring training when Greinke decided to walk away from baseball.

Children in a sunflower field in Lira, Uganda. The sunflower plant is used as a natural way to control pests on the cotton farms instead of using pesticides. The pests are attracted to and eat the sunflowers instead of the cotton plants nearby. (Photo: Nicole Mackinlay Hahn)Africa may be the second largest continent, but in the fashion world, it can be pretty darned difficult to find on the map. "Most American don't know where Tunisia is," exclaims Leslie Hoffman, the executive director of the environmental organization Earth Pledge. The could soon change. "Reap What You Sew," a new interactive video installation at Barneys New York by the artist and filmmaker Nicole Mackinlay Hahn aims to connect items like Christian Louboutin pumps and Phillip B. beauty products (not to mention consumers) to their place in the African supply chain. No mean feat according to Julie Gilhart, Barneys Fashion Director. "We asked all of the buyers where their products were made, and a lot of them didn't even know," she says. Hahn spent several years traveling all over Africa, documenting people at work and at play. Some 200 clips - from the enlightening (factory workers dying fabric) to the entertaining (a group of men practicing their dance moves set to multiple versions of Toto's "Africa") - are on view on the ninth floor at Barneys through the end of May. Hahn predicts that the RFID technology she used to make her art piece (the same used to create E-Z Pass) will soon be the norm in the retail world, ushering in a new age of accountability for producers and consumers alike. And she has a point: If you could click on an image of the sweatshop where your sneakers were constructed by 11-year-olds, would you still buy them?

The "eggs," or digesters, at the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Brooklyn are going into operation. Each tank is 140 high and 80 feet wide. The eight steel eggs weigh about two million pounds apiece when empty, and it has been calculated that one may weigh up to 32 million pounds when it is processing waste. Two began running late last week; the remainder are expected to be at work by year's end.

In an evocative front-page article, Cara Buckley examines life at two sprawling, almost identical five-story former factories that face each other and sit at 248 and 255 McKibbin Street. Perhaps 300 people -- mostly young, white, and hip -- live in each building, from one to eight people to each loft. Few were born before the mid-1980s. Rents can range from $375 for one person to roughly $800 for a space. "To spend a few days at the McKibbin lofts is to experience what it is to be young, hungry for acceptance, and willing to put up with just about anything in order to gain a foothold in the city's competitive, and thriving, underground art and music scenes," Ms. Buckley writes. "This could have been Greenwich Village 60 years ago, or SoHo 30 years ago, or the East Village in the 1990s."

Creating the sharpest television images depends on more than just having a lot of pixels. Video engineers agree that contrast --- the ratio between the blackest black and the whitest white -- is just as critical. Other things being equal, the higher the contrast ratio, the sharper the image.

AMLER--Helene (Nini), 80, of Somers, NY and formerly of Manhattan, died on May 4, 2008. Born January 23, 1928 in Vienna, Austria. Nini is survived by her devoted husband Dr. Melvin Amler of Somers, NY. Loving children Dr. Robert Amler (Dr. Sherlita Amler) of Brewster, NY, Caroline Mechanick (Peter Mechanick) of NYC and Jennifer Goldstein (Thomas Goldstein) of Lincolnshire, IL. Also survived by seven cherished grandchildren and two cherished step - grandchildren. Predeceased by brother Stephan Rollin. Visiting Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave., Hawthorne, NY, 10532 914-769-4404 Thursday 5-8pm, where funeral services will be held on Friday 11 am. Interment Mt. Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne. In lieu of flowers donations to charity of one's choice would be appreciated.

ELLIS--Charles R., 72, of New York, NY, and Paris, France, died May 4, 2008, after a brief, brave battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife Sandi, son Kenneth Ellis; stepchildren Christopher, Shannon, Patrick, and Nicholas Moore; their spouses; and ten grandchildren. He will be deeply missed. A graduate of Princeton University, Charles began his career teaching at a preparatory school and working for Bertrand Russell, the British philosopher and activist. Charles soon found a balance between the intellectual life and concerns of making a living by turning to publishing. After successful stints in executive positions at Pergamon Press, D.C. Heath, and Elsevier Science Publishing Company, he joined John Wiley & Sons, Inc, in 1988, where he served as the President and CEO from 1990-98. A sophisticated and diplomatic man, Charles was an influential advocate for the worldwide publishing community through his work the International Publishers Association and the Association of American Publishers and on behalf of intellectual property rights; in 1998, he received the AAP's highest honor, the Curtis Benjamin Award. In lieu of flowers, donations to World Education, Inc., 44 Farnsworth Street, Boston, MA 02210 (wei@worlded.org) are requested.

WOOLNER--Gertrude. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member, Gertrude Woolner. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to Jim and their entire family. Lew Kramer, President Willa S. Rosenberg, Secretary WOOLNER--Gertrude, age 83, beautiful in every way, passed away on May 6, 2008 at Sarah Neuman Center. Trudy was the loved and loving wife of Jim Woolner since July 1945 and was adored also by Dan Woolner of Vail, Colorado, Steve and Andrea Woolner of Sharon, Massachusetts and their son, almost two years old James Thomas Woolner, known as J.T. She also was a close friend of Jim's sister, Mary Kaufman and Jim's brother, Dr. William Woolner and all the nieces and nephews who idolized her. Trudy and Jim's eldest son Jim Jr. died in 1998 and is remembered every day. Trudy was born in Peoria, Illinois, grew up in Chicago, graduated from Francis Parker School and was accepted by Smith, Vassar and Wellesley. She graduated from Smith in 1946 after marrying Jim in July, 1945 when the 95th Infantry Division was brought home from the ETO through the U.S. on its way to the invasion of Japan. Fortunately President Truman ordered the atomic bombs dropped, ending World War II. Trudy went back to Smith to graduate since Jim didn't get out of the army until November 1946. Trudy worked for The League of Women Voters for two years in New York City and then taught Remedial Reading at the Edgewood School in the Scarsdale School System for 22 years, which she loved. Fairview Country Club in Greenwich was the center of her social life, a place she loved and where she was an active member since 1946, playing a lot of Tennis year-round as well as bridge. She became a proficient skier and went to Vail almost every year from the early 60s until 1980. Trudy and Jim took nine White Water River wilderness trips in Oregon and Idaho with friends from Portland, Oregon. These trips averaged five days and the trip through rivers in British Columbia was 13 days of what was called ''BigWater'', camping along the shore each night on every trip. Trudy and Jim visited Russia, Afghanistan, Nepal, India and Hong Kong in 1970 with Jim Jr. and went to China for two weeks on business in 1976 when only 500 Caucasians per month could get Visas. They also took Dan and Steve on a trip to Japan, Thailand, Malaysia and Hong Kong in 1975. She had her guide take her to elementary schools in almost every country she visited. Funeral Services for Trudy will be held on Friday May 9th, 12 Noon. at Temple Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, New York (914) 967-4382.
WINTER--Marvin. You are in our hearts. We remember you every day. Your family

LESBERG--Eileen, of Lloyd Neck, New York, formerly of Swan's Nest, Water Mill, died May 3, 2008 peacefully and with grace at the age of 79. Eileen was the founder of World Wide Specialty Programs, Inc., formerly World Wide Facilities, Inc. Eileen was the pioneering force in the niche industry of insurance for staffing firms, and the leader in that field for over 40 years. Her life was filled with many passions, animals, her business, friends. It was a privilege to know her and those who did will never forget her. Eileen was a woman of consummate taste and enthusiasm. She continues to be an inspiration to all who knew her. She is survived by a close and loving family of friends, employees and Charlie. Donations in her memory may be made to the College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University, or Friends of CRG on behalf of the students of Mulvihill-Lynch School of Irish Dance, 1800 Middle Country Rd, Centereach, NY 11720.

FLECK--Ruth Melchior, 89, of South Orleans, died peacefully at Cape Cod Hospital on May 1, 2008, surrounded by her daughters. Ruth Fleck grew up in the Netherlands and immigrated to the United States with her beloved husband, G. Peter Fleck, in 1941. A long-time resident of New Jersey, she was active in the First Unitarian-Universalist Church of Plainfield where she built life-long friendships. She and her husband moved to Cape Cod in 1974. A gifted photographer, she also worked at Monomoy Community Services and coordinated volunteers for Hospice of Cape Cod. With her husband, she was very active in the Unitarian - Universalist churches of Brewster, Chatham, and Provincetown. Ruth Fleck's kindness and generosity touched many lives. She had a talent for recognizing and appreciating what was special in each individual. She was preceded in death by an infant son, and by her husband of sixty years. Her daughters Ann Fleck - Henderson, Andrea Fleck Clardy, and Marjorie Fleck Withers survive her, as do six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, May 31, at First Parish Brewster, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Cape Cod.

TRUESDALE--Philemon E., Jr., ''Pete'', of Westport, MA, died Saturday, May 3, 2008 in New Bedford, MA at age 85. He was the husband of Nancy (Clemens) Crosby of New Bedford, MA, the late Patricia (Short) Truesdale and former husband of Mary (Skidmore) Truesdale of New York City. Born in Fall River, MA, he was a graduate of The Middlesex School and attended Harvard College, Class of 1944. During World War II he flew 36 missions in the European Theater in a B-26 for the United States Army Air Corps with the 9th Air Force 387th Group, receiving the Air Medal with 6 Oak Leaf Clusters, the African Middle Eastern Service Medal and the Distinguished Unit Badge. As a resident of New York City for 40 years, he founded, owned and operated the Truesdale Chemical Sales Company. Mr. Truesdale was a member of The Harvard Club in New York and Boston, The Chemist Club of NYC, The Short Hills Club and the Baltusrol Golf Club. He was former chairman of the Referees Committee of the United States Squash Racquets Association. Surviving in addition to his wife are his daughters Barbara Wisbach of Westport, MA, Cynthia Krause and her husband Dr. William of New Hartford, NY and New York City, his son Philemon E. III and his wife Barbara of New Rochelle, NY, two sisters, nine grandchildren, three great grandchildren and was predeceased by two sisters and two brothers. His Memorial Service will be held Saturday, May 17, 2008 at 12:00pm in United Congregational Church, The Commons, Little Compton, RI. Memorial contributions may be made to Fall River YMCA, 199 No. Main St. Fall River, MA 02720 or Westport Fishermans Assn. P.O. Box 83, Westport Point, MA 02791. Services in the care of Waring-Sullivan Home of Memorial Tribute, Fall River, MA

Marzulli, M.D. Widely respected as the ''go to'' surgeon, he trained a generation of Cornell surgical residents. Dr. Marzulli was adored by the entire hospital staff, and his calming influence and wisdom will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Grace, his children and his grandchildren. Neil Phillips, Chairman, Board of Trustees David P. Rosen, President & C.E.O. Antonietta Morisco, M.D., President of the Medical Staff

MISHKIN--Esther. The Board of Directors and staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the passing of Esther, our dear friend and colleague, mother of YIVO Trustee Jonathan Mishkin. A social worker by profession, Esther was also a devoted volunteer for many years. In 2007 she received YIVO's ''Me'Dor Le'Dor'' Award along with her sons Jonathan and Arnon. She was a survivor of the Kovno ghetto, who helped establish the YIVO Women's Committee. Esther will be remembered by all at YIVO for her love of yidishkayt, and Israel, her intelligence, strength of character, and warmth. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her family. She will be sorely missed. May her memory be a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Carl J. Rheins, Exec. Director

ECKSTEIN--Samuel, 91, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Garden City, NY, on May 4, 2008. Adoring husband of 63 years to Beatrice, loving father of Randi, Laurie and sonin-law Abe Gorelick, cherished grandfather of Sarah, Jordan and Molly. Dear brother - in - law, devoted uncle, and great-uncle. Beloved by his many cousins, extended family and friends. Known as ''Echo'' to those he grew up with as a member of the Celtics basketball club at Bronx House, he was a proud WWII veteran, avid golfer, amateur stock trader and ardent Democrat. He was a past president of the Mens Apparel Club of NYC and, as a career-long salesman for Dee Sportswear, he was trusted and admired by his colleagues and customers. Supporter of Jewish causes, Sam was an early and sustaining member of the Garden City Jewish Center. Graveside services, Wednesday, May 7, 2008 at 1:30pm, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

The ''eggs,'' or digesters, at the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Brooklyn are going into operation. Each tank is 140 high and 80 feet wide. The eight steel eggs weigh about two million pounds apiece when empty, and it has been calculated that one may weigh up to 32 million pounds when it is processing waste. Two began running late last week; the remainder are expected to be at work by year's end.

9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) MARVIN GAYE: WHAT'S GOING ON From his 1960s hits to ''Sexual Healing'' in 1982, Marvin Gaye helped transform not only pop music but also the cultural landscape of America. A maverick and a sex symbol, Gaye, above, struggled with substance abuse and emotional conflict, eventually dying at the hand of his father, who shot him during a confrontation in 1984, just a day shy of Gaye's 45th birthday. This ''American Masters'' documentary traverses Gaye's troubled life through an archival interview with him; performances; and conversations with Nick Ashford, Mos Def, Lamont Dozier, Michael Eric Dyson, Berry Gordy, Gladys Knight, Martha Reeves, Smokey Robinson, Valerie Simpson and Mary Wilson, among others. Jesse L. Martin narrates. 8 P.M. (13, 49) DOPING FOR GOLD ''Secrets of the Dead'' investigates the state-sponsored doping program in East Germany during the 1970s, in which female athletes as young as 12 were given, unbeknownst to many of them, untested steroids and male hormones -- leaving some to live out their lives as men.

WOOLNER--Trudy. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of Jewish Home Lifecare extend their heartfelt condolences to trustee Jim Woolner and his family on the passing of their beloved wife, mother, and grandmother Trudy. Jim, a trustee since 1985, and Trudy were strong supporters and good friends to Jewish Home and were very involved with the Sarah Neuman Center campus in Westchester. Jim serves on the Jewish Home Lifecare Board and on the Bronx and Westchester Division Boards and on numerous board committees. The ''Walk for What Matters'' event he has chaired annually since 1994, has raised over half a million dollars for Sarah Neuman Center. Through Trudy and Jim's thoughtfulness and generosity, Jewish Home has been able to provide services and amenities that make a significant difference in the lives of our elders. Our thoughts will be with Jim and his family during their time of loss. Gene D. Resnick, MD Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

ELLIS--Charles R. Peter Booth Wiley, Chairman of the Board of Directors of John Wiley & Sons, Inc.; William J. Pesce, President and CEO; the Board of Directors; and Wiley colleagues around the world are greatly saddened by the death of Charles R. Ellis, 72, who led our company from the difficult days of the late 1980s into the sustained period of growth and profitability that continues into the present. A publisher by temperament and trade, Ellis served as Wiley's President and CEO from 1990-98 and was instrumental in bringing about the company's revival and initiating its transition to a truly global corporation. On his watch, Wiley became profitable again; executed major strategic acquisitions including VCH Publishing Group, Alan R. Liss, and JosseyBass; was listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE: JWa); and launched its first online ventures. In the year of Charles's retirement, the Financial Times ranked Wiley as the world's 27th most respected company. Beyond his role in Wiley's resurgence, Charles has acted as an influential advocate for the worldwide publishing community. With a cosmopolitan perspective enhanced by European postings with Pergamon Press and Elsevier in his pre-Wiley days, Charles was President of the International Publishers Association. He was also Chair of the Association of American Publishers from 1992-94; in 1998, he received the AAP's highest honor, the Curtis Benjamin Award. He was an avid supporter of the Digital Object Identifier, a code embedded in digital content that helped lay the groundwork for publishing online; and worked tirelessly on behalf of intellectual property rights. Those fortunate to have known and worked with this charming, gracious, and diplomatic man will miss him terribly. On behalf of the entire Wiley community, we extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Sandi, and their family. In lieu of flowers, donations to World Education, Inc., 44 Farnsworth Street, Boston, MA 02210 (wei@worlded.org) are requested.

How the polls were conducted The Indiana and North Carolina exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters in each state's primary election. All the Indiana voters and most of the North Carolina ones were sampled as they left 35 primary election locations throughout each state on Tuesday. The polls were conducted by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J., and Mitofsky International of New York City for the National Election Pool, which consists of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News.

She is survived by husband Jay Hildebrand and sister Kay Skilton and niece Mora G. Muir. Donations preferred, Bobbi and The Strays, PO Box 170129, Ozone Park, NY, 11417.

HALL--James C. The dean, faculty, staff, and students of the Lubin School of Business at Pace University extend our heartfelt sympathy to the family and friends of James C. Hall, former Associate Dean and Director of Graduate Programs, Associate Dean for Planning and Assessment, and Professor of Management and Management Science at Lubin. Jim joined Pace in 1979 after earning his MA and Ph.D. degrees in Adult Education at the University of Chicago. He oversaw all of the Lubin School's full-and part-time graduate programs: MBA, MS, EMBA, and DPS; the assessment of undergraduate and graduate learning outcomes; and reaccreditation by AACSB International, The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. Typically, MBA classes focus on single disciplines like accounting, finance, or marketing. Jim was one of a team of six faculty members who designed and implemented Lubin's problem - centered Executive MBA program (EMBA), lauded by the AACSB Peer Review Team as ''highly innovative, ahead of its time, and unique in the marketplace.'' The approach has become a touchstone for Lubin instruction. Jim was, above all, a teacher who enjoyed nothing more than being in the classroom. Lubin and Pace have become far richer institutions of learning for his involvement and guidance, and he will be remembered for his positive impact on the way business schools teach. He will be greatly missed. Jim's wife, Julia, survives him, as do his stepchildren, Julia Ashenhurst of Chicago, Illinois; Martha Ashenhurst-Lundin of LaGrange, Illinois; David Ashenhurst of Oberlin, Ohio; and John Ashenhurst of Yonago, Japan; and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Pace's downtown New York City campus, in the lobby of the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, on Wednesday, May 28, from 4pm to 6pm. A fund is being created in Jim Hall's memory to benefit graduate program development. If you would like to contribute, please send a check drawn to Pace University to the attention of Dean Joseph R. Baczko, Lubin School of Business, Pace University, 1 Pace Plaza, New York, NY 10038.

HEYL--Lawrence, Jr. (b. October 1919), co-founder of the Princeton Hot Club, and longtime resident of Nyack, NY, died on May 5, after a long illness. The only child of Bertha and Lawrence Heyl (Associate Librarian at Princeton University), Larry was a graduate of Princeton Country Day, Lawrenceville, and Princeton (class of 1940). He joined the 9th Division of the Army in January 1941, landing at Normandy on June 12, 1944, following training in England, where he met a British private, Jean, at a dance in Winchester. They married four years later in NYC, while he was Associate Editor of Theatre Arts. Larry was a skilled photographer in the style of Cartier-Bresson, capturing the lives, in black and white, of his family, friends and Rockland County artists. He served on the boards of the Rockland Foundation and Edward Hopper House, and edited Nyack in Black & White (2005). Larry spent most of his career in the oil industry, first at Texaco and API, and then at Mobil, heading Investor Relations. A foe of artifice, prejudice, solecisms, superstition, and poor lighting, Larry is deeply missed by Jean, his wife of 60 years (now of Kendal in Sleepy Hollow), his two surviving children, Margery Heyl (director of Nonotuck Community School in Northampton, MA.) and Dorothy Heyl (a lawyer at Milbank Tweed) and their husbands, and his five grandchildren, Julie and Molly Heyl-Rushmer, Regina Heyl DePietro, and Emily and Gregory Nichols (children of Catherine Heyl, d. 1998). In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be given to Kendal on Hudson (for the healing garden) in Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591 c/o Executive Director.

The phrase "generation gap" came into vogue in the 1960s as a way of describing the wide gulf in values, beliefs and lifestyles that emerged between baby boomers and their parents and grandparents. Indeed, this difference between younger and older people played out sometimes turbulently in the '60s in virtually all aspects of life, including the ballot box. Unlike in previous elections, from 1968 to 1980 young voters gave much stronger support to Democratic presidential candidates than did their elders.

Leaving Paris yesterday for my trip to Turkey I decided to lighten the suitcases by not taking coats or heavy sweaters. Fortunately, I decided I'd take one sweater in case it was cold on the airplane. Turkey previously hosted the race in August, remember, and I was under the impression it would be about 80 degrees Celsius in May as well. Dumb. Arriving at the track yesterday under dark, cloudy skies and very cold air temperature, I regretted my lack of winter clothes.

Once again, several New York supermarkets have been accused of not paying any wages to those friendly baggers who help shoppers pack up groceries. In years past, many city teenagers would bag groceries just for tips after school or during the summer. But supermarkets are increasingly using immigrant workers -- who often receive $1 to $4 an hour in tips -- and state officials say the law requires that these workers receive wages and not just tips. Some store owners say that the baggers are independent contractors who work for themselves. But state officials insist that they are employees who follow management's orders.

I had to laugh when I was awakened in my apartment yesterday to a bathroom flood. It was clean water (unlike the heavy-laden waters of Lake Fingerbone) overflowing the toilet tank, and it was a relatively simple matter to turn off the valve and use every towel I own to mop up the mess. But few things make a person feel so helpless as water that won't stop running over things one takes for granted, like floors. I wondered at the time if this was punishment for messing with Marilynne Robinson's fine novel.

The results keep coming in. Since we began asking for your photos back in February, hundreds of readers from San Diego to Strasbourg, Jakarta to Jersey City, have submitted images to the Polling Place Photo Project, our joint effort with the AIGA, the national association for design. The Polling Place Photo Project was created in 2006 by William Drenttel and AIGA during the midterm elections.The photos range from the quirky to the mundane - a bevy of ballot boxes, curtains, and levers - representing the far-flung corners of the nation. Often the images stray yards, perhaps miles, from the polling sites themselves, spilling out onto streets, walkways, and even cemeteries. Together they form a "voter-generated" portrait of the election season.

I'm very sad to report that the venerable, wonderful Mei Lai Wah Coffee House in Chinatown appears to have closed for good. At least that was the report at Eater.com last week, which I have no reason to doubt. Rumors that Mei Lai Wah would close have floated for more than a few years now, but apparently the continuing clampdown by the Department of Health over the last year and a half was the last straw. This is a great loss both to the Chinatown community and to occasional visitors like me.

In 1979, the photographer Jill Freedman was walking through the flower district when a young couple, leaning against a storefront's riot grating, caught her attention. The emblem of a gun on the man's shirt pointed menacingly at the woman's head. Ms. Freedman aimed her Leica M4 and captured the moment.Almost 30 years later, Mario Pesa, 55, unexpectedly discovered the black and white image of himself, entitled "Love Kills," which appeared with an April 27 article on the cover of The City section about Ms. Freedman. Mr. Pesa, who lives with a 17-year-old daughter in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, is a mail handler for the postal service. He was handed the article by a co-worker. Unaware before last week that there even was a photograph, he said, "I recognize the shirt, but I'm not sure who took this picture."

The perfect state of mind for our Hockey Nighters who blog in support of the rival teams from -- how apt -- the battleground state of Pennsylvania. Warner Music Group struck a minor chord with investors Thursday: The private-equity-backed company reported a wider loss for the second quarter -- $37 million compared with $27 million during the same period of 2007 -- and suspended its dividend in what it described as an effort to maintain "financial flexibility."
Officials in Moscow have devised a novel strategy to handle an onslaught of British soccer fans for a championship game: Give them barely a chance to set foot on Russian soil.

There is a class of fragrance that lies somewhere between perfume and scent. On the one hand, there are classical perfumes - multifaceted works of olfactory art, based on ideas and built with complexes of raw materials, in styles as varied and intellectualized as pointillism and expressionism. On the other, aromatherapy - mono-themed smells, generally built in minimalist (if not inchoate) style and structure, meant simply to hypnotize like the single, pulsing tone of a Buddhist bowl, lulling into a state of non-thought. Where perfumes seek to convey ideas, aromas are designed to produce the opposite outcome, intentionally tamping down thought: the scent concept of being free of scent concepts.
A symbiotic relationship has developed between the presidential campaigns and the entertainment press, Julie Bosman reports in Thursday's New York Times.

Twice now on City Room, David W. Dunlap has written about the winking, thumbs-up, Italian chef statue that guards the entrance to many a cafe, trattoria and restaurant in New York and other cities. Last October, after a vacation in Rome, Mr. Dunlap invited City Room readers to guess which of four chefs was the real Roman, and last month, he pointed out another sighting of the chef, this time on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

E.S. Lamoreaux III won four national television Eclipse Awards and was a founding producer and the long-time executive producer of "CBS News Sunday Morning with Charles Kuralt." He reflected on Ruffian's death for The Rail.
Having lost the use of his legs at four years old, Joshua George has gone on to become one of the top wheelchair athletes in the world.

Even a benign lesion on a mammogram makes women and doctors nervous, and doctors sometimes recommend a biopsy anyway. But new data show that waiting six months for a follow-up mammogram is a safe option.

In the great hunt for superdelegates, there is no better place to look than the floor of the House, and Senator Barack Obama dived right into a sea of them on Thursday morning, shaking hands, clapping backs, doling out hugs and even doing a little curtsy before Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the chairman of the Budget Committee.

Business is down at the Celeste Diner, but not because of what's on the menu. The tacos, eggs and sandwiches are as tasty as ever. The place might be quieter now, because of what's on top of it: signs urging truckers at a nearby company to join the Teamsters in an election scheduled for May 21. This year, union organizers waging a campaign against Baldor Specialty Foods in Hunts Point, paid $250 a month to perch the bilingual signs declaring "It's Your Time to Organize -- Yes We Can" on the corner diner, right where Baldor's drivers are sure to see them as they go out to deliver produce to restaurants in the metropolitan region.

CHARLESTON, W. Va. -- Beneath the Capitol Dome, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began a 20-hour, three-state campaign swing with a promise to keep campaigning despite calls for her to cede the race to Senator Barack Obama.
What we're looking at on the Web today...

The Patriot Tapes live on. The Times reported today that the league received eight tapes showing that the team recorded the play-calling signals in six games between 2000 and 2002. Not all details are known, but the question can be raised: Will the additional taping revelations affect the way people regard the accomplishments of Bill Belichick and his recent teams?
David Pogue tests Apple’s Time Capsule, which backs up your computer automatically, constantly, completely and wirelessly.

The Jockey Club has announced that it will study all aspects of safety in horse racing. I am all for exploring how we can improve our industry to benefit the horse, but I have two major concerns with the newly formed Thoroughbred Safety Committee.

Is it time for an international coalition to invade Myanmar? "The French foreign minister is making noises that sound curiously close to a humanitarian invasion," Megan McArdle notes at Asymmetrical Information, her blog for The Atlantic. She cites the report in today's Times that "the French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, suggested that the United Nations should invoke its 'responsibility to protect' civilians as the basis for a resolution to allow the delivery of international aid even without the junta's permission."

- The Daily Telegraph columnist Neil Tweedie discussing the campaign tactics of London's new mayor, Boris Johnson, and his main Conservative Party ally, the PM-hopeful, David Cameron. Both Johnson and Cameron are said to represent the new wave of post-labor political poshness. Sounds more like New Romantic.

OlivesI almost always keep a bowl of olives in the fridge; the type varies, and is often a mixture. (These, as it happens, are Portuguese, from My New Favorite Store, Xavier's in New Bedford, Mass., right down the street from Antonio's.) Every now and then I add oil to the mix, and every now and then I use the oil for cooking which, needless to say, is wonderful. A little rosemary is good, as are thyme, and sage -- alone, together, whatever. Fennel seeds, too. Lemon, orange, tangerine peel. I fish the old spices out when they look tired, and add new ones. (I don't like chiles in olives, but you could do that too.)

Following MySpace out of the penalty box of 50 state attorneys general, the social network Facebook is agreeing to a broad set of principles to protect young users from predators and inappropriate material.

As part of Generation Faithful, our ongoing series examining the lives of young people across the Muslim world at a time of religious revival, The New York Times has established an Arabic-language blog. It's hosted through the news and blogging site Al Bawaba, and will allow readers in the Middle East to read and comment on articles in our series in Arabic.
Say goodbye to the medical sitcom "Scrubs," at least on NBC.

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Hey, this Sunday is Mother's Day. Now, if you haven't gotten your mom a gift yet, can't go wrong with a gallon of gasoline, huh? It's a little pricey, but, hey, you only got one mom, you know?

Strictly defined, tandoori chicken is chicken marinated in yogurt and spices and cooked in a clay oven. But you can also think of it as chicken in a yogurt and spice sauce that is simply broiled. You can assemble the marinade in less time than it takes to preheat the broiler.
Location: Birmingham, Ala.

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Of course, another two primaries yesterday. That's the big story. Very tough night for Hillary Clinton, who says she isn't dropping out because there are still six states that haven't had their Democratic primary. That's right. Yep. Barack Obama's favored in the states of Oregon, Montana and South Dakota, and Hillary is favored in the state of denial.

Fossella, a Staten Island Republican who was arrested on May 1 in Alexandria, Va., and charged with drunken driving, issued a statement on Thursday acknowledging that he had had an extramarital affair with Laura Fay, a former Air Force lieutenant colonel, and that the two of them have a 3-year-old daughter together.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt is a writer and public relations consultant based in Norwalk, Conn. His father owned and bred Native Dancer, whose bloodline is now reported to be in 75 percent of all thoroughbreds. He also contributed to "To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory." He shares with the Rail memories of Native Dancer.
Whether it is the English Premier League or the second-tier Championship, the veteran American striker Brian McBride said he wants to stay in London with Fulham.
What will become of the TV Guide magazine and television channel? "Days after getting new owners and new editors, the long-troubled TV Guide is back on the block," Richard Perez-Pena reports.

The Jockey Club formed a Thoroughbred Safety Committee today and commissioned seven of its members to review every facet of equine health, including breeding practices, medication, the rules of racing and track surfaces. It intends to issue recommendations to be adopted by the industry to insure safety.

Last Sunday the A's and Rangers played in throwback uniforms and baseball purists (at least those that obsess over fashion) rejoiced. It was not the sight of Oakland players wearing vests or even butter cream yellow batting helmets that caused the celebration. Rather, it was the sight of seeing two teams of major leaguers wearing classic stirrup socks.

One of our astute Railbirds asked a question about trainer Larry Jones and his penchant for exercising his own horses. Jones is hardly jockey size. We took the question to Dr. Larry Bramlage, who is a partner in Rood and Riddle Equine Hospital in Lexington, Ky. He is past president of the American Association of Equine Practitioners.
I would like a two-day itinerary for the Cotswolds from London. What are the main attractions and the best towns to see? Must I rent a rent a car?

There's a lot cooking at Cablevision, the New York-based cable company. It just agreed to buy the Sundance Channel through its Rainbow Media subsidiary for nearly $500 million. It is reportedly bidding against Rupert Murdoch for Newsday, a newspaper owned by Tribune. And Cablevision recently considered buying a stake in AEG Live, the concert promoter.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- At least he got the name of the ship right.

This has been a great Beckett season in New York. In January, the fab Fiona Shaw was terrific in Deborah Warner's production of "Happy Days" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. And now John Turturro is strutting his stuff - albeit from a wheelchair - as Hamm in "Endgame," directed by Andrei Belgrader. Although Turturro has touches of Dr. Strangelove and the old guy in the orchid hothouse at the beginning of "The Big Sleep," he makes the role his own, with just the right combination of kookiness, cruelty and pathos. Max Casella excels as Clov, Hamm's co-dependent manservant, and Elaine Stritch and Alvin Epstein are quite wonderful as Nell and Nagg, popping up from their garbage cans. ("Endgame" runs through May 18 at BAM.)

A group of ardent backers of Ron Paul, the maverick congressman and Republican presidential candidate, are flocking to Paulville.org, a Web site that promises to help them set up exclusive residential enclaves open only to the like-minded -- presumably to help them replicate in the physical world the comfortable feeling they've experienced online, of being fenced-off from the rest of us.

My dim recollection of the "Housekeeping" I read in 1980 was of a wonderful saga, a comic novel about an eccentric family and a group of unforgettable woman characters. Nowadays I come away from multiple re-readings of the novel with a heavy heart. For all its pleasures, the novel is so suffused with loneliness and grief that the more I read, the sadder I get.
U.N. relief arrived on Thursday after an excruciating delay during which the junta resisted offers of large-scale help.
John Edwards's endorsement still eludes the Democratic candidates, but today one of his top advisers threw his support behind Barack Obama.

HALF MOON BAY, Calif. - There were plenty of winners at last weekend's Legend of the Motorcycle concours event and accompanying bike auction. The biggest winner, however, was Vince Martinico, an admitted pack rat, and his 1908 Indian Torpedo Tank Racer.

As if the divisions between race and gender in the Democratic Party hadn't been further exposed through Tuesday night's exit polls -- and by a very heated exchange on CNN between Donna Brazile and Paul Begala -- Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's interview with USA Today on Wednesday is further mining those tense depths.

The Hollywood Reporter: "AMC has renewed 'Breaking Bad' for a second season. The cable network ordered 13 new episodes of the series, which stars Bryan Cranston as a chemistry teacher who begins cooking up crystal meth to make some extra money after he's diagnosed with cancer."

The New York Police Department has turned over 11 years of annual firearms-discharge reports to the City Council and to the New York Civil Liberties Union, and Al Baker has set about poring through the voluminous records. In a front-page article, he highlights several of the most intriguing findings. New York City police officers fire their weapons far less often than they did a decade ago, a statistic that has dropped along with the crime rate. But when they do fire, even at an armed suspect, there is often no one returning fire at the officers. Officers hit their targets roughly 34 percent of the time.

The Moody's Corporation said Wednesday that Brian Clarkson would retire as president and chief operating officer of Moody's Investors Service.
The proxy showdown between Charming Shoppes and two activist hedge fund will come to a head on Thursday -- and no one knows how the story will end, according to The New York Post.

China's Huawei Technologies, a telecom equipment maker, is considering the sale of a multibillion dollar stake in its mobile devices unit to a foreign investor, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.
To make money, you have to move up the economic food chain into higher-value, more profitable work and markets. That economic fact of life applies to nations, companies and individuals.

Some Northern Rock shareholders are planning to challenge the British mortgage lender's nationalization by filing a request for judicial review, The Times of London reported. If successful, they could claim 2.1 billion pounds ($4.1 billion) in compensation.

The chief executives of Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines defended on Wednesday their plans to merge, telling a Senate subcommittee that the consolidation was essential to preserve jobs and service to small cities, and to compete with foreign-flag carriers. They also insisted that consumers would not suffer.
In the wake of its failed $47.5 billion takeover bid for Yahoo, Microsoft apparently sent a calling card to Facebook, the social networking site, to see if it might be up for a deal.

In the News Corporation's earnings conference call on Wednesday, Rupert Murdoch voiced skepticism that Cablevision can succeed in its bid for Newsday, which is now at the center of a tussle among three New York moguls, even as he vowed not to get into a bidding war for the newspaper.

Britain's Carphone Warehouse will sell a 50 percent stake in its retail unit to U.S. electronics chain Best Buy for 1.1 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) and they will launch a new company to expand across Europe.

JPMorgan Chase, which is buying Bear Stearns, expects to regain business from Bear clients who stopped doing business with the troubled investment bank, JPMorgan's co-chief executive of investment banking said on Wednesday.

The Healthy Beverage Company, which operates under the trade name Steaz, has raised $11 million for fairly traded, organic teas, VentureBeat reported. The funding was provided by Inventages Venture Capital and Whitefish Group, the publication said.
Giant Realm, the entertainment portal geared towards men, has received $2 million in funding from SoftBank Capital.
Albireo has closed its Series A round at $40 million.

Bear Stearns shareholders suing over the planned JPMorgan Chase takeover are dropping efforts to block the deal but will seek damages of at least $2.8 billion, an attorney for the plaintiffs said on Wednesday.
Carl C. Icahn is adding to his foothold in Motorola, now that he's won seats on the board and is getting his way.
Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.

GLG Partners, the British hedge fund manager that on Wednesday announced losses of more than $200 million for the first three months of the year, said it hoped to retain $2 billion of the once $7 billion of assets in the emerging markets funds run by star manager Greg Coffey, who resigned last month.
Days after getting new owners and new editors, the long-troubled TV Guide is back on the block.
Private equity firms are charging investors more for managing their investments and giving them back less of the fees they charge to their portfolio companies, according to a new report.
Colfax, a maker of industrial pumps and valves, said Wednesday that it has priced its initial public offering at $18 a share, giving the stock offering a total value of $337.5 million.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke to about 1,500 supporters Wednesday night at a "Generations of Women for Hillary" fund-raiser at the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington. The campaign said the event brought in close to $1 million, although the crowd was not without agitators.
It looks like Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital, which are suing a group of banks over the buyout of Clear Channel Communications, will have their day in court.
A nervous Wall Street scorned initial public offerings for months, but suddenly I.P.O.s are popular again, BusinessWeek reported.

Wall Street markets tumbled the most in nearly a month late Wednesday afternoon, casting some doubt on the staying power of the calm that has settled over investors recently after the winter's tumult. Perhaps further adding to the jittery market, Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called for stricter oversight of investment banks.

The merger advisory business is in a downturn, and Stefan Selig may know this as well as anyone. Mr. Selig, the global head of mergers and acquisitions at Bank of America, talked about the state of the market in an interview with Investment Dealers' Digest, telling the publication that 2008 might look more like 2003 in terms of announced deal volume.

The Carlyle Group and JMI Equity have agreed to buy Gemcom Software International , the largest global supplier of specialized mining technology and software, in a cash deal valued at about 180 million Canadian dollars ($178 million).

Dr Pepper Snapple Group shares began trading in New York on Wednesday at a lower-than-expected $25, indicating that U.S. investors aren't that thirsty for the country's third-largest soft drink maker.

Marsh & McLennan, which runs one of the world's largest insurance brokerage companies, posted a first-quarter loss on Wednesday after it wrote down the value of its Kroll corporate security unit by $425 million.

Germany's United Internet on Wednesday ratcheted up its opposition to a 1.63 billion euro ($2.53 billion) purchase of mobile-services group Debitel by Freenet, an Internet and cellular-service provider that United wants to buy.

Illinois Tool Works, the manufacturer of Duo-Fast nail guns and Wilsonart countertops, agreed to buy Enodis for $2.1 billion, trumping a rival offer for the British catering-gear maker from Manitowoc.

The American military is fighting daily battles for the control of Baghdad's Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City. On May 3, the Americans fired at least three missiles at a small building next door to the Sadr General Hospital. The building was identified by the U.S. military as a command center for the militia.

Massachusetts Attorney General Martha Coakley's office reached a $37 million agreement with UBS Wednesday, requiring the bank to return funds to the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority and 17 municipalities that it allegedly misled into buying auction-rate securities.

The initial public offering of Sprott Asset Management is expected to be priced early Thursday, with underwriters likely to put in the pin at 10 Canadian dollars a share, valuing the Canadian hedge fund at 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, The Globe and Mail reported.

Investors and agents in Turkey are certainly breathing a sigh of relief after the government moved quickly to reinstate the ability of foreigners to buy property. Sales to foreigners were temporarily suspended last month, in order to give the Turkish legislature a chance to rework regulations.
Hometown Baghdad, a series of videos documenting the lives of three young people in Iraq, was among the many winners at the Webby Awards announced on Tuesday. [chattheplanet.com]

Vic Zast is thoroughbred racing's only travel critic -- with a "Destinations" column in The Blood-Horse that features a five-star rating for international events. He has written about horse racing for ESPN.com, MSNBC.com and National Public Radio. He has been a participant in the sport for over 45 years and was president of Finger Lakes Racetrack and Turfway Park.

The question on everyone's lips today is whether Hillary will quit now that her chances of winning the nomination are extremely remote. She is strong. She is invincible. Or, at minimum, extremely hard to discourage.
Caryl Churchill’s “Top Girls” opened in a well-acted revival directed with intelligence and sensitivity by James Macdonald.
Hezbollah’s leader called the government’s decision to shut down its phone network an act of war.
Mr. Arnold, a gentleman crooner who took country music uptown and sold more than 85 million recordings over seven decades, was 89.

The Patriot Tapes live on. The Times reported today that the league received eight tapes showing that the team recorded the play-calling signals in six games between 2000 and 2002. Not all details are known, but the question can be raised: Will the further taping revelations affect the way people regard the accomplishments of Bill Belichick and his recent teams?.

It’s a question that crosses the mind of many triathletes: Is it possible to peak in more than one sport at once? As Gina Kolata reports today in The Times, the training necessary to excel in one sport will likely counteract what’s necessary to be good at another. But that simple fact doesn’t stop many athletes to complain about their times, saying, for example, that they aren’t running as fast as they think they should be. “I have conversations with them,” said Joel Friel, a coach and author of 10 books, including “The Triathlete’s Training Bible” (VeloPress, 2004). “Do you really want to be a triathlete? If you want to run faster you have to give up swimming and cycling.”.

In case you need reminding, and it never hurts, the gap between your life and that of a Major League Baseball player is immeasurably vast. Here are two case studies, both from this beautiful, vivid sports city we call home.

Janelle Pierson, a high school senior in Florida, has traveled like a professional athlete since her early teens, flying around the country to play in soccer tournaments. She has also suffered ruptures of the anterior cruciate ligament, or A.C.L., in both knees. In this week’s New York Times Magazine, Michael Sokolove, a regular contributor to Play, describes Pierson’s singular dedication to soccer, and how she, like so many other young female athletes and several of her teammates, has endured serious injuries. The article is adapted from Sokolove’s upcoming book, “Warrior Girls: Protecting Our Daughters Against the Injury Epidemic in Women’s Sports,” which will be published in June.

Do some elite female athletes get an advantage from having abnormal ovaries? That’s the intriguing question raised by work recently completed by scientists in Sweden. During their extensive study of all the athletes who competed for Sweden in the 2002 or 2004 Olympic Games, an anomaly emerged among the female team members that researchers believe may have improved their athleticism.
The Bank of England and the European Central Bank left their interest rates unchanged on Thursday, as they sought to balance slowing growth with inflationary pressures.
The two major central banks in Europe had to weigh the risk of high inflation against concerns about economic growth.
Toyota, which said that it would likely face an annual profit drop, is finding its profit growth in new markets.
Cliff Lee pitched seven scoreless innings on Wednesday, handing Chien-Ming Wang his first loss as he stymied the Yankees.
Unlike at the Christie’s sale, which was dominated by European buyers, at Sotheby’s Americans took home 67 percent of the work, and Europeans bought 27 percent.

Offensive tackle David Diehl signed a two-year extension with the Giants that will keep him under contract with the team through the 2013 season. Diehl, who had four years left on an extension he signed in 2005, will make $31 million under terms of the deal. Diehl has been a starter since being taken by the Giants in the fifth round of the 2003 draft.

A son of Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid was sent to state prison after admitting he smuggled 89 prescription pills into a county jail. Garrett Reid, 25, pleaded guilty to drug-smuggling charges and faces a minimum of two years in state prison. His 23-year old brother, Britt, is serving a jail sentence of 8 to 23 months for pointing a gun at a driver.
The German government shut down two groups, accusing them of spreading anti-Semitic propaganda and glorifying the Nazis.
Armed men kidnapped two female Japanese tourists near the town of Marib in Yemen, but released them hours later, local officials said.
Major Argentine airlines suspended flights to some cities in Patagonia as the huge ash cloud from the Chaitén volcano in Chile blew east into Argentina.
Health officials in China, responding to the continued spread of hand, foot and mouth disease, issued new regulations requiring all health care providers to report new cases of the disease.

London’s new mayor said that he was banning alcohol on the city’s public transportation system, effective next month, in an effort to “end the problem of drunken and intimidating behavior on the Tube.”
Xavier Nady hit a two-run homer to spoil Barry Zito’s mostly effective return to the Giants’ rotation and Phil Dumatrait pitched five and two-thirds scoreless innings for his first career victory.

The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency said Syria had an obligation to tell his agency whether the site Israeli warplanes bombed there in September was an undeclared nuclear reactor.

Plácido Polanco hit a broken-bat, tie-breaking single with two outs in the ninth against Jonathan Papelbon to lift the host Detroit Tigers to a 10-9 victory against the Boston Red Sox on Wednesday night.
The maker of luxury apparel and accessories said first-quarter revenue rose 13 percent, helped by store openings and sales of leather goods.
British American Tobacco reported a 21 percent increase in first-quarter profit, with rising global sales more than compensating for declining volumes in the United States.
The brewer, which makes Carlsberg and Tuborg beer, posted a loss of 129 million kroner ($27 million) compared with a profit of 45 million kroner a year earlier.
India has expanded bans on trading of food futures as the government intensifies efforts to cool inflation that is at the highest level in more than three years.

Usain Bolt of Jamaica is aiming toward a 100-meter showdown with the reigning world champion Tyson Gay at the Reebok Grand Prix on May 31 in New York, according to Bolt’s coach, Glen Mills. No official announcement was made by the Grand Prix, but Mills said Bolt “is scheduled to race Tyson Gay in New York.” Bolt was timed in the second-fastest 100 in history at the Jamaican International Invitational in Kingston on Saturday. His 9.76 was 0.02 seconds off the world record held by his fellow Jamaican Asafa Powell.

Recapturetheglory, fifth in the Kentucky Derby, will challenge the Derby winner Big Brown in the Preakness Stakes on May 17. “We’re there to win,” the co-owner Ronnie Lamarque said from New Orleans. “Big Brown is a bear, but we’re not going to run in it to run second. I’ll look at all the other entrants. They don’t scare me at all, and I believe our horse definitely belongs and we feel like the Preakness is our kind of race.”.

Paul Maurice was fired as coach of the Maple Leafs on Wednesday after Toronto failed to make the playoffs during his two years. The dismissal was the first big move in what is expected to be an active off-season for the team. The Maple Leafs finished 12th in the Eastern Conference with a 36-35-11 record and missed a playoff spot by 11 points. They are looking for a full-time general manager after firing John Ferguson in January. Cliff Fletcher is the interim G.M.

The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame, which chose 13 players and 2 coaches from major colleges last week, added 4 players and 2 coaches from smaller colleges. The players were defensive end John Randle of Texas A&M-Kingsville (1988-89), quarterback Jim Ballard of Mount Union (1991-93), linebacker Ronald McKinnon of North Alabama (1992-95) and halfback Brad Rowland of McMurry (1947-50). The coaches were W. C. Gorden of Jackson State (1976-91) and Doug Porter of Mississippi Valley State (1961-65), Howard (1974-78) and Fort Valley State (1979-96).

Local governments and state universities cannot offer health insurance to the partners of gay workers, the State Supreme Court ruled. The court ruled 5 to 2 that Michigan’s 2004 ban against same-sex marriage also blocks domestic-partner policies affecting gay employees at the University of Michigan and other public-sector employers. The decision affirms a February 2007 appeals court ruling. Up to 20 public universities, community colleges, school districts and local governments in Michigan have benefit policies covering at least 375 gay couples.

Federal prosecutors violated the rights of victims of a deadly 2005 explosion at a BP plant when they did not consult them about a plea agreement to settle criminal conduct in connection with the blast, a three-judge panel of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled. The panel did not block the deal, but sent the case back to a Houston judge and asked that she fully consider the victims’ objections before deciding whether to accept the agreement. A company spokesman, Neil Chapman, declined to comment. The deal, in which a BP subsidiary would plead guilty to a violation of the Clean Air Act, includes a $50 million fine and three years’ probation. Family members of those killed and injured argue that federal sentencing laws allow the fine to be as high as $3.2 billion. The explosion killed 15 people and injured more than 170 in Texas City, about 40 miles southeast of Houston.

A lesbian couple from Englewood was found guilty of trespassing by a Denver jury, in a case stemming from a brief sit-in they staged on Sept. 24, when the Denver Clerk and Recorder’s Office refused to grant them a marriage license. The couple, Sheila Schroeder, left and Kate Burns, had sought to overturn Colorado’s ban on same-sex marriage, contending that it violated their right to equal protection, but Judge James B. Breese of Denver County Court told the six-woman jury to focus on the trespassing charge. The women will each have to pay $41 in court fines and serve 28 hours of community service. “This was an excellent opportunity for them to stand proudly as Americans and exercise their First Amendment rights to protest what they believe was an unfair law that treated people unequally,” said Mari Newman, a lawyer for the couple.

Ten Tulane University fraternity members faced felony charges and the university suspended the Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity after accusations that the group burned pledges with hot water and pepper spray during a “hell night” initiation. “The two students were treated at a local hospital for severe burns,” Officer Garry Flot, a New Orleans police spokesman, said. Tulane issued a news release saying it had suspended Pi Kappa Alpha and would investigate. The pledges were scalded late April 25 or early April 26, Frank D’Amico Jr., a lawyer for one of the victims, told a television station.

A federal judge has approved a settlement between the Texas Youth Commission and the Justice Department over inmate safety at the state’s juvenile prison in Edinburg. The judge, Ricardo Hinojosa of Federal District Court, signed the settlement Monday, and it was announced by the commission Wednesday. Judge Hinojosa had previously rejected a settlement on grounds that it lacked a specific timeline. Federal prosecutors began investigating the prison, the Evins Regional Juvenile Center, in 2006. An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about Lightstone Group, a New York real estate company facing challenges in paying its debt, misstated the name of a research company that tracks commercial mortgage-backed securities and gave an outdated description of its ownership. It is Realpoint L.L.C. — not Realpoint Research — and it is now an independent company, no longer a division of Capmark.
An article in some editions on Friday about the fatal stabbing of a Brooklyn teenager gave an erroneous surname from a relative for the victim. He was Renato Scantlebury, not Rowe.

An article on April 18 about the Senate’s vote to direct the Justice Department to investigate how a change was made in a 2005 transportation bill misstated the location where Senator Barbara Boxer spoke against having a bicameral investigative committee. It was on the Senate floor, not the House floor.

An article in some editions on April 22 about customer reaction to calorie counts posted in some coffee shops and fast-food restaurants in New York City misspelled the surname of a Starbucks customer who said posting the numbers would not be good for business. He is Bruno Mastropasqua, not Mastropasqui.
FOREIGN.
An Inside The Times capsule summary on Sunday of an article about the birthplace of Jell-O misidentified the state in some editions. It is Le Roy, N.Y. — not N.J.

The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the Flushing area of Queens, included a quotation from City Councilman John C. Liu, whose district includes Flushing, that referred incorrectly to Main Street there. There are Main Streets in the Bronx and Brooklyn, and on Roosevelt Island and Staten Island; the Main Street in Flushing is not the only one in New York City.

An article on Tuesday about an agreement between Microsoft and the Hyundai Kia Automotive Group to develop software for voice control over cellphones and entertainment systems in automobiles misstated the name of the software. It is Microsoft Auto — not Microsoft Automotive or Windows Automotive, which is a separate platform for use in vehicles.

An article on Saturday about television appearances on Sunday by Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated the channel for “Fox News Sunday.” It is Fox Broadcasting, the over-the-air network — not Fox News Channel, a cable channel. (Both are part of the Fox Entertainment Group.).

A theater review last Thursday about “Thurgood,” a one-man show about Thurgood Marshall at the Booth Theater, referred incorrectly, at one point, to the Supreme Court’s 1896 ruling in Plessy v. Ferguson in citing Marshall’s efforts to end segregation while chief counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. As noted elsewhere in the review, the ruling enshrined de jure segregation (segregation by law), not simply de facto segregation (segregation in fact).

The Critics’ Choice column on Monday about new CDs misidentified the composer of “King Korn,” a song on the new album “January” by the Marcin Wasilewski Trio. It is by Carla Bley — not Paul Bley, her former husband.

A picture caption on April 29 with the continuation of a music column about the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., omitted the name of the large sculpture shown in a photograph of fans and the name of its creator. The sculpture is by Mike Ross and is called “Big Rig Jig.”.

CONWAY--Alvin J., was president and chief executive officer of Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens and Director of Health and Hospitals for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn for 25 years, 1970-1995. Under his leadership, the Catholic Medical Center became the largest voluntary health care provider in New York, and one of the largest in the United States. CMC comprised four hospitals and three longterm care facilities, which included a total of 1,695 beds and the largest hospital based home care program in the country. During Mr. Conway's presidency, four hospitals were remodeled or replaced and 18 Family Health Centers were established in medically undeserved areas of Brooklyn and Queens. In addition, the School of Nursing, as well as schools for emergency medical service technicians, radiological technicians and laboratory technicians were organized. CMC also included a substantial substance abuse program. Mr. Conway also oversaw businesses as diverse as a ''captive'' insurance company, a Medicaid managed care program and the Kennedy Medical offices at JFK International Airport. Before his tenure at CMC, Mr. Conway served as executive director of Knickerbocker Hospital in New York City (1960-70) and as administrative assistant at Roosevelt Hospital in New York (1954-60). He was named President Emeritus of the Catholic Medical Center (now St. Vincent's Catholic Medical Center) upon his retirement. He received a BA in management at City College of New York and an MS in hospital administration at Columbia University. He served with the Army in Europe in the Second World War. Mr. Conway was a consultant and lecturer to professional groups and health care organizations in the United States, Europe and the Far East. He was past president of the New York State Catholic Healthcare Council. He participated in various state and national policy groups, including the House of Delegates of the American Hospital Association and the Regent's Advisory Council of the American College of Healthcare Executives. Mr. Conway's publications dealt with diverse issues of health care administration including the future of the multi-hospital system and an article on the career of the physician-pope, John XXI. He was a Life Fellow of the American College of Healthcare Executives. In 1995, he was awarded the B'Nai Birth Distinguished Achievement Award for his lifetime of accomplishment in health care and the Samaritan Foundation bestowed its annual award to him for outstanding achievement in administration. Mr. Conway was named Fellow of the Year of the New York American College of Hospital Administrators in 1985. Mr. Conway was the beloved husband of Gail of Tarrytown, NY and the devoted father of Jimmy (Barbara) of Goshen, NY; Jack (Jo Ann) of Albany, NY; Susan (Timothy) of Yorktown Heights, NY and Christopher of Denver, CO, and the loving grandfather of Jesse, Brian, Rebecca, Kyra, Cory, Kieran, Cassandra and C.J. Visiting Thursday, May 8, 2008, 7-9pm, Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY.

SOBEL--Beatrice. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Sr. Rabbi Hon. Richard Kestenbaum, President

GOODMAN--Joan, a freelance print journalist for 35 years and widow of ABC TV News writer-producer Lawrence Goodman, died on May 6 after bouts with cancer lasting many years. She was best known for her profiles of celebrities, published in newspapers and magazines in the U.S. and the UK, including the New York Times, the Los Angeles Times, the London Times, the Sunday Times of London magazine, the Observer, New York Magazine, Cosmopolitan, US, Playboy and Time Out. She wrote about some of the entertainment world's biggest stars, but equally enjoyed seeking out younger performers before they became household names. All who knew Joan considered her to be a fascinating individual. She was a priceless raconteur, but resisted the temptation to sensationalize what was told to her in confidence -a trait that endeared her to the subjects of her portraits. While claiming ignorance of figures, she occasionally admitted to her age and to her children. She is survived by two sons, Andrew and Michael Goodman, a daughter, Wendy Thum, and four grandchildren. Family visitation will be at the Barrett Funeral Home on West 51st Street on May 10, from 8:45 to 10:45, followed by a funeral mass at the Church of St Paul the Apostle at 11:15. Interment will be at Kensico Gardens in Valhalla immediately following. Charitable donations can be made to New York University ''for the Lawrence Goodman Fund in memory of Joan Goodman'' and sent to Alan Shapiro, Director of NYU Gift Planning, 25 West 4th Street, Fourth Floor, New York, NY 10012.
