ISELIN--John Jay. PBS remembers John Jay Iselin, a public television pioneer and an inspiration to a generation of public media leaders. As president of Thirteen/WNET, Jay nourished a wonderfully creative period in our history, helping us usher into America's living rooms iconic series such as ''The MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour'', ''Great Performances'' and ''Nature''. We honor his memory and keep alive the torch of innovation he lit more than 30 years ago. Paula A. Kerger President and CEO ISELIN--John Jay. The Board of Trustees and Management of Sesame Workshop mourn the loss of John Jay Iselin, and send our deepest sympathies to Lea and his entire family. We will all miss Jay's infectious enthusiasm, his impeccable eye for quality, and his deeply held belief in the inherent power of television to inspire and teach. ISELIN--John Jay. The Trustees, faculty, students and staff of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art note with deep sorrow the passing of the College's tenth president. His distinguished career in the academy, public television and journalism, and his tireless devotion to The Cooper Union and its students exemplified a life lived in service and generosity to his community. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his wife Lea, their five children, and their entire family. Ronald W. Drucker, Chairman George Campbell Jr., President ISELIN--John Jay. The Board and staff of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation extend our heartfelt sympathies to Jay's wife, Lea, and their children and spouses, and their grandchildren. Jay gave the Foundation 19 years of wise and insightful service, always available for consultation with his cheerful and constructive outlook. We will miss his sharp intellect, his ever cooperative demeanor, and his wonderful sense of humor. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman Clarence F. Michalis, Chairman Emeritus George E. Thibault M.D., President

GREHAN--Farrell, 81, nature and travel photographer died on May 6. Farrell who lived in Manhattan is survived by his former wife Yvonne of Piermont, NY, sons Patrick and Christopher, and grandsons Connor and Jackson. He was a passionate man who loved art, nature and photography. In lieu of a wake, his life will be celebrated in the Club Room at 5 East 22nd Street in Manhattan from 5-9pm on Friday. Funeral services will be held on Saturday at 10am at Rockland Cemetery in Sparkill, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to charity of one's choice would be appreciated.

One Saturday morning in March, Laurence D. Fink got some urgent news: Wall Street needed his help. Mr. Fink runs BlackRock, a money management company whose name probably rings few bells outside financial circles. But on that March weekend the Federal Reserve, moving to defuse a crisis threatening the American financial system, began turning to BlackRock to play a critical role in the government-brokered rescue of Bear Stearns, the faltering investment bank.

To the Editor: I think that Kayleen Schaefer understated an important point in ''Hard Times, But Your Lips Look Great,'' (Thursday Styles, May 1). ELLIS--Charles R. Peter Booth Wiley, Chairman of the Board of Directors of John Wiley & Sons, Inc.; William J. Pesce, President and CEO; the Board of Directors; and Wiley colleagues around the world are greatly saddened by the death of Charles R. Ellis, 72, who led our company from the difficult days of the late 1980s into the sustained period of growth and profitability that continues into the present. A publisher by temperament and trade, Ellis served as Wiley's President and CEO from 1990-98 and was instrumental in bringing about the company's revival and initiating its transition to a truly global corporation. On his watch, Wiley became profitable again; executed major strategic acquisitions including VCH Publishing Group, Alan R. Liss, and JosseyBass; was listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE: JWa); and launched its first online ventures. In the year of Charles's retirement, the Financial Times ranked Wiley as the world's 27th most respected company. Beyond his role in Wiley's resurgence, Charles has acted as an influential advocate for the worldwide publishing community. With a cosmopolitan perspective enhanced by European postings with Pergamon Press and Elsevier in his pre-Wiley days, Charles was President of the International Publishers Association. He was also Chair of the Association of American Publishers from 1992-94; in 1998, he received the AAP's highest honor, the Curtis Benjamin Award. He was an avid supporter of the Digital Object Identifier, a code embedded in digital content that helped lay the groundwork for publishing online; and worked tirelessly on behalf of intellectual property rights. Those fortunate to have known and worked with this charming, gracious, and diplomatic man will miss him terribly. On behalf of the entire Wiley community, we extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Sandi, and their family. In lieu of flowers, donations to World Education, Inc., 44 Farnsworth Street, Boston, MA 02210 (wei@worlded.org) are requested. ELLIS--Charles R., 72, of New York, NY, and Paris, France, died May 4, 2008, after a brief, brave battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife Sandi, son Kenneth Ellis; stepchildren Christopher, Shannon, Patrick, and Nicholas Moore; their spouses; and ten grandchildren. He will be deeply missed. A graduate of Princeton University, Charles began his career teaching at a preparatory school and working for Bertrand Russell, the British philosopher and activist. Charles soon found a balance between the intellectual life and concerns of making a living by turning to publishing. After successful stints in executive positions at Pergamon Press, D.C. Heath, and Elsevier Science Publishing Company, he joined John Wiley & Sons, Inc, in 1988, where he served as the President and CEO from 1990-98. A sophisticated and diplomatic man, Charles was an influential advocate for the worldwide publishing community through his work the International Publishers Association and the Association of American Publishers and on behalf of intellectual property rights; in 1998, he received the AAP's highest honor, the Curtis Benjamin Award. In lieu of flowers, donations to World Education, Inc., 44 Farnsworth Street, Boston, MA 02210 (wei@worlded.org) are requested.

An article on Tuesday about a street protest in the southwestern Chinese city of Chengdu against a planned petrochemical plant referred incorrectly to Xiamen, an eastern Chinese city where protesting residents stopped construction of a nearby chemical plant last year. It is a seaport in Fujian Province -- not the provincial capital, which is Fuzhou.

TOGNINO--Alexander, Associate General Counsel, Trademarks & Licensing and Managing Attorney, IBM Corporation, died suddenly on May 5, 2008 at age 58. Alex was born in The Bronx, the adored son of the late Gennaro and the late Catherine Tognino. Alex was Associate General Counsel for IBM with worldwide responsibility for all activity associated with trademarks, domain names and brand licensing, as well as Managing Attorney for the IBM's Intellectual Property Law Group, with worldwide budget and personnel responsibility. Alex joined IBM in 1985 and worked as a Patent and Trademark attorney at various IBM locations. During his 23 year career at IBM, Alex personally mentored many IP Law professionals and provided invaluable advice and service to IBM senior management. Alex's early education was at Saint Phillip Neri School and Cardinal Hayes High School. Alex holds a BA degree (cum laude) in Physics from the State University of New York at New Paltz, an MS Ed in Physics from the State University of New York at Cortland, and a Juris Doctor Degree from Pace University School of Law, White Plains, New York. Alex was admitted to the Bars of New York and Connecticut. He was the beloved partner, Patricia Cramer; the devoted brother of John Tognino and Norma Tognino; the loving uncle of John N. (Terry) Tognino, Jr.; Michael Tognino and Katherine (Mark) Albanese, and fond granduncle of John N. III and Michael Tognino and Christopher Albanese, all of whom survive him. The family will receive friends at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY on Thursday from 5:00pm to 9:00pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be on Friday, May 9, at 11:00am at Fordham University Church, on the Fordham University Campus, Bronx, NY. The reception will follow at Duane Library of Fordham University. Interment will be private. In memoriams to Tognino Endowment for Disability Services, 888 7th Ave, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10106 would be deeply appreciated.

AS rivers swell with spring runoff and lakes shimmer with a slightly warmer surface, canoeing enthusiasts are once again hitting the water. Now, thanks to a host of new and improved waterproof backpacks, their gear can also hit the water -- and still stay dry. Canoe-camping and canoe-hiking are rising in popularity among paddlers, according to Martin Bartels, the executive director of the American Canoe Association. This season's packs are designed to make both activities easier. Among the features are seamless construction, waterproof vinyl and nylon fabrics, roll-top and zipper-like closures to seal out moisture, and padded straps to help shoulder the load on portages and day hikes. ''Lighter and more efficient gear adds to the pleasure of an outing,'' Mr. Bartels said.

Will Google and Yahoo come together on a search advertising partnership? The two companies have been discussing an agreement under which Google would deliver some ads alongside Yahoo's search results. Since Google on average earns much more than Yahoo for every search, the deal, at least in theory, would bolster Yahoo's revenue. The two companies conducted a two-week experiment to make sure that was indeed true and both companies have called the test a success.

Two days after the April 27 assassination attempt on President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the photojournalist Stephen Dupont and the writer Paul Rafael, both Australian, were traveling with an opium eradication team in eastern Afghanistan's Nangarhar Province when a suicide bomber attacked their convoy. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed at least 15 and wounded 14. Both journalists were among the injured; Mr. Dupont suffered minor injuries to his head, and Mr. Rafael serious ones.

Tomorrow, May 10, is the 38th anniversary of one of the most storied goals in hockey history, Bobby Orr's flying leap in front of Glenn Hall as he scored the winner 40 seconds into overtime of Game 4 of the 1970 Stanley Cup final, giving the Boston Bruins a sweep of the St. Louis Blues. It was the Bruins' first Cup since 1941.

The tough drug laws signed into law by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1973 have long been the target of criminal-justice advocates who called the laws cruel. In 2005, the laws were slightly eased under a reform agreed to by the State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki; mandatory sentences under the laws were reduced and prisoners who had been sentenced to the longest terms under the laws could ask to be re-sentenced. Some advocates believe the change did not go far enough, and on Thursday, the 35th anniversary of the day the laws were signed, the State Assembly held a lengthy series of hearings on whether the laws should be further revised.
Ron Paul never could quite claw his way to the top of the Republican presidential pack, but now he's sitting on the top of several best seller lists with his new book, "The Revolution."

When I was 19, my father gave me an Oxford English Dictionary, the 1971 compact edition with the 1987 supplement. Citations for every English word since the eighth century were crammed into three bulky volumes of minuscule print. I hallucinated before the speckled onion-skin pages until I discovered that the dictionary came with a magnifying glass.

There is a dream most mothers have, a nightmare really. It goes like this: you are away somewhere, and you remember you have left your children at home, perhaps for a week, and haven't fed them. You can't get back to them. Or it could be a litter of puppies or kittens other stand-ins for children, but you have lost or neglected to feed them, or they are in a storm, or you have rolled over in bed and smothered them. It's a frantic nightmare and it recurs, for some of us, throughout our lives. My daughter and I laugh at the nightmare together, conceding that it must have something to do with our mothering skills, which we both accept as erratic.

For the third consecutive week, CBS's Thursday night line-up earned more viewers than any of its network competitors during every time slot of the night. Beginning with the second to last installment of "Survivor: Micronesia," CBS drew 12.7 million viewers to lead the 8 p.m. hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS then dominated the rest of the night with "CSI" at 9 p.m. (17.8 million) and "Without a Trace" at 10 p.m. (14.6 million).

One of the most notable features in the saga of Representative Vito J. Fossella is the clear reluctance on the part of his fellow politicians, Democrat or Republican, to weigh in on the matter publicly. But his local paper, The Staten Island Advance, showed no such reticence, calling this morning for Mr. Fossella to resign immediately. Mr. Fossella, a Staten Island Republican, was arrested on May 1 in Alexandria, Va., and charged with drunken driving. On Thursday, he issued a statement that he had had an extramarital affair with Laura Fay, a former Air Force lieutenant colonel, and that the two of them have a 3-year-old daughter together.

Other than being the most hyped recruits in the history of college lacrosse, Rhamel and Shamel Bratton really didn't have any pressure on them heading into their freshman season at the University of Virginia. The twins from Huntington, Long Island, were christened as legends before they even stepped on campus, appearing twice on the cover of Inside Lacrosse magazine. (The Times also checked in, though we will bow down to the guest blogger John Jiloty as the arbiter of all lacrosse judgments.) The Brattons were an alluring story not only because of their immense talent, but also because they were African-American stars in a sport that Virginia Coach Dom Starisa described as "lily white."

Parents consider it a sacred tenet of city life: If you move into a good elementary school's zone, your children can go to the school, Elissa Gootman writes. But Public Schools 234 and 89, in Battery Park City - part of Lower Manhattan, which has experienced a baby and construction boom -- are faced with a glut of children and nowhere to put them. Some three dozen children are already on the waiting lists for these schools, an unusual predicament that has surprised parents, setting off outrage on playgrounds, at meetings and on the Internet.

Vikram S. Pandit is doing some serious spring cleaning at Citigroup.
Score two more for Barack Obama this morning.

Private investment firms have been amassing what may seem like unusual stakes in New York real estate: they have bought hundreds of apartment buildings with thousands of rent-regulated units across the city that produce decidedly meager returns.
When times were sunny, banks promised scores of companies money for a rainy day. Now that day is here - and the banks, hard pressed themselves, are worried they will have to keep their promises.
Wachovia stripped its chief executive, G. Kennedy Thompson, of his chairman role on Thursday, separating the top management position from the top oversight post.

A recent comment by Blackstone Group chieftain Stephen Schwarzman comparing a failed buyout to dropping the atomic bomb on Japan has industry observers chattering that the private equity titan may have put his foot in his mouth.
The Americans are the favorite to win the gold medal for softball in Beijing, but will struggle to follow their performance in 2004.

Onex, Canada's largest investment firm, is looking for deals in the United States gambling industry, and some think it might consider the recently bankrupt Tropicana Entertainment. The Globe and Mail reports that Onex has turned to Alex Yemenidjian, the former president of Kirk Kerkorian's MGM Grand casino empire, for help in seeking out these kinds of investment opportunities.

Microsoft continued to distance itself from Yahoo on Thursday, telling the people it had lined up to nominate to the board as part of a prospective hostile takeover battle that their services were no longer needed, according to The Los Angeles Times.

The chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, the largest European telecommunications company, fed speculation Thursday that it was considering a takeover bid for the U.S. mobile operator Sprint Nextel, saying the German company had an obligation to consider all acquisitions that would improve its bottom line.
Investment bank Bear Stearns may have hit rough times but at least one of its hedge funds, the $1.2 billion Emerging Markets Macro Fund, is bouncing back from earlier losses this year.

Shareholders of publicly-traded hedge fund and buyout firms need to re-check their checklists, says Breakingviews. The downturn is highlighting the disadvantages of public scrutiny, with performance fees evaporating and new investment slowing, the publication said. But the supposed pluses - having a public currency to retain talent and grow - aren't holding up their end of the bargain, either, it argues.
A links roundup on the seemingly fizzling conclusion to the Patriots' spying scandal:
The fortunes of American International Group, one of the world's biggest insurance companies, rise and fall on precise calculations of risk. Last quarter, those calculations went seriously awry.
A dramatic proxy showdown at apparel company Charming Shoppes ended Thursday with an 11th-hour truce that will expand the company's board to 11 from 10.
Gomez, an Internet performance monitoring company, has filed to go public. But is the market ready for this small, unprofitable but fast-growing company?
Alcoa named its president, Klaus Kleinfeld, as its new chief executive on Thursday.
RealNetworks said Thursday that it plans to spin off its casual games business into a separate company and distribute its shares to RealNetworks stockholders.
The Carlyle Group will lead a 58.1 billion yen ($560 million) management buyout of an LCD glass venture jointly owned by Japan's Hoya and Nippon Sheet Glass, Hoya said on Friday.
The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of semiconductors, agreed on Thursday to pay a $10 million civil fine to settle regulators' accusations of improper backdating of stock options.
SlideShare, the PowerPoint social network backed by Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban and others, has closed on a $3 million A round led by Venrock, the company announced Thursday.
Julius Baer Holding Friday tempered profit expectations as the strong Swiss franc and unpredictable markets ate into managed assets.
Serious Business, a San Francisco-based Internet application start-up, has raised $4 million in Series A funding, according to a regulatory filing.

Lime Rock , a private equity firm that focuses on the global energy sector announced Thursday that it had closed its fifth Lime Rock Partners fund, Lime Rock Partners V, L.P., with a total $1.4 billion in investor capital commitments.
Société Générale, the French bank hit by a rogue trading scandal, said Didier Valet would become its new chief financial officer.
Shares in nuclear power generator British Energy fell 2.5 percent on Friday on fading hopes that a bidding war would push up the price for the stake being sold by the British government.
Sovereign Bancorp, the second-largest U.S. savings and loan, plans to raise just over $1 billion in an equity offering to help it navigate a difficult economic environment, Reuters reported.
Sprott, a mining and energy hedge fund, raised 200 million Canadian dollars ($197 million) in the biggest Canadian initial public offering in five months.
Shares in Julius Baer Holding rose Thursday amid rumors British bank Standard Chartered is preparing a bid, valuing the Swiss private bank at over 23 billion Swiss francs ($2.2 billion)

Shares in British engineering software firm Flomerics Group surged on Friday after rejecting a buyout offer from larger U.S. rival Mentor Graphics, saying it would explore interest from several other parties.

The chaos that unfolded around the opening of Heathrow's Terminal 5 over the last few months, prompted me to visit was has proved a far more successful transportation unveiling: the transfer of London's Eurostar terminus from Waterloo to St. Pancras Station.
Jenna Bush's wedding in Texas on Saturday is touted as a low-key affair, but it's a fair bet it won't be this low-key:
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):

Moscow's endless spate of springtime festivals and arts events must surely have something to do with the end of the dark winter (which was actually quite warm, but nonetheless dark). After all, residents of the Russian capital, which is 24/7 as it is, need more and more entertainment as the days grow longer and longer.

For his first major U.S. building, Dutch architect Ben van Berkel is wrapping a 20-story residential tower in New York City with black ribbons of metal, creating a look that mocks conventional high-rise design.
“Turn the River” is a finely observed portrait of a desperate working-class woman who refuses to play by ordinary rules.
The sensationalistic documentary “Bloodline” explores the supposition that there exists a lineage traceable to Jesus and Mary Magdalene.
More tired than the fantasy it promotes, “A Previous Engagement” aims at middle-aged women with the subtlety of a pitch for bladder-control medication.
“Refusenik” falls short as entertainment because of the plodding, overly studious approach of the director, Laura Bialis.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
With most of Oregon and California’s commercial salmon fishery shut down this year, fishermen like Steve Wilson are looking for alternatives.
Locals muse about a neighborhood man they know as Jesus. Video by Corey Kilgannon.
This year's Kentucky Derby returned the horse Flip Sal back into the news. The largely forgotten Flip Sal was the 1974 Kentucky Derby's answer to Barbaro.

"The Walt Disney Company signed the president of ABC, Stephen McPherson, to a new contract, signaling confidence in the maverick executive's ability to deliver new hits to succeed workhorses like 'Grey's Anatomy,'" Brooks Barnes reports.

Variety reports: "Comedy Central is reviving Chuck Barris' 'The Gong Show,' with comedian Dave Attell as host." The show will premiere July 17. The original "Gong Show" was hosted by Mr. Barris, left, and aired on NBC and in syndication in the late 1970s.
Location: Waco, Tex.
“Vice,” a muddled, disposable crime thriller, has modest merits.
“What Happens in Vegas,” one of those junky time-wasters that routinely pop up in movie theaters, won’t make you laugh much or at all.
Adam Hootnick’s “Unsettled” makes the political personal, drawing a scattershot yet intimate picture of a nation divided.
Viewed as the sum of its sad incidents, “The Tracey Fragments” seems like the kind of adolescent melodrama that has become a staple of young-adult literature.
“Surfwise” has a bohemian vibe and a cool sheen, but it’s an eager-to-please, pleasing commercial enterprise with a reassuring narrative arc.
“Speed Racer” sets out to honor and refresh a youthful enthusiasm from the past and winds up smothering the fun in self-conscious grandiosity.
The ingredients of the Indian director Santosh Sivan’s period piece “Before the Rains” may be awfully familiar, but the film lends them the force of tragedy.
“Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead” is just about as perfect as a film predicated on the joys of projectile vomiting and explosive diarrhea can be.
The hero of “OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies” might be described as a French equivalent of James Bond.
“Noise,” the second part of a projected “fanatic trilogy,” is shallow and loud.
In “The Memory Thief,” a strange and melancholy journey to the heart of madness, a rootless young man finds meaning in the horrors of a stolen past.
The real surprise of “Frontier(s)” is that this creepy, bloody contemporary gross-out also has some ideas, visual and otherwise, wedged among its sanguineous drips.
Shot piecemeal over the course of four years on locations in 18 countries, “The Fall” is a genuine labor of love — and a real bore.
“Dilemma” is an earnest if schematic attempt to address conditions in Johannesburg under apartheid.
Male midlife crisis presents as pathological self-loathing in “Meet Bill,” an imperative to which the only sane response is: No thanks.
Until it crosses a shadowy line dividing serious comedy from distasteful exploitation, “The Babysitters” has the makings of an incisive satire of greed and lust in suburbia.
Vicious curveballs are tricky, both on and off the field. And while knowing they’re coming doesn’t necessarily help, they can be dealt with.
The 2008 race for the White House is casting a long shadow over President Bush. So long, in fact, that it may extend all the way to the Middle East.
Utah’s attorney general said that polygamist homes in his state could take in some of the children seized in a raid.
An American marine accused in an alleged gang-rape of a 19-year-old Japanese woman last year was sentenced Friday to two years in prison.

The Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court refused to stay a lower court’s ruling that San Francisco’s Golden Gate Yacht Club is the challenger of record in the America’s Cup, according to the United States syndicate. Officials for Alinghi of Switzerland, the America’s Cup champion, were not available for comment following the late-afternoon ruling.

Zach Parise’s power-play goal with 8 minutes 57 seconds remaining snapped a tie and gave the United States a 6-4 victory over Germany in a qualifying-round game at the world championship in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The Americans scored three times in the opening 2:52 but still needed Parise’s second goal of the game to secure the victory.
The agreement to pay Suffolk County $74 million is part of a national settlement involving nearly 160 suits filed by water suppliers in 15 states.
Alcoa named its president, Klaus Kleinfeld, as its new chief executive on Thursday.
Michelle Wie had one birdie and shot a four-over-par 75 at the Michelob Ultra Open at Kingsmill in Williamsburg, Va. It was her first round on the L.P.G.A. Tour since February.

An article last Friday about President Bush’s proposal for $770 million in foreign food aid misidentified the room in the White House where he made the announcement. It was the Diplomatic Reception Room, not the East Room.

The On Education column on Wednesday, about the impact of the planned closing of Lafayette High School in Brooklyn’s Bath Beach neighborhood, misstated this year’s enrollment in the Lafayette building. It is 1,064, not 720.
Farmers in Argentina began cutting off grain exports on Thursday after the breakdown of talks to resolve a conflict over government agricultural policies.

An article on Tuesday about research into how animals learn misspelled the Latin name of a worm used frequently in laboratory experiments. It is Caenorhabditis elegans, not Caenorhadits. The article also misspelled the name of the university where one of the researchers, Reuven Dukas, works as a biologist. It is McMaster University, not McMasters.
NATIONAL.

An article in some editions on May 1 about a lawsuit against the Empire State Development Corporation over the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misstated, in some copies, the year in which a financing agreement that prompted the lawsuit was signed by the state agency and the project’s developer, Forest City Ratner. It was 2007, not 2006.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on April 14 about the funeral of Rabbi Jacob S. Rubenstein and his wife, Deborah, who were killed in a fire at their home in New Rochelle, N.Y., misidentified the community where the rabbi’s synagogue is located. Although the synagogue is named Young Israel of Scarsdale, it is actually in New Rochelle.

The Advertising column on Wednesday, about the effect of a racehorse’s death at this year’s Kentucky Derby on Yum Brands, one of the race’s sponsors, misidentified the location of the corporate headquarters of United Parcel Service, a sponsor of the winning horse, Big Brown. It is Atlanta — not Louisville, Ky., site of U.P.S.’s air hub.

An article on Thursday about new theater productions at the World Financial Center misstated the schedule for two works. “Giant Place Detail” is to be performed on Saturday night; tonight, is not the final performance. And “Corporate Carnival” opens on Wednesday for a four-day run, not for three days.

An article on Tuesday about changes in the way diseases are classified misspelled the university where Dr. Jacalyn Duffin works as a professor of the history of medicine. It is Queen’s University, not Queens.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on May 1 about allocations by a New York City councilman, Mathieu Eugene, to Youth for Education and Sports, a community organization he once ran, referred incorrectly to the group’s sign on its former headquarters in Brooklyn. The sign does not in fact mention Liberty Multiple Services, an insurance and tax preparation business run by Mr. Eugene’s brother, Maxi. (A separate sign on the building for Liberty Multiple includes the phone numbers of both the youth organization and Maxi Eugene.).
The Cipriani family may lose its liquor licenses because of multiple violations of state laws including filing false information about its ownership.
Imam Qatanani, a Palestinian hailed as a voice of moderation, is facing questions of whether he lied about his detention in Israel on his application for U.S. residency.

Unilever reported a better-than-expected 31 percent increase in first-quarter profit, partly because of asset sales, and raised its full-year sales growth target. The company, whose products include Skippy peanut butter and Dove soap, said its profit rose to 1.41 billion euros ($2.18 billion) from 1.07 billion euros a year earlier. Sales from continuing operations for the quarter rose slightly to 9.57 billion euros ($14.8 billion) from 9.53 billion euros.

Bridgestone, the tire maker, said its profit fell 18.4 percent in the first quarter as a result of sluggish demand in the United States and a strengthening yen. Net profit fell to 22.96 billion yen ($220 million) from 28.14 billion yen a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.6 percent to 797.84 billion yen ($7.6 billion).

Deutsche Telekom said first-quarter profit rose more than 33 percent on the sale of its media and broadcast unit and lower interest expenses. The company, which provides landline, mobile phone and Internet access, earned 750 million euros ($1.16 billion) in the period, compared with 563 million euros in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell 3 percent to 15 billion euros ($23.2 billion) from 15.5 billion euros.

InBev, brewer of Stella Artois and Beck’s, posted an unexpected 11 percent decline in first-quarter profit, blaming rising costs for ingredients and shipping, and weak sales in Brazil. The company also said that the latest results were being compared with strong earnings a year ago. InBev’s profit fell to 249 million euros ($385 million) from 280 million euros a year earlier. Revenue rose to 3.19 billion euros ($4.93 billion) from 3.05 billion euros.

The Best Buy Company, the electronics retailer, will open its first stores in Europe by investing £1.1 billion ($2.16 billion) in a joint venture with the Carphone Warehouse Group. Best Buy, based in Richfield, Minn., will open stores under its brand name across Europe beginning next year in Britain.

Illinois Tool Works, the conglomerate based in Glenview, Ill., agreed to buy a British restaurant equipment supplier, Enodis, for $2 billion, the companies said. Illinois Tool’s bid was 8.5 percent higher than an offer that Enodis agreed to last month from the Manitowoc Company of Manitowoc, Wis. Manitowoc said it was considering its position and would make an announcement later.
Officials in Baghdad early on Friday were confronted with conflicting reports about whether the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia had been captured.
Former Gov. James E. McGreevey and his estranged wife settled child custody matters on Thursday as they moved closer to dissolving their marriage, their lawyers said.
Vito Fossella, who was so upset about President Bill Clinton’s actions several years ago, now has his own sex scandal and his own rule-of-law problem.
Liberty Media’s first-quarter revenue rose in all three of its business units, which include QVC and Starz television channels and a stake in DirecTV, the company said.

El Paso Corporation posted a higher first-quarter operating profit on Thursday and said it expected full-year earnings to be sharply higher than previously forecast on stronger oil and natural gas prices.
The Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm, reported a quarterly loss on Thursday.
The sense among politicians and analysts is that Vito J. Fossella’s political prospects are dim at best.
The plan for a vast complex of office towers, apartment buildings and parks over the railyards on the West Side of Manhattan has fallen apart.
Senator Richard C. Shelby, who has links to the mortgage industry, is helping to decide the fate of a housing bill.
After years of enabling Robert Mugabe, it is time for South Africa and all of Zimbabwe’s neighbors to enable democracy.
The loss of manufacturing jobs, coupled with an achievement gap, is a recipe for perpetually worsening poverty.
There were talks between party leaders and Senator Barack Obama as he made a public return to the Capitol.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said Thursday that the contributions he had taken from Long Island businessman Morris Talansky were legitimate campaign funds, not bribes.
Companies enriched by taxpayers in the war boom should not be able to compound their profits by not paying their fair share of taxes.
The general manager of a Utah mine withheld information that could have prevented a disaster, the chairman of a Congressional investigation said.
We believe it is Senator Hillary Clinton’s right to stay in the fight and challenge Senator Barack Obama as long as she has the desire and the means to do so.
Senator John McCain has an interest in the filling of vacancies at the Federal Election Commission, to which President Bush announced three nominees.
The House approved legislation that seeks to broadly expand the availability of mortgages insured by the federal government to help families who are in danger of losing their homes.
The taking-off point of a suicide bomber in Mosul was his experience at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
In swooping, or canopy piloting, skydivers fly in at low altitudes, performing maneuvers inches over land or water.
Airlines are passing their financial pain to their passengers in the form of sharply higher airfares and new fees.
There was no third-quarter breakdown for the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night, just the desperate play of a team whose quest for a second straight N.B.A. title was on the line.
Nevada health officials said that the reuse of anesthesia syringes among multiple patients has led to one of the country’s largest outbreaks of hepatitis C.
The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of semiconductors, agreed to pay a $10 million civil fine to settle regulators’ accusations of improper backdating of stock options.
An appeals panel ordered the release on bail of Abu Qatada, a Muslim preacher from Jordan once described by a Spanish judge as Osama bin Laden’s “ambassador to Europe.”

Twenty million tourists a year are bringing more birdseed sales, then more pigeons, then more damage to the historic buildings in the square, including the mosaics on the facade of St. Mark’s Basilica.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad called Israel a “stinking corpse” that was doomed to fail.
A truck driver working for the United Nations World Food Program was killed while delivering food in central Somalia.
The government intensified its crackdown on critics and opponents.
Several highly selective colleges are offering admission to an unusually large number of students from their wait lists, which will probably lead others to do the same.
The prices of rice, wheat, soybeans and several other foods have come down recently, a development that could ease some of the panic in global food markets.
Cablevision Systems reported a wider deficit for its first quarter on Thursday on losses from derivative contracts.
North Korea has turned over 18,000 pages of documents related to its plutonium program, ahead of an agreement meant to begin the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.
A frenzied push for cash by alumni and students at Hudson Catholic Regional High School will keep the school open for at least one more year.

Brandon Webb became the first pitcher in three years to win his first eight starts, pitching his 13th career complete game Thursday to help the Arizona Diamondbacks beat the visiting Philadelphia Phillies, 8-3.
Two “West Wing” actors are backing up Arianna Huffington’s account of a Los Angeles dinner party, where she says she heard John McCain say that he had not voted for George W. Bush in 2000.
Sergio García caught the course before the wind did, finishing six-under-par and two strokes ahead of the field after the first round of the Players Championship.
Almost all of the Tejon Ranch will be kept permanently free of development under the terms of a deal between the ranch corporation and five major conservation organizations.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s diminished political momentum appears to have had a dampening effect on her fund-raising, aides said.
Hundreds of lawyers in New York have been illegally granted state pension benefits, according to Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo.
Vito J. Fossella declined to address questions about his political future after being arrested for drunken driving and acknowledging fathering a daughter in an extramarital affair.
Joba Chamberlain put on quite a show after striking out David Dellucci in the eighth inning A bit over-the-top, some thought, considering the score wasn’t that close.
Maj. Gen. Jay W. Hood’s assignment was cancelled after the Pakistani media excoriated him for his previous job as commander of Guantánamo Bay.
The prospect of an electronic Trojan horse, lurking in the circuitry of a computer and allowing attackers clandestine access or control, was raised again recently by the F.B.I. and the Pentagon.
Hezbollah’s leader said the government had threatened to shut down the group’s telephone network, and the TV station of a Sunni leader’s party went off the air.
Fishermen who are unable to fish for salmon up and down the West Coast are trying to diversify along with the rest of the regional economy.
Lawyers for Brian McNamee are preparing to the investigators to dig up information about Roger Clemens, including any possible connections to steroids and human growth hormone.
The company will require users under 18 to confirm they have read Facebook’s safety tips when they sign up; the site will also display a prominent “report abuse” icon.
Swimmers who endorse other brands are being tempted by the hotter-than-a-jalapeño Speedo LZR Racer swimsuit.
Critics say that the process the city uses to determine when to build new schools is flawed, preventing construction from keeping pace with residential development.
The Warner Music Group suspended dividends Thursday after reporting that higher costs and a shift to digital music resulted in a wider second-quarter loss.
Christine Quinn’s grandmother was one of the few survivors of the Titanic, which was built in Belfast.
Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group, petitioned the government to pull the birth control patch off the market, calling it far riskier than the pill.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,066 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:.
The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4 percent on Thursday, saying that the region’s economy remained resilient despite financial turmoil.
Wal-Mart and Costco reported April sales that rose more than analysts estimated as American consumers sought discounts on clothing and food.
The collapse of the rim of an underground salt dome has created a huge and ravenous sinkhole that quickly threatened to swallow an East Texas oil town.
Johan Franzen, Brian Rafalski and Tomas Holmstrom scored power-play goals for the Detroit Red Wings, in their 4-1 win against the Dallas Stars in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.

A 78-year-old legally blind man from northwest Iowa has bowled a perfect game. The Alta resident Dale Davis had 12 consecutive strikes for a 300 score Saturday night during league play. Davis has limited peripheral vision but cannot see straight ahead.

Shane Mosley’s fight with Zab Judah on May 31 in Las Vegas was canceled after Judah injured his arm in a fall. Judah (36-5, 25 knockouts), the former undisputed welterweight champion, severely cut his right forearm and needed 50 stitches to close the wounds, which will keep him out of training for four weeks. Mosley (44-5, 37 knockouts), lost a competitive unanimous decision to Miguel Cotto in his last fight on Nov. 10.
AS Roma advanced to its fourth consecutive Italian Cup final. With a 1-1 tie against Catania, Roma advanced on 2-1 aggregate in their home-and-home series.

Dathan Ritzenhein, who set a Central Park record a year ago in the Healthy Kidney 10k, withdrew Thursday from this year’s race on May 17. He said an injury to his left foot had kept him from racing for 13 weeks and had set back his training for the marathon in this summer’s Beijing Olympics.

Cleveland Browns linebacker Willie McGinest said the 2008 season would be his last. McGinest told SI.com that he wanted to finish his career on one last playoff run in his 15th N.F.L. season. McGinest, who played 12 seasons and won three Super Bowls with the New England Patriots, signed a three-year, $12 million contract with the Browns in 2006, reuniting him with his former defensive coordinator Romeo Crennel.
The Bronx Opera’s contemporary version of “The Impresario” features squabbling sopranos seeking to be the prima donna of a company called the Bronx Opera.
One of the biggest sticking points on the $300 billion bill has been how much money would be paid to wealthy farmers.
The Bush administration proposed on Thursday to crack down on the aggressive marketing of private Medicare insurance plans.
The number of newly laid-off workers seeking unemployment benefits dropped much more than expected last week, the Labor Department reported.
Casino Drive, the mystery horse from the Far East, has the breeding to interrupt Big Brown’s bid for the Triple Crown.
Recent DNA tests to identify which of two skeletons belongs to German writer Friedrich Schiller instead showed that the skeletons proved to contain bones from at least six people.
Wachovia stripped its chief executive, G. Kennedy Thompson, of his chairman role on Thursday, separating the top management position from the top oversight post.
A team of scientists has reconstructed the climate of northern Africa as the savannah changed to the Sahara.
Mr. Arnold was a gentleman crooner who took country music uptown and sold more than 85 million recordings over seven decades.
Wall Street closed with a moderate advance Thursday, with energy and other commodities companies leading the market as oil prices extended their record-breaking run.
An actor, director and writer, Mr. Reznikov helped run the avant-garde Living Theater for 23 years.
Ms. McKinsey, a well-known soap opera actress of the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s, played memorably strong women on “Another World” and “Guiding Light.”
The Walt Disney Company signed the president of ABC Entertainment, Stephen McPherson, to a new contract, signaling confidence in the maverick executive’s ability to deliver new hits.
When a woman does ascend through the glass ceiling into the White House, it will be, in part, because of the race of 2008, when Hillary Clinton got down with the boys.
Private firms are buying up rent-regulated buildings and harassing tenants to increase vacancies, advocates say.

I watch “Brothers & Sisters,” like many other women I know, with the pre-emptive regret of someone gustily digging into a second piece of cake.
With two gripping productions of “Macbeth” in New York right now, the good news is, there’s no need to choose.
The actor John Lithgow brings his family’s tradition of storytelling to the stage in a one-man show called “John Lithgow: Stories by Heart.”
A grand Art Deco mural is made whole for the first time since the Normandie sank.
After nine hours of questioning, Amy Winehouse was released from police custody in London after her arrest on suspicion of drug offenses.
The opera has for the first time named a woman, the Bulgarian-born Albena Danailova, to serve as concertmaster, Agence France-Presse reported.
President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia has announced plans for a $177 million restoration of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts, the largest museum of European art in Moscow, CBC News reported.
On Aug. 23, a week after she turns 50, Madonna will embark on a tour of Europe and North America, Agence France-Presse reported.
Whoopi Goldberg will host the 62nd annual Tony Awards ceremony, to be broadcast live by CBS from Radio City Music Hall on June 15.
ABC’s news special on Barbara Walters was no match for Fox’s “American Idol” on Wednesday in the ratings.
A court in India has quashed three obscenity cases against M. F. Husain, one of the country’s most famous contemporary painters, the BBC reported.
Less than a month after a New York State judge dismissed large parts of his lawsuit against CBS, Mr. Rather has amended his original lawsuit and resubmitted it to the court.
Jan. 26 has been set for the trial of Maurice Agis, who is charged with manslaughter by gross negligence.
Despite setbacks, three soccer players who left Cuba’s under-23 men’s soccer team almost two months ago do not seem discouraged as they try to survive in America, both on and off the field.
Charlie Haden and Paul Motian brought in Ethan Iverson, the pianist from the Bad Plus, into their set of narrative tension at the Village Vanguard this week.
In the worst three months of the company’s 89-year history, American International Group lost $7.81 billion, primarily from bad investments in complex financial instruments.
The death of the financier Robert L. Vesco, confirmed by documents and interviews, has closed the books on one of Washington’s longest and most prominent fugitive hunts.
Lately, it seems, biennial exhibitions don’t do much except sit there, looking good and offending no one. The 55th Carnegie International is no exception.
Organizers of the awards show plan to change the format to acknowledge live music that is not limited to the heirs of Phish and the Grateful Dead.
One of the pleasures of this excellent production is how clearly and sympathetically it renders the character of Alma.
The International Fine Art Fair at the Park Avenue Armory, now in its 15th year, is a good place to find highly decorative examples of familiar styles.
Edgar Millán Gómez was killed Thursday in the most brazen attack so far in the year-and-a-half-old struggle between the government and organized crime gangs.

AROUND TOWN.
Selective listings from theater critics of The New York Times.
Selective listings from art critics of The New York Times.
This tale of a beleaguered honeymoon exposes its characters’ foibles with gentleness and compassion.
Kristin Griffith gives a commanding performance in this inventive play about President Richard M. Nixon’s loyal-to-the-end secretary.
A major selling point of this “Camelot” is the chance to hear this winning 1960 score sumptuously performed by the New York Philharmonic under the musical theater maestro Paul Gemignani.
As Hillary Rodham Clinton rejected calls for her to drop out, Terry McAuliffe, her campaign manager, said the battle would probably end before August.
Applebee’s and Wendy’s have opted for a more recession-proof approach: glamour shots of food.
Banks have promised scores of companies money for a rainy day. Now that day is here — and the banks, hard pressed themselves, are worried they will have to keep their promises.
The 73-year-old Austrian man who imprisoned and raped his daughter for nearly a quarter century, admitted a lifetime of abuse and depraved domesticity.
The energetic young players of the ensemble juxtaposed works of harmonic ingenuity and continuously morphing timbres at Columbia University on Wednesday.
Ronald Larsen has found himself in the middle of a battle between President Evo Morales, who plans to break up large rural estates, and the wealthy light-skinned elite in eastern Bolivia.
The Metropolitan Museum offers a playful look at comic book costumes and their influence on radical haute couture.
American pressure for a quick end to a Europe-wide ban on U.S. poultry imports threatened to backfire after European officials contradicted claims that the dispute was almost resolved.

Iranian officials told reporters that six people involved in the attack had been arrested and their links with the United States and Britain had been confirmed.

10 P.M. (13) NA KAMALEI: THE MEN OF HULA Thanks to Hollywood movies and tourist tales, most of us think of the hula as a female tradition. Yet in ancient times men learned the dance along with martial arts in preparation for battle. That continued until the 1820s, when hula was suppressed by missionaries and went underground for 150 years. In this ''Independent Lens'' documentary Lisette Marie Flanary journeys to Hawaii to chronicle the story of the master teacher Robert Cazimero as his all-male hula school, the only one in Hawaii, prepares to compete in the world's largest hula festival, above. 8 P.M. Cindy McCain, the wife of Senator John McCain, said in an interview televised Thursday that she would never release her tax returns, even if her husband was elected president and she became the first lady. Mrs. McCain, who has a significant stake in a beer distributorship in Phoenix that her late father helped found, is wealthier than her husband and files her taxes separately from him. In an interview broadcast on NBC's ''Today,'' Mrs. McCain, who has cited privacy concerns for her children, said she had no intention of releasing her returns.

REGGIE WILSON AND ANDRÉYA OUAMBA In August the financial district got a taste of what a collaboration between Reggie Wilson and Andréya Ouamba, from left above, might entail, when ''Accounting for Customs'' received several free lunchtime showings on the steps of the United States Custom House. The brief dance was both visually lush and historically resonant, with lines of performers executing wonderfully inventive phrases up, down and across the imposing stone steps. At one point a dancer scrambled up one of the sheer walls buttressing the staircase, as if trying to reach the giant seated monument above. Failing to gain purchase, she slid back to the ground. ''There is only so much we can do to reinvent our circumstances,'' the beautiful, Sisyphean action seemed to suggest. ''History won't be denied.'' ''Accounting for Customs'' was like a notebook sketch for ''The Good Dance,'' which the Brooklyn Academy of Music will present at its 2009 Next Wave festival. This week, in a program titled ''Kwenda Vutuka (Come Go Return),'' these choreographers are showing a more substantial work in progress excerpt of the piece, along with repertory from their respective companies. Mr. Wilson's Fist & Heel Performance Group, from Brooklyn, will offer two solos, ''Untitled,'' for the captivating Rhetta Aleong, and ''Introduction,'' a much-beloved piece performed by Mr. Wilson. In the New York premiere of his Senegalese Compagnie 1er Temps, the Congolese-born Mr. Ouamba will dance ''Impro-Visé 2,'' a duet with Fatou Cisse.

YEEND--Frances. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, the great American soprano Frances Yeend. Between her 1948 City Opera debut as Violetta in Traviata and her 1959 Turandot performances, she was a company mainstay, singing leading roles in works by Bizet, Gounod, Leoncavallo, Menotti, Mozart, Offenbach, Puccini, Verdi, Wagner, and Wolf-Ferrari. After a distinguished worldwide career, she retired from the faculty of West Virginia University in 1978. We offer our deepest sympathies to her husband, James Benner, her family, her fans, and her many friends. Susan L. Baker, Chairman

'JAZZ GIANTS: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF HERMAN LEONARD' There have been many great jazz photographers but none more accomplished than Herman Leonard. In a celebrated career that began in the late 1940s, Mr. Leonard, now in his mid-80s, is responsible for some of the music's defining images. His geometrically balanced musician portraits in particular, with their suggestions of cool composure, have long captured what seemed like the essence of jazz, at least in its golden age. Try to conjure the drummer Art Blakey in the mind's eye, and you might well summon him as captured in a photograph by Mr. Herman from 1958: head tilted back, mouth agape, arms in mid-flail. Or consider Dexter Gordon, whose most famous portrait, above, perfectly distills his air of roguish charm and watchful ease. Or think of Lester Young, whom Mr. Leonard once implied by photographing only his personal effects: tenor saxophone case, porkpie hat and a lighted cigarette resting on the lip of an empty soda bottle. It's an ingenious still life and a shrewd act of portraiture in absentia.

TOGNINO--Alexander, Associate General Counsel, Trademarks & Licensing and Managing Attorney, IBM Corporation, died suddenly on May 5, 2008 at age 58. Alex was born in The Bronx, the adored son of the late Gennaro and the late Catherine Tognino. Alex was Associate General Counsel for IBM with worldwide responsibility for all activity associated with trademarks, domain names and brand licensing, as well as Managing Attorney for the IBM's Intellectual Property Law Group, with worldwide budget and personnel responsibility. Alex joined IBM in 1985 and worked as a Patent and Trademark attorney at various IBM locations. During his 23 year career at IBM, Alex personally mentored many IP Law professionals and provided invaluable advice and service to IBM senior management. Alex's early education was at Saint Phillip Neri School and Cardinal Hayes High School. Alex holds a BA degree (cum laude) in Physics from the State University of New York at New Paltz, an MS Ed in Physics from the State University of New York at Cortland, and a Juris Doctor Degree from Pace University School of Law, White Plains, New York. Alex was admitted to the Bars of New York and Connecticut. He was the beloved partner, Patricia Cramer; the devoted brother of John Tognino and Norma Tognino; the loving uncle of John N. (Terry) Tognino, Jr.; Michael Tognino and Katherine (Mark) Albanese, and fond granduncle of John N. III and Michael Tognino and Christopher Albanese, all of whom survive him. The family will receive friends at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY on Thursday from 5:00pm to 9:00pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be on Friday, May 9, at 11:00am at Fordham University Church, on the Fordham University Campus, Bronx, NY. The reception will follow at Duane Library of Fordham University. Interment will be private. In memoriams to Tognino Endowment for Disability Services, 888 7th Ave, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10106 would be deeply appreciated.

'JEWELRY ON SCREEN' Follow the jewels. The stones in the Wiener Werkstätte Jewelry exhibition upstairs at the Neue Galerie are agate, amethyst, bloodstone, coral, jasper, lapis lazuli, moonstone, opal or tourmaline. The stones in the ''Jewelry on Screen'' film series are diamonds, emeralds and pearls. But craft or carats, beautiful objects so desirable that they cry out to be touched (and copied or stolen) provide plenty of drama. Descend to Café Fledermaus to view the jewel-encrusted stars. The 1955 film ''To Catch a Thief'' (Friday and May 16) is even better than you may remember: Cary Grant and Grace Kelly, above, as Hitchcock-directed cat and mouse on the Côte d'Azur, caught by the Oscar-winning cinematography of Robert Burks. At the start Kelly is jewelry-free in Edith Head ensembles, and Grant's tanned neck is the one to admire, with a red-and-white foulard tucked neatly into his striped pullover. Kelly's neckline redeems itself, of course, in the scene in which she strokes her dazzling necklace and purrs ''di-a-monds'' as a three-syllable word, followed by ''the only thing in the world you can't resist.'' Fireworks ensue.

ERNST LUDWIG KIRCHNER: 'THE UNEXPECTED NEW: LATE PAINTINGS' The German Expressionist painter Ernst Ludwig Kirchner is best known for his riotous Berlin street scenes, all sharp elbows and clashing colors. His later paintings, created after a move from Germany to Davos, Switzerland, and a long recovery from a nervous breakdown, appear less strident. Some 20 of these works, made between 1921 and 1935, are on view in this exhibition at the Michael Werner gallery. From the relative isolation of the Swiss Alps, Kirchner seems to be channeling Matisse in the patterned tablecloth of ''Wine Glass'' (1927-29) and Picasso in the conjoined bodies of ''Singer at the Piano'' and ''Eaters'' (both 1930). Kirchner's flattened, curvilinear forms also betray a less avant-garde influence, that of the turn-of-the-20th-century Jugendstil decorative arts movement.

NETZER--Dick. We grieve with the rest of the NYU Wagner School community and the University community over the sad loss of our cherished friend and colleague, Dick Netzer. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service Robert Berne Sr. VP for Health, NYU

The Senate Ethics Committee dismissed a complaint against Senator David Vitter, Republican of Louisiana, who was linked to a prostitution ring, because it occurred before he was elected to the Senate. The committee also noted that no criminal charges were filed against him. Mr. Vitter apologized last July after he was identified as a client of an escort service run by Deborah Jeane Palfrey, who was known as the D.C. Madam. Ms. Palfrey was convicted in April of running a prostitution ring, and died in Florida on May 1.

ISELIN--John Jay. The Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine profoundly mourns the death of John Jay Iselin, a Trustee since 1999. His intelligence, humor and courage inspired and embodied the mission of this Cathedral. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Lea and to all of his family and friends. The Rt. Rev. Mark S. Sisk, Bishop of New York Henry L. King, Esq., President The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski, Dean ISELIN--John Jay. The Trustees, staff, and volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation (EBC), licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW New York, are deeply saddened by the loss of John Jay Iselin, a man whose passion and leadership were a transformative force for this institution and all of public television. It was during Jay's remarkable tenure as President that ''Channel 13'' became an icon of culture and lifelong learning throughout the New York metropolitan community. From 1973 through 1987, Jay built WNET into America's leading producer of programming for the Public Broadcasting Service and led the creation of many of the programs that have given public television its indelible reputation for quality, integrity and independence. ''Great Performances'', ''Live From Lincoln Center'', ''Nature'', ''The NewsHour'' and ''Bill Moyers Journal'' all sprang to life under Jay's guidance, each adding an illustrious new chapter to the history of American television. Throughout his life, Jay cultivated the kind of cultural and humanistic vision upon which public television and all our society's highest aspirations rest. We extend our most profound sympathies to Jay's wife, Lea, and to their entire family. Every day, as we work to create media that illuminates and inspires, we honor Jay's phenomenal legacy. We will be forever influenced by his vision. James S. Tisch Chairman Neal Shapiro President and CEO ISELIN--John Jay. The Trustees, faculty, students and staff of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art note with deep sorrow the passing of the College's tenth president. His distinguished career in the academy, public television and journalism, and his tireless devotion to The Cooper Union and its students exemplified a life lived in service and generosity to his community. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his wife Lea, their five children, and their entire family. Ronald W. Drucker, Chairman George Campbell Jr., President ISELIN--John Jay, 74, died on May 6, 2008 of respiratory failure in New York. Son of William Jay and Fanny (Humphreys) Iselin, he was born in Greenville, SC and graduated from Saint Mark's School and Harvard College, class of 1956. He received a law degree from Cambridge University (Corpus Christi) which he attended as a Marshall Fellow, and a Ph.D. in Government from Harvard University in 1964. During his long and distinguished career in New York, he was National Affairs editor of Newsweek, editor of the trade division of Harper & Row before joining WNET/Channel 13 as general manager in 1971. He served as President of the public television station from 1973 to 1987 where he oversaw its transformation into a major force in the broadcasting world. In 1988, he was appointed President of the Cooper Union in New York, where he remained for 12 years, completing a $50 million capital campaign and endowing several new professorships. In 2000, he became President of the Marconi Society which, based at Columbia University, promotes innovation in telecommunications. Iselin remained on its board until his death. He was a longtime trustee of the Josiah C. Macy Jr. Foundation, the National Geographic Society, The Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, Waterford Institute and The New York State Archives Partnership Trust, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Advisory Council of Storm King Art Center. Throughout his life he was passionately involved in New York civil affairs and remained devoted to Harvard where he had been an overseer and to Cambridge University and the Marshall Fellowships. In 2004, he was appointed honorary Commander of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II. He was a member of the Century Association and the Harvard Club of New York. He was also beloved in Columbia County, NY and in Vinalhaven, Maine where he summered with his family for over 40 years. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Lea, five children: William of Paris, Benjamin and his wife Cathy of Brooklyn, Josie and her husband Ken Pearce of San Francisco, Fannie Minot of South Hamilton, MA, Alison Russell and her husband Dan of Brooklyn and thirteen grandchildren. He is also survived by two brothers, Duane of Mt. Desert, ME, William of Charleston, SC and two sisters, Judy Cromwell of Greenville, SC and Lea Rohrbaugh of New York. A Memorial Service will be held at 11am on May 29 in the Great Hall of the Cooper Union. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to The Franklin Fund, Cooper Union, 30 Cooper Sq. 7th Floor, NYC 10003, or the Friends of the John Jay Homestead, P.O. Box 148, Katonah, NY 10536.

ASTRONOMY DAY On Sunday Mike Francis will bring ''Siderius Nuncius'' to life. To children that may sound like a mythological creature, a Frankenstein-like monster or some other fearsome invention by a mad scientist. But ''Siderius Nuncius'' was created by an eminently rational scientist: Galileo, whom Mr. Francis, above, has been portraying for 17 years. In doublet and breeches he will dramatize ''Siderius Nuncius'' (''Starry Messenger''), Galileo's 1610 treatise on the heavens, as part of Astronomy Day at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. And his demonstrations won't be dryly academic, any more than Galileo's were.

It took the government 43 years to call me for jury duty (25 if you subtract the years before I became eligible at 18). To my surprise, I was seated on a civil case last week, despite my suspicion that lawyers prefer not to pick journalists to serve on juries. So I spent many hours since cooped up in a small jury room at the State Supreme Court in Manhattan with five other jurors and two alternates. It is nothing like the jury room in the movie ''Twelve Angry Men,'' which also took place in New York City. It is far smaller, has only one window and the bathroom fits only one person at a time, not the larger room where the jurors mingled during the movie.

HERRERA--Philip M., 74, of New York City died May 7th, after a brief battle with liver cancer. A writer and editor, he most recently held the position of executive editor of Town and Country magazine. He spent eight years at Time magazine where he launched the Environment section, and a decade as executive editor at Connoisseur magazine. Born in Paris, France, he was educated at Brooks School and Harvard College; he received masters degrees from Cambridge University and Columbia University. He is survived by his wife Maggie Simmons, his brother Julio Herrera, his son John Herrera, his daughter Margot Herrera, five grandchildren, and two stepchildren Edward Simmons and Jane Bullock. A wonderful family member, friend, and colleague, he was beloved by many and will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make a donation to the Foundation of the University of the Valley of Guatemala, Educational Service Group, P.O. Box 30, Princeton, NJ 08542.

Bronfman's Sour Note Warner Music Group struck a sour note with investors on Thursday: The private equity backed company reported a wider loss for the second quarter -- $37 million compared with $27 million during the same period of 2007 -- and suspended its dividend in what it described as an effort to maintain ''financial flexibility.''

MOTHER'S DAY Flowers are easy; so is brunch. Can't you put a little effort into your Mother's Day celebration? She raised you, for crying out loud, and that was hard work. Here are a few ideas to get you started. Take her dancing: Quick, quick, slow. Quick, quick, slow. That's salsa at its most basic, and the Ballet Hispanico School of Dance is happy to offer some pointers. My Sunday column is about high school and younger students moving into philanthropy and social action. It's something that my wife and I noticed in particular in our work on a forthcoming book about women in the developing world. High school students, for example, have done great work on human trafficking, perhaps because it's kids their age who are being locked up in brothels in India and Cambodia. Among the high school-led groups on that issue are Loosen Change to Loosen Chains and Minga. Minga's founder was inspired by Free the Children, a network of children helping other exploited children through education and other means. Girls Learn International is another example of high school kids fighting trafficking and helping kids abroad by keeping them in school.

NEW WAVERLY, Texas -- This week, a group of Olympic gymnastics hopefuls headed for Bela and Martha Karolyi's women's national team training center held about 60 miles north of Houston. The last time I was at this 2,000-acre ranch was four years ago, just before the Athens Games. Since then, I'd forgotten about how far away this training center was from civilization. It's in the boondocks, or maybe just south of there: about 16 miles away from the Texas State Prison in Huntsville, death row capital of the United States, and smack in the middle of Sam Houston National Forest, where the Karolyis settled in the early 80s.

8 P.M. (TCM) NOW, VOYAGER (1942) Turner Classic Movies celebrates the 120th birthday of the Austrian composer Max Steiner, who wrote the scores to hundreds of American films, was nominated for 20 Academy Awards and won 3. The tribute begins with ''Now, Voyager'' (1942), starring Bette Davis, above with Paul Henreid, as a rich ugly duckling turned swan, and continues with ''Since You Went Away'' (1944), John Cromwell's World War II story, produced and written by David O. Selznick, at 10:15; ''Johnny Belinda'' (1948), with Jane Wyman as a country girl who is deaf and mute, at 1:15 a.m.; and ''Sergeant York'' (1941), starring Gary Cooper as a war hero, at 3. 7 P.M. (Sundance) PLAY IT AS IT LAYS (1972) Joan Didion and her husband, John Gregory Dunne, wrote this adaptation of Ms. Didion's 1970 novel about an egocentric filmmaker (Adam Roarke) and his neglected wife (Tuesday Weld), whose only salvation seems to be her friendship with a gay producer (Anthony Perkins).

ISELIN--John Jay. The officers and members of the Alumni Association of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art mourn the passing of John Jay Iselin, the tenth president of the college. Jay is warmly remembered for his unstinting support of the Alumni Association and his generous and enlightened vision for the entire Cooper Union community. We extend sincere condolences to his wife, Lea, and his family. Carmi Bee President of the Cooper Union Alumni Association

OLOFSON--Phillip Harrison. The trustees and staff of the Stella and Charles Guttman Foundation mourn the death in Fort Wayne, Indiana on May 8, 2008 of Phillip Harrison Olofson, age 88, the father of the Foundation's exemplary and much loved Executive Director. Mr. Olofson was a leading citizen of Fort Wayne, Indiana, whose successful and varied career in business and community activities included the position of General Manager of the Fort Wayne Memorial Coliseum and promoting, marketing and publicizing a variety of entertainment and other programs for the City of Fort Wayne. We extend our sympathy and love to Elizabeth and her entire family.

Cindy McCain said Thursday that she would never release her personal income tax filing even if her husband, Senator John McCain, was elected president. But Federal Aviation Administration records indicate that she appears to be using her personal wealth to help his campaign, through the continued use of her corporate jet. The New York Times reported last month that during a crucial five-month period Mr. McCain's campaign regularly used a corporate jet owned by the Phoenix-based beer distributor that Mrs. McCain heads, saving the campaign hundreds of thousands of dollars. His campaign pays rates well below market ones for the plane's use because of an unresolved exemption in a recent campaign finance law that Mr. McCain backed.

DAIMLER A.G., the maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles, will deal with slowing auto sales in the United States in part by shifting sales to Russia, China and the Middle East, says Dieter Zetsche, Daimler's chief executive. And the company, based in Stuttgart, Germany, expects to be the first to introduce a car with a lithium- ion battery, the technology that is seen as critical to creating all-electric vehicles, he says. Mr. Zetsche was previously based in Detroit as head of Chrysler, then owned by Daimler, before the Germans decided to sell majority control to private equity investors. Most recently, Daimler reported a 32 percent decline in earnings in the first quarter of this year largely because the value of its remaining 19.9 percent stake in Chrysler fell. They fell below .500 again at 18-19, and their pitching problems are compounding in the rotation and in the bullpen.

MANET--Edie. Born Edith Gross in 1932 in NYC, (a.k.a. Schwimmer) and daughter of Henrietta and Martin Gross, she died April 25, 2008, in Paris, France, a city she loved, and where she and her devoted husband, George, were married 54 years ago. They met as students in UCLA's Theater Arts Department, and made their home in California. They also lived in London for 10 years in the 1980s90s. Everyone who knew her loved her for her innate goodness, her sharp wit and wry sense of humor, her perceptive intelligence and sound judgment, and her insights into so many areas of life. Edie was an original spirit. New York was in her genes, but California was in her heart, and she loved being here among her many friends. We will miss her constant concern for our welfare and wellbeing. At her request there will be no religious or memorial service.

EMMONS--Sophie Mavro (Mavrokefalo), died on May 8, 2008 at the age of 98. As an interior decorator with a long and highly respected career, she had an eye that developed a creative and expressive aesthetic for the human habitat. Her heart was filled with deep care for children and animals as beings dependent upon the good will of others. She was an early supporter of The Fund for Animals, and over many years she volunteered countless hours at UNICEF. For information about a memorial service call 917-286-2343.

PARROTT--Barbara Brown, 91, of Washington, DC and Fishers Island, NY passed away at her home in Georgetown on May 4, 2008. She was born in New Rochelle, NY on July 27, 1916 and had lived in Washington since 1949. A graduate of Miss Porter's School, she was married for 67 years to the late Thomas A. Parrott. She is survived by and will lovingly be missed by her daughters, Cynthia P. MacNair and Susan P. Crary, a son-in-law Horace I Crary, Jr., and three grandchildren, Gardner, Nicholas and Ian, all of NYC. Her son Tommy predeceased her. Services will be held at Arlington National Cemetery on June 17th at 10:00am. Contributions may be made in her memory to St. Albans School-Development Office, Mount St. Alban, Washington DC, 20016.
